https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/chemotherapy-doctor-blows-the-whistle/	dr. hardin b. jones recently revealed that chemotherapy doesn't work 97% of the time
column2: and doctors only recommend it to get kickbacks.	false	['anonhq'
column3: 'cancer'
column16: the average cancer cure rate is close to 60%.

column1: Some time ago I happened to read a discussion on Tony Isaacs’s Curezone
column2: on the best treatment for breast cancer. The thread was started by a woman who had just been diagnosed with breast cancer.

column1: Tony Isaacs’ partner Luella May suggested the forum member paint her breasts with iodine to combat the cancer and advised strongly against surgery and all other forms of conventional cancer treatments:
What does this mean? I can only mean that 98% were not cured – which means they died; look at this website
column2: where it says: Chemo has a 97% fatality rate!

column1: Some time later I read the same kind of unsettling statement concerning chemotherapy
column2: this time posted on a discussion board of Breastcancer.org:

column1: Where do these numbers come from??
The “2% chemo efficacy” comes from an Australian study into the contribution of chemotherapy to 5-year cancer survival
column2: and the researchers claimed to have found that the average benefit of chemotherapy was about 2%. So: the study is about the contribution of chemotherapy to survival and not about survival of patients having chemotherapy.

column1: For obvious reasons
column2: this study has become immensely popular with alternative therapists and is quoted by them ad nauseam.

column1: A rather strange phenomenon took place after the publication of this study: over time
column2: the 2-3% contribution to survival had somehow become 2-3% plain survival – period. Some of these altmeds now actually claim the outcome of the study was that of all cancer patients receiving chemo
column3: only 2-3% survive for more than 5 years.

column1: In other words: chemotherapy kills an average 97% of cancer patients within 5 years.
Now
column2: as these numbers sound totally weird – to say the least – we decided to find out if there was any truth in them.

column1: What the study was about
The researchers stated as the aim of their study:
a literature search for randomised clinical trials reporting a 5-year survival benefit attributable solely to cytotoxic chemotherapy in adult malignancies.
So they wanted to know what the contribution was of chemotherapy to 5-year survival. There are many therapies to treat cancer: surgery
column2: radiotherapy
column3: hormonal therapy
column4: immune therapy – and chemotherapy. The researchers wanted to know to what extent chemotherapy contributed to five-year-survival of cancer patients.

column1: Of all 154
column2: 971 patients whose files were examined
column3: in 3306 of these
column4: 5-year survival could be attributed solely to chemotherapy.

column1: In 98% of the patients
column2: 5-year survival was due to a combination of factors
column3: of which chemotherapy sometimes also was a factor and sometimes was not.

column1: The researchers then extrapolated the outcomes to all cancers. The average 5-year cancer survival in Australia at the time of the study was 60%. On the basis of the extrapolation of the outcome of their study
column2: the researchers estimated that the average contribution of chemotherapy to 5-year survival would be 2.3% in Australia and 2.1% in the USA.

column1: Nowhere in the study does it say that only 3306 patients survived their chemotherapy and that consequently 151
column2: 665 patients died because of chemotherapy.

column1: Leave out a few words and you get a completely different message.
The study design
The study was carried out in 2004
column2: using data from 1998. A number of things can be said about the design of the study.

column1: The researchers looked at a lot of cancers
column2: but they didn’t look at all of them.

column1: They did not differentiate between cancers for which chemotherapy is the primary treatment and cancers for which chemotherapy is only given as an adjuvant. This is the case in most solid cancers
column2: for which surgery is the primary – and by far the most effective – treatment.

column1: They did not include cancers for which chemotherapy is very effective
column2: such as leukemia.

column1: They did not include children’s cancers
column2: some of which are highly responsive to treatment
column3: e.g. Wilms’ tumour
column4: with about 90% of patients surviving at least five years.

column1: They did not differentiate between early stage cancers (tumour <1cm
column2: no mets in lymph nodes)
column3: for which chemotherapy often is not even indicated
column5: incurable cancers which had already metastasized at the time of diagnosis

column1: They did not look at the effect of chemotherapy on life extension (median survival)
column2: which in my opinion they should have
column3: since they included already incurable cancers in their study.

column1: Correction for these factors would result in an average contribution of chemotherapy to 5-year survival of about 8%
column2: based on the data from 1998.

column1: Statistics: average and specific
It is important to keep in mind that a statistical average is always about middling
column2: about the ‘mean.’ Statistics are never about the many deviations from the mean
column3: such as your or anyone else’s specific situation.

column1: A few examples:
1. Suppose the effect of chemotherapy on 5-year survival in leukemia is 60% and the effect of chemotherapy on 5-year survival of very early stage breastcancer is 0% (because: not indicated
column2: therefore not administered). The average effect of chemotherapy on both cancers combined is 30% (60+0 : 2 = 30). But what does this overall average tell the individual patient regarding their prognosis? Well… nothing actually.

column1: 2. In a number of situations
column2: depending on stage
column3: grade and type of cancer
column4: women with breast cancer are advised to take adjuvant chemotherapy
column5: in order to destroy any (clinically invisible) micrometastases in their blood.

column1: This kind of chemo improves the 10-year survival prognosis with an average 5 – 7%. The percentage is based on all women receiving adjavant chemo. If you don’t have micrometastases
column2: the chemo will do nothing for your prognosis. However
column3: for the women who do have them
column4: the chemo may enhance their personal prognosis much more

column1: 3. Cancer with unknown primary tumour (CUP) has a very bad prognosis: average 5-year overall survival rate is about 10%. Yet there are cases known of patients who have been surviving for 14 years or more without any evidence of disease.

The big differences in the overall effects of chemotherapy on 5-year survival become obvious if we look at the tables in which the specific numbers are given for each particular cancer that was included in the study. In the 4th and 3rd column on the right you can see to what extent chemotherapy contributed to cancer survival. When chemotherapy was no factor in survival
column2: the column shows a dash.

column1: So… now what?
The data from the study are from 1998. We are now in 2009 and progress has been made in those years. There is better medication to diminish side effects of chemotherapy. There is new
column2: sophisticated technology to assess which breast cancers are prone to metastasize and which are not
column3: resulting in less women having to undergo chemotherapy. Scientists are working hard on similar tests for other cancers.

column1: There are over 80 different kinds of chemotherapy. Some are sheer hell
column2: but many are quite doable
column3: including the one I had. Nevertheless: chemotherapy still is the ultimate cancer scare factor and the sooner we can do without it
column4: the better. But it is not true that only 2-3% survive chemotherapy. It is not true that the average benefit of chemotherapy to 5-year survival is as low as 2%. And it is also not true that all chemotherapy is by definition completely and totally unbearable.

column1: If we really want to get anywhere at all
column2: then honesty about the facts
column3: not manipulation
column5: should be the basis for discussion and decision making."	Is It True That Only 2 Or 3 % Of Cancer Patients Survive Chemotherapy?	2009-09-02 00:00:00	[]	['cancers'

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/ruin-nation/	the remains of an ancient city were discovered in the australian desert.	false	['Not Necessarily The News'
column2: 'nucleation']		David Mikkelson	['http://worldnewsdailyreport.com/ruins-of-ancient-city-discovered-in-australian-desert/']	http://worldnewsdailyreport.com/ruins-of-ancient-city-discovered-in-australian-desert/	http://worldnewsdailyreport.com/	"Alice Springs | A team of archaeologists working for the Australian National University
column3: who were proceeding to an excavation near the sandstone rock formation of Uluru
column4: has unearthed the ruins of a large pre-colonial city dating back to more than 1500 years ago.

column1: The important number of tombs and artifacts already discovered on the site suggests that it could have been the capital of an ancient empire
column2: completely unknown to historians until now.

column1: The site which was first noticed on satellite pictures taken in October 2013
column2: using a newly developed ground-penetrating radar.

column1: The images revealed many 90° angles and various common geographic figures over a 16 km2 area
column2: leading the team of scientists to direct some archaeological excavations on the spot
column3: starting in May 2014.

column1: Over the last few months
column2: many structures have been unearthed including what looks like a royal palace
column3: a few temples

column1: Professor Walter Reese
column2: in charge of the site
column3: claims that the extent of the site and the superposition of various layers of constructions
column4: suggests that it was occupied for 400 to 500 years

column1: He believes that the city could have held between 20000 and 30000 inhabitants
column2: making it the most important center of civilization in the Southern Pacific at the time.

column1: “This was certainly the capital of a vast empire
column2: that practised some sort of international trade” says Mr Reese. “The fact that we have discovered some bodies of various origins suggests that this state could have been a very influential throughout the Pacific islands and Southeast Asia. We have found many objects on the site that were obviously imported from other regions
column3: like rice

column1: The various artifacts gathered from the site suggest that the city flourished thanks to some form of control over various gold mining operations in Southern Australia.
The precious metal was purified and transformed by the hundreds of goldsmiths of the city before being traded for various other goods through an extensive network reaching as far as New Zealand
column2: Indonesia
column3: Malaysia

column1: Professor Reese believes that the city could have been abandoned after some climatic changes in the 9th Century brought a dramatic decrease in the level of rainfall
column2: making the city unsustainable."	Ruins of Ancient City Discovered in Australian Desert	2014-09-07 00:20:42+00:00	['Barbara Jennnings']	['making'

column1: Caldera-Forming Eruptions
The Yellowstone region has produced three exceedingly large volcanic eruptions in the past 2.1 million years. In each of these cataclysmic events
column2: enormous volumes of magma erupted at the surface and into the atmosphere as mixtures of red-hot pumice
column3: volcanic ash (small
column4: jagged fragments of volcanic glass and rock)
column5: and gas that spread as pyroclastic (“fire-broken”) flows in all directions. Rapid withdrawal of such large volumes of magma from the subsurface then caused the ground to collapse
column6: swallowing overlying mountains and creating broad cauldron-shaped volcanic depressions called “calderas.”

column1: The first of these caldera-forming eruptions 2.1 million years ago created a widespread volcanic deposit known as the Huckleberry Ridge Tuff
column2: an outcrop of which can be viewed at Golden Gate
column3: south of Mammoth Hot Springs. This titanic event
column4: one of the five largest individual volcanic eruptions known anywhere on the Earth
column5: formed a caldera more than 60 miles (100 km) across.

column1: The region’s most recent caldera-forming eruption 640
column2: 000 years ago created the 35-mile-wide
column3: 50-mile-long (55 by 80 km) Yellowstone Caldera. Pyroclastic flows from this eruption left thick volcanic deposits known as the Lava Creek Tuff
column4: which can be seen in the south-facing cliffs east of Madison
column5: where they form the north wall of the caldera. Huge volumes of volcanic ash were blasted high into the atmosphere
column6: and deposits of this ash can still be found in places as distant from Yellowstone as Iowa

column1: Each of Yellowstone’s explosive caldera-forming eruptions occurred when large volumes of “rhyolitic” magma accumulated at shallow levels in the Earth’s crust
column2: as little as 3 miles (5 km) below the surface. This highly viscous (thick and sticky) magma
column3: charged with dissolved gas
column5: stressing the crust and generating earthquakes. As the magma neared the surface and pressure decreased
column6: the expanding gas caused violent explosions. Eruptions of rhyolite have been responsible for forming many of the world’s calderas
column7: such as those at Katmai National Park
column9: which formed in an eruption in 1912

column1: If another large caldera-forming eruption were to occur at Yellowstone
column2: its effects would be worldwide. Thick ash deposits would bury vast areas of the United States
column3: and injection of huge volumes of volcanic gases into the atmosphere could drastically affect global climate. Fortunately
column4: the Yellowstone volcanic system shows no signs that it is headed toward such an eruption. The probability of a large caldera-forming eruption within the next few thousand years is exceedingly low.

column1: Lava Flows

column5: visitors to the park drive and hike across the lavas that fill the caldera
column6: most of which were erupted since 160

column10: and some cover as much as 130 square miles (340 km2)
column13: these flows oozed slowly over the surface
column14: moving at most a few hundred feet per day for several months to several years

column1: VOLCANIC HISTORY AND RECENT SEISMIC ACTIVITY IN THE YELLOWSTONE REGION

(Click the map for a larger version.) Yellowstone is home to one of the world’s largest active volcanic systems. Cataclysmic eruptions in the past few million years created huge volcanic depressions called “calderas.” The youngest

column1: Earthquakes
From 1
column3: 000 earthquakes typically occur each year within Yellowstone National Park and its immediate surroundings. Although most are too small to be felt
column4: these quakes reflect the active nature of the Yellowstone region
column5: one of the most seismically active areas in the United States. Each year
column6: several quakes of magnitude 3 to 4 are felt by people in the park.

column3: major faults along the Teton

Movements along many of these faults are capable of producing significant earthquakes. The most notable earthquake in Yellowstone’s recent history occurred in 1959. Centered near Hebgen Lake
column7: it had a magnitude of 7.5. This quake caused $11 million in damage (equivalent to $70 million in 2005 dollars) and killed 28 people

column1: Even distant earthquakes can affect Yellowstone. In November 2002
column2: the magnitude 7.9 Denali Fault earthquake struck central Alaska
column5: 100 km) northwest of Yellowstone. Because this quake’s energy was focused toward the active Yellowstone volcanic and hydrothermal system
column6: it triggered hundreds of small earthquakes there. The region’s hydrothermal system is highly sensitive to quakes and undergoes significant changes in their wake. Earthquakes may have the potential to cause Yellowstone’s hot-water system to destabilize and produce explosive hydrothermal eruptions.

column1: Hydrothermal Explosions
The large magma reservoir beneath Yellowstone may have temperatures higher than 1
column3: and the surrounding rocks are heated by it. Because of this
column4: the average heat flow from the Earth’s interior at Yellowstone is about 30 times greater than that typical for areas elsewhere in the northern Rocky Mountains. As snowmelt and rainfall seep deep into the ground
column5: they can absorb enough of this heat to raise the temperature of the ground water close to the boiling point. Geyser basins and other thermal areas in Yellowstone National Park are places where hot ground water has risen close to the surface. Research drilling at Yellowstone in the 1960s confirmed that the ground water beneath many of the park’s thermal areas is very hot. At Norris Geyser Basin
column6: water temperatures as high as 460°F (238°C) were recorded at depths of only 1

column1: Because the boiling point of water increases with increasing pressure and pressure increases with depth
column2: deep water can be hotter than boiling water near the surface. If the pressure that confines this deep water is reduced quickly
column3: pockets of water may suddenly boil
column4: causing an explosion as the water is converted to steam. Such activity drives the eruptions of geysers
column6: which are repetitive releases of plumes of steam and water. Rarely
column7: steam explosions are more violent and can hurl water and rock thousands of feet. In Yellowstone’s geologic past
column11: creating new landscapes of hills and craters.

column1: A recent and notable hydrothermal explosion occurred in 1989 at Porkchop Geyser in Norris Geyser Basin. The remains of this explosion are still clearly visible today as an apron of rock debris 15 feet (5 m) across surrounding Porkchop’s central spring. In the 1880s and early 1890s
column2: a series of powerful hydrothermal explosions and geyser eruptions occurred at Excelsior Geyser in the Midway Geyser Basin. Some of the explosions hurled large rocks as far as 50 feet (15 m).

column1: Much larger hydrothermal explosions have occurred at Yellowstone in the recent geologic past. More than a dozen large hydrothermal-explosion craters formed between about 14
column2: 000 and 3
column3: 000 years ago
column4: triggered by sudden changes in pressure of the hydrothermal system. Most of these craters are within the Yellowstone Caldera or along a north-south-trending zone between Norris and Mammoth Hot Springs.

column1: The largest hydrothermal-explosion crater documented in the world is along the north edge of Yellowstone Lake in an embayment known as Mary Bay. This 1.5-mile (2.6 km)-diameter crater formed about 13
column2: 800 years ago and may have had several separate explosions in a short time interval. What specifically triggered these very large events is not firmly established
column3: but earthquakes or a pressure release caused by melting glaciers or rapid changes in lake level may have been a significant factor.

column1: These very large and violent hydrothermal explosions are independent of associated volcanism. None of the large hydrothermal events of the past 16
column2: 000 years has been followed by an eruption of magma. The deeper magma system appears to be unaffected even by spectacular steam explosions and crater excavations within the overlying hydrothermal system.

column7: their remains can be noticed by observant visitors and attest to the nearly continuous geologic activity at Yellowstone.

column1: HYDROTHERMAL (STEAM) EXPLOSIONS AT YELLOWSTONE

Excelsior Geyser erupted in a series of violent hydrothermal explosions in the 1880s and early 1890s; one of these eruptions is shown in this colorized postcard made from a photograph. These were the largest such events to occur in the Yellowstone region in historical times. (Original photograph by F. Jay Haynes
column2: 1888; date on postcard is incorrect.)

column2: but sometimes changes in “plumbing” result in large volumes of water suddenly flashing into steam
column3: causing violent hydrothermal explosions. A large hydrothermal explosion can hurl water and rock thousands of feet and create new landscapes of hills and craters. In Yellowstone’s geologic past
column4: hydrothermal explosions have occurred countless times. In 1881
column7: witnessed a spectacular hydrothermal explosion at Excelsior Geyser in the Midway Geyser Basin. He described the aftermath as follows: “The pool was considerably enlarged

column9: enough of which had been hurled or forced back to form a ridge from knee to breast high at a distance of from 20 to 50 feet [ 6 to 15 m] from the ragged edge of the yawning chasm.” After a series of such explosions that ended in the early 1890s
column11: once the world’s largest active geyser

column13: it has remained so ever since. A more recent hydrothermal explosion occurred in 1989 at Porkchop Geyser in Norris Geyser Basin. The remains of this explosion are still clearly visible today as a 15-foot (5 m)-diameter apron of rock debris surrounding Porkchop’s central spring. Much larger hydrothermal explosions have occurred at Yellowstone in the recent geologic past. The greatest concentration of hydrothermal-explosion craters lies around the north end of Yellowstone Lake. These craters owe their origins to spectacular explosions thousands of years ago.

column1: PREHISTORIC CALDERA-FORMING ERUPTIONS OF YELLOWSTONE

Eruptions of the Yellowstone volcanic system have included the two largest volcanic eruptions in North America in the past few million years; the third largest was at Long Valley in California and produced the Bishop ash bed. The biggest of the Yellowstone eruptions occurred 2.1 million years ago
column2: depositing the Huckleberry Ridge ash bed. These eruptions left behind huge volcanic depressions called “calderas” and spread volcanic ash over large parts of North America (see map). If another large caldera-forming eruption were to occur at Yellowstone
column3: its effects would be worldwide. Thick ash deposits would bury vast areas of the United States
column4: and injection of huge volumes of volcanic gases into the atmosphere could drastically affect global climate. Fortunately
column5: the Yellowstone volcanic system shows no signs that it is headed toward such an eruption in the near future. In fact
column6: the probability of any such event occurring at Yellowstone within the next few thousand years is exceedingly low.

How Big Were the Yellowstone Eruptions?

Explosive eruptions are best compared by recalculating the volume of erupted volcanic ash and pumice (see photos) in terms of the original volume of molten rock (magma) released (shown in this diagram by orange spheres). On this basis
column2: the 585 cubic miles (mi3) of magma that was erupted from Yellowstone 2.1 million years ago (Ma) was nearly 6
column3: 000 times greater than the volume released in the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens
column5: which killed 57 people and caused damage exceeding $1 billion. Even the 1815 Tambora
column7: eruption—the largest on Earth in the past two centuries—was more than five times smaller than the smallest of Yellowstone’s three great prehistoric eruptions at 1.3 Ma.

column1: HAZARDOUS EVENTS AT YELLOWSTONE
Scientists evaluate natural-hazard levels by combining their knowledge of the frequency and the severity of hazardous events. In the Yellowstone region
column2: damaging hydrothermal explosions and earthquakes can occur several times a century. Lava flows and small volcanic eruptions occur only rarely—none in the past 70
column3: 000 years. Massive caldera-forming eruptions
column4: though the most potentially devastating of Yellowstone’s hazards
column5: are extremely rare—only three have occurred in the past several million years. U.S. Geological Survey
column7: and National Park Service scientists with the Yellowstone Volcano Observatory (YVO) see no evidence that another such cataclysmic eruption will occur at Yellowstone in the foreseeable future. Recurrence intervals of these events are neither regular nor predictable.

column1: How Dangerous Is Yellowstone?
None of the events described above—cataclysmic caldera-forming eruptions
column2: lava flows
column3: large earthquakes
column4: or major hydrothermal explosions—are common in Yellowstone. Although visitors to Yellowstone National Park may never experience them
column5: some hazardous events are certain to occur in the future. Fortunately
column6: systematic monitoring of Yellowstone’s active volcanic and hydrothermal systems
column7: including monitoring of earthquakes and ground deformation
column8: is now carried out routinely by YVO scientists. This monitoring will allow YVO to alert the public well in advance of any future volcanic eruptions. Currently the ability to reliably predict large quakes or hydrothermal explosions
column9: events more likely than a volcanic eruption
column11: changes in the patterns of ongoing seismicity or other indicators of possible geologic unrest are quickly reported to officials responsible for public safety in the National Park Service and other agencies.

column1: Through continuous monitoring and research
column2: YVO is greatly improving understanding of Yellowstone’s volcanic
column3: earthquake
column4: and hydrothermal hazards. The work of USGS scientists with YVO is only part of the USGS Volcano Hazards Program’s ongoing efforts to protect people’s lives and property in all of the volcanic regions of the United States

column1: Antonino Fernandez
column2: who was born in the Spanish village of Cerezales del Condado in 1917

column1: 3 Antonino Fernández
column2: founder of Corona Extra Beer
column3: died in August 2016 but left £2m to each resident in the Spanish village of Cerezales del Condado Credit: YouTube3 The Billionaire founder of Corona beer has made the entire Spanish village he grew up in Millionaires Credit: ReutersThe drinks mogul left the 80 residents of his home village £2 million each.

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/obama-behavioral-experiments/	president obama ordered behavioral experiments be carried out on the american people.	mostly false	['barack obama'
column2: 'behavioral experiments'
column3: 'behavioral insights'
column6: 'obama executive orders']		Kim LaCapria	['http://blog.practicalethics.ox.ac.uk/2015/09/behavioral-science-public-policy-ethics/']	http://blog.practicalethics.ox.ac.uk/2015/09/behavioral-science-public-policy-ethics/	http://blog.practicalethics.ox.ac.uk/	"The President of the United States has issued an executive order (see here) – government agencies are to use ‘insights’ from behavioral sciences to better serve the American people.

column1: In my view this is a good thing. Science is our friend. Obama’s heart is in the right place. Nonetheless
column2: the order raises a number of ethical and practical issues.

column1: The term ‘behavioral sciences’ is a little broad. However
column2: the executive order mentions the behavioral economics and psychology of decision making as an example of what is in mind. This indicates that what this order is really about is the implementation of ‘nudge’ policies. Some have objected to such policies on the grounds that they violate autonomy or dignity in some way. Perhaps that is right
column3: although it appears to depend on the case at hand. As Cass Sunstein – who has been influential for the Obama administration’s stance on the importance of behavioural science – has pointed out
column4: nudges are inevitable in policy making. A failure to take this into account ensures that the nudges in play will be unintentional rather than intentional. Further
column7: and fairness may very well support nudge policies in many instances.

column1: This will depend heavily on the effectiveness of the nudge policy
column2: which itself depends in part on the quality of the behavioral science. Given recent evidence that many results from experimental and social psychology fail to replicate
column3: there might be reason to worry here. The executive order does not define what counts as an ‘insight’ from behavioral science. Is it the result of one study? A couple? Deployment of an insight that is nothing more than an experimental artifact could be damaging

column1: Suppose a genuine insight exists. Even so
column2: implementing it is not straightforward. The executive order reflects thought on this matter
column3: as it encourages executive departments and agencies to:

column1: (i) identify policies
column2: programs
column3: and operations where applying behavioral science insights may yield substantial improvements in public welfare
column5: and program cost effectiveness; (ii) develop strategies for applying behavioral science insights to programs and
column7: rigorously test and evaluate the impact of these insights; (iii) recruit behavioral science experts to join the Federal Government as necessary to achieve the goals of this directive; and (iv) strengthen agency relationships with the research community to better use empirical findings from the behavioral sciences.

column1: This seems like solid advice
column2: although in practice – given the state of behavioral science – there is sure to be some trial and error in following it.

column1: This is not a post on the ethics of horrible journalism
column2: so I won’t comment overmuch on just how silly and paranoid the response to this directive has been from various conservative publications. Nor will I dignify the publications I have in mind with links. But it is worth noting that beneath the scaremongering you may see regarding this directive may be a legitimate concern. It is this: greater government attention to behavioral science data creates a motivation to collect and analyze and implement such data more generally. This is an issue much broader than the implementation of nudge policy-making
column3: but it affects this policy-making as well. Since the relevant kind of data can be both collected and implemented in ways we would deem unethical
column4: it is important that government collection and use of such data be highly transparent. The executive order makes provisions for a yearly report by the National Science and Technology Council that will summarize “agency implementation of section 1 of this order each year until 2019.” That’s some transparency
column5: but arguably not enough – much more can be done to keep the public informed regarding the use of behavioral science in guiding policy. Ideally
column6: the scientists assisting in this initiative would be given explicit roles in so informing the public."	Behavioral Science
column21: the executive order mentions the behavioral economics and psychology of decision making as an example of what is in mind.

column1: This will depend heavily on the effectiveness of the nudge policy
column2: which itself depends in part on the quality of the behavioral science.

column1: The executive order does not define what counts as an ‘insight’ from behavioral science.
This seems like solid advice
column2: although in practice – given the state of behavioral science – there is sure to be some trial and error in following it.

column1: It is this: greater government attention to behavioral science data creates a motivation to collect and analyze and implement such data more generally."

column5: CA –Mark Zuckerberg announced that Facebook will be shut down in May of 2013. Managing the site has become too stressful.

column1: “Facebook has gotten out of control
column2: ” reportedly said Zuckerberg in a press conference outside his Palo Alto office
column3: “and the stress of managing this company has ruined my life. I need to put an end to all the madness.”

column1: Zuckerberg reportedly went on to explain that starting May 15th
column2: users will no longer be able to access their Facebook accounts. That gives users (and Facebook addicts) a year to adjust to liwithout Facebook.

column1: “After May 15th
column2: 2013 the whole website shuts down
column3: ” said Avrat Humarthi
column4: Vice President of Technical Affairs at Facebook. “So if you ever want to see your pictures again
column5: I recommend you take them off the internet. You won’t be able to get them back after Facebook goes out of business.”

column1: Zuckerberg said the decision to shut down Facebook was difficult
column2: but that he does not think people will be upset.

column1: “I personally don’t think it’s a big deal
column2: ” he said in a private phone interview to a source close to a friend. “And to be honest
column3: I think it’s for the better. Without Facebook
column4: people will have to go outside and make real friends. That’s always a good thing.”

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/bill-nye-blasts-todd-akin/	bill nye blasted rep. todd akin for accusing him of personally provoking hurricane isaac.	false	[]		David Mikkelson	['http://superofficialnews.com/todd-akin-accepts-bill-nyes-challenge-for-a-debate/']	http://superofficialnews.com/todd-akin-accepts-bill-nyes-challenge-for-a-debate/	http://superofficialnews.com/	"by
The Ass Press
Petersburg
column2: KY — In a move that is shocking the nation
column3: Missouri Representative Todd Akin has agreed to Bill Nye’s challenge for a debate in science. The announcement was made this afternoon at a press conference held at the Creation Museum in Kentucky. “I accept Bill ‘Lies’ the Science Guy and his challenge for a debate
column4: ” Akin told reporters. “He’ll quickly learn that the word of god will always win over the word of some guy.”

column1: The Akin/Nye feud started with Akin’s recent statements regarding “legitimate” rape and homosexuality. Akin claims that science educator Nye has angered god with a Youtube video in which he says creationism “hurts kids”. He also claims that Nye is to blame for Hurricane Issac – the deadly storm currently heading towards New Orleans.
Nye was quick to respond to Akin’s comments during a live interview Thursday on the Smithsonian Channel. Nye called Akin “a f*cking idiot” for accusing him of personally starting Hurricane Issac.
“Look
column2: these people
column3: they’re f*cking retarded
column4: ” Nye said. “Rape can’t cause pregnancy? Breast milk cures homosexuality? I caused a hurricane by challenging creationism? Who can possibly take these people seriously anymore?”

column1: Nye went on to say
column2: “It used to be these Republicans didn’t believe in global warming or evolution. That was bad enough. Now they don’t even believe in egg + sperm = baby. Where does Todd Akin think babies come from? Does he think there are separate storks for people who were raped and people who weren’t? Hey look over there! It’s the rape stork. It drops it’s babies directly at the orphanage.”

column1: That’s when Nye offered the challenge of a science debate with Akin. “So Todd I got an offer for you. You and me. Any time. Any place. Debating science mano-a-mano. I’ll bring the facts
column2: and you bring the Vaseline. Because your ass is gonna f*cking need it when I’m done whipping.”

column1: “This name calling by Bill just shows his true colors
column2: ” Akin told reporters. “That’s how all these atheists are. They anger god with their gays in the military
column3: lesbians on the Supreme Court
column4: all this promiscuity in Hollywood and in music and on the streets. Then we have this guy Bill Nye going around saying we can’t teach the word of god to our children! Of course this angers god and that is what is causing these hurricanes.”

column1: Akin finished the press conference by agreeing to Nye’s challenge for a debate. “Bill Nye said any place
column2: any time. Well I’m naming the Creation Museum in Kentucky
column3: September 15th at noon sharp. I’ll be there to debate real
column4: legitimate science. We’ll see if Bill has the guts to show up.”

column1: Paul Horner who is an executive at NBC has already agreed to air the debate if Nye agrees to Akin’s terms. “This will be the debate of the century
column2: ” says Horner. “Forget about the Presidential debates
column3: I wanna see Bill Nye versus Todd Akin.”

column1: Nye has yet to respond. The Creation Museum is located at 2800 Bullittsburg Church Rd. Petersburg
column2: KY 41080."	Todd Akin Accepts Bill Nye’s Challenge For A Science Debate		['Jimmy Rustling'

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/politiqs/	a new harvard study has shown that liberals have a lower average iq than conservatives.	false	['Not Necessarily The News']		David Mikkelson	['https://iahymnewsnetwork.wordpress.com/2011/08/10/new-study-shows-liberals-have-a-lower-average-iq-than-conservatives/']	https://iahymnewsnetwork.wordpress.com/2011/08/10/new-study-shows-liberals-have-a-lower-average-iq-than-conservatives/	https://iahymnewsnetwork.wordpress.com/	"No
column2: don’t go anywhere.

column1: We need to talk. I’ll keep it brief.
Below is a fake news article I wrote around six years ago as a joke
column2: trying to show a friend how easy it is to come up with an article that looks plausible and official At the bottom of the page
column3: there is a message saying that this is bullshit
column5: just to make sure nobody took this seriously.

column1: And yet
column2: despite this article being the most poorly written piece of shit and probably the worst joke I have ever made
column3: it has been taken so seriously that I have 256 comments awaiting approval
column4: snopes has had to debunk it by noting the last paragraph
column5: and I’ve had NUMEROUS cases of people sending this link to me as an argument.

column1: This is a microcosm of a very serious problem.
We have a serious problem with fake news in this country
column2: and if you have come across this page
column3: you probably googled something to the effect of IQ and political views.

column1: Please
column2: stop.

column1: If you keep googling things like this
column2: you’re going to find what you’re looking for. You’re going to find one of those fake/fictitious news websites run by think tanks or fringe political groups
column3: and you’re going to read what you want to hear.

column1: Except
column2: next time
column3: you won’t come across this message. You won’t come across the disclaimer at the bottom saying this bullshit.

column1: Because while I was just a kid trying to make a point
column2: the other news sources are not. They are political groups who want more than anything to tell you what you want to hear and gull you to join their ranks.

column1: You need to do better. You need to check sources
column2: you need to confirm what people are saying is true
column3: even when you agree with them.

column1: Especially when you agree with them.
If you believe what people say because they look like they’re telling the truth
column2: because you agree with them and you assume that they know what they’re talking about
column3: then you are going to be brainwashed
column4: you are going to be gulled
column5: you are going to be fooled. They’ll lie to you more and more.

column1: Save yourself
column2: and help save everyone else from this epidemic. Don’t get gulled. Don’t become some liar’s follower.

column1: Check sources
column2: especially when you want the story to be right. If you see something you agree with
column3: don’t be a fool and nod your head then move on like so many have with this page.

column1: Stop
column2: look at the source
column3: follow the numbers
column5: figure out how they came to that conclusion and why. That way
column6: if what someone says is true
column7: you won’t just think it’s true
column8: you’ll know it’s true. And if it’s not
column9: you will have discovered a liar
column10: and no matter how much you wish what they said were true
column11: call them out — because the only thing worse than ignorance is willful ignorance.

column1: Ask questions
column2: think critically. We do not want a future run by liars and their followers.

column1: That’s all.
And now
column2: back to this.

column1: A new study conducted at Harvard University shows that in America
column2: Liberals have a significantly lower IQ than Conservatives. The study was conducted on 100
column3: 000 registered voters in 40 different states over the last twelve years

column1: The first part of the study lists the correlation between political beliefs and intelligence. Subjects of the study were chosen at random and requested to come to an unmarked van to take a test and answer some questions for a reasonable amount of money.
Of the 100
column2: 000 people
column3: there were people from many doctrines
column4: from conservative to liberal to marxist to fascist. Socialists came out on bottom
column5: with an average IQ of 87. The second worst were Liberals and then Marxists
column6: with 88 and 89 respectively. Conservatives received an average score of 110
column7: which is significantly above average. However
column8: the conservatives did not score the highest. The holder of second place were Communists with an average I.Q of 115
column9: and the first place was apolitical people who did not follow any specific doctrine
column10: who received a whopping score on average of 135.

column1: IAHYM News attempted to interview President Barack Obama on the new find
column2: but he refused to speak directly. Instead
column3: while walking down the strange hallway
column4: he told correspondent Joseph Ducreux that the study

column1: was ridiculous and false
column2: but failed to provide any reason as to why or

column1: how the science of the study is at fault.
Hilary Rodham Clinton was also contacted
column2: but she immediately hung up

column1: the phone when she figured out that the study was being mentioned at all.
Other parts of the study included the daily activities of the various people based on their doctrines. Apparently
column2: Liberals are five times more likely to commit a crime
column3: steal or cheat on a test than anybody else except for Socialists
column4: 52% of which have committed a major felony while being watched. Conservatives not only did not commit any crimes
column6: as the few events where a Conservative was threatened by a thief or mugger was hindered by a concealed handgun. Also
column7: Communists are the most likely to commit rape or sexual assault

column1: The study was conducted in other countries as well
column2: where 81% of Muslim Extremists admitted to following the Liberal doctrine and idolizing President Barack Obama. The study was conducted by a group of roughly 900 different scientists across the country over the past twelve years
column3: each one taking on a little over a hundred people per person.

column1: Reporting from New York City
column2: this is John Bowling.

column1: © IAHYM News Network
Oh yeah
column2: and everything in that bullshit you just read is completely and totally false. There has been no such conclusive study
column3: and all of the “Finds” are based on public paranoia.

column1: If you
column2: even for a second
column3: thought this find might be true
column4: you are probably an idiot."	New Study shows Liberals have a lower average IQ than Conservatives	2011-08-10 00:00:00	[]	['liberals'

Lawrence was scheduled to checkout this morning after 10 AM. At approximately 10:15 AM
column2: a maid named Verna Del Sosa went to Lawrence’s room to clean and thats when Lawrence’s body was discovered on the floor. “I was shocked
column3: I’ve never seen a dead body before”
column4: says Del Sosa. Del Sosa immediately called for an ambulance but it was too late. According to the paramedics
column5: it appears that Lawrence’s body laid lifeless on the hotel floor for several days.

column1: An autopsy is scheduled to take place Thursday which will hopefully uncover the mystery of Martin Lawrence’s death. So far
column2: foul play is not suspected but has not been ruled out. Martin Lawrence was anticipating shooting the third installment in the “Bad Boys” trilogy alongside long-time friend
column3: Will Smith. Filming was supposed to begin next month in Miami

column352: Your Lordship and Fellow Klansmen: It Is with some embarrassment that I undertake to dis- charge the duty devolving upon me as a representative of the Klans- men of this great State

The preservation and maintenance of the splen- did heritage that is ours is worthy of our best thought and effort. column101: who delivered an address of welcome on i i in. nit n of Missouri. ' AMERICA AT THE CROSS ROADS By A Distinguished Klansman ""Mr
column105: Americans: There is given to me the very great pleasure this afternoon of responding to the address of welcome which has been delivered to us by the Grand Dragon of Missouri in behalf of the Klansmen of Missouri and the Central West
column108: that I do not hope to attain to the high levels of thought and eloquence of the man who has delivered us this remarkable and splendid address of welcome. I
column110: do hope that I shall match him in the sincerity of my purpose
column111: and in the earnestness of my heart
column112: as I shall try to make vocal and articulate the feelings of the Klansmen who have come here from the various parts of the nation
column113: as we try in this brief address to express the appreciation that we feel for the remarkable welcome that has been delivered. ""The Grand Dragon of the Realm of Missouri has called our at- tention to the fact that the city of Kansas City is known as the heart I of America. I am wondering if there is not a double significance in that slogan today. Is it not a fact that
column114: in a very true sense of the word
column115: this Klonvokation assembled here in this city is the heart of America? ""Are not the Klansmen
column116: here gathered from our far flung battle lines

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/gringo/	the word gringo came from mexicans overhearing american soldiers sing the song green grow the lilacs during the mexicanamerican war.	false	['Story Time']		David Mikkelson	['http://www.contemplator.com/america/lilacs.html']	http://www.contemplator.com/america/lilacs.html	http://www.contemplator.com/	"This ballad is based on a similar song
column2: Green Grows the Laurel
column3: that was popular in 17th century Scotland. The American ballad tells the story of an American soldier's love for a Mexican lass. Though I don't have the words for the earlier version
column4: it evidently had a similar theme
column5: albeit with different nationalities. There are countless versions of the song
column6: I have included only two. One story of the songs origin speculates that Cowboys in South Texas loved to sing the song. Across the way
column8: who could not understand the words
column9: could only hear ""GREEN GROW"". So white Americans became known as ""Gringo"" by the Mexicans. However
column10: other scholars date the term to the incursion of American troops in Mexico to search for Pancho Villa.

column5: 'transgenderism']	2018/11/30	David Emery	['https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-6139305/Transgender-prisoner-rapist-identifies-woman-admits-sexually-assaulting-fellow-inmates.html']	https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-6139305/Transgender-prisoner-rapist-identifies-woman-admits-sexually-assaulting-fellow-inmates.html	https://www.dailymail.co.uk/	"A transgender prisoner charged with raping a woman was remanded to a female prison where she indecently assaulted four inmates

column1: Karen White
column3: was sent to the jail despite the fact that she was a convicted sex offender and paedophile.

column1: All her previous offences had been committed when she was a man – and White had not had gender reassignment surgery when she went to women-only New Hall Prison near Wakefield
column2: West Yorkshire
column3: where the sex assaults took place.

column1: Karen White (pictured)
column3: confessed to two counts of sexual touching during her time in jail

column1: The case could lead to a review of the rules for dealing with transgender inmates in the prison system.
Yesterday White pleaded guilty at Leeds Crown Court to the historic rape of a woman in August 2003
column2: when she was then called Stephen Wood.

column1: Last month she also pleaded guilty at the same court to two counts of raping another woman between February and December 2016.
It was for these rape offences that White was remanded in custody to New Hall Prison.
And while locked up there she took advantage of living alongside women inmates to carry out further sex attacks.
White had not had gender reassignment surgery when she went to women-only New Hall Prison (pictured) near Wakefield
column2: West Yorkshire
column3: where the sex assaults took place

column1: White admitted sex assaults on two inmates and denied sexually assaulting two others. All the incidents took place between September and November last year.
How many transgender prisoners are there in England and Wales? The latest figures showed there were 125 transgender prisoners in England and Wales up to the end of March 2017
column2: an increase from 70 a year earlier. About 25 are thought to be in women's jails. At least 34 male-born inmates are living as women in four specialist sex offender jails for men
column3: according to Freedom of Information Act requests. But prison governors say many have sought to be transferred to women's jails. Advertisement

column1: She was transferred to HM Prison Leeds
column2: a category B men's prison
column3: after the jail attacks.

column1: The sex assault offences she denied have been left to lie on file
column2: as have a further rape allegation against the 2016 victim and a charge of controlling behaviour against her.

column1: White had been living as a man called David Thompson before she began to identify as a woman.
She became Karen White and lived near Mytholmroyd in West Yorkshire. She was in transition when she committed the latest rape.
White is also awaiting sentence for stabbing a neighbour. Yesterday she appeared in the dock with her auburn hair in a ponytail
column2: wearing glasses and walking with a stick.

column1: Judge Christopher Batty adjourned sentencing until October 11 for the preparation of reports and to obtain victim personal statements.
While locked up at New Hall Prison
column2: she took advantage of living alongside women inmates to carry out further sex attacks

column1: When White appeared before a district judge at Leeds Magistrates' Court in July

column1: Prosecutor Charlotte Dangerfield told the court the first assault in September happened when White stood close to another inmate
column2: touched her arm and exposed herself.

column1: For the second assault she made 'inappropriate comments about oral sex' and put the woman's hand on the 'defendant's left breast' so she could feel her padded bra.
Miss Dangerfield said the third alleged assault involved White pushing herself indecently against another prisoner
column2: and on the fourth incident she allegedly kissed an inmate on the neck.

column1: White pleaded guilty at Leeds Crown Court (pictured) to the historic rape of a woman in 2003

column1: Now that you're back
column2: you should be sufficiently chilled out as you're listening to the Callin' Oates emergency hotline. The Hall & Oates-infused phone number hit our Twitter stream this afternoon
column3: and we tracked down the creators of this Daryl & John project to see how and why it was built. Turns out that while it may not have been built pro bono by a H&O mega-fan for the community
column4: it's still a pretty good story.

column1: It's from ""Go Solo"" fan Michael Selvidge (@selviano)
column2: who recently joined cloud communications company Twilio
column3: and his high school buddy Reid Butler (@rbutlersf). The San Francisco-based company requires that all new employees build an app
column7: who formerly worked PR part time for Twilio before coming on as a full time employee
column8: knew that he'd have to build something
column9: but lacked an idea. He told me
column11: 'If only there was a pun that would work with this...' Then 'Callin' Oates' hit me

column1: With the idea secure
column2: Selvidge and Butler built and launched the hotline this weekend
column3: mixing a bit of PHP and links to public URLs on Dropbox to create a simple interactive voice response system. The custom 1-719-26-OATES number costs $1 / month
column4: and Selvidge found it via an online phrase search. Twilio's obviously helping out here
column5: but any user can build a custom app on the Twilio API
column6: and even with viral success like this
column7: you'd just be out a ""couple hundred bucks."" Today alone
column8: the first day it's gotten any serious visibility on the web
column10: 223 requests as of 5:00 PM EST. And
column11: if we're decent judges of the '80s revival in modern culture or the need for instant Hall and Oates fulfillment
column12: the @CallinOates hotline should continue growing just fine.

He told the attendant that he wasn’t an American and that he preferred another doctor help if possible. Unfortunately

column1: As he approached
column2: he could see that the man was barely managing to breathe and going in and out of consciousness. What the doctor did next may seem normal to people where he comes from
column3: but here it was simply disgusting. He leaned over the man and asked him if he believed in God. “Yes
column5: “Jesus Christ is my Lord and Savior.”

column1: At that point
column2: Kohmeni informed the flight attendant that he could only “give the man the comfort of knowing Allah will give him the chance to redeem himself in heaven
column3: ” but that he couldn’t help save him. The attendant reminded him that he was a doctor and that he was in the United States

column1: The plane instead made an emergency landing in Pittsburgh
column2: where the man was taken by ambulance to Mercy General
column3: where he was pronounced dead. The doctor in the ER said “simple CPR” would have saved his life.

column1: Dr. Khomeni was taken into custody by the Pennsylvania State Police for willfully endangering the life of his patient. Trooper Donald Deekman told us that in their state
column2: the doctor assumed the man as a patient when he raised his hand and subsequently left his seat. Not treating him is a felony. “It will be up to the DA to charge him with felony murder
column3: ” said Deekman
column4: “we knew he’d broken the law so we arrested him.”

column1: Two cell-phone recordings of the incident were recovered by officials who said they should be processed and released by the end of the day. Khomeni’s lawyer says he can’t possibly be held accountable for a law in a state he was flying over in a country he’s not a resident of. The nuances are too extreme.
The Pennsylvania DA said in a statement that “ignorance of the law doesn’t exclude you from it.”
Either way
column2: this “doctor” let a man die because he wasn’t a Muslim and because “Allah wanted to judge him.” That’s basically what he said. He wanted to murder the guy for loving God. Hopefully
column3: they charge him with murder and hang him in the town square for all to see.

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/glade-plugins-fire-hazard/	glade plugins brand air fresheners have been proved a significant fire hazard.	false.	['Household Hints']		David Mikkelson	['http://web.archive.org/web/20020917035438/http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/news/7onYourSide/WABC_7side_041902fresheners.html']	http://web.archive.org/web/20020917035438/http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/news/7onYourSide/WABC_7side_041902fresheners.html	http://web.archive.org/	"Looking At Potential Dangers Of Plug-In Air Fresheners

A popular home air freshener may be to blame for several fires. The Glade plug-in air freshener has already been recalled by SC Johnson. Seven On Your Side's Tappy Phillips takes a closer look at this and other potentially dangerous air fresheners.
It's a warning for consumers: The Consumer Product Safety Commission says the 'Glade Extra Outlet Scented Oil Air Fresheners' may cause fires
column2: and now the commission is now looking into potential fire dangers from all air fresheners. If you went shopping for the Glade plug-in air freshener that features an extra outlet
column3: you probably found an empty shelf. The voluntary recall of 2.5 million 'Glade Extra Outlet Scented Oil Air Fresheners' was announced Friday by the manufacturer
column5: and the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Both say the air fresheners have been recalled because the manufacturer found a loose connection inside the extra outlet
column6: which could pose a fire hazard. Ken Giles
column7: CPSC: ""The misassembly causes an electrical problem that could lead to a fire."" So far
column8: the CPSC says the plug-in has caused no injuries but... Giles: ""Consumers should unplug it right away."" So just how safe are other plug-in air fresheners? The CPSC showed us scores of reports from consumers
column9: chronicling fire hazards associated with plug-in air fresheners from various manufacturers. Doing our own searching
column10: we found two instances where air fresheners are suspected in house fires. Karen Myers
column11: Fire Victim: ""The flames were just... it was so hot. I've never seen anything like it."" Karen Myers is talking about a fire she discovered in her kitchen
column12: where she had plugged in an air freshener. Myers: ""It just ignited and went up. And it was all the way going up to the ceiling."" Karen's air freshener was not a Glade
column14: made by the White Barn Candle Company. Myers: ""I think we were very lucky... but everybody should know they're not going to be so lucky."" We spoke to another homeowner
column15: who said he also used a 'Wallflower
column16: ' but wasn't as lucky as Myers. His house was destroyed by fire. Richard Wolfson
column17: Fire Investigator: ""It was at the junction where the outlet and air freshener were located."" Rich Wolfson was hired by the homeowners insurance company to investigate this fire. He says he tested the wiring and looked at the fire pattern and concluded that the air freshener was the most likely cause. Wolfson: ""There was no evidence of failure of the outlet itself."" The CPSC says some fires attributed to air fresheners may be caused by faulty electrical wiring. But at least one fire investigator says it's better to be safe than sorry. Wolfson: ""If there is a problem with this
column18: we want to save lives. This could be a potential hazard for homeowners."" Despite repeated calls
column19: the White Barn Candle Company didn't respond to our request for a comment. If your air freshener has shown any signs of fire
column21: you should report it to your local fire department and they will investigate. If you have a 'Glade Extra Outlet Scented Oil Air Freshener
column22: ' unplug it immediately and call their recall line at 800-571-0920
column23: to get a refund or replacement.

column6: 'vaccines']	2017/07/21	Dan MacGuill	['https://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/finnish_diabetes_vaccine_trials_to_start_in_2018/9730247']	https://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/finnish_diabetes_vaccine_trials_to_start_in_2018/9730247	https://yle.fi/	"Image: Lääketieteen ja biotieteiden tiedekunta / Tampereen yliopisto

column1: A vaccine for type 1 diabetes developed by Finnish researchers will be tested on mainly Finnish human subjects in late 2018
column2: researchers announced on Tuesday.

column1: The scientists first found that the prototype works effectively and safely on mice
column2: and now say

column1: Image: Yle uutisgrafiikka
that the vaccine could be in mainstream use within eight years if the coming rounds of tests prove successful.
The vaccine will first be given to a group of 30 healthy men during the first phase of the clinical trials
column2: followed by a group of some 150 children if all goes well. After two successful rounds the vaccine can be considered safe and effective against viruses. The final round of vaccinations
column3: intended for a group of some 4
column5: should tell researchers whether the vaccine specifically prevents type 1 diabetes.

column1: Virus likely culprit
A virus may be behind a significant proportion of type 1 diabetes cases
column2: which are especially common among children. Professor Heikki Hyöty from the University of Tampere and Professor Mikael Knip of the University of Helsinki have worked on the pathology of diabetes from more than 20 years
column3: and say they are confident that an enterovirus that attacks the pancreas to destroy insulin-producing cells is the root cause of type 1 diabetes.

column1: Image: Lääketieteen ja biotieteiden tiedekunta / Tampereen ylipopisto
If the vaccine proves effective in humans
column2: it could do much to minimise suffering as well as expenses.

column1: It is estimated that the additional cost of care for one child with diabetes over their lifetime is about a million euros
column2: Knip says. ""This vaccine could prevent at least half of new cases
column3: which amounts to some 250 million euros in annual savings.""

column1: Enteroviruses are the most common type of infectious virus in humans; they cause a wide variety of health problems from the flu and eye infections to meningitis and heart inflammation.
Humanity last beat back an enterovirus via vaccination when polio was all but eradicated in the late 1980s.
US funding
column2: biotech co-op

column1: The team of researchers sought funding for their vaccine trial for four years
column2: with no European benefactors stepping up.

column1: Eventually American biopharmaceutical company Provention Bio agreed to fund the trial in full. The company has raised just under 25 million euros
column2: most of which will go towards seeing the vaccination trials through. Investors include companies
column3: individuals and funds.

column1: Professors Hyöty and Knip founded a company of their own
column2: Vactech
column3: in 2001. They are part-owners of the firm
column4: which has given Provention Bio the green light to use and manage their enterovirus vaccine. Vactech owns shares in Provention Bio.

column1: The only way to change years of university study into a working vaccine is through business cooperation
column2: says Hyöty. ""Human trials are so expensive that only a large enough international company with enough room for risk management to be prepared in case the vaccine is found wanting.""

column1: Finland suffers highest rate of type 1 diabetes
Type 1 diabetes may be more common in Finland than anywhere else in the world. Some 500-600 children contract it each year
column2: which is also the largest relative figure worldwide.

column1: Image: Yle Uutisgrafiikka
The number of type 1 diabetes sufferers has multiplied by six since the 1950s. It is only in the recent decade that incidence growth has plateaued. There are some 45
column2: 000 people in Finland who suffer from type 1 diabetes
column3: and nearly half a million people who carry some form of diabetes."	Finnish diabetes vaccine trials to start in 2018		[]	['start'

column3: 'trump memes']		David Mikkelson	['https://www.facebook.com/business/news/page-likes-update']	https://www.facebook.com/business/news/page-likes-update	https://www.facebook.com/	"Businesses use Page audience data to understand what their followers care about. To make audience data even more meaningful for businesses
column4: we’re updating the way Page likes are counted by removing memorialized and voluntarily deactivated accounts from Pages’ like counts. This change ensures that data on Facebook is consistent and up-to-date.

column1: Removing inactive Facebook accounts
There are two primary benefits to removing voluntarily deactivated and memorialized Facebook accounts from Pages’ like counts:

Business results : Removing inactive Facebook accounts from Page audience data gives businesses up-to-date insights on the people who actively follow their Page and makes it easier for businesses to find people like their followers through tools like lookalike audiences.
Consistency : We already filter out likes and comments generated by deactivated or memorialized accounts from individual Page posts
column2: so this update keeps data consistent.

column1: What to expect
Over the coming weeks
column2: Page admins should expect to see a small dip in their number of Page likes as a result of this update. It’s important to remember
column3: though
column4: that these removed likes represent people who were already inactive on Facebook.

column1: Going forward
column2: any accounts that are voluntarily deactivated or memorialized will be removed from a Page’s like count. If a deactivated account is reactivated
column3: the account will be re-added to a Page’s like count.

column1: Everyone benefits from meaningful information on Facebook. It’s our hope that this update makes Pages even more valuable for businesses."	Making Page Likes More Meaningful		[]	['memorialized'

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/word-imperfect/	a fedup computer tech support specialist finally tells a particularly frustrating customer shes too stupid to own a computer.	false.	['Business Babble']		David Mikkelson	['http://web.archive.org/web/19970209064552/http://www.progress.demon.co.uk/Fun/Trouble-with.html']	http://web.archive.org/web/19970209064552/http://www.progress.demon.co.uk/Fun/Trouble-with.html	http://web.archive.org/	"From: dwiebe@csi.compuserve.com Newsgroups: alt.shenanigans Subject: Re: phonestuff cyberknght@aol.com (CyberKnght) writes: >I like that idea! > >When I worked as a customer service rep at the cable company
column2: few things >frustrated me more than vague customers. > >""Hi. My cable's not working right"" > [...] >""How do I tell if my TV is on channel 3?"" > >And on and on and on and on... this kind of call was typical of my day at >the cable company This reminds me of a call I got from a faculty member when I was computer-assisting my way through college: ""Welch Hall computer assistant; may I help you?"" ""Yes
column3: well
column4: I'm having trouble with WordPerfect."" [Instant voice-recognition: I know it's a particularly ditzy blonde French professor with whom I have had prior dealings.] ""What sort of trouble
column7: and all of a sudden the words went away."" ""Went away?"" ""They disappeared."" ""Hmm. So what does your screen look like now?"" ""Nothing."" ""Nothing?"" ""It's blank; it won't accept anything when I type."" ""Are you still in WordPerfect
column8: or did you get out?"" ""How do I tell?"" [Uh-oh. Well
column9: let's give it a try anyway.] ""Can you see the C:\> prompt on the screen?"" ""What's a sea-prompt?"" [Uh-huh
column10: thought so. Let's try a different tack.] ""Never mind. Can you move the cursor around on the screen?"" ""There isn't any cursor: I told you
column11: it won't accept anything I type."" [Ah--at least she knows what a cursor is. Sounds like a hardware problem. I wonder if she's kicked out her monitor's power plug.] ""Does your monitor have a power indicator?"" ""What's a monitor?"" ""It's the thing with the screen on it that looks like a TV. Does it have a little light that tells you when it's on?"" ""I don't know."" ""Well
column12: then look on the back of the monitor and find where the power cord goes into it. Can you see that?"" [sound of rustling and jostling] [muffled] ""Yes
column13: I think so."" ""Great! Follow the cord to the plug
column14: and tell me if it's plugged into the wall."" [pause] ""Yes
column16: that's interesting. I doubt she would have accidentally turned it off
column17: and I don't want to send her hunting for the power switch because I don't know what kind of monitor she has and it's bound to have more than one switch on it. Maybe the video cable is loose or something.] ""When you were behind the monitor
column18: did you notice that there were two cables plugged into the back of it
column20: there are. I need you to look back there again and find the other cable."" [rustle rustle] [muffled] ""Okay
column21: here it is."" ""Follow it for me
column22: and tell me if it's plugged securely into the back of your computer."" [still muffled] ""I can't reach."" ""Uh huh. Well
column23: can you see if it is?"" [clear again] ""No."" ""Even if you maybe put your knee on something and lean way over?"" ""Oh
column24: it's not because I don't have the right angle--it's because it's dark."" ""Dark?"" ""Yes--the office light is off
column25: and the only light I have is coming in from the window."" ""Well
column26: turn on the office light then."" ""I can't."" ""No? Why not?"" ""Because there's a power outage."" ""A p--!"" [ARGH!] This woman was good friends with my supervisor
column27: who was also a French professor (still is
column30: so I couldn't deal with her the way I really wanted to
column31: and was forced to explain sweetly and gently to her that computers needed power just like office lights
column32: and if the office lights were out
column35: if she hadn't saved her work she had probably lost everything she'd done so far in WordPerfect. But I could still fantasize: ""A power outage? Aha! Okay
column36: we've got it licked now. Do you still have the boxes and manuals and packing stuff your computer came in?"" ""Well
column38: I keep them in the closet."" ""Good! Go get them
column39: and unplug your system and pack it up just like it was when you got it. Then take it back to the store you bought it from."" ""Really? Is it that bad?"" ""Yes
column42: I suppose. What do I tell them?"" ""Tell them you're TOO STUPID TO OWN A COMPUTER!"" [slam] But that wouldn't have been a very nice thing to do

column1: I see a cute dinosaur who does seem to be missing an appendage

column3: but the mother on the other hand…

column1: Jessica Eckerdt of Queen Creek
column2: Arizona bought a cake for her son’s sixth birthday. She picked the dinosaur from a selection of cake patterns. When she brought the cake out to sing to her son
column3: though
column4: she noticed something weird: the dinosaur had three legs. Oh
column5: and she thought the icing wrote out “666.”

column1: “I was extremely shocked and upset to see a demonic symbol written clear as day on my six-year-old son’s birthday cake. What was supposed to be a whimsical dinosaur became something very distasteful. I was extremely surprised at Costco for allowing such an inappropriate joke be sold to an unsuspecting victim.” Source: Inquisitr.com
Now
column2: she and some right-wing sources are convinced that it’s either of the devil or a bad joke. One piece of evidence
column3: they claim
column4: is that the Costco is located in Superstition Springs. Another

column4: 'pets']	2003/05/25	Snopes Staff	['http://web.archive.org/web/20020615094522/http://www.petcare.umn.edu/FAQ/Toxicology/Chocolate.htm']	http://web.archive.org/web/20020615094522/http://www.petcare.umn.edu/FAQ/Toxicology/Chocolate.htm	http://web.archive.org/	"Toxicity - Chocolate Written by Dr. Peggy Root

column1: Reviewed by Dr. Mike Murphy The toxic compounds in chocolate are theobromine and caffeine
column2: which are classified as methylxanthine alkaloids. Theobromine is the primary chemical involved in chocolate toxicity in small animals. Dogs and cats are exposed to chocolate especially during the holiday season. Because of their small body size relative to human beings
column3: ingestion of a fairly small amount of chocolate may cause toxicity. As little as 4 ounces of baking chocolate or 1 pound of milk chocolate could be fatal if ingested by a dog weighing 10 pounds or less. Dogs will readily eat a toxic dose of chocolate. Ingestion of the rich smelling cocoa bean landscaping mulch also can be a cause of methylxanthine toxicity. The relative amount of theobromine contained in various chocolate compounds is described in the table below. CHOCOLATE PRODUCT THEOBROMINE CONTENT (mg/oz) Cocoa bean landscaping mulch 300-1200 Cacao beans 400-1500 Cocoa powder 400-550 Unsweetened baking chocolate 450 Semi-sweet baking chocolate (chips) 135-260 Milk chocolate 60 Hot chocolate beverage 12 White chocolate 1 Theobromine is absorbed from ingested chocolate products slowly
column4: reaching peak levels in the blood about 10 hours after ingestion. Initial clinical signs are seen 2 to 4 hours after ingestion
column9: diarrhea and increased heart rate. Over time
column12: and the muscles become rigid. Finally
column14: followed by death. Treatment involves decreasing further absorption of theobromine from ingested chocolate. Induction of vomiting only is beneficial if the animal is seen within 2 hours of having ingested the chocolate and if seizures have not begun. Chocolate products may coagulate into a ball in the stomach
column15: preventing their expulsion or movement through the intestinal tract. Supportive care that will be provided by the veterinarian includes administration of intravenous fluids
column16: medications as needed for heart abnormalities and seizures
column17: and maintenance of normal body temperature. Because chocolate products generally are high in fat
column18: secondary pancreatic disease may occur. Prognosis for dogs with chocolate toxicity is good if the animal is treated by the veterinarian within 2 to 4 hours of their having eaten a toxic dose of chocolate. Prognosis is guarded if heart abnormalities or central nervous system signs
column22: develop. Potential chocolate poisoning is an emergency. Please call your veterinarian. Do not leave e-mail messages on this site about possible poisonings
column23: as messages are not answered swiftly enough to ensure your pet's safe recovery. Emergency personnel at the University of Minnesota Veterinary Teaching Hospital can be reached at 612-625-1919 during the day before 4:30 pm
column24: and at 612-625-9711 in the evening and on weekends. References: Carson TL. Methylxanthines. In: Small animal toxicology
column28: 2001;563-570. Gwaltney-Brant S. Toxicology of common household hazards. Proceedings
column30: Columbus OH
column31: 2001;127-134. Osweiler GD. Chocolate toxicity. In: The five minute veterinary consult

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/hillary-clinton-rated-admired-woman-twenty-times/	"hillary clinton has been rated ""most admired woman"" by gallup polls 21 times."	true	['hillary clinton']	2017/01/11	Bethania Palma	['http://dailyheadlines.com/hillary-clinton-most-admired-woman/']	http://dailyheadlines.com/hillary-clinton-most-admired-woman/	http://dailyheadlines.com/	"Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has been declared the Most Admired Woman of 2016. Who the hell are they surveying is what I want to know!
Loading...
According to a newly released Gallup survey
column2: Clinton has topped the list of America’s most admired woman for the 15th year in a row
column3: and the 21st time ever.

column1: In the poll
column2: 12 percent of respondents said that Clinton was their top pick
column3: with Michelle Obama in second place with 8 percent. German Chancellor Angela Merkel and television personality Oprah Winfrey tied for third with 3 percent of the votes each
column4: and talk show host Ellen DeGeneres rounded out the top five with 2 percent of votes.

column1: The survey
column2: conducted Dec. 7 through 11
column3: has been run every year since 1946.

column1: This year’s Most Admired Man was President Barack Obama
column2: who garnered 22 percent of respondents votes. The year’s second most admired man is President-elect Donald Trump
column3: with 15 percent of votes. Trailing in third is Pope Francis with 4 percent
column4: followed by Sen. Bernie Sanders in fourth with 2 percent of votes
column5: and Rev. Billy Graham rounds out the top five with 1 percent support.

column1: Graham has been in the top 10 every year since 1955.
According to The Washington Post
column2: Clinton has enjoyed a relatively high public approval rating for the majority of her 25 years on the national stage. However
column3: her favorability rating dropped dramatically during her two attempts at the White House.

column2: as first lady during the Monica Lewinsky scandal
column3: Clinton saw a favorable rating of 64 percent. However
column4: at the end of her first run for president in 2008 (against then-Senator Barack Obama)
column5: her approval rating dropped to 44 percent (and her disapproval rating shot up from 28 percent in 1998 to 54 percent).

column1: Then
column3: after spending time as the Secretary of State
column4: Clinton reached her highest yet favorability rating of 67 percent (coupled with a 26 percent unfavorable rating). Her second attempt at the presidency once again plummeted her approval score. As of August
column5: her favorability rating stood at 41 percent
column6: while disapproval of Clinton rose to an all-time high of 56 percent.

column1: Sources: Gallup
