https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/army-implements-mandatory-divorce/	the army is instituting a mandatory divorce policy to improve readiness.	false	['actually funny satire'
column2: 'army implements mandatory divorce'
column3: 'duffel blog'
column5: KY – In an effort to increase soldiers’ interchangeability and world-wide assignment eligibility
column6: the Army has announced that married individuals will no longer be considered for enlistment
column7: and all active-duty married soldiers must divorce their spouses within thirty days or be subject to administrative separation in accordance with AR 600-8-2.

column1: Dependents must return to their home of record at their own expense.
“What we’re seeing is an awful lot of dependents in the Army community
column2: who – let’s be honest – contribute nothing to military readiness
column3: ” said Army Secretary John McHugh to reporters. “They distract our married soldiers from putting the mission first
column4: and they suck up a huge amount of resources.”

column1: McHugh pointed to Army spouse and family wellness programs like the Family Readiness Group
column2: the MyCAA spouse-education program
column3: Army Community Services
column4: and the Army Family Action Plan
column5: which cost the Army roughly $475 million a year to maintain. “In addition
column6: you have the DEERS system and the DoDDS school system
column8: plus the massive costs involved in providing healthcare
column9: exchange and commissary services to dependents. There’s also the higher cost-of-living allowances and all the other allotments to which married soldiers are entitled.”

column1: But there’s also the elephant in the room: the spiraling cost of married soldiers’ housing.
“Unlike single soldiers
column2: who live in on-post barracks and often live two to four per room
column3: which is more space than anyone really needs anyway
column5: “married soldiers enjoy lavishly opulent housing accommodations at government expense
column9: even a backyard in most cases. You can’t tell me that a family of five NEEDS a three-bedroom house. In this time of fiscal austerity
column10: it’s a luxury that we can no longer afford.”

column1: Army leaders applauded the move
column2: calling it “long overdue.”

column1: “This is more than I could have ever hoped for. Finally
column2: we can put our soldiers wherever we need them without having to worry about their do-nothing families causing problems for us
column3: ” said one USAREUR command sergeant major
column4: who had previously called for the ending of all command-sponsored overseas tours. “Seriously
column5: I can’t tell you how many times I had some whiny soldier ask to leave the field or return early from a deployment because their wife had another baby
column6: or she crashed her car and wound up in the hospital
column7: or their kid had a seizure or something. Plus
column8: housing has always been an issue at OCONUS duty stations in Europe
column9: where we just don’t have the housing facilities to accommodate families
column10: and oftentimes have to put married soldiers up in off-post government-leased apartments
column11: which is a huge expense. Now that these married soldiers are going to become geo-bachelors
column12: we’ll have a lot more flexibility in our billeting options.”

column1: The move will likely generate intense backlash among married soldiers who will be affected by the policy change. “The simple fact is
column2: these soldiers joined an all-volunteer Army
column3: ” McHugh said. “If the Army wanted its soldiers to have families

column1: However
column2: the reaction among married soldiers was sharply negative. “If this doesn’t just beat all
column3: ” said SFC Gregory Martineau
column8: an eighteen-year Army veteran who is married with four children. “I’ve never regretted my service until now.”

column1: Martineau would have been eligible to retire in two years
column2: but now will separate with no retirement benefits because he’s unwilling to comply with the new policy. “If I wanted to join a service branch that craps all over families
column3: I’d have joined the Marines. At least they’re up front about it.”"	Army Implements Mandatory Divorce Policy To Improve Readiness	2013-03-14 07:00:40-04:00	['Posted By']	['divorce'

column2: 'daria'
column3: 'purple eyes']"	2015/02/06	Dan Evon	['http://outpost-daria-reborn.info/fanfic/purple_eyes.html']	http://outpost-daria-reborn.info/fanfic/purple_eyes.html	http://outpost-daria-reborn.info/	"Purple Eyes and Other Interesting Anomalies

column1: If you have read any of the statistics of my Daria-based fan fiction characters or any of my stories about those characters
column2: you will have noticed that three of my characters (Raven
column3: Rebecca
column4: and Zia) have deep purple eyes. It's not because they wear contacts in order to hide their real eye colors. It's because of a genetic mutation called ""Alexandria's Genesis.""

column1: The Origins of the ""Genesis""
Alexandria's Genesis
column2: as it has been called since the 1960s
column3: is a genetic mutation generally found in women of Euro-American (a.k.a.
column4: Caucasian) descent. This mutation can be traced as far as the Middle Ages in Northern Europe. The first known record of ""Alexandria's Genesis"" was written in the year CE 1330 (Common Era).

column1: A woman named Alexandria Augustine came into the world on April 29
column2: CE 1329 in London
column3: England. At the time
column5: but her parents soon noticed that her eyes were changing from the blue eyes Alexandria had at birth to the purple eyes she would have by her first birthday. The parents were startled by this dramatic change. They took her to their priest
column6: thinking that a witch did this to their child
column7: and that the priest might be able to ask God to change the eye color back. The priest told the parents that it was not the work of the devil
column8: but a myth come true. This particular priest had heard a story about a race of people who had purple eyes. These humans were thought to have come from Egypt after a mysterious light flashed in the sky during a moonless night thousands of years ago. The purple-eyed humans also had very fair skin
column9: and were thought to be spirits because of their appearance. The so-called ""spirit people"" eventually went north and vanished without a trace. The priest told her parents not to worry
column10: for they had a special child in their hands and they should take good care of her.

column1: Eventually
column2: Alexandria grew up to be a very beautiful woman
column3: got married
column4: had four children (all four were girls
column5: and all four also had the mutation)
column7: and died at the age of 150 of natural causes. It is this discovery that helped to name the genetic mutation when the gene was discovered in 1968.

column1: The Characteristics of ""Alexandria's Genesis""
The first characteristic of people with ""Alexandria's Genesis"" is their eye color. When someone is born with this genetic mutation
column2: the eyes are either blue or gray at birth. At six months
column3: the eyes begin their transformation from the original color to purple. This process is completed by the person's first birthday. A second process
column5: starts as soon as the first is completed. This slow process continues until the onset of puberty. By then
column6: the eye will have become a dark purple
column10: and will be that color for the rest of their time. These changes do not affect the person's eyesight

column1: Speaking of puberty
column2: those who have the mutation will never grow any facial
column3: body
column5: or anal hair during this stage of growth. In fact
column6: the only hair they will ever have is what is on their heads
column9: and their eyelashes. Women also have an added bonus beyond never having to shave: never buying tampons or pads. It turns out that females born with ""Alexandria's Genesis"" never menstruate in their lives. They are fertile
column11: and can go through the same things that women without the mutation can go through every month. Beyond these differences
column12: those with the mutation go through puberty as normally as everyone else does.

column1: Below are all of the characteristics of ""Alexandria's Genesis.""
Clear
column2: silver-like purple eyes (after 1st birthday; deepen in color until onset of puberty)

column1: No facial or body hair growth beyond what was already there at birth
Dark brown or black hair
Shimmering white skin that resist tanning and burning
Lack of menstruation cycle (in women)
Highly evolved immune system (has been known to resist every disease known to man so far)
Appear 5-20 years younger (after the age of 21
column2: the aging process slows down greatly; it stops completely between the ages of 40-50)

column1: Long life span (ranges from 130-170 years)
Perfect vision
Never overweight (their metabolism prevents the gaining of too much fat [a.k.a.
column2: partial lipodystophy])

column1: Well-developed and proportioned bodies
Found mainly in women of Euro-American descent
Women are the primary carriers of the mutation
Children born from mothers with the mutation are also carriers
Mutation remains active generation after generation
Mutation grows stronger generation after generation
Interracial Children of the ""Genesis""
An interesting aspect of this mutation is that if it passed on to a child whose mother or father is not of Euro-American descent
column2: the child will receive all of the qualities of those who have the gene. The only quality that changes is the skin color; it is lighter than those without the gene are
column3: but it is not as light as the parent with the mutation is. So far
column4: this gene has shown up in children whose mother or father was Hispanic
column6: or Arabic. If these children were to marry someone within their own race
column7: their offspring would also develop the same characteristics. The most startling aspect of the biracial ""Genesis"" children is that they take on a more Euro-American appearance. Not much more is known about these children beyond these initial findings.

column1: Another Interesting Development
In ten percent of the population that has ""Alexandria's Genesis
column2: there is another characteristic of this mutation that is increasing on a yearly basis: the processing of human waste… or lack thereof.

column1: As it turns out
column2: in some of these people
column3: the mutation is actually causing the digestive system to produce no waste. No one has found out how this is possible
column4: but most scientists have a theory that may explain this increasing phenomenon.

column1: The digestion process goes through its normal procedure until the digested product enters the large intestine. It is there
column2: scientists suggest
column3: that the large intestine absorbs everything and uses the product to keep the body in top shape. This makes the bladder completely useless
column4: and leaves the small intestine and rectum as just an opening. It is not much of a theory
column5: since very little is still known about ""Alexandria's Genesis.""

column1: Conclusion

There are questions about this genetic mutation that remain unanswered. The biggest question left unanswered is where ""Alexandria's Genesis"" actually first appeared. Many researchers are looking into the myth of the ""spirit people"" of Egypt in order to find out if this mutation really did exist several thousands of years ago. If that is indeed the case
column2: the next question to be answered is if this mutation is of Earth origin… or of a different place."	Purple Eyes and Other Interesting Anomalies		[]	['anomalies'

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/lionesses-grow-manes/	"under certain conditions
column2: lionesses can grow manes and develop ""masculine behavior""."	true	['gender'
column3: 'lionesses'

column1: This lion king (pictured above) is a queen. And she’s not the only one.
Five lionesses in Botswana have grown a mane and are showing male-like behaviours. One is even roaring and mounting other females.
Male lions are distinguished by their mane
column2: which they use to attract females
column3: and they roar to protect their territory or call upon members of their pride. Females lack a mane and are not as vocal.

column1: Advertisement
But sometimes lionesses grow a mane and even behave a bit like males. However
column2: until now
column3: reports of such maned lionesses have been extremely rare and largely anecdotal. We knew they existed
column4: but little about how they behave.

column1: Now
column2: Geoffrey D. Gilfillan at the University of Sussex in Falmer
column3: UK
column4: and colleagues have reported five lionesses sporting a mane at the Moremi Game Reserve in Botswana’s Okavango delta.

column1: Gilfillan started studying these lionesses back in March 2014
column2: and for the next two years he focused on recording the behaviour of one of them
column3: called SaF05. She had an underdeveloped mane and was larger than most females.

column1: “While SaF05 is mostly female in her behaviour – staying with the pride
column2: mating males – she also has some male behaviours
column3: such as increased scent-marking and roaring
column4: as well as mounting other females

column1: “Although females do roar and scent-mark like males
column2: they usually do so less frequently
column3: ” he says. “SaF05
column5: was much more male-like in her behaviour

column1: Jessica Vitale
A likely explanation is an increased level of testosterone as these lionesses mature
column2: says Luke Hunter
column3: president and chief conservation officer at the global wild cat conservation organisation Panthera.

column1: In lions
column2: testosterone directly affects the development of manes. Castrated males
column3: for example
column4: lose their ability to produce testosterone and promptly lose their mane

column2: a captive lioness called Emma at the National Zoological Gardens of South Africa developed a mane. Tests revealed high levels of testosterone due to a problem in her ovaries
column3: and once they were removed she reverted to a typical lioness.

column1: The idea that testosterone is implicated in the Botswana lionesses is also backed by observations of their reproductive success
column2: says Kathleen Alexander at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg.

column1: “While some of the maned lionesses were observed mating
column2: none of them became pregnant
column3: suggesting they are infertile
column4: a known consequence of high levels of androgens such as testosterone in females
column5: ” she says. “The behavioural changes suggest this is likely the case.”

column1: Hunter suspects this explanation applies to the animals studied by Gilfillan and his colleagues. “Given all five known maned females come from the Okavango region
column2: there must be a genetic component in this population underlying the phenomenon
column3: ” he says.

column1: “I don’t think this is anything to be concerned about
column2: ” says Hunter. “Although the females are apparently infertile
column3: they otherwise appear to live long
column4: healthy lives. And from a conservation perspective
column5: there is nothing to suggest the pattern is increasing or will ever be anything more than a rare

column1: No one seems to be studying the exact genetic and hormonal causes of this phenomenon at the moment. “I guess there are just one or a few genes altered
column2: ” says Vincent Savolainen at Imperial College London
column3: who had a student briefly work on the possible causes. “I believe some masculinised genes have been documented in domesticated cats – it would be good to look into this
column4: especially given that the cat genome is available as reference.”

column1: Could the masculinised females in fact be a boon to the pride when it comes to competing with other prides? It’s possible
column2: it seems.

column1: Gilfillan says he once saw SaF05 bring down a zebra. “A neighbouring pride stole the zebra from SaF05
column2: but in return SaF05 killed two of their cubs.”

column1: Cub-killing behaviour is rare in females but common in males.
Journal reference: African Journal of Ecology
column2: DOI: 10.1111/aje.12360"	Five wild lionesses grow a mane and start acting like males		['Karl Gruber']	['females'

column1: Response to Michael Moore's
column2: ""Open Letter to Bill Timmins
column3: President Aladdin Casino and Hotel""

column1: Me | 7-21-04 | Jayhawk5150
Posted on by Jayhawk5150
Response to Michael Moore's
column2: ""Open Letter to Bill Timmins
column3: President Aladdin Casino and Hotel""

column1: As you most likely know
column2: Michael Moore posted the following letter: After the letter
column3: you will find the response...

column1: Open Letter to Bill Timmins
column2: President Aladdin Casino and Hotel http://www.michaelmoore.com/words/index.php?id=93

column1: Bill Timmins President Aladdin Casino and Hotel Las Vegas
column2: NV

column1: July 20
Dear Mr. Timmins:
I understand from the news reports I've read that
column2: after Linda Ronstadt
column3: one of America's greatest singers
column4: dedicated a song to me from your stage on Saturday night
column5: you instructed your security guards to remove her from the Aladdin

column1: What country do you live in? Last time I checked
column2: Las Vegas is still in the United States. And in the United States
column3: we have something called ""The First Amendment."" This constitutional right gives everyone here the right to say whatever they want to say. All Americans hold this right as sacred. Many of our young people put on a uniform and risk their lives to defend it. My film is all about asking the questions that should have been asked before those brave soldiers were sent into harms way.

column1: For you to throw Linda Ronstadt off the premises because she dared to say a few words in support of me and my film
column2: is simply stupid and Un-American. Frankly
column3: I have never heard of such a thing happening. I read that you wouldn't even let her go back up to her room at your hotel! Are you crazy? For crying out loud
column4: it was a song DEDICATION! To ""Desperado!"" Every American loves that song! Sure
column5: some people didn't like the dedication
column6: and that's their right. But neither they nor you have the right to remove her from your building when all she did was exercise her AMERICAN right to speak her mind.

column1: Of all the things that go on in Las Vegas
column2: this is what creates the need for serious action? What about the other half of the crowd at the Aladdin who
column3: according to the Las Vegas Sun
column4: cheered her when she made her remarks? Did you throw them out

column1: I think you owe Ms. Ronstadt an apology. And I have an idea how you can make it up to her -- and to the millions of Americans you have offended. Invite her back and I'll join her in singing ""America the Beautiful"" on your stage. Then I will show ""Fahrenheit 9/11"" free of charge to all your guests and anyone else in Las Vegas who wants to see it.
Mr. Timmins
column2: as the song ""Desperado"" says -- ""Come to your senses!"" How can you refuse this offer? I await your reply.

column1: Yours
column2: Michael Moore Director
column3: ""Fahrenheit 9/11""

column1: July 21
Attention: Michael Moore
In response to your letter dated July 20
column2: 2004: You are correct that I had security remove Linda Ronstadt from Aladdin Casino and Hotel where the fun never ends and everybody wins. How very interesting to learn you are such a fan of Ms. Ronstadt.

column1: You questioned where I live and surprisingly knew Las Vegas is in the United States. You should visit it sometime. There are thousands of wonderful 'All You Can Eat' buffets.

There are also a lot of casinos who's owners don't **** around. I am aware of the First Amendment and you have the right to talk about your hatred of America but once you are on my property and you are upsetting my guests
column2: you will quickly learn about my rights.

column1: I can't remember if it was Jesus or George W. Bush that said
column2: ""Freedom is a two-way street."" Ms. Ronstadt learned this long before I had her thrown out of my casino. You question my actions? If you come onto my property and upset my guests
column3: you will receive the same
column5: treatment than Ms. Ronstadt received. I am sure your mere presence would upset my guests.

column1: You claim you film
column2: ""...is all about asking the questions that should have been asked before those brave soldiers were sent into harms way."" I think you film does nothing but aid the enemy and hurt our troops. You have betrayed our troops
column3: our leader and America. I have no respect for you or your vision of what America should be.

column1: I paid Ms. Ronstadt to entertain my guests
column2: not divide them. The half that did not leave probably thought the verse you mentioned
column3: ""Why don't you come to your senses"" was addressed to you. Maybe she should have dedicated her song
column4: 'You're No Good' to you. I would have asked her back

column1: Regarding your request for me to apologize to her
column2: have you and her on my stage singing anything about this Country and then playing your piece of **** film is ludicrous!

column1: One of my workers is currently throwing away every complaint letter from brainless followers of you
column2: claiming they will never visit my Casino. I could not be more pleased to know my casino and hotel will always be void of the kind of people who support you. Meanwhile
column3: my hotel has been quickly booked solid for the rest of the year with true Americans who love this Country and support our efforts overseas.

column1: They will see a framed copy of your letter and my response in the lobby to ensure they begin their experience with a laugh.
Sincerely
Bill Timmins President Aladdin Casino and Hotel Las Vegas

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/grand-theft-auto-reply/	thieves are stealing computer lists of out of office autoreplies to target homes for burglary.	false	['Criminal Intent']		David Mikkelson	['http://web.archive.org/web/20031005181402/http://www.tif.co.uk/news/PR20021204.html']	http://web.archive.org/web/20031005181402/http://www.tif.co.uk/news/PR20021204.html	http://web.archive.org/	"4 December 2002

UK office workers are today being advised to use caution when writing 'away from office' auto reply email messages because of a new email security risk first discovered at a meeting of industry group The Corporate IT Forum - tif.
tif.
column2: a blue-chip membership association representing 120 of Britain's largest organisations with over 3.6 million employees worldwide and 1.3 million desktop computers is issuing the warning after it emerged that criminals are able to discover the personal details
column3: and in some cases the home addresses
column4: of staff through cross-referencing the information contained in 'away from office' email messages.

column1: The advisory is being issued by tif. in an effort to make Britain's office workers more aware of the potential risk and to give them a few simple guidelines to follow to ensure the practice does not escalate any further.
The 'away from office' function
column2: a part of everyday life for many office workers
column3: can be set to send automatic replies from an e-mail account saying that a person is
column5: away on holiday between certain dates. The function is especially popular among businesses that need to inform clients and customers of absences and ensure that enquiries are re-directed to another member of staff.

column1: The new practice involves criminals buying lists of so-called 'spam' email addresses
column2: now readily available over the internet
column3: and sending mass mailings with the intention of gaining 'away from office' replies with details of holiday absences. Using online directories such as www.192.com or www.bt.com
column4: would-be burglars can cross-reference the information contained within the automatic email replies
column7: to find out the personal details and even the home address of the sender.

column1: tif.
column2: whose membership includes 47% of the FTSE 100 and collectively spends £20 billion each year on IT
column3: also warns that people with unusual names
column4: and especially those living in smaller towns
column5: are particularly vulnerable to this new practice as uncommon names can be tracked down more easily. Furthermore
column6: tif. members urged company bosses to think twice before revealing their status in an 'away from office' email signature. Job titles can give a would-be burglar a good idea of a possible haul and a managing director being away from home or out of the country can make a tempting target.

column1: Chief executive of tif
column2: David Roberts comments: ""You wouldn't go on holiday with a note pinned to your door saying who you were
column3: how long you were away for and when you were coming back so why would you put this in an email? Email is the most popular form of office communication but many people forget that the information contained in these messages can get into the wrong hands. There's no reason why this threat should become common practice but employees and businesses should act now to stop it - there are a few simple precautions we should all take to help nip this in the bud.""

column1: tif. has issued a series of simple recommendations for office workers to follow and for businesses to incorporate into their email policies.
tif. Recommends
Advice comes on behalf of tif.'s Information Security Group.
Do's
Keep messages as bland as possible. Say that you are currently 'unable to deal with this query' or that you are 'out of the office on business'.
Redirect enquiries to a colleague's business telephone number so someone else can assess the enquiry and verbally inform the caller of a period of absence.
If you have an important sounding job title
column2: think very carefully about whether you want to reveal your job title to a wide audience.

column1: Be very careful with giving away alternative contact details
column2: only include them if the person concerned has agreed.

column1: Always prepare for your absence and pre-warn key contacts personally of your holiday.
Don'ts"	Press release		[]	['workers'

column1: PITTSBURGH — A longtime newspaper cartoonist who says his work has been banished from the editorial page lately because of ""political differences"" with his editors says he's been fired.
Rob Rogers tweeted Thursday he's been fired after 25 years as the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette's editorial cartoonist. The paper has declined to run many of his cartoons in recent months.
Scroll through this gallery for a look at some of Rogers' cartoons the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette would not publish.
The Association of American Editorial Cartoonists recently issued a statement linking Rogers' situation to ""the recent arrival of a Trump-supporting editorial page editor.""
Keith Burris became the paper's editorial director in March. Burris did not immediately return a call and email seeking comment. A message left with publisher John Block wasn't immediately returned.
Block told The Washington Post last week the matter ""had little to do with politics"" or Trump but primarily involved the editing process.
Read more:"	Rob Rogers cartoons: What Pittsburgh Post-Gazette wouldn't publish	2018-06-15 00:00:00	['Associated Press']	['immediately'

column8: 'https://www.si.com/vault/1992/03/23/126195/scholar-lawyer-catcher-spy-moe-berg-baseballs-renaissance-man-of-the-20s-and-30s-was-a-us-atomic-spy-in-world-war-ii#']	https://www.si.com/vault/1992/03/23/126195/scholar-lawyer-catcher-spy-moe-berg-baseballs-renaissance-man-of-the-20s-and-30s-was-a-us-atomic-spy-in-world-war-ii#	https://www.si.com/	"Friendship can be the best of distractions
column9: and that is how it was when Flute met Remus in Switzerland in 1944. Flute
column11: had traveled far and met a great many people
column12: but never had he encountered the likes of Remus. There was something irresistible about this tall
column13: sturdy American whose eyebrows cut straight across his face in one thick stroke and whose wardrobe—charcoal-gray suit
column16: gray fedora—never varied no matter what the season. Languages
column19: women—if there was a subject worth talking about
column20: Remus could discuss it with acumen. Unless

column1: Riding bicycles through sun-swept Swiss villages
column2: skiing in the Alps or just strolling beside Lake Geneva
column3: Remus made Flute forget for a moment that his friends in the European scientific community were being ripped away from their research to build bombs for Adolf Hitler. And what the American taught him! The day after Christmas
column5: Flute spent hours diagramming atomic chain reactions. Then Remus took the pencil
column6: sketched a diamond and proceeded to explain the American sport of baseball. Remus had played a lot of baseball
column7: and Flute could see that he cared deeply about the game.

column1: Flute didn't keep that sketch. Remus took it and
column2: perhaps
column3: sent it off to Washington with Flute's scribbled formulas. Such was Remus's obligation
column4: and Flute understood that anything he told Remus might well end up on President Roosevelt's desk in the White House. Flute was
column6: the code name that the Office of Strategic Services (OSS)
column8: had given to Dr. Paul Scherrer
column9: director of physics at the Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich and a pioneer of atomic energy research. Remus was an OSS spy whose task was to assess Nazi Germany's progress toward building an atomic bomb. Remus's real name was Moe Berg
column10: and just three years earlier he could have been found on most any summer day seated holding his catcher's mitt in the Boston Red Sox bullpen
column11: telling stories to the relief pitchers.

column1: There was a protean quality to Moe Berg. He graduated with high honors in modern languages from Princeton in 1923 and then summered in Brooklyn
column2: playing shortstop for the Dodgers. That October
column3: he was off to Paris to study experimental phonetics at the Sorbonne. Over the next few years his time was divided between baseball and Columbia Law School in New York. He graduated and passed the New York State bar exam
column4: but instead of signing up full time with a law firm
column5: he devoted 13 more years to baseball
column6: spending most of them as a third-string catcher.

column1: His best year was 1929
column2: when his batting average (.288) and RBIs (47) were career highs. That season he caught 106 games for the Chicago White Sox and allowed only five stolen bases. Besides a strong arm
column3: Berg had fast reactions and shrewd judgment. The best White Sox pitchers
column5: always requested Berg as their batterymate. ""In the years he was to catch me
column6: I never waved off a sign

column1: When World War II began
column2: Berg was first a U.S. goodwill ambassador in Latin America and then a spy in Europe
column3: where
column5: he met Flute. They seemed an unlikely pair
column6: but perhaps they really weren't. For Moe Berg could get along with anyone
column7: if only for a time. ""Marvelous!"" he would say
column8: adjusting his fedora. ""Wonderful!"" And then one of the most extraordinary characters in baseball or any other profession would vanish.

column1: Moe was a mysterious man
column2: says Charles Owen
column3: a baseball researcher and Berg specialist. ""He'd be among friends
column5: and he was gone. People who hadn't seen him in years would be talking in a group

column1: After the war Berg received occasional CIA assignments
column2: contracts from consulting firms and scraps of legal business. None of it seemed to make him any money. ""Moe was indifferent to the practical side of things
column3: wrote his older brother
column6: a physician who died in 1990. For 25 years the sober
column7: hardworking Dr. Sam put a free roof over the head of his prodigal brother. ""He was happy that he lived the life he loved
column8: not caring about tomorrow or about where he would get the wherewithal
column11: there is much to be said for such a life.""

column1: The real business of Moe Berg's days was reading the newspaper. ""There is a majesty about the printed word. There is life to it. I consider a newspaper my friend
column2: he said
column3: according to Moe Berg: Athlete
column6: Barbara Fitzgerald and Tom Sewell. Berg took this rather literally. Every day he purchased a collection of U.S. and foreign papers—he read a dozen languages—and woe to the man who touched a paper before Berg had finished with it. Rage would cloud Berg's black eyes
column7: and he would refuse to look at the paper again.

column1: Newspapers contained information on all subjects
column2: and if you knew something about everything
column3: you could adjust to anyone. This was Berg's genius. He brought such warmth
column5: such life to people that he was beloved. Nobody ever really knew Moe Berg
column6: but dozens of people considered the times they spent with him to be some of the best of their lives. ""He was magical
column8: Institute Professor of Physics Emeritus at Cal Tech and the 1983 Nobel Prize winner in physics. ""I'd go to Physical Society meetings in New York
column9: and between sessions we'd all get together and be talking nuclear physics
column10: and I'd look up and there'd be Moe
column12: taking it all in. We always gave each other a big hug. I'd have to say
column14: that most of what I found out about Moe came from reading about him.""

column1: When Chicago Tribune sportswriter Jerome Holtzman

column1: Stones are essential for penguins to build their nests. A shortage has led to the unorthodox tactics.
Stones are the valuable currency in penguin terms
column2: said Dr Fiona Hunter
column3: a researcher in the Zoology Department at Cambridge University
column4: who has spent five years observing the birds' mating patterns.

column1: Prostitution is described as the world's oldest profession. But Dr Hunter is convinced it is the first time it has been seen in animals.
Penguin partners
All of the female penguins Dr Hunter observed trading sex for stones had partners.
Penguins stick to the same mate
column2: she said
column3: but none of the males twigged what was happening.

column1: There was no suspicion on the part of the males. Females quite often go off on their own to collect stones
column2: so as far as the males are concerned there is no reason to suspect.""

column1: She added: ""It tends to be females targeting single males
column2: otherwise the partner female would beat the intruder up.""

column1: Dr Hunter and Dr Lloyd Davis of the University of Otago watched the penguins at work on Ross Island
column2: about 800 miles from the South Pole as part of a Antarctica New Zealand programme.

column1: Tricking their prey
On some occasions the prostitute penguins trick the males. They carry out the elaborate courtship ritual
column2: which usually leads to mating.

column1: Having bagged their stone
column2: they would then run off.

column1: The courtship display is a head-bowing display
column2: Dr Hunter said. ""It usually starts with the male
column3: who bows his head and looks out the corner of his eye.""

column1: She said she does not think the female penguins are doing it just for the stones.
The female only takes one or two stones
column2: she said. ""It takes hundreds to build the nest to get their eggs off the ground.

column1: I think what they are doing is having copulation for another reason and just taking the stones as well. We don't know exactly why
column2: but they are using the males.""

column1: She said the female penguins could also be testing potential future mates
column2: in case their existing partner died before the next mating period.

column1: The single male penguins appeared to have only their own pleasure as a motive.
The action takes place during a three-week mating period starting in late October.
The most stones Dr Hunter saw a single female taking was 62
column2: although she said she suspects her final total was higher.

column1: The number of prostitute penguins is quite low

column1: It's probably only a few percent

column3: so I can't give an exact figure of how common it really is.""

column1: UPDATE: January 10
column2: 2017 – The question remains
column3: where is Eric Braverman? As I covered 11 days ago
column5: no one has been able to get in contact with the former Clinton Foundation CEO since October 22nd. That’s when Wikileaks released an email in which John Podesta named him as a possible mole within the Clinton Foundation. The mainstream media continues to ignore the story.

column1: And is he really missing? I just spoke with his father
column2: Stanley Braverman
column3: who told me
column7: ” before hanging up on me. Note how easy it would be for his dad to disprove it. Instead
column8: he just denied it and hung up.

column1: Snopes reports
column2: “New Haven
column3: New York City and Washington D.C. police have no record of a missing person with his name
column4: nor is Braverman listed on NamUs
column5: a national database of missing persons maintained by the Justice Department.”

column1: Emails from The Stream to Braverman
column2: Yale University
column3: where he teaches one course
column5: and his “husband” Neil Brown received no substantive response. The Free Thought Project had no luck getting information from the university.

column1: In Custody? Laying Low? Seeking Asylum?
Braverman had been hired by Chelsea Clinton to clean up corruption within the foundation
column2: but was forced out by longtime Clinton insiders. The right-wing blogosphere has speculated that the FBI has him in protective FBI custody to protect him from the Clintons or that he’s lying low at the Clintons’ request
column3: in order to avoid being subpoenaed to testify against the organization. Others speculate that he has sought asylum in the Russian embassy.

column1: While the rightwing blogosphere is boiling over with theories
column2: the mainstream media isn’t covering the story.

column1: While the rightwing blogosphere is boiling over with theories
column2: the mainstream media isn’t covering the story. CNN is running around the clock coverage of the congressional investigation into Russia allegedly hacking into Podesta’s emails and the DNC’s emails
column3: but has not mentioned the possibility Braverman might have leaked Podesta’s emails to Wikileaks.

column1: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange said a disgruntled Democratic insider gave him the emails
column2: not the Russians.

column1: Braverman isn’t the only one at the Clinton Foundation who Podesta thought could be a mole. In an email exchange with an ally
column2: Podesta said
column3: “could be doug or ira
column4: ” referring to Doug Bales and Ira Magaziner.

column1: Still Missing
Since my previous article came out
column2: the only mention of Braverman’s disappearance by the mainstream media has been Politico’s derisive reference to the story as fake news. At least Snopes revised their entry on the story
column3: changing the status from “fake” to “unknown
column4: ” with a link to my article.

column1: The date to watch is Thursday
column2: January 19th. That’s the Yale class Braverman teaches
column3: “Innovation in Government and Society
column4: ” begins. We’ll know whether he is missing or not depending on whether he shows up to teach. But don’t expect to see a New York Times journalist there. They’re too busy covering the congressional hearings about the claim that the Russians hacked the emails and gave them to Wikileaks.

column1: December 29
column2: 2016 – Eric Braverman
column3: the Clinton Foundation CEO from 2013 until 2015
column4: has apparently been missing since October. His absence has fueled speculations in the blogosphere but so far has been ignored by the media.

column1: Some speculate
column2: with good reason
column3: that Braverman may have gone into hiding after an email mentioning his name was released by Wikileaks on October 22 of this year. In the March 2015 email exchange
column4: Center for American Progress President Neera Tanden told Clinton campaign manager and confidant John Podesta there was a mole within the Clinton Foundation. Podesta in his reply told Tanden the mole was Braverman.

column1: Braverman had abruptly resigned from the Clinton Foundation shortly before this email exchange took place. And then
column2: after the email exchange was made public by Wikileaks
column3: Braverman vanished from the public eye.

column1: This seems like a story that someone might want to report.
The last evidence of Braverman’s public activity was October 12
column2: when he posted his last tweet on Twitter. (Usually he tweets about once a month. His “husband
column3: ” Neil Brown
column5: although he rarely tweets.) I left a voicemail on Braverman’s personal phone and sent him an email
column6: but received no response. He is still listed as a lecturer at Yale University and
column8: there is a record of his lectures going back several years. I contacted the press office and Braverman’s department at Yale and received no response.

Politico ran a long story about Braverman’s ouster in 2015. Based on email correspondence released by Wikileaks
column2: Braverman was apparently hired by Chelsea Clinton to clean up the corruption in the foundation
column3: but then forced out of the foundation by longtime Clinton loyalists; sources say Podesta made him a target.

column2: Podesta’s leaked emails show that Chelsea was aggressively calling for an internal investigation. For example
column3: former President Bill Clinton had raised over $1 billion though the foundation to rebuild 100 villages in India
column4: but only $53 million was spent on the project. Also
column5: Braverman resigned at the time Hillary was arranging one of her notorious “pay to play” deals with foreign leaders: a $12 million contribution from the king of Morocco in exchange for giving a speech.

column1: #Where’s Eric: Did Braverman Request Asylum From the Russians?
So far Braverman’s apparent disappearance has only been discussed by bloggers and fringe websites
column2: which often mix the fact that he has gone silent with other unconfirmed claims. For instance
column3: the site WhatDoesItMean.com reported that Braverman requested asylum in Russia on October 23. The information apparently came from a Russian blogger
column4: who reported it in a rambling blog post on LiveLeak.

column1: That’s pretty thin evidence. Moreover
column2: WhatDoesItMean.com is known for posting questionable news stories. The left-leaning
column3: myth-debunking site Snopes labeled the news site’s account of Braverman as false
column4: but based its judgment on the fact that website publishes false stories. Aside from this circular argument
column5: Snopes provides no independent evidence for its judgment. I contacted the Russian embassy and received no response. So at the moment
column6: the claim that Braverman requested asylum from the Russians is an unconfirmed rumor.

column1: #Where’sEric: Could Braverman be in FBI Protective Custody?
There are also rumors that Braverman is in FBI protective custody
column2: perhaps in exchange for testifying against the Clintons. Sources within the FBI have said it is likely there will be indictments handed down over the Clinton Foundation’s pay-to-play schemes. Senior FBI officials told CNN that the investigation into the Clinton Foundation had never ended and is still ongoing. According to The Daily Caller News Foundation
column3: that probe now involves as many as five FBI bureaus across the country: New York

column1: Would the FBI have hustled Braverman to safety once it was known Podesta had pegged him as a mole? This theory seems plausible
column2: given what we know. But there is still no independent evidence of it.

column1: All Questions
column2: No Answers

column1: If Braverman is in hiding to protect his life
column2: is it because he leaked the Podesta emails to Wikileaks
column3: and/or is he preparing to testify against the Clintons? The one thing we know is that Braverman has disappeared from the public eye
column8: has made a single public statement to dispel the speculations.

column1: Last year our world was immersed in crises

column1: Nevertheless

column1: The report
column2: The State of the World’s Human Rights
column3: covers 159 countries and delivers the most comprehensive analysis of the state of human rights in the world today.

column1: “The transparently hateful move by the US government in January to ban entry to people from several Muslim-majority countries set the scene for a year in which leaders took the politics of hate to its most dangerous conclusion

column1: “We saw the ultimate consequence of a society encouraged to hate

column1: “The feeble response to crimes against humanity and war crimes from Myanmar to Iraq

column1: With the report launching in Washington D.C.

column1: “Defenders of human rights around the world can look to the people of the United States to stand with them

column5: executive director of Amnesty International USA.

column3: 'https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/02/07/the-devos-vote-is-a-bad-case-study-for-the-power-of-campaign-contributions/']	https://www.opensecrets.org/news/2016/12/betsy-devos-big-giving-relatives-family-qualifies-gop-royalty/	https://www.opensecrets.org/	"It’s no secret that Betsy DeVos
column4: President-elect Donald Trump’s pick to lead the Education Department
column5: is a political fundraising juggernaut. Her contributions to candidates and school choice causes around the country have been all over the news since she was named the nominee.

column1: More consequential
column2: though
column3: are the depth and breadth of contributions by her family — by birth and by marriage — going back decades. The donations have helped make the clan a pillar of the Republican Party
column4: immensely influential in steering GOP politics and causes.

column1: Since 1989
column2: Betsy DeVos and her relatives have given at least $20.2 million to Republican candidates
column3: party committees
column5: according to an OpenSecrets.org analysis. (A tabbed spreadsheet is here.) Amway
column6: the multilevel marketing giant now known as Alticor that earned much of the family its wealth
column7: gave another nearly $3.6 million to the party prior to 2002. And that’s just at the federal level — family members have given hundreds of millions more to state and local level politics and to nonprofit groups
column8: think tanks and media outlets championing their favored conservative causes.

column1: *At the federal level since 1989
In the 2016 cycle alone
column2: the family had given at least $10 million as of late October to a host of GOP candidates and committees. Much of that — $4.4 million — went to super PACs: those supporting the White House bids of Sens. Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz as well as former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and businesswoman Carly Fiorina
column3: and the Koch brothers-backed Freedom Partners Action Fund and the super PAC started by Republican strategist Karl Rove
column4: American Crossroads; the latter two groups helped support numerous Republicans in tight House and Senate races.

column1: Betsy herself
column2: along with her husband
column3: Dick DeVos
column5: has contributed more than $7.7 million to federal candidates
column7: including almost $4.8 million to super PACs. DeVos and her husband ramped up their gifts significantly in the 2016 cycle
column8: setting a new personal record of about $2.7 million. None of that
column10: went to Trump or his supporting super PACs.

column1: Not so for her brother
column2: Erik Prince
column3: co-founder of controversial private security contractor Blackwater (now known as Academi). He made two donations to Make America Number 1
column4: a super PAC that backed Cruz and then Trump; Prince’s $150
column5: 000 in gifts came after Trump had become the Republican party nominee. Since 1990
column6: he and his ex-wives have given $519

column1: Betsy DeVos voiced her thoughts about her family’s abundant political giving in a 1997 piece in Roll Call
column2: in which she wrote that she had decided “to stop taking offense at the suggestion that we are buying influence. Now I simply concede the point. They are right. We do expect some things in return. We expect to foster a conservative governing philosophy consisting of limited government and respect for traditional American values.”

column1: The definition of “traditional American values” is in the eye of the beholder
column2: of course.

column1: It was Dick Jr.’s father
column2: 90-year-old Richard “Rich” DeVos
column3: Sr.
column4: who first established the family as a force in conservative fundraising. The elder DeVos
column6: which his sons have helped lead in various capacities
column7: and owns the NBA’s Orlando Magic
column8: has an estimated worth of $5.1 billion
column9: according to Forbes. He’s a past president of the Council for National Policy
column10: a secretive network of conservative leaders of which he was an early funder.

column1: *At the federal level since 1989
This cycle
column2: he and his wife
column3: Helen
column4: also contributed their highest-ever cash totals
column5: donating almost $2.9 million – the first election cycle they have crested $1 million since 1998. Overall
column6: the elder DeVoses have given nearly $6.8 million in federal elections since 1990.

column1: These are big numbers
column2: relatively speaking. On the Center for Responsive Politics’ list of top individual donors for 2016
column3: Rich and Helen DeVos came in at No. 61 and Dick and Betsy DeVos at No. 65. Family members also made the list in previous election cycles – Dick and Betsy were 53rd in 2014. The Richard DeVos family ranked 54th in 2010.

column1: More broadly
column2: Amway’s employees and PAC combined also rank highly among organizational donors: They placed 19th in 2004 and fourth in the nation in 1994.

column1: A web of nonprofits
Help us keep government accountable by making a donation today.

Savvy political players like the DeVoses don’t engage only in direct electoral action. Through organized giving by its various foundations and strategic involvement in the institutions that receive their money
column2: the DeVos family has leveraged extensive influence in nonprofit networks structured around their pet causes.

column1: Most DeVos giving in this sphere is done through five foundations: the Richard and Helen DeVos Foundation; the Dick and Betsy DeVos Foundation; the Daniel and Pamella DeVos Foundation; Cheri DeVos’ CDV5 Foundation; and the Douglas and Maria DeVos Foundation. (Daniel
column2: Cheri and Douglas DeVos are all siblings of Dick Jr.
column3: Betsy’s husband.) According to one analysis of foundation tax records
column4: the DeVos family donated more than $90 million in 2013 altogether and around $94 million in 2014 — with nearly half going to groups involved in education.

column1: The DeVos family’s philanthropic efforts have a more social conservative bent than those of
column2: say
column3: the Koch brothers; for years the DeVoses have provided generous grants to religious-based organizations and — in particular — religious schools. Still
column4: they have found common ground with the Kochs on a number of issues. Regular attendees at Koch network biannual donor meetings
column5: the DeVoses have provided substantial support to the Koch-seeded charitable arm of their Americans for Prosperity
column6: a very active dark money group; the FreedomWorks Foundation
column7: which is connected to another dark money outfit that originated with one started by the Kochs; and the Mercatus Institute
column8: a “market-focused” research center at George Mason University that has received funding from the Kochs since the 1980s.

column1: And the family has actively fought to sweep away restrictions on money in politics with substantial contributions to nonprofits that litigate against such limits. Those include the Center for Competitive Politics and the James Madison Center for Free Speech
column2: a nonprofit set up by Citizens United attorney James Bopp and Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) that consistently funnels nearly the entirety of its funds to Bopp’s firm each year. Bopp has taken a broadsword to campaign finance restrictions nationwide
column3: mounting legal challenges to them at the federal

column1: Betsy DeVos may have married into the DeVos dynasty
column2: but her own family has its own strong ties to the conservative movement. Her father
column3: Edgar Prince
column4: helped Gary Bauer create the Family Research Council
column5: an influential conservative group. And along with her siblings
column6: Betsy sits on the board of the Edgar & Elsa Prince Foundation
column7: a major donor to groups that include the Education Freedom Fund
column8: the Heritage Foundation and the Alliance Defense Fund.

column1: Trump’s pick holds strategic advisory positions with a number of nonprofit organizations that lobby to varying degrees on education issues
column2: including Jeb Bush’s Foundation for Excellence in Education. But her baby is the American Federation for Children a 501(c)(4) “dark money” group that promotes school voucher programs and charter schools across the country. AFC has significantly increased its efforts in recent years: It told the IRS that it made just $250
column3: 000 in political expenditures in 2009
column4: a figure that increased to over $1 million by 2010 and nearly $1.7 million by 2011. In 2014
column5: the number dropped a bit to just over $1 million.

column1: But that year
column2: AFC and its affiliated organizations boasted spending $4.5 million between the primary and general elections on 242 races in nine states — without ever disclosing its donors. It reported that pro-school choice candidates — mainly governors
column3: state legislators and other non-federal politicians — won in 92 percent of the general election races it targeted
column5: with Betsy DeVos as its chair
column6: as a powerhouse in the movement.

column1: And AFC’s efforts go far beyond direct involvement in political contests. Among other activities
column2: it has funneled money into other “dark money” groups that support contenders for state supreme court seats deemed likely to be friendly to policies advocated by AFC that could be legally challenged.

column1: The Education nominee also heads All Children Matter
column2: a political committee that lobbies for school choice. Started with seed money from DeVos’ Advocates for School Choice
column3: the predecessor to AFC
column4: All Children Matter has been funded by millions from the DeVos family over the years
column5: but has also received substantial sums from the Walton family (of Walmart fame) and other high profile conservative donors. Though DeVos was not personally named in the case
column6: All Children Matter has millions in outstanding fines for election law violations dating back to 2008 — a record amount that is nearly a decade past due. Betsy DeVos led the group at the time of the violations — in fact
column7: she is the only person who has been listed on All Children Matter’s leadership page since 2006.

column1: Supporting the bench
Megadonors tend not to focus their contributions only on those in the majors; they direct some of their investments to minor leaguers
column2: too
column3: as well as those who might have a more direct local impact on their concerns. The Grand Rapids
column4: Mich.- based DeVoses are no exception
column5: giving extensively in state and local elections. They’ve contributed
column7: a combined $9.5 million to the Michigan Republican Party in the last 20 years.

column1: According to National Institute on Money in State Politics data
column2: Betsy DeVos has given over $1.9 million in state and local elections since 1996
column3: a total that pales in comparison to her husband Dick’s $40.2 million. To be fair
column4: the lion’s share of that sum was the nearly $35.4 million that he gave to his own 2006 gubernatorial campaign.

column1: In that contest
column2: DeVos family members (including the candidate) accounted for three of his top four donors. But DeVos
column3: who was challenging Democratic incumbent Jennifer Granholm
column4: fell short in the general election by a 56-to-42 percent margin.

column1: Overall
column2: Dick DeVos’s siblings have cut large checks at the state and local levels. Doug DeVos
column3: the current president of Amway
column4: has donated almost $2.8 million in these elections with his wife
column6: according to the National Institute on Money in State Politics. Dan
column7: a sports executive and the current chairman of the Orlando Magic
column8: has contributed a little less than $2.4 million with his wife
column12: has given more than $1.25 million to state and local political causes.

column1: State-level advocacy organizations have also drawn significant DeVos largesse. For example
column2: eight DeVos family members together gave an even $2 million to Protecting Michigan Taxpayers
column3: a group that sought (unsuccessfully) in 2015 to repeal Michigan’s prevailing wage law
column4: which ensures state construction contractors pay union wages to their workers.

column1: But if the family has adopted a second state
column2: it’s Florida. DeVos ownership of the Magic dates back to 1991
column3: and family members have donated to a number of Florida politicians and advocacy organizations. In 2008
column4: when the group Florida4Marriage sponsored an amendment to the state constitution that would limit the definition of marriage to a heterosexual union
column7: making him the second-highest donor to the effort. The measure passed — but it was later struck down by the Supreme Court’s 2015 decision in Obergefell v. Hodges.

column4: 'http://history.house.gov/People/Detail/21764']	http://history.house.gov/People/Detail/21764	http://history.house.gov/	"An escaped slave and a Civil War hero
column5: Robert Smalls served five terms in the U.S. House
column6: representing a South Carolina district described as a “black paradise” because of its abundant political opportunities for freedmen.1 Overcoming the state Democratic Party’s repeated attempts to remove that “blemish” from its goal of white supremacy
column7: Smalls endured violent elections and a short jail term to achieve internal improvements for coastal South Carolina and to fight for his black constituents in the face of growing disfranchisement. “My race needs no special defense
column8: for the past history of them in this country proves them to be equal of any people anywhere
column9: ” Smalls asserted. “All they need is an equal chance in the battle of life.”2

column1: Robert Smalls was born a slave on April 5
column3: in Beaufort
column6: was a slave who worked as a nanny
column7: and the identity of Robert Smalls’s father is not known
column8: but Smalls had distinct mulatto features.3 Owned by John McKee
column9: he worked in his master’s house throughout his youth and
column11: moved to the McKees’ Charleston home. Smalls was hired out on the waterfront as a lamplighter
column16: and became an expert navigator of the South Carolina and Georgia coasts. In 1856
column18: a slave who worked as a hotel maid in Charleston. The couple had two daughters: Elizabeth and Sarah. A third child
column21: died of smallpox as a toddler.4 The Smalls lived separately from their owners
column22: but sent their masters most of their income.5

column1: During the Civil War
column2: the Confederate Army conscripted Robert Smalls into service aboard the Planter
column3: an ammunitions transport ship that had once been a cotton steamer. On May 13
column5: a black crew captained by Smalls hijacked the well–stocked ship and turned it over to the Union Navy. Smalls became a northern celebrity.6 His escape was symbolic of the Union cause
column6: and the publication of his name and former enslaved status in northern propaganda proved demoralizing for the South.7 Smalls spent the remainder of the war balancing his role as a spokesperson for African Americans with his service in the Union Armed Forces. Piloting both the Planter
column7: which was re–outfitted as a troop transport
column9: Smalls used his intimate knowledge of the South Carolina Sea Islands to advance the Union military campaign in nearly 17 engagements.8

column1: Smalls’s public career began during the war. He joined free black delegates to the 1864 Republican National Convention
column2: the first of seven total conventions he attended as a delegate.9 While awaiting repairs to the Planter
column3: Smalls was removed from an all–white streetcar in Philadelphia on December 30
column5: his celebrity allowed him to lead one of the first mass boycotts of segregated public transportation. A city law finally permitted integrated streetcars in 1867.10

column1: At the war’s conclusion
column2: Smalls received a commission as brigadier general of the South Carolina militia. He then purchased his former owner’s house in Beaufort
column3: but he was generous to the economically devastated McKees.11 Having received a rudimentary education from private tutors in Philadelphia during the war
column4: Smalls continued his studies after settling in Beaufort.12 He embarked on business ventures
column5: opening a store and a school for black children in 1867. He also published a newspaper
column7: starting in 1872.13 Smalls’s impressive résumé and his ability to speak the Sea Island Gullah dialect enhanced his local popularity and opened doors in South Carolina politics. He joined other prominent black and white politicians as a delegate to the 1868 South Carolina constitutional convention. Later that year
column8: Smalls won his first elective office: a term in the state house of representatives. From 1870 to 1874
column9: he served in the state senate

column2: redistricting gave Smalls the opportunity to run for the U.S. Congress in a southeast South Carolina district with a majority–black constituency (68 percent of the population). In Smalls’s hometown of Beaufort
column3: African Americans outnumbered whites seven to one.14 In an uneventful campaign
column4: Smalls defeated Independent nominee J. P. M. Epping—a white man who ran on a “reform” platform opposing the Radical Republican state government—with nearly 80 percent of the vote. Smalls received a position on the Agriculture Committee in his freshman term
column5: a key assignment for his farming constituency and thus a boost to his efforts to prepare for the potentially formidable opposition to his re–election.

column1: Despite the Democratic majority
column2: Smalls’s first term was one of his most active and fruitful. For his coastal constituents
column3: he obtained appropriations to improve the Port Royal Harbor that passed with little debate
column4: owing to a letter from the Secretary of War presented as evidence.15 Smalls also sought other internal improvements
column5: including compensation from the federal government for its use of Charleston’s military academy

column1: Smalls spoke openly in defense of his race and his party. In June 1876
column2: he attempted unsuccessfully to add an antidiscrimination amendment to an army reorganization bill. His amendment
column3: which would have integrated army regiments
column4: required that race would no longer affect soldiers’ placement. The following month
column5: Smalls addressed a bill to redeploy federal troops in the South to patrol the Texas–Mexican border. Smalls argued against transferring federal troops stationed in his home state
column6: warning that private Red Shirt militias—South Carolina’s version of the Ku Klux Klan—would make war on the government and freedmen. Advocates of the troop transfer argued that the corrupt Republican government in South Carolina brought on the violence and that it remained a state issue. Smalls disagreed
column7: noting that the federal presence would help “cut off that rotten part all round South Carolina so as to let the core stand. It is those rotten parts which are troubling us. We are getting along all right ourselves.”17

column1: While touring the state with Republican Governor Daniel Chamberlain during the 1876 campaign

column3: South Carolina
column4: where Red Shirt leader and former Confederate General Matthew Butler overran the meeting and threatened Smalls’s life. Though the Republican entourage escaped unharmed

column6: but in South Carolina they are called ‘reformers.’” Smalls’s opponent
column8: who hailed from a prominent Democratic family

column2: hounded down

column4: which Tillman—who returned as his opponent—used to defeat him. Though Smalls received a majority of the black votes in the district

column2: Democratic Governor William Simpson pardoned him on April 29
column3: 1879—acting on assurances from the U.S. District Attorney that charges would be dropped against South Carolinians accused of violating election laws in 1878.26 Smalls
column5: remained optimistic about Republican politics in South Carolina. “Robert S. is very cheerful
column6: and says that the outrageous bulldozing and cheating in this last election is the best thing that could have happened for the Republican Party
column8: “for it has been so barefaced and open that it cannot be denied.”27 Smalls still controlled the Beaufort Republican Party
column9: and he remained popular among the town’s substantial black population. By 1880
column10: Smalls resolved to take back his seat from Tillman. However
column11: his allegiance to the Republican Party made it increasingly difficult for Smalls to rally black voters to his side. Issues that wedded black voters to the GOP—primarily fears of returning to slavery—were fading in light of black disenchantment with local Republican corruption scandals. The state party also was in chaos
column12: as the South Carolina Republican convention was unable to nominate a state ticket. Smalls’s attachment to the disorganized and disgraced state party proved to be the strongest point of attack for Democratic opponents. Red Shirt intimidation
column13: which had become routine in recent elections

column1: Smalls failed to defeat Tillman in a violent campaign
column2: garnering only 15
column3: 287 votes
column6: hoping to capitalize on the slim Republican majority in the 47th Congress (1881–1883). His case came before the Committee on Elections on July 18

column15: 141 to 1 with 144 abstentions.30 Smalls returned to his appointments on the Agriculture and Militia committees. While his victory was yet another blow to southern Democrats
column16: the curtailed term again left him little time to legislate.

column2: South Carolina Democrats had gerry–mandered the state so that only one district retained any hope of electing a black candidate. The new district’s lines demonstrated the legislature’s intent; completely ignoring county lines
column3: the district contained one–quarter of the state’s substantial black population (82 percent of the district’s population was black).31 Smalls sought the nomination but was opposed at the Republican convention by longtime black politician Samuel Lee and Smalls’s congressional friend and ally Representative Edmund Mackey. Smalls deferred to Mackey—a sympathetic white man whose wife was mulatto—to maintain unity in the party. However

He offered an amendment that would guarantee the integration of restaurants and other eating facilities in the nation’s capital. After parliamentary debate about the germaneness of the amendment

column6: Smalls’s victory over Democrat William Elliott was unexpectedly easy. Though both candidates expected a violent campaign

column9: made up of a safe Democratic majority. Encouraged by his recent victory

column1: In his first full term since he was a freshman

Smalls also steered through the House a bill that allowed for the redemption of school farmlands outside Beaufort that had been owned by the federal government since the Civil War.37 He also submitted a resolution requesting relief funds after a flood in 1886 destroyed crops and homes in his district. The House refused to appropriate funds
column11: despite Smalls’s appeal that the state government would not furnish relief money until late in the year. Smalls also failed in a bid to make Port Royal a coaling station for the U.S. Navy.38

column1: Smalls faced a challenge from within his own party for re–election in 1886. African–American rival Henry Thompson attempted to capitalize on the growing competition within the black community between dark–skinned blacks and mulattos. Thompson’s radical position proved less of a threat for the nomination; however

column7: returned to defeat him with 56 percent of the vote in an election in which black disfranchisement was routine.41 Smalls contested his loss. column8: a House weary of handling the South’s racial problems declined to seat Smalls
column9: with a vote of 142 to 127 on February 13
column10: 1889.42 Accepting the inevitability of his loss

column10: before Annie’s death in 1895.Smalls benefited throughout this period from GOP patronage. In 1889
column11: Republican President Benjamin Harrison appointed him the collector at the port of Beaufort. He held the post until Republicans lost the White House in 1892. Smalls regained the appointment in 1898 from Republican President William McKinley. Over time
column12: his duties as collector became more onerous in the face of racism and segregation in Beaufort. He was forced to step down in 1913 after the White House again transferred to a Democrat. Smalls died of natural causes in his Beaufort home on February 22
