column1: SCHOLASTIC APTITUDE TEST (SAT)

INTRODUCTION The Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) is dreaded by high school juniors and seniors because a single SAT urday morning can ruin the rest of their lives! This article describes my system for getting extraordinary raw scores on this challenging test. Rather than fight the test
column2: I use the SAT's difficulty to my advantage
column3: leveraging down to a new
column4: elite level of distinction: Answering all questions incorrectly ! On 2003 April 5th
column12: that humans can do things ""The System"" didn't anticipate. Things didn't turn out exactly as planned
column13: but it was a crazy experience!

column1: TABLE OF CONTENTS [ 1] Introduction [ 2] Table of Contents [ 3] The Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) [ 4] Calculating the Test Score [ 5] Registering for the Test [ 6] Test Preparation [ 7] Test Day! [ 8] My Test-Taking Experience [ 9] My Test Scores [10] Conclusion [11] Disclaimer [12] Reader Feedback [13] Contact Information
THE SCHOLASTIC APTITUDE TEST (SAT) The Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) is a test of mathematical and verbal intelligence. This test was created by the College Entrance Examination Board (CEEB)
column2: and was administered for the first time in June 1926 to 8
column3: 040 people. In the 2000-2001 test year
column4: more than 2.1 million people took the ""SAT I: Reasoning Test"" as part of the admission process for more than 1
column6: 80 percent of the national (U.S.) total. All references to ""SAT"" in this article refer to the ""SAT I: Reasoning Test"". What does the SAT stand for? (From College Board literature) ""Originally
column7: SAT was an acronym for the Scholastic Aptitude Test. In 1993
column8: the test was renamed the SAT I: Reasoning Test. At the same time
column9: the former Achievement Tests were renamed the SAT II: Subject Tests. SAT has become a simple way of referring to the SAT I: Reasoning Test.""

column1: The College Board has a page describing the fascinating history of the SAT: http://www.collegeboard.com/about/newsat/history.html The SAT is given seven times a year at thousands of testing centers throughout the world. Unless there are special circumstances
column2: the test is given on a Saturday
column3: starting at approximately 9:00 A.M. in each time zone. Cheating on the SAT! In the United States there is a three-hour time zone difference between the East Coast and the West Coast. At one time this created a SAT cheating opportunity: Professional test-takers on the East Coast would steal or memorize test materials
column4: and relay this information to student test-takers on the West Coast. One business apparently flew students to the West Coast to take advantage of this possibility. These days
column5: with Infra-Red ports on calculators and wristwatches
column6: hands-free earpieces and digital video on mobile phones
column7: cheap wireless cameras that can be planted anywhere in a room or on a person
column8: I'm sure there must be someone out there who had a whole support team helping him through the test! Wouldn't it be hilarious to have an Internet chat room or instant messaging group helping one through the SAT! The transcript would be damaging evidence
column9: though. Undoubtedly other people have simply exited the test room with the test booklet and answer sheet
column10: worked on the test with a group of smart friends and a dictionary
column12: perhaps with some sort of distraction. It would be ironic for cheaters to get admitted to Harvard and one day learn the school motto: ""Veritas"" (Truth).

column1: The testing part of the SAT lasts a total of exactly three hours. There are seven timed sections: (1) 30-minute Verbal (2) 30-minute Verbal (3) 30-minute Math (4) 30-minute Math (5) 30-minute Equating Section (Verbal or Math) (6) 15-minute Verbal (7) 15-minute Math
The 30-minute sections can appear in any order. Test proctors need to indicate when to start and stop for all sections
column2: so it is necessary for all test-takers in a testing room to encounter each of the two 15-minute sections at the same time. For my test group
column3: both 15-minute sections occurred in the final 30 minutes of the three-hour testing period. The following table describes various properties of the sections: Verbal Sections: ================ * 75 minutes total (30 min + 30 min + 15 min) * 78 questions total: 40 Critical Reading (5-choice) 19 Analogies (5-choice) 19 Sentence Completion (5-choice) Math Sections: ============== * 75 minutes total (30 min + 30 min + 15 min) * 60 questions total: 35 Standard (5-choice) 15 Quantitative Comparisons (4-choice) 10 Student-produced responses (NO-choice) Or
column4: by question type: 44 Arithmetic and Algebraic Reasoning 14 Geometric Reasoning Equating Section: ================= * 30 minutes total * Used to test new questions
column5: and compare editions of the exam * Does NOT count toward final score * Is NOT explicitly identified to test-takers
column6: and looks exactly like an ordinary Verbal or Math section; thus
column7: taken with the same seriousness as ""real"" sections

column1: CALCULATING THE TEST SCORE Two Divisions: Math and Verbal The SAT has two divisions: Math and Verbal. A score report has performance statistics for the math division
column2: and performance statistics for the verbal division. Three Statistics for each Division Performance on each division of the SAT is described by three statistics: (1) Raw Score; (2) Scaled Score; (3) Relative Percentage;

column1: Almost all statements regarding ""SAT Score"" are implicitly referring to the Scaled Score. (1) Raw Score Raw Score is an integer (whole number) that is calculated for each division of the test. Applying the following rules to the set of answers for a division of a test will yield a number (potentially non-integer) that will be the basis of the Raw Score: (a) Ignore each blank answer (often called an ""omitted question""); (b) Ignore each incorrect answer for math questions requiring ""student-produced"" (non-multiple-choice) responses; (c) Add one point for each correct answer; (d) Subtract 1/4-point for each incorrect answer for multiple-choice questions having 5 choices; (e) Subtract 1/3-point for each incorrect answer for multiple-choice questions having 4 choices;

The Raw Score is the number computed directly above rounded to the ""nearest integer"". Mathematical Detour: All Possible Fractional Values The calculation of the integer Raw Score involves rounding a potentially non-integer value to the ""nearest integer"". It so happens there are twelve (12) cases of the fractional part: FRACTIONAL PART EXAMPLE ROUNDING =================== =============== ============ 0/12 = 0.0 (0-(0/4)-(0/3)) None 1/12 = 0.083333... (1-(1/4)-(2/3)) Down 2/12 = 0.166666... (1-(2/4)-(1/3)) Down 3/12 = 0.25 (1-(3/4)-(0/3)) Down 4/12 = 0.333333... (1-(0/4)-(2/3)) Down 5/12 = 0.416666... (1-(1/4)-(1/3)) Down 6/12 = 0.5 (1-(2/4)-(0/3)) Up <-- Look! 7/12 = 0.583333... (2-(3/4)-(2/3)) Up 8/12 = 0.666666... (1-(0/4)-(1/3)) Up 9/12 = 0.75 (1-(1/4)-(0/3)) Up 10/12 = 0.833333... (2-(2/4)-(2/3)) Up 11/12 = 0.916666... (2-(3/4)-(1/3)) Up If J is an integer
column2: (J + 0.5) is equidistant from two integers: J and (J+1). Obviously the CEEB needs to specify what to do in this special case -- and it must be deterministic (so random rounding and alternate rounding cannot be used). One candidate convention
column3: called ""Banker's Rounding""
column4: rounds to the nearest EVEN number (e.g.
column5: 0.5 --> 0; 1.5 --> 2; -11.5 --> -12). Another convention is to round to the nearest integer
column6: and round UPWARD for the ambiguous case of (J + 0.5). (e.g.
column7: 0.5 --> 1; 1.5 --> 2; -11.5 --> -11) This is what the ""FIX"" function does for 0.5 on scientific calculators ({2nd
column11: =} --> 1). This is the convention used by the CEEB
column12: as described by this quote: ""If the resulting [raw] score is a fraction
column13: it is rounded to the nearest whole number -- 1/2 or more is rounded up; less than 1/2 is rounded down."" Keep in mind that rounding up for 1/2 is not the definition of ""nearest whole number""; this quote is merely describing the convention used by the CEEB.

column1: Verbal Division Raw Score Range The Verbal Division has three question categories: ======================================================================= Question Type Questions Min Raw Score Max Raw Score ======================================================================= Critical Reading : 40 : -40/4 = -10 --> -10 : +40 Analogies : 19 : -19/4 = -4.75 --> -5 : +19 Sentence Completion : 19 : -19/4 = -4.75 --> -5 : +19 ======================================================================= (NOTE: All questions are five-choice types.) These three raw scores are reported on the printed score report. Note that (-10-5-5) = -20
column2: whereas (-78/4) = -19.5 --> -19. Which method is used to compute the raw score for the verbal division? Who knows! But it could make a significant difference in scaled score. Math Division Raw Score Range The Math Division has two question types: ======================================================================= Question Type Questions Min Raw Score Max Raw Score ======================================================================= Arithmetic and Algebraic Reasoning : 44 : -10 : +44 Geometric Reasoning : 14 : < -1 : +14 ======================================================================= These two raw scores are reported on the printed score report. I am not sure how the 35 five-choice
column3: 15 four-choice
column4: and 10 student-response questions are distributed between these two categories
column5: so I cannot show the calculations. Again
column6: I am not sure if these two raw score values are added to yield an overall division raw score
column7: or if all questions for the entire math division are considered together as in (0-35*(1/4)-15*(1/3)-10*0) = -13.75 --> -14 for computing the scaled score. (2) Scaled Score The Scaled Score is intended to be a measurement of ability on an absolute scale. In principle
column8: the Scaled Score enables the objective comparison of test-taker abilities throughout the history and future of the SAT
column9: regardless of variations in the difficulty of each edition of the test. A Raw Score is converted to a Scaled Score through a statistical process called ""equating"". Equating may involve correlating performances between different questions
column10: and to the same questions or similar questions on past editions of the SAT. If the equating process works
column11: and Scaled Scores are an absolute measure of ability
column12: then Scaled Scores for a particular edition of the SAT do not depend on the relative performances of test-takers for that edition. The Scaled Score is a multiple of 10 in the range 200 to 800. FIGURE: An example conversion of Raw Score to Scaled Score (based on example data published by the College Board). According to these example curves

The percentages are based on: ""the most recent scores earned by current-year college-bound seniors who took the test at any time during high school."" Relative Percentages are given for the nation and state. Relative Percentage (Number Of Test-Takers with a Lower Score) Fraction = ------------------------------------------ (Total Number of Test-Takers) Relative Percentage = Max( 1

column2: the combined score is a multiple of 10 in the range 400 to 1600. If a person fills out an SAT answer sheet with all required personal and site- specific information

column1: Standard Scores Since the SAT was first administered in 1926
column2: there have been over 20 different sets of scales used to convert raw scores in to scaled scores
column3: all in an effort to better describe the abilities of people who take the test. The most dramatic change in score calculation for the SAT in recent decades is described by the following quote from the College Board: ""In April 1995
column4: the College Board recentered the score scales for all tests in the SAT Program to reflect the contemporary test-taking population. Recentering reestablished the average score for a study group of 1990 seniors at about 500 -- the midpoint of the 200-to-800 scale -- allowing students
column6: and colleges to more easily interpret their scores in relation to those of a similar group of college-bound seniors."" One effect of recentering is that scores are apparently ""inflated"" relative to scores before 1995. For example
column7: what would have been a 1490 cumulative (V+M) score before 1995 is now called a 1600
column8: the maximum possible score. Put another way
column9: a score of 1600 today could correspond to a score as low as 1490 for scales prior to 1995. All scores
column11: are inflated relative to historical counterparts. The following page has a table that shows the effect of recentering on cumulative (V+M) scores: http://www.collegeboard.com/sat/cbsenior/equiv/rt027027.html The following is a fascinating research paper published by the College Board on the theory and motivation for the recentering process: sat_recentering.pdf [380 KB] If you read the research paper mentioned above
column12: one gets a sense of the difficulties faced by the College Board in establishing a standard. One can find scandal in the paper if one is looking for it
column13: and it is easy to see how this complicated problem and associated solution could be regarded as more of an art than a science. High Intelligence Quotient (IQ) Organizations Many high-intelligence organizations believe that there is enough correlation between pre-1995 SAT scores and IQ to use those scores alone as a qualification standard for membership. For example
column14: an SAT combined score of 1250 (1974-1994 SAT editions) correlates with a Stanford-Binet IQ of 132

column22: as described in the previous section. Because of score inflation
column23: and total lack of ability to differentiate performance beyond a moderately high level
column24: SAT scores could no longer be correlated to IQ with sufficient range or precision to serve as a basis for admission to high-intelligence organizations.

column1: REGISTERING FOR THE TEST The SAT is given seven times each year. Although you must register (enroll) with the College Board before a specific deadline to be assured the opportunity to take the SAT on a specific date
column2: there is a chance that you will be able to simply show up at a designated test center on the morning of a test and sign up to take the SAT. There is no guarantee that the site will have spare test booklets and answer sheets
column3: so it's a bit of a gamble. Here are several fees that may interest a person planning to take the SAT I: (1) ""SAT I: Reasoning Test"" : $26 ============================== This is payment for the test. Included in this price is the option to have up to four official score reports mailed to college and university admission programs of one's choice. (There is a charge for each additional score report if more than four are requested. Score reports are only official if mailed directly from the College Board.) (2) ""Student Answer Service"" : $ 6 ============================== This is an optional report that shows you an enumerated list of questions
column4: and whether your response was: correct (+)
column6: or omitted (O). Maybe this product exists to address possible paranoia about the Raw Score calculation. (3) Detailed Answer Report : $15 ============================== This product is only offered on certain test dates. This report shows the actual questions on the exam
column9: and an analysis of your apparent strengths and weaknesses
column12: could be used as a basis for deciding how to prepare for taking the test again.

TEST PREPARATION The beauty of my special test-taking system is that it requires significantly less preparation than other test-taking systems. Perhaps the best way to learn how to fail is to learn how to succeed. The College Board offers a handy manual to the SAT I: www_college_board_taking_sat.pdf [538 KB] However
column2: I have discovered that failure favors the unprepared mind
column3: and so I did not read this manual before taking the test.

column1: MY TEST-TAKING EXPERIENCE This section describes some of my impressions of this test-taking experience. The Math Sections were Easy for Me I thought I solved all math problems correctly on paper (pages of test booklet). (It turns out I may have made a mistake on one problem. See conclusion.) After solving each math problem
column2: and noting that the solution corresponded to an existing option
column3: I selected the MOST ABSURD alternative answer. Since this test date did not offer a detailed question and answer reporting option
column4: I cannot share this extra humorous touch with the public. For the ""student-produced"" responses
column5: which cannot subtract points from the raw score
column6: I simply wrote a sequence of numbers that encodes my name: C O L I N P F --> 3
column12: 6; I think this will show up in my ""Student Answer Service"" report. (2003 May 26th: I received my ""Student Answer Service"" report
column13: and I learned that one of my ""random"" answers turned out to be a correct answer! Note to self: I'm an idiot!) Sometimes
column15: I felt a little pang of regret that my mission prevented me from proving that I actually knew the correct answers. The Calculator was Handy For several math problems the calculator came in handy. Sometimes it seemed easier to simply add up a bunch of numbers rather than work out a formula that would yield the answer. The Verbal Sections were Difficult for Me The verbal division of the SAT is dominated by ""Critical Reading"" subsections. Each Critical Reading subsection has several sets of Critical Reading questions. Each set of questions begins with a passage having several paragraphs
column16: followed by questions that refer to the passage. Many questions refer to specific lines of the passage using line numbers. The passages are extracted from existing literary sources
column21: and journals. The passages are not manufactured by the College Board researchers. The topics of the passages are very diverse; essentially random. The College Board points out that the opinions expressed in the passages do not reflect the opinions of the College Board. In principle
column22: presenting a test-taker with various types of written material (scientific
column26: etc) seems like an ideal way to gauge how the test-taker might perform in an environment that involves exposure to the same degree of literary diversity. My gripe with the ""Critical Reading"" questions is with the questions themselves. It is my opinion that the questions
column28: involve subjective factors and implicit assumptions that often make them impossible to answer in a rational manner. It is possible that people with the same subjective influences and implicit assumptions do well in college
column29: because college faculty belong to the same dominant species of irrationality. So
column30: the value of the verbal section of the SAT as a predictor of performance in college might be quite high. However
column31: the side-effect of optimizing a test to better predict success in college is that truly objective minds might be punished for not keeping up with the latest delusions. The following questions are typical of the types of questions found in the Critical Reading subsections: ""Which of the following would be the most appropriate title for this passage?"" ""The author of this passage would likely agree with which of the following statements:"" ""Which of the following best describes the author's opinion about XXXX ?"" ""According to the passage
column32: the American Indian notion of time involves which of the following concepts:"" ""The author of Passsage #1 would most likely have which of the following opinions regarding statements made by the author of Passage #2:""

column1: While trying to figure out the answers to Critical Reading questions I am convinced that I fully understand the passages
column2: the questions
column3: and the meanings of all multiple-choice options
column4: and yet there are times when there doesn't seem to be a basis for selecting an answer. Maybe I should take the SAT on a date when the detailed ""Question and Answer"" service is offered. Then I could debate concrete examples with people and decide if there really is a kind of verbal intelligence that helps people answer these questions in a consistent and rational manner. Or maybe I will comprehend the principles of this variety of intelligence and decide that I am better off without it! Thankfully
column5: my test-taking strategy involves choosing the wrong answers
column6: which made some of the trickier verbal questions much easier. Sometimes the best answer was hard to identify
column7: but the absurd answers were very easy to spot. In 2005
column8: multiple-choice questions will require students to identify sentence errors
column10: and improve paragraphs. I'm glad my future doesn't depend on someone's ""improvement"" aesthetic! A 25-minute written essay section will also be added to the SAT
column11: which means that the arbitrary forces of subjectivity on the overall verbal score may be taken to an entirely new level. It is very difficult for me to imagine grading criteria for these essays that would transcend personal opinions about writing style. I've heard of cases in which a single essay earned radically different grades from different college professors -- and sometimes radically different grades from the SAME college professor
column12: who unwittingly grades the same essay twice at different times. Three Hours of Test-Taking is Exhausting The SAT requires sitting at a desk for exactly three hours of actual problem solving
column13: filling in up to approximately 165 bubbles with a #2 pencil. When one adds in the time spent writing down personal information
column16: the whole experience lasts about 3.5 hours. Something about the need to not screw up over a prolonged period like this is really fatiguing. I was grateful for my inspiration to bring a cold bottle of Pepsi and a bottle of orange juice. Still
column17: near the end of the exam I wished I had a third drink
column18: and maybe a chocolate chip cookie! [Make mental note
column19: in case there's a ""next time""! :-O] To answer all math questions
column20: you have an average of 75.0 seconds per question to read
column22: and completely fill in the answer bubble. For the verbal sections the pace is a little bit faster
column23: at 57.7 seconds per question. This seems generous
column24: but to me it felt like I was racing the clock for all sections of the test
column25: finishing each section with very little time to spare. So
column26: the pace of the test kept me feeling a little bit harassed. As the test wore on
column27: I became increasingly distracted by the thought of how tedious it was to repeatedly locate bubbles and fill them in. I almost laughed out loud at various times during the test I definitely passed through some kind of mental barrier as a result of this experience. Up to this point
column28: my relationship to exams was based on the strong desire to get every question correct. My educational career lasted 20 years. Assuming an average of 8 distinct courses each year
column29: and two major exams per course
column30: that's 320 exams! When you add in the CTBS
column40: that's at least ten more major exams. I have been conditioned to try very hard to determine correct answers. So
column42: when I worked very hard to determine the correct answer for each question
column43: and then proceeded to pick the exact WRONG answer (in fact
column45: I had a very strong emotional reaction. For a while I worried that this new peculiar feeling of freedom was in fact insanity; I was finally making the transition to madness. But after a few minutes of settling in to the routine of NOT filling in the correct answers
column46: and beginning to crave this new sense of accomplishment
column47: I started to think of how radically different my mental state was from that of the high school students in the same room
column48: taking the same test. An earlier show of hands indicated that most of the students were taking the SAT for the first time. So
column49: I think it's very likely there were some people in the room who were terrified. For better or for worse they were confronting destiny. Meanwhile
column50: I was confronting silliness. The difference in perspective seemed so extreme that there were moments when I shook with desperately suppressed laughter. I did not laugh aloud or smile conspicuously
column51: but the instinct to laugh was as powerful and as involuntary as a case of hiccups. I admire people who devote themselves to improvement
column52: and I know very well how stressful it can be to have success depend on a relatively short personal demonstration
column53: but humor draws its strength from fear
column54: and the kind of anxiety surrounding the SAT is so familiar
column56: that one can only laugh or become depressed. From the very beginning of the test to the very end I felt euphoric. I was having complex emotions I couldn't describe. This experience was far more rewarding than I had imagined.

column1: MY TEST SCORES The Torture of Waiting for Scores I was surprised how bothered I was waiting for my score report
column2: especially considering the fact that I am not a high school student
column3: and I am not facing deadlines. Still
column4: I was checking my mailbox daily
column5: and I even figured out when the postal worker delivered mail (4 PM for me)
column6: and I checked at the earliest possible time each day. All day long I was distracted by the anticipation of getting the score report. I wrote an e-mail to the College Board and learned that score reports were sent with first-class postage. (I bet they get that question all the time!) But most people don't have to wait nearly as long to find out their scaled scores. About ten days after the test date
column7: scores are available online for a charge of $13. On the first Monday three weeks after the test date
column8: scores are mailed out to test-takers and any specified institutions via first-class mail (usually 5 full business days to arrive at points in the US). Starting on the date the scores are mailed
column9: the online scores for that test date can be accessed without paying a fee. FIGURE: Looking at my SAT scores online. Unfortunately
column10: the online report does not indicate the raw scores. Still
column11: it is reassuring that my scaled scores and percentages are at the minimums. (NOTE: Contrary to popular opinion
column12: one is likely to have to get at least one question wrong on the test to result in the lowest scaled scores possible. Blank tests are interpreted as requests to cancel scores
column13: but even if they were given scaled scores
column14: such scores would likely be significantly greater than the minimum scaled scores of 200.) FIGURE: I love how the advice avoids making any significant promises: Tensai can look forward to checking his mailbox for big fat envelopes. Oh
column17: eight days after the College Board claims score reports are mailed out
column18: I received the following: FIGURE: Envelope containing my destiny. But check out the date stamped by the postage meter: FIGURE: April 24th? I suspected(*) a conspiracy! (*...Thanks
column20: for ""clearing up"" a suspected conspiracy! [See e-mail section] Or is it ""covering up""...?!) Failing at Failure: Total Humiliation! Opening the envelope
column22: I find the following report: FIGURE: Printed score report. The first part is reassuring: FIGURE: Scaled scores and percentiles. But
column23: OH NO! I actually answered two questions correctly on the test!! FIGURE: Two questions correct
column25: I have failed to achieve total failure! That is pathetic. But somehow this seems like a fitting outcome -- and it is a wide-open invitation for competition. I can't believe I accidentally answered two MATH problems correctly! I was preparing myself for the disappointment of getting a few VERBAL questions wrong
column28: but MATH?!...How? Sabotage! ;-) ""Student Answer Service"" Report A few weeks later I received the ""Student Answer Service"" report
column29: which told me a little more about which questions I answered correctly by accident: FIGURE: ""Student Answer Service"" report. The two ""+"" signs indicate questions I answered correctly: FIGURE: Two questions answered correctly (""+"") in mathematics. As you can see
column30: one correct answer was in the ""Student-Produced Responses"" section. It's impossible to get negative raw score points for these questions
column31: so it would have been better to simply leave all 10 answers blank -- but instead I encoded my name (COLIN P F... --> 3
column38: and it appears that ""9"" was a correct answer! As for the other geometric reasoning question
column39: I'm guessing I simply answered it correctly by accident.

column1: CONCLUSION I am confident that I am one of the few people in the long history of the SAT to answer practically every question incorrectly. Getting a score of 1600 is more of a challenge
column2: but my goal was novelty! ""It is better to have answered incorrectly than never to have answered at all!""
the introduction of the ""student-response"" math questions made it impossible to lose points on some questions
column3: which represents a blow to the goal of extremely wrong performance. In 2005
column4: the introduction of the written essay section
column5: replacing a section of multiple-choice questions
column6: will deprive test-takers of the current negative point potential. This experiment grew on me as time passed by
column7: and now I am thinking of other funny angles
column8: like asking Princeton Review or Kaplan if they would be interested in being able to make the claim that a person who participated in their SAT preparation course improved his test score by 1200 points! FIGURE: ""Could my future get any brighter?!"" -- Colin P. Fahey
column9: immediately after taking the SAT I at the UCI test center I want it to be known that I think the SAT is a reasonable test. I also believe that the College Board web site and e-mail notifications are very good resources for high school students on their way to college. Some aspects of the SAT are bizarre
column10: and perhaps competition in the standardized testing business would be good for consumers (students and institutions)
column11: but I can't think of any particular improvements that would be big enough to justify entering the market.

column3: 2003. CLAIM #1 : ""A high school student took the SAT in the 1960s
column5: then took the SAT again and answered all questions correctly and was admitted to Berkeley."" CLAIM #2 : ""A high school student took the SAT in 1989
column6: getting all questions wrong. This student was admitted to Harvard."" I have made efforts to get in direct contact with the ""friends"" to eventually get proof of their accomplishments
column7: but I have not received any responses. I have changed some of the comments in this article to leave room for the possibility of other people having done the same stunt before me
column8: and I would actually be a little surprised to learn that I was in fact the first to get such an extreme negative raw score
column9: but so far I have not received any direct claims from people
column10: or any supporting evidence. I WILL GLADLY REPORT SIMILAR ACCOMPLISHMENTS I will gladly report any past or future accomplishments similar to my own. However

column1: Love them or hate them
column2: beards have become the latest trend in male fashion. For those of us that love wearing a beard
column3: there are plenty of social media websites to illustrating an unconditional love for facial hair.

column1: However
column2: a new study has shown that beards are basically filled with more bacteria than the inside of a toilet. According to KOAT Albuquerque
column3: several anonymous men allowed a microbiologist to swab their beards for bacterial testing. A few of the beards contained standard stuff while others revealed fecal matter. While the microbiologist recommended a good beard scrubbing and regular hand-washing to diminish the amount of germs
column4: he didn’t explain how a man’s beard could end up with poop in the first place.

column1: So the next time you see someone with a long and gorgeous beard
column2: remember there is a good chance it has fecal bacteria crawling through it.

column1: Are YOU going to keep your beard? Share with us your thoughts on beards in the comments below!
Discuss this story with fellow Project Casting fans on Facebook. On Twitter

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/tourist-arrested-trading-wife/	a u.s. tourist in saudi arabia was arrested for refusing to trade his wife to a prince for 45 camels.	false	['']	2019/06/11	David Emery	['https://worldnewsdailyreport.com/disclaimer_/'
column2: 'https://worldnewsdailyreport.com/saudi-arabia-american-tourist-arrested-for-refusing-to-trade-his-wife-to-a-prince-for-45-camels/']	https://worldnewsdailyreport.com/saudi-arabia-american-tourist-arrested-for-refusing-to-trade-his-wife-to-a-prince-for-45-camels/	https://worldnewsdailyreport.com/	"An American citizen was arrested under the Saudi counterterrorism law this morning in Riyadh and accused of “defaming the reputation of the state or the king” after refusing an offer from a Saudi prince to trade his wife for a herd of 45 camels.

column1: 59-year old Karim Najibullah
column2: a Ford Motor Company executive from Dearborn in Michigan
column3: and his 27-year old Saudi wife Aliyah
column4: spent the last two weeks visiting her family in the city of Abha
column5: located in the south-western part of the kingdom.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: the couple was invited to a wedding reception where several members of the royal family were also present
column3: including Prince Khalid bin Abdullah Al Saud
column4: a famous horse and camel breeder with a herd including some rare specimens worths over 2 million riyals ($533

column1: During the reception
column2: Prince Khalid attempted to negotiate the purchase of Mr. Najibullah’s wife by offering several of his prized animals
column3: but the American repeatedly declined the prince’s offers.

column1: When the couple attempted to take their plane back to U.S. this morning
column2: they were arrested by the Saudi police. Mr. Najibullah was taken into police custody
column3: while the whereabouts of his wife remain unknown.

column1: The Minister of Justice and President of Supreme Judicial Council
column2: Sheikh Walid bin Mohammed Al-Samaani
column3: justified the arrest and called for an exemplary sentence against Mr. Najibullah.

column1: “The Prince was extremely generous
column2: offering 45 camels worth at least 30 million riyals ($8 million) for a woman that was hardly worth a quarter of that.”

column1: Refusing any demand from a member of the royal family is a serious crime for Saudi citizens
column2: but only 7 Americans have ever been sentenced for such crimes. According to Sheikh Al-Samaani
column3: the accused didn’t simply refuse
column4: but “insulted and defamed the prince and the kingdom”

column1: “Not only did he have the arrogance to rudely decline
column2: but he didn’t even thank the prince for his benevolence and generosity. This is an insult to the crown.”

column1: Mr. Najibullah faces some extremely serious accusations and could be sentenced to harsh corporal punishment
column2: including public lashings
column3: lengthy jail terms

column1: The U.S. State Department confirmed that an envoy has been dispatched to Riyadh to attempt to negotiate his liberation
column2: but did not give more details."	Saudi Arabia: American tourist arrested for refusing to trade his wife to a prince for 45 camels	2019-05-31 19:15:17+00:00	['Barbara Jennnings']	['family'

column1: Time is actually speeding up (or collapsing). For thousands of years the Schumann Resonance or pulse (heartbeat) of Earth has been 7.83 cycles per second
column2: The military have used this as a very reliable reference. However
column3: since 1980 this resonance has been slowly rising. Some scientists believe that it is rising faster than we can measure seeing as it is constantly rising while measuring.

column1: This is from a member of the Physics Forum:
“The universe is expanding; interstellar distances are becoming greater and greater. How does the relationship between space
column2: time
column3: and the speed of light compensate for this? Changes in interstellar distances are measurable. The speed of light is constant and is measurable. But what about Time itself
column4: can changes to time be measured? Or is that a paradox within itself? How can we measure a potential change in Time itself if it is changing while we are trying to measure it? For example
column6: if you are trying to measure how much a yard stick is decreasing in length against a second yard stick that is also decreasing in length at the same rate as the first one and if everything else around you (including yourself) was shrinking at the same rate than you would never confirm that such a change actually did occur. So if we look at the relationship between space
column8: and the speed of light; if space is measurably expanding and the speed of light is still constant
column9: can Time be speeding up? No wonder they say
column12: if they only new. Humanity continually strives to make its vehicles
column14: and processes faster yet we never seem to have enough time or wish we had more time

column1: More and more frequently people are suggesting that time is speeding up. We hear people saying things like “I never seem to have enough time to get everything done anymore” or “where has the time gone to”. The years are certainly flying by faster than ever and there is a scientific reason why time is speeding up. There are also a number of reasons why we are changing so rapidly and it is all related to time speeding up. Human beings are becoming more consciously aware and people are being drawn towards spirituality and personal development in greater numbers than ever before. Why is this happening?

Scientists discovered many years ago that the earth gives off a pulse. This pulse or frequency which has been likened to a heartbeat has been stable at approximately 7.8 cycles per second for thousands of years. However
column2: since around the year 1980 the earth’s heartbeat began to speed up. The most incredible thing is some scientists believe the earth will actually stop rotating when this pulse reaches 13 cycles per second. When the earth stops rotating on its axis it is believed that it will remain still for around 3 days and then start spinning in the other direction. This will cause a reversal in the magnetic field around the earth but what will happen after this point is unclear. At this point you are thinking one of two things. Either you are thinking this sounds pretty amazing or you simply cannot believe it. I’m kind of in the middle myself
column3: I think it’s hard to believe but I’m prepared to keep an open mind. Since I have become interested in spirituality I have seen wonderful things happen in my life and because of this I believe almost anything is possible.

column1: It is due to this increasing pulse rate that we feel as though time is speeding up. Why do we “feel” as though time is moving faster than it used to be? The reason is what we once perceived to be a period of 24 hours now feels like only 16 hours. Our clocks still move in seconds
column2: minutes and hours and still click over a full day in 24 hours but due to the earths increased heartbeat
column3: we perceive it to be only two thirds as long or a perception period of merely 16 hours.

column1: As far fetched as all this may seem
column2: a number of reports suggest that we will reach this critical mass or zero point when the earth stops rotating
column3: very soon. From my research into this phenomena and the changes I can see happening in my body and mind as well as what I see happening around the globe
column4: I believe as do many others that we are now moving into the 4th dimension. The fourth dimension is where our thoughts will manifest almost instantly. This period of life on earth is where our good and bad karma will come back to us almost immediately. This is why so many people
column5: although perhaps unaware as to why
column6: are becoming consciously aware and turning towards spirituality and away from materialism and greed. We are feeling the urge to not only do the right thing for our own body and mind but we are more willing to help others than ever before in history.

column1: The growth rate in awareness is off the charts. What once took years of reading
column2: learning and watching to become more spiritually aware may now only take a year or even months. There is so much more information than ever before on spirituality available in books and on the internet that is serving to accelerate our learning and helping us move away from the darkness of fear and towards the light of love. As we feel the need to change our direction in life and release our bad habits we are starting to meet others who feel the same way and collectively we are helping each other. We are realizing that we are part of something greater than our individual self and this further accelerates our spiritual evolution.

column1: We are leaving the Age of Pisces
column2: a destructive and oppressive period and moving into the Age of Aquarius
column3: a period of love and peace. This is a difficult time for many people as they struggle to come to terms with what is happening around them and what is happening to their mind and feelings. The key is to let go and trust in this natural process of change and not to fight your feelings. As we move closer to the fifth dimension and as time speeds to an all time high
column5: feelings and intentions will manifest into our reality in the twinkling of an eye. What this means effectively is that those of us living with thoughts of fear and trepidation
column6: will manifest just that into their lives causing untold pain. However
column7: those of us feeling happy and positive will manifest only love and joy into their lives. It’s all about choice
column8: and it’s your choice to make
column9: nobody can make it for you.

column1: As we continue through this exciting period of history the entire world will change along with everyone in it. Eventually we will be forced to release our fears
column2: there is no other way. Fear will cease to exist and the greatest causes of fear
column3: being time and money
column4: will no longer be a part of our existence. This is an exciting period to be alive so I’m going to go with the flow and enjoy the ride

1. Time will appear to speed up as we approach Zero Point. A 24 hour day will seem to about 16 hours or less. Remember the Schumann Resonance (or “heart beat” of Mother Earth) has been 7.8 cycles for thousands of years

column2: 'http://web.archive.org/web/20050104011640/http://www.collegeboard.com/student/testing/sat/about/aboutFAQ.html#quest03']	http://web.archive.org/web/20050104011640/http://www.collegeboard.com/student/testing/sat/about/aboutFAQ.html#quest03	http://web.archive.org/	"Frequently Asked Questions

column1: What does the SAT stand for?
Originally
column2: SAT was an acronym for the Scholastic Aptitude Test. In 1993
column3: the test was renamed the SAT I: Reasoning Test. At the same time
column4: the former Achievement Tests were renamed the SAT II: Subject Tests. SAT has become a simple way of referring to the SAT I: Reasoning Test. In 2004
column6: and the test became the SAT Reasoning Test
column8: the SAT. The SAT II: Subject Tests became the SAT Subject Tests

column1: Back to top
What are the similarities and differences between the SAT and the PSAT/NMSQT?

Both the SAT and the PSAT/NMSQT measure verbal and math reasoning skills. The PSAT/NMSQT contains questions from actual SATs but it is designed to be slightly easier than the SAT. The PSAT/NMSQT also measures writing skills
column2: with multiple-choice questions like those on the SAT Subject Tests in Writing
column3: and like those that will be on the new SAT in March 2005. The PSAT/NMSQT is two hours and 10 minutes
column4: whereas the SAT is a three-hour test. The SAT is used for college admission
column5: but PSAT/NMSQT scores are not sent to colleges. The PSAT/NMSQT Score Report gives you personalized feedback on areas in which you could improve
column6: along with specific advice on how to improve. Taking the PSAT/NMSQT gives you a chance to qualify for scholarship and recognition programs and is a good way to practice for the SAT.

column1: Back to top
Is it true that you get a 200 on the SAT just for signing your name?
Theoretically speaking
column2: if you just sign your name and don't complete the answer sheet
column3: you would get a score of 200. That's because we don't report scores that are lower than 200. In reality
column4: if we received an answer sheet that wasn't filled out
column5: it would be considered an automatic request to cancel scores and no scores would be reported.

column1: Back to top
Are some SAT tests more difficult than other ones?
All editions of the SAT are developed using the same test specifications. Even if there are tiny differences in difficulty from test to test
column2: a statistical process called ""equating"" ensures that a score for a test taken on one date or at one place is equivalent to a score for a test taken on another date or in another place. The rumors that the SAT in one month
column3: say in October

column1: Back to top
Are all SAT questions multiple-choice?

All of the SAT is multiple-choice except for 10 student-produced response math questions. These questions ask you to fill in or ""grid-in"" your own answers using a special section of the answer sheet. . In March 2005
column2: the new SAT will contain a 25-minute written essay. Read more about the new SAT.

column1: Back to top
What's the difference between the SAT and Subject Tests?
The SAT is a three-hour test that measures verbal and mathematical skills. SAT scores are used for college admission purposes because the test predicts college success. The Subject Tests are one-hour
column2: primarily multiple-choice tests in specific subjects. Subject Tests measure knowledge or skills in a particular subject and your ability to apply that knowledge.

column1: Back to top
How many times can you take the test?
You can take the test as many times as you want. Your score report shows your current test score
column2: in addition to scores for up to six SAT and six Subject Test administrations.

column1: Back to top
What test should I take first
column2: the SAT or the Subject Tests?

column1: Most students take the SAT in the spring of their junior year and again in the fall of their senior year of high school. Most students who take Subject Tests take them toward the end of their junior year or at the beginning of their senior year. Because Subject Tests are directly related to course work
column2: it's helpful to take tests such as World History
column3: Biology E/M
column5: or Physics as soon as possible after completing the course in the subject
column6: even as a freshman or sophomore
column7: while the material is still fresh in your mind. You'll do better on other tests like languages after at least two years of study.

column1: Back to top
Will the SAT Subject Test in Writing still be offered after the new SAT is introduced?
When the new SAT is introduced in March 2005
column2: all students will be required to take a test with a writing section. For this reason
column3: the Subject Test in Writing will no longer be offered after January 22
column4: 2005. Read more about the new SAT.

column1: Back to top
Which test should I take?
To find out which test(s) you should take
column2: contact the colleges you are interested in attending or use our College Search to determine admissions requirements and deadlines. Most colleges require the SAT I for admission and many other schools require both the SAT and Subject Tests for admission purposes or placement. Additionally
column3: some colleges require specific Subject Test tests while others allow you to choose which tests you take. It's best to check directly with the school. If you're uncertain about your readiness to take a specific Subject Test
column4: see Which Subject Test to Take.

column1: Back to top
Why do I have to take the SAT and why is it required by so many colleges?
You may have to take the test because it is an admission requirement of the college you are interested in attending.
Many colleges require the SAT for admission because it is a standard way of measuring a student's ability to do college-level work.
The SAT is the best independent
column2: standardized measure of a student's college readiness. It is standardized across all students
column3: schools
column5: providing a common and objective scale for comparison. High school grades are a very useful indicator of how students perform in college
column6: yet there is great variation in grading standards and course rigor within and across high schools.

column1: Remember
column2: too
column3: that the SAT in only one of a number of factors that colleges consider when making admission decisions. Other factors
column9: also play a role in admission decisions.

column1: Back to top
What do my SAT scores tell college admission staff about me?
Your SAT scores can tell admission staff how you compare with other students who took the test. That's because all scores are reported on the 200-to-800 scale. For example
column2: if your verbal and math scores were about 500
column3: which is the average score
column4: then college admission staff would know you scored about as well as half of the students who took the test.

column1: Back to top
Can the SAT really show how well I'll do in my first year of college?
No test can accurately predict with 100 percent certainty what your grades will be in college. That's because many factors
column2: including personal motivation
column3: influence your college grades.

column1: However
column2: colleges admissions offices use SAT scores to help estimate how well students are likely to do at a particular college. For example
column3: a college looks at the SAT scores
column5: and college grades of its freshman class. The college finds that students who scored between 450 and 550 on the SAT and maintained a ""B"" average in high school are the students who perform well at its school. Knowing your SAT scores and high school GPA helps the college make a decision about how likely it is that you'll do well at the school.

column1: Back to top
Why does the SAT have the kinds of questions that it does?
The SAT measures verbal and math reasoning abilities. These abilities relate to some of the things you need to know to be successful in college.
The SAT was designed with questions that reflect or show your reasoning abilities
column2: not just the amount of information you've accumulated during school. As an example
column3: many math items can be answered by using complex equations
column4: but they can also be answered correctly if you can reason through the problem. Reading passages don't just test that you can read but require extended reasoning in order to answer the questions related to the passage. This means that you have to be able to make inferences
column6: and interpretations based on the passage provided
column7: in order to understand what the author is trying to say.

column1: Back to top
Why don't the questions on the SAT ask about the things I'm learning in my high school courses?

The SAT measures verbal and math reasoning abilities that you develop over years of schooling and in your outside reading and study. The test is designed to allow you to demonstrate your abilities in these areas regardless of the particular type of instruction you've received or textbooks you've used. These important abilities — understanding and analyzing written material
column2: drawing inferences
column3: differentiating shades of meaning
column5: and solving math problems — are necessary for success in college and life in general. This doesn't mean that the SAT is irrelavent to your course work
column7: the new SAT will align more closely with the type of skills being taught in the classroom and necessary for college success. Read more about the new SAT.

column1: Back to top
Who comes up with the questions?
Test Development Committees comprised of educators and subject-matter experts determine the test specifications and the types of questions that are asked
column2: including topics and areas that should be covered. Internal test developers write the questions
column3: which are then submitted to another test committee
column4: made up of high school and college faculty and administrators
column5: which reviews the test questions and makes recommendations for improving them
column6: if needed. Some test questions are also submitted by high school and college teachers from around the country.

column1: Back to top
Why do some of the questions on the SAT seem so tricky? Are you trying to ""catch"" me?

The test questions are not designed to be tricky! But there are some difficult questions that require careful attention and figuring out. Many have incorrect answers that look good at first glance or that will seem correct if you don't pay attention. But the questions are not designed to ""catch"" you.
Back to top
Why can't I have more time to take the SAT?
Much effort is made so that most students are given enough time to attempt every question on the test. But even if more time were given
column2: not all students would be able to answer all the questions.

column1: Studies are done to find out whether most students have enough time to attempt to answer all the questions in each test section. These studies show that time limits are appropriate if all students taking the test answer 75 percent of the questions in each section and if 80 percent reach the last question in the section. Based on studies like these
column2: the time limits are appropriate for the majority of the students.

column1: Students with Disabilities may request extended time for taking the SAT.
Back to top
If coaching for the SAT doesn't help
column2: why are there so many test prep companies?

column1: While trying to learn ""tricks"" to answer the question will not help you
column2: there are things you can do to prepare for the test. The best way to prepare for the SAT is to take challenging academic courses and work hard in school. It's a fact that students who have taken challening academic courses and have earned good grades receive
column3: on average
column4: higher scores than students who have taken fewer academic courses and have lower grades.

column1: We recommend these basic ways to prepare:
Take the PSAT/NMSQT.
Spend time going over sample questions.
Review the directions
column2: learn to pace yourself
column3: and study the types of questions in the SAT I.

column1: Take the sample SAT Reasoning Test provided in Taking the SAT Reasoning Test
column2: which is available in the SAT Preparation Center or in your high school-see your school counselor for a copy.

column1: Back to top
What if I don't have money for a test preparation course? Doesn't that put me at a disadvantage compared to students who can afford to pay for them?
The best preparation for the SAT is taking challenging academic courses and working hard at them. There are other things you can do to prepare for the test that are free:
Get a free copy of Taking the SAT Reasoning Test from the SAT Preparation Center or from your school counselor's office. This booklet provides test-taking tips
column2: hints to help you get ready
column3: and a complete test.

column1: from the SAT Preparation Center or from your school counselor's office. This booklet provides test-taking tips
column2: hints to help you get ready
column3: and a complete test. Know the test directions and be familiar with the answer sheet (all this is included in Taking the SAT Reasoning Test ).

column1: ). Read extensively from a variety of books and journals.
Test preparation materials like the College Board's 10 Real SATs are available for loan at your school and public library — check them out.

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/adolf-hitler-smashing-the-nucleus/	adolf hitler said that the only way that the nazi party could have been stopped was if it were destroyed in its infancy.	mostly true	['adolf hitler']	2017/02/13	Dan Evon	['https://zuriz.wordpress.com/2013/10/06/smashing-the-nucleus/'
column2: 'http://archive.org/stream/Die-Reden-Hitlers-am-Reichsparteitag-1933/DieRedenHitlersAmReichsparteitag1933193427Doppels.ScanFraktur#page/n21/mode/1up']	https://zuriz.wordpress.com/2013/10/06/smashing-the-nucleus/	https://zuriz.wordpress.com/	"Most readers will be familiar with Hitler’s infamous quote
column3: regularly presented to reinforce the notion that fascists must be physically smashed when they’re still small:

column1: “Only one thing could have stopped our movement – if our adversaries had understood its principle and from the first day smashed with the utmost brutality the nucleus of our new movement“.
The first time I heard these words was in Bash the Fash
column2: a 1994 song by the anarcho-punk band Oi Polloi. I have since been confronted with it countless times at political talks
column3: in anti-fascist pamphlets
column4: and so on. My reply is the same every time: Hitler was a crafty politician but no great historian.

column1: The fact that the quote only ever appeared in anti-fascist agitprop and an exact source was never produced made me wonder. Some websites claimed that Hitler “wrote” these words in 1934
column2: but they did not specify where. Others attributed them to a speech given at the August 1939 party rally in Nuremberg
column3: yet no available documents of that event (which was dedicated to revving up the armed forces for the imminent war) contained it.

column1: For some time
column2: the earliest source I could find was David Edgar’s 1976 play about the National Front
column3: Destiny. At the end of the play
column4: a voice meant to be Hitler’s is heard delivering it in English language. After a pause

column1: Finally
column2: I found a scan of Die Reden Hitlers am Reichsparteitag 1933
column3: a 1934 book that contained complete transcripts of all speeches given by Hitler at Nuremberg in the previous year. It turned out that he had employed a variation of the infamous phrase.

column1: Find below my translation and marvel at the Führer’s social-Darwinist wisdom:
“And so
column2: in 1919 I established a programme and tendency that were a conscious slap in the face of the democratic-pacifist world (…) [We knew] it might take five
column3: ten or twenty years
column4: yet gradually an authoritarian state emerged within the democratic state
column5: and a nucleus of fanatical devotion and ruthless determination formed in a wretched world that lacked basic convictions.

column1: Only one danger could have jeopardised this development – if our adversaries had understood its principle
column2: established a clear understanding of these ideas
column3: and not offered any resistance. Or
column5: if they had from the first day annihilated with the utmost brutality the nucleus of our new movement.

column1: Neither was done. The times were such that our adversaries were no longer capable of accomplishing our annihilation
column2: nor did they have the nerve. Arguably
column3: they also lacked the understanding to assume an entirely appropriate stance. Instead
column4: they began to tyrannise our young movement by bourgeois means
column7: they assisted the process of natural selection in a very fortunate manner. From there on
column8: it was only a question of time until the leadership of the nation would fall to our hardened human material. (…)

column1: The more our adversaries believe they can obstruct our development by employing a degree of terror that is typical of their nature
column2: the more they encourage it. Nietzsche said that a blow which does not kill a strong man only makes him stronger
column3: and his words have been confirmed a thousand times. Every blow strengthens our defiance
column4: all persecution reinforces our single-minded determination
column5: and the elements that do fall are good riddance to the movement.”

column1: I’m not aware what source David Edgar used for his play (and my attempt to contact him elicited no response)
column2: but it’s interesting that his variation did not contain the first part of Hitler’s statement – i.e. the notion that the Nazi movement would have remained marginal had it been ignored by its opponents. I say interesting because that was the ‘tactic’ employed
column3: for instance
column4: by Austrian Social Democracy in the face of early fascist assemblies and disturbances in 1919. Evidently

column1: ‘Physical force anti-fascists’
column2: on the other hand
column3: like Hitler’s second point for obvious reasons. However
column4: the two have to be read together and in context. Hitler’s ‘advice’ reflects his conviction that battle inspires the fittest warriors to great deeds
column5: that the weak naturally fall by the wayside
column6: and that the thugs always emerge on top. It doesn’t offer any profound strategical or historical insight.

column7: Texas (CNN) First lady Melania Trump touched down in McAllen
column9: Thursday for a publicly unannounced and hastily planned trip to get a firsthand look at the crisis affecting immigrant families at the US border.

column1: I want to thank you for your hard work

column3: explaining Trump's decision to visit.

column1: Trump becomes the first member of the President's inner circle to personally witness the situation that has captured the country's attention. Something else that grabbed attention: the jacket the first lady donned as she left Washington.
She wore an olive green jacket
column2: which said on the back: ""I really don't care. Do U?"" in white graffiti-style lettering. Trump was not wearing the jacket when she landed in McAllen.

column1: The $39 jacket is last season Zara.
The first lady's team said there was no hidden meaning behind the sartorial choice.
It's a jacket. There was no hidden message. After today's important visit to Texas

Today's visit impacted me greatly. I was very impressed with the center and the hardworking staff and leadership there -- and thank them for all of their hard work. The children were eager to learn and were kind and in good spirits. Spending time with them reinforces the fact that these kids are in this situation as a direct result of adult actions. It is my hope that Members of Congress will finally reach across the aisle and work together to solve this problem with common sense immigration reform that secures our borders and keeps families together.""

column1: Introduction A lunar eclipse occurs when the Earth comes between the Sun and the Moon and the Earth's shadow passes over the Moon. This phenomenon can be seen by any observer on Earth for whom the Moon is above the horizon. Lunar eclipses occur at the time of a Full Moon
column2: but not every Full Moon
column3: because the Moon has to be near one of the nodes of intersection between its orbit and the ecliptic plane. The Earth umbra is larger than the whole Moon. So
column4: one will observe either a total eclipse by the umbra (which can be well observed)
column5: a partial eclipse by the umbra and penumbra
column6: or a total or partial eclipse by the penumbra only
column7: depending on where the centre of the earth's shadow is with respect to the disk of the Moon. The duration of a lunar eclipse is much longer than a solar eclipse
column8: and can take as much as six hours. The Earth umbra is larger than the whole Moon. So
column9: one will observe either a total eclipse by the umbra (which can be well observed)
column10: a partial eclipse by the umbra and penumbra
column11: or a total or partial eclipse by the penumbra only
column12: depending on where the centre of the earth's shadow is with respect to the disk of the Moon. The duration of a lunar eclipse is much longer than a solar eclipse
column13: and can take as much as six hours. In practice
column14: the lunar eclipse conditions are modified due to the refraction of the Sun's rays by the Earth's atmosphere. This refraction (of 35 minutes of arc) allows some light to penetrate the cone of the geometric umbra. So even during total lunar eclipse
column15: the lunar disk is not completely dark. This grazing light is more absorbed by the Earth's atmosphere in the blue and yellow portions of the spectrum
column16: giving a particular reddish light during total lunar eclipse. Next article: Science of Eclipses >

column1: Science of Eclipses The study of the Earth's shadow projected on the Moon allows us to deduce that the Earth is spherical. The Ancient Greeks worked this out. Using lunar eclipse timing
column2: as far back as 3rd century BC Aristarchus from Samos estimated the lunar diameter. Using Eratosthene's previous measurement of the Earth's diameter
column3: he deduced the Earth-Moon distance. Hipparcos (150 BC) and Ptolemeus (2nd century AD) improved with impressive precision the measurements of the lunar diameter and Earth-Moon distance. In the 17th century
column4: in order to improve longitude determination
column5: absolute cartography made use of lunar eclipse phenomena
column6: which were observable simultaneously from different points. Today
column8: laser ranging measurements can be made with great accuracy using reflectors placed on the Moon during the Apollo and Lunakhod missions. This has allowed more precise measurement of lunar acceleration and the slow down in the Earth's rotation. Analysis of the refracted light of the Earth's atmosphere during lunar eclipses has also made it possible to show that atmospheric ozone is confined to a layer between 50 and 80 km above the Earth's surface. < Previous article: Introduction Next article: Eclipse Conditions >"	ESA Science & Technology - Lunar Eclipse Overview		[]	['technology'

column1: The latest PR coup for Pope Francis has seen him hire famous and revered children’s author JK Rowling to rewrite the Bible.
It is hoped the author
column2: most famous for her Harry Potter series
column3: can make it more accessible and believable for a new generation of Catholics and Christians.

column1: While the specifics of the rewrite are not yet known
column2: it is believed Rowling is tasked with producing a compelling tale that young Catholics and Christians can engage with. Figures such as Dementors and other popular creations may take the place of less realistic Biblical creatures such as unicorns and the leviathon.

column1: “We are very happy Miss Rowling has agreed to the rewrite
column2: we keenly await the first draft
column3: ” a Vatican insider told WWN.

column1: Rowling’s selection has raised some eyebrows
column2: but the decision by Pope Francis to select the wildly popular author is mainly due to commercial concerns.

column1: “The sales of the Jesus Christ action figure have dropped by over 200% in the last 10 years
column2: we are in need of new
column3: compelling and toy-friendly characters…like the dinosaur in Toy Story
column4: ” a source close to the Pope told WWN.

column1: “Our revenue streams are shrinking so the more Hollywood-esque the better
column2: ” the source concluded.

column1: Rowling has thus far remained tight lipped on her vision for the Bible and its merry band of characters
column2: but a number of Hollywood producers are in discussions to turn it into a movie.

column1: In the last century
column2: many Christian leaders have offered revisions on the interpretations of many of the Bible’s passages
column3: but Rowling is expected to take a more drastic approach.

column1: “Judas is probably going to wear a leather jacket and JK is toying with the idea of a nervous twitch or even an eye-patch. Also
column2: why have one book when can have more? She is thinking of splitting it up into 9
column3: maybe 10 books” the author’s publicist shared with WWN."	Church Hires JK Rowling To Rewrite The Bible	2014-01-21 00:00:00	['January']	['author'

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/board-stiff/	woman takes revenge on her cheating husband by advertising his infidelities on a billboard.	false	['revenge']		David Mikkelson	['http://web.archive.org/web/20060827073359/http://www.thatgirlemily.blogspot.com/'
column2: 'http://web.archive.org/web/20060823073153/http://www.courttv.com/onair/shows/parco/']	http://web.archive.org/web/20060827073359/http://www.thatgirlemily.blogspot.com/	http://web.archive.org/	Day 14. This is the grand finale. I really want to stick it to Steven one last time. And I wanted to make sure he was going to have plenty of time to contemplate what has happened to him and why.And he’ll have the time while on hold
column3: waiting for countless automated services and operators… See
column4: the first thing I did was cancel all his credit cards by calling in and saying they were stolen. Same with his cell phone. Same with his online DVD membership. Same with his gym membership. I went online and changed the password to our bank account and changed the pin number to our ATM cards. I canceled Steven’s car insurance and reported his car stolen. I put an ad in a newspaper with Steven’s work phone
column5: saying he had a fabulous 750 square foot studio apartment in Soho available for a steal--$300/month and to call him 24/7—can only imagine the message overflow! I made sure the post office will now forward all of Steve’s mail to an old folk’s home. And I signed him up for dozens of magazine subscriptions
column9: ” to be sent to his office and I checked the “bill me later” box.These past 14 days
column10: I’ve done everything to make Steven’s life a living hell. It’s definitely been cathartic but I also realize I haven’t had much time to simply work all of this out in my own mind. To really absorb what’s happened to me. So I’m sure I’ll still be sad sometimes. But at least I’ll know I never took it sitting down.I want to thank all of you for your support during my campaign against a cheating husband. It’s been an emotional rollercoaster and I’m just trying to make the best of it. So often
column11: people are hurt by the infidelity of a loved one
column12: and there’s no easy way to mend that pain. The last two weeks was only meant to embolden those betrayed to speak out
column14: and find the strength and self-confidence to move on.I hope this blog helps anyone who’s ever been hurt
column15: humiliated or scorned. Helps anyone who has invested feelings in someone and then had them turned upside down and inside out. Hopefully
column17: there are people who now better understand how much pain
column18: anguish and grief is involved when you decide to hurt someone by being unfaithful. Also
column19: if you think someone is cheating on you
column20: I definitely recommend the private investigator my brother used
column21: Vinny Parco from Intercontinental Investigations. He’s a real straight shooter – he showed me what I needed to know but he did it with real sensitivity and compassion. I think he has a show on Court TV. But no matter how you found out
column22: I hope that those who have been hurt can at least live vicariously through me.I’m signing off for now… but one final word: next time you’re tempted to cheat

column1: WASHINGTON
column2: DC – A senior U.S. general has confirmed that the military has secretly drawn up plans to round up large numbers of privately-owned firearms from American gun owners.

column1: Gen. James M. Scott of the U.S. Air Force confirmed that the Pentagon received a series of formal directives from the White House between November 7 and December 13 to begin plans for a massive nationwide operation to confiscate guns using a series of federal databases compiled over the last few decades.
Scott spoke with Duffel Blog reporters in a parking garage in northern Virginia.

Scott also confirmed that a certain four-star general who heads the U.S. Transportation Command was intimately involved in the planning. General Scott would not reveal the general’s name out of concerns for his safety.
The plan
column2: known in the military as Operation PREAKNESS
column3: combines a series of tactics developed for house sweeps and room clearing in Iraq and Afghanistan
column4: which Scott admitted had been used as test-runs for the U.S.

column1: “If we can confiscate millions of firearms in a country where we don’t speak the language or understand the culture
column2: the U.S. should be easy
column3: ” Scott told Duffel Blog. “I just feel sorry for that poor Osama fellow we had to kill to justify the whole thing.”

column1: According to Scott
column2: the actual planning for Operation PREAKNESS was initiated in early 2009 and developed in conjunction with the United Nations
column3: Senator Dianne Feinstein
column4: and several other liberal organizations such as the National Organization for Women
column9: which is apparently a front for all the previous groups.

column1: While there was initially some concern about the constitutionality of using the military on American soil
column2: page 2131 of the ObamaCare Act actually amends the Posse Comitatus law to allow the military to disarm private citizens at the direction of the Secretary of Homeland Security. Objections by then-CIA Director David Petraeus were quietly silenced in November.

column1: A test-run for PREAKNESS was actually conducted in early December in Clinger
column2: Pennsylvania. A joint platoon of Army Rangers and UN Peacekeepers
column3: working with select state and local officials and using imagery collected by the Google Street View Car
column4: quietly went door-to-door and managed to collect all the firearms from Clinger owners.

column1: The few owners who did complain were initially transported to Fort Leavenworth in Kansas to explain their case before a special international tribunal
column2: before being sent to the National Center For Gun Control in Guantanamo Bay
column3: Cuba.

column1: A follow-on operation using just the UN Peacekeepers is planned later this week for any owners missed in the previous sweep
column2: although the Peacekeepers have confirmed they will be using a post office truck to infiltrate the area."	Military Drawing Up Plans For Nationwide Gun Confiscations	2013-01-10 07:00:48-05:00	['Posted By']	['gun'
