column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/laurel-clark/	email sent from orbit captures space shuttle columbia astronaut laurel clarks final words to her family.	true.	[]		David Mikkelson	['http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/02/02/sprj.colu.salton.cnna/index.html'
column2: 'http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/02/01/sprj.colu.profile.clark/index.html']	http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/02/02/sprj.colu.salton.cnna/index.html	http://www.cnn.com/	"Astronaut's brother: Last contact 'very special'

column1: MILWAUKEE
column2: Wisconsin (CNN) -- As the nation mourns the tragedy of the space shuttle Columbia
column3: the families of the seven astronauts who were killed struggle with their losses and remember their loved ones. Daniel Salton
column4: the brother of astronaut Laurel Clark
column5: shared memories of his sister with CNN Anchor Paula Zahn Sunday.

column1: ZAHN: I know you were tracking your sister's return yesterday. And as I understand it
column2: it was many minutes before you truly understood what was going on.

column1: SALTON: Yes. It was -- I had no idea that -- I had not watched the landing. I did not realize that
column2: when they lost communication
column3: that wasn't normal. When it went on for a long time I just thought that they were in some kind of blackout zone. And it took me a good 10 minutes to finally realize what had happened
column4: and it was a shock. I couldn't believe it.

column1: ZAHN: I don't think anybody in the country could believe it. Where were you?

SALTON: I was here in my house. I was sitting in my computer room on the computer. And so I was running between -- after a few minutes I was trying to check the TV and the computer and just trying to figure out what was going on.
ZAHN: I understand the computer was a bit of a lifeline between you and your sister
column2: and she fired off an e-mail to you a couple of days ago. Can you share with us what she was trying to tell you?

column1: SALTON: It was an e-mail to all of her family. ... It was a very special e-mail for us because it was the last real communication we had directly from her. And she just talked about how thrilled she was to be up there
column2: the view from up there
column3: how great it was seeing different sites
column4: being able to see on her very first day Wind Point in Wisconsin
column6: and seeing something familiar there. Also different places around the world.

column1: And then getting into how blessed she felt to be serving her country and getting to do the medical experiments
column2: working with scientists around the world and how thrilling it was. And really helping to share with us a little bit of what she was going through ... what it was like to eat in space and how she was acclimating to it
column3: and that she was having fun. And I think it was -- it was great to get that at the end.

column1: ZAHN: How passionate was she about the science that was being done on this mission?
SALTON: Well
column2: any time you talk to her actually it's what you ended up talking about usually. It's what she wanted to talk about. It's what she really cared for.

column1: She was -- being a medical doctor
column2: I think it's what she really got out
column3: and what she was excited about the space program is what they were able to do in the microgravity research. And she was very into it and loved to talk about it. So I think she was very excited about it.

column1: ZAHN: Were you part of any calls the president made to members of the family affected by this tragedy?
SALTON: I think that the president called the people who were down in Houston. I had -- my sister Lynn was in Houston and my brother-in-law John Clark and Ian were there
column2: of course. And he talked to them. So we are heading to -- I'm sorry. They were in Florida at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. And I think that's where he talked to them.

column1: We are heading to Houston after this. Well
column2: sometime in the next day or two
column3: where we're going to be with family and hopefully there will be a memorial service. I think there's a plan to having a memorial service there that we plan on attending.

column1: ZAHN: I know you mentioned your sister's husband. Without violating your privacy
column2: are you able to share with us anything this morning about how your sister's 8-year-old son is doing and her husband?

column1: SALTON: Well
column2: we're very thankful that one of his brothers
column3: Dave Clark
column4: was able to get down to Houston. And my brother John Salton
column5: was able to get down there to Houston last night to help out. And so they're there now and helping out any way they can. And we'll be hearing from them later as to what the plans are
column6: when the rest of us should come down and how it will all work. And I'm just thankful that they were able to get there.

column1: ZAHN: You've said so much this morning about what drove your sister to the excellence that she accomplished in her life. Just a final thought on what else you want people in America to know about the sacrifice she made and how serious she was about serving her country.
SALTON: Well
column2: Laurel was a very intense person who would set goals and would go for them. And I think that that's a great role model for kids today
column3: to know that the goal-oriented stuff that they talk about
column4: that the counselors at school tell you about
column5: it works. It gets you places. You can do great things for humanity if you just set some small goals and always go for the next thing and set your sights higher.

column1: When you reach that goal
column2: go for the next thing. And that's what she did. And we're all very proud for what she was able to do. And we certainly all hope that NASA keeps going and continues on with its research. I think it's very important for humanity to keep this going."	Astronaut's brother: Last contact 'very special'		[]	['think'
column3: 'sister'

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/elon-musk-buy-facebook/	elon musk told a room of investors that he planned on buying facebook so that he could delete the social media platform.	false	['alternative-science.com']	2018/11/07	Dan Evon	['https://alternative-science.com/elon-musk-facebook/'
column2: 'https://www.facebook.com/pg/AlternativeScienceEnthusiast/about/?ref=page_internal']	https://alternative-science.com/elon-musk-facebook/	https://alternative-science.com/	"Earlier this week
column3: Elon Musk made global headlines when he deleted the official SpaceX and Tesla pages from Facebook. Musk made certain to clarify that he didn’t make the decision for political reasons
column4: but rather because Facebook gives him “the willies.”

column1: It’s not a political statement and I didn’t do this because someone dared me to do it. Just don’t like Facebook. Gives me the willies. Sorry. — Elon Musk (@elonmusk) March 24
Today
column2: Musk announced that he has reached out to Facebook and offered to buy every share of the company
column3: effectively making him the sole owner of the social media platform. Musk was speaking to a gathering of SpaceX and Tesla investors and told the group even though he has deep misgivings about the site
column4: he’d “do humanity a favor” and buy it.

column1: “I’ve got some cash to burn
column2: so if Zuck wants to make a deal
column3: he knows where to find me
column4: ” Musk told investors. “I’d make him a fair offer.”

column1: Musk then showed a PowerPoint presentation that detailed in great length what his plan for Facebook would be.
“You know
column2: when I told some close confidantes about this idea of mine
column3: they all wanted to know what I’d do with Facebook
column4: ” Musk explained. “And as much as I know people like to use it as the Internet’s premier ex-girlfriend or boyfriend stalking platform
column5: I think I have much better solution
column6: and I mean better for the species

column1: Musk showed the investors in the room an animated video that detailed his plans for Facebook. The video shows a SpaceX Falcon rocket blasting off into the sky. At one point the two solid boosters fall off and glide on a precise path down to the landing pad. Both rockets land perfectly square
column2: and one ends up resting gently on a big red button labeled “DELETE.”

column1: “And you can see that the second side booster would end up pressing the delete button
column2: ” Musk said. “Which would send a proton torpedo down the exhaust port of Facebook’s headquarters
column3: triggering a chain reaction that should destroy the platform.”

column1: Cheers erupted in the room. Chants of “Fuck Zuck! Fuck Zuck! Fuck Zuck!” reverberated throughout the building
column2: growing so loud it drowned out the sound of the ocean’s waves at every beach on the planet. Musk stepped away from the podium he was speaking from
column3: raised his arms in the air in triumph
column4: and took in the adulation from everyone in the room.

column1: This story is developing.
Writer/comedian James Schlarmann is the founder of The Political Garbage Chute and his work has been featured on The Huffington Post. You can follow James on Facebook
column2: Spotify
column3: and Instagram
column4: but not Twitter because Twitter is a cesspool.

column1: James’ newest satirical compilation is out now and available from Amazon
column2: Barnes & Noble
column3: and soon at WalMart.com."	Elon Musk Offers To Buy And Then Delete Facebook	2018-03-30 15:00:59+00:00	[]	['investors'

column3: 'https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-43035474']	https://www.timeslive.co.za/news/south-africa/2018-02-14-man-killed-by-lions-in-limpopo-is-identified/	https://www.timeslive.co.za/	"A man who was mauled to death by lions at a private game reserve near Hoedspruit has been identified as a Mozambican.

column1: He was suspected of being one of three illegal poachers who were attacked by lions in Limpopo on Friday. Two survived the attack and escaped.

Limpopo police spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Moatshe Ngoepe on Wednesday identified the man as 50-year-old David Baloyi from Masingiri area at Mavudza Village in Mozambique. He was positively identified by his sister-in-law in the Maphutha Malatji Hospital motuary in Namakgale outside Phalaborwa.
She told police that she had been phoned by family members in Mozambique who had heard that Baloyi had been killed by lions in South Africa.

“She confirmed to the family that she also heard over the radio that there is an unknown person who was killed by lions‚” said Ngoepe. After checking with police she was directed to the hospital mortuary.

“The police are still investigating the possibility that the deceased might have been a poacher after a hunting rifle and ammunition were found in the vicinity of the scene. Subsequent to this gruesome discovery‚ the police in Hoedspruit outside Phalaborwa have since opened an inquest case for further investigations‚” said Ngoepe."	Man killed by lions in Limpopo is identified	2018-02-14 00:00:00	['Image']	['identified'

column3: 'http://www.teamhoyt.com/About-Team-Hoyt.html']	http://www.teamhoyt.com/About-Team-Hoyt.html	http://www.teamhoyt.com/	"The Early Years

column1: Rick was born in 1962 to Dick and Judy Hoyt. As a result of oxygen deprivation to Rick’s brain at the time of his birth
column2: Rick was diagnosed as a spastic quadriplegic with cerebral palsy. Dick and Judy were advised to institutionalize Rick because there was no chance of him recovering
column3: and little hope for Rick to live a “normal” life. This was just the beginning of Dick and Judy’s quest for Rick’s inclusion in community

column1: Dick and Judy soon realized that though Rick couldn’t walk or speak; he was quite astute and his eyes would follow them around the room. They fought to integrate Rick into the public school system
column2: pushing administrators to see beyond Rick’s physical limitations. Dick and Judy would take Rick sledding and swimming
column3: and even taught him the alphabet and basic words
column4: like any other child. After providing concrete evidence of Rick’s intellect and ability to learn like everyone else
column5: Dick and Judy needed to find a way to help Rick communicate for himself.

column1: With $5
column2: 000 in 1972 and a skilled group of engineers at Tufts University
column3: an interactive computer was built for Rick. This computer consisted of a cursor being used to highlight every letter of the alphabet. Once the letter Rick wanted was highlighted
column4: he was able to select it by just a simple tap with his head against a head piece attached to his wheelchair. When the computer was originally first brought home
column5: Rick surprised everyone with his first words. Instead of saying
column11: Bruins!” The Boston Bruins were in the Stanley Cup finals that season. It was clear from that moment on
column12: that Rick loved sports and followed the game just like anyone else.

column2: at the age of 13
column3: Rick was finally admitted into public school. After high school
column5: and he graduated with a degree in Special Education in 1993. Dick retired in 1995 as a Lt. Colonel from the Air National Guard
column6: after serving his country for 37 years.

column1: The Beginning of Team Hoyt
In the spring of 1977
column2: Rick told his father that he wanted to participate in a 5-mile benefit run for a Lacrosse player who had been paralyzed in an accident. Far from being a long-distance runner
column3: Dick agreed to push Rick in his wheelchair and they finished all 5 miles
column4: coming in next to last. That night
column8: it feels like I’m not handicapped.”

column1: This realization was just the beginning of what would become over 1
column2: 000 races completed
column3: including marathons
column4: duathlons and triathlons (6 of them being Ironman competitions). Also adding to their list of achievements
column5: Dick and Rick biked and ran across the U.S. in 1992

column1: In a triathlon
column2: Dick will pull Rick in a boat with a bungee cord attached to a vest around his waist and to the front of the boat for the swimming stage. For the biking stage
column3: Rick will ride a special two-seater bicycle
column4: and then Dick will push Rick in his custom made running chair (for the running stage).

column1: Rick was once asked
column2: if he could give his father one thing
column3: what would it be? Rick responded
column4: “The thing I’d most like is for my dad to sit in the chair and I would push him for once.”

column1: The 2009 Boston Marathon was officially Team Hoyt’s 1000th race. Rick always says if it comes down to doing one race a year he would like it to be the Boston Marathon: his favorite race.
2013 was going to be Dick and Rick's last Boston Marathon together
column2: but they were not able to finish due to the bombings. They vowed to be back in 2014 to finish ""Boston Strong"" with all the other runners
column3: which they did; stopping many times along the 26.2 distance to take photos and shake hands of the many well wishers
column4: and finishing with several of the runners from their Hoyt Foundation Boston Marathon team.

column2: 'http://dailybuzzlive.com/contact-us/']	http://dailybuzzlive.com/woman-buried-alive-funeral-goers-hear-screams-grave/	http://dailybuzzlive.com/	"Woman Buried Alive

column1: Woman Buried Alive
column2: Funeral Goers Hear Screams From The Grave – A 34 year old woman in now recovering from a most bizarre scene
column3: one you only hear about in the movies.

column1: A Chicago family was grieving the loss of their son
column2: as they said their final goodbye’s at his funeral. Police say it was unlike anything they had ever seen before. Reports say that approximately 15 minutes after the body of the man was laid to rest
column3: the family of the deceased began to hear screams.

column1: “We decided to stay for a bit after the funeral
column2: to let it all sink in. When all of a sudden we heard screams
column3: but we could not figure out where they were coming from
column4: ” said one family member who wished to stay anonymous. “We realized it was coming from under the grave where we just laid my brother. We ran and got help.”

column1: Police say when firefighters arrived
column2: they received permission from the family to dig up the freshly dug grave. As they did
column3: the screams became louder and louder.

column1: When they reached the coffin
column2: they pried it open
column3: to find 34 year old Linda Lynch inside.

column2: the Police march “Polis Repablik Singapura March” has been updated with new lyrics and is now known as the “Singapore Police Force March”. The lyrics of the SPF March is written by Dr Norshahril Saat who served his national service with the SPF. The SPF March was first played at the Graduation Parade at Home Team Academy on 18 January 2020. The Singapore Police Force March has retained the melody of the PRS March as a tribute to its rich heritage and unifying qualities. The revised lyrics reflect the SPF’s contemporary needs and challenges
column3: and embody the Police core values and the vision. The march serves to remind officers why they serve and what the SPF stands for. The march is played at police ceremonial events and sang by trainees during their training
column4: which aims to create a sense of belonging
column5: instil pride and promote the Police core values. The lyrics to the SPF March are inspired by SPF’s vision: A Force for the Nation – To make Singapore the safest place in the world. The first two verses reflect the Force’s core values of courage
column8: and how these values have strengthened the Force’s mission to prevent
column9: deter and detect crime. Verse 3 demonstrates officers’ sense of duty towards Singapore and the Force as well as their enduring commitment towards the Force’s vision of making Singapore the safest place in the world. The chorus underscores the strong teamwork and camaraderie amongst officers and the importance of unity among officers in our policing mission
column10: thus the phrase “let us close our ranks”. ---- History of the Polis Repablik Singapura March The Polis Repablik Singapura (PRS) March was composed as a ceremonial song to be played at all Police parades and at the National Day Parade
column11: to represent the Force’s history and traditions and uplift the morale of officers. The march was composed by our first local Director of Music
column13: after Singapore gained independence in 1965. It has remained the official Police march ever since.

column4: prompting the U.S. Border Patrol to fire tear gas at the group.

column1: The incident marks a serious escalation in the tensions that have roiled Tijuana in recent weeks as thousands of migrants from Central America have amassed there with hopes for entering the United States. President Trump has vowed to seal off the Mexican border in recent days and pushed to keep any migrants in Mexico as they await the immigration process.

Border Patrol officials said they used the tear gas after migrants threw objects at them. The gas was used to “dispel the group because of the risk to agents’ safety. Several agents were hit by the projectiles
column2: ” the agency said in a statement.

column1: The dramatic images of the clash were already being used by the various sides of the immigration debate. Backers of Trump’s crackdown said the events showed the need to secure the border
column2: while some critics said they were disturbed to see tear gas used on the group
column3: which included some children.

column1: Advertisement
As Mexican authorities tried to move the migrants away from the border
column2: gridlock was occurring at what is one of the world’s busiest international crossings.

column1: U.S. Customs and Border Protection closed northbound and southbound access
column2: as well as pedestrian access
column3: to the port of entry around 11:30 a.m. Sunday. At 3:45 p.m.
column4: authorities reopened pedestrian access. By 6 p.m.
column5: all northbound and southbound vehicle crossings were opened.

column1: Extra Border Patrol personnel were deployed to the San Ysidro port on Sunday “in preparation for multiple planned demonstrations on both side of the border
column2: ” according to a statement from U.S. Customs and Border Protection on Sunday afternoon.

column1: “As the demonstrations on the Mexican side reached the border area
column2: some members of the demonstration split off to head toward multiple locations along the border
column3: ” the statement read. “Some attempted to illegally enter the U.S. through both the northbound and southbound vehicles lanes at the port of entry itself. Those persons were stopped and turned back to Mexico.”

column1: Advertisement
The port was closed “to prepare for the possibility that additional groups would also break off from demonstrations for a possible attempt or attempts to rush illegally through the port of entry
column2: ” according to the statement.

column1: The move came as hundreds of Central American migrants who have been gathering in Tijuana pushed past a blockade of Mexican police standing guard and rushed toward the border.
The migrants carried hand-painted American and Honduran flags and chanted: “We are not criminals! We are international workers!”
A small clash occurred late in the morning when migrants tried to run around Mexican federal police
column2: leaving one officer with a cut on his lip.

column1: Advertisement
A helicopter circled overhead when a small group of men and teenage boys ran past Mexican police to a small hole in the border fence.
U.S. authorities appeared to deploy tear gas and a flash bang
column2: which makes a loud noise but does not fire a projectile
column3: at a group of people who were trying to get through a section of the border fence.

column1: Some at the fence could be seen throwing rocks.
Advertisement
At one point before noon
column2: Border Patrol authorities fired what appeared to be a flash bang and launched tear gas at a group of people trying to make their way through a fence. Some mothers ran under a train
column3: clutching their crying children. Photos from the scene showed children in the area where the tear gas landed.

column1: Shortly after noon
column2: the skirmishes appeared to be calming down. A woman used a bullhorn to spoke through the fence to U.S. Border Patrol agents
column3: trying to persuade them to let in migrants.

column1: “We don’t want war
column2: we don’t want killing
column3: ” she said across the line. In response
column4: Mexican federal police in riot gear pushed people away from the fence.

column1: Advertisement
At least three helicopters circled the area. Traffic was backed up along Interstate 805 into National City and Bonita.
Around 1:30 p.m.
column2: a large Homeland Security bus was ushered past the border barricade.

column1: The additional personnel at the border included Customs and Border Protection officers
column2: U.S. Border Patrol agents and Air and Marine agents recently sent to the region.

column1: San Diego police also readied on-duty officers Sunday afternoon to respond to the border division if needed.
Advertisement
None of the migrants managed to cross the border into the U.S.
More than 4
column2: 700 Central Americans have been living crammed together in a Tijuana sports complex.

column1: State authorities say by the time it is over
column2: as many as 9
column3: 000 Central Americans will have arrived in Tijuana with the hope of crossing to the United States.

column1: Advertisement
Many of them are from Honduras
column2: a country beset by violence and poverty
column3: and came with the intention of seeking asylum in the United States.

column1: U.S. Secretary of Homeland Security Kirstjen Nielsen said in a statement the department “will not tolerate this type of lawlessness and will not hesitate to shut down ports of entry for security and public safety reasons. We will also seek to prosecute to the fullest extent of the law anyone who destroys federal property
column2: endangers our front-line operators
column3: or violates our nation’s sovereignty.” Homeland security will maintain “a robust presence” along the border and continued “close contact with Mexican authorities

column1: The Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights
column2: CHIRLA
column3: an immigrant rights organization in California
column4: condemned the use of tear gas against immigrants at the border.

column1: “It is a despicable act on the part of the Trump administration and CBP officials to attack defenseless women and children firing tear gas

column3: at them
column6: said in a statement. “These are human beings who are reaching a point of desperation because their asylum claims are being processed at a snail’s pace or not at all.”

column1: Advertisement
On Sunday morning
column2: before the border closed
column3: President Trump used his presidential Twitter account to blame Democrats for allowing border crossings
column4: and suggested that Mexico and “originating countries” should prevent caravans from reaching the border
column5: or forming at all. Such caravans
column7: are “a way they get certain people out of their country and dump in U.S. No longer.”

column1: Mexico’s incoming leadership denied a report that it had agreed to a Trump administration proposal requiring asylum seekers arriving at the southwest border to wait in Mexico as U.S. authorities consider their claims for safe haven.

The Washington Post reported Saturday that Trump had won the support of the government of Mexican President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador — who takes office on Dec. 1 — for a plan mandating that asylum seekers at the border remain in Mexico as their claims move through the U.S. immigration system.

Later Saturday
column2: however
column3: Olga Sanchez Cordero
column5: denied that Mexico had agreed to host people seeking U.S. asylum as their cases awaited judgment.

column1: “There is no agreement of any sort between the future Mexican federal government and the U.S.

column1: Sunday’s confrontation became become a part of the national immigration debate. Trump’s weekend tweets
column2: as well as the border incident
column3: quickly elicited responses from Washington Democrats on weekend talk shows.

column1: Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) interviewed on ABC’s “This Week
column2: ” was dismissive of the president’s efforts to blame Democrats for the failure to enact comprehensive immigration reform
column3: saying Trump himself had “gut-punched” such efforts.

column1: Advertisement
Klobuchar said the Trump administration “should have been working with these Central American countries a long time ago” to curb mass flight from violence and poverty.
Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.)
column2: the incoming chairman of the House Oversight Committee
column3: said on NBC’s “Meet the Press” that he does not support a potential deal where asylum-seekers coming through Mexico would stay in Mexico until their court date in the United States.

column1: “That’s not the law

column3: seek asylum

column1: Others said Sunday’s event support Trump’s policies.

“This makes the president’s point: That these are people who are willing to not just defy immigration law in an abstract sense — crossing a border where nobody is looking — but actually rush the border in the full light of day
column2: ” said Mark Krikorian
column3: executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies.

column1: Critics said they were troubled that federal authorities would use tear gas against mothers and children seeking asylum.
“What we saw at the San Ysidro border crossing should horrify the whole country; it was simply inhumane
column2: ” said Cristóbal J. Alex
column3: president of Latino Victory Fund. “His administration has gone from locking children in cages to firing tear gas at toddlers and mothers. These families have the right to seek asylum in the United States. Denying them entry makes a mockery of our American values.”

column1: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has used 2-chlorobenzylidene malononitrile
column2: or CS

column1: Use of CS rose again in fiscal 2017
column2: which was split between Mr. Obama and Mr. Trump
column3: and reached 29 deployments in fiscal 2018
column5: according to CBP data seen by The Washington Times.

column1: Border authorities also use another agent
column2: pepper spray
column3: frequently — including a decade-high record of 151 instances in 2013
column4: also under Mr. Obama. Pepper spray
column6: was used 43 times in fiscal year 2018

column1: “It’s horrifying to see tear gas used on mothers and young children as they seek refuge in the United States. That’s not what America should be
column2: ” said Sen. Dianne Feinstein
column3: California Democrat.

column1: Other Democrats complained about threats of “deadly force” against the border incursions
column2: which saw migrants punch through fencing
column3: and launch rocks and bottles at agents who responded to stem the intrusion.

column1: Brandon Judd
column2: president of the National Border Patrol Council
column3: took umbrage at the outrage
column4: questioning where the critics were when tear gas was deployed under Mr. Obama.

column1: “This policy that we use was an Obama-written policy and it was used in 2013 at the same port of entry
column2: ” he told CNN
column3: wondering in particular about the intense media interest now versus then.

column1: “The facts are
column2: the policy written under President Obama allows us to use tear gas to disperse a crowd that was very dangerous
column3: ” he told the network.

column1: Host Erin Burnett scoffed at Mr. Judd’s facts
column2: saying the agents were using tear gas against women and children this weekend.

column1: “The tear gas was not deployed at the children
column2: ” Mr. Judd countered
column3: saying migrants were attempting to use them as human shields.

column1: Some 9
column2: 000 members of the migrant caravans are camped in Baja California along the U.S.-Mexico border
column3: plotting their attempts to enter the U.S.

column1: Mexican authorities have said 500 migrants were involved in the attempts to storm the border. Some U.S. officials have put the number higher.
Mexico said it has deported 98 caravan members it has identified as part of the violence and chaos.

column2: 'teachers'
column3: 'world news daily report']	2017/05/03	Arturo Garcia	['http://www.gossiptrend.com/culture/teacher-arrested-for-stapling-a-loudmouth-students-lips-shut/'
column6: Missouri | A 61-year old high school teacher was arrested this morning
column7: after she allegedly assaulted a student with a stapler in order to “keep his mouth shut”.

column1: According to witnesses at the Central High School
column2: Dorothy Fransen was furious after one of her students
column3: 17-year old Jeremy Dunlop
column4: kept interrupting her class and making jokes about her physical appearance.

column1: She reportedly tackled the young man and held him on the ground while stapling his lips more than 45 times.
Amanda Jones
column2: one of the victim’s classmates who witnessed the whole incident
column3: says that the teacher “completely lost it” after the young man made a joke about her weight.

column1: “She was just enraged! She yelled ‘This will shut you up
column2: you little fucker!’ and just jumped on him. She held him down and then she began stapling his lips over and over again.”

column1: Another witness
column2: Justin Reynolds
column3: says he tried to help his classmate
column4: but was kicked by the infuriated teacher.

column1: “I tried to pull her off Jeremy and the first time she violently pushed me away. When I tried again
column2: she kicked me in the guts with her high heels.”

column1: Fortunately
column2: two officers of the Springfield Missouri Police Department were already on the site and Ms Fransen was arrested less than five minutes after the beginning of the assault.

column1: Ms Fransen now faces a total of 21 criminal charges
column2: including 5 charges of aggravated assault
column3: and could now face up to 110 years in jail.

column1: Her lawyer
column2: Robert Monroe
column3: says that her violent reaction was due to the fact that she was being harassed by Mr Dunlop on a regular basis.

column1: Mr Monroe claims that Ms Fransen is in fact the victim in this story
column2: and that she “temporarily lost contact with reality” as a result of the harassment.

column1: She is expected to appear in court in May
column2: but her lawyer has already announced that she would plea “not guilty”."	Teacher arrested for stapling a “loudmouth” student’s lips shut	2017-04-07 13:12:33+00:00	['Barbara Jennnings']	['teacher'

column1: ATLANTA
column2: GA—While Empire actor Jussie Smollett has been having a tough week so far
column3: there appears to be a silver lining: cable news channel CNN has offered Smollett a job as an investigative reporter and on-air anchor after witnessing his skills at fabricating a story entirely out of thin air.

column1: CNN producers were reportedly impressed throughout the ongoing saga of Smollett's apparent hoax attack on himself. They realized early on the facts didn't add up but were fascinated with how well the actor kept the narrative going. An HR rep quickly reached out to Smollett to see if he'd be interested in taking on a position at the news organization after news broke that the entire thing was probably fabricated.
Smollett has exactly the kind of skills we look for at our fine organization
column2: said CNN correspondent Brian Stelter. ""He picked a narrative
column3: made up all the relevant facts and details
column4: and stuck with his story in spite of glaring holes in the plot. It's hard to find people who understand our core values here at CNN
column5: but Smollett seems to be just the guy for us.""

column1: The actor has accepted the offer and is now undergoing training to learn how to weave even more intricate narratives ex nihilo
column2: according to insiders.

column6: 'https://www.overlawyered.com/2018/10/18000-facebook-shares-later-a-tale-of-legal-misinformation/']	https://www.cbsnews.com/news/north-dakota-voter-id-law-upheld-by-supreme-court-could-affect-senate-race/	https://www.cbsnews.com/	"The Supreme Court ruled this week to uphold a North Dakota voter identification law which requires that voters present an ID which includes a residential address in order to vote
column7: potentially restricting the rights of Native Americans in the state who do not have residential addresses.

column1: The law
column2: signed by Republican Gov. Doug Burgum in 2017
column3: had been blocked by a U.S. District Court which found it to be discriminatory towards the state's Native American population. The Eighth Circuit overturned that ruling
column4: and the Supreme Court upheld the circuit court's decision
column5: with only Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Elena Kagan dissenting. The two noted in their dissent that this ruling was confusing because voters who used their identification to vote in the primaries could now find that same identification insufficient
column6: because ""the injunction against requiring residential-address identification was in force during the primary election and because the secretary of state's website announced for months the ID requirements as they existed under that injunction.""

column1: Native Americans living on reservations often do not have residential addresses
column2: but have IDs which feature P.O. boxes. Native Americans are North Dakota's largest minority population
column3: comprising over 5 percent of the state's population.

column1: This Supreme Court ruling could significantly affect the re-election chances of Democratic Sen. Heidi Heitkamp
column2: who is trailing Republican opponent Kevin Cramer in polling. Heitkamp won her seat by just under 3
column3: 000 votes in 2012
column4: with the help of Native American voters. If a few thousand Native American voters lack the necessary identification and are unable to vote
column5: that could damage Heitkamp in a close race.

column1: However
column2: it is possible to obtain a residential address before Election Day
column3: according to a Facebook post by the organization Native Vote ND
column4: which encourages voter participation by Native Americans in the state.

column1: Individuals can reach out to their county's 911 coordinator to begin the process of having a residential address assigned. They can then describe where their homes are located
column2: enabling coordinators to assign addresses. The office assigning the addresses will provide letters upon request to confirm each individual's new address. The voter can use this letter to obtain a new ID
column3: or as proof of a residential address for voting purposes.

column1: If you encounter anyone who says to you that they do not have a residential street address to provide to either the DOT... Posted by Native Vote ND on Monday
column2: October 1

column1: Native Americans did not obtain the right to vote in the United States until 1965
column2: when the Voting Rights Act was passed
column3: prohibiting voter restriction based on race."	North Dakota voter ID law upheld by Supreme Court could affect Senate race		['Grace Segers'

column6: 'https://www.space.com/37677-perseids-lunar-and-solar-eclipse-august-2017.html']	https://www.space.com/9517-leonid-meteor-shower-revealed-shooting-star-show-brilliant-history.html	https://www.space.com/	"TheLeonid meteor shower is back this month and poised tohit its peak next week. But there's a long history associated with theannualskywatching event.

column1: Itall began on the night of Nov. 12
column3: when theWestern Hemisphere unexpectedly came under attack by a firestorm ofshootingstars that were reportedly silent

column1: Duringthis historic display
column2: which was seen under clearskies across the eastern United States
column3: an estimated 240
column4: 000 meteorswereobserved. So heavy was the concentration of meteors that to thosegazingskyward it was visually obvious that they were fanning out from a spotwithinthe star pattern known as the Sickle in the constellation of Leo

column1: Followingthis realization
column2: the meteors were given theLatin family name for their apparent place of origin: the Leonidmeteor shower.

column1: Leonidmeteor shower is born
Thisspectacular 1833Leonid meteor storm made a deep and terrifying impression onthe Americanpeople.
Accordingto newspaper reports almost everyone saw it
column2: awakened either by the commotion in the streets or by the moving glareoffireballs shining into bedroom windows.

column1: Thispoint of emanation of the meteors (called the ""radiant"")was in the same place for all observers and remained so as the nightwore onand the sky turned. Here was proof that the meteors were travelingparallel toeach other from somewhere outside of our atmosphere.
Upuntil only some years earlier
column2: astronomers had refusedto believe that meteors ? those streaks of light so commonly seen inthe upperatmosphere ? could have any astronomical connection at all.

column1: Thisremarkable finding
column2: that meteors are visitors fromastronomical realms
column3: was striking in its own way as the shower itself.Itsparked intense study into this new field of astronomy.

column1: After1833
column2: many astronomers researched the history ofthe Leonids in ancient European
column3: Arab and Chinese documents. In 1837
column4: theGerman physician and astronomer Heinrich Olbers suggested thatbetter-than-average displays occurred in cycles of 33 or 34 years.

column1: Otheraccounts subsequently came to light. In 1799
column2: Alexander von Humboldt ? the great German naturalist and explorer ?watched astupendous display of brilliant fireballs during his explorations inVenezuela.

column1: Therewas not a space in the heavens equal to twicethe moon?s diameter which was not filled every instant by shootingstars
column2: Humboldt wrote.

column1: TheLeonids had apparently been observed for almost 1
column2: 000years. [Gallery:Spectacular Leonid Meteor Shower Photos]

column1: Particularlyimpressive displays were found to have takenplace in the years of 1533
column5: 967 and 934. Arabhistoricalaccounts have called the year of 902 A.D. the ""Year of the Stars
column6: asLeonid meteors lit up the night sky during which Ibrahim

column1: TheLeonids comet connection
Afterastronomers began studying the Leonid meteor shower
column2: they ultimately traced its origins to a so-called dense ""knot"" ofmatter that revolved around the sun in a period that
column4: wasdetermined at33.25 years. That same year
column5: the likely source of meteor streams wasestablished by Italian astronomer Giovanni Schiaparelli: The Leonidscame from a comet.

column1: Schiaparelli'sLeonids origins discovery came after heestablished that the orbit of another famous shower ? the AugustPerseids ? closelymatched that of Periodic Comet Swift-Tuttle. In that same work
column2: Schiaparellipublished his calculations for the orbit of the Leonid stream.

column1: Otherexperts in celestial mechanics noticed a strikingresemblance of the Leonid orbit to that of the newly discoveredPeriodic CometTempel-Tuttle. This relatively small comet is in an orbit that at itsclosestpoint to the sun almost coincides with the Earth?s orbit andalso movesthrough space in a direction opposite to Earth.
Sowhen we meet its dusty trail in mid-November theseparticles collide with us at the maximum possible speed ? 45 miles (72kilometers) per second. From our perspective on Earth
column2: the meteors comeat usfrom the direction of the constellation of Leo
column3: the lion
column4: which inmid-Novemberappears dead ahead of us in our path around the sun.

column1: Thismeans that we have to be on the forward side of the Earthto see them coming ? that is
column2: we must be up during the hours betweenmidnight anddawn. Leonids tend to be quite bright and are tinged with green or bluebecauseof their great speeds.

column1: Abouthalf of the Leonids create bright
column2: luminous trails ?in the most extreme cases
column3: hanging in the air for eight or even 10minutes. Themeteors begin to flow when they are still nearly 100 miles (160 km)highbecause they
column4: like the Orionid meteors of October
column5: are thin flakes fromthenucleus of their parent comet. So the relationship becameclear: meteorstreams are the debris of crumbling comets.

column1: Jupiter
column2: the spoiler

column1: AfterSchiaparelli's 1866 discovery
column2: the Leonid meteorstorms returned on schedule that same year and in 1867
column3: though notnearly asabundant as what had been seen in 1833. The meteor rates reported inthoseyears were about to be 5

column1: Anothergreat shower was confidently expected for 1899and fairly wide publicity was given to the possibility of are-enactment of theevents of 1867 and especially 1833.
Butinstead
column2: the anticipated Leonids spectacular failedto materialize. It was later determined that their orbit had beensignificantlyperturbed by Jupiter ? as happens to most comets and meteors sooner orlater ?or perhaps
column3: as some suggested
column4: the meteors in the Leonid stream werebecomingmore evenly and thinly spread along their orbit.

column1: Theonce great Leonids had seemingly become just a minorstream. Even worse
column2: Comet Tempel-Tuttle
column3: the source of the meteordebris
column4: failed to be seen both in 1899 and 1932 and was presumed to be lost.

column1: Butthis was not so.
They'reback ?

column2: the Leonid meteor shower began to revive
column3: unexpectedly reaching rates of up to 50 per hour. Then in 1965

column1: Observersthat same year in Hawaii and Australiawitnessed Leonid rates of 120 per hour
column2: many of these appearing asspectacularfireballs. Then one year later
column3: on Nov. 17
column5: a tremendous storm oftens ofthousands of Leonids fell for a short interval timed for skywatchers inthecentral and western United States.

column1: Therate was estimated by some as 40 per second!
Thatworks out to 144
column2: 000 per hour. It was a veritable stormof Leonid meteors
column3: the greatest meteor display ever seen atany rate inhistorical time.

column1: CometTempel-Tuttle swept through the inner solar systemonce again in early 1998. New studies using computer modeling indicatedthat itwas not a singular knot
column2: but rather several dense trails of materialimbeddedwithin the Leonid stream that gave rise to spectacular meteorstorms.

column1: Aspectacular display of hundreds of fireball meteorsappeared in 1998. This was followed by meteor storms numbering in thethousandsper hour in 1999
Morethan a decade has now passed since the comet?s mostrecent visit
column2: and the Leonids are now producing far more modestdisplays. Attheir peak
column3: perhaps a dozen or more meteors might be seen streakingfrom out ofthe Sickle of Leo.

column1: Itseems that we?ll have to wait until Tempel-Tuttlereturns to the vicinity of the inner solar system in 2031 for the nextgreatLeonid cycle.
JupiterAgain!
However
column2: long-range orbital computations indicate that aclose encounter with Jupiter in 2028 is expected to once againseriouslyperturb both the comet's path and its accompanying dense trails ofmaterial
column3: making storms of historic magnitude (meteor rates in the thousands perhour)unlikely for many decades to come.

column1: Aboutthe best we can hope for are Leonid displaysnumbering not in the thousands
column2: but maybe only the hundreds per hourforseveral years beginning perhaps in the year 2033. The Leonids have thepotential to be quite impressive in those years ? a display of
column3: say
column4: 500meteors per hour would be more meteors than most people would see in anentirelifetime.

column1: Butany hope of a repeat of the amazing spectacles of1799
column2: 1833 or 1966 does not appear likely until sometime after thestart of the22nd century; something for our great-grandchildren to look forward to.

column6: 'https://www.bustle.com/articles/192939-what-is-the-25th-amendment-donald-trump-mike-pence-would-likely-not-be-friends-if']	https://www.bustle.com/articles/192939-what-is-the-25th-amendment-donald-trump-mike-pence-would-likely-not-be-friends-if	https://www.bustle.com/	"The 2016 Election has been a roller coaster of emotions and scandals for everyone involved. But if Donald Trump somehow gets elected and if the early days of his presidency look anything like his campaign
column7: he may find himself becoming particularly familiar with the 25th Amendment to the U.S Constitution. So what is the 25th Amendment?

column1: Ratified and adopted in 1967 following the assassination of John F. Kennedy
column2: the 25th Amendment lays out the rules of succession in the case of a president's death
column3: resignation
column5: or incapacitation. The key part of the 25th Amendment for a Trump presidency is Section Four
column7: backed by the majority of the executive cabinet
column8: the power to declare the president unable to serve and assume the role of acting president. In such a case
column9: we would all be waving bye-bye to President Trump and hello to President Mike Pence.

column1: If Trump were to object to this action
column2: the decision would be left up to a two-thirds vote in Congress. Considering the number of senators and representatives who opposed a Trump presidency
column3: the odds of Trump winning a congressional vote are unlikely.

column1: MANDEL NGAN/AFP/Getty Images
Pence invoking the 25th Amendment would be a move straight out of a political thriller
column2: and though the first three sections of the amendment have been cited before
column3: the fourth never has. The last time the 25th Amendment was used
column5: President George Bush cited Section Three to temporarily transfer his powers to Vice President Dick Cheney before undergoing a colonoscopy. Bush reassumed his powers only a couple hours later.

column1: Possible reasons for Pence to invoke the 25th Amendment could include anything from a classic Trumpian outburst in which he (if elected) threatens to act against the wishes of his party to yet another revelation of Trump's sexual misconduct. In any case
column2: the moment the 25th Amendment comes into play after a Inauguration Day is the moment Trump and Melania should start getting ready to move out of the White House (if they make it there)." column8: there is a Constitutional loophole that could remove him from office. Could Donald Trump be removed with the 25th Amendment? Yes
column9: Mike Pence could fire the president

column1: Here's how the 25th amendment works.
Once Trump assumes office
column2: Mike Pence
column3: along with either a majority of Trump's cabinet or Congressional Republicans
column4: can invoke the 25th amendment because the president is unfit or lacks the capacity to serve
column5: according to Cornell University Law School Legal Institute. And in the event a President Trump is endangering national security or is deemed completely unable to do the job
column6: that's a solid option. It's been invoked six times since it was ratified in 1967
column7: most notably by President Richard Nixon
column8: according to Politico. But if the 25th amendment is used for political purposes
column9: that becomes a dangerous threat to democracy itself.

column1: Vice President Pence deciding with a handful of presidential advisers or Congressional GOPs to wrestle control away from a democratically-elected sitting president sounds a lot like a coup. Trump was elected
column2: whether you agree with it or not
column3: because Americans wanted a president who would break from the Washington D.C. political establishment.

column1: If Trump uses his presidency to challenge the Republican establishment in Congress
column2: the idea of getting rid of Trump and replacing him with a party faithful like Pence might seem like a good idea. And that's the scenario that should concern all Americans.

column1: Consider the fact that many right-wing news outlets called for the 25th amendment to be invoked against President Obama for mental illness
column2: among other perceived incapacities

column1: Is it now time to invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment?
Has our president officially lost his ability to discharge the powers and duties of his office?
Anyone who listened to President Obama speak to reporters in Paris on Tuesday would reasonably conclude it is high time to start drawing up the papers to transmit to Congress for his removal.
The 25th amendment is
column2: if you'll forgive the metaphor
column3: the nuclear option — the emergency glass we can break in the event of a catastrophe. And if President Trump turns out to be a danger to national security then it will be up to those around him to make the decision of whether to strip him of the powers of his office. But if Trump can be elected by the American people and simply discarded once he's no longer useful to the political machine

column4: often by distorting legitimate research. It consists of around 200 members and started because a small group of anti-LGBT physicians and other healthcare professionals broke away from the 60
column6: composed of leaders in the professional field
column7: to form its own group after the AAP issued a new policy statement in 2002 in support of adoption and foster parenting by same-sex couples.

column1: Anti-marriage equality protester at the Supreme Court
ACPeds has a history of propagating damaging falsehoods about LGBT people
column2: including linking homosexuality to pedophilia
column3: and claiming that LGBT people are more promiscuous than heterosexuals
column4: and that LGBT people are a danger to children.

column2: for example
column3: ACPeds mailed a letter to over 14
column4: 000 school district superintendents pushing so-called “ex-gay” therapy and making other false claims about LGBT people in its “Facts About Youth” campaign
column5: which brought a scathing response from a researcher whose work the group had distorted. That wasn’t the first time ACPeds had been called out for distorting legitimate research
column7: if the brief they filed is any indication

column1: ACPeds filed the brief with the Alabama Supreme Court on Nov. 6 in response to that court’s pending decision regarding the U.S. Supreme Court (SCOTUS) ruling in Obergefell v. Hodges last June
column2: which legalized same-sex marriage in the United States. In defiance of Alabama federal district court judge Callie Granade
column3: the Alabama Policy Institute and Alabama Citizens Action Program petitioned the Alabama Supreme Court to uphold Alabama’s state law
column4: which declares that marriage is between one man and one woman. While the Alabama Supreme Court requested that the parties in the case have their briefs filed by July 6
column6: amicus briefs seem to still be tricking in and the court has yet to rule.

column1: The ACPeds brief urges the court to defy the U.S. Supreme Court and confirm that marriage is only between one man and one woman. The brief states that ACPeds is “concerned by the delay of the Alabama Supreme Court and the immediate threat of Obergefell to the stability of families
column2: the safety of children and our constitutional republic.”

column1: Unsurprisingly in the brief
column2: ACPeds cites professors Loren D. Marks and Mark Regnerus
column3: both of whom have attempted to claim through discredited research that children “do worse” in same-sex parent households than in heterosexual-parent households. Regnerus’s infamous study
column4: which received almost a million dollars from right-wing anti-LGBT think tanks
column5: was released in 2012 and was immediately trumpeted by anti-LGBT groups around the country and has been used repeatedly in various amicus briefs in opposition to same-sex marriage.

column1: Loren Marks (top) is a professor of family life at BYU and Mark Regnerus is a professor of sociology at the University of Texas
column2: Austin

column1: Regnerus has become a darling on the anti-LGBT circuit
column2: though in legitimate social science circles
column3: his credibility continues to wane. Last year
column4: Regnerus testified in a federal court case in Michigan regarding the legality of same-sex marriage. Federal judge Paul Friedman dismissed Regnerus’s testimony as “unbelievable” and “not worthy of serious consideration” and wrote that his study was “hastily concocted at the behest of a third-party funder.” In addition
column5: Regnerus’s own academic department has distanced itself from him.

column1: In spite of that
column2: ACPeds relies heavily on Regnerus as well as on other researchers affiliated with the National Association for the Research and Therapy of Homosexuality (NARTH; now the NARTH Institute)
column3: which supports the discredited “ex-gay” therapy movement. So-called “ex-gay” or “reparative” therapy seeks to change gay people to heterosexual.

column1: The ACPeds brief also cites outdated sources from the 1970s
column3: and 1990s to bolster claims that same-sex relationships don’t last very long
column4: and that same-sex relationships are “more violent” than heterosexual. “This Court
column6: “should take care that innocent and helpless Alabama children are not sacrificed on the altar of adult passions

column1: In a supreme case of irony
column2: the brief further claims that legitimate research by professional organizations like the American Psychological Association are the result of a “biased political agenda.” The brief goes on to cite
column3: for example
column4: a 2002 report by physician Ellin Perrin in support of ACPeds’ views that legitimate research is “biased.”

column1: That 2002 report actually found the opposite of what ACPeds claims. The report states that
column2: “the weight of evidence gathered during several decades using diverse samples and methodologies” is persuasive in demonstrating that “there is no systematic difference between gay and nongay parents in emotional health
column3: parenting skills
column4: and attitudes toward parenting.” The report further notes that “no data have pointed to any risk to children” as a result of growing up in a family of one or more gay parents.”

column1: Perrin’s report
column2: co-authored by the Committee on Psychosocial Aspects of Child and Family Health is part of what caused ACPeds to break away from the AAP in the first place
column3: because it helped form the basis for AAP’s support of adoption and foster parenting by same-sex parents
column5: the group has no problem taking one line in that report out of context and using it to bolster their own flagging position.

column1: But in the strange world of the anti-LGBT right
column2: damaging falsehoods about LGBT people are considered true while legitimate science is seen as false. This is why fringe think tanks like ACPeds have formed in hard-right circles: a means to hold on to and perpetuate views that are being proven wrong with every passing day."	Meet the Anti-LGBT Hate Group that Filed an Amicus Brief with the Alabama Supreme Court	2015-11-13 00:00:00	[]	['supreme'

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/americas-pediatricians-gender-kids/	the u.s.'s leading group of pediatricians issued a strong statement condemning tolerance of gender dysphoria in children.	mostly false	['american college of pediatricians'
column2: 'gender dysphoria'
column3: 'not actually a study'

column1: The American College of Pediatricians urges healthcare professionals
column2: educators and legislators to reject all policies that condition children to accept as normal a life of chemical and surgical impersonation of the opposite sex. Facts – not ideology – determine reality.

column1: 1. Human sexuality is an objective biological binary trait: “XY” and “XX” are genetic markers of male and female
column2: respectively – not genetic markers of a disorder. The norm for human design is to be conceived either male or female. Human sexuality is binary by design with the obvious purpose being the reproduction and flourishing of our species. This principle is self-evident. The exceedingly rare disorders of sex development (DSDs)
column3: including but not limited to testicular feminization and congenital adrenal hyperplasia
column4: are all medically identifiable deviations from the sexual binary norm
column5: and are rightly recognized as disorders of human design. Individuals with DSDs (also referred to as “intersex”) do not constitute a third sex.1

column1: 2. No one is born with a gender. Everyone is born with a biological sex. Gender (an awareness and sense of oneself as male or female) is a sociological and psychological concept; not an objective biological one. No one is born with an awareness of themselves as male or female; this awareness develops over time and
column2: like all developmental processes
column3: may be derailed by a child’s subjective perceptions
column5: and adverse experiences from infancy forward. People who identify as “feeling like the opposite sex” or “somewhere in between” do not comprise a third sex. They remain biological men or biological women.2

column1: 3. A person’s belief that he or she is something they are not is
column2: at best
column3: a sign of confused thinking. When an otherwise healthy biological boy believes he is a girl
column4: or an otherwise healthy biological girl believes she is a boy
column5: an objective psychological problem exists that lies in the mind not the body
column6: and it should be treated as such. These children suffer from gender dysphoria. Gender dysphoria (GD)
column7: formerly listed as Gender Identity Disorder (GID)
column8: is a recognized mental disorder in the most recent edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of the American Psychiatric Association (DSM-5).5 The psychodynamic and social learning theories of GD/GID have never been disproved.2

column1: 4. Puberty is not a disease and puberty-blocking hormones can be dangerous. Reversible or not
column2: puberty- blocking hormones induce a state of disease – the absence of puberty – and inhibit growth and fertility in a previously biologically healthy child.6

column1: 5. According to the DSM-5
column2: as many as 98% of gender confused boys and 88% of gender confused girls eventually accept their biological sex after naturally passing through puberty.5

column1: 6. Pre-pubertal children diagnosed with gender dysphoria may be given puberty blockers as young as eleven
column2: and will require cross-sex hormones in later adolescence to continue impersonating the opposite sex. These children will never be able to conceive any genetically related children even via artificial reproductive technology. In addition
column3: cross-sex hormones (testosterone and estrogen) are associated with dangerous health risks including but not limited to cardiac disease

column1: 7. Rates of suicide are nearly twenty times greater among adults who use cross-sex hormones and undergo sex reassignment surgery
column2: even in Sweden which is among the most LGBTQ – affirming countries.12 What compassionate and reasonable person would condemn young children to this fate knowing that after puberty as many as 88% of girls and 98% of boys will eventually accept reality and achieve a state of mental and physical health?

column1: 8. Conditioning children into believing a lifetime of chemical and surgical impersonation of the opposite sex is normal and healthful is child abuse. Endorsing gender discordance as normal via public education and legal policies will confuse children and parents
column2: leading more children to present to “gender clinics” where they will be given puberty-blocking drugs. This
column3: in turn
column4: virtually ensures they will “choose” a lifetime of carcinogenic and otherwise toxic cross-sex hormones
column5: and likely consider unnecessary surgical mutilation of their healthy body parts as young adults.

column1: Michelle A. Cretella
column2: M.D.

column1: President of the American College of Pediatricians
Quentin Van Meter
column2: M.D.

column1: Vice President of the American College of Pediatricians
Pediatric Endocrinologist
Paul McHugh
column2: M.D.

column1: University Distinguished Service Professor of Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins Medical School and the former psychiatrist in chief at Johns Hopkins Hospital
Originally published March 2016
Updated September 2017
CLARIFICATIONS in response to FAQs regarding points 3 & 5:
Regarding Point 3: “Where does the APA or DSM-5 indicate that Gender Dysphoria is a mental disorder?”
The APA (American Psychiatric Association) is the author of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders
column2: 5th edition(DSM-5). The APA states that those distressed and impaired by their GD meet the definition of a disorder. The College is unaware of any medical literature that documents a gender dysphoric child seeking puberty blocking hormones who is not significantly distressed by the thought of passing through the normal and healthful process of puberty.

column1: From the DSM-5 fact sheet:
“The critical element of gender dysphoria is the presence of clinically significant distress associated with the condition.”
“This condition causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social
column2: occupational
column3: or other important areas of functioning.”

column1: Regarding Point 5: “Where does the DSM-5 list rates of resolution for Gender Dysphoria?”

On page 455 of the DSM-5 under “Gender Dysphoria without a disorder of sex development” it states: “Rates of persistence of gender dysphoria from childhood into adolescence or adulthood vary. In natal males
column2: persistence has ranged from 2.2% to 30%. In natal females
column3: persistence has ranged from 12% to 50%.” Simple math allows one to calculate that for natal boys: resolution occurs in as many as 100% – 2.2% = 97.8% (approx. 98% of gender-confused boys). Similarly
column4: for natal girls: resolution occurs in as many as 100% – 12% = 88% gender-confused girls.

column1: The bottom line is this: Our opponents advocate a new scientifically baseless standard of care for children with a psychological condition (GD) that would otherwise resolve after puberty for the vast majority of patients concerned. Specifically
column2: they advise: affirmation of children’s thoughts which are contrary to physical reality; the chemical castration of these children prior to puberty with GnRH agonists (puberty blockers which cause infertility
column3: stunted growth
column5: and an unknown impact upon their brain development)
column8: the permanent sterilization of these children prior to age 18 via cross-sex hormones. There is an obvious self-fulfilling nature to encouraging young GD children to impersonate the opposite sex and then institute pubertal suppression. If a boy who questions whether or not he is a boy (who is meant to grow into a man) is treated as a girl
column9: then has his natural pubertal progression to manhood suppressed
column10: have we not set in motion an inevitable outcome? All of his same sex peers develop into young men
column11: his opposite sex friends develop into young women
column12: but he remains a pre-pubertal boy. He will be left psychosocially isolated and alone. He will be left with the psychological impression that something is wrong. He will be less able to identify with his same sex peers and being male
column13: and thus be more likely to self identify as “non-male” or female. Moreover
column14: neuroscience reveals that the pre-frontal cortex of the brain which is responsible for judgment and risk assessment is not mature until the mid-twenties. Never has it been more scientifically clear that children and adolescents are incapable of making informed decisions regarding permanent
column15: irreversible and life-altering medical interventions. For this reason
column16: the College maintains it is abusive to promote this ideology
column17: first and foremost for the well-being of the gender dysphoric children themselves
column19: for all of their non-gender-discordant peers
column20: many of whom will subsequently question their own gender identity
column21: and face violations of their right to bodily privacy and safety.

column1: For more information
column2: please visit this page on the College website concerning sexuality and gender issues.

column1: A PDF version of this page can be downloaded here: Gender Ideology Harms Children

column4: former NSA Contractor Edward Snowden dropped a bag of coal on his former employers by revealing the hugely popular “Elf on a Shelf” trend is actually an intelligence gathering operation originating with and run by the National Security Agency.

column1: “It actually started out as a joke
column2: ” Snowden said in his speech. “Someone photocopied a picture of an elf with the caption ‘I’m watching you
column3: ’ and it just kept moving from cubicle to cubicle.”

column1: Snowden said that at some point it occurred to someone that if people as paranoid as NSA staff would play this game
column2: what would happen with civilians?

column1: “Now
column2: the NSA has an agent inside practically every home with a child in it
column3: ” Snowden said.

column1: “The elves have basic mobility
column2: which isn’t a problem because when one shows up someplace unexpected
column3: ” Snowden added
column4: “it’s just assumed to be part of the game.”

column1: Through these adorable snoops
column2: the NSA has gained access to millions of tax returns
column3: bank statements
column4: and 10-year old boys unwrapping and re-wrapping their presents in the days ahead of Christmas.

column1: “We would flag those kids for later recruitment to the intelligence community
column2: ” Snowden said. “Especially for Tailored Access Operations.”

column1: In addition
column2: the NSA has uncovered a trove of data about the personal lives of millions of Americans
column3: sources confirmed.

column1: “The NSA has incorporated advanced sensors into these things that can uncover all kinds of information
column2: ” journalist Glenn Greenwald told Duffel Blog in an email. “They can tell things about people’s health — cancer
column3: heart disease
column4: liver disease. They know who’s being naughty
column6: things that even extensive online snooping couldn’t provide. Dildos
column8: chains — all the things stashed in closets and under beds.”

column1: Sources told reporters these were previously inaccessible to the government’s leading intelligence agency
column2: if the owners paid cash at least.

column1: “If you want to know why the ‘privacy advocates’ have settled down
column2: and moved on? My guess is
column3: blackmail. These elves have accumulated petabytes of evidence against pretty much everybody

column1: “You wouldn’t believe what perverse things people will do to each other
column2: right in front of these things
column3: ” Snowden concluded. “It’s why ‘ElfMonitor’ is such a highly sought after duty assignment.”"	Snowden: 'Elf On A Shelf' Is An NSA Project	2014-12-15 07:00:51-05:00	['Posted By']	['project'

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/no-two-snowflakes-alike/	no two snowflakes are exactly alike.	true	['classic urban legends'
column2: 'identical objects'
column3: 'no two snowflakes'

column1: The essence of science is figuring out what things are made of
column2: and how things work. This page gives just a brief introduction to the science of snowflakes.

column1: Delving deeper brings one into a fascinating
column2: and still unfolding
column3: story about the molecular dynamics of how crystals grow and develop. For that you can browse the Contents page
column4: and from there jump to a wide variety of topics relating to snowflake science. What is a snowflake?

column1: When people say snowflake
column2: they often mean snow crystal . The latter is a single crystal of ice
column3: within which the water molecules are all lined up in a precise hexagonal array. Snow crystals display that characteristic six-fold symmetry we are all familiar with. The picture on the left shows a snow crystal.

column1: A snowflake
column2: on the other hand
column3: is a more general term. It can mean an individual snow crystal
column4: but it can also mean just about anything that falls from the winter clouds. Often hundreds or even thousands of snow crystals collide and stick together in mid-air as they fall
column5: forming flimsy puff-balls we call snowflakes. Calling a snow crystal a snowflake is fine
column6: like calling a tulip a flower. Frozen water vapor

column1: Snow crystals are not frozen raindrops; that is called sleet . A snow crystal appears when water vapor in the air converts directly into ice without first becoming liquid water. As more water vapor condenses onto a nascent snow crystal
column2: it grow and develops
column3: and that is when its ornate patterns emerge. Why such complex

column1: And why are no two alike?
A stellar snow crystal begins with the formation of a small hexagonal plate
column2: and branches sprout from the six corners when the crystal grows larger. As it tumbles through the clouds
column3: the crystal experiences ever changing temperatures and humidities
column4: and each change makes the arms grow a bit differently.

column1: The exact shape of the final snow crystal is determined by the precise path it took through the clouds. But the six arms all took the same path
column2: and so each experienced the same changes at the same times. Thus the six arms grow in synchrony
column3: yielding a complex
column4: yet symmetrical shape. And since no two snow crystals follow the exact same path through the clouds as they fall

column1: We have made ""identical-twin"" snowflakes by exposing a pair of tiny seed crystals to nearly identical varying conditions as a function of time. This shows essentially what would happen if two snow crystals traveled side-by-side as they fell from the clouds. What synchronizes the growth of the arms?
Nothing. The six arms of a snow crystal all grow independently
column2: as described in the previous section. But since they grow under the same randomly changing conditions
column3: all six end up with similar shapes. There are no mysterious forces -- quantum-mechanical
column5: or anything else you might have heard about -- that provide communication between the arms to ensure they all grow alike.

column1: One analogy I like is what happens on a rainy day. You look outside
column2: see that it is raining
column3: so you grab your umbrella on your way out. Then you find out that your neighbors are all carrying umbrellas too. You didn't communicate with one another about this
column4: yet everyone's umbrella usage was synchronized. The same goes for the six branches of a snow crystal. When the temperature or humidity changes around the crystal
column5: the six branches all change their growth in snychrony
column6: even though the branches do not communicate with one another.

column1: Now
column2: let me assure you that the vast majority of snow crystals are not very symmetrical. Don't be fooled by the pictures -- irregular crystals (see the Guide to Snowflakes) are by far the most common type. Just take a look for yourself next time it snows. Near-perfect
column3: symmetrical snow crystals are fun to look at
column5: but they are not common. Why six?

column1: The six-fold symmetry you see in a snow crystal arises from the arrangement of water molecules in the ice crystal lattice. As this ice crystal model spins around
column2: you can see the hexagons in the structure. But a crystal is a three-dimensional structure
column3: and snowflakes are also three-dimensional. Stellar plates are thin and flat (see the Guide to Snowflakes)
column4: but other snow crystals are not.

column1: The simplest snowflakes
When snow crystals first begin growing
column2: they are shaped like the simple hexagonal prisms shown here. Each prism has two basal facets and six prism facets .

column1: Hexagonal prisms can be long
column2: slender
column3: hexagonal columns

column1: Hexagonal prisms display the simple
column2: perfect order of the molecular lattice. These crystals result from slow growth
column3: and they are usually small in size.

column1: Snowflake Asymmetry
If you take a close look at the snow crystal on the left
column2: you will see that it is not very symmetrical. Sure it has six similar branches
column3: but the sidebranches are randomly positioned on the each of the branches. This is a fernlike stellar dendrite (see the Guide to Snowflakes)
column4: and each branch grows independently of the others. Plus each branch grows rapidly (compared to other snowflake types)
column5: sending out sidebranches at irregular intervals.

column1: The chaotic branching of a fernlike stellar dendrite arises during rapid ice growth
column2: in contrast to the slow
column3: simple growth of hexagonal prisms.

column1: Faceting
column2: Branching
column3: and Sharpening

column1: There is no blueprint or genetic code that guides the growth of a snowflake. Yet they appear in these amazingly ornate
column2: symmetrical shapes. The shape of each crystal is not determined by any plan or predetermined design
column3: but by different processes that govern its growth behavior.

column1: Faceting. One such process is faceting
column2: which causes flat surfaces to appear on the crystal
column3: surfaces that reflect the underlying molecular symmetry. Click on the link to read more about faceting.

column1: Branching. This process causes complex structures to grow out from the ice. Click on the link to read more.
Sharpening. This process pushes snow crystal growth to thin
column2: flat plates
column3: happening mainly at temperatures near -15C (5 F).

column1: The different growth processes guide snow crystal growth differently. Faceting creates order
column2: as embodied by the simple
column3: perfect
column5: as embodied by the randomly spaced sidebranches in a fernlike stellar dendrite. But with the right mix of order and chaos
column6: nature sometimes creates beautiful snow crystals that are both complex and symmetrical.

column1: As you learn more about snowflakes
column2: you soon find that the underlying science is quite complicated. The growth of a snowflake depends on how water molecules diffuse through the air surrounding a growing crystal
column3: and it depends on how water molecules stick to ice surfaces. There is a lot going on as these crystals form in the clouds. Of course
column4: that is what makes it all so fascinating!

column1: The Snow Crystal Morphology Diagram

The way snow crystals grow depends strongly on the temperature and humidity in the clouds. This is summarized in the Snow Crystal Morphology Diagram shown on the right. This is also called the Nakaya Diagram
column2: after Japanese physicist Ukichiro Nakaya
column3: who discovered this behavior by growing snow crystals in his lab in the 1930s.

column1: Go ahead
column2: click on the diagram for a closer look. It shows that the largest
column3: most photogenic stellar snow crystals only grow in a narrow temperature range around -15 C (5 F). Needles and columns are best found around -6 C (21 F). Capped columns appear when the temperature changes as the crystals grow. Remember these are temperatures in the clouds; it is often substantially warmer on the ground.

column1: You can also see that more elaborate
column2: branched crystals grow when the humidity is high. Simple prisms grow when the humidity is low (or when the crystals are tiny).

column1: Exactly why snow crystals grow this way is not yet fully understood
column2: although much progress has been made. The growth behavior of ice depends on the molecular structure and dynamics at the crystal surface
column3: and this is all so complicated that no one really understands everything about it.

column1: Although science has made great advances in understanding the secrets of the Universe
column2: there remains a bit of mystery still in these remarkable ice structures. More...

column1: John le Carré - English novelist

This is High Noon for American democracy. The rights and freedoms that have made America the envy of the world are being systematically eroded. A new McCarthyism is abroad. Bush tells us that those who are not with him are against him. I am not with him.
The American over-reaction is beyond everything Osama could have hoped for in his nastiest dreams. But this war was planned long before Osama struck
column2: and it is Osama who made it possible. Without him
column3: the Bush junta would have been mired in Enron
column4: electoral scandal and taxation sleaze. Thanks to Osama
column5: Americans are instead being daily misled by their leaders and by their compliant corporate media.

column1: There is a stink of religious self-righteousness in the air that reminds me of the British Empire at its worst. I cringe when I hear my Prime Minister lend his head prefect’s sophistries to this patently self-interested adventure to secure our oil supplies.
“But will we win
column2: Daddy?”

column1: “Of course we will
column2: child
column3: and quickly
column4: while you are still in bed.”

column1: “But will people be killed
column2: Daddy?”

column1: “There will be a few Western casualties. Very few. Go to sleep.”
“And after that
