column1: “Wait till you’re older
column2: dear. Goodnight.”

column1: “And is it really true that last time round Iraq lost twice as many dead as America lost in the entire Vietnam war?”
“Hush child. That’s called history.”
Where’s the hurry? Iraq is a vile dictatorship
column2: and Saddam is a monster who sits on the world’s second largest oil reserves. But there is ample time to consider how to unseat him before we plunge into this predatory and dishonest war. Leave the UN inspectors there. Convene Iraq’s neighbours. And consider for a moment where the will came from to make this war in the first place.

column1: Americans can still awake to the shame of what is being done in their name.

Britain is half way there. The French and Russians have been bribed and browbeaten into submission. Only the good Germans have so far succeeded in sticking to their silent guns. I wish profoundly that the rest of us Europeans
column2: in the spirit of a nobler President
column3: would declare ourselves to be citizens of Berlin.

John Berger – Anglo-French writer and critic
I write in a night of shame.
Many fear that U.S. military forces will soon be launching its “preventive” war against Iraq. Others hope that this can be avoided. Between the announced decisions and the secret calculations
column2: everything is kept unclear
column3: since lies prepare the way for missiles.

column1: By shame I do not mean individual guilt. Shame
column2: as I’m coming to understand it
column3: is a species feeling which
column5: corrodes the capacity for hope and prevents us looking far ahead. We look down at our feet
column6: thinking only of the next small step.

column1: The shame begins with the contestation (which we all acknowledge somewhere but
column2: out of powerlessness
column3: dismiss) that much of the present suffering could be alleviated or avoided if certain realistic and relatively simple decisions were taken.

column1: To understand and take in what is happening
column2: an inter-disciplinary vision is necessary in order to connect the “fields” which conventional arguments keep separate. The precondition for thinking on a global scale is to see the unity of the unnecessary suffering taking place. Any such vision is bound to be
column3: in the original sense of the word

column1: Democracy is a proposal (rarely realised) about decision making; it has little to do with election campaigns. Its promise is that political decisions be made after
column2: and in the light of
column3: consultation with the governed. This is dependent upon the governed being adequately informed about the issues in question
column4: and upon the decision makers having the capacity and will to listen and take account of what they have heard. Democracy should not be confused with the “freedom” of binary choices
column5: the publication of opinion polls or the crowding of people into statistics. These are its pretense.

column1: Today the fundamental decisions
column2: which effect the unnecessary pain increasingly suffered across the planet
column3: have been and are taken unilaterally without any open consultation or participation.

column1: The new tyranny
column2: like other recent ones
column3: depends
column5: on a systematic abuse of language. Together we have to reclaim our hijacked words and reject the tyranny’s nefarious euphemisms; if we do not
column6: we will be left with only the word shame.

column1: This is written in the night. In war the dark is on nobody’s side

Three horses draw George W. Bush’s furiously racing chariot of war. Their names are Vengeance

column3: and Fear. Vengeance is a young steed born on 11 September 2001
column4: and gallops well. Greed is old but sturdy
column5: can smell oases of oil from afar
column6: and understands his master’s corporate compulsions. The third horse
column8: is weak and anaemic. Despite lashes from the Texan’s whip
column9: he is a drag on the team. Nevertheless he is indispensable for convincing the American public that a puny Saddam Hussein
column10: castrated of weapons of mass destruction
column11: remains a mortal threat to a superpower many oceans away. So far the finest spin doctors in Washington have failed to make Fear strong
column12: and Hans Blix has not been totally helpful. Fortunately
column13: Vengeance and Greed have made up admirably well.

Salman Rushdie – writer
There is a strong
column2: even unanswerable case for a “regime change” in Iraq that ought to unite Western public opinion and all those who care about the brutal oppression of an entire Muslim nation.

column1: Saddam Hussein and his ruthless gang of cronies from his home village of Tikrit are homicidal criminals
column2: and their Iraq is a living hell. This obvious truth is no less true because we have been turning a blind eye to it – and “we” includes
column3: until recently
column4: the government of the United States. Nor is it less true because it suits the politics of the Muslim world to inveigh against the global bully it believes the United States to be
column5: while it tolerates the all-too-real monsters in its own ranks.

column1: Iraqi opposition groups in exile have been trying to get the West’s attention for years. Now
column2: there’s a change in Washington’s tune. Good. One may suspect the commitment of the Wolfowitz-Cheney-Rumsfeld axis to the creation and support of a free
column3: democratic Iraq

column1: The complicating factors
column2: sadly

column4: unilateralist approach which looks like bullying because
column6: it is bullying. And the United States’ new pre-emptive strike policy would

column9: because if the United States reserves the right to attack any country it doesn’t like the look of
column10: then those who don’t like the look of the United States might feel obliged to return the compliment. It’s not always as smart as it sounds to get your retaliation in first.

column1: Nor does America’s vagueness about its plans for a post-Hussein Iraq and its own “exit strategy” inspire much confidence.
These are some of the reasons why I have remained unconvinced by President Bush’s Iraqi grand design. But as I listen to Iraqi voices describing the numberless atrocities of the Hussein years
column2: then I am bound to say that if
column3: as now seems possible
column4: the United States and the United Nations do agree on a new Iraq resolution; and if Hussein gets up to his old obstructionist tricks or refuses to accept the new U.N. resolution; then the rest of the world must stop sitting on its hands and join the Americans and British in ridding the world of this vile despot and his cohorts.

column1: It should be said loudly that the primary justification for regime change in Iraq is the dreadful and prolonged suffering of the Iraqi people
column2: and that the remote possibility of a future attack on America by Iraqi weapons is of secondary importance. A war of liberation might just be one worth fighting. The war that America is currently trying to justify is not.

column1: Political
column2: ethical and pragmatic arguments against invading Iraq have been made familiar. But the fearful and uncertain atmosphere created by the information warriors makes them sound worn out. We have to struggle to restore their meaning and to invest dissent with moral and cultural authority especially now that attempts are being made in England to popularise the war by linking the theme of terrorism to a nativist hatred of asylum seekers - the latest ‘enemy within’.

column1: I reject the voices in favour of war which have recently suggested that the measurable good involved in having resurgent US imperial power obliterate the tyranny of Saddam Hussein can somehow be offset against the problems involved in an endorsement of the Bush junta's imperial project. column2: but that their long-term plans will require them to remove it with an assertive flourish.

Fantasy projects of pre-emptive and proactive aggression inflated by the unchallenged power of all the old Project for a New American Century (PNAC) warriors and orchestrated as redemption and invulnerability by the technocratic offices of worthy folk like Admiral Poindexter are now the absolute guarantors of Britain's moral aspirations towards a better planet. column1: Saddam Hussein has spent the last twelve years breaching every provision of the Ceasefire Agreement that ended the Gulf War. Though required to “unconditionally accept” disarmament of his weapons of mass destruction under UN supervision
column2: he has actively sought to acquire such weapons
column3: expelled the inspectors and hidden the WMD he already had. After the defection of the head of his biological weapons program in 1995
column4: Saddam Hussein was compelled to acknowledge that he had produced no fewer than 183 biological weapons in violation of the Agreement. Since 1998
column5: he has repeatedly attempted to acquire weapons-grade uranium. He has replaced the original design for a nuclear warhead with a new design that could accommodate a Scud missile. Nine such missiles are still unaccounted for in the Iraqi inventory.

column1: When Saddam Hussein attacked the unprotected Kurds in violation of the Agreement
column2: the Coalition should have acted

Indeed the US was barely able to keep the sanctions in place even after Saddam had threatened and expelled the inspectors. During those years

column2: ” or for something new in Saddam Hussein’s behavior that would compel us to act now
column3: or for some link between al-Qaida and Iraq in order to justify a change of regime by force are looking in the wrong place. It is not new evidence that is driving the response now; I for one pray he hasn’t been able to get nuclear weapons
column4: despite his best efforts. Rather there is a new resolve

column1: For we must act now. In August 2002
column2: former weapons inspectors for the UN testified that “the current leadership in Baghdad will eventually achieve a nuclear weapon in addition to their current inventories of weapons of mass destruction.” Once Saddam Hussein has nuclear weapons
column3: the West will be deterred from using force to thwart an Iraqi move against it neighbors; the chances of an attack by terrorists using these weapons increases significantly; and Iraq’s neighbors will scramble to acquire nuclear weapons of their own.

column1: If we could avoid Saddam Hussein’s acquisition of weapons of mass destruction through a combination of sanctions and inspections
column2: I would surely favor this instead of war
column3: in spite of the human cost an indefinite continuation of the sanctions would impose on the people of Iraq. But Saddam Hussein’s unique combination of vast wealth (which can quickly replace any weapons decommissioned under pressure)
column5: and resolute mendacity makes inspections hopelessly inadequate
column6: even if they were to be continued indefinitely
column7: which we all must know is impossible. Given the divided
column8: impotent nature of the Western response to Saddam Hussein’s shredding of the Ceasefire Agreement and all the UN Resolutions that
column10: repeatedly called on him to respect its provisions without success
column11: I see no grounds for confidence in a system of sanctions and inspections.

column1: If we want to restore Iraq’s wealth to its people
column2: to avoid nuclear proliferation
column3: and to lessen the dangers of terrorism
column4: Saddam Hussein cannot remain in power. If he cannot be persuaded to leave
column5: he must be forced to leave.

column1: ©Philip Bobbitt 2003

Todd Gitlin
column2: American sociologist and writer

column1: If wishes were arguments
column2: the strongest argument for an American war would be the most ambitious - the wish
column3: or prayer
column4: that by deposing Saddam Hussein and occupying Iraq
column5: the US would instal a democratic regime in the Arab world
column8: would undermine the autocratic consensus that governs the region
column9: reverse the fundamentalist Islamic movement and foster the growth of anti-fundamentalist tendencies everywhere. Such an outcome is devoutly to be desired. If only the wish sufficed!

column1: But the world in which the wish would suffice is not the world we live in. An American war in Iraq is very unlikely to bring it about. What it is far more likely to bring about is carnage and more terror. The risks are far too great to justify war. Is it not an elementary truth that wars get out of control and are
column2: after all
column3: hellish? That’s why they must only be last resorts. There are simply too many ways in which an Iraq war could get out of control. In fact
column4: the scenario most likely to bring about the use of weapons of mass destruction is precisely the one George W. Bush has been angling for: an attack on Saddam Hussein’s regime. The scenario most likely to bring about terror attacks - on Americans
column5: too - is precisely the same. The scenario most likely to win recruits for al-Qaida is precisely the same.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: against Saddam Hussein’s future threats
column3: there are substantial
column5: alternatives. The case for containment is strong. Smart sanctions (not the current blunderbuss kind)
column7: and maintenance of the no-fly zones are the alternatives to war.

column1: But let it be understood that Americans are indeed - as John le Carré hoped -”awakening to the shame of what is being done in their name.”
Don’t underestimate popular American conscience and sense. Understand that the American public has not been swept away by Bush’s bravado. Far from it. The latest national Knight Ridder poll
column2: taken 3-6 January
column3: finds only about a third of Americans supporting unilateral war - while 83% would support multilateral war with UN backing. And this after more than a year of drum-beating
column5: and the panic induced by terror attacks.

column1: On 16 January
column2: by a vote of 46-1
column3: the Chicago City Council “opposed a pre-emptive US military attack on Iraq unless it is demonstrated that Iraq poses a real and imminent threat to the security and safety of the United States”. The demonstrations are growing and deepening. The antiwar movement is getting out from under the sectarian left. Churches and unions are coming forward.

column1: Recall
column2: for that matter
column3: that no American majority elected George W. Bush.

column1: Surely this is a time to refresh the optimism of the will!
©Todd Gitlin 2003

Meena Alexander
column2: poet and academic of Indian origin

column1: A cold day
column2: the temperatures have dipped below normal. I see the black lattice work of winter trees
column3: glisten of light on the street. Lines come to mind
column4: by the poet Huda Naamani who wrote in Beirut in a season of war:

column1: We will write our bodies with snow
column2: the soul

column1: remains a horizon
I imagine a woman in Baghdad. She waits for the bombs to fall. What is it like to live
column2: waiting for bombs to fall?

column1: She wakes in the morning light. She washes herself
column2: combs her hair
column3: touches her throat. She hears again the voice she heard in dreams. It is her own voice

column1: Here come back. It’s not safe out there. She is calling to her children. I gave birth to you and now you must come back.
But they do not hear her. When she wakes she sees the wall
column2: the street. She understands you can’t turn time back.

column1: I live far away from her
column2: in the country that is sending thousands of young people to attack Iraq. Other means of change are possible
column3: and may well be within arm’s reach. Why this massive military build-up? For oil? For a ghostly empire?

column1: ‘No blood for oil’ is the chant of thousands of antiwar demonstrators in cities across the United States and all over the world. It is a cry that needs to be heard.
If fire rains down on the heads of innocent people
column2: if soldiers start fighting and people start dying as they will
column3: how shall we continue our ordinary lives?

column1: What will become of our so-called normalcy?
How will we cross the street
column2: bring our children home from school
column3: approach our lovers

column1: Steel from the twin towers was melted down
column2: used to make a battleship. Is this what the new world brings?

column1: Rather than the first war of a new century
column2: we should make an effort to stitch together peace
column3: a difficult and necessary peace. A harvest of light.

column1: Somewhere on a city street a woman surrenders her scarves.
They are black. The wind blows them back.
©Meena Alexander 2003 . Her most recent book is the volume of poems Illiterate Heart (Triquarterly Books/Northwestern University Press

column1: I am deeply troubled by this crisis which threatens to further divide and polarise people. It is bound to make our world a much more dangerous place.
No one wins a war: wars yield nothing but devastation

column3: in the West

column2: white
column3: black or Asian
column7: who actually wants this war. If our government here blatantly disregards public opinion and chooses to participate in the action

column1: There seem to be two kinds of left-wing reasoning. (Many more
column2: of course
column3: it's in the nature of the left to fragment itself - which is both good and bad.) The kind that reasons all tyranny must be brought down; the kind that reasons anything the right supports must be wrong.

column1: By March 1933 in Germany the Communists refused to join a United Front with the Social Democrats thus leaving the way free for Hitler to come to power. British Communists later opposed the war with Hitler because it had been declared by a right-wing government. They changed their minds when the Soviet Union entered the battle.
Having campaigned for years against the tyrannical Argentinean generals who slaughtered thousands
column2: many unaccounted for - 'the disappeared ones' - the 'right-is- wrong' left then refused to support the war against Argentina's invasion of the Falklands because it was lead by the right-wing leader
column3: Margaret Thatcher. She brought down the fascist generals
column4: and democracy returned to the Argentine.

column1: One of the most dangerous
column2: murderous tyrants of recent times
column3: Saddam Hussein of Iraq
column4: has usurped the sovereignty of his people and dragged them through three bloody wars
column5: one of them against his own Kurdish people. Bush and Blair are attempting to lead an international force to physically disarm and overthrow him.

column1: The 'right-is-wrong' left opposes a war with Iraq.
I belong to that part of the left that reasons all tyranny must be brought down.

Donald Sassoon
column2: historian and writer

column1: Wars present many problems. One is that we never know what’s going to happen. For most of us
column2: and this excludes genuine pacifists and Saddam-sympathisers
column3: such knowledge would determine our support. Assume the ‘best scenario’: the inspectors find overwhelming evidence of the presence of weapons of mass destruction; the United Nations decide to intervene; the subsequent attack on Iraq kills very few people. Foremost among the casualties is Saddam Hussein himself. The whole operation is accompanied by a popular movement which establishes a genuine democracy in Iraq. Unlikely but not impossible.

column1: Take a far darker outcome: though no weapons are found and without UN support
column2: Bush attacks with Blair’s enthusiastic support; the war drags on for weeks
column3: months even
column4: with considerable ‘collateral damage’; what’s worse (from the point of view of western public opinion
column5: so resilient when the dead are not theirs) body bags return in large numbers to London and Washington. And even worse: the inevitable skyrocketing of oil price makes driving prohibitive while the recession turns into a depression. The medium-term outcome is just as catastrophic: ‘friendly’
column6: i.e. pro-Western governments are toppled throughout the Middle East which is swept by an unprecedented wave of Islamic fundamentalism; Israel proceeds to a massive ethnic cleansing of the West Bank; al-Qaida’s recruiting agents are besieged by applicants eager to join and die for the cause. Still gung-ho on the war? I don’t believe you.

column1: The actual outcome is likely to be between these two poles; the precise point impossible to predict. But then
column2: if we knew the outcome
column3: there might never be wars. We certainly would not have had the first
column5: world war. So war is risky. But before you cast your vote
column6: think seriously: who is risking? Whose children? Whose future?

column1: ©Donald Sassoon 2003

Sonja Linden
column2: playwright and theatre director

column1: I have been feeling confused about my attitude to this proposed war - a lone and rather timid voice amongst all the people I know. I share their feelings about American dominance and the US’s profound abuse of its economic and military supremacy. Yet I have been amazed at the absence of concern for a totally oppressed population; there is almost no mention of it. All the talk is about whether action over Iraq is good or bad for 'us'.

My feeling is that all this resurgent energy against war should be directed to finding ways to aid populations in getting rid of regimes that murder and oppress them. The left's natural sympathies here have been skewered by virulent suspicion and hatred of the US. That's why people are clamouring for a United Nations lead; but the UN as it stands has proved to be a weak and much manipulated tool (not least by great powers like the US). In my opinion
column2: changes are urgently needed in the functioning and remit of the UN
column3: including reform of Security Council membership.

column1: The premise for action in cases like Iraq is genocide. Along with the likes of Milosevic and Pinochet
column2: we should be able to indict and extradite Saddam Hussein. Terror and murder of one's own population is in my mind a much more legitimate reason for intervening in another state than weapons of mass destruction (how to intervene is of course the next big question). So many states currently fall under that category and the world still stands by. So much for 'Never Again'!

column1: We have more information now than at any other time in history about what is happening behind closed borders
column2: and yet we are still paralysed. The current Iraq war hysteria has so many subtexts that the real issues are being totally fudged. The people of Iraq have suffered too long under this brutal regime. In this they share the fate of many countries in the Middle East and Africa. It is the casualties of these regimes that are washed up on Britain’s unwelcoming shores. These are the voices we should be hearing from now - the fugitives of hideous oppression.

column1: ©Sonja Linden 2003

column1: The war on Iraq may well be the first disaster of the century. This war
column2: regardless of the rhetoric from Bush

column4: is an unjust war. Ironically if preemptive strikes are justifiable then Iraq at the moment may be justified in attacking the US and the UK who have been threatening to attack it for the last six months. Saddam has had access to chemical and biological weapons for over two decades
column5: he used them against Iran (without any criticism from the US or UK) and he has used them against the Kurds
column6: but he has never passed them on to any terrorists so far. It may sound strange but it is true
column7: Saddam's record is his best defense.

column1: An unjust war and prolonged occupation (direct colonialism) will generate intense anti-west sentiments

column1: The people of Iraq have suffered enough at the hands of Saddam Hussein and the US-UK sponsored sanctions. It is difficult to say who has killed more innocent people

Behind the mask of this puppet we have a staff of right-wing fanatics totally out of line with the mainstream America they manipulate with a brazen braggadoccio that is
column3: as our teens say

column1: The republican virtue of Lincoln and Eisenhower has been tattered by those who inherit the name. Would even my Republican mother
column2: a supporter of Barry Goldwater in 1964

column4: his opponents warned the people should not be confused by his avuncular manner. If he were elected

column6: look where we are today! I pray they will not prevail.

column1: For in threatening war to realise their geopolitical fantasies
column2: they would sell our very souls. I am worried about my soul. It is against the law
column3: the moral law
column4: to invade a foreign country that has not attacked you
column5: just because they might sometime attack you. There is no connection between Iraq and 9/11. None. These fanatics are out on a limb. The whole lot of them needs to be confined
column6: with their weapons taken away from them
column7: until we can throw them out of office.

column1: Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice
column2: Goldwater taught us back then when the radical right was fighting as if it were a saving remnant. Now
column3: it behaves like a Leninist vanguard leading by the nose people it regards as dumb or ""just following orders"". It is up to American liberals and leftists to stop talking as if Bush is dumb. Let him rather be accountable. We must demand he speak. He may be an agent of a faceless military-industrial complex
column4: but he has a face and voice. We must demand that he stop hiding behind a bureaucratic iron curtain and explain himself. We have to insist on his individual responsibility - and our own.

column1: Are there grounds for hope? In the last week
column2: opinion polls have registered a 5% fall in Bush's popularity; some large surveys report only 24% supporting the war; 18 January saw a huge antiwar demonstration in Washington. I have confidence that the American people will reject this war. The idea that politics is contemptible has been promoted by zealots who want the general public to stop paying attention. America is an idea and an open practice; to work well
column3: it needs the engagement of its citizenry. Americans need to become political again and take back their country. We will be answerable when the last days come.

Hugh Beach
column2: retired general working for peace

column1: There could be four good reasons for going to war with Iraq. The first would be if she waged aggressive war against another country
column2: as against Iran in 1980-88
column3: and against Kuwait in 1990-91. She poses no such threat at present. The second would be gross
column4: flagrant and continuing abuse of human rights. Iraq suppressed a Kurdish revolt during the 1980s
column5: using chemical weapons and systematically killing an estimated 100
column6: 000 men women and children. Though the regime remains abusive and tyrannical it is doing nothing like this. The third would be a direct and provable link with the attacks of 11 September 2001
column7: such as led to the forcible ejection of the Taliban regime from Afghanistan by a US-led coalition
column9: in 2001. Despite its best efforts the US has established no such connection. The fourth reason would be blatant refusal to comply with United Nations Security Council Resolutions
column11: in maintaining a covert stock of biological and chemical weapons. Western intelligence sources are sure that these exist and they are probably right. But action lies squarely in the hands of the UN Security Council and its investigators – UNMOVIC and the IAEA. Military deployments by the US and Britain have greatly strengthened their hand. But they must be given the time and intelligence assistance to find and
column13: to destroy these things. Unless and until the Security Council expressly so determines there can be no justification for bombing or invasion.

column1: ©Hugh Beach 2003

column1: In this part of Africa I have friends young and old who are asking the following:
How destructive are Saddam’s weapons?

Has everything been done to avert this war?
Let those concerned with this war give it another thought

column1: If this war really does take place
column2: it will save many more lives than it will cost
column3: and millions of Iraqis (if no-one else) will show their gratitude for that. I’m not an Iraqi
column4: but I shall rejoice with them as if I were.

column1: As someone who has been warning the world about the ultimate ambitions of Saddam Hussein since 1973 - when I sneaked into northern Iraq to report on his preparations for his first war
column2: on the Kurds - I am convinced that only the removal of this psychopath will prevent more conflicts in the future. When he waged his second war
column3: on Iran in 1980
column4: the world rightly felt reluctant to act to stop him
column5: for that would have helped the only slightly less repugnant regime of the ayatollahs. But when the full extent of the gassing of over 280 Kurdish villages and small towns became clear in the summer of 1988
column6: after the end of the war with Iran
column7: surely there was then no excuse to tolerate the vile regime any longer.

column1: To my disgust
column2: and after my pleadings in BBC programmes and press articles
column3: Mrs Thatcher’s government doubled Saddam’s Export Credit Guarantee to £320m a year
column4: and the leader of the Labour Party
column6: refused even to add his name to a dozen other prestigious figures in a statement in The Times to condemn the gassings.

column1: If resort had been made then to the 1948 Geneva Protocol on Genocide to overthrow Saddam
column2: perhaps more than a million people would not subsequently have lost their lives: in the deportations and disappearances of some 180
column3: 000 Kurds
column4: the eviction of the Iraqi army from Kuwait
column5: the massacres of the Shia in the south of Iraq
column6: the destruction of the Marsh Arabs
column7: all those dead Iraqis who were deliberately deprived of food and medicines supplied by the UN in order to blame their deaths on sanctions.

column1: Just before the war of 1991
column2: the foreign minister of India asked me to advise him what position to take at the UN. When I failed to persuade him that backing Saddam would be a complete betrayal of Gandhi
column3: under whose portrait we had just had lunch
column4: he felt ashamed. ""I can’t oppose Saddam""
column5: he said. ""If I do and he still ends up in possession of Kuwait
column6: India will pay an extra £2bn a year in oil imports"". Now the pleadings of those two big sleazebags
column8: to bind America and Britain to their vetoes in the Security Council reminds me of that Indian minister and how politicians determine their moralities. Russia and France have been offered massive contracts to work for the survival of Saddam.

column1: Twice recently
column2: I have questioned Tony Blair in Downing Street. I do not know about George Bush
column3: but I have the firm impression that Britain’s leader hates war and hates having to spend £4-5bn on overthrowing Saddam just as much. I’d rather be on his side than on the side of men like Chirac.

column1: ©Hazhir Teimourian 2003

column1: You ask me where I stand?
My immediate reaction: any question about the Iraq crisis which mentions George W. Bush
column2: but not Saddam
column3: contains per se a tendentious answer. Which prompts me to ask back: ""And where do you stand?""

column1: My second spontaneous reaction is to say: ""I am on Israel’s side
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: primarily on Israel’s side!""

column1: No
column2: I do not want this war
column3: I dread it and its consequences – but I strongly oppose the impulse which lets the arch crook Saddam off the hook

column5: and delegating sole responsibility for the crisis to ""the Americans"". I am fed up to the point of nausea with the pathology of anti-Americanism and refuse to identify oil greed as the motive for the escalation of the crisis in the Middle East.

column1: I am not a blind defender of the United States
column2: and I have often raised my voice against a foreign policy which connived in the Cold War with all right-wing dictators around the globe. America
column3: however
column4: does not have one face. It has many. And it is a good thing to have America – I owe her my life after all
column5: even though the 8th British Army liberated me on 4 May 1945.

column1: I hope that Saddam will be defeated without a war – but he has to be defeated! And the UN must be behind it.

Ian McEwan - novelist
Ambivalence is not a useful sentiment on the brink of war
column2: but my misgivings about military action have been tempered
column3: or complicated
column4: by the writing of various Iraqi exiles as well as the testimonies of those persecuted by the regime. Nor does it seem outlandish
column5: the possibility of Saddam Hussein passing on weapons of mass destruction to the enemy of his enemies. In the right context
column7: it could be a moral act to remove Saddam and his hideous entourage by force and restore Iraq to its people. By the right context
column8: I refer to an attempt to begin the process of a focussed
column9: creative and inclusive settlement to the Palestinian problem.

column1: Naturally
column2: it would require deep American involvement
column3: if not leadership
column4: and at present this is a remote prospect. But without such an initiative
column5: and in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks
column6: the whole area is too unstable; it seethes with hatred. Mutual incomprehension between the Arab world and the West is at a new peak. Only last month
column7: the mainstream Cairo press was repeating the story that the US itself destroyed the Twin Towers in order to have a pretext to attack Islam.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the US Administration is vague about its post-invasion plans. There has been no forthright commitment to a democratic Iraq. This invites suspicion. Military action in the Middle East now could prompt any number of very undesirable
column3: if not tragic
column6: can know what is going to happen. But I think it is safe to assume
column7: given the present pandemic of irrationality
column8: that this is not the best time to be going to war against an Arab nation.

column1: For all that
column2: I can’t say I’ve been much impressed by the integrity of the anti-war movement in Britain. Peace movements are of their nature incapable of choosing lesser evils. The failure to take an interest in
column3: or engage with
column5: or the Iraqi National Congress meeting in London recently
column6: was a moral evasion. All the more shameful when a large part of the INC embraces the liberal or libertarian and secular values that much of the anti-war movement professes. I keep hearing the raised voices of those very same people who preferred to leave the Taliban in power
column7: and who were prepared to let the Kosovars rot in their camps on the borders of their homeland
column8: and to let Serbian genocidal nationalism have its way. Why should we trust those voices now? Tony Blair
column10: played a tough hand in both those campaigns
column11: and he was proven right. Far more would have suffered if nothing had been done. The “Bush’s poodle” charge this time round is lazy. It was the Blair-Powell axis of compromise that brought the US to the UN. Another empty argument I keep hearing is that it is inconsistent to attack Iraq because we are not attacking North Korea
column12: Saudi Arabia and China. To which I say
column13: three dictatorships are better than four.

column1: To the waverer
column2: some of the reasoning from the doves seems to emerge from a warm fug of illogic: that the US has been friendly to dictators before
column3: that it cynically supported Saddam in his war against Iran
column4: that there are vast oil reserves in the region - none of this helps us decide what specifically we are to do about Saddam now. The peace movement needs to come up with concrete proposals for containing him if he is not to be forcefully disarmed. He has obsessively produced chemical and biological weapons on an industrial scale
column5: and has a history of bloody territorial ambition. What to do?

column1: No one seriously disagrees about his record of genocide - perhaps a quarter of a million Kurds slaughtered
column2: thousands of their villages destroyed
column3: the ruthless persecution of the Shi’ites in the south
column5: the widespread use of torture and summary imprisonment and execution
column6: with the ubiquitous security services penetrating every level of Iraqi society. It is an insult to those who have suffered to suggest
column8: that the US administration is the greater evil.

column1: Nor does it advance the cause of peace to ignore the opportunity as well as the responsibility Saddam has
column2: even at this late stage
column3: to avoid a war. Those in the peace camp who argue for a complete military withdrawal from the area ignore the fact that the Kurds would face further genocide without the current protection of the no-fly zones. The peace movement does not have a monopoly of the humanitarian arguments.

column1: As for the hawks
column2: they have evasions of their own. There is a simple piece of arithmetic that they cannot bring themselves to do in public: given the vile nature of the regime and the threat it presents to the region
column3: how many Iraqi civilians should we allow ourselves to kill to be rid of him? What is the unacceptable level?

column1: The best argument for a pre-emptive invasion would be evidence of a recent nuclear weapons programme. So far
column2: nothing has been found. Other questions do not dissolve because they are unanswerable: if nation building is too lowly a task for this US administration
column3: what might follow from the break-up of the nation state of Iraq
column4: an artifice devised and imposed last century by the British? What if a missile attack draws in the efficient and the bellicose Israelis? Will an invasion be al-Qaida’s recruiting sergeant? And might Saddam
column5: the ‘serial miscalculator’ in Kenneth Pollack’s memorable phrase
column6: take everyone down with him in a final frenzy of psychosis? To choose war is to choose unknown terrifying futures. Containment by perpetual inspection might be the duller

column1: Still
column2: the hawks have my head
column3: the doves my heart. At a push
column4: I count myself - just - in the camp of the latter. And yet my ambivalence remains. I defend it by reference to the fact that nothing any of us say will make any difference: ambivalence is no less effective than passionate conviction.

column1: At present
column2: following the Blix and Powell reports to the UN Security Council
column3: a war looks inevitable. One can only hope now for the best outcome: that the regime
column5: rootless in the affections of its people
column6: will crumble like a rotten tooth: that the federal
column7: democratic Iraq that the INC committed itself to at its conference can be helped into existence by the UN
column10: will find in its olman’s heart the energy and optimism to begin to address the Palestinian issue. These are fragile hopes. As things stand
column11: it is easier to conceive of innumerable darker possibilities.

column1: ©Ian McEwan 2003
back to top
Ghada Karmi
column2: recent author of the memoir
column3: ‘In Search of Fatima: A Palestinian Story’

column1: This war is something no one wants
column2: least of all an Arab and a Palestinian like myself. There is no rational reason why it should be prosecuted and no argument proffered to date has been convincing – certainly not the weapons of mass destruction argument
column3: which has fallen flat on its face ever since the US showed itself willing to counter a real threat coming from North Korea with diplomacy and offers of economic and energy support. For Arabs
column4: the tolerance shown to Israel’s brutality against the Palestinians and its known possession of nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction while castigating Iraq in the harshest and most bellicose of ways is nauseating. Many theories have been put forward to explain the American imperative to attack a country which is on its metaphorical knees and which poses not the faintest threat to the US or the West
column5: but the real reason it seems to me lies in the West’s foolish policy towards Iraq

column1: Having decided that Saddam Hussein was becoming a liability rather than the asset he had been during the 1980s
column2: the US led a war designed to squash the Iraqi leader. But
column3: despite stringent sanctions and a degraded country
column4: he clung onto power and is a living monument to Western double-dealing and ineptitude. Iraq therefore poses a conundrum: how to resume normal business with it but have to stomach the fact that if Saddam stays in power
column6: and the US with all its might and power will have lost? This is unthinkable and
column8: so as to enable the West deal with Iraq once more. The fact that this may get out of hand and drag the US (and Britain) into an Iraqi post-invasion quagmire is a nightmare which was not anticipated when the eagerness to teach Saddam a lesson first rose to fever pitch. If this ego-driven enterprise goes ahead
column9: we will now all have to live with its dire consequences.

column1: ©Ghada Karmi 2003
back to top
Ben Okri
column2: writer

column1: A vision of the broken rose
In an inferno of oil and blood
Earth in dying clothes
Unleash the hidden will of God.

Nuha Al-Radi
column2: Iraqi artist and writer

column1: It comes as a big shock that in this age of supposed democracy
column2: a country can be invaded
column3: colonized and occupied in so blatant a manner – daisy-cuttered and e-bombed
column4: all in the name of peace. And that it’s even feasible to look on
column5: like at a play unfolding or something live on T.V. Even more extraordinary is the fact that this war on terror and all the so-called ‘Islamic’ terrorist activities that are taking place all over the world are the work of every nationality except Iraqi. There is no logic to this action
column6: unless it is the logic of power and greed
column7: hypocrisy and lies. These are the virtues and morals of the U.S. - the country that rules the world. It is morality driven by the black gold - oil.

column1: I am a potter
column2: sculptor
column3: painter. I try to visualise things. Right now I am in Pakistan preparing for an exhibition. One of the journalists interviewing me asked me why my work did not depict Iraq – the million children dead
column5: the damage left behind with the depleted uranium etc. During the first Gulf War I was in Baghdad and wrote a diary that was published. It was just every day life under bombardment
column6: which later became just living and trying to mind one’s own business. I wished then that something could happen to the U.S.
column7: and now 12 years later a repeat is about to take place
column8: on a now weak and battered nation
column9: 22 million people trying to mind their business and live their lives.

column1: A dictatorship within is to be replaced by a military occupation from outside. We already know how much (and how little) care is given later to helping put right the damage done. How can we hope for a different reality?
©Nuha Al-Radi 2003
back to top
David Hayes
column2: assistant editor
column3: openDemocracy

column1: The way that Iraqis will take possession of war to reach for inner liberation is the decisive element in the story that is unfolding. This will transform the field of political calculation
column2: inside and outside the country.

column1: There are no perfect choices. No one would wish to start from here. The complicity and misdeeds of western states and corporations are indeed extensive
column2: and must in time be paid for.

column1: Yet
column2: overriding all other factors is one
column3: whose immensity no current debate has begun fully to register. The Saddam Hussein regime is the most pathologically violent in the history of the Arab world. Destroying it will be an unequivocal service to the Iraqi people and to humanity.

column1: The revolution that will follow in the minds and hearts of Iraqis – astonishing
column2: liberating
column3: and inevitable - will be definitive justification for the war that has freed them. In Iraqi memory

column1: The aftermath will be convulsive. The nature of the dictatorship has prescribed its own fate. Every grotesque monument will fall
column2: every statue in every town will be blown up
column3: every mosaic or document with his inlaid handprint and inscripted blood will be torn apart. Every trace of the monster will be erased from Iraqi life. Soon
column4: not a single Iraqi will be found who confesses the smallest allegiance to his memory.

column1: There will be many dangers in this period. The need for massive food
column2: health
column3: and infrastructural aid from the military victors will be urgent. Territorial integrity and stable governance will require intense efforts of military

column1: Behind them
column2: the political victors
column3: the Iraqi people
column4: will begin the confusing and necessary task of remaking their society – and in an extraordinarily painful process
column5: exploring the meaning of living with trust and freedom in everyday life.

column1: Iraqis are about to reclaim an active role in their own country’s history. They will be seen and heard telling
column2: in their own voices
column3: the unimaginable stories of these unforgettable years.

column1: In the process
column2: they will write a new script that makes sense out of nationalist madness
column3: as Cambodians
column5: and Bosnians have done before them. Every power in the world

Bahman Nirumand – Iranian author of ‘An Alien Amongst Germans’
column2: and journalist in exile

column1: The warmongering in Washington flows from an arrogance of power mixed with unlimited stupidity and ignorance. Nobody has any doubt that the US are capable of bulldozing Iraq with their gigantic military machinery
column2: of killing hundreds of thousands and of taking control of the oilfields. However
column3: they will not be able to quench the rising hatred and the wrath of the survivors. And this hatred and wrath will spread like a bushfire in the whole region and beyond. Nothing could provide a better basis for the fundamentalists and terrorist organisations.

column1: A war against Iraq will jeopardise the partly artificially-drawn borders between states in the region. What if Iraq splits into several parts
column2: if the Kurds found a new state
column3: if the Shiites in Southern Iraq forge an alliance with their brothers in Kuwait
column5: if the Wahhabite fundamentalists in Saudi Arabia chase away the king and the five hundred corrupt princes? Will the USA take the war to these countries as well? How many casualties do Bush and Rumsfeld find acceptable: a hundred thousand
column7: more than a million? And what happens if Saddam Hussein
column9: sets the oilfields in Iraq alight?

column1: According to international law no country has the right to use military force to cause regime change in another country. It cannot be denied that Saddam Hussein is a criminal
column2: that he has total control over his people
column3: that he is not only dangerous for his own country
column4: but also for the neighbouring states. Nevertheless how would Americans react if Saddam Hussein decided to direct his weapons at the USA
column6: to topple the government in Washington? Would the world allow him to do that if he had the power? After all the US possesses nuclear
column7: biological and chemical weapons. If weapons of mass destruction justified a military attack
column8: is it not Iraq who has the right to attack the United States
column9: if only because it has not yet been proven to possess these weapons?

column1: Should the USA in breach of international law and any humanitarian principle and in disregard of majority opinion at home and in the world really invade Iraq
column2: they will begin a new era of global history
column3: an era which encourages only the law of the fist. Is this the new global order
column4: which President Bush and Mr Rumsfeld

Sulak Sivaraksa
column2: Thai activist and teacher

column1: If one must summarise Buddhism in one word
column2: then it would be ahimsa or non-violence. In order to act non-violently
column3: one must overcome the three poisons of the mind and sources of violence - greed
column5: and delusion - through mindfulness and loving kindness.

column1: Non-violence does not mean inaction or omission. It requires continuous and active dialogue with others
column2: and overcoming dualisms that pit ""us"" against ""them""
column3: human against subhuman. It is the recognition that
column5: ""An eye for an eye just makes the whole world blind."" Is it really greed for oil and power in the Middle East that is blinding Bush and Blair
column6: with the disarmament of Iraq as the deceitful but easily refutable pretext for war? Is it hatred that enables them to render 23 million Iraqis
column7: already facing a humanitarian crisis after ten years of economic sanctions
column8: faceless and reduce them to one hated figure

column1: Another war would not only lead to unnecessary loss of life of hundreds of thousands of people
column2: but also trigger a humanitarian disaster in Iraq. Is it the delusion of the lone superpower that makes it so impervious to the growing planetary sentiments against war on Iraq? War on Iraq would be unjust
column3: destructive
column4: and illegal. It would also diminish the faculties for critical self-reflection in the American and British governments
column5: thus hindering the wisdom that is necessary for peace. It is very important to understand that non-violence is an effective and very powerful response to the present conflict.

column1: ©Sulak Sivaraksa 2003

Eyal Weizman
column2: Israeli architect

column1: Nobody has yet managed to provide a good explanation why - even in its own terms - America needs to go to war with Iraq.
Could it be that the true
column2: missing relation between its rhetoric and its plans lies well beyond our ability to see only two steps ahead?

column1: For the latter possibility I have a 1960s technophobic-fantasy version. Somewhere at the renovated Pentagon there is a giant computer that simulates possible scenarios when you press ‘play’. It is a kind of an ‘international relations laboratory’ that runs alternative futures in fast forward mode.
Maybe when they ran it often enough
column2: it no longer came up with deadly urban warfare in Iraq
column3: a massive humanitarian problem or a wave of global terrorism. Maybe Sharon withdrew from the West Bank and established Palestine. Maybe Iran
column4: rubbing shoulders with half a million Americans
column5: switched to the west again. Maybe Saudi Arabia brought science back into its textbooks.

column1: This is a simple call for the American administration to come clean - and tell us what the end-game is (or put the software on the web)
column2: and why what we think will happen will not happen. In an age when even ‘good causes’ are questionable
column3: how can we be expected to accept something whose relation to any cause or common-sense is so feeble? And yet we do.

column1: ©Eyal Weizman 2003

column1: Some of you may get this twice. Sorry. I'm mass-posting this. My apologies.
In short
column2: for those in the know (most of you): They're back. Yes
column3: I mean ""they."" Them. Those. The infamous black-eyed kids. But not to me. This time
column4: they've appeared to a trusted friend who didn't know my orignal story.

column1: I'm a channel operator on the Undernet #ghosts channel. Generally a fun time is had by all
column2: but last night was not.

column1: This is going to be very
column2: very long
column3: people. I'm sorry.

column1: I'll repost my original story first for background. Those who've read it hundreds of times can skip to the IRC transcript below it.
Evil Kids
Date: Fri
From: ""Brian Bethel"" (brianbet@camalott.com)
To: ghost-discuss@lido.com
Subject: Those Darned Black-Eyed Kids
Ghosters:
Well
column2: believe it or not
column3: the Ram Page follow-up still languishes unfinished on my hard drive. I don't know when I'll have it done
column4: and I'll probably have to break it up into multiple posts to get it in any way manageable. Patience

column1: But since a lot of people seem to be requesting this one
column2: here's some info on those darned black-eyed kids.

column1: I've just woken up from a mega nap. It's 1 a.m. I'll never get to sleep again. So why not write
column2: eh? I guess I was exhausted from too many forays onto Sixth Street in Austin at my reporting conference.

column1: Enjoy. Or whatever. :)
I don't really know what I'd call this story if I was submitting it for publication in Fate or something of its ilk. ""Brian vs. the Evil
column2: Black-eyed
column3: Possibly Vampiric or Demonic But At Least Not Bloody Normal Kids"" doesn't have much of a ring to it. (Shrug.) :)

column1: But that's at least an accurate title.
As so many things do
column2: it all started out innocently.

column1: My Internet Service Provider used to have offices in a shopping center before they moved to their (comparatively) lush accommodations elsewhere. There was a drop box at that original location. The monthly bill was due
column2: and thus
column3: there but for the Grace of the Net I went.

column1: It was about 9:30 p.m. when I left. From my relatively isolated apartments
column2: it's about 10-15 minutes or so to downtown (Abilene has a population of about 110

column1: Right next to Camalott Communications' old location is a $1.50 movie theater. At the time
column2: the place was featuring that masterwork of modern film
column3: Mortal Kombat. I drove by the theater on the way into the center proper and pulled into an empty parking space.

column1: Using the glow of the marquee to write out my check
column2: I was startled to hear a knock on the driver's-side window of my car.

column1: I looked over and saw two children staring at me from street. I need to describe them
column2: with the one feature (you can guess what it was) that I didn't realize until about half-way through the conversation cleverly omitted.

column1: Both appeared to be in that semi-mystical stage of life children get into where you can't exactly tell their age. Both were boys
column2: and my initial impression is that they were somewhere between 10-14.

column1: Boy No. 1 was the spokesman. Boy No. 2 didn't speak during the entire conversation -- at least not in words.
Boy No. 1 was slightly taller than his companion
column2: wearing a pull-over
column3: hooded shirt with a sort of gray checked pattern and jeans. I couldn't see his shoes. His skin was olive-colored and had curly
column4: medium-length brown hair. He exuded an air of quiet confidence.

column1: Boy No. 2 had pale skin with a trace of freckles. His primary characteristic seemed to be looking around nervously. He was dressed in a similar manner to his companion
column2: but his pull-over was a light green color. His hair was a sort of pale orange.

column1: They didn't appear to be related
column2: at least directly.

column1: Oh
column2: great
column3: I thought. ""They're gonna hit me up for money."" And then the air changed.

column1: I've explained this before
column2: but for the benefit of any new lurkers out there
column3: right before I experience something strange
column4: there's a change in perception that comes about which I describe in the above manner. It's basically enough time to know it's too late. ;)

column1: So
column2: there I was
column3: filling out a check in my car (which was still running) and in a sudden panic over the appearance of two little boys. I was confused
column4: but an overwhelming sense of fear and unearthliness rushed in nonetheless.

column1: The spokesman smiled
column2: and the sight for some inexplicable reason chilled my blood. I could feel fight-or-flight responses kicking in. Something
column3: I knew instinctually
column5: but I didn't know what it could possibly be.

column1: I rolled down the window very
column2: very slightly and asked ""Yes?""

column1: The spokesman smiled again
column2: broader this time. His teeth were very
column3: very white.

column1: Hey
column2: mister
column3: what's up? We have a problem
column4: he said. His voice was that of a young man
column6: quiet calm and ... something I still couldn't put my finger on ... made my desire to flee even greater. ""You see
column7: my friend and I want to see the films
column9: he continued. ""We need to go to our house to get it. Want to help us out?""

column1: Okay. Journalists are required to talk to lots of people
column2: and that includes children. I've seen and spoken to lots of them. Here's how that usually goes:

column1: Uh ... M ... M ... Mister? Can I see that camera? I ... I won't break it or anything. I promise. My dad has a camera
column2: and he lets me hold it sometimes
column3: I guess
column4: and I took a picture of my dog -- it wasn's very good
column5: 'cause I got my finger in the way and ...""

column1: Add in some feet shuffling and/or body swaying and you've got a typical kid talking to a stranger.
In short
column2: they're usually apologetic. People generally teach children that when they talk to adults
column3: they're usually bothering them for one reason or another and they should at least be polite.

column1: This kid was in no way fitting the mold. His command of language was incredible and he showed no signs of fear. He spoke as if my help was a foregone conclusion. When he grinned
column2: it was as if he was trying to say
column3: ""I know something ... and you're NOT gonna like it. But the only way you're going to find out what it is will be to do what I say ...""

column1: Uh
column2: well ..."" was the best reply I could offer.

column1: Now here's where it starts to get strange.
The quiet companion looked at the spokesman with a mixture of confusion and guilt on his face. He seemed in some ways shocked
column2: not with his friend's brusque manner but that I didn't just immediately open the door.

column1: He eyed me nervously.
The spokesman seemed a bit perturbed
column2: too. I still was registering something wrong with both.

column1: C'mon
column2: mister
column3: the spokesman said again
column4: smooth as silk. Car salesmen could learn something from this kid. ""Now
column5: we just want to go to our house. And we're just two little boys.""

column1: That really scared me. Something in the tone and diction again sent off alarm bells. My mind was frantically trying to process what it was perceiving about the two figures that was ""wrong.""
Eh. Um ...."" was all I could manage. I felt myself digging my fingernails into the steering wheel.
What movie were you going to see?"" I asked finally.
Mortal Kombat
column2: of course
column3: the spokesman said. The silent one nodded in affirmation

column1: Oh
column2: I said. I stole a quick glance at the marquee and at the clock in my car. Mortal Kombat had been playing for an hour
column3: the last showing of the evening.

column1: The silent one looked increasingly nervous. I think he saw my glances and suspected that I might be detecting something was not above-board.
C'mon
column2: mister. Let us in. We can't get in your car until you do
column3: you know
column4: the spokesman said soothingly. ""Just let us in
column5: and we'll be gone before you know it. We'll go to our mother's house.""

column1: We locked eyes.
To my horror
column2: I realized my hand had strayed toward the door lock (which was engaged) and was in the process of opening it. I pulled it away
column3: probably a bit too violently. But it did force me to look away from the children.

column1: I turned back. ""Er ... Um ...
column2: I offered weakly and then my mind snapped into sharp focus.

column1: For the first time
column2: I noticed their eyes.

column1: They were coal black. No pupil. No iris. Just two staring orbs reflecting the red and white light of the marquee.
At that point
column2: I know my expression betrayed me. The silent one had a look of horror on his face in a combination that seemed to indicate: A) The impossible had just happened and B) ""We've been found out!""

column1: The spokesman
column2: on the other hand
column3: wore a mask of anger. His eyes glittered brightly in the half-light.

column1: Cmon
column2: mister
column3: he said. ""We won't hurt you. You have to LET US IN. We don't have a gun ...""

column1: That last statement scared the living hell out of me
column2: because at that point by his tone he was plainly saying
column3: ""We don't NEED a gun.""

column1: He noticed my hand shooting down toward the gear shift. The spokesman's final words contained an anger that was complete and whole
column2: and yet contained in some respects a tone of panic:

column1: WE CAN'T COME IN UNLESS YOU TELL US IT'S OKAY. LET ... US .... IN!""
I ripped the car into reverse (thank goodness no one was coming up behind me) and tore out of the parking lot. I noticed the boys in my peripheral vision
column2: and I stole a quick glance back.

column1: They were gone. The sidewalk by the theater was deserted.
I drove home in a heightened state of panic. Had anyone attempted to stop me
column2: I would have run on through and faced the consequences later.

column1: I bolted into my house
column2: scanning all around -- including the sky.

column1: What did I see? Maybe nothing more than some kids looking for a ride.
And some really funky contacts. Yeah
column2: right.

column1: A friend suggested they were vampires
column2: what with the old ""let us in"" bit and my compelled response to open the door. That and the ""we'll go see our mother"" thing.

column1: I'm still not sure what they were
column2: but here's an epilogue I find chilling:

column1: I talk about Chad a lot. He's still my best friend
column2: my best ghost-hunting companion and an all-around cool guy. He recently moved to Amarillo
column3: but at the time this happened was still living in San Angelo of Ram Page fame.

column1: I called him and talked to him briefly. He had two female friends with him at the time
column2: both professing some type of psychic ability.

column1: I started telling him the story
column2: leaving out the part about the black eyes for the kicker. One of the women (we were on a speakerphone) stopped me.

column1: These children had black eyes
column2: right?"" she asked. ""I mean
column3: all-black eyes?""

column1: Er ... Yes."" I said. I was a bit taken aback.
Hmmm
column2: she said. ""One night last week
column3: I had a dream about children with black eyes. They were outside my house
column5: but there was something wrong with them. It took me a while to realize it was the eyes.""

column1: I hadn't even gotten as far as them wanting to come in.
What did you do?"" I asked.
I kept the doors and windows locked
column2: she said. ""I knew if they came in
column3: they would kill me.""

column1: She paused.
And they would have killed you
column2: too
column3: if you had let them into your car.""

column1: So
column2: from this extra-long post
column3: we have three unanswered questions:

column1: A) What did I see?
B) What would have happened if I opened my car door?
C) Why does Chad always get the cool psychic chicks? ;)
Well
column2: there you have it. I'll write some more later. But for now
column3: your comments are welcomed as always.

Okay. Original's there. Now check this out:
I should preface this by saying that Jon Northwood is one of my very good Internet friends. A gentleman of high intelligence and candor
column2: he's an investigator for SPIRIT
column3: a pagan rights coordinator in his home state of Oregon and one of the nicest fellows I've ever met. He doesn't joke around about the paranormal.

column1: Which is why this scares me to no end. I'm absolutely certain it's true.
Jon and I had never talked about the ""black-eyed kids"" before. In fact
column2: he wasn't aware that I had an experience like his.

column1: He swears that all of the text below is true.
I believe him
(I'm THOTH in the transcript
column2: by the way.)

column1: <Hellraisr> ah I remember that Thoth
<Hellraisr> remember u telling it
<Lykaon> jeez!
<Thoth> It was most disturbing.
<Lykaon> just regular kids but with black eyes...
<JonNrthwd> I was in downtown Portland (Oregon) after a seminar series on software development. I'd grabbed a bite of dinner about 10pm
column2: and when I left it was about 11(ish). I'd grabbed a bite of dinner about 10pm
column3: and when I left it was about 11(ish).

column1: <JonNrthwd> I'd gotten in my car
column2: locked and belted up and just started the

column1: engine when someone tapped on my window.
<Thoth> This sounds ... incredibly familiar
column2: Jon.

column1: <JonNrthwd> I was in an above-ground garage on the third floor
column2: so I wasn't too freaked (good lighting
column3: still some people around).

column1: <JonNrthwd> It was one of the guys from the conference
column2: so I rolled down my window and asked him what was up.

column1: <JonNrthwd> He wanted a ride around the block a few times
column2: as he was freaked about who was standing outside his car.

column1: <JonNrthwd> I figured (so sue me) that it was some of Portland's homeless
column2: or some punker kids. So
column3: being a good Samaritan
column4: I let him in and we took off.

column1: <JonNrthwd> We drove by his car
column2: and there were three kids around it
column3: two boys and a girl.

column1: <JonNrthwd> The girl was . . . weird. Just freaky. Y'know
column2: clothes and hair and makeup -- Goth-O-Matic. <g>

column1: <JonNrthwd> The two kids were . . . I dunno . . . just scary as shit.
<Lykaon> thats goths for ya..heh..
<Lykaon> how old roughly?...
<JonNrthwd> She was probably fourteen or fifteen
column2: the oldest boy was probably fourteen(ish) and the youngest between ten and twelve.

column1: <JonNrthwd> She looked bored and was smoking a cigarette
column2: the two boys were just leaning against the car.

column1: <JonNrthwd> They looked _way_ too intense for kids.
<JonNrthwd> Anyway
column2: I started itching behind my eyes
column3: like I needed to really look at them

column1: <JonNrthwd> BIG mistake.
<JonNrthwd> The two boys sauntered over and the girl stayed against the car.
<JonNrthwd> The eldest was on Doug's side (the guy from the seminar) and the youngest was on mine.
<JonNrthwd> I made sure the doors were locked (I love electronic locks) and asked why they were standing around his car.
<JonNrthwd> The young one said ""It's scary out there all alone
column2: and we just wanted a ride home.""

column1: <JonNrthwd> The eldest one said ""You promised you'd help us out"" and Doug said ""I don't even _know_ you.""
<JonNrthwd> By this time
column2: I was really on edge -- I felt caught between throwing up and jazzing -- adrenaline does that to me.

column1: <JonNrthwd> All of a sudden Doug said he was getting out of the car
column2: and I told him not to. As soon as he reached for the handle
column3: the two kids . . . I don't know how to say this right . . . they looked a _lot_ older.

column1: <JonNrthwd> Their faces were somewhat drawn
column2: and their eyes were _solid_ black. Edge to edge -- no pupil
column3: no iris -- nothing. Just a liquid black pool.

column1: <JonNrthwd> I just about wet myself
column2: slapped the car into reverse and burned rubber backing about sixty feet away. They started running after the car
column3: so I spun around one of the support struts and we took off. I kid you not -- I was convinced that if they got ahold of the car
column4: I was going to die -- and not in anything approaching a pleasant fashion.

column1: <JonNrthwd> Anyway
column2: the oldest one was at the bottom of the garage when we came out
column3: and almost made it to my side door.

column1: <Lykaon> preservation instinct prevails yet again...
<JonNrthwd> We'd gone down from the third floor doing thirty-ish
column2: maybe thirty-five around the ramp. He'd _beaten_ us down the stairs and onto the sidewalk.

column1: <JonNrthwd> Anyway
column2: we left him on the corner
column3: and when I turned to look -- nothing. He was gone.

column1: <JonNrthwd> Doug just about passed out.
<JonNrthwd> All of a sudden
column2: the feeling of menace -- left.

column1: <Lykaon> i've never heard of a sighting of those entities in human bodies tho i've had my speculation on the fact that it could happen...
<Hellraisr> did you ever go back there?
<JonNrthwd> We went back about ten minutes later
column2: nobody was around his car.

column1: <JonNrthwd> He got out
column2: got in his car
column3: and drove home.

column1: <JonNrthwd> He'd said that he had met the young one earlier in the evening
column2: and had said he'd take him home -- had even given him a short ride in his car to the seminar and told him to wait. Apparently
column3: though
column5: so he felt that all bets were off.

column1: <JonNrthwd> I was behind him about forty-five feet when the feeling of *menace* hit again. At that moment
column2: Doug misjudged going across an intersection on a yellow light and his car was hit by a truck. He was killed instantly.

column1: <JonNrthwd> I gave a police report
column2: and the whole time
column3: felt _really_ freaked out and very exposed.

column1: <The_JAmis> that's one freaky ass story :/
<JonNrthwd> I got back to my car
column2: got in
column3: locked the door

column1: <JonNrthwd> I saw the kids again
column2: from about two blocks away.

column1: <Hellraisr> wow
<JonNrthwd> I'm not making it up -- I'm not thinking they were ""vampires"" or something like that
column2: but they weren't as pale
column3: they weren't as skinny
column4: and they felt a damn sight more menacing. I left

column1: <JonNrthwd> My only concern now
column2: though
column3: is that this upcoming Wednesday I'm going back to the area for another seminar
column4: and I won't be leaving until 9:30.

column1: <JonNrthwd> I'm _freaked out_
column2: people.

column1: As was I
column2: for obvious reasons.

column1: Okay
column2: now
column3: the commentary:

column1: I've been haunted -- no pun intended -- by this story ever since I decided to share it. Rather than the ridicule I expected
column2: it seems that it touches some sort of strange
column3: primal chord in people.

column1: I've been trying
column2: of course
column3: to move beyond and forget these events
column4: but inevitably something comes along to remind me of it.

column1: Apparently
column2: I've become something of an urban legend. I have people ask me all the time on the Net: ""Hey
column3: did you read the ghost story about the guy who saw the black-eyed kids who wanted to get in his car?""

column1: Yeah
column2: that was me.""

column1: Really? Cool!""
Not exactly.""

And that's something I can't seem to get the point across about. This was not ""cool."" It was not ""just like being in a Stephen King novel!"" or any of the inane comments that sometimes go along with it. It was real
column2: though sometimes it made me feel crazy.

column1: And now
column2: I have a report from someone I trust that an extremely similar event has occurred -- and even resulted in the death of someone
column3: at least indirectly.

column1: In a word: Help?
I need thoughts. I need ideas. I need to calm down. ;) But beyond that ... I just want to know what people think about this?
I've protected myself in my own manner. I am not worried about any danger to me. But this is too close to what I experienced to be mere coincidence.
Your thoughts are welcomed.
Brian

column1: By now

column3: Disney catapulted into the headlines a few weeks ago on reports that there are subliminal sexual messages in three popular Disney videos: ``The Lion King″ and ``The Little Mermaid
column4: ″ as well as ``Aladdin.″ The charges were reported around the world; TV news shows broadcast the offending snippets in slow motion

column1: Disney denies inserting any subliminal messages. And the three allegedly obscene sequences are hardly crystal clear; even using the pause button on a VCR
column2: viewers may debate whether they exist. Yet they have quickly become the stuff of suburban myth
column3: like the ``Paul is dead″ rumor from the heyday of the Beatles or the persistent allegations that Procter & Gamble Co.’s moon-and-stars logo symbolizes devil worship.

column1: AMERICA has entered one of its periods of historical madness
column2: but this is the worst I can remember: worse than McCarthyism
column3: worse than the Bay of Pigs and in the long term potentially more disastrous than the Vietnam war.

column1: The reaction to 9/11 is beyond anything Osama could have hoped for in his nastiest dreams. As in McCarthy times
column2: the domestic rights and freedoms that have made America the envy of the world are being systematically eroded.

column1: The hounding of non-national US residents continues apace. 'Non-permanent' males of North Korean and Middle Eastern descent are disappearing into secret imprisonment on secret charges on the secret word of judges. US-resident Palestinians who were formerly ruled stateless
column2: and therefore not deportable
column3: are being handed over to Israel for 'resettlement' in Gaza and the West Bank
column4: places where they may never have set foot before.

column1: Are we playing the same game here in Britain? I expect so. Another 30 years and we'll be allowed to know.

The combination of compliant US media and vested corporate interests is once more ensuring that a debate that should be ringing out in every town square is confined to the loftier columns of the East Coast press: see page A27 if you can find and understand it.
No American administration has ever held its cards so close to its chest. If the intelligence services know nothing
column2: that will be the best-kept secret of all. Remember that these are the same organisations who brought us the biggest failure in intelligence history: 9/11.

column1: The imminent war was planned years before Osama bin Laden struck
column2: but it was Osama who made it possible. Without Osama
column3: the Bush junta would still be trying to explain such tricky matters as how it came to be elected in the first place; Enron; its shameless favouring of the already-too-rich; its reckless disregard for the world's poor
column4: the ecology and a raft of unilaterally abrogated international treaties. They might also have to be telling us why they support Israel in its continuing disregard for UN resolutions.

column1: But Osama conveniently swept all that under the carpet. Eighty-eight per cent of Americans want the war
column2: we are told. The US defence budget has been raised by another $60 billion to around $360 billion. A splendid new generation of US nuclear weapons is in the pipeline
column3: tailored to respond equally to nuclear
column4: chemical and biological weapons in the hands of 'rogue states'. So we can all breathe easy.

column1: And America is not only deciding unilaterally who may or may not possess these weapons. It also reserves to itself the unilateral right to deploy its own nuclear weapons without compunction whenever and wherever it considers its interests
column2: friends and allies threatened. Precisely who these friends and allies are going to be over the next years will
column3: as ever in politics
column4: be a bit of a conundrum. You make nice friends and allies
column5: so you arm them to the teeth. Then one day they're not your friends and allies any more

column1: It is worth remembering here for just how many long hours
column2: and how deeply
column3: the US cabinet weighed the option of nuking Afghanistan in the wake of 9/11. Happily for all of us
column4: but for the Afghans in particular whose complicity in 9/11 was much less than Pakistan's
column5: they decided to make do with 25
column7: which by all accounts deliver as much clout as a small nuke anyway. But next time it'll be for real.

column1: Quite what war 88% of Americans think they are supporting is a lot less clear. A war for how long
column2: please? At what cost in American lives? At what cost to the American taxpayer's pocket? At what cost -- because most of those 88% are thoroughly decent and humane people -- in Iraqi lives? It is probably by now a state secret
column3: but Desert Storm cost Iraq at least twice as many lives as America lost in the entire Vietnam war.

column1: How Bush and his junta succeeded in deflecting America's anger from Osama bin Laden to Saddam Hussein is one of the great public relations conjuring tricks of history. But they swung it. A recent opinion poll tells us that one in two Americans now believes Saddam was responsible for the attack on the World Trade Centre.
But the American public is not merely being misled. It is being threatened
column2: bullied
column3: browbeaten and kept in a permanent state of ignorance and fear
column4: with a consequent dependence upon its leadership. The carefully orchestrated neurosis should
column6: carry Bush and his fellow conspirators nicely into the next election.

column1: Those who are not with Mr Bush are against him. Worse -- see his speech of January 3 -- they are with the enemy. Which is odd
column2: because I'm dead against Bush
column3: but I would love to see Saddam's downfall -- just not on Bush's terms and not by his methods. And not under the banner of such outrageous hypocrisy.

column1: Old-style American colonialism is about to spread its iron wings over all of us. More Quiet Americans are slipping into unsuspecting townships than at the height of the Cold War.
The religious cant that will send American troops into battle is perhaps the most sickening aspect of this surreal war-to-be. Bush has an arm-lock on God.
And God has very particular political opinions.
God appointed America to save the world in any way that suits America.
God appointed Israel to be the nexus of America's Middle Eastern policy
column2: and anyone who wants to mess with that idea is: a) anti-Semitic
column3: b) anti-American

column1: God also has pretty scary connections. In America
column2: where all men are equal in His sight
column3: if not in one another's
column4: the Bush family numbers one President
column7: the governor of Florida and the ex-governor of Texas. Bush Senior has some good wars to his credit
column8: and a well-earned reputation for visiting America's wrath on disobedient client states. One little war he hand-launched was against his own former CIA pal
column10: who served him well in the Cold War but got too big for his boots when it was over. Power doesn't come much more naked than that

column1: Care for a few pointers?
George W Bush. 1978-84: senior executive
column2: Arbusto Energy/Bush Exploration
column3: an oil company. 1986-1990: senior executive of the Harken oil company.

column1: Dick Cheney. 1995-2000: chief executive of the Halliburton oil company.
Condoleezza Rice. 1991-2000: senior executive with the Chevron oil company
