column1: And so on.
But none of these trifling associations affects the integrity of God's work. We're talking honest values here. And we know where your children go to school.

column2: while ex-President George Bush was paying a social visit to the ever-democratic Kingdom of Kuwait to receive their thanks for liberating them
column3: somebody tried to kill him. The CIA believes that 'somebody' was Saddam Hussein. Hence Bush Junior's cry: 'That man tried to kill my Daddy.' But it's still not personal
column4: this war. It's still necessary. It's still God's work. It's still about bringing freedom and democracy to the poor

column1: To be an acceptable member of the Bush team it seems you must also believe in Absolute Good and Absolute Evil

column3: with a lot of help from his friends
column5: is there to tell us which is which. I think I may be Evil for writing this

column1: What Bush won't tell us is the truth about why we're going to war. What is at stake is not an Axis of Evil -- but oil
column2: money and people's lives. Saddam's misfortune is to sit on the second biggest oilfield in the world. Iran's
column3: next door
column4: is to possess the world's largest repositories of natural gas. Bush wants both
column5: and who helps him get them will receive a piece of the cake. And who doesn't

column1: If Saddam didn't have the oil
column2: he could torture and murder his citizens to his heart's content. Other leaders do it every day -- think Saudi Arabia
column3: think Pakistan
column6: think Egypt -- but these are our friends and allies.

column1: In reality
column2: I suspect
column3: Baghdad represents no clear and present danger to its neighbours
column4: and none to America or Britain. Saddam's weapons of mass destruction
column6: will be peanuts by comparison with the stuff Israel or America could hurl at him at five minutes' notice. What is at stake is not an imminent military or terrorist threat
column7: but the economic imperative of American growth.

column1: What is at stake is not -- as presently offered -- a handful of empty rocket-heads
column2: but America's need to demonstrate its over-arching military power to all of us -- to Europe and Russia and China
column3: and poor mad little North Korea
column4: as well as the Middle East; to show who rules America at home
column5: and who is to be ruled by America abroad.

column1: The most charitable interpretation of Tony Blair's part in all this is that he believed that
column2: by riding the tiger
column3: he could steer it. He can't. Instead
column4: he gave it a phoney legitimacy
column5: and a smooth voice. Now I fear
column6: the same tiger has him penned into a corner
column7: and he can't get out. Ironically
column8: George W himself may be feeling a little bit the same way.

column1: In One-Party Britain
column2: Blair on a lousy turnout was elected supreme leader by about a quarter of the electorate. Given the same public apathy and the continued dismal showing by the opposition parties at the next election
column3: Blair or his successor will achieve similar absolute power with an even smaller proportion of the vote. It is utterly laughable that
column4: at a time when Blair has talked himself against the ropes
column5: neither of Britain's opposition leaders can lay a glove on him. But that's Britain's tragedy
column6: as it is America's: as our governments spin
column8: and the supposed parliamentary alternatives to them merely jockey for their clothes
column9: the electorate simply shrugs and looks the other way. Politicians can never believe how little they deceive us.

column1: So the point in Britain is not which political Party will form a government after the looming shambles
column2: but who will be in the driving seat.

column1: Blair's best chance of personal survival must be that
column2: at the eleventh hour
column3: world protest and an improbably emboldened UN will force Bush to put his gun back in his holster unfired. But what happens when the world's greatest cowboy rides back into town without a tyrant's head to wave at the boys?

column1: Blair's worst chance is that
column2: with or without the United Nations
column3: he will drag us into a war that
column4: if the will to negotiate energetically had ever been there
column5: could have been avoided; a war that has been no more democratically debated in Britain than it has in America or the UN. By doing so
column6: Blair will have helped provoke unforeseeable retaliation
column8: and regional chaos in the Middle East. He will have set back our relations with Europe and the Middle East for decades to come. Welcome to the party of the Ethical Foreign Policy.

column1: There is a middle way
column2: but it's a tough one: Bush dives in without UN approval and Blair stays on the bank. Goodbye to the Special Relationship.

column1: The stink of religious self-righteousness in the American air recalls the British Empire at its worst. Lord Curzon's cloak sits poorly on the shoulders of Washington's fashionably conservative columnists. I cringe even more when I hear my Prime Minister lend his Head Prefect's sophistries to this patently colonialist adventure. His very real anxieties about terror are shared by all sane men. What he can't explain is how he reconciles a global assault on al-Qaeda with a territorial assault on Iraq.
We are in this war
column2: if it takes place
column3: in order to secure the fig-leaf of our special relationship with America
column4: to grab our share of the oil pot
column6: after all the public hand-holding in Washington and Camp David
column7: Blair has to show up at the altar.

column1: 'But will we win
column2: Daddy?'

column1: 'Of course
column2: child. It will all be over while you're still in bed.'

column1: 'Why?'
'Because otherwise Mr Bush's voters will get terribly impatient and may decide not to vote for him after all.'
'But will people be killed
column2: Daddy?'

column1: 'Nobody you know
column2: darling. Just foreign people.'

column1: 'Can I watch it on television?'
'Only if Mr Bush says you can.'
'And afterwards
column2: will everything be normal again? Nobody will do anything horrid any more?'

column1: 'Hush
column2: child
column3: and go to sleep.'

column1: Still

column4: I think. He tried to talk to one of my girlfriends and he said she was cute

“He was off
column2: ” Giovanni Watford
column4: told BuzzFeed News. “He was super stressed-out all the time and talked about guns a lot and tried to hide his face.”

column1: Watford told the site he had been in the same Junior ROTC program as Cruz and that Cruz would complain about bullying at Douglas High.

Broward County Sheriff Steve Israel told reporters the suspect was a former student of the school who was expelled for “disciplinary reasons.” Math teacher Jim Gard told the Miami Herald that Cruz was identified as a threat to the school in previous years.
“We were told last year that he wasn’t allowed on campus with a backpack on him
column2: ” Gard said. “There were problems with him last year threatening students
column3: and I guess he was asked to leave campus.”

column1: Helen Pasciolla
column2: a former neighbor of Cruz
column3: told The New York Times that he had told her his family had been forced to sell their house in the upscale neighborhood because of money problems. She also told the paper both Cruz and his brother were adopted and their adoptive father had died.

column2: Lynda Cruz

column1: “I think she wanted to scare them a little bit

column3: I think

column1: Broward County Public Schools superintendent Robert Runcie told reporters outside the school he was unaware of previous concerns about the student. “We received no warnings
column2: ” he said. “Potentially there could have been signs out there. But we didn’t have any warning or phone calls or threats that were made.”

column1: Ocean Parodie
column2: for his part
column3: felt bad for Cruz—and visited him after he was thrown out of Douglas High.

column1: “After he got expelled he worked at a Dollar Store next to the movie theater
column2: ” Parodie said. “I went there and asked him what happened once. He said he was expelled and was happy that he was thrown out. I felt bad for him. I think just to treat someone differently [for] how they look is wrong
column3: so I tried to treat him like I treat everyone else.”

column1: Parodie was in anatomy class on Monday afternoon when he saw his fellow students running away. Then he heard the fire alarm go off—minutes before school was supposed to end.
“One stairway was crowded
column2: so I went down a different stairway

column4: the administrators didn’t know what was going on. Once they had an idea of what’s going on they sent us to the middle school next to our school. We walked near a canal to stay away from the school in case it showed up.”

column1: A few hours later
column2: Parodie realized the outcast he had pitied was the person who had just executed his schoolmates.

column1: National Historic Landmark

Sherwood Forest Plantation was the home of the 10th U.S. President John Tyler from 1842 until his death in 1862. Sherwood Forest Plantation has been the continuous residence of the Tyler family since the President purchased it in 1842. Known to be the longest frame house in America
column2: it is over 300 feet long. Sherwood Forest Plantation reflects the lifestyle of this mid-19th century Presidential family. Beautifully wooded landscape and 12 dependencies surround President Tyler's home. Sherwood Forest Plantation's grounds are open 9:00 am-5:00 pm daily. Located on State Rt. 5
column3: 14501 John Tyler Highway
column5: VA. 30 minutes from Williamsburg and 45 minutes from Richmond. 804-829-5377. 3 miles west of the courthouse in Charles City County - Tyler Country. John Tyler was the first vice president to ascend to the presidency upon the death of 9th President
column7: first recorded in a 1616 land grant
column8: was originally known as Smith's Hundred. The house
column10: is a classic example of Virginia Tidewater design: big house
column13: and kitchen. It had several owners before Tyler purchased the home and its surrounding 1
column14: 600 acres in 1842. He bought the plantation from his cousin
column16: while he was still in the White House and renamed the plantation ""Sherwood Forest"" referring to his reputation as a political outlaw. The Tyler family still maintain the plantation today through the Sherwood Forest Plantation Foundation. Their children and grandchildren frequently are seen at the Plantation. Sherwood Forest Plantation remains the longest frame house in America -- expanded to its present length of over 300 feet in 1845 when Tyler added a 68-foot ballroom catering to the popular dance of his time
column17: the Virginia Reel. The grounds are 25 acres of terraced gardens and lawn based on the landscape designs of Andrew Jackson Downing of New York and include original outbuildings or dependencies. It is considered one of the most complete plantation yards left in America
column18: dating from c. 1680. Please enjoy your visit to our WWW site. To find your way around
column19: click on the topics listed to the left. Be sure to take the virtual tours! Then be sure to come by and take a real-life tour when you're in Virginia. More detailed information can be found by clicking on the navigational bar at the left or call us at (804) 829-5377. For information
column20: please call or write to our office:

A Quarter Century of Disinformation Exclusive commentary by Greg Lewis
March 2

It's a methodology which has a long history but which has been particularly effective in the U.S. since the late 1960s. It turns out that the media versions of many important events for more than a quarter century have often borne very little relation to the events themselves. John Kerry's involvement in those events
column2: particularly in the aftermath of the War in Vietnam
column3: is one of the elements of that story.

column1: A few weeks ago in a column about Kerry
column2: I referred to what has turned out to be an ""urban legend."" Specifically
column3: based on a ""news"" item that appeared on NewsMax.com
column4: I repeated a reference to a volume of memoirs supposedly published by North Vietnamese General Vo Nguyen Giap in 1985 as the source of an assertion by Colonel Oliver North. After a reader requested a reference to Giap's 1985 ""Memoirs
column5: I did research that convinced me no such volume exists. For that matter
column6: I haven't been able to verify through Fox News that Colonel North actually made the comments he is said to have made and which I repeated. My apologies to Colonel North and to WashingtonDispatch.com readers for including inadequately verified material in my piece on Kerry.

column1: What has emerged for me from all this
column2: however
column3: is something truly bizarre having to do with verifiable and unverifiable reportage and commentary. On the one hand
column4: the current President of the United States (with the backing — depending on which week's polls you refer to and how the poll questions are loaded — of anywhere from just above half to well over 70 percent of the American people) has conducted enormously successful and necessary wars and subsequent police actions in Afghanistan and Iraq. The same was true in the late 1960s and early '70s: Popular support in America for the War in Vietnam held consistently above 50 percent through the end of the war.

column1: On the other hand
column2: as in the Vietnam era
column3: U.S. tactical and strategic successes in Iraq are barely even mentioned in most of the media. The print and broadcast headlines represent such a disconnect from reality that
column4: in the words of comedian Lewis Black
column5: ""It makes you want to stick a pencil in your ear!"" This is the understandable response of someone encountering truly schizophrenic behavior just before realizing that the behavior is actually psychotic and is comprehensible only as such.

column1: And the behavior of the media is at best borderline psychotic
column2: at worst certifiable. News headlines and Op Eds veritably scream out the ""fact"" that the President duped the country into going to war in Iraq on the false pretense of trying to prevent the spread (and the use against the United States) of weapons of mass destruction
column3: which weapons obviously didn't exist
column4: since we haven't been able to sift through every grain of desert sand in Iraq in the past eight months and actually find them. Those same headlines then turn around and announce the story of talks in North Korea aimed at forestalling that dictatorship's further development and deployment of

column1: In Pakistan the story is even scarier. The founder of Pakistan's nuclear weapons program
column2: Abdul Qadeer Khan
column3: has admitted to transferring nuclear weapons technology to Iran
column5: and North Korea. Wonder if Khan had any dealings with Saddam Hussein or members of his regime? I know it sounds preposterous
column6: but people who sell the secrets of how to make nuclear weapons on the black market don't much care who they sell them to. Not everyone believes this
column7: but guys like Khan are bad guys
column8: and their intentions and those of the people who now possess nuclear weapons capability because of them
column9: are not honorable nor beneficent toward the United States.

column1: The point is that you often don't read stories like this in the papers or see them on TV. And if you do

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/generation-giap/	vietnamese general vo nguyen giaps memoirs pinned u.s. military failure in vietnam on antiwar reporting in the american media.	false	[]		David Mikkelson	['http://web.archive.org/web/20010610022952/http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/episodes/11/interviews/giap/'
column2: 'http://web.archive.org/web/20040408003001/http://www.washingtondispatch.com/article_8268.shtml']	http://web.archive.org/web/20010610022952/http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/episodes/11/interviews/giap/	http://web.archive.org/	"Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap is perhaps the most important figure in the early history of communist Vietnam -- with the exception of Ho Chi Minh. At the end of World War II
column3: Ho named Giap commander in chief of the Viet Minh forces fighting French colonial rule. Giap orchestrated the defeat of the French at the battle of Dien Bien Phu in 1953 and remained minister of defense of the newly independent Democratic Republic of Vietnam. He was the chief North Vietnamese military leader in the subsequent war against U.S. forces. This interview

column1: On the battle of Dien Bien Phu:
The Dien Bien Phu campaign is a great and first victory of a feudal colonial nation
column2: whose agricultural economy is backward
column3: against the great imperialist capitalist which has a modern industry and a great army. Thus
column4: it means a lot to us
column5: to people all over the world
column6: and to other countries. This is also how Ho Chi Minh saw it.

column1: We see the Dien Bien Phu victory as the victory [over] the French army and [over] the intervention of the Americans --because in the Dien Bien Phu campaign
column2: 80 percent of the war expenditures were spent by the Americans. The Americans had their hands in it. So the Dien Bien Phu defeat was a defeat for both the French and the Americans. But whether the Americans had drawn the lessons from that
column3: I don't think so. That's why the Americans continued in South Vietnam. ...

column1: When we received news of the Dien Bien Phu victory
column2: everyone practically jumped up in the air
column3: they were so happy about it. But Ho Chi Minh said that this is only victory of the first step: we have yet to fight the Americans. It was very clear then.

column1: On the United States' involvement in Vietnam:

column2: some Americans parachuted into our war zone [for a] meeting [with] our late President Ho Chi Minh. ... Back then
column3: President Roosevelt's attitude was that the U.S. did not want to see events like the war with France coming back to Indochina
column4: but later this attitude was changed. After the August Revolution in 1945
column5: the relationship between Vietnam and the U.S. could have been good
column6: and we wished that it had been good.

column1: Then only the intelligent people or those with vision and wisdom
column2: such as Eisenhower
column3: ... saw the impracticality of the [domino] theory. And any mistakes were due to following the domino theory. They thought that if the theory was put into practice here
column4: it would become the pivotal location for [preventing] the spread of communism to the whole Southeast Asia. So Vietnam was made the central location to check the expansion of communism
column5: and this was what President Kennedy believed

column1: The Americans sent advisers to each and every division in the South Vietnamese [army] before 1965. In 1965
column2: they started to commit big forces. We discussed among ourselves in the Politburo whether at that point it was ... a limited war. We decided that it was already a limited war. We discussed it in the Politburo that with America bringing in gigantic forces was to carry out a new campaign
column3: with the American forces committed
column4: it was not good for America but it would be very hard for us to fight. The struggle would be very fierce but we already concluded that we would win the war. ...

column1: On fighting technologically superior U.S. forces:
When American combat forces were committed
column2: it was a myth that we could not fight and win because they were so powerful. ... [We survived] because of our courage and determination
column3: together with wisdom
column4: tactics and intelligence. During the attacks of B-52s
column5: we shot down a few B-52s and captured documents. One of them was a order by the [U.S.] air command about the targets to be bombed in and around Hanoi and the positions of [our] forces. Some [of the figures] were correct
column6: [but] some were wrong because of our deception [measures]. And our conclusion was that with such anti-air-power measures
column7: the B-52 is not an effective way to fight. ...

column1: We had to resort to different measures
column2: some of which are quite simple
column3: like hiding in man-holes and evacuating to the countryside. And we fought back with all our forces and with every kind of weapon. We fought with anti-aircraft artilleries and with small guns
column4: even though [it was] sometimes solely with the strength of our local force. An 18-year-old girl once said that she followed routes every day and studied the patterns of American flights and when they would attack. I told her that she is a philosopher to understand that
column5: because only philosophers talk about principles. Later she used small gun to shoot down an aircraft from a mountainside. That is an example of the military force of the common people. ... We had ingenuity and the determination to fight to the end.

column1: I appreciated the fact that they had sophisticated weapon systems but I must say that it was the people who made the difference
column2: not the weapons. There was also a human factor involved. [As to] whether they were tempted to use nuclear weapons during the war: there was a time during the Dien Bien Phu campaign in which the Americans were going to use nuclear weapons
column3: and this is back in 1954 during the Eisenhower era. We were also aware of possible use of nuclear weapons and we were prepared for it. But whether the Americans could really use nuclear weapons was a question of international politics
column4: and it also depended on the American allies. But looking at the intertwined forces
column6: the result [of a nuclear blast] would not be good
column7: and the Americans had to think hard. If nuclear weapons were used on locations where the Vietnamese troops were concentrated

column1: On the Ho Chi Minh Trail:
The Ho Chi Minh Trail was a very extensive system; it started with a trail but later became a road. Many roads
column2: actually: the Western road system and the Eastern road systems
column3: criss-crossing here and there. And also there were the extensive systems of gas pipelines and communications lines
column4: and routes on rivers and across the sea. We did everything possible to keep the whole system going. I visited many important points which were subjected to many B-52 bombings 23 out of 24 hours a day; we had many teams working toward maintaining the operation
column5: including a team made up of women who had to use iron rings to defuse the [unexploded] bombs. ...

column1: We made big sacrifices. I visited a dozen girls who maintained the route in Dong Lap of Nghe An Province; they showed me how they invented camouflage to cover the lamps so that those in vehicles can see
column2: but the planes could not see. They urged us to move fast; and they all died during the bombing. There was danger of the trail being cut off
column3: but it never really was cut off. With a long procession of vehicles
column4: and with the bombing from the B-52s
column6: but we had to use both courage and wisdom. There are some routes that the Americans did not know about
column7: but if they had used a telescope they would have seen the routes quite clearly. But we did not use those routes. We used some secret smaller trails as a detour and we went during the day.

column1: On the Tet Offensive:
The Tet Offensive is a long story. ... It was our policy
column2: drawn up by Ho Chi Minh
column3: to make the Americans quit. Not to exterminate all Americans in Vietnam

column1: It could be said [Tet] was a surprise attack which brought us a big victory. For a big battle we always figured out the objectives
column2: the targets
column3: so it was the main objective to destroy the forces and to obstruct the Americans from making war. But what was more important was to de-escalate the war -- because at that time the American were escalating the war -- and to start negotiations. So that was the key goal of that campaign. But of course
column4: if we had gained more than that it would be better.

column1: And [after Tet] the Americans had to back down and come to the negotiating table
column2: because the war was not only moving into the cities
column3: to dozens of cities and towns in South Vietnam
column4: but also to the living rooms of Americans back home for some time. And that's why we could claim the achievement of the objective.

column1: On the U.S. leadership during the war:
In general
column2: I must say they were the most intelligent people
column3: with certain talents such as military
column4: political and diplomacy skills. They were intelligent people. That was the first point that I want to say. The second point I want to say is that they knew little about Vietnam and her people. They didn't understand our will to maintain independence and equality between nations even though these are stated in President Jefferson's manifestation. And so they made mistakes. They did not know the limits of power. ... No matter how powerful you are there are certain limits
column5: and they did not understand it well. ...

column1: The people in the White House believed that Americans would definitely win and there is not chance of defeat. There is a saying which goes
column2: ""If you know the enemy and you know yourself
column3: you would win every single battle."" However
column5: but they did not know much about Vietnam or anything at all about the Vietnamese people. Vietnam is an old nation founded in a long history before the birth of Christ. ... The Americans knew nothing about our nation and her people. American generals knew little about our war theories

column1: During the war everyone in the country would fight and they [would] do so following the Vietnamese war theory. We have a theory that is different from that of the Russians and that of the Americans. The Americans did not understand that. They did not know or understand our nation; they did not know our war strategies. They could not win. How could they win? As our president said
column2: there was nothing more precious than independence and freedom. We had the spirit that we would govern our own nation; we would rather sacrifice than be slaves.

column1: Now that the normalization between our two countries have been established
column2: we hope for better relations
column3: but it should be based on equality. Otherwise
column4: if America is at advantage simply because she is richer
column5: it will be unacceptable for us. Now we hope that American leaders can understand Vietnam and her people better."	Interviews: Vo Nguyen Giap		[]	['americans'

column1: Many of the children were sent there after U.S. immigration authorities accused them of belonging to violent gangs
column2: including MS-13. President Donald Trump has repeatedly cited gang activity as justification for his crackdown on illegal immigration.

column1: Mr. Trump said Wednesday that ""our Border Patrol agents and our ICE agents have done one great job"" cracking down on MS-13 gang members. ""We're throwing them out by the thousands

The youth were being screened as gang-involved individuals. And then when they came into our care
column2: and they were assessed by our clinical and case management staff ... they weren't necessarily identified as gang-involved individuals

column4: a program director at the facility. She testified April 26 before a Senate subcommittee reviewing the treatment of immigrant children apprehended by the Homeland Security Department.

column1: Most children held in the Shenandoah facility who were the focus of the abuse lawsuit were caught crossing the border illegally alone. They were not the children who have been separated from their families under the Trump administration's recent policy and are now in the government's care. But the facility there operates under the same program run by the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement.

column2: after the lawsuit was filed.

The Shenandoah lockup is one of only three juvenile detention facilities in the United States with federal contracts to provide ""secure placement"" for children who had problems at less-restrictive housing. column2: Virginia
column3: a board overseeing the Northern Virginia Juvenile Detention Center voted this week to end its contract to house federal immigration detainees

column1: The Shenandoah detention center was built by a coalition of seven nearby towns and counties to lock up local kids charged with serious crimes. Since 2007
column2: about half the 58 beds are occupied by both male and female immigrants between the ages of 12 and 17 facing deportation proceedings or awaiting rulings on asylum claims. Though incarcerated in a facility similar to a prison
column3: the children detained on administrative immigration charges have not yet been convicted of any crime.

column1: Virginia ranks among the worst states in the nation for wait times in federal immigration courts
column2: with an average of 806 days before a ruling. Nationally
column3: only about half of juveniles facing deportation are represented by a lawyer

column1: On average
column2: 92 immigrant children each year cycle through Shenandoah
column3: most of them from Mexico and Central America.

column1: Wong said many of the 30 or so children housed there on any given day have mental health needs that would be better served in a residential treatment unit. But such facilities are often unwilling to accept children with significant behavioral issues

column1: Wong and other managers at the Shenandoah center

column1: Financial statements reviewed by AP shows the local government commission that operates the center received nearly $4.2 million in federal funds last year to house the immigrant children -- enough to cover about two-thirds of the total operating expenses.

column1: The paper reported that neighbors heard the explosion and rushed to the house to find young Wilson lying in the grass

column1: Initially

column1: One week later

column1: The paper said Wilson led officers to where he buried the rifle used to kill them.

column1: Wilson was tried on homicide charges.
Court records show that three years after he was charged with the murders
column2: Wilson filed with the court for ""mental incapacity to make a rational defense.""

column1: He claimed he suffered from amnesia during the time of the allegations
column2: and with no clear memory of the night's events
column3: was unable to plan his defense with attorneys or tell his side of the story.

column1: The court ordered a jury to decide whether evidence supported Wilson's claims of memory loss.
Four days later
column2: the jury returned its verdict: Wilson indeed suffered from amnesia
column3: they said. The judge ruled Wilson was thus ""not capable of proceeding to trial and making a rational defense.""

column1: The case was ""suspended"" until Wilson could regain enough memory to defend himself
column2: the judge said.

column1: More: Unlocked and loaded: Families confront dementia and guns
Seven years later
column2: in late 1973
column3: Wilson moved to dismiss entirely the charges against him.

column1: According to court filings
column2: his attorney argued that because the district attorney
column3: state and district court had taken no action in seven years
column4: he had been ""deprived of his right to speedy trial."" He added that his witnesses were no longer available because they had died. He motioned for all charges to be dismissed.

column1: The court dismissed his case.
Wilson then moved to Texas for college and law school. After graduating
column2: he practiced law in Texas for 20 years.

column1: Last year
column2: Wilson told the Green Valley News
column3: a southern Arizona publication
column4: that he regained all of his memory of the events in a momentous day as a lawyer.

column1: He was investigating the case of one of his first clients
column2: ""who also had been falsely accused of murder
column3: Wilson told the Green Valley News.

column1: He said he was looking for clues in the woman's vehicle

column1: The horrible
column2: nauseating smells off the car plummeted me back like a lightning bolt to that fateful night in my childhood
column3: and all the memories flooded in
column4: Wilson told the paper. ""It was an incredibly disturbing experience
column5: but it also brought relief: Now I had the truth.""

column1: Wilson told the Green Valley News that after his amnesia subsided
column2: he could fully recount the events of that night in 1963. He proceeded to pen a book and tell his version of the story.

column1: More: Judge temporarily blocks assault weapons ban in Chicago suburb of Deerfield
Wilson moved to Arizona in 1995 to teach law as a college professor.

column2: he also owned a private-investigation agency in Arizona for 10 years.

column1: He teaches paralegals at Rio Salado College. He said he is a three-time recipient of a teaching award for adjunct faculty at the college.

column1: In the interview with The Republic

column1: When I was in high school

column1: In today's world

column3: and yes

column1: Wilson reiterated his belief that legislation will make no difference.

column2: he said. ""They keep looking for a magic-bullet law that they can pass where it’s gonna put an end to the killings and the gun violence
column3: and they're not gonna find the magic bullet. There is no magic bullet.""

column1: In another take on American government
column2: Wilson penned a 2016 book explaining his theory that the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing was part of a government sting operation and that ""a massive cover-up had occurred and possibly an innocent man executed.""

column1: Man who helped save Gabby Giffords responds
State Rep. Daniel Hernandez
column2: D-Tucson
column3: was seated next to Wilson at the forum — what Hernandez called ""a bizarre meeting"" — as both are running to represent Legislative District 2 at the Capitol.

column1: Hernandez was an intern for former Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords in 2011 when she was shot in the head and almost died at a mass shooting outside a Tucson-area supermarket.
He is credited with saving her life. He applied pressure to her forehead wound and made sure she didn't choke on blood.
Giffords was in the audience at the forum.
Hernandez said he was ""so confused"" upon hearing Wilson's comments
column2: and said he checked with Wilson after the event to make sure he heard correctly.

column1: I thought I had misheard him
column2: Hernandez said. ""We were just like 'Wait
column3: what did he just say?!'

column1: More: Two years after the Orlando shooting
column2: young activists hold a die-in on the Capitol lawn

column1: Even though I was sitting right next to him
column2: it just took me aback that at this forum put on by Moms Demand Action
column3: when we were talking about common-sense gun-violence prevention
column4: he was talking about how he had to kill his mother in what I take is self-defense

column1: After his experience at the Jan. 8
column3: shooting
column4: Hernandez became an outspoken advocate for gun-violence prevention at the state and federal levels.

column1: The idea that we can't actually do anything as a policymaker is just something that baffles me to this day

column1: Candidate: Giffords 'created a target'

column1: Wilson said Giffords should have had security with her at the 2011 supermarket meet and greet.

column2: he said. ""Anytime you have a group of celebrities or a group of people like at the forum last night
column3: you better have security there. It's the same with a public school.""

column1: Wilson mentioned that an armed officer was present in the back of the church at Monday's forum

column1: But Hernandez said that even if armed people are present in a violent incident

column3: be it for lack of training or for not wanting to add to the ""confusion"" in a mass-shooting event.

column1: He added that the officer present on Monday was a trained professional.

column2: Hernandez said. ""It was utter shock at hearing a candidate talk about killing his own mother
column3: and then also just being really surprised that he would come to this forum where gun-violence prevention was really the main topic.""

column1: On Friday
column2: her family went to look for her at the garden but found only her belongings

column1: ADVERTISEMENT

column2: ” Faris said. “She was swallowed first from her head.”

column1: Reticulated pythons
column2: which are widespread in Indonesia and other parts of Southeast Asia
column3: grab onto their prey with dozens of sharp curved teeth and then squeeze it to death before swallowing it whole.

column1: Reports of humans being killed by pythons are extremely rare. In the wild they are known to eat monkeys
column2: pigs and other mammals.

column3: 'https://www.sbir.gov/sbirsearch/detail/1207769']	https://www.sbir.gov/sbirsearch/detail/1207769	https://www.sbir.gov/	"Description:

column1: TECHNOLOGY AREA(S): Weapons
OBJECTIVE: Develop biodegradable training ammunition loaded with specialized seeds to grow environmentally beneficial plants that eliminate ammunition debris and contaminants.

DESCRIPTION: Currently the US Army manufactures and consumes hundreds of thousands of training rounds. These rounds are fired at proving grounds and training ranges in the United States and around the world. In addition
column2: special forces conduct day and night training exercises utilizing these training rounds. These rounds include low velocity 40mm grenades; 60mm
column3: 81mm
column4: and 120mm mortars; shoulder launched munitions; 120mm tank rounds; and 155mm artillery rounds. The projectiles
column5: and in some circumstances the cartridge cases and sabot petals
column6: are either left on the ground surface or several feet underground at the proving ground or tactical range. Components of current training rounds require hundreds of years or more to biodegrade. Further
column8: farmers or construction crews) encountering these rounds and components do not know if they are training or tactical rounds. Proving grounds and battle grounds have no clear way of finding and eliminating these training projectiles
column10: especially those that are buried several feet in the ground. Some of these rounds might have the potential corrode and pollute the soil and nearby water. The solution sought by this topic is naturally occurring biodegradable material to replace the current training round materials
column11: eliminating environmental hazards. This SBIR will prove out the technology and replace current training round components with biodegradable parts. The biodegradable materials identified can be utilized by private industry to manufacture biodegradable water bottles
column13: or any other composite or plastic product(s) on the market today. The US Army Corps of Engineers' Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory (CRREL) has demonstrated bioengineered seeds that can be embedded into the biodegradable composites and that will not germinate until they have been in the ground for several months. This SBIR effort will make use of seeds to grow environmentally friendly plants that remove soil contaminants and consume the biodegradable components developed under this project. Animals should be able to consume the plants without any ill effects.

column1: PHASE I: In Phase I the contractor develop a process to produce biodegradable composites with remediation seeds that can be used to manufacture 40mm-120mm training rounds. These Training rounds shall meet all the performance requirements of existing training rounds. The contractor should also explore avenues to produce biodegradable composites with remediation seeds for use in products outside the defense sector.

PHASE II: In Phase II the contractor will prove out the fabrication process and manufacture prototypes that demonstrate the process is ready for industrial use. Provide a sufficient number of prototypes for the government to perform ballistic tests.
PHASE III: Contractor will coordinate with PEO Ammunition and ammunition prime contractors to establish a transition path for the SBIR technology.
REFERENCES:
Satyanarayana

column8: ’ Says Company With Ties to Putin

column1: WASHINGTON – One of the world’s biggest producers of asbestos
column2: a Russian company with ties to Vladimir Putin
column3: is praising President Trump for allowing asbestos to remain legal in the U.S.

column1: The company’s applause for Trump comes as Russia is poised to become the leading importer to the U.S. of asbestos
column2: which causes diseases that kill an estimated 15
column3: 000 Americans a year. A recent study led by Jukka Takala
column4: president of the International Commission on Occupational Health
column5: found the death toll from asbestos exposure may be much higher
column7: 000 Americans a year and more than 255

column1: On June 25
column2: the asbestos producer Uralasbest posted photos on its Facebook page of pallets of its signature product
column3: chrysotile asbestos
column4: wrapped in plastic adorned with Trump’s image. Trump’s picture is at the center of a large red seal declaring: “APPROVED BY DONALD TRUMP

column1: Photo: Uralasbest OJSC
column2: via Facebook

column1: In an English translation of the post
column2: Uralasbest said:

column1: Donald is on our side! … He supported the head of the United States Environmental Protection Agency
column2: Scott Pruitt
column3: who stated that his agency would no longer deal with negative effects potentially derived from products containing asbestos. Donald Trump supported a specialist and called asbestos “100% safe after application.""

column1: Pruitt resigned as EPA administrator last week
column2: after an 18-month tenure marred by ethical scandals
column3: profligate spending of taxpayer dollars and aggressive attempts to roll back public health protections. One of his last decisions was to exclude so-called legacy uses of asbestos from the scope of an ongoing safety assessment. He also declined to ban new uses of asbestos. The Obama administration had designated asbestos a priority for a new safety assessment under the nation’s new toxic chemicals law.

column1: Trump has long rejected the scientific consensus that asbestos is so dangerous that there is no safe level of exposure. In his 1997 book
column2: “The Art of the Comeback
column3: ” the future president claimed asbestos is “100 percent safe
column5: he tweeted that if asbestos had not been removed from the World Trade Center
column6: the twin towers “would never have burned down” in the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

column1: Not to be outdone in showering adoration on Trump
column2: Kostanai Minerals
column3: the largest chrysotile asbestos producer in neighboring Kazakhstan
column4: shared the post on its own Facebook page.

column1: Uralasbest claims its asbestos mine in the Ural Mountains city of Asbest is the largest in the world. According to an investigation by the Center for Public Integrity
column3: Putin met with the head of the Uralasbest workers union
column4: who said he “promised to support Russian producers of chrysotile
column5: especially in situations where we find ourselves under political pressure at the international level.” The Center also reported that Kostanai Minerals has received financial backing from state-controlled banks in both Russia and Kazakhstan.

column1: According to the U.S. Geological Survey
column3: roughly 95 percent of the asbestos imported into the U.S. came from Brazil
column4: with the rest coming from Russia. The Commerce Department and the U.S. International Trade Commission estimate that 705 metric tons of asbestos came into the U.S. in 2016
column5: compared to 343 metric tons the year before.

column1: But in November
column2: Brazil joined more than 60 other nations and banned asbestos. Brazil’s ban leaves Russia
column3: Kazakhstan and China as the world’s dominant asbestos producers. With Brazil no longer providing the vast majority of asbestos to the U.S.
column4: Russia and Kazakhstan could fill the void.

column1: “Vladimir Putin and Russia’s asbestos industry stand to prosper mightily as a result of the Trump Administration’s failure to ban asbestos in the U.S.
column2: ” said EWG President Ken Cook. “Helping Putin and Russian oligarchs amass fortunes by selling a product that kills thousands each year should never be the role of a U.S. president or the EPA
column3: but this is the Trump administration. Russia’s interests are Trump’s interests
column4: and any clear-eyed American knows it.”

column1: “By allowing asbestos to remain legal
column2: the Trump administration would be responsible for a flood of asbestos imports from Russia and other countries into the U.S.
column3: as well as the wave of illnesses and deaths that will continue for years to come
column5: co-founder and president of the Asbestos Disease Awareness Organization. “Americans know Putin does not have their interests at heart
column6: but it’s becoming increasingly apparent that neither does Trump.”

column1: Trump and Putin are scheduled to hold a one-on-one summit in Helsinki
column2: Finland
column3: on July 16. The agenda for the meeting has not been made public
column4: but it is safe to assume talks over trade between the two countries could be part of the discussion.

column1: This comes as the federal agency Housing and Urban Development is rolling out its nationwide ban on smoking in public housing
column2: and just a few years after many states have outlawed smoking in beaches and public parks. This trend raises the question: Are we getting closer to prohibiting tobacco smoking altogether? And would that be such a bad thing?

column1: “In America
column2: it’s very difficult to be simply paternalistic
column3: ” Ronald Bayer
column4: co-director of the Center for the History and Ethics of Public Health at Columbia University’s Mailman School of Public Health
column5: tells Yahoo Lifestyle. American values of privacy and freedom make it very difficult to prohibit anything as mainstream as tobacco
column6: even if it’s to save the lives of smokers. That old “nanny state” argument rears its head every time.

column1: Smoking isn’t good for anyone
column2: but would an all-out ban work? (Photo: Getty Images)
a Gallup poll found that 79 percent of Americans would be against an outright ban of smoking. On the other hand
column3: 56 percent were in favor of prohibiting smoking in public places. The difference is that people accept the concept of protecting nonsmokers from the dangers of secondhand smoke.

column2: the surgeon general declared that there is no risk-free level of second-hand smoke. So even if some are skeptical that smoke coming in from the street to the second or third floor of a building would do real damage to nonsmoking residents
column3: second-hand smoke is the only politically acceptable grounds for such laws.

column1: You won’t hear anyone arguing that smoking with children in the car is a good thing either.
“Exposing a child to smoke in a closed environment is really unhealthy
column2: ” Bayer says. But laws like Alabama’s pose other problems
column3: and he wonders if this would become a new way to target minorities
column4: like controversial “stop and frisk” policies. “How are you going to enforce it?” he asks. “Are people of color going to be stopped more frequently and searched to see if they are smoking? … The questions of enforceability and what intrusions are necessary to enforce it are critically important.”

column1: Story continues
Alabama has passed a bill to ban smoking in vehicles with any riders under the age of 19. (Photo: Getty Images)
While there is plenty of evidence that public space and workplace bans on smoking improve the health of adults and their children
column2: not even the scholars trying to envision a future without tobacco smoking are pushing for all-out prohibition. One of the stumbling blocks for prohibition would be the disproportionate affect such a law would have on the poor.

column1: “About 5 percent of people with a graduate degree smoke and about 30 percent of people with a GED smoke
column2: so there’s a very steep social gradient
column3: ” Bayer explains.

column1: With millions of people still addicted to cigarettes
column2: there is also the very real fear that a ban would spawn a black market similar to what exists with illegal drugs or what happened with alcohol during Prohibition.

column1: Bayer suggests that one way to help people quit would be by tackling the problem from the supply side. “I think we would do much better to think about reducing the nicotine content
column2: so that the addictive quality of cigarettes wasn’t as severe
column3: and make quitting easier.”

column1: The World Health Organization’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control established a method called MPOWER in 2008 that aims to end the “global tobacco epidemic
column2: ” which kills over 7 million people each year. The way to do this is not by banning it all at once
column3: but instead by monitoring use and prevention
column5: offering ways to help people quit
column6: warning people of the dangers of smoking
column8: and raising taxes on tobacco products.

column1: Four Wilmington Police Department officers shot Jeremy McDole on September 23
column2: 2015. The Delaware Department of Justice (DOJ) undertook an investigation to determine whether any of the four officers should be charged with a criminal offense. As detailed in this report
column3: DOJ also examined whether
column4: notwithstanding any potential violations of criminal law
column5: there were deficiencies in the Wilmington Police Department’s policies and/or training that should be corrected in light of Mr. McDole’s shooting
column6: to ensure that similar incidents do not occur in the future.

column1: Our investigation revealed serious deficiencies in the way in which the Wilmington Police Department prepares its police officers to deal with situations like the one that Mr. McDole presented
column2: specifically with regard to use of force policies and training and policies for dealing with individuals with mental illness
column3: disabilities
column5: we find that the “continuum of force” provisions of the Wilmington Police Department’s use of force policy are effectively meaningless for police officers as currently written.

column1: With respect to three of the four officers – Senior Corporal (S/Cpl) Daniel Silva
column2: Corporal (Cpl) Thomas Lynch
column3: and Corporal (Cpl) James MacColl – DOJ did not find probable cause to charge them with a criminal offense. Through our investigation
column4: we determined that these three officers believed – at the moment they discharged their firearms – that doing so was necessary to protect themselves
column6: against death or serious physical injury. Because of that belief
column7: they were entitled under Delaware law to use deadly force to subdue Mr. McDole. Under Delaware’s deferential legal standard for the use of deadly force by a law enforcement officer
column8: their subjective belief that using deadly force was necessary to protect themselves or others immunizes them from criminal responsibility.

column1: With respect to the fourth police officer who discharged his firearm
column2: Senior Corporal (S/Cpl) Joseph Dellose
column3: the Attorney General did believe that the state should attempt to gather sufficient evidence to pursue a felony assault charge
column4: based upon S/Cpl Dellose’s conduct in immediately confronting Mr. McDole rather than communicating with officers who S/Cpl Dellose knew were already on the scene
column5: and discharging his shotgun in the manner that he did. However
column6: after hiring a former federal prosecutor from Pennsylvania to prepare a case for possible criminal prosecution and after consulting with two nationally recognized police use-of-force experts who had recently recommended criminal charges against the Cleveland police officer who shot Tamir Rice
column7: and after receiving opinions from both of those experts that S/Cpl Dellose’s actions did not constitute criminal conduct under the Delaware Code
column8: DOJ concluded that it could not proceed with a criminal prosecution against S/Cpl Dellose given that the defense would present unchallenged expert testimony that S/Cpl Dellose’s conduct was reasonable.

column1: Although DOJ is not able to pursue criminal charges against S/Cpl Dellose
column2: it is DOJ’s position that S/Cpl Dellose’s conduct in this case was extraordinarily poor police work that endangered both the public and his fellow officers. DOJ does not believe that S/Cpl Dellose should be employed by the Wilmington Police Department in any role where he would be carrying a firearm in public.

column1: Scope of Investigation

The scope of the investigation into Mr. McDole’s death was much broader than the scope of prior investigations that have been undertaken by DOJ regarding police-involved shootings. There were a number of reasons for this. First
column2: this case was the first police-involved shooting since Attorney General Denn assumed responsibility in January 2015 where there was a bona fide question as to whether the individual who was shot was armed with a weapon at or around the time of the shooting. This created a need for a broader factual investigation. Second
column3: concerns were raised by Mr. McDole’s family as to (among other things) (1) the integrity of the scene of the shooting (and
column5: whether evidence may have been placed at the scene by Wilmington Police Department officers)
column6: (2) the possibility of prior contact between Mr. McDole and one or more of the officers involved
column7: and (3) the possibility of additional video of the incident. All of these issues had to be thoroughly investigated by DOJ investigators
column8: in addition to their investigation of the shooting incident itself. Third
column9: a decision was made early in the investigation that
column10: notwithstanding any issues of criminal liability
column11: the shooting raised serious questions about the Wilmington Police Department’s preparation of its officers
column12: which DOJ should attempt to address through the use of outside experts for the future benefit of both the Wilmington Police Department and other Delaware police departments. All of these factors resulted in an investigation that was more extensive than other investigations of police-involved shootings.

column1: Finally
column2: the preliminary conclusion that DOJ should attempt to gather sufficient evidence to pursue a felony assault charge against S/Cpl Dellose required that DOJ (a) recruit
column3: hire
column4: and deputize a former federal prosecutor who was not a member of the Delaware bar to prepare the case for possible presentation to a Delaware grand jury
column5: and (b) consult with two national experts with respect to police conduct who had supported criminal charges against a Cleveland police officer with respect to the shooting of Tamir Rice
column6: in order to determine whether the facts collected by DOJ were sufficient to initiate a criminal prosecution against S/Cpl Dellose. DOJ first consulted with Jeffrey Noble
column7: former Deputy Chief of the Irvine Police Department in California
column8: who has been involved in over one thousand police use-of-force investigations and
column10: authored an expert opinion on behalf of Tamir Rice’s family that criticized the expert opinions of the Cleveland District Attorney and argued that the Cleveland police officer who shot Tamir Rice should be held responsible for his death. After reviewing all of the materials in the McDole case
column13: S/Cpl Dellose’s conduct did not violate Delaware’s criminal statute. After receiving Mr. Noble’s opinion
column14: DOJ solicited a second opinion from Roger Clark
column15: the former head of the Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department’s North Regional Surveillance and Apprehension Team. Mr. Clark has been retained as a consulting expert 1
column17: the majority of times for cases involving the use of force
column19: authored an expert opinion last year on behalf of Tamir Rice’s family that criticized the expert opinions of the Cleveland District Attorney and argued that the Cleveland police officer who shot Tamir Rice should be held responsible for his death. Like Mr. Noble
column20: Mr. Clark reviewed all of the materials in this case
column23: S/Cpl Dellose’s conduct did not violate Delaware’s criminal statute.

column1: DOJ’s investigation included:
In the days immediately after the shooting
column2: a broad-based neighborhood canvass involving multiple DOJ investigators to locate eyewitnesses
column3: video or audio evidence
column4: or any other information that would help DOJ prosecutors to understand all relevant facts from the incident in which Mr. McDole was shot. This canvass was accompanied by a public request through traditional media and social media for persons with information to come forward.

column1: Ballistic evidence was analyzed by Carl M. Rone of the Delaware State Police Forensic Firearms Services Unit. The evidence itself was gathered by the Wilmington Police Department and the Delaware Division of Forensic Science from the crime scene.
Performance of an autopsy by the Delaware Medical Examiner’s office. This autopsy
column2: which was received by DOJ on January 28

column1: Interviews of Wilmington Police Department officers who were at the scene of Mr. McDole’s shooting and civilian witnesses. Some of these interviews were conducted by Wilmington Police Department officers and observed by DOJ investigators
column2: others were conducted jointly between DOJ and WPD officers
column3: and some were conducted by DOJ investigators outside the presence of WPD officers.

column1: Interviews by DOJ of members of Mr. McDole’s family (accompanied by their legal counsel)
column2: followed by interviews of persons identified by those family members as potentially having relevant knowledge.

column1: Subpoenaing and reviewing thousands of pages of documents from the Wilmington Police Department
column2: and hundreds of pages of documents from other third parties.

column1: Microscopic examination of swabs taken from Mr. McDole’s hands by the R.J. Lee group
column2: an independent laboratory. The swabs themselves were gathered by the Wilmington Police Department at the scene

column1: Video evidence
column2: including a version of the cell phone video processed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation
column3: providing a detailed review of the images captured by the cell phone video.

column1: Collection and review of video evidence from multiple stationary locations in the area of Mr. McDole’s shooting.
Retention of experts in police policies and training to review the policies and trainings of the Wilmington Police Department
column2: in order to identify any relevant deficiencies relating to the incident involving Mr. McDole.

column1: Retention of an attorney from the Pennsylvania bar (a former federal prosecutor) sworn as a Delaware DOJ Special Deputy Attorney General to prepare the case for possible prosecution
column2: in order to avoid any real or perceived conflicts presented by DOJ prosecutors presenting a case involving criminal charges against a Wilmington Police Department officer.

column1: Retention of two national experts in police practices to determine whether
column2: if charges were filed
column3: the State could rebut expert testimony expected from the defendant officer with respect to the justification of his conduct under Title 11
column4: Section 464 of the Delaware Code. As noted above
column5: the national experts retained by DOJ were the two experts retained by Tamir Rice’s family who recommended criminal charges against a police officer in Cleveland
column6: Ohio for the police shooting incident that led to Tamir Rice’s death.

column1: (a) Classes of deportable aliens
Any alien (including an alien crewman) in and admitted to the United States shall
column2: upon the order of the Attorney General
column3: be removed if the alien is within one or more of the following classes of deportable aliens:

column1: (1) Inadmissible at time of entry or of adjustment of status or violates status
(A) Inadmissible aliens
Any alien who at the time of entry or adjustment of status was within one or more of the classes of aliens inadmissible by the law existing at such time is deportable.
(B) Present in violation of law
Any alien who is present in the United States in violation of this chapter or any other law of the United States
column2: or whose nonimmigrant visa (or other documentation authorizing admission into the United States as a nonimmigrant) has been revoked under section 1201(i) of this title
column3: is deportable.

column1: (C) Violated nonimmigrant status or condition of entry
(i) Nonimmigrant status violators
Any alien who was admitted as a nonimmigrant and who has failed to maintain the nonimmigrant status in which the alien was admitted or to which it was changed under section 1258 of this title
column2: or to comply with the conditions of any such status
column3: is deportable.

column1: (ii) Violators of conditions of entry
Any alien whom the Secretary of Health and Human Services certifies has failed to comply with terms
column2: conditions
column3: and controls that were imposed under section 1182(g) of this title is deportable.

column1: (D) Termination of conditional permanent residence
(i) In general

Any alien with permanent resident status on a conditional basis under section 1186a of this title (relating to conditional permanent resident status for certain alien spouses and sons and daughters) or under section 1186b of this title (relating to conditional permanent resident status for certain alien entrepreneurs
column2: spouses
column3: and children) who has had such status terminated under such respective section is deportable.

column1: (ii) Exception
Clause (i) shall not apply in the cases described in section 1186a(c)(4) of this title (relating to certain hardship waivers).
(E) Smuggling
(i) In general
Any alien who (prior to the date of entry
column2: at the time of any entry
column3: or within 5 years of the date of any entry) knowingly has encouraged
column7: or aided any other alien to enter or to try to enter the United States in violation of law is deportable.

column1: (ii) Special rule in the case of family reunification
Clause (i) shall not apply in the case of alien who is an eligible immigrant (as defined in section 301(b)(1) of the Immigration Act of 1990)
column2: was physically present in the United States on May 5
column4: and is seeking admission as an immediate relative or under section 1153(a)(2) of this title (including under section 112 of the Immigration Act of 1990) or benefits under section 301(a) of the Immigration Act of 1990 if the alien
column11: or aided only the alien's spouse
column14: or daughter (and no other individual) to enter the United States in violation of law.

column1: (iii) Waiver authorized
The Attorney General may
column2: in his discretion for humanitarian purposes
column3: to assure family unity
column4: or when it is otherwise in the public interest

column9: or aided only an individual who at the time of the offense was the alien's spouse
column12: or daughter (and no other individual) to enter the United States in violation of law.

column1: (G) Marriage fraud

An alien shall be considered to be deportable as having procured a visa or other documentation by fraud (within the meaning of section 1182(a)(6)(C)(i) of this title) and to be in the United States in violation of this chapter (within the meaning of subparagraph (B)) if-

(i) the alien obtains any admission into the United States with an immigrant visa or other documentation procured on the basis of a marriage entered into less than 2 years prior to such admission of the alien and which
column2: within 2 years subsequent to any admission of the alien in the United States
column3: shall be judicially annulled or terminated
column4: unless the alien establishes to the satisfaction of the Attorney General that such marriage was not contracted for the purpose of evading any provisions of the immigration laws

column1: (ii) it appears to the satisfaction of the Attorney General that the alien has failed or refused to fulfill the alien's marital agreement which in the opinion of the Attorney General was made for the purpose of procuring the alien's admission as an immigrant.
(H) Waiver authorized for certain misrepresentations

The provisions of this paragraph relating to the removal of aliens within the United States on the ground that they were inadmissible at the time of admission as aliens described in section 1182(a)(6)(C)(i) of this title
column2: whether willful or innocent
column3: may
column4: in the discretion of the Attorney General
column5: be waived for any alien (other than an alien described in paragraph (4)(D)) who-

column1: (i)(I) is the spouse
column2: parent
column3: son
column4: or daughter of a citizen of the United States or of an alien lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence; and

column1: (II) was in possession of an immigrant visa or equivalent document and was otherwise admissible to the United States at the time of such admission except for those grounds of inadmissibility specified under paragraphs (5)(A) and (7)(A) of section 1182(a) of this title which were a direct result of that fraud or misrepresentation.
(ii) is a VAWA self-petitioner.

A waiver of removal for fraud or misrepresentation granted under this subparagraph shall also operate to waive removal based on the grounds of inadmissibility directly resulting from such fraud or misrepresentation.
(2) Criminal offenses
(A) General crimes
(i) Crimes of moral turpitude

(ii) of a violation of

column1: is deportable.
(C) Document fraud
(i) In general
An alien who is the subject of a final order for violation of section 1324c of this title is deportable.
(ii) Waiver authorized

The Attorney General may waive clause (i) in the case of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence if no previous civil money penalty was imposed against the alien under section 1324c of this title and the offense was incurred solely to assist
column2: aid
column3: or support the alien's spouse or child (and no other individual). No court shall have jurisdiction to review a decision of the Attorney General to grant or deny a waiver under this clause.

column1: (D) Falsely claiming citizenship
(i) In general
Any alien who falsely represents
column2: or has falsely represented
column3: himself to be a citizen of the United States for any purpose or benefit under this chapter (including section 1324a of this title) or any Federal or State law is deportable.

column1: (ii) Exception
In the case of an alien making a representation described in clause (i)
column2: if each natural parent of the alien (or
column3: in the case of an adopted alien
column4: each adoptive parent of the alien) is or was a citizen (whether by birth or naturalization)
column5: the alien permanently resided in the United States prior to attaining the age of 16
column6: and the alien reasonably believed at the time of making such representation that he or she was a citizen
column7: the alien shall not be considered to be deportable under any provision of this subsection based on such representation.

column1: (4) Security and related grounds
(A) In general
Any alien who has engaged
column2: is engaged
column3: or at any time after admission engages in-

column1: (i) any activity to violate any law of the United States relating to espionage or sabotage or to violate or evade any law prohibiting the export from the United States of goods
column2: technology
column3: or sensitive information

column1: (ii) any other criminal activity which endangers public safety or national security
column2: or

column1: (iii) any activity a purpose of which is the opposition to
column2: or the control or overthrow of
column3: the Government of the United States by force

column1: is deportable.
(B) Terrorist activities
Any alien who is described in subparagraph (B) or (F) of section 1182(a)(3) of this title is deportable.
(C) Foreign policy
(i) In general

An alien whose presence or activities in the United States the Secretary of State has reasonable ground to believe would have potentially serious adverse foreign policy consequences for the United States is deportable.
(ii) Exceptions

The exceptions described in clauses (ii) and (iii) of section 1182(a)(3)(C) of this title shall apply to deportability under clause (i) in the same manner as they apply to inadmissibility under section 1182(a)(3)(C)(i) of this title.
(D) Participated in Nazi persecution
column2: genocide
column3: or the commission of any act of torture or extrajudicial killing

column1: Any alien described in clause (i)
column2: (ii)
column3: or (iii) of section 1182(a)(3)(E) of this title is deportable.

column1: (E) Participated in the commission of severe violations of religious freedom
Any alien described in section 1182(a)(2)(G) of this title is deportable.
(F) Recruitment or use of child soldiers
Any alien who has engaged in the recruitment or use of child soldiers in violation of section 2442 of title 18 is deportable.
(5) Public charge
Any alien who
column2: within five years after the date of entry
column3: has become a public charge from causes not affirmatively shown to have arisen since entry is deportable.

(A) In general
Any alien who has voted in violation of any Federal

In the case of an alien who voted in a Federal
column2: State
column3: or local election (including an initiative
column5: or referendum) in violation of a lawful restriction of voting to citizens
column6: if each natural parent of the alien (or
column7: in the case of an adopted alien
column8: each adoptive parent of the alien) is or was a citizen (whether by birth or naturalization)
column9: the alien permanently resided in the United States prior to attaining the age of 16
column10: and the alien reasonably believed at the time of such violation that he or she was a citizen

column1: (7) Waiver for victims of domestic violence
(A) In general

The Attorney General is not limited by the criminal court record and may waive the application of paragraph (2)(E)(i) (with respect to crimes of domestic violence and crimes of stalking) and (ii) in the case of an alien who has been battered or subjected to extreme cruelty and who is not and was not the primary perpetrator of violence in the relationship-
(i) 1 upon a determination that-
(I) the alien was acting is 2 self-defense;
(II) the alien was found to have violated a protection order intended to protect the alien; or
(III) the alien committed
column2: was arrested for
column3: was convicted of
column4: or pled guilty to committing a crime-

column1: (aa) that did not result in serious bodily injury; and
(bb) where there was a connection between the crime and the alien's having been battered or subjected to extreme cruelty.
(B) Credible evidence considered
In acting on applications under this paragraph
column2: the Attorney General shall consider any credible evidence relevant to the application. The determination of what evidence is credible and the weight to be given that evidence shall be within the sole discretion of the Attorney General.

column1: (b) Deportation of certain nonimmigrants
An alien
column2: admitted as a nonimmigrant under the provisions of either section 1101(a)(15)(A)(i) or 1101(a)(15)(G)(i) of this title
column3: and who fails to maintain a status under either of those provisions
column4: shall not be required to depart from the United States without the approval of the Secretary of State
column5: unless such alien is subject to deportation under paragraph (4) of subsection (a).

column1: (c) Waiver of grounds for deportation
Paragraphs (1)(A)
column5: and (3)(A) of subsection (a) (other than so much of paragraph (1) as relates to a ground of inadmissibility described in paragraph (2) or (3) of section 1182(a) of this title) shall not apply to a special immigrant described in section 1101(a)(27)(J) of this title based upon circumstances that existed before the date the alien was provided such special immigrant status.

column1: (d) Administrative stay

(1) If the Secretary of Homeland Security determines that an application for nonimmigrant status under subparagraph (T) or (U) of section 1101(a)(15) of this title filed for an alien in the United States sets forth a prima facie case for approval
column2: the Secretary may grant the alien an administrative stay of a final order of removal under section 1231(c)(2) of this title until-

column1: (A) the application for nonimmigrant status under such subparagraph (T) or (U) is approved; or
(B) there is a final administrative denial of the application for such nonimmigrant status after the exhaustion of administrative appeals.
(2) The denial of a request for an administrative stay of removal under this subsection shall not preclude the alien from applying for a stay of removal
column2: deferred action
column3: or a continuance or abeyance of removal proceedings under any other provision of the immigration laws of the United States.

column1: (3) During any period in which the administrative stay of removal is in effect
column2: the alien shall not be removed.

column1: (4) Nothing in this subsection may be construed to limit the authority of the Secretary of Homeland Security or the Attorney General to grant a stay of removal or deportation in any case not described in this subsection.

column1: PORTLAND
column2: Maine (AP) — The summer air is sizzling as the Fourth of July approaches
column3: yet 86-year-old Richard Perkins already worries about how he’s going to stay warm this winter.

column1: President Donald Trump has proposed eliminating heating aid for low-income Americans
column2: claiming it’s no longer necessary and rife with fraud. People needn’t worry about being left in the cold
column3: he says
column4: because utilities cannot cut off customers in the dead of winter.

column1: But he is wrong on all counts.
ADVERTISEMENT
The heating program provides a critical lifeline for people like Perkins
column2: and officials close to the program don’t see any widespread fraud. Guidelines for winter shutoffs by utilities vary from state to state and don’t apply to heating oil
column3: a key energy source in the brittle New England winter.

column1: “It’s beyond my thinking that anyone could be that cruel
column2: ” said Perkins
column3: a retired restaurateur who relies on the program to keep warm in Ogunquit

column1: The proposal to kill the program
column2: which has distributed $3.4 billion to about 6 million households this fiscal year
column3: will face strong opposition in Congress.

column1: Forty-three senators from mostly cold-weather states already signed a letter urging the Republican chairman and ranking Democrat on an appropriations subcommittee to ensure funding for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program
column2: known in many states by its acronym
column3: LIHEAP (pronounced LY’-heep).

column1: In Maine
column2: the poorest state in New England
column3: the program helped about 77
column5: and those numbers represented less than a quarter of eligible households
column7: which helps to run the program.

column1: Perkins is a typical recipient.
His income was fine 10 or 12 years ago when he retired
column2: but gasoline
column3: food and other expenses grew faster than he anticipated. In the winter
column4: he keeps an eye on his oil storage tank
column5: and the local community action agency sends 100 gallons when it gets low.

column1: It’s difficult for him to keep warm because he’s on a blood thinner
column2: and he shudders at the thought of being cold. But he doesn’t want to move south
column3: either.

column1: “I was born and raised here
column2: ” he said. “Maine is part of me. I can’t imagine living anywhere else.”

column1: Mark Wolfe
column2: of the National Energy Assistance Directors’ Association

column6: only 100 cases — 0.3 percent of all submitted applications — are being investigated for potential fraud

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
And programs aimed at preventing utilities from being turned off wouldn’t protect everyone. Utility regulations vary
column2: with some states preventing shutoffs during the entire winter and others doing so only on exceptionally cold days.

column1: And there’s absolutely no requirement for heating oil and propane dealers
column2: which are not regulated like electric and natural gas utilities
column3: to make deliveries to customers who cannot pay. That’s a big problem in the Northeast
column4: which accounts for more than 80 percent of the nation’s residential heating oil consumption.

column1: Health and Human Services Secretary Thomas Price

column3: ” said difficult decisions are necessary to streamline the government to focus on the administration’s goals of defense and public safety.

column1: The LIHEAP program already has undergone substantial cuts.

The average benefit has been reduced by $100 from 2010 to 2015 as funding was slashed during the Obama administration. That coincides with Venezuela’s Citgo Petroleum Corp. ending participation in a free-oil program run by a Massachusetts-based nonprofit.
