column1: The Satanic Temple’s “After School Satan Club” Returns With a Nationwide Volunteer Network
SALEM
column2: Mass. — In 2016
column3: The Satanic Temple (TST) generated nationwide controversy with the roll-out of its After School Satan Club (ASSC) campaign
column4: placing openly Satanic clubs in public schools to counterbalance what TST sees as a coercive presence of Evangelical extracurricular clubs in public schools. After a successful first year
column6: and it promises to be much bigger than before.

column1: “Last year
column2: the After School Satan Club curriculum was only offered in school districts where local chapters of The Satanic Temple could manage and maintain them
column3: ” explains Chalice Blythe
column4: National Director for The Satanic Temple’s ASSC campaign. “In that time
column5: we received a flood of emails from parents
column7: and other qualified parties who were interested in operating After School Satan Clubs in schools near them. This year
column8: we have made our curriculum available to this volunteer network
column9: and we expect to see a much larger After School Satan Club presence in 2017. Our curriculum has also been revised by qualified experts in education to provide a reason-based
column10: fun alternative to the evangelical indoctrination clubs already present in the schools. This year’s After School Satan Club is going to be even better and much bigger.”

column1: The ASSC campaign was created specifically to offer an alternative to other religious clubs that seek to indoctrinate children after school
column2: particularly the Good News Club
column3: an Evangelical Fundamentalist club run by the Child Evangelism Fellowship. According to the ASSC website
column5: and we’re not interested in converting children to Satanism. However
column6: we feel that our presence in schools that are burdened with the loathsome stink of the Good News Clubs serves an anti-indoctrination function
column7: illustrating to children that opposing religious perspectives can be held by moral and responsible people who don’t live in fear of divine retribution. We think it’s a positive and strong character-developing lesson that we are happy to deliver.”

column1: Those interested in volunteering to operate an ASSC should contact The Satanic Temple at: info@afterschoolsatan.com. To help support The Satanic Temple efforts to expand the ASSC program
column2: please visit www.afterschoolsatan.com

column1: Judicial Watch Creates Bizarre Fabricated News Story Claiming IRS Gave After School Satan Club “Fast-Track” Tax Exemption
Chalice Blythe – After School Satan Club Director
Stu De Haan – The Satanic Temple Legal Counsel
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
On March 16
column2: 2017 the website Judicial Watch published an article entitled “IRS Gives ‘After School Satan Club’ Tax-Exempt Status in 10 Days” which claimed that the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) “fast tracked a deranged Satanic cult to operate as a nonprofit in taxpayer-funded elementary schools.” While this claim has been repeated by several news organizations
column3: including Fox and The Washington Times
column4: it is utter fiction. The Satanic Temple (TST) does
column6: run After School Satan Clubs (ASSC) as a reason-based science-centered counterbalance to fundamentalist evangelical after-school programs
column7: but the IRS played absolutely no role in the approval of these clubs. The After School

column1: Satan Clubs are sponsored by the non-profit 501(c)(3)
column2: Reason Alliance
column3: Ltd.; however
column4: Reason Alliance earned its tax-exempt status long before ASSC existed and did not
column6: receive its exemption in 10 days. Further
column7: nothing in the filings for Reason Alliance make reference to Satan or Satanism. Clearly
column8: any insinuations that “Obama’s IRS” struck a secret alliance with Satanists are nothing more than an absurd fabrication.

column1: Not only is Judicial Watch’s story demonstrably false
column2: it is a clear example of gross journalistic negligence across the reporting spectrum and an inability to comprehend not only what the After School Satan Club is
column3: but also what procedures ASSC underwent to get approval for operation in public schools. Procedures
column5: that are very clearly laid out in the documentation they themselves obtained and released.

column1: Reason Alliance
column2: Ltd.
column3: was formed in 2014 by the founders of The Satanic Temple (TST). The non-profit was set up to encourage reason and empathy
column6: and advocate pragmatic common sense. Reason Alliance also supports activities that advance these core values. When the After School Satan Club was formed in July 2016
column7: Reason Alliance was used to sponsor this program as ASSC operations are consistent with its mission statement. This sponsorship supports The Satanic Temple’s After School Satan Club by way of covering the rental fees and liability insurance coverage required by law. The assertion by Judicial Watch and all other news outlets that ASSC is somehow itself a tax exempt entity or operated by Reason Alliance Ltd. has no grounding in reality nor does the documentation they’ve obtained support this claim.

column1: Additionally
column2: multiple news outlets have and continue to refer to The Satanic Temple as a “cult.” This slanderous categorization of our organization is precisely the type of irresponsible
column3: lazy
column4: and sensational journalism that Americans have come to expect. This expectation
column6: does not absolve the media from propagating such falsehoods. By any definition of the term
column7: The Satanic Temple does not fall into this category and any accusation of such is not only a bald face lie
column8: it’s libelous due to the heinous connotations implied. Any cursory research of this organization would debunk this allegation
column9: calling into question the actual efforts these journalists put into verifying the facts prior to publishing. This
column11: is why the After School Satan Club is so necessary in schools to teach critical thought and rational inquiry so this type of vitriol can be avoided in the future.

column1: We hope that news outlets exercise more skepticism toward Judicial Watch press releases in the future.
The Satanic Temple leverages Religious Freedom laws to put After School Clubs in elementary schools nationwide
This school year The Satanic Temple will have After School Clubs in public elementary schools across the nation leveraging Religious Freedom laws established by decades of Evangelical litigation

The Satanic Temple (TST) has announced that this coming school year (2016) will find their organization operating in elementary schools across the nation where they will be offering their new After School Satan Club program to students. While the presence of a religious organization in public schools will no doubt be shocking to some
column2: evangelical litigants — primarily the Child Evangelism Fellowship (CEF) represented by lawyers from the Liberty Counsel — have solidly established the legal rights of religious organizations to operate clubs in public schools.

column1: According to the CEF website
column2: “[…] the United States Supreme Court ruled that a public school which allows use of its facilities to secular groups may not discriminate against religious groups.” And now that the CEF has established its Bible-based Good News Clubs across the nation
column3: TST are eager to offer their own after school clubs

column1: According to TST spokesperson
column2: Lucien Greaves
column3: “School districts across the nation have received letters from The Satanic Temple explaining that we will be offering our clubs in their schools this coming school year
column4: and parents in those schools can expect to be presented with a permission slip from their children in the first weeks of the Fall semester. All of the districts we’ve approached are nearby to local chapters of The Satanic Temple
column5: and each school district has hosted
column7: Good News Clubs in their schools. This being the case
column8: we are sure that the school districts we’ve approached are well aware that they are not at liberty to deny us use of their facilities
column9: nor are they at liberty to deny us any level of representation in the schools that they afford to other school clubs — such as fliers
column12: and school-wide announcements. We would like to thank the Liberty Counsel
column14: for opening the doors of public schools to the After School Satan Club through their dedication to religious liberty.”

column1: Elaborating the mission of the After School Satan Clubs
column2: Greaves states
column3: “It’s important that children be given an opportunity to realize that the evangelical materials now creeping into their schools are representative of but one religious opinion amongst many. While the Good News Clubs focus on indoctrination
column4: instilling them with a fear of Hell and God’s wrath
column5: After School Satan Clubs will focus on free inquiry and rationalism
column6: the scientific basis for which we know what we know about the world around us. We prefer to give children an appreciation of the natural wonders surrounding them
column7: not a fear of everlasting other-worldly horrors.”"	Press Releases		[]	['school'

column1: Community leaders continued Sunday to sound off about the Wilmington police shooting that left a 28-year-old wheelchair-bound man dead.
Jeremy “Bam” McDole
column3: was shot and killed by four city officers Wednesday around 3 p.m. in the 1800 block of Tulip Street.

column1: Some called for the Attorney General’s Office to swiftly file charges against the four officers – three of whom are white and one of whom is Hispanic. Others denied police accounts that McDole had a .38-caliber gun
column2: pointing to a YouTube video where a gun is not visible.

column1: “This is an injustice
column2: ” said community activist and Hilltop resident Robert Bovell. “There is no way someone in a wheelchair should be shot that many times.”

column1: Wilmington Police Chief Bobby Cummings said McDole was armed when officers arrived around 3 p.m. to a report of a man who had shot himself. McDole was reaching for a gun when the officers opened fire
column2: he said.

column1: Police also say they found a .38-caliber gun at McDole’s side after the shooting.
Cell phone video captured by a bystander and posted to YouTube shows an officer pointing a shotgun at McDole
column2: screaming at him to “drop the gun
column3: ” while other officers scream “hands up.”

column1: McDole
column2: who was paralyzed from the waist down
column3: is seen fidgeting and trying to raise himself from the wheelchair. Then he slides his hands up his thigh and toward his waist as the officers open fire.

column1: The video has drawn international attention and a growing chorus of questions about what led up to the shooting. In response
column2: police released a portion of the 911 call where a woman reported to police that a man had shot himself.

column1: She asked police to get an ambulance to the AutoZone parking lot along Lancaster Avenue
column2: saying that the man was still moving and had a gun.

column1: The recording did little to quell some activists’ disbelief that McDole had a gun.
“There was no weapon in that video
column2: ” Bovell said. “There is no system in this place we call America that they give you justification for what happened to Mr. McDole.”

column1: Two investigations – one by city police and another by Attorney General Matt Denn’s office – are ongoing. Few details have been released from either office
column2: and a city police spokeswoman said the department may provide more information Monday depending how the investigation progresses.

column1: Frustration over the lack of details could be seen Sunday during Bovell’s live television program called “Community Conversations.”
McDole’s family
column2: including his mother Phyllis
column3: were invited to be on the show. They arrived for the taping
column5: refusing to talk about McDole’s shooting.

column1: The show went on with Bovell hosting three activists for an hour-long discussion.

column1: While commenting on President Donald Trump's very public support for Christianity

column4: demonic items and artificats from the Obama and Clinton years be removed.

column1: Melania Trump reportedly said
column2: ""I’m not going to go into that White House unless it has been completely exorcised
column3: according to Pastor Begley. One thing was left
column4: a cross on the wall. ""They cleansed the White House
column5: he said. ""They had people in there anointing it with oil and praying everywhere.”

column1: Pastor Begley made his remarks during the Feb. 2 edition of Weekend Vigilante
column2: hosted by Sheila Zilinsky.

column1: “I have to say
column2: when the president allowed 40 pastors to come in to the White House and anoint him with oil and lay their hands and pray on him—seven times he’s done this—that is unheard of

column4: we all do. But at least he is humble enough and recognizing that he needs God enough that he keeps bringing them in for the prayer.""

column1: And I’ve got to say this
column2: it might have started with the first lady

column1: I can tell you

column1: According to the Washington Post

column3: “They toured the old hotel where the writer Ernest Hemingway once stayed and visited a voodoo high priest dressed in all white.” The article does not say why they visited the voodoo high priest.

column1: Christians pray over President Donald Trump at the White House. (Twitter)

column2: said The Post. ""They flew back again and again. Hillary Clinton once said that theirs was a 'Haiti-obsessed family.'""

column2: 'civil liberties'
column3: 'constitution'

column1: STATE v. ROBINSON.
Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
March 8
Lloyd H. Stitham
column2: County Attorney for the County of Somerset
column3: Pittsfield

column1: Dubord & Dubord
column2: by F. Harold Dubord
column3: Waterville

column1: Before MURCHIE
column2: C. J.
column3: and THAXTER

column1: MERRILL
column2: Justice.

column1: On exceptions. The respondent
column2: Rodney L. Robinson
column3: was tried at the May Term of the Superior Court in the County of Somerset
column4: upon a complaint and warrant charging him with assault and battery upon one John B. Gallant. At the close of the testimony
column5: motion for a directed verdict of not guilty was seasonably made
column7: and exceptions alleged and allowed. At the conclusion of the charge
column8: the respondent in writing requested eleven instructions to the jury. To the denial of the eleventh request
column9: the respondent seasonably alleged exceptions which were allowed. The jury having found the respondent guilty
column10: the case is now before this Court upon the foregoing exceptions.

column1: The record clearly discloses that the complaining witness
column2: John B. Gallant
column3: a deputy sheriff
column4: and the respondent engaged in a serious physical struggle in which both parties were severely and grieviously injured. Each of them complained that the other was the unprovoked aggressor and struck the first blow. The respondent's plea was not guilty. He admitted striking the complainant
column5: and relied upon self defense in justification thereof. He sought to justify his acts upon two grounds
column6: repelling an unwarranted attack by the complaining witness upon him
column7: and resistance of an unlawful arrest.

column1: *261 It would be profitless to relate the conflicting testimony of the complaining witness and the respondent and the witnesses called on behalf of the State and the respondent. Issues of fact were raised and their solution in a large measure depended upon the credence given by the jury to the conflicting testimony of the complaining witness and the respondent. The determination of these questions of fact was peculiarly within the province of the jury which observed and heard the witnesses. As said by this Court in State v. Hume
We are of opinion that
column2: if the testimony of the state's witnesses was believed
column3: it was sufficient to establish the guilt of the respondent beyond a reasonable doubt. A direct denial of the state's charges and a contradiction of its witnesses raised an issue of fact which was for the jury. There was no error in the denial of the respondent's motion for a directed verdict. State v. Donahue

column1: The exception to the refusal to direct a verdict of not guilty must be overruled.
The requested instruction which was refused was as follows:

The jury is instructed as a matter of law that the evidence adduced by the State is insufficient for you to find that the respondent at the time of the alleged assault was intoxicated to that degree sufficient to authorize the officer to arrest the respondent without a warrant for intoxication. This being true
column2: the attempted arrest without a warrant was unlawful and the respondent had a right to resist with reasonable force. You are further instructed that unless you are convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the respondent used more force to resist the unlawful arrest than was reasonable
column3: that you should find the respondent not guilty.""

column1: The rule of law with respect to the denial of requested instructions is correctly stated in State v. Cox
A requested instruction which is not
column2: in its totality
column3: sound law
column4: is properly withheld. It is no part of the duty of the court to eliminate errors in a requested instruction. State v. Cleaves

column1: Neither is it the duty of the Court to supply omissions in a requested instruction in order that the same may be applicable to the case at bar.
Whether or not the respondent was intoxicated was peculiarly a question of fact for the jury. The jury were properly instructed by the court as to what constituted intoxication
column2: and this at the request of the respondent. The determination thereof depended upon the condition of the accused as exhibited by conduct. There was a sharp conflict of testimony between the respondent and his witnesses and the State's witnesses
column3: including the complaining witness
column4: as to the conduct of the accused.

column1: It was an undisputed fact that the respondent had been drinking at the time the alleged assault occurred. This fact
column2: coupled with his unprovoked assault upon the complaining witness
column3: his use of vile epithets
column4: and his appearance both to the witness and to the other officers at the scene of the altercation and later at the jail as related by the State's witnesses
column5: even though denied by the respondent
column6: was sufficient to justify the court in submitting the question of his intoxication at the time of the alleged assault to the jury.

column1: The requested instruction
column2: however
column3: has another infirmity. The instruction taken as a whole was a direction to the jury to return a verdict for the respondent unless they were convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the respondent used more force than was reasonable in resisting unlawful arrest.

column1: To entitle a respondent to an instruction that he should be acquitted if the jury find or fail to find the existence of a single fact set forth in the instruction
column2: the fact so set forth must be absolutely determinative of the guilt or innocence of the accused upon the entire evidence before the jury. In other words
column3: the record must show that such fact is the only disputed fact upon which the guilt or innocence of the accused depends.

column1: *262 An illegal arrest is an assault and battery. The person so attempted to be restrained of his liberty has the same right
column2: and only the same right
column3: to use force in defending himself as he would have in repelling any other assault and battery. See 4 Am.Jur. Sec. 41

column1: According to the testimony of the complaining witness
column2: he was seated in his truck behind the steering wheel with the door closed and the window open. The respondent was in the street close to the truck. The State's witness testified as follows as to the beginning of the trouble:

column1: A. After I saw Mr. Robinson I thought he was waving at me to stop
column2: so I stopped
column3: rolled down the window and asked him if he wanted to see me and he said no
column4: that he was talking to his wife. Then I started rolling back up the window and he run up
column5: opened the door and said: `You sons of bitches are laying for me.' I said: `We are watching you and if you continue to drive as you are we will pick you up.' Then he said: `You sons of bitches
column6: you are laying for me now and this is once you can't pick me up.' And then he came into the truck
column9: cut off my wind. We had some struggling and scuffling in the truck.""

column1: Even if the officer told the respondent that he was under arrest before he entered the officer's truck
column2: which is denied by the respondent
column3: this evidence would show that the respondent violently assaulted the officer before the officer made the slightest attempt to take physical custody of him. While it is true that a person who is illegally arrested may use such force as is reasonably necessary to resist the force used against him
column4: he cannot initiate the use of force. We recognize that there are circumstances under which an assault may be repelled by a battery
column5: and a show of force may be repelled by actual force. But words alone do not justify an assault. A mere statement by an officer that a person is under arrest
column6: even if the officer has no authority to arrest
column7: does not justify an attack by him on the officer before any physical attempt is made to take him into custody.

column1: As said in Harris v. State
column2: 21 Ga.App. 792

column1: The officer must
column2: by some physical attempt
column3: endeavor to make the unlawful arrest before the other person can lawfully strike him or otherwise resist him by the use of physical force.""

column1: Absent physical attempt to arrest
column2: the question is not whether the respondent used reasonable force but whether he used any force whatsoever.

column1: Even though the complaining witness
column2: an officer
column3: without right told the respondent he was under arrest
column4: it was a question of fact for the jury whether or not the respondent attacked the officer before the latter made any physical attempt to make the arrest. If so
column5: the respondent was not entitled to use any force whatsoever and he would be guilty. The requested instruction ignored this question of fact. It did not leave its determination to the jury. It presupposed the right of the respondent to use some force and that the only question of fact was whether the force actually used was reasonable. As the instruction did not require the jury to pass upon this issue of fact which could be determinative of the respondent's guilt it was properly refused and the exception to its refusal should be overruled.

column1: Exceptions overruled.
Judgment for the State."	State v. Robinson		[]	['robinson'
column2: 'state'
column3: 'witness'
column12: 'respondent']	"As said by this Court in State v. Hume

column1: State v. Donahue
433; State v. Harvey
The rule of law with respect to the denial of requested instructions is correctly stated in State v. Cox
As said in Harris v. State

column1: Eleven orca and 90 beluga whales are being held in the pens

column2: activists believe

column3: even for scientific or educational reasons.

column1: Catching them at this tempo

column1: Terry Glenn MILLER
column2: Appellant
column3: v. STATE of Alaska

column1: Supreme Court of Alaska.
December 15
*422 Denis R. Lazarus
column2: Anchorage
column3: for appellant.

column1: Douglas B. Baily
column2: Dist. Atty.
column3: Keith E. Brown

column1: Before DIMOND
column2: RABINOWITZ

column1: OPINION
CONNOR
column2: Justice.

column1: Appellant was convicted by a jury verdict of the crime of stabbing at another with intent to wound
column2: in violation of AS 11.15.150. The one at whom the stabbing *423 was directed was Trooper Russell Anderson of the Alaska State Police
column3: who was attempting to effect an arrest of appellant at the time of the attempted stabbing.

column1: The incident out of which the indictment resulted took place in the parking lot of a bowling alley in Soldotna
column2: Alaska
column3: shortly before midnight on March 18

column1: At about 11:30 that evening Trooper Anderson and a friend
column2: Ed Meyer
column3: left Anderson's home in Soldotna to remove a dead moose from the Sterling Highway. On the way
column4: they happened to notice a car parked in the lot of a bowling alley which had closed for the night. Anderson decided to check it out; and as he drew near in his patrol car
column5: the other car made a U-turn and proceeded to the back of the bowling alley building. Anderson activated the red light on his patrol car and the other car stopped.

column1: Anderson then walked to the driver's side of the car and found Darlene Heatherton behind the wheel and the car's owner
column2: Terry Glenn Miller
column3: next to her. The trooper testified that he knew both of them
column4: and that he knew they were both minors. When he asked Miss Heatherton for her driver's license
column5: he noticed what appeared to be a case of Lucky Lager beer on the floor behind the driver's seat. Anderson told Heatherton and Miller to get out of the car and informed them that they were under arrest for being minors in possession of an alcoholic beverage. He then took possession of the case of beer
column6: and he noticed at that time that several of the bottles of beer were empty.

column1: Miss Heatherton got into the patrol vehicle
column2: but appellant became argumentative. After a scuffle
column3: appellant returned to his car. Anderson removed appellant forcibly from his car and managed to jostle him to the patrol car where he was planning to handcuff appellant. They slipped to the ground and appellant came up wielding a bayonet. Trooper Anderson testified that Miller slashed at him with the bayonet and that his clip-on necktie might have been knocked loose by the bayonet.

column1: Because he was now wary of appellant and the bayonet
column2: Trooper Anderson stepped backward
column3: unsnapped his revolver and ordered appellant to drop his weapon. Thus the investigation of an automobile parked after hours near a bowling alley had mushroomed into a serious event.

column1: While Trooper Anderson and appellant were standing off from each other
column2: Anderson repeatedly told appellant to drop the weapon and appellant told Anderson to leave him alone. Miss Heatherton then went to appellant to try to convince him to submit to the officer. According to the testimony of Anderson
column3: Miller was so upset that he threatened Miss Heatherton. Finally
column4: the impasse ended when Miller and Miss Heatherton got into Miller's car
column5: and a few moments later the bayonet was dropped out of the car window. About this time Trooper Provine of the Alaska State Police arrived in another patrol car. Anderson and Provine then were able to remove appellant from the car
column6: advise him that he was under arrest for attempting to stab Anderson
column7: and turn him over to custody of Corporal English
column8: who had just come upon the scene.

column1: Appellant specified a number of errors in the prosecution and trial of his case. Although twelve errors are specified
column2: these are not correlated with the body of the argument in appellant's brief. Accordingly
column3: we must deal with the claims of error as we are best able to discern them.

column1: Appellant's first contentions can be grouped under the proposition that the indictment was defective because of irregularities in the constitution and administration of the grand jury. Appellant moved to dismiss the indictment on the grounds that the grand jury was extended beyond the five-month limitation prescribed by Rule 6 of the Rules of Criminal Procedure
column2: that the foreman of the grand jury and one other grand juror were not qualified to sit as grand jurors because they had served beyond the five-month limitation
column3: *424 that the witness before the grand jury that indicted appellant was never properly sworn because the foreman was not qualified to administer the oath to the witness
column4: and that the endorsement of the indictment was defective because the foreman was not qualified to act.

column1: The record is clear that the grand jury foreman served in the months of August and September of 1966
column2: that he was excused from service in October
column3: but again served in January and March of 1967. His actual service did not exceed four separate months. He acted as foreman in January and March of 1967. It is also plain that 15 members of the grand jury voted for the indictment against appellant. Under Criminal Rule 6(c) (2) the disqualification of one or two grand jurors would not invalidate the indictment. Crawford v. State

column1: We see no harm inflicted on appellant because the grand jury foreman served for a few months
column2: was temporarily excused
column3: and then resumed service a few months later. We find this to be in substantial compliance with the pertinent rule.[1]

column1: A case similar to this one is People v. Whalen
column2: 26 Misc.2d 714
column3: 208 N.Y.S.2d 130 (1960). In that case an indictment returned by a grand jury containing two unqualified members was held to be valid. The court noted that a grand jury can act through a de facto foreman without violating any constitutional rights of the accused.

column1: The role of the foreman was described by the court in People v. Whalen
column2: supra
column3: in the following terms:

column1: The foreman of the grand jury is appointed by the judge of the court which impaneled the grand jury. He occupies roughly the same position as the foreman of a petit jury. He has no greater or lesser powers than any other grand juror. Each paneled grand juror is a distinct legal entity and the identity of the foreman is merged along with the other jurors. ""The foreman is
column2: in the absence of the courts
column3: the presiding officer of the inquiry; he is merely the instrumentality through which the proceedings and actions of the grand jury are reported to the court
column4: and the most important of his duties is to report all indictments which are returned by the grand jury and to endorse on such bills
column6: whether or not they are true bills."" 208 N.Y.S.2d

column1: Thus
column2: even if the foreman was somehow not qualified
column3: it would require a greater showing of prejudice to appellant before we would be willing to invalidate the indictment on the ground that the foreman was disqualified and that he had no power to administer oaths or sign indictments.

column1: II
Appellant contests the validity of his arrest
column2: made without a warrant
column3: on the misdemeanor charge of being a minor in possession of an alcoholic beverage.

column1: His claims of error are based upon the rejection by the trial court of appellant's exhibit B
column2: offered to show that the misdemeanor charge against him had been dismissed
column3: the denial of a motion for mistrial based upon the judge's statement in the presence of the jury that the only issue about the legality of the arrest was whether the officer had probable cause to believe that appellant had committed a misdemeanor in his presence
column4: and that the court erred in instructing the jury on the legality of the arrest. Additionally
column5: appellant claims that there was no probable cause to justify the arrest itself.

column1: *425 The relevant arrest statute
column3: authorizes a private citizen or a police officer
column5: to make an arrest for a crime ""committed or attempted in his presence."" An arrest for a misdemeanor made by an officer without a warrant is valid if the offense is committed in his presence. Rubey v. City of Fairbanks

column1: Appellant contends that ""an officer who arrests without a warrant on a misdemeanor charge acts at his peril
column2: since the arrest will be unlawful if the offense was actually not committed
column3: even though the officer acted on reasonable grounds and in good faith."" Under appellant's theory
column4: Anderson's arrest of appellant on the misdemeanor charge without a warrant was lawful only if the prosecution proved that the offense was actually committed in Anderson's presence. We disagree.

column1: In Rubey v. City of Fairbanks
column2: supra
column3: we held that an arrest for a misdemeanor committed in the presence of an officer was valid where what the officer observed was sufficiently indicative that an offense was in the course of commission as to lead to the logical conclusion that it was in progress. Support for that ruling was found in United States v. Viale
column5: in which the United States Court of Appeals applied the New York statute. The New York statute is similar to our own. In Viale

column1: It is now clear under New York law that one person may without a warrant justifiably arrest another who commits a misdemeanor in his `presence' only when the arrestor actually observed acts which were `in themselves sufficiently indicative of a crime being in the course of commission * * *' [T]he arrestor must have perceived `indications of the commission of the offense sufficient to induce reasonable belief of the fact.'"" (Citations and footnote omitted.) 312 F.2d
In Coverstone v. Davies
column4: the California Supreme Court construed the applicable statute
column5: which was also similar to AS 12.25.030(1)
column6: as allowing an officer to make a warrantless arrest for a misdemeanor where the officer had probable cause to believe the arrestee was committing the offense in his presence. The court held that the arrest is proper when circumstances exist that would cause a reasonable person to believe that a crime had been committed in his presence. The court explained the policy reasons underlying its interpretation:

column1: When an arrest for a misdemeanor is made upon the complaint of one other than the arresting officer
column2: it is proper to require the securing of a warrant to justify the arrest. * * * However
column3: to make the same requirement
column4: when the officer sees that in all probability a public offense is being committed in his presence
column5: would be to hamper law enforcement officers in their everyday enforcement of the law. Peace officers would be reluctant to make arrests for fear that they would be held liable for having made an honest and reasonable mistake. It is thus manifest that the day to day problems of law enforcement require that peace officers be allowed to act without fear of being held liable upon the facts as they see them
column6: provided such facts would lead a reasonable person to conclude that he was witnessing the commission of a public offense by the person arrested."" 239 P.2d

column1: We find these authorities persuasive. We hold that an arrest under AS 12.25.030(1) is lawful where the peace officer has perceived facts which would lead a reasonable man to believe that the *426 arrestee has committed or attempted to commit an offense in his presence. We further hold that appellant's arrest on the charge of being a minor in possession of an alcoholic beverage was lawful.[3] Anderson
column2: an experienced police officer
column3: properly set out to investigate a car parked adjacent to a closed business
column5: and stopped it when it started to move away. He recognized both occupants and while questioning them saw a partially open case of beer on the floor behind the driver's seat. These facts reasonably indicated that the offense was being committed in his presence.

column1: Lastly
column2: we take up the question of whether one can resist a peaceful arrest even though the arrest is unlawful. The weight of authoritative precedent supports a right to repel an unlawful arrest with force. United States v. Di Re
column6: 92 L. Ed. 210 (1948); John Bad Elk v. United States
column10: 44 L. Ed. 874 (1900); United States v. Heliczer
column17: Sec. 216 (1957). This was the rule at common law. It was based upon the proposition that everyone should be privileged to use reasonable force to prevent an unlawful invasion of his physical integrity and personal liberty.

column1: But certain imperfections in the functioning of the rule have brought about changes in some jurisdictions. A new principle of right conduct has been espoused. It is argued that if a peace officer is making an illegal arrest but is not using force
column2: the remedy of the citizen should be that of suing the officer for false arrest
column3: not resistance with force. The legality of a peaceful arrest may frequently be a close question. It is a question more properly determined by courts than by the participants in what may be a highly emotional situation. Because officers will normally overcome resistance with necessary force
column4: the danger of escalating violence between the officer and the arrestee is great. What begins as an illegal misdemeanor arrest may culminate in serious bodily harm or death.

column1: The control of man's destructive and aggressive impulses is one of the great unsolved problems of our society. Our rules of law should discourage the unnecessary use of physical force between man and man. Any rule which promotes rather than inhibits violence should be re-examined. Along with increased sensitivity to the rights of the criminally accused there should be a corresponding awareness of our need to develop rules which facilitate decent and peaceful behavior by all.
The common law rule was developed in a time when self-help was a more necessary remedy to resist intrusions upon one's freedom.
[It] was developed largely during a period when most arrests were made by private citizens
column2: when bail for felonies was usually unattainable
column3: and when years might pass before the royal judges arrived for a jail delivery. Further
column4: conditions in English jails were then such that a prisoner had an excellent chance of dying of disease before trial."" Warner

column1: Section 5 of the Uniform Arrest Act provides:
If a person has reasonable ground to believe he is being arrested by a peace officer
column2: it is his duty to refrain from using force or any weapon in resisting arrest regardless of whether or not there is a legal basis for the arrest.""

column1: That provision
column2: or its equivalent
column3: has been enacted as statutory law in California
column6: and Delaware. The Model Penal Code
column7: Section 3.04(2) (a) (i) similarly prohibits the use of force ""to resist an arrest which the actor knows is being made by a peace officer
column8: although the arrest is unlawful."" In support of this provision Judge Learned Hand stated:

column1: The idea that you may resist peaceful arrest * * * because you are in debate about whether it is lawful or not
column2: instead of going to the authorities which can determine
column3: * * * [is] not a blow for liberty but on the contrary
column4: a blow for attempted anarchy."" 1958 Proceedings

column1: At least one state court has adopted the recommended rule as a matter of its common law development. State v. Koonce
column2: 89 N.J. Super. 169
column3: 214 A.2d 428 (1965). The legal literature contains discussions on how much force may be used by either an officer making a lawful arrest or by an unlawfully arrested person in resisting arrest. ""Justification for the Use of Force in the Criminal Law
column4: 13 Stan.L.Rev. 566 (1961); ""Criminal Law: Force That May be Used to Resist an Illegal Arrest
column5: 9 Okl.L.Rev. 60 (1956). At best only elastic standards can be employed
column6: as so much depends upon the exigencies of the situation
column8: and the amount of force and counterforce used or threatened.

column1: To us the question is whether any amount of force should be permitted to be used by one unlawfully but peaceably arrested. We feel that the legality of a peaceful arrest should be determined by courts of law and not through a trial by battle in the streets. It is not too much to ask that one believing himself unlawfully arrested should submit to the officer and thereafter seek his legal remedies in court. Such a rule helps to relieve the threat of physical harm to officers who in good faith but mistakenly perform an arrest
column2: as well as to minimize harm to innocent bystanders. The old common law rule has little utility to recommend it under our conditions of life today. We hold that a private citizen may not use force to resist peaceful arrest by one he knows or has good reason to believe is an authorized peace officer performing his duties
column3: regardless of whether the arrest is illegal in the circumstances of the occasion.[4]

column1: Under this standard appellant was given the benefit of instructions to the jury more favorable than that to which he was entitled
column2: as the case was submitted on the theory that one has a right to resist with force an unlawful arrest. We reject the claims of error both for the reason that the arrest was proper and because appellant in any event had no right to resist a peaceable arrest.

column1: III
Appellant asserts that the trial court erred in unduly assisting the prosecution
column2: particularly in advising the prosecutor
column3: after he had rested his case
column4: that the proof was not sufficient to withstand a motion for a judgment of acquittal and that he should request leave to reopen his case in order to cure evidentiary deficiencies which had been noted by the court.

column1: The record is somewhat unclear as to what occurred
column2: as there was a conference between court and counsel held at the bench but not on the record.

column1: It appears that at the close of the cross-examination of Trooper English the state's attorney advised the court that the state had no further witnesses but would like to read into evidence several pertinent statutes. A brief conference at the bench
column2: off the record
column3: then ensued
column4: during which appellant claims that the court advised the state's attorney that his evidence was insufficient in proving appellant's age. It appears that the state then continued examining *428 English
column5: who was on the witness stand
column7: and called a custodian of vital statistics records to establish that Anderson reasonably believed that appellant was a minor at the time of the arrest.

column1: Whether this can be characterized as a reopening of the prosecution's case is not clear from the record. The defendant's case had not yet commenced. But in any event
column2: we do not find in this case that the court abused its discretion in allowing the state to call the additional witnesses.

column1: The trial court has a large discretion with respect to order of proof in permitting a party to reopen after it has rested. * * * There is no suggestion that this surprised the appellant
column2: or that any further preparation was necessary to meet this testimony."" Massey v. United States

column1: In the case just quoted the trial court had twice permitted the government to reopen its case and to introduce testimony to identify a stolen automobile
column2: after the government had clearly rested. In the case before us we are unable to find that appellant was prejudiced by the trial court's action.

column1: We cannot pass upon appellant's claim that the court improperly aided the state by advising it of the evidentiary deficiency because there is nothing in the record to substantiate such a claim. Appellant
column2: in his brief
column3: states that an objection was made
column4: but a review of the record reveals no such objection. If one was made off the record
column5: appellant's trial counsel should have seen to it that an additional objection was registered for the record.

column1: IV
In support of the proposition that there was probable cause for the arrest
column2: the state attempted to introduce the birth certificate of appellant
column3: which indicated appellant was under twenty-one at the time of the arrest. As foundation for the introduction of the document
column4: the state produced Mrs. Louise Hoffer. Mrs. Hoffer testified that she was the Vital Statistics Clerk in Anchorage
column5: that she was the custodian of the birth certificate which she had been required by subpoena to bring to court. The certificate was admitted
column6: although appellant objected on various grounds.[5]

column1: Appellant testified that at the time of the trial he was twenty years of age. Because of this testimony the introduction of the birth certificate
column2: if it were error
column3: could not have amounted to harmful error under Love v. State
column4: 457 P.2d 622 (Alaska 1969). The effect of this birth certificate was completely cumulative
column5: insofar as appellant's actual age was a relevant issue at all. For these reasons we will not give further consideration to this point.

column1: The trial court permitted Trooper Anderson
column2: over appellant's objection
column3: to testify that on an occasion previous to the evening of the arrest he had seen appellant's driver's license and had observed the birth date stated on it. This evidence was offered for the purpose of establishing that Trooper Anderson had probable cause to arrest appellant for the misdemeanor of being a minor in possession of alcoholic beverages.

column1: Appellant objected to this testimony on the ground that it violated the hearsay rule. It appears to us that for the purposes for which this testimony was offered the hearsay rule never came into play. We view this testimony as falling under the doctrine which permits statements by a third party declarant when they are offered to show the state of mind of the *429 one who hears the statement. C. McCormick
column2: Evidence § 228 (1954). This testimony was clearly admissible to show that Trooper Anderson possessed such knowledge as would reasonably lead him to believe that the offense was being committed in his presence. Once again
column3: we are unable to find any error committed by the trial court.

column1: VI

Appellant makes a number of claims of error which we have examined and find to be of little merit. In many instances appellant sets forth a scant discussion of the legal reasoning of the authorities on which the claim of error is based. We have
column2: nevertheless
column3: examined these points to be certain that plain error was not committed which might affect the integrity of appellant's conviction.

column1: The claim is made that during the cross-examination of the witness Meyer
column2: who had accompanied Trooper Anderson on the night in question
column3: he was asked whether he recalled using in his report to the police some words to the effect that appellant had stabbed or threatened Anderson with the bayonet. His first answer was that he did not recall any such words. On redirect examination
column4: after refreshing his recollection with the written statement he had made the morning after the arrest
column5: Meyer answered that he did use such words in his report to the police. On recross-examination
column6: defense counsel attempted to question Meyer about another portion of his written statement
column7: but the court sustained the appellee's objection on the ground that the question was outside the scope of the redirect examination.

column1: Finally the state offered to put the whole statement in evidence. Appellant's counsel then moved for a mistrial
column2: which was denied. In his brief
column3: appellant claims that the state knew that the entire statement would be hearsay and inadmissible and that its offer to place the statement in evidence was in itself enough to require the granting of a mistrial. We find
column5: that appellant himself was responsible for the state's offer because he had gone beyond the scope of redirect examination
column6: thus causing the question of what was in the statement to be left unanswered. We conclude that the denial of the motion for mistrial was proper.

column1: During the direct examination of Trooper Anderson
column2: in answering a question in a somewhat narrative form
column3: he volunteered the statement that he had had contacts with appellant on occasions previous to the evening in question and that he
column5: was able to perceive that appellant was ""under the influence
column6: presumably of alcohol. The prosecutor stopped the witness at this point. Appellant's counsel then moved for a mistrial. Appellant argues that such evidence was irrelevant and prejudicial and that a mistrial should have been granted. The state argues that the statement was not prejudicial because the officer was stopped before his statement was completed
column7: and it is pointed out that no request was made by appellant to strike the testimony or to have the jury instructed to disregard it.

column1: Not every volunteered statement becomes a ground for mistrial. In the particular circumstances of this case we are unable to conclude that the statement objected to required the granting of a mistrial
column2: particularly in view of appellant's failure to seek other remedies to cure any harm which might have been done by the words uttered by the witness.

column1: Trooper Anderson testified that a few months prior to the arrest he had seen appellant's driver's license in the course of investigating a gun accident in which appellant had shot himself and that he knew appellant was a minor at the time of the arrest. On cross-examination Anderson said he had made notes at the time he saw the driver's license. Appellant's counsel moved for a production of Trooper Anderson's notes under AS 12.45.060.[6]*430 Trooper Anderson said that he did not know where his notes were
column2: and the prosecutor said that the state had no idea where they might be. Appellant moved to strike the testimony of Trooper Anderson or in the alternative to declare a mistrial under AS 12.45.080.[7] The denial of this motion is claimed as error.

column1: Anderson's notes of appellant's age made in the course of an investigation not related to the present criminal charge are not a ""statement"" or ""report"" for purposes of AS 12.45.060 and .070. The trial court properly denied appellant's motion to invoke the sanction under AS 12.45.080.[8]
The court instructed the jury to the effect that it was a misdemeanor for a minor to possess or control alcoholic beverages. Alaska Administrative Code
column2: Title 15
column3: Ch. 4
column4: § 4073. Appellant claims that the instruction was not complete and should have included the language of AS 04.15.080(b)
column5: which defines the crime of giving liquor to minors as not including a parent as to his own child. This latter offense had no relevancy to the case at bar. It may have been appellant's theory that he could be in lawful control of alcoholic beverages because they had been placed in his control by his parent. But appellant was not on trial for possessing alcoholic beverages. The mere existence of a possible defense of this kind would not negate the probable cause for arrest as perceived by Trooper Anderson. We find no error.

column1: Appellant requested an instruction which would have told the jury that intoxicating liquor is defined by AS 04.20.010 as containing more than one per cent alcohol by volume
column2: and that an instruction should have been given to the effect that a beverage cannot be determined to be alcoholic in content by sight alone. In response
column3: the state argues that the instruction given was a proper statement of the law on the question of whether the officer had probable cause to believe that appellant was in the unlawful possession of an alcoholic beverage. We agree. The instructions contended for by appellant would only have confused the issue to be determined by the jury.

column1: The indictment charged that appellant attempted to stab Trooper Anderson. The statute under which the indictment was brought
column3: uses the term ""stab at another"" in defining the offense. The verdict found the appellant guilty of attempting to stab with the intent *431 to wound
column4: but did not include the words ""at another."" The appellant claims that this is a material variance and the verdict should not have been accepted. No authority is cited in support of this contention. We do not think that extended discussion is in order. We are unable to find any error.

column1: Finally
column2: we find that appellant's contention that in sentencing appellant the court improperly relied upon mere contacts with the police not resulting in convictions is not supported by the record. We find no error.

column1: The judgment of conviction is affirmed.
NESBITT
column2: C.J.
column3: not participating.

column1: NOTES

[1] Crim.R. 6(l) provides: ""Discharge and Excuse. A grand jury shall serve until discharged by the presiding superior court judge of the judicial district but no grand jury may serve more than 5 months
column2: unless for good cause such period is extended. The tenure and powers of a grand jury are not affected by the beginning or expiration of a term of court. At any time for cause shown the presiding judge may excuse a juror either temporarily or permanently
column3: and in the latter event said judge may impanel another person in place of the juror excused."" (Emphasis supplied.)

column1: [2] The statute dealt with in Coverstone v. Davies
column2: supra
column3: was amended in 1957 to authorize warrantless arrests where the officer reasonably believes that an offense is being committed or attempted in his presence. See California Penal Code

column1: [3] It is recognized
column2: of course
column3: that the grounds for arresting a person without a warrant for a misdemeanor committed in the presence of an officer are considerably more restricted than those which would constitute probable cause for a felony arrest without a warrant. By our opinion today we do not mean to imply any change in the rules concerning felony arrests.

column1: [4] It should be noted that the rule we formulate today has no application when the arrestee apprehends bodily injury
column2: or when an unlawful arrest is attempted by one not known to be a peace officer. Quite different problems are then presented.

column1: [5] The document in court was a carbon copy of an original which is kept in Juneau. Appellant in effect claimed this carbon copy should not be considered a duplicate original but simply an uncertified copy of an original. He further claimed he was not served in advance with a copy of the document and that it was introduced contrary to ""the statutes and regulations.""
[6] AS 12.45.050 ""In a criminal prosecution
column2: no statement or report in the possession of the state which was made by a prosecution witness or prospective prosecution witness (other than the defendant) to an agent of the state may be the subject of subpoena
column3: discovery
column4: or inspection until the witness has testified on direct examination in the trial of the case.""

column1: AS 12.45.060 ""After a witness called by the state has testified on direct examination
column2: the court shall
column3: on motion of the defendant
column4: order the state to produce any statement of the witness in the possession of the state which relates to the subject matter as to which the witness has testified. If the entire contents of the statement relate to the subject matter of the testimony of the witness
column5: the court shall order it to be delivered directly to the defendant for his examination and use.""

column1: [7] AS 12.45.080 ""If the state elects not to comply with an order of the court to deliver to the defendant a statement or a portion of a statement as the court may direct
column2: the court shall strike from the record the testimony of the witness
column3: and the trial shall proceed unless the court in its discretion determines that the interests of justice require that a mistrial be declared.""

column1: [8] We do not view our ruling as relaxing in any way the requirements of Mahle v. State
column3: that certain reports and materials must be made available to the defendant. Here we are dealing with notes that have to do with a case other than the one being tried. These were not notes as to which the prosecutor or the witness would have reasonably anticipated a requirement of production at trial
column4: nor would there have been any reason for them to anticipate that they should search for these notes before trial so as to have them available for inspection."	Miller v. State		[]	['state'

column1: In that case an indictment returned by a grand jury containing two unqualified members was held to be valid.
The role of the foreman was described by the court in People v. Whalen
column2: supra
column3: in the following terms:""The foreman of the grand jury is appointed by the judge of the court which impaneled the grand jury.

column1: Rubey v. City of Fairbanks
column3: 474 (Alaska 1969); Herrin v. State

column1: At least one state court has adopted the recommended rule as a matter of its common law development."

column5: the Theory points out that no two countries that both have McDonalds franchises have ever gone to war. The reasoning behind this correlation
column7: is that once economies become sufficiently integrated
column8: both the cost of going to war and the amount of contact between two countries will increase. Both these factors lead to more effective conflict resolution
column9: as states will attempt to pursue the more economically beneficial option. Friedman’s argument echoes the main suppositions of the democratic peace theory
column10: which states that democracies never go to war. Friedman’s analysis simply takes this argument further in his economic emphasis
column11: although he places a similar amount of emphasis on the role of domestic society in influencing a government’s willingness to go to war.

column1: Problems with the Golden Arches Theory
The Golden Arches Theory has not held true in all cases
column2: and explanations to explain these inconsistencies vary. In some cases
column3: the increased contact between two countries due to integration may actually exacerbate points of contention between the two states
column4: leading to more opportunities for conflict. Or
column5: the difference may lie in the type of government in power: a democratic government may follow the Golden Arches Theory
column6: but the Theory may break down when confronted with cases of nondemocratic or authoritarian regimes. The Golden Arches Theory assumes that governments respond to the desires of their constituents for economic stability and that the government knows it will be held accountable in the case that it does not provide for the economic well-being of its citizens. In the case of an authoritarian or nondemocratic state
column7: leaders may not experience these dilemmas
column8: causing them not to act in accordance with the Golden Arches Theory. [1]

column6: 'https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2018/09/27/watch-lindsey-graham-angry-defense-brett-kavanaugh/lWntvrd4xP02cXr5R7w25L/story.html']	https://mashable.com/article/lindsey-graham-tweets/	https://mashable.com/	"The bruising battle over Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination may be finished
column7: but the political scars will last a lifetime. That is true for no one more than Sen. Lindsey Graham.

column1: Formerly a believer that a judge must be removed if he commits perjury
column2: the Republican from South Carolina turned a blind eye to Kavanaugh's many demonstrable fibs. Formerly known for his bipartisanship
column3: Graham elected to play the attack dog. (Curiously enough
column4: this turn came after the Judiciary Committee's counsel started asking Kavanaugh searching questions about his history of drinking and partying.)

column1: For Graham watchers
column2: the hearings were the latest evidence of the senator's disturbing transformation from Never Trumper to Trump apologist. ""What happened to Lindsey Graham?"" is the question asked by three separate profiles in the past month. A New York Times columnist just dubbed him ""the saddest story in Washington.""

column1: Some commentators have pointed to the death of his good friend Sen. John McCain of Arizona this summer as a turning point for Graham. In reality
column2: he's been sliding down this path for years. And the best place to witness his transformation — indeed
column3: to glimpse the regression of the GOP as a whole — is via his Twitter account

column1: First
column2: let's remind ourselves of what Graham used to be like in 2009. In Obama's first term
column3: he was to be found working with John Kerry on a bipartisan bill to put a price on carbon emissions back when Kerry was a senator: ""Yes we can (pass climate change legislation)
column4: the pair wrote in the Times. (No

column1: You can see the exact moment Graham realized his fellow Republicans were not as keen on Obama as he was. In the middle of a September 2009 speech to Congress
column2: Graham starts to applaud the president's words on education
column3: then suddenly thinks better of it.

column1: Graham didn't join Twitter until December 2011
column2: and didn't start tweeting until March 2012. His first tweet thanked supporters for coming to a fish fry and vowed to make Obama a ""one-term president.""

column1: But nearly all his tweets were innocuous back then: bland statements of support for GOP candidates; approving reports of his visits to Google and Apple; a photo of his fashion choices on the links.
Enjoyed playing golf today with friends from Electric Co-ops of SC. They provide invaluable service to us. #sctweets pic.twitter.com/VhKdleAS — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) May 14
Graham announced his own bid for the presidency on June 1
column2: 2015. He touted his experience
column3: and compared himself favorably to Hillary Clinton in that area. But he was also careful to strike a note of civility and bipartisanship — one that sounds like it's from a lifetime ago

column1: To my friends in the other party: Our differences are real
column2: and we’ll debate them. But you’re not my enemy. You’re my fellow countrymen. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) June 1

column1: Donald Trump announced his candidacy two weeks later. Graham didn't even think it worth tweeting about. Nor did he mention Trump's comments calling Mexican immigrants criminals and ""rapists."" His first ever Trump tweets came a month later
column2: after Trump denied that McCain was a ""war hero"" because ""I like people that don't get captured.""

column1: .@SenJohnMcCain
column2: like every other POW
column3: went through hell & has earned our respect & gratitude — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) July 18

column1: That subtweet was immediately followed by a direct attack on Trump's fitness for office.
If there was ever any doubt that @realDonaldTrump should not be our commander in chief
column2: this stupid statement should end all doubt. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) July 18

column1: Trump punched back by giving Graham's cellphone number out during a campaign speech. Graham's response was to bring a droll understatement to a knife fight.
Probably getting a new phone. iPhone or Android? — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) July 21
Still
column2: Graham wasn't cowed; his attacks on Trump ramped up over the following months.

column1: .@RealDonaldTrump unrelenting & offensive comments about @MegynKelly puts the @GOP at a crossroads w/Mr. Trump — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 8
Here's Graham's first actual joke at Trump's expense:
Donald Trump gets his foreign policy from watching television - the Cartoon Network. #CNNDebate #ReadyToLead — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) September 17
But when Trump called for a ""total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States
column2: Graham — like many of us — decided the reality TV star's campaign was no laughing matter.

column1: .@Realdonaldtrump has gone from making absurd comments to being downright dangerous with his bombastic rhetoric. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) December 7
The next day
column2: Graham took direct aim at the MAGA slogan using his strongest swear word.

column1: “You know how you make America great again? Tell @realDonaldTrump to go to hell” https://t.co/pBLaZ1kgUV — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) December 8
The following week
column2: Trump made an ominous statement of support for Russia's president. Back then
column3: Graham considered it an even more serious foreign policy blunder.

column1: Just when you think it can’t get worse: A leading American candidate for President praising Putin. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) December 17
Graham dropped out of the presidential race on December 21
column3: citing poor polling numbers. But that didn't stop him from attacking Trump in unequivocal language.

column1: Donald Trump is not a conservative Republican. He's an opportunist. He's not fit to be President of the United States. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) February 17
On February 20
column3: Trump swept the GOP primary in Graham's home state
column5: Graham and Trump got into the first of two Twitter spats.

column1: @realDonaldTrump I never got past 2%.
You aren't prepared to be Commander in Chief of worlds finest fighting force https://t.co/7prb7ZdEVg — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) March 7
On May 3
column3: Trump's last opponent with a shot at defeating him
column5: dropped out of the race. Graham was in an apocalyptic mood. He posted a dire prediction to his party — one that remains his most liked

column1: If we nominate Trump
column2: we will get destroyed.......and we will deserve it. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) May 3

column1: Just nine days later
column2: however
column3: Trump won the delegates he needed. Graham posted this
column4: and you can almost hear the gnashing of teeth.

column1: I had a cordial
column2: pleasant phone conversation with Mr. Trump yesterday. I congratulated him on winning the GOP nomination for President. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) May 12

column1: If anyone on Trump's campaign expected Graham to fall into line
column2: however
column3: they were disappointed.

column1: Last night
column2: if you were looking for competency Donald Trump fell short. #CommanderInChiefForum — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) September 8

column1: A day after the infamous Access Hollywood tape was released
column2: Graham again made his anti-Trump feelings clear.

column1: I have never been comfortable with Donald Trump as our Republican nominee. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) October 8
Name one sports team
column2: university
column3: publicly-held company
column4: etc. that would accept a person like this as their standard bearer? — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) October 8

column1: In the wake of three disastrous debate performances by Trump
column2: Hillary Clinton was riding high in the polls. Graham's tweets indicated he considered Trump's campaign to be a lost cause.

column1: Keeping GOP in control of Congress is best insurance policy American people can take out against Clinton agenda.https://t.co/TSfHsgrl0F — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) October 24

Not even the last-minute bombshell of then FBI director James Comey reopening an investigation into Clinton's emails deterred Graham from making it clear on election day that he did not vote for Trump.
In the prez race
column2: voting for Hillary Clinton was always a non-starter and I couldn’t go where Donald Trump wanted to take the USA & GOP. #2 — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) November 8

column1: Instead the senator punched his ballot for a Republican running as an independent
column2: Evan McMullin.

column1: I voted @Evan_McMullin for President. I appreciate his views on a strong America and the need to rebuild our military. #3 — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) November 8
Even after a perfunctory statement congratulating Trump on his surprise victory
column2: Graham remained cautious — particularly about Trump's relationship with Russia.

column1: I hope President-elect Trump won’t become the 3rd American president to misjudge Vladmir Putin. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) December 16
In the month after Trump's inauguration
column2: Graham's tweets continued to be ambivalent. Reacting to a Trump proposal for a ""border tax"" on Mexico to build the wall
column3: Graham tried to bring the funny by tweeting that it was ""mucho sad.""

column1: Simply put
column2: any policy proposal which drives up costs of Corona
column3: tequila
column4: or margaritas is a big-time bad idea. Mucho Sad. (2) — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) January 26

column1: Graham tweeted support for all Trump's cabinet picks
column2: but also pushed for investigations into Russia's impact on the 2016 election — and cautioned against the first Muslim travel ban.

column1: Ultimately
column2: I fear this executive order will become a self-inflicted wound in the fight against terrorism. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) January 29

column1: But if there is a pivot point in Graham's relationship with Trump
column2: it arrived in March 2017. He issued a statement in support of the second travel ban
column3: and had a White House meeting that seemed to thaw relations — to the point where he and Trump became phone buddies again.

column1: How good was the meeting with @POTUS?
I gave him my NEW cell phone number. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) March 7
Still
column2: Graham was prepared to defend Jeff Sessions against Trump's insistence that the Attorney General prosecute Hillary Clinton — even if the strongest word he could muster to describe this norm-breaking outrage was ""inappropriate.""

column1: President Trump’s tweet today suggesting Attorney General Sessions pursue prosecution of a former political rival is highly inappropriate. 4 — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) July 25
When literal Nazis and Klansmen rallied in Charlottesville
column2: Graham was prepared to attack Trump over his ""many sides"" statement. But he didn't dare tweet his complaints directly
column3: preferring to link to a newspaper interview.

column1: Spoke with the media earlier today in Columbia about #charlottesville and steps forward.https://t.co/FFwxaUKDcj — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 15
Two days later Trump struck back at Graham directly
column2: calling him ""publicity seeking"" and a ""disgusting"" liar. Graham then got into his second ever quote-tweet spat. In a non-threaded thread
column3: he warned Trump that he was now being quoted approvingly by racist hate groups
column4: implored him to ""fix this"" and said that ""history is watching us all.""

column1: Mr. President
column2: like most I seek to move our nation
column3: my state
column4: and our party forward - toward the light - not back to the darkness. (1) https://t.co/K1j4JnhCgf — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 17

column1: But by this point
column2: Graham could not attack Trump without sending an approving tweet literally one minute later.

column1: Your tweet honoring Miss Heyer was very nice and appropriate.
Well done. (2) https://t.co/8I6LVMDXUy — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 17
Trump's announcement calling for a troop surge in Afghanistan the following week seemed to patch things up as far as the hawkish Graham was concerned.
And then
column2: a couple months later
column3: the golfing began.

column1: How bad did he beat me? I did better in the presidential race than today on the golf course!
Great fun. Great host. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) October 9
Trump International Golf Club is a spectacular golf course.
Great day of fun playing with @POTUS @realDonaldTrump. https://t.co/92Xjk8d8B2 — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) December 10
Later that month
column2: the supposed fiscal conservative Graham voted for Trump's deficit-ballooning trillion-dollar tax cut. By Trump's first State of the Union in January 2018
column3: the senator was tweeting full-throated support for the ""law and order president.""

column1: President Trump clearly relishes being the Law and Order president and a strong Commander in Chief.
Just what America needs! — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) January 31
In April
column2: two years after predicting the GOP would be ""destroyed"" by Trump
column3: Graham announced he was all in for Trump 2020.

column1: As to the 2020 presidential race
column2: I believe President @realDonaldTrump will run for reelection and I intend to support him. https://t.co/vsExZ1XehG — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) April 19

column1: The preemptive endorsement also marked a distinctive trend in Graham's tweets: Since March 2018
column2: he has started using Trump's twitter handle. A lot.

column1: Happy Birthday
column2: Mr. President!

column1: You’re keeping your promise to make America safer and more prosperous.
And unfortunately for me
column2: you’re doing all this without losing a step in your golf game!@realDonaldTrump #TrumpBirthday pic.twitter.com/PJRa54FVAP — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) June 14

column1: In July
column2: Trump's craven display of obsequiousness towards Vladimir Putin in Helsinki shocked the world. Graham had once considered Trump's support for Putin worse than his proposal for a Muslim travel ban. Now he merely described it as a ""missed opportunity.""

column1: Missed opportunity by President Trump to firmly hold Russia accountable for 2016 meddling and deliver a strong warning regarding future elections.
This answer by President Trump will be seen by Russia as a sign of weakness and create far more problems than it solves. (1/3) — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) July 16
Even that mild display of dissent was erased a couple days later
column2: when Graham credulously insisted Trump was not denying the conclusions of his own intelligence services.

column1: I have just been reassured unequivocally by the White House legislative team that the President’s ‘no’ response today to shouted questions was not intended to suggest that President Trump doubts the intelligence community’s assessment that Russia is continuing to attack.... — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) July 18
Soon enough
column2: Graham was couching his Russia criticism within a statement that he was ""totally"" agreeing with Trump.

column1: Totally agree with President Trump’s observation about Russia not being long-term pro-Republican or pro-Trump. Putin is pro-Chaos and is an Equal Opportunity Disruptor of the American electoral system.
Let’s act together
column2: let’s act now. https://t.co/iY5or4mLpA — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) July 24

column1: In April 2018
column2: Graham had signed on to a bipartisan Senate bill that would have specifically protected Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

column1: But in August 2018
column2: the bill having gone nowhere
column3: Graham tweeted that he hoped Mueller would ""wrap up his investigation sooner rather than later.""

column1: He also gave an interview in which he appeared to back away from supporting Jeff Sessions. For the first time
column2: Trump quoted Graham approvingly.

column1: .@LindseyGrahamSC “Every President deserves an Attorney General they have confidence in. I believe every President has a right to their Cabinet
column2: these are not lifetime appointments. You serve at the pleasure of the President.” — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 25

column1: There was little time for Graham to respond to that tweet. John McCain
column2: who had not wavered in his opposition to Trump
column3: passed away later the same day.

column1: I will need some time to absorb this
column2: but I want Cindy —and the entire McCain family — to know they are in my prayers. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 26

column1: McCain had specifically disinvited Trump from the funeral
column2: but Graham was able to wangle an invite for Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner. Around the same time
column3: he tweeted a photo of his meeting with Ivanka.

column1: Great meeting with @IvankaTrump and her daughter Arabella.
I appreciate all Ivanka is doing to improve the plight of women in the developing world. pic.twitter.com/OLNdxzWPop — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 29
After the McCain funeral
column2: Graham's long transformation into a Trump surrogate seemed complete. Here he is a week later
column3: tweeting his support in the wake of early revelations from Bob Woodward's book Fear.

column1: By any reasonable measure we have one of the strongest economies in modern history
column2: President Trump has rebuilt a broken military
column3: and we are pushing back hard against America’s enemies. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) September 5

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Republican representatives in the House were in the throes of discrediting Mueller's investigation by attacking the investigators. This presented no problem for Graham.

column1: It is increasingly clear it was the Obama Administration who politicized the DOJ/FBI
column2: not the Trump Administration. — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) September 11

column1: What is interesting to follow through all this is how much more frequently Graham tells us to tune in to appearances on Fox News
column2: Fox Business News
column3: and CNN. The more controversial he gets

column1: And then we come to the Kavanaugh nomination
column2: and the revelation of Dr. Christine Blasey Ford's accusation. In a startling display of hypocrisy
column3: the senator who had gone all-in for a man he once despised now accused Democrats of acting in a Machiavellian manner.

column1: When it comes to stopping Pres @realDonaldTrump and his agenda there seem to be no boundaries.
Whether it’s coaching witnesses or reporting thinly-sourced stories without proper verification
column2: everything is fair game and falls into the category of – ‘The Ends Justify the Means.' — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) September 24

column1: By the end of the nomination process
column2: Graham wasn't just supporting Trump in his tweets — he was starting to sound like him. Note the use of ellipses instead of numbering his tweets
column3: the one-word descriptions
column4: and the very Trumpian touch of capitalizing the word ""victory.""

column1: …..finally thank you President @realDonaldTrump for the good judgment in selecting Judge Kavanaugh and the toughness and determination to stick by his side and see it through to Victory! — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) October 6
Perhaps there is more of Graham's Twitter story to be told; maybe he will disentangle himself from Trump after the midterms. But at the moment
column2: his trail of shifting positions looks like a cautionary tale for future generations.

column1: Here
column2: kids
column3: is what happens when you gain a tax cut
column5: and a whole lot of airtime
column6: but lose your political soul."	The decline and fall of Lindsey Graham
column7: as told by his tweets	2018-10-09 10:00:00+00:00	['Chris Taylor']	['president'

column1: — Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) December 7
