column1: The Honorable Rosa DeLauro
U.S. House of Representatives
2262 Rayburn House Office Bldg.
Washington
Dear Representative DeLauro:
On behalf of the American Medical Association (AMA)
column2: I am writing to express our appreciation for your introduction of H.R. 536
column3: ""Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 2001."" The AMA applauds this bipartisan effort aimed at providing coverage for the reasonable treatment of breast cancer.

column1: Your bill focuses on the fundamental concept that medical decisions should be made by patients and their physicians
column2: rather than by insurers. The AMA feels that decisions regarding medical matters
column3: including a patients length of stay in a hospital
column4: must reside with patients and physicians. Moreover
column5: decisions impacting an individual patient must be determined by the specific circumstances affecting that patient. We believe that H.R. 536 meets these objectives.

column1: The AMA will continue to work to ensure that appropriate medical decision making is left in the hands of physicians in consultation with their patients.
Respectfully
E. Ratcliffe Anderson
column2: Jr.
column3: MD"	"AMA (Washington) AMA Letter to Representative Rosa DeLauro Supporting HR 536
column4: the ""Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 2001"""		[]	['hr'

column1: Your Name Displayed during the State of the Union

column6: H.R. 1886 Back to Legislation This year
column10: and grandmothers will be diagnosed with invasive breast cancer. Another 44
column11: 300 women will die from this deadly form of cancer. With every one in eight American women developing this disease
column12: it's difficult to find a person who doesn't know someone who is affected by breast cancer. In 1996
column13: a Middletown surgeon named Dr. Kristin Zarfos sought the help of Congresswoman DeLauro in confronting what she described as the greatest challenge of her surgical career. She faced two HMOs refusing hospitalization for women undergoing a mastectomy or lymph node removal for breast cancer. Despite a prevailing medical standard of two to four days to recuperate and gain physical and emotional strength
column14: women were regularly faced with being sent home a few hours after surgery. Dr. Zarfos and Congresswoman DeLauro worked together to find a legislative solution to the problem of outpatient mastectomies. DeLauro introduced the Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act in January 1997 to ensure that women suffering from breast cancer receive the medical attention they deserve. It was reintroduced in 108th Congress on April 30
column15: 2003 and designated H.R. 1886. The Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act will guarantee a minimum hospital stay of 48 hours for a woman having a mastectomy
column16: and 24 hours for a woman undergoing a lymph node removal
column17: and will ensure that any decision to have a shorter hospital stay will be made by the patient and her doctor -- not an insurance company more concerned with the health of its profits than the health of the patient. Forcing women to leave the hospital too soon after surgery is dangerous and demeaning
column18: and this bill intends to stop the practice. Additional cancer and health related resources on the Internet: Yale University Cancer Center

Brady Press Briefing Room

column1: 2:41 P.M. EST
MS. SANDERS: Good afternoon
column2: everyone. Many of you probably saw Protective Life Corporation’s announcement this morning. As a direct result of the Trump tax cuts
column3: the Alabama-based company is raising their minimum wage to $15 per hour

column1: For those of you keeping track
column2: we now have over 350 companies that have announced wage increases
column3: bonuses
column5: or increased retirement benefits as a direct result of tax reform
column6: which not a single Democrat supported. These announcements have affected over 4 million American workers.

column1: The President is working to build an economy that works for all Americans. The tax cuts and reforms are a big part of that
column2: and so is infrastructure.

column1: As you all saw yesterday
column2: the President unveiled a Legislative Outline for Rebuilding Infrastructure in America. To cure decades of neglect
column3: we are committed to quickly building a safe
column5: and modern infrastructure to meet the needs of the American people and to fuel economic growth.

column1: And to help make this possible
column2: we have a very special announcement today. In keeping with his campaign pledge
column3: the President donates his salary on a quarterly basis to further work being done on important projects.

column1: Most recently
column2: the President donated his third-quarter salary to help the Department of Health and Human Services combat the opioid epidemic. Prior to that
column3: he donated to the Department of Education and the National Park Service.

column1: And today
column2: the President is proud to donate his fourth-quarter salary — 2017 salary to the Department of Transportation to support their programs to rebuild and modernize our crumbling infrastructure.

column1: Secretary of Transportation Elaine Chao is here to accept the check. I’d like to bring her up to say a few words
column2: take a couple of questions on infrastructure and about how these funds will be used. And I trust that you’ll stay on topic
column3: and then I’ll be back up afterwards to answer your questions on the news of the day.

column1: With that
column2: Secretary Chao. Thank you so much for being here.

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: Thank you. We have to get this check here
column2: and with all of us. (Laughter.)

column1: Thank you. Thank you
column2: Sarah. I’m accompanied here
column3: in case you were wondering
column4: by two officials of the U.S. Department of Transportation. I have with me
column8: the Senior Advisor to the Secretary for Infrastructure. They’re here because of this gift. And so let me proceed.

column1: As many of you have heard yesterday
column2: 12 federal agencies have been working with the White House on the comprehensive infrastructure proposal that the President announced yesterday. Transportation is one component. The proposal also includes energy
column3: drinking and waste water

column1: The goal of the President’s proposal is to stimulate at least $1.5 trillion in infrastructure investment
column2: which includes a minimum of $200 billion in direct federal funding. And a key element is to empower decision-making at the state and the local level because state and local officials know best the infrastructure needs of their communities.

column1: Many of you know that the principles are behind this
column2: and so I wanted to reiterate some of the principles. The principles behind this proposal are
column3: one
column4: to use federal dollars as seed money to encourage infrastructure investment by the states
column7: provide for the infrastructure needs of rural communities. Three
column9: invest in transformative projects that benefit everyone.

column1: We are already applying these principles to the Department of Transportation’s major existing infrastructure grant programs
column2: including
column3: for example
column4: the INFRA grants. And that is why these two gentlemen to my right are here — because their offices will be among those at the Department of Transportation that will be taking the applications and also administering these INFRA grants.

column1: This quarter
column2: as mentioned
column3: the President has generously decided to donate his annual salary to the Department’s INFRA Grant Programs. INFRA directly reflects the President’s proposal by providing dedicated
column4: discretionary funding for projects that address critical issues facing our nation’s highways and bridges and ports.

column1: Under the INFRA program
column2: states and localities that secure some funding or financing of their own are given higher priority access to federal funds. In addition
column3: INFRA also reserves at least 25 percent of its funding to be awarded to rural projects.

column1: So infrastructure is the backbone of our economy
column2: and it’s key to keeping our country competitive. The President’s proposal will create new jobs
column3: strengthen our economy
column4: and improve the quality of life for everyone.

column1: And so with that quick summary
column2: I’ll be more than glad to answer any questions.

column1: Yes
column2: John.

column1: Q Madam Secretary
column2: some of the criticisms of the President’s plan as outlined yesterday are that it puts too much of a burden on the states financially because the federal portion is about 13 percent of the overall
column3: and might also end up in people paying more taxes
column5: that sort of thing. What do you say to that?

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: You know
column2: federal money is not free. Federal money comes from our communities
column3: people
column5: and our communities. They take that money
column7: and then we decide how to use it
column8: and send it back to the communities with a lot of strings attached on what they need to do.

column1: So what we are trying to do is to recognize the states and localities
column2: communities understand best what their infrastructure needs are
column3: and to allow them to have much greater flexibility to decide their own projects
column4: in conjunction and in partnership with the federal government.

column1: Yes
column2: sir.

column1: Q Thanks
column2: Secretary Chao. One of the other criticisms about the President’s plan is that it doesn’t include addressing the Highway Trust Fund
column3: which only has so many years ahead of it — of funding — just a few years. Could you address why that was not included in the President’s broader infrastructure plan? And then
column4: what does the administration plan to do about that very important source of funding for infrastructure projects across the country?

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: Well
column2: the Highway Trust Fund does need to be addressed because
column3: every year
column4: more money goes out of it than receipts are received. And this will be a huge problem in 2021. So we
column6: have got to address this issue. So we’re not in any disagreement about that. And the issue is how
column7: and we look forward to consulting with Congress on how to do that. Because

column1: Q Madam Secretary
column2: so there are no plan — the White House doesn’t have a proposal right now for that?

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: Well
column2: we don’t want to do it unilaterally. As mentioned
column3: the President’s proposal consisted of principles. And we want to discuss and work in consultation
column5: with the Hill to address the infrastructure needs of our country.

column1: Q Madam Secretary
column2: thank you. The crumbling infrastructure. Could you talk to us about — we know what’s going on with roads
column3: bridges
column5: what have you. But when it comes to rural America
column6: can you give us specifics about what’s crumbling
column8: and what jobs will be given where?

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: Well
column2: I come from the state of Kentucky. I’m a proud Kentuckian
column3: and I come from a rural state. So I am especially concerned about the needs of rural America
column4: and we recognize that the needs of rural America are special. And that is why
column6: there is actually a provision which addresses the unique needs of rural America.

column1: So it will be separate from the — there’s a separate title that is addressed to rural America. And similarly
column2: there’s a separate title addressed to transformative technology as well. So
column3: for example
column6: one of his portfolio areas is transformational technology — autonomous vehicles
column7: automated driving systems. So that is another part of the President’s infrastructure proposal that we will be also discussing with the Hill.

column1: MS. SANDERS: Let’s take one last question.
SECRETARY CHAO: Yes.
Q Thank you
column2: Secretary Chao. As you know
column3: the federal gas tax has remained at 18.4 cents per gallon since 1993. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce has advocated an increase in the gas tax of 25 cents per gallon. The truckers — the American Trucking Associations recommended a 20-cent-per-gallon increase in the gas tax. What’s your view on this subject?

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: Well
column2: the President has not declared anything out of bounds
column3: so everything is on the table.

column1: The gas tax
column2: like many of the other pay-fors that are being discussed
column3: is not ideal. There are pros and cons. The gas tax has adverse impact
column5: on the most vulnerable within our society; those who depend on jobs
column6: who are hourly workers. So these are tough decisions
column9: we need to start the dialogue with the Congress
column10: and so that we can address these issues on this very important point.

column1: Q Could you just clarify your answer to John from the first question? Were you saying — there are strings attached. So you’re saying that taxes will increase and that tolls may increase
column2: or they won’t?

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: That is a decision that is up to the state and local governments. And also
column2: it’s going to depend — you know
column3: that gentleman mentioned about federal gas taxes. These are tough decisions. We all want better infrastructure. But unfortunately
column4: there’s just not enough money in the world to pay for all the infrastructure
column5: which is why the President’s infrastructure also emphasizes the private sector.

column1: Private sector pension funds are a tremendous source of capital for funding public infrastructure. There are states which disallow the private sector from investing in public infrastructure. So we hope that those restrictions can be removed.
And then
column2: for those states and localities that want to work with the private sector
column3: it’s their decision as to whether they want to use private activity bonds
column4: whether they want to use tolls
column5: whatever. What we are saying in this proposal is that we’re looking for creative ways for financing.

column1: And so tolls is one way. We’re not advocating for them. We’re also not endorsing them. It is really up to the local entities that are involved in trying to raise the financing.
Q Well
column2: but as a quick follow-up
column3: you’re from Kentucky
column4: so you well know the Watterson Expressway
column5: when it was widened in Louisville
column6: one of the biggest — one of the things they liked the best about it
column7: there was no toll. And so in rural areas
column8: it helped people get to where they wanted to go quicker. Here
column11: you have an abundance of tolls
column12: and it cuts into people’s paychecks. So while you’re espousing that you want to help out rural America
column13: isn’t that going to impact — or won’t tolls hurt rural America?

column1: SECRETARY CHAO: That’s really — okay
column2: you’re mixing up
column3: I think
column4: several things here. I’m so sorry. There’s actually going to be a title
column6: on rural America. So that is separate from the rest of the titles in this proposal that we’re talking about. So there will be a special section for rural America.

column1: And then
column2: as for whether other — urban areas want to embark upon tolls
column3: or private activity bonds
column5: that is up to them. We are giving them the flexibility to do so. So it’s actually — they’re getting much greater flexibility now to be able to look at the panoply of creative financing mechanisms
column6: and decide for themselves what they want.

column1: MS. SANDERS: Thank you so much.
SECRETARY CHAO: Thank you so much. I’m sure we’ll be talking more. Thank you.
MS. SANDERS: Thank you
column2: Secretary Chao. Due to the fact the President has got an event here momentarily
column3: we’ll jump straight into the questions for today.

column1: John.
Q As you know
column2: FBI Director Christopher Wray laid out a different timeline than the White House has been telling us
column3: or one that would seem to be in contradiction to the timeline that the White House has laid out
column4: in terms of what we knew when about Rob Porter. Can you speak to what the Director said? He seemed to indicate that the first that you would have known about this might have been in March
column7: then in January when the case was actually closed.

column1: MS. SANDERS: Look
column2: we explained the process extensively last week. The White House Personnel Security Office
column3: staffed by career officials
column4: received information last year in what they considered to be the final background investigation report in November. But they had not made a final recommendation for adjudication to the White House because the process was still ongoing when Rob Porter resigned.

column1: In the view of Personnel Security Office
column2: the FBI’s July report required significant additional investigatory fieldwork before Personnel Security Office could begin to evaluate the information for adjudication.

column1: As Director Wray said
column2: information was still coming to the White House Personnel Security Office in February.

column1: Q So just to be clear then — in the July report
column2: if not back to March
column3: was there information contained in those reports about the allegations about Rob Porter?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I wouldn’t have access to that information. I wouldn’t know the answer to that
column2: John.

column1: Kristen.
Q I just want to drill down on one important fact
column2: because you and Raj
column3: and you just said this again that the investigation was ongoing. Christopher Wray said it was closed in January. So who’s telling the truth here?

column1: MS. SANDERS: Both. As I said
column2: the FBI portion was closed. The White House Personnel Security Office
column3: who is the one that makes a recommendation for adjudication
column4: had not finished their process and therefore not made a recommendation to the White House.

column1: Q And let me just clarify one more point. You said yesterday that you didn’t get any paperwork from the FBI. Chris Wray said that he did submit paperwork in all the various months that were (inaudible).
MS. SANDERS: Again
column2: that would come through the White House Personnel Security Office
column3: which had not completed their investigation and not passed that information to the White House.

column1: Q But you acknowledge that you did receive paperwork.
MS. SANDERS: Again
column2: the White House — I think you need to be very clear about — there’s multiple groups here.

column1: The White House Personnel Security Office
column2: which is staffed by career officials
column3: would have — may have received information
column4: but they had not completed their process and made a recommendation to the White House for adjudication.

column1: Q And
column2: Sarah
column3: finally
column4: who allowed John Kelly — or Rob Porter rather
column5: to stay here without a permanent security clearance?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I can’t comment on specifics of that other than what we’ve already said on that matter.
Cecilia.
Q And
column2: Sarah
column3: could you answer questions about —

column1: MS. SANDERS: Sorry
column2: Kristen
column3: I’m going to keep moving because we got a short time fuse here today.

column1: Q Is the White House still maintaining that John Kelly really had no idea about these allegations of domestic abuse until this story broke?
MS. SANDERS: I can only give you the best information that I have
column2: and that’s my understanding.

column1: Q And does the President believe the women?
MS. SANDERS: Again
column2: the President takes all of these accusations very seriously. He believes in due process. Above everything else
column3: he supports the victims of any type of violence
column4: and certainly would condemn any violence against anyone.

column1: Q But we still haven’t heard him say that himself. The cameras were in front of him today —
MS. SANDERS: Again
column2: the President dictated to me specifically
column3: that comment yesterday which I read out to you guys.

column1: Zeke.
Q Thanks
column2: Sarah. I’ve got two you. First
column3: can you speak to — did anyone at the White House Personnel Security Office have any communication with anyone in the West Wing about Rob Porter’s clearance
column4: between when the FBI started submitting its interim reports and —

column1: MS. SANDERS: I’m not aware of any communication. I can’t say definitively
column2: but I’m not aware of any communication.

column1: Q And then
column2: secondly — on Capitol Hill today
column3: in an interview with the Associated Press
column4: DNI Coates said that those with interim security clearances should not be granted — should have limited access to classified information rather than access to the full gamut that a full clearance would provide.

column1: Can you speak to whether that is a current practice right now for the large number — for the significant number of officials
column2: whether it be the West Wing or the broader White House complex? The President’s aides who don’t have permanent security clearances
column3: do they have limited access to classified information?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I can’t speak to whether people have interim or permanent security clearances at all
column2: and therefore can’t comment on the process.

column1: We are following the process that has been used by previous administrations
column2: and we would rely on the law enforcement and intelligence communities to determine if that process needed to be changed.

column1: Q But the DNI suggested that it would be changed.
MS. SANDERS: And they would be the ones that would make that determination and play a role in what those changes would look like.
Josh.
Q Sarah
column2: are you saying that
column3: on four different occasions
column4: the FBI obviously said that it made the White House aware of the allegations
column5: and the White House said — officials said that
column7: they did not realize the extent of the allegations. Should someone at the FBI or the Personnel Security Office be punished for not telling White House officials? How can those two things be?

column1: MS. SANDERS: That’s something that would be well beyond my scope to determine
column2: Josh.

column1: Q Is the President upset
column2: though
column3: that they weren’t told
column5: but no one in the senior staff found out. Are you guys upset about that?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I haven’t asked him about that
column2: specifically.

column1: Matthew.
Q Thanks
column2: Sarah. Raj
column3: the other day
column6: that the situation could have been handled better. Yesterday
column7: you echoed that and said the situation could have been handled better. Today
column8: the Chief of Staff said it was all done right. Can you explain — does the White House think this Rob Porter situation could have been handled differently? Or do you guys think this was all done right?

column1: MS. SANDERS: Look
column2: as I said yesterday
column3: I think every day we come here
column4: we do the very best that we can
column5: and every day we can do better than the day before. And we’re going to continue to strive for that. We’re humans
column6: making us imperfect people. And so
column8: I think we can learn from the day before
column9: and we can strive to do better. And that’s our goal
column11: and we’re going to continue to try to do everything we can to help serve the American people to the best of our ability.

column1: Q Was it appropriate for Hope Hicks to be involved in drafting some of these statements
column2: given her relationship with Mr. Porter?

column1: MS. SANDERS: She was not part of a lot of the conversations that took place. I don’t recall any of you being in the room to be able to say specifically what comments she made or didn’t make. She’s the White House Communications Director
column2: and is an important and valuable member of the staff
column3: and she has done a great job in that role.

column1: Steve.
Q Was there some discussion here about promoting Rob Porter to another job at the time that this all blew up?
MS. SANDERS: Not that I’m aware of. I just — I don’t know the answer to that.
Jeff.
Q Sarah
column2: you said that the FBI has said it was completed in late July
column3: but you said a follow-up required more fieldwork on that. Was that because of something that Rob Porter said in response to that
column4: that the allegations weren’t true? Or what required more fieldwork follow-up?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I wouldn’t know the specifics. I can only refer you back to the previous statement.
Q If I could ask again
column2: though. In an op-ed this morning in the Washington Post
column3: the first wife of Rob Porter said specifically of you
column4: “I expected a woman to do better.” Based on what you know
column5: do you believe you were personally misled? And do you have any regret for how you have explained this to the American people?

column1: MS. SANDERS: Look
column2: as I said
column3: we do the very best job we can every single day. I would never presume to understand anything going on with that individual
column4: nor would I think that she could presume what’s going on with me or the way that I’m responding.

column1: Look
column2: we’ve condemned domestic violence in every way possible. In fact
column3: the President’s budget that he released yesterday fully funds the Violence Against Women Act. We’re looking for ways that we can take action to help this prevent this from ever happening to anyone. And to presume that I feel differently is simply a very strong mischaracterization of who I am and who this White House is
column4: and what our actions are focused on
column5: and what we’re trying to do here.

column1: Q If I could ask one more —
MS. SANDERS: Sorry
column2: I’m going to keep moving
column3: Joe.

column1: Q — where does John Kelly stand as we sit here today
column2: in terms of — if the President has confidence in him
column3: why does he have confidence in him
column4: based on everything we’ve learned over the last week?

column1: MS. SANDERS: Look
column2: I don’t have anything further to add. The President has confidence in his Chief of Staff. We’re going to continue trying to do the best we can to help the American people.

column1: Julie.
Q So a clarification and a question. In July
column2: when the FBI was sent back into the field to get more information
column3: are you telling us that no senior staff — not Don McGahn
column5: not John Kelly — nobody in the senior staff in the West Wing was involved in that decision to tell them to go back and see if they could get more information on what was —

column1: MS. SANDERS: Again
column2: not that I’m aware of. I can’t say with 100 percent certainty
column3: but not that I’m aware of
column4: of any conversations between those individuals.

column1: Q And then
column2: are you looking at
column3: now
column4: ways that you could change the process so that
column5: if a senior official in the White House is facing credible allegations of spousal abuse or some other criminal charge
column6: that senior staff would be notified in a more timely way? I mean
column7: this appears to have — if your timeline is accurate — taken more than a year.

column1: MS. SANDERS: Look
column2: again
column3: I think that this is a process that the law enforcement and intelligence community should weigh in on and determine if changes should be made to the way that it’s carried out.

column1: Q I’m not talking about their process; I’m talking about the process here — where an investigation
column2: where serious allegations could surface
column3: and that nobody in the West Wing would be aware of that.

column1: MS. SANDERS: But that would include those agencies and those departments. So you couldn’t exclude them from a conversation about what changes should and need to be made to any program.
I think that that would have to be something that involved all of the stakeholders and something
column2: certainly
column3: far beyond my purview to walk you through today.

column1: Q Just following up on what Julie was asking. You’re saying that law enforcement should weigh in
column2: but you’re the White House
column3: you’re in charge
column4: and this is your process. Should you not weigh in and take —

column1: MS. SANDERS: It’s actually not our process. A large number of the background component is run by the FBI. Other intelligence agencies weigh in.
Again
column2: what I said is that all of the stakeholders should be part of that discussion and it should be looked at and determined whether or not changes need to be made to the process.

column1: Q Given that it impacts the White House staff
column2: do you not want to request an improved process here?

column1: MS. SANDERS: Again
column2: that would go beyond my scope that I can walk you through here today
column3: but I think it’s certainly a conversation that all of those stakeholders should have.

column1: April.
Q Sarah
column2: a couple questions. In light of everything that’s going on
column3: is there a review now — an internal review — of all of those who have interim security clearances to see if they should stay or should they go?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I can’t speak about whether or not different staff have interim or permanent security clearances —
Q I’m not asking about different staff
column2: I’m asking about the process — all right. Is there a review of those who have interim passes to see if they’re going to stay or they’re going to go because — in light of what’s happening now?

column1: MS. SANDERS: My understanding is that has been ongoing for a while
column2: and that determination would be made outside of anything I can walk you through at this point.

column1: Q And you spoke of fully funding the Violence Against Women Act. It’s up for reauthorization. Tell me the price — how much the President is trying to put in that. And was that the price prior to all of this that’s happened with these two people in the last week?
MS. SANDERS: I’m sorry
column2: I’m not following your question.

column1: Q The budget. You’re saying the President is going to fully fund the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act that’s up in March. How much — what is he putting in his budget proposal?
MS. SANDERS: I’d have to look at the specific number
column2: but it was rolled out in the budget that was presented yesterday.

column1: Q You mentioned it
column2: but is the number
column3: the number that it’s always been
column4: or was it just done? Can you talk to us about the funding?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I know it what was requested has been put into the President’s budget.
Q When was it put in?
MS. SANDERS: It was in the budget that was rolled out yesterday that’s been part of the ongoing process.
Q But we just got the budget —
MS. SANDERS: We don’t write a budget
column2: like
column3: in 20 minutes
column4: so it’s been part of something that’s been ongoing.

column1: Q I understand that. I understand that. I understand that. But there’s some things in that budget Mr. Mulvaney did not tell us about yesterday.
MS. SANDERS: That means you probably didn’t ask those questions. I’m going to keep going.
John
column2: go ahead.

column1: Q He didn’t give us an answer. He purposely didn’t give us that information.
Q Thanks a lot
column2: Sarah. I wanted to just get some clarification from you regarding the testimony — the sworn testimony today by the FBI Director. He laid out the timeline. And according to the FBI Director’s testimony
column3: the FBI submitted a partial report on the investigation in question of Porter’s background check in March
column4: and then a completed background investigation in late July.

column1: And yesterday
column2: when I was asking you about when the White House Counsel learned about Mr. Porter
column3: had he learned before the report in the Daily Mail last week
column4: your reply to me was that
column5: “the process for the background was ongoing
column6: and the White House had not received any specific papers regarding the completion of that background check.”

column1: So those two statements — the FBI Director’s statement
column2: Mr. Wray
column3: and your statement yesterday seemed to be at odds with one another. Do you see anything that you’d like to clarify
column4: in terms of what I asked you today

column1: MS. SANDERS: Yeah
column2: as I said earlier
column3: my understanding is any information would have gone to the personnel security office. That office had not completed their process in order to make a recommendation for adjudication to the White House. That was still ongoing and therefore

column1: Q But you said the specific papers regarding the completion of the background check had not been received.
MS. SANDERS: That’s part of that process that the White House Personnel Security Office plays
column2: run by career officials
column3: and we hadn’t received a recommendation from that office.

column1: Q And yet
column2: the FBI Director said today
column3: under oath
column4: that the completed background investigation was actually submitted in late July. So which one is it?

column1: MS. SANDERS: Let me read this to you again:
The White House Personnel Security Office
column2: staffed by career officials
column3: received information last year in what they considered to be the final background investigation report in November. But they had not made a final recommendation for adjudication to the White House because the process was still ongoing when Porter resigned.

column1: In the view of Personnel Security Office
column2: the FBI’s July report required significant additional investigatory fieldwork before Personnel Security Office could begin to evaluate the information for adjudication.

column1: We find those statements to be consistent with one another.
Jacqueline.
Q Could Mr. McGahn come out here and answer —
MS. SANDERS: Sorry
column2: John
column3: I’m going to keep moving.

column1: Q — any questions that we may have regarding what he knew and when he knew it?
Q Sarah
column2: you’ve said repeatedly that you and the press team do the very best job you can to relay whatever information you know up there. So is there a feeling that Chief of Staff John Kelly has misled you and his colleagues on what he knew and when
column3: and set up the communications staff for failure to relay credible information to us over the past week in order to cover up the way that he handled the firing of Rob Porter?

column1: MS. SANDERS: No
column2: we’re simply stating that we’re giving you the best information that we’re going to have. Obviously
column3: the press team is not going to be as read-in
column5: as some other elements at a given moment on a variety of topics. But we relay the best and most accurate information that we have
column6: and we have get those from those individuals.

column1: Q And can you talk about the other staffers who have been dismissed previously for not passing background checks
column2: and why Porter wasn’t treated in a similarly timely manner?

column1: MS. SANDERS: My understanding is the same process was followed for all employees
column2: and it’s the same process that was used in previous administrations. And I can’t comment on anybody else’s dismissal.

column1: Toluse.
Q Thank you
column2: Sarah. You’ve talked multiple times about
column3: sort of
column4: wanting to get us the best information that you have. This scandal has been going on for a week now
column5: and we still don’t have answers to the basic questions of

column1: MS. SANDERS: I’ve done the best I can to walk you through that process
column2: as has Raj. We’ve done that pretty extensively
column3: and I’d refer you back to all of the statements we’ve given on that.

column1: Q So I want to ask you whether you’ve spoken specifically to General John Kelly and to the White House Counsel to ask them these questions. Because you’ve said
column2: I’m not aware or I’m not sure.

column1: MS. SANDERS: I have
column2: and this is the information that was given to me by those individuals.

column1: Q House Speaker Paul Ryan
column2: this morning
column3: on the Fox Business Network said we’ve got to get out on entitlements. He talked about a structural deficit problem. He said
column4: we need to “get our other partners in government
column6: to be willing to do the kind of entitlement reform that we’re willing to do in the House.” What — does the President disagree with House Speaker Paul Ryan on that question of the structural deficit and the problem of mandatory spending?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I would have to ask him specifically on that question. I know the President certainly would like to reduce the deficit
column2: and it’s one of the reasons that his budget — this budget reduced the deficit by $3 trillion
column3: which is one of the largest in history. And he’s going to continue to look for ways to do that.

column1: Q The Speaker says that it’s the structural deficit for mandatory spending
column2: not the discretionary spending
column3: that is the driver. He’s been saying this for years. Does the President disagree with him? I know he’s said he doesn’t agree with that approach to entitlements. Why does he not agree with that assessment?

column1: MS. SANDERS: I’d have to ask him what the specifics are that he doesn’t agree with him on.
Dave. We’ll make this the last question.
Q Thanks
column2: Sarah. Majority Leader McConnell said today that the DACA negotiations have to be done by the end of this week. Did he give the White House a heads-up on that decision? And does that reflect any view from the White House that Democrats are not bargaining in good faith? For example
column3: they didn’t — they blocked a vote on sanctuary cities today.

column1: MS. SANDERS: Look
column2: it’s up to Congress to set the timeline. The President has laid out the priorities that he has for that legislation
column3: and we’re only going to support a legislation that deals with those four priorities that we’ve laid out. We hope Republicans and Democrats can come together to a consensus to fix that problem and not kick the can down the road.

column1: Thanks
column2: guys.

column1: END
3:13 P.M. EST"	Press Briefing by Press Secretary Sarah Sanders and Secretary of Transportation Elaine Chao		[]	['president'

column1: MS. SANDERS: Again
column2: the White House — I think you need to be very clear about — there’s multiple groups here.

column1: Can you explain — does the White House think this Rob Porter situation could have been handled differently?
MS. SANDERS: I’m sorry
column2: I’m not following your question.

column1: And does that reflect any view from the White House that Democrats are not bargaining in good faith?"

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/foam-on-the-range-rover/	the contents of a few cans of frozen shaving cream will
column2: when thawed
column3: expand to fill an automobile.	false	[]		David Mikkelson	['http://cockeyed.com/inside/trueshave/trueshave.html'
column7: 'http://www.cockeyed.com/pranks/frozen/frozen.html']	http://www.cockeyed.com/pranks/frozen/frozen.html	http://www.cockeyed.com/	"I first heard of the frozen shaving cream prank during my first year at U.C. Santa Barbara. The prank goes like this: If you freeze a can of shaving cream in liquid nitrogen
column8: then carefully hacksaw the can open
column9: you can pull out a frozen shaving cream cylinder. This frozen foam block will expand at it heats up
column10: making a huge mess! Two frozen shaving cream ""bombs"" can fill an entire car
column11: so a car with a window rolled down makes the perfect target!

column1: This prank idea is well documented on the internet. It is posted in several places
column2: with some skepticism about the expansion possibilities of a frozen block of cream.

column1: The problem with this joke is the liquid nitrogen. Who has access to it? I love science. I love chemistry and physics. One time I held both Potassium and Daisy in my very hands
column2: but I've never even seen liquid Nitrogen in person. Nevertheless
column3: I accepted this prank as possible for many years.

column1: Upon completion of how much is inside shaving cream
column2: I began to have serious doubts about the legitimacy of this story. I witnessed first hand the pitiful patty of shaving cream that lives in those cans.

column1: Then
column2: one day
column3: I heard that a can of shaving cream could be frozen solid by a household freezer. I decided I'd have to try that some day.

column1: I kept a can of Colgate shaving cream in my freezer for about four days. I wanted to use it as a cool
column2: whipped desert topping
column3: but one night Tony left his car window down a bit and I decided to act. The steel can was extremely cold to the touch
column4: and felt very solid. I wore an oven mitt to protect my hand from the cold. I also wanted to shield the can from my warm hand. I wonder how one would grip a can frozen in liquid nitrogen.

column1: I used bolt cutters to snip the bottom seam of the can. A little shaving cream puffed out
column2: so I continued to work quickly.

column1: After a few minutes of work
column2: I was able to remove the bottom of the can with some pliers. I peeled off the thin steel and extracted the frozen core.

column1: The inside of a wrecked shaving cream can.
I had my prize
column2: an 11-ounce frozen block of shaving cream. It was already starting to heat up and foam out.

column1: It was a frozen cylinder. There was a little mound on the top
column2: where the cream had reached into the dome of the can.

column1: I placed the cream bomb into a small metal bowl.
In 17 minutes
column2: it was surrounded by a little lake of shaving cream.

column1: The lake grew...
... and grew as the shaving cream thawed. The shaving cream wasn't holding my attention
column2: so I started watching television instead. Unfortunately
column3: ""Blind Date"" was the only show on
column4: so I went back to watching the shaving cream.

column1: Two hours after it was released from the can
column2: the shaving cream crested the sides of the bowl. This was about 8 cups of foam.

column1: After three hours
column2: I fell asleep.

column1: The next morning
column2: I was in a panic. I had somehow forgotten to study for my Music117 exam! As I rushed to locate my backpack
column3: I found the entire back room overflowing with shaving cream! Luckily

column1: When I actually awoke
column2: the shaving cream had reached the end of it's growth. The shaving cream had nearly overflowed from the bowl
column3: overfilling it with about 12 cups of foam. It appears that the foam had expanded to about 850% of its frozen volume. Unfortunately
column4: this isn't very much shaving cream. This could make a real mess
column5: but it certainly isn't enough to fill up a car."	Cockeyed.com presents: Frozen Shaving Cream Prank		[]	['prank'

column8: 'https://www.thedailybeast.com/vatican-no-3-cardinal-george-pell-on-trial-for-historical-child-sex-charges/']	https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-43957330	https://www.bbc.com/	"Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Cardinal George Pell has pleaded not guilty to charges of sexual assault

column1: Vatican treasurer Cardinal George Pell will stand trial on historical sexual assault charges
column2: a court has ruled.

column1: Cardinal Pell formally pleaded not guilty to the charges on Tuesday. He has consistently denied any wrongdoing.
An Australian magistrate ruled on Tuesday that there was enough evidence for the case to proceed to a trial on some charges
column2: but not on others.

column1: Cardinal Pell
column3: is Australia's most senior Catholic and one of the most powerful officials in the Vatican.

column1: He was given a large police guard as he entered the Melbourne Magistrates' Court in front of dozens of media representatives and members of the public.
Cardinal Pell
column2: who is considered the Church's third-ranked official
column3: took a leave of absence from the Vatican last year to fight the charges in his home country.

column1: Most of the evidence given remains confidential.
But following the hearing on Tuesday
column2: his lawyer
column3: Robert Richter QC
column4: argued that the most ""vile"" allegations against his client had been dismissed.

column1: What is known about the allegations?
Last June
column2: police in the state of Victoria charged the senior cleric with what they described as historical charges involving ""multiple complainants"".

column1: More than 30 witnesses testified during a preliminary court hearing
column2: known as a committal
column3: that ran for four weeks from March. Many sessions were closed to the public
column4: which is standard practice in Victoria in sexual offence cases.

column1: Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Cardinal George Pell and his lawyer were given a police guard entering court
In open hearings
column2: the court heard that an alleged incident took place at a Melbourne cathedral in the 1990s when the cleric was archbishop of Melbourne.

column1: Another allegation related to a swimming pool in the city of Ballarat in the 1970s
column2: when Cardinal Pell was a local priest
column3: the court heard.

column1: What does Cardinal Pell say?
The cleric has consistently denied all accusations
column2: saying last year: ""I am innocent of these charges
column3: they are false. The whole idea of sexual abuse is abhorrent to me.""

column1: Cardinal Pell's lawyer
column2: Robert Richter QC
column3: told a previous hearing that the allegations were ""impossible""

column1: He argued that Cardinal Pell had been targeted by accusers because of his role as Australia's most senior Catholic figure
column2: and that his client had fully co-operated with police.

column1: What happened on Tuesday?
Magistrate Belinda Wallington said about half of the charges had sufficient evidence to be put to a trial.
An allegation that Cardinal Pell committed a sexual assault in a Ballarat cinema during a screening of Close Encounters of The Third Kind was among the charges that were dismissed.
In explaining that decision
column2: Magistrate Wallington cited inconsistencies between the evidence of the accused and other witnesses
column3: as well as timelines of when the film was screening.

column1: The evidence as a whole is not a sufficient weight for a jury to convict
column2: she said.

column1: Pell defiant
Hywel Griffith
column2: BBC News Sydney correspondent

column1: For over an hour
column2: Cardinal Pell listened studiously
column3: arms folded
column4: as all of allegations against him were described in detail.

column1: Surrounded by supporters in the front row
column2: he didn't react when the magistrate announced that half of the charges were to be dismissed.

column1: When he entered his plea
column2: Cardinal Pell remained seated but spoke in a loud
column3: defiant voice with two words: ""Not guilty.""

column1: And with that
column2: it was clear that the cardinal will now face a trial before a jury.

column1: His appearances so far have seen dozens of cameras trail his every move in and out of court. When a trial does finally take place
column2: the scrutiny is likely to be even more intense.

column1: What will happen now?
Cardinal Pell's trial will be held before a judge and a 12-person jury in the County Court of Victoria.
The court will hold an administrative hearing on Wednesday
column2: but the trial is not expected to begin for several months.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: the Archbishop of Melbourne
column3: Denis Hart
column4: said he had ""confidence in the judicial system in Australia and said that justice must now take its course""."	Cardinal Pell ordered to stand trial on sexual assault charges		[]	['evidence'

column1: (Before It’s News)
‘Songbird’ McCain: The evidence – in his own words

column1: My six years of hell: John McCain recalls life a prisoner of war in Vietnam – Daily Mail
Excerpt from “Faith of My Fathers” by McCain
“Hero” John McCain as Phony and Collaborator: What Really Happened When He Was a POW? – CounterPunch 6/13/08
EXCERPTS: “on March 25
column3: two of his fellow POWs
column4: Ted Guy and Gordon “Swede” Larson told the Phoenix New Times that
column5: while they could not guarantee that McCain was not physically harmed
column6: they doubted it. As Larson said
column7: “My only contention with the McCain deal is that while he was at The Plantation
column8: to the best of my knowledge and Ted’s knowledge
column9: he was not physically abused in any way. No one was in that camp. It was the camp that people were released from.”Guy and Larson’s claims are given credence by McCain’s vehement opposition to releasing the government’s debriefings of Vietnam War POWs. McCain gave Michael Isikoff a peek at his debriefs
column10: and Isikoff declared there was “nothing incriminating” in them

column1: McCain had a unique POW experience. Initially
column2: he was taken to the infamous Hanoi Hilton prison camp
column3: where he was interrogated. By McCain’s own account
column5: he cracked. He promised his Vietnamese captors
column6: “I’ll give you military information if you will take me to the hospital.”His Vietnamese capturers soon realized their POW
column8: came from a well-bred line of American military elites. McCain’s father
column12: were both full Admirals. A destroyer
column14: is named after both of them. While his son was held captive in Hanoi
column17: was the Commander-in-Chief of U.S. Pacific Command; Admiral McCain was in charge of all US forces in the Pacific including those fighting in Vietnam. ..The Admiral’s bad boy was used to special treatment and his captors knew that. They were working him.For his part
column18: McCain acknowledges that the Vietnamese rushed him to a hospital
column19: but denies he was given any “special medical treatment.” However….two weeks into his stay at the Vietnamese hospital
column20: the Hanoi press began quoting him. It was not “name rank and serial number
column22: ” as specified by the military code of conduct. McCain divulged specific military information: he gave the name of the aircraft carrier on which he was based
column23: the number of US pilots that had been lost
column24: the number of aircraft in his flight formation
column25: as well as information about the location of rescue ships…

column1: On the other hand
column2: according to one source
column3: McCain’s collaboration may have had very real consequences. Retired Army Colonel Earl Hopper
column4: a veteran of World War II
column6: contends that the information that McCain divulged classified information North Vietnam used to hone their air defense system…McCain told his North Vietnamese captors
column8: the most important of which was the package routes
column9: which were routes used to bomb North Vietnam. He gave in detail the altitude they were flying
column11: if they made a turn… he gave them what primary targets the United States was interested in.” Hopper contends that the information McCain provided allowed the North Vietnamese to adjust their air-defenses. As result
column13: the US lost sixty percent more aircraft and in 1968
column14: “called off the bombing of North Vietnam
column15: because of the information McCain had given to them.”

column1: ‘When John McCain was my captive‘: interview with former head of Vietnamese prison ‘Hanoi Hilton’ – BBC 6/23/08

EXCERPT: “But I can confirm to you that we never tortured him. We never tortured any prisoners.” Mr Duyet reminisces instead about how he often summoned the future US presidential candidate to his private office for informal chats….So is Mr Duyet implying that that Senator McCain lied about his treatment at the Hanoi Hilton? “He did not tell the truth
column2: ” he says. “But I can somehow sympathise with him. He lies to American voters in order to get their support for his presidential election.”

column1: EXCERPT: from 1992 Senate Select Committee on POW/MIA’s:
“When two U.S. Army enlisted men were captured by the Viet Cong in 1963
column2: they were plunged into an ordeal that would prove to be a relentless trial of body and spirit by torture. Once they were finally freed
column3: however
column4: their trials began all over again
column5: when their statements critical of the U. S. Vietnam policy landed them in a military court facing a capital offense for violating the military Code of Conduct by “aiding the enemy.”

column1: But
column2: if your name is John McCain and your father and grandfather were famous admirals
column3: violating the Code of Conduct by “aiding the enemy” translates into fodder for a political career
column5: and adulation bordering on sainthood. Even though news reports of McCain collaborating with the enemy continued from the time he was captured in 1967 through 1970
column6: the Navy never considered prosecution as an option.

column1: Instead
column2: Pentagon pencil pushers chose a political spin that lifted McCain
column3: the former POW turned U.S. Senator
column4: up to a glorified pedestal where he sprouted a halo and wings and became America’s “POW-hero” and today a presidential candidate.

column1: No such luck for the two lowly “grunts.”
SANTOLI: But on the Senate side
column2: we had one person standing in the way of getting in positions that would have been very tough on government bureaucrats who didn’t tell the truth. And that one person was Sen. John McCain.

column1: Cpl. BOB DUMAS
column2: U.S. Army (Ret.): He didn’t want nobody to check his background because a lot of the POWs that was in the camps said he was a collaborator of the enemy. He gave the enemy the information they wanted.

column1: Dr. JAMES LUCIER
column2: former U.S. Senate Chief of Staff: But We do know that when he was there [in the Vietnamese prison]
column3: he cooperated with the communist news services in giving interviews there
column5: not flattering to the United States.

column1: USRY: Information shows that he made over 32 tapes of propaganda for the Vietnamese government. Certainly
column2: you do what you need to do to stay alive. Nobody would fault anybody for that. But there comes a point in time when enough is enough.

column1: REP: DORNAN: They made those transcriptions
column2: and in the transcriptions
column3: I heard a POW who heard them comin’ into his cell and said
column6: is that Admiral McCain’s son? Is that the admiral’s son? Is that Johnny — telling us that our principal targets are schools
column10: churches?” That was Jane Fonda’s line. Where are those transcriptions? Believe me — they’re in the archives of the museum
column11: the bragging military phony museum in Hanoi. McCain could not have wanted those [to] turn up in the middle of a presidential race. He knows that. I know that
column12: and a few other people know that
column13: and that’s why he went against Bob Dole’s legislation.

column1: DUMAS: And he didn’t want nobody looking into his background in that camp
column2: what went on in that camp. That stuff is still classified so nobody can see it. And he just had it classified forever
column3: so nobody’ll ever look at it.

column1: LUCIER: That he was given special treatment and was put in a room with two other defectors who were later given special treatment. Although I will say to his credit he refused to be repatriated as a result.

REP: DORNAN: This sounds so good at first. McCain was offered the chance to come home. They called him the “Prince.” And he could have. But nobody ever takes that one step beyond that. If John … Admiral John McCain II … “Junior” … if his son
column2: a lieutenant senior grade
column3: had accepted this princely status and come home in 1967 while the others would sit there for five years
column4: what would the Navy have done
column5: with the son of an admiral who opted to get special treatment and come home? No Navy career. No House seat. No Senate seat. It would have been the end of his career. [Edit.] And they were offering him this chance to go home in one of three groups that came home in ‘68.

column1: SANTOLI: They were all collaborators.
REP. DORNAN: And McCain called them this — except for Bill Kagill [phonetic] — the “slipperies
column2: ” the “slimies” and the “sleazies.” I once forgot one of those names — and he refreshed my memory. The slipperies
column3: the slimies and the sleazies. So that meant that he would have become a slimy
column5: ruining his career and the admiral’s son goes home. What I’m saying is
column6: yes — he chose to stay. But did he have an alternative if he ever wanted to have a life? And what would it have done to his father?

column1: DOUGLASS: And his activities were sufficiently consistent and widespread in opposing efforts to learn the truth that he was written up in a number of articles as a Manchurian candidate in this issue.
REP. DORNAN: In Hanoi
column2: he saw McCain turn red in the face. He even used the term “Rumblestiltskin” [sic]
column3: jumping up and down in place in a rage: “If you release any of these records that you have here in Hanoi on me or the other POWs
column4: you will NEVER get diplomatic recognition.”

column1: USRY: McCain may have been an expert on being a prisoner of war but he was by no means an expert on the POW issue.”

column1: KD. Katie. Zombie.
A common street name for a variety of drugs
column2: KD has taken on a frightening form on the city's east side.

column1: Users writhing on the ground
column2: wide-eyed and struggling to breathe. Standing but moving in slow motion. Sweating. Convulsing.

column1: Indianapolis firefighter Scott Lebherz told IndyStar this variation of KD can take many forms — marijuana
column2: spice
column3: tobacco
column4: even banana leaves — but shares a common trait: all laced with a heavy-duty household bug spray.

column1: It’s cheap — you can buy a bag for about $20
column2: Lebherz said — and it can give users a 45-minute
column3: zombie-like high that leaves them nearly catatonic.

column1: “You look at what it does to a bug
column2: ” he said
column3: “and then you got to think what it’s doing to your brain
column4: and your body and everything else.”

column1: The practice of mixing drugs with other chemicals is not new to Indianapolis. Worrisome still is the problem it presents for medics and other rescue personnel who are faced with giving critical aid to people who have smoked or otherwise ingested some uncertain substance.
The uncertain substance continually changes.
Firefighters can’t be surprised: But I was shocked by people smoking roach spray.
More than a game: How IHSAA basketball tournament run lifts entire small Indiana town
In January personnel from Indianapolis Emergency Medical Services
column2: the Indianapolis Fire Department and the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department responded to dozens of overdoses in or around Downtown’s Wheeler Mission. At least 17 guests were believed to have overdosed on ""Katie"" — another mix of spice and an unknown chemical or drug.

column1: Most of the men were able to bounce back
column2: but at least one was taken to the hospital and placed on a ventilator that week
column3: according to mission leadership.

column1: Indianapolis police said a subsequent investigation led them to several drug houses connected to the distribution of spice mixed with an unknown chemical. Officers made six arrests in connection with the overdoses and confiscated nearly 10 pounds of synthetic marijuana and five handguns.
You’re looking at people who will mix (a chemical) with a drug as a way to try to make more profit
column2: said Daniel Rusyniak
column3: medical director of the Indiana Poison Center. ""Cutting your drug with ingredients has been a longtime thing that drug dealers have done to increase profits.""

column1: Last year
column2: a Tennessee man admitted to smoking a mix of methamphetamine and bug spray called ""wasp"" before ransacking a family's home and trying to cut himself at the family's dinner table in front of a woman and four children
column3: NBC26 reported.

column1: In Monroe County
column2: Mississippi
column3: authorities last year observed a trend of residents crystallizing wasp spray and injecting it intravenously

column1: “Oftentimes
column2: when they mix a substance
column3: they're just trying to enhance the predicted high
column5: medical director for IFD and IEMS.

column1: O'Donnell said these ever-changing combinations present an ongoing challenge for first responders and medical professionals.
A person’s reaction to a mixed drug like KD depends on the concentration of the chemical
column2: the ingredients used to produce the base substance and their own physiological response to that substance
column3: he said
column4: making it especially difficult for responders to know exactly what they are treating.

column1: Someone can go from extremely combative to suddenly unconscious
column2: not breathing and potentially in cardiac arrest
column3: O’Donnell said. ""... We try to stay on top of it as much as we can through education and training and situational awareness about just what drugs are in the city
column4: but as soon as we kind of catch up to one
column5: they seem to introduce a new substance out there.""

column1: The active ingredients in household bug sprays
column2: pyrethroids
column3: are generally considered to be safe in small exposures
column4: Rusyniak said. Exposure to high concentrations could induce respiratory distress and neuroexcitations
column7: and the risk of falling into a coma.

column1: It’s why we use it on bugs
column2: he said
column3: ""because it overstimulates the bug
column4: they have the equivalent of seizures and die.""

column1: Despite likely knowing the dangers of ingesting bug spray

column1: If someone sprays a legal substance on something that is harmful to their health

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/tick-causes-meat-allergy/	the bite of a rare breed of tick most commonly called the lone star tick can cause itching
column2: stomach cramps
column3: breathing difficulties
column4: and an allergic reaction to red meat.	true	['lone star tick'

column1: Many people
column2: even health care providers
column3: can be confused about whether the lone star tick causes Lyme disease. It does not. Patients bitten by lone star ticks will occasionally develop a circular rash similar to the rash of early Lyme disease. The cause of this rash has not been determined; however
column4: studies have shown that the rash is not caused by Borrelia burgdorferi
column5: the bacterium that causes Lyme disease.

column1: This condition has been named southern tick-associated rash illness (STARI). The rash may sometimes be accompanied by fatigue
column2: headache
column3: fever
column4: and muscle pains. In the cases of STARI studied to date
column5: the rash and accompanying symptoms have resolved following treatment with an oral antibiotic (doxycycline)
column6: but it is unknown whether this medication speeds recovery. STARI has not been linked to arthritis
column8: or chronic symptoms. Researchers once hypothesized that STARI was caused by the spirochete
column10: however further research did not support this ideaExternal . The cause of STARI remains unknown.

column1: Lone star ticks have not been shown to transmit Borrelia burgdorferi
column2: the cause of Lyme disease. In fact
column3: their saliva has been shown to kill Borrelia (Ledin et al.

column1: The lone star tick
column2: Amblyomma americanum
column3: is found throughout the eastern
column4: southeastern and south-central states. The distribution
column5: range and abundance of the lone star tick have increased over the past 20-30 years
column6: and lone star ticks have been recorded in large numbers as far north as Maine and as far west as central Texas and Oklahoma. All three life stages (larva
column8: adult) of the lone star tick will feed on humans
column9: and may be quite aggressive. Lone star ticks will also feed readily on other animals
column11: and may be brought into the home on pets. The saliva from lone star ticks can be irritating; redness and discomfort at a bite site does not necessarily indicate an infection.

column1: People should monitor their health closely after any tick bite
column2: and should consult their physician if they experience a rash
column3: fever
column6: or swollen lymph nodes within 30 days of a tick bite. These can be signs of a number of tickborne diseases.

column1: Tick-borne illness may be prevented by avoiding tick habitat (dense woods and brushy areas)
column2: using insect repellents containing DEET or permethrin
column3: wearing long pants and socks
column4: and performing tick checks and promptly removing ticks after outdoor activity. Additional prevention tips are available."	STARI or Lyme?		[]	['borrelia'

column1: According to reports:

column1: le. From an EV email ""As we navigate these challenging and uncertain times
column2: what we do know with confidence is that we will pull through this by pulling together. As the spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus) increases
column3: many LGBTQ people and allies are understandably concerned about how this virus may affect us and our communities. We can take comfort by remembering that our families and neighborhoods are stronger when we come together in moments of joy and celebration
column4: as well as in times of crisis. This is certainly true now more than ever as LGBTQ communities are among those who are particularly vulnerable to the negative health effects of this virus due to several factors: *The LGBTQ population uses tobacco at rates that are 50% higher than the general population. COVID-19 is a respiratory illness that has proven particularly harmful to smokers. *The LGBTQ population has higher rates of HIV and cancer
column5: which means a greater number of us may have compromised immune systems
column6: leaving us more vulnerable to COVID-19 infections. LGBTQ people continue to experience discrimination
column8: and lack of understanding from providers and staff in many health care settings
column10: many are reluctant to seek medical care except in situations that feel urgent – and perhaps not even then. * In addition
column11: there are more than 3 million LGBTQ elders living in the United States
column12: and they are already less likely to reach out to health and aging providers
column15: and other programs designed to ensure their health and wellness
column16: because they fear discrimination and harassment. The devastating impact of COVID-19 on elders makes this a huge issue for the LGBTQ community
column17: and a stark reminder that we are all better off when we are all healthy -- especially the most vulnerable among us. We believe that the antidote to fear is not despondency or self-isolation
column20: shared purpose and collective action. By standing together and ensuring that each and every LGBTQ Virginian has the resources and information they need
column21: we can and will prevail through this time. To that end
column22: we have created a COVID-19 Resource Hub that lists a range of online resources including information about healthcare
column25: and food access. While we have not worked with or vetted each organization
column28: we are excited to promote resources and inclusive spaces for LGBTQ+ people. We recommend that you do your own research before providing any organization with your personal information or resources."" https://www.equalityvirginia.org/…/co…/…"	Equality Stafford		[]	['health'

column12: 'https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/01/paul-nehlen/551312/']	https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/01/paul-nehlen/551312/	https://www.theatlantic.com/	"And he loves making odd generalizations about what Jews are like. “Poop
column14: and pedophilia. Why are those common themes repeated so often with Jews?” he tweeted. One of Nehlen’s 89
column15: 000 followers declared that “@pnehlen is one of the few American Christians courageous and honest enough to defend the Faith against Islamists and Talmudic Pharisees alike even when it’s unpopular. God bless you

column1: And that’s just what’s happened in the last few days. There’s a lot more. These examples
column2: which are representative of how Nehlen conducts himself online
column3: also represent the well-worn tropes of anti-Semitism: conspiracy theories about Jews controlling the media; using Christianity to target and direct suspicion toward Jews; rewriting history to put distance between Judaism and Christianity. His comments are so over-the-top
column5: that they almost seem like a joke—a not-particularly-creative parody of Jew-hating
column6: rather than shocking comments from a man who won more than 10

column1: All of this is worth noting not because Nehlen seems primed to win office; if anything
column2: whatever influence he once had seems to be slipping. When he ran for office in 2016
column3: he won endorsements from such conservative stars as Sarah Palin and Ann Coulter. He showed up at Roy Moore’s last rally in Alabama and was apparently favored by the former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon. Yet Breitbart News
column4: where Nehlen was formerly a contributor
column5: recently dumped him after he tweeted a string of anti-Semitic messages in December. By all appearances
column6: he remains a fringe figure with a diffuse online following that probably won’t boost his chances in Wisconsin.

column1: But Nehlen does represent two troubling
column2: pernicious political trends. The first is the appropriation of Christianity to justify white-supremacist views. Nehlen says he is not a white supremacist; he is just “pro-white.” Whatever meaningless semantic distinctions he wants to make
column3: the behavior is the same: He repeatedly uses his purported faith as a rallying cry against Jews—a group
column5: that is not white. I reached out to Nehlen for an interview about his views on Christianity. He did not respond.

column1: “Save your breath little man
column2: ” he tweeted at Ben Shapiro
column3: the editor in chief of the conservative outlet The Daily Wire
column4: who has been the target of extreme anti-Semitism online. “Christians have nothing to learn about Christ from Jews.” While it is not unusual for conservative politicians to tweet their support for Second Amendment rights
column5: it is unusual to “urge Christians to concealed carry
column7: when asked why he specifically called out Christians
column8: reply that “I’ll advocate for whomever I want
column9: and that will be my Christian brothers and sisters. If you want to advocate for Jews
column10: who’s stopping you?”"	Paul Nehlen Is an Anti-Semitic Clown	2018-01-24 11:14:55-05:00	['Emma Green']	['online'
