https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/flight-attendant-redeye-immigrant-children/	facebook posts by commercial flight attendants describe their experiences working on flights transporting unaccompanied immigrant children to detention facilities.	true	['american airlines'
column2: 'family separation'
column3: 'immigration'
column10: 'http://news.aa.com/news/news-details/2018/Statement-on-Recent-Reports-of-Separated-Families/default.aspx']	https://www.azcentral.com/story/travel/arizona/2018/06/19/flight-attendant-migrant-children-phoenix-miami-american-airlines/706803002/	https://www.azcentral.com/	"Did a flight attendant see 16 immigrant children on a flight from Phoenix to Miami?

column1: The flight attendant's story started to spread on Facebook over the weekend
column2: as the debate over immigrant children being separated from their parents at the border raged.

column1: On a red-eye flight from Arizona to Miami last week
column2: the story goes
column3: the flight attendant and crew of an unnamed airline were saddened to see a group of 16 children

column1: Sixteen. All dressed in black and gray cheap Walmart sweat suits
column2: quietly boarding the 12:30am flight
column3: '' according to two Facebook posts on Friday that claim the story was copied and pasted from a post by the unnamed flight attendant. ""Children! Thirty-two scared eyes looking straight forward dazed. We try to speak

column1: UPDATE: Airlines ask government not to use flights to separate families
During the beverage service
column2: one of the crew comes to me in tears. They can't face these children that have been ripped from their families with a smile.""

column1: The posts were shared widely and by Monday the flight attendant's story had gone viral.
A post by Twitter user @EmRazz
column2: who has nearly 45
column3: 000 Twitter followers and describes herself as ""your favorite friendly feminist
column5: 000 comments and was retweeted more than 28
column7: 000 times as of Tuesday at 3 p.m.

column1: One of the retweets came Monday from Ana Navarro
column2: a Republican strategist and CNN political commentator. She had just two words for the situation: ""Dear God.''

column1: Navarro's post about the flight attendant's story has also been retweeted more than 24
column2: 000 times as of Tuesday afternoon.

column1: The comments were predictably political
column2: underscoring the deeply divisive immigration issue
column3: in the spotlight with the Trump administration's zero-tolerance policy.

column1: But there was another
column2: major thread in the comments: Is the flight attendant story true or a hoax?

column1: Readers said some things about the story shared on Facebook and Twitter don't add up. One of the biggest: the flight times. The flight attendant reportedly said the flight departed at 12:30 a.m. and the children got off in Miami at 2:30 a.m.
A 12:30 a.m. flight from Arizona to Miami
column2: presumably from Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport
column3: can't land at 2:30 a.m. because it's already 3:30 a.m. Miami time when the flight takes off given the three-hour time difference. American Airlines
column5: has a non-stop red-eye flight from Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport that departs at 12:10 a.m. and gets in around 7:36 a.m. Miami time.

column1: Here's what we know and don't know
1. The incident did occur — at least according to the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA
column2: the union representing 50
column3: 000 flight attendants from 20 airlines including United
column5: Alaska and Frontier. Union spokeswoman Taylor Garland told The Arizona Republic the union has confirmed the original Facebook post was authentic and written by a flight attendant. She declined to say how the union confirmed that
column8: including whether the airline is represented by AFA-CWA.

column1: The union issued a statement saying flight attendants
column2: as aviation's ""first responders'' have extensive experience ushering migrant children to families or deportation but that the climate has changed.

column1: The difference today is the overwhelming American opposition to a new immigration policy that separates families
column2: '' president Sara Nelson said in the statement. ""This national discussion and response is being felt on the planes and discussed among crews. Some are struggling with the question of participating in a process that they feel deeply is immoral. Airlines are often a first point of contact for any public debate on these issues because all of society passes through our aircraft. Communication to crews from the airlines and the government is paramount as tensions are high and flight attendants continue to serve as aviation's first responders.""

column1: The Association of Professional Flight Attendants
column2: the flight attendants' union at American
column3: did not return calls seeking comment.

column1: RELATED: Immigrant children at detention center cry for parents in audio
2. American Airlines is the likely airline
column2: bad flight math and all. Nowhere in the viral flight attendant story does it say the red-eye flight from Arizona to Miami was a non-stop flight. American is the busiest carrier at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport and has a major hub here
column3: offering one-stop service several times a day in addition to the non-stop flights. The shared post also mentions computer outages
column4: cancellations and delays the day of the flight with the ""migrant'' children. On Thursday
column7: hub was a mess due to technology problems at its PSA subsidiary. American flight 1682 was due to leave Charlotte for Miami at 10:40 p.m. that night but was delayed until nearly 12:30 a.m. That's the departure time mentioned in the flight attendant's recounting of the incident. It arrived in Miami 1:52 a.m.
column9: also fitting the timetable in the viral post. The airline has a 2:50 p.m. flight from Phoenix to Charlotte that connects with the late-night Charlotte to Miami flight.

column1: American spokeswoman Shannon Gilson said American can't ""confirm the accuracy"" of the flight attendant's post.
We don't disclose passenger manifests
column2: '' she said.

column1: The airline issued this statement on Tuesday: ""We have been asked about transporting undocumented children and are aware of the narrative that is circulating online. American
column2: like all U.S. airlines
column3: provides travel to the federal government through our Government Services Agreements; however the government does not disclose information about the nature of the flights they take or the passengers who are traveling. We have no way to substantiate the report at this time but would be disappointed to learn that our airline was being used to separate families.''

column1: 3. The flight attendant who was shaken by the incident is staying out of the spotlight. No one who has shared the flight attendant's story on Facebook
column2: at least publicly
column3: identifies the flight attendant or links to the original post. It's always a co-worker or a friend of a friend. New York attorney Victoria Cook shared the story on Facebook
column4: saying her flight attendant friend Anika Lodzinski's co-worker posted about the incident following a red-eye flight from Arizona to Miami. Lodzinski
column6: said she has been a flight attendant for 18 years but declined to name the airline or her friend and referred other questions to the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA. Tom Johnson shared the flight attendant/migrant children story on Friday
column7: noting that it came from an American Airlines flight attendant
column8: who copied and pasted it from a co-worker who was working the flight. The flight attendant declined to comment.

column1: 4. Since we don't know the flight
column2: the attendants or the children
column3: it's impossible to verify the details. Were the children really ""ripped from their families""? Were they headed somewhere because of the current situation — adult parents held awaiting prosecution with their minor children shipped off to shelters elsewhere? Or were they perhaps unaccompanied minors
column4: many of whom have been handled by federal authorities for years now? How did the flight attendants know the children's situations if they couldn't communicate with them?

column1: Immigration and Customs Enforcement spokeswoman Lauren Mack said the agency does not comment on speculative information it cannot verify.
The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
column2: which runs the Office of Refugee Resettlement
column3: in charge of housing children who have crossed the border or been taken from their parents
column4: did not immediately respond to questions about the report.

column1: MORE: Detention crisis: Trump defends 'zero-tolerance' immigration
Stephanie Corcoran
column2: a Phoenix immigration lawyer and president of the Arizona chapter of the American Immigration Lawyer's Association
column3: said she and other immigration advocates were not surprised by the story.

column1: I actually shared it (on Facebook) because I thought it was probably true
column2: '' she said.

column1: She said the details about the children's matching outfits — she called it prison garb — make sense because sometimes their personal belongings are taken.
Corcoran
column2: who volunteered at an immigration advocacy center in Miami when she was in law school
column3: also said she has heard about a recent influx of migrant children in Miami.

column1: If they (the Office of Refugee Resettlement) don't have room here
column2: they're going to transfer them wherever they have space.''

column1: Ethnopharmacological relevance The convolvulacea Argyreia nervosa (Burm. f.) is well known as an important medical plant in the traditional Ayurvedic system of medicine and it is used in numerous diseases (e.g. nervousness
column2: bronchitis
column3: tuberculosis
column6: in the Indian state of Assam and in other regions Argyreia nervosa is part of the traditional tribal medicine (e.g. the Santali people
column8: and others). In the western hemisphere
column9: Argyreia nervosa has been brought in attention as so called “legal high”. In this context
column10: the seeds are used as source of the psychoactive ergotalkaloid lysergic acid amide (LSA)
column11: which is considered as the main active ingredient.

column1: Aim of the study As the chemical structure of LSA is very similar to that of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD)
column2: the seeds of Argyreia nervosa (Burm. f.) are often considered as natural substitute of LSD. In the present study
column3: LSA and LSD have been compared concerning their potential pharmacological profiles based on the receptor binding affinities since our recent human study with four volunteers on p.o. application of Argyreia nervosa seeds has led to some ambiguous effects.

column1: Material and methods In an initial step computer-aided in silico prediction models on receptor binding were employed to screen for serotonin
column2: norepinephrine
column3: dopamine
column5: and histamine receptor subtypes as potential targets for LSA. In addition
column6: this screening was extended to accompany ergotalkaloids of Argyreia nervosa (Burm. f.). In a verification step
column7: selected LSA screening results were confirmed by in vitro binding assays with some extensions to LSD.

column1: Results In the in silico model LSA exhibited the highest affinity with a pK i of about 8.0 at α 1A
column2: and α 1B . Clear affinity with pK i >7 was predicted for 5-HT 1A
column3: 5-HT 1B
column7: and D 2 . From these receptors the 5-HT 1D subtype exhibited the highest pK i with 7.98 in the prediction model. From the other ergotalkaloids
column8: agroclavine and festuclavine also seemed to be highly affine to the 5-HT 1D -receptor with pK i >8. In general
column9: the ergotalkaloids of Argyreia nervosa seem to prefer serotonin and dopamine receptors (pK i >7). However
column10: with exception of ergometrine/ergometrinine only for 5-HT 3A
column11: and histamine H 2 and H 4 no affinities were predicted. Compared to LSD
column12: LSA exhibited lower binding affinities in the in vitro binding assays for all tested receptor subtypes. However
column17: and α 2 could be demonstrated. For DA receptor subtypes and the α 1 -receptor the pK i ranged from 6.05 to 6.85." column12: 'http://countercurrentnews.info/2016/09/wic-program-started-black-panter-party/']	https://www.aaihs.org/the-black-panther-party/	https://www.aaihs.org/	"The Black Panther Party and the Free Breakfast for Children Program

column1: This is a guest post by Darryl Robertson
column2: an undergraduate student at Queens College
column3: majoring in History and Journalism. Robertson is a McNair Scholar who is passionate about hip-hop and African-American history. He is especially interested in understanding how the Black Panther Party serviced black communities during the late-1960s. Robertson’s most recent research examined how the Free Breakfast for Children’s Program sustained the Black Panther Party organization. Robertson is currently a music writer at VIBE Magazine and he’s also an intern at Ebony Magazine. You can follow Darryl on Twitter @darry_Robertson

column1: Usually when we think about the Black Panther Party (BPP)
column2: we envision the images that have long dominated public media—images of black men armed with guns
column3: dressed in black. Yet
column4: as Stanley Nelson’s recent documentary highlights
column5: the BPP was far more complex. Established in 1966 by Huey Newton and Bobby Seale
column6: the BPP was created in response to the rise of police violence in the Bay area. Originally called the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense
column7: the BPP set out to monitor police activities and protect black residents from police brutality. One of the fundamental aspects of the BPP was their commitment to serving black communities through a variety of social programs including ambulance services
column9: and the creation of schools. One of the most successful of these social programs was the Free Breakfast for Children Program
column10: which provided food for children all across the United States.

column1: The BPP’s Survival Programs were fundamental to the Party’s mission to improve black communities during the late 1960s. According to Newton
column2: “these programs satisfied the deep needs of the community.”[1] Significantly
column3: the BPP’s Survival Programs were deeply intertwined with the Party’s political goals. BPP members understood that in order to advance their political goals
column4: black men and women needed to be able to sustain themselves. As BPP member David Hilliard explained
column5: the “actions the BPP engaged in were purely strategic for political purposes designed to mobilize the community.”

column1: The first BPP Breakfast Program opened in January 1969 at Father Earl A. Neil’s St. Augustine Episcopal Church in Oakland
column2: California. On the first day of the Free for Children Breakfast Program
column3: Party members fed eleven children. By the end of that week
column4: the number rose to 135 children. According to BPP member Flores Forbes
column7: knocked on doors to let the people know which apartment the food was being served in.” Less than two months later
column8: the Party opened up another breakfast program at San Francisco’s Sacred Heart Church.

column1: In Los Angeles
column2: Forbes and others spoke to parents and business owners
column3: explaining how the Breakfast Program would help black children “grow and intellectually develop because children can’t learn on empty stomachs.” Forbes later recalled that the response was “overwhelming.” Breakfast Programs were springing up everywhere. During the height of the Party’s influence
column4: the Los Angeles Breakfast Program provided food for an estimated 1
column5: 200 children per week. In New Orleans
column6: the BPP’s Breakfast Program fed more than 300 children on a weekly basis.

column1: As the BPP became overwhelmingly successful
column2: it became mandatory for all chapters to have a Free Breakfast for Children Program.[2] The minimum requirement for the Free Breakfast Program was an available space with tables and chairs for at least fifty people. Panther leaders requested a minimum of ten persons working—two persons on traffic control; one person at the sign in table; one person taking coats and hats; four servers; and two cooks.[3] As a grassroots organization
column3: the BPP relied on the support of ordinary men and women to help fund the Breakfast Programs and the organization as a whole. To that end
column4: members of the Party organized a number of fundraising events in order to collect money
column6: and kitchen supplies from local churches and businesses.

column2: the Breakfast Program could be found in every city with a BPP chapter including Philadelphia
column3: Seattle
column4: and New York City. The success of these programs coincided with the federal government’s efforts to quell the Party and limit its influence on black communities across the country and the globe. Under the auspices of COINTELPRO
column5: a counterintelligence program run by FBI agents
column6: director Edgar J. Hoover and others devised a range of strategies aimed at destroying the BPP.

column1: Along with propaganda
column2: infiltration
column3: and various attempts to discredit the organization
column4: the FBI also targeted the BPP’s Free Breakfast for Children Program. Melvin Dickson
column5: a former member of the BPP
column6: has argued that the FBI disliked the BPP because the Party helped to shed light on the failure of the U.S. government to address issues of poverty. According to Dickson
column7: “[the U.S. government] have all this money
column9: a grassroots organization feeding kids all across the U.S.” During his tenure in the BPP
column10: Dickson ran the BPP’s Breakfast Program at the Atlantic Street Center in Seattle
column12: which opened in 1969. “We wanted to give [people] the organizational skills

column1: Despite the positive impact of the Free Breakfast for Children Program in black communities
column2: they could not outmatch the powers of the FBI. By the late 1980s
column3: the BPP
column5: had been obliterated. While the Party’s Free Breakfast for Children Program was short-lived
column6: it left a lasting impact. Indeed
column7: the Party’s influence can still be seen in public schools nationwide
column8: which now provide free breakfast and lunch for children in need. Moreover
column9: the Free Breakfast for Children Program underscores how the BPP sought to address the social and economic needs of black communities during the Civil Rights-Black Power era. This is a fundamental
column11: aspect of the Party’s history and legacy.

column6: 'https://www.fredericksburg.com/news/local/stafford/stafford-superintendent-apologizes-to-transgender-student-amid-national-outcry/article_8d0f967a-2092-57c0-9328-33a68a084c15.html']	http://www.fox5dc.com/news/local-news/transgender-student-left-out-of-locker-rooms-during-lockdown-drill-because-of-confusion-over-policy	http://www.fox5dc.com/	"A transgender middle school student was directed to stand out in the open during a lockdown drill while her peers were instructed to shelter in either the boys or girls locker rooms

column1: Lesley Woods
column2: co-facilitator for Equality Stafford
column3: relayed the events from the student's family. The group is not identifying the student or the school out of fear for the student's safety and the safety of the other students.

column1: Woods says on Sept. 28
column2: the school held a lockdown drill while the transgender female student was in gym class. The students were instructed to take shelter in the boys and girls locker rooms
column3: but the transgender student was told to sit in a hallway outside of the locker rooms because the staff did not know if it would be appropriate to allow her to go with the other girls into the locker room.

column1: According to Woods
column2: the incident led to anxiety for the girl and her family
column3: and is a clear sign that Stafford County Public Schools needs a clear policy when it comes to transgender students.

column1: This is nothing new for the family
column2: said Woods. ""They are a solid family and they are very much in support of their child
column3: and they are really solid advocates for the community. So I would say all in all
column4: the rest of us are shocked and appalled and motivated to come and speak and learn
column5: but this family - this is their life everyday

column1: Woods says there have been inconsistencies previously in how the school handled the transgender student's bathroom and facility use.
Stafford County Public Schools does not have a policy and has been dealing with transgender students on a case-by-case basis
column2: according to Woods.

column1: Advertisement
In a statement to FOX 5
column2: the school district wrote:

column1: Stafford County Public Schools does not comment on individual student incidents to avoid divulging confidential information. However
column2: the new superintendent has requested a review of all protocols and procedures including security to ensure that all children are treated with dignity and respect. We take such matters very seriously and they will be addressed. The welfare of all students is of the utmost importance for SCPS.""

column1: Stafford County Public Schools declined to answer FOX 5's questions about policies regarding transgender students or the specific incident.
The school board will meet Tuesday at 7 p.m. where Equality Stafford is expected to speak about the incident and the call for a clear policy for transgender students.
The group says it has received hundreds of comments on its Facebook post about the transgender student's recent experience. However
column2: some of the comments have turned ugly
column3: including several threats.

column1: Other school systems have policies that guide staff on caring for transgender students. D.C. Public Schools has a comprehensive policy which allows transgender students access to spaces that correspond with their gender identity. Fairfax County Public Schools has a similar draft policy
column2: but it has not gone into effect
column3: pending the outcome of several court cases and the Trump administration's move to rescind Obama-era guidance that allowed transgender students to use the bathrooms that match their gender identity.

column1: Equality Stafford says despite the September incident
column2: it has been working well with Stafford County Public Schools on LGBTQ-inclusive policies.

column1: The school is receptive
column2: the school board is receptive and what we're trying to do now is really highlight the need for a little bit more pressure and for a little bit more advocacy from the community to make sure that these changes happen more efficiently
column3: said Woods."	Transgender student left out of locker rooms during lockdown drill because of confusion over policy		['Evan Lambert'

column10: 'http://news.aa.com/news/news-details/2018/Statement-on-Recent-Reports-of-Separated-Families/default.aspx']	https://www.houstonchronicle.com/local/gray-matters/article/Flight-attendant-I-won-t-work-flights-that-13008372.php	https://www.houstonchronicle.com/	"For the past 29 years I have been a flight attendant for a major U.S. airline. Several weeks ago
column11: I worked two flights (one to San Antonio and the other to McAllen) which proved to be two of the most disturbing flights I've ever experienced in my career.

column1: On board these particular flights were ICE agents and migrant children (approximately four to eleven years old) who had been separated from their families and were being flown to a ""relocation"" site.
UPDATE: 2 airlines ask US not to put migrant children on flights
Since working the two flights
column2: the images of those helpless children have burned into my psyche. The little children whose faces were full of fear
column3: confusion
column4: sadness and exhaustion left me somewhat traumatized as it occurred to me a few weeks later that I might as well have been a collaborator in their transport.

column1: I can't help but think about their journey to their makeshift ""homes"" which
column2: historically speaking reminds one of another group of people who were forced out of their homes and relocated to ghettos.

column1: LATEST: Trump says he will put an end to family separations on border
As a result of what I witnessed
column2: I have made a decision that if I'm ever assigned to a flight with children who've been separated from their families
column3: I will immediately remove myself from the trip due to the nature of this unconscionable act by my government and my employer's complicity.

column1: I have told my story to many of my flight attendant colleagues and they have pledged to do the same.
Since sharing my story
column2: I learned from a fellow flight attendant that he was lied to by an ICE agent who said the children on the flight were part of a soccer team. When pressed
column3: the agent finally admitted that they were
column4: indeed children who were being relocated to assigned camps.

column1: This inhumane separation of migrant children from their families is against the morals and principles instilled in me
column2: as well as my religious and spiritual teachings.

column1: EXPLAINER: Must immigrant parents
column2: children be separated at the border?

column1: This is not the American citizen that I was raised to be nor the one that I will embrace. What we are experiencing is painful
column2: unnecessary and completely unacceptable and I feel somewhat ashamed that it took me this long to process these feelings. I keep kicking myself for not trusting my gut and walk off of both of those flights.

column1: I will no longer be complicit and will walk away from any future flight assignments that try to make me a pawn for this disgusting and deplorable cause.
Hunt Palmquist is a flight attendant based in Dallas. This is a lightly edited version of his Facebook post.
Sign up for the Gray Matters newsletter. It feels somewhat ashamed that it took it this long to process these feelings.

column1: STARI rashes take many forms.
The rash of STARI is a red
column2: expanding “bull’s-eye” lesion that develops around the site of a lone star tick bite. The rash usually appears within 7 days of tick bite and expands to a diameter of 8 centimeters (3 inches) or more. The rash should not be confused with much smaller areas of redness and discomfort that can occur commonly at the site of any tick bite. Patients may also experience fatigue
column3: headache
column5: and muscle pains. The saliva from lone star ticks can be irritating; redness and discomfort at a bite site does not necessarily indicate an infection.

column1: Diagnosis
STARI is diagnosed on the basis of symptoms
column2: geographic location
column3: and possibility of tick bite. Because the cause of STARI is unknown
column4: no diagnostic blood tests have been developed. Researchers once hypothesized that STARI was caused by the spirochete
column6: further research did not support this idea.External

column1: Treatment
It is not known whether antibiotic treatment is necessary or beneficial for patients with STARI. Nevertheless
column2: because STARI resembles early Lyme disease
column3: physicians will often treat patients with oral antibiotics."	Symptoms

column9: globally. Understanding internalised concentrations in the organism could further improve the risk assessment process. column10: UK. Quantitative method performance was acceptable for 67 compounds including pharmaceuticals

The internal concentrations of pesticides were used to estimate toxic pressure which showed that for the measured pesticides toxic pressure was low ranging from logTU ≤−7 to ≤−2. This methodology was extended to pharmaceuticals and drugs of abuse in a novel approach that proposed the use of pharmacological data (human therapeutic plasma concentrations) to estimate the likelihood of an effect (or effect pressure) to occur based on the internal exposure of the organism. The quantified effect pressure ranged from logEU ≤−9 to ≤1 with haloperidol showing the largest likelihood for an effect. The approach showed that several pharmaceuticals have the potential to elicit effects but further investigation surrounding thresholds for effects would be required. This new approach presented showed potential to be used to improve risk assessment for pharmaceuticals in the environment.	Biomonitoring of pesticides

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/tedx-pedophilia-sexual-orientation/	a tedx speaker gave a talk that referred to pedophilia as an 'unchangeable sexual orientation.'	true	['']	2018/07/26	Bethania Palma	['https://www.apa.org/about/policy/parenting.aspx'

column7: 'https://www.cnn.com/2017/08/21/politics/kfile-sam-clovis-lgbt-comments/index.html']	https://blog.ted.com/tedx-talk-under-review/	https://blog.ted.com/	"Click to email this to a friend (Opens in new window)

column1: An independently organized TEDx event recently posted
column2: and subsequently removed
column3: a talk from the TEDx YouTube channel that the event organizer titled: “Why our perception of pedophilia has to change.”

column1: After reviewing the talk
column2: we believe it cites research in ways that are open to serious misinterpretation. This led some viewers to interpret the talk as an argument in favor of an illegal and harmful practice. TED would like to make clear that it does not promote pedophilia.

column1: In the TEDx talk
column2: a speaker described pedophilia as a condition some people are born with
column3: and suggested that if we recognize it as such
column4: we can do more to prevent those people from acting on their instincts and harming children. This field of science is developing
column5: and the definition of the condition is just one of many points that are in debate across the global scientific community (and even in standard reference works).

column1: While there is much debate around this field
column2: scholars in the field are united in their wish to keep children from coming to harm — as the speaker makes clear in her own talk
column3: saying “Let me be very clear here. Abusing children is wrong without any doubt.”

column1: TEDx events are organized independently from the main annual TED conference
column2: with some 3
column3: 500 events held every year in more than 100 countries. Our nonprofit TED organization does not control TEDx events’ content.

column1: After contacting the local TEDx organizer to understand why the talk had been taken down
column2: we learned that the speaker herself requested it be removed from the internet because she had concerns about her own safety.

column1: Our policy is and always has been to remove speakers’ talks when they request we do so. That is why we support this TEDx organizer’s decision to respect this speaker’s wishes and keep the talk offline.
Original
column2: posted June 19
column3: 2018: An independently organized TEDx event recently posted
column5: a talk from the TEDx YouTube channel that the event organizer had titled: “Why our perception of pedophilia has to change.”

column1: We were not aware of this organizer’s actions
column2: but understand now that their decision to remove the talk was at the speaker’s request for her safety.

column1: In our review of the talk in question
column2: we at TED believe it cites research open for serious misinterpretation.

column1: TED does not support or advocate for pedophilia.
We are now reviewing the talk to determine how to move forward.
Until we can review this talk for potential harm to viewers
column2: we are taking down any illegal copies of the talk posted on the Internet."	TEDx talk under review	2018-06-19 22:19:35+00:00	['Ted Staff']	['event'

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/drink-young-blood-health/	a scientific study has concluded that âdrinking young peopleâs bloodâ provides health and longevity benefits.	false	['blood']	2018/09/11	Alex Kasprak	['https://www.newscientist.com/article/2133311-human-tests-suggest-young-blood-cuts-cancer-and-alzheimers-risk/'
column2: 'http://archive.is/r75yp'
column3: 'http://archive.is/NL0lD'
column7: 'https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-018-0457-8']	https://www.newscientist.com/article/2133311-human-tests-suggest-young-blood-cuts-cancer-and-alzheimers-risk/	https://www.newscientist.com/	"Rejuvenation in the bag? blickwinkel / Alamy Stock Photo

column1: Older people who received transfusions of young blood plasma have shown improvements in biomarkers related to cancer
column2: Alzheimer’s disease and heart disease
column3: New Scientist has learned.

column1: “I don’t want to say the word panacea
column2: but here’s something about teenagers
column3: ” Jesse Karmazin
column5: told New Scientist. “Whatever is in young blood is causing changes that appear to make the ageing process reverse.”

column1: Since August 2016
column2: Karmazin’s company has been transfusing people aged 35 and older with plasma – the liquid component of blood – taken from people aged between 16 and 25. So far
column3: 70 people have been treated
column4: all of whom paid Ambrosia to be included in the study.

column1: Advertisement

Karmazin spoke to New Scientist ahead of presenting some of the results from the study at the Recode conference in Los Angeles today. These results come from blood tests conducted before and a month after plasma treatment
column2: and imply young blood transfusions may reduce the risk of several major diseases associated with ageing.

column1: Blood biomarkers
None of the people in the study had cancer at the time of treatment
column2: however Karmazin’s team looked at the levels of certain proteins called carcinoembryonic antigens. These chemicals are found in the blood of healthy people at low concentrations
column3: but in larger amounts these antigens can be a sign of having cancer.

column1: The team detected that the levels of carcinoembryonic antigens fell by around 20 per cent in the blood of people who received the treatment. However
column2: there was no control group or placebo treatment in the study
column3: and it isn’t clear whether a 20 per cent reduction in these proteins is likely to affect someone’s chances of developing cancer.

column1: Karmazin says the team also saw a 10 per cent fall in blood cholesterol levels. “That was a surprise
column2: ” he says. This may help explain why a study by a different company last year found that heart health improved in old mice that were given blood from human teenagers.

column1: They also report a 20 per cent fall in the level of amyloids – a type of protein that forms sticky plaques in the brains of people with Alzheimer’s disease. One participant
column2: a 55-year-old man with early onset Alzheimer’s
column3: began to show improvements after one plasma treatment
column4: and his doctors decided he could be allowed to drive a car again. An older woman with more advanced Alzheimer’s is reportedly showing slow improvements
column5: but her results have not been as dramatic.

column1: Reversing ageing
Instead of halting the ageing process
column2: Karmazin says he thinks plasma transfusions actually reverse it. But if this is true
column3: the effects don’t last forever. “Some people have felt great since they had the treatment 9 months ago
column4: ” he says. “Others have felt the effects wore off after a few months.”

column1: Neither the intensity nor staying power of the treatment’s effects seemed to have any obvious relationship to the age of the people treated. “Whether you’re 40 or 80
column2: the effect is really similar
column3: ” says Karmazin. “Ageing is just wear and tear.”

column1: We all age at different rates
column2: but Karmazin thinks that
column3: on average
column4: people will benefit most from receiving the treatment around twice a year. “We haven’t treated enough people to say with certainty.”

column1: Many researchers are currently trying to chase down individual factors in the blood that may be responsible for any anti-ageing affects young blood may have. But Karmazin thinks the plasma’s rejuvenating properties come from the cumulative effects of many aspects of blood. “It’s not just one thing
column2: there’s a lot going on.”

column1: Placebo problems
The company’s trial has been criticised for having no placebo group. “There is no telling what may be down to the placebo effect
column2: ” says Arne Akbar at University College London.

column1: The placebo effect is known to be able to influence biochemistry in the body. Because the treatment cost the participants $8000 each
column2: it’s possible those involved would imagine any effects they felt to be bigger than they really were.

column1: David Gems
column2: also at University College London
column3: would like to see more tests. “It would be best to be tested at several time intervals before and after the treatment
column4: and ideally to have the tests done under similar conditions
column5: ” he says. “A single test before and after will be too anecdotal.”

column1: The Earth is not warming. The White Cliffs of Dover are tumbling into the sea and causing sea levels to rise. Global warming is helping grow the Antarctic ice sheet.
Those are some of the skeptical assertions echoed by Republicans on the House Science
column2: Space and Technology Committee yesterday. The lawmakers at times embraced research that questions mainstream climate science during a hearing on how technology can be used to address global warming.

column1: A leading climate scientist testifying before the panel spent much of the two hours correcting misstatements.

The purpose of the hearing was to focus on how technology could be deployed for climate change adaptation. But the hearing frequently turned to the basics of climate science. Many of the questions by Republicans and Democrats alike were directed to Philip Duffy
column2: president of the Woods Hole Research Center in Massachusetts and former senior adviser to the U.S. Global Change Research Program.

column1: Advertisement
Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) said he was bothered that established climate science has not been questioned more by the committee
column2: which has accused federal climate scientists of fraudulently manipulating climate data and subpoenaed their records.

column7: when basically we should all be open to different points of view.""

column1: Rep. Lamar Smith (R-Texas)
column2: chairman of the committee
column3: entered into the record an opinion piece published in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that claimed sea levels are not rising because of climate change
column4: a view that rejects thousands of scientific studies. The piece was written by Fred Singer

column3: Duffy pointed out that his chart was from a single tide gauge station
column5: and that sea levels rise at different rates around the world. Smith did not show rising atmospheric CO2 levels or temperatures
column6: both of which have climbed steadily in recent decades as emissions have increased.

column1: The rate of global sea-level rise has accelerated and is now four times faster than it was 100 years ago
column2: Duffy told Smith in response to the charts.

column1: It's accurate

column1: Rep. Mo Brooks (R-Ala.) questioned Duffy on the factors that contribute to sea-level rise
column2: pointing out that land subsidence plays a role
column3: as well as human activity.

column1: Brooks then said that erosion plays a significant role in sea-level rise

column1: Brooks added that Antarctic ice is growing. That was true a few years ago
column2: and scientists say it does not disprove the theory of global warming because different factors affect the Arctic and Antarctic rates of melting.

column1: We have satellite records clearly documenting a shrinkage of the Antarctic ice sheet and an acceleration of that shrinkage

column1: I'm sorry
column2: but I don't know where you're getting your information
column3: but the data I have seen suggests — "" Brooks said.

Well

column1: Earlier this year

column3: sea ice extent at both poles set a record low last year. Scientists are racing to better understand the changes occurring in Antarctica because much of its ice is land-based

column1: Lead author

column1: “As part of our ongoing work

column1: Professor Nic Bury from the University of Suffolk said: “Whether the presence of cocaine in aquatic animals is an issue for Suffolk
column2: or more widespread an occurrence in the UK and abroad
column3: awaits further research. Environmental health has attracted much attention from the public due to challenges associated with climate change and microplastic pollution. However
column4: the impact of ‘invisible’ chemical pollution (such as drugs) on wildlife health needs more focus in the UK as policy can often be informed by studies such as these.”

column3: 'http://www.levenseindekliniek.nl/blog/category/nieuws/'
column8: The Netherlands allows physician-assisted suicide in certain circumstances. But 17-year-old Noa Pothoven's tragic story of sexual assault and subsequent mental health problems did not come to an end with the state permitting a doctor to kill her—despite what many in English-language media have reported.

column1: Pothoven did indeed apply with a clinic for The Netherlands' legal euthanasia process
column2: but physicians reportedly denied her request
column3: saying she was too young
column4: her brain was not fully developed yet
column5: and she should try more trauma treatment first.

column1: Her recent death came after a long struggle with anorexia and depression
column2: in which the teen ultimately refused to consume food
column3: water
column4: or anything to keep her alive.

column1: News of this tragedy reached international audiences via a flurry of media reports that implied or outright said that the state had officially granted Pothoven's euthanasia application. But initial reports in Dutch media said no such thing
column2: as POLITICO Europe reporter Naomi O'Leary was the first to point out.

column1: Outlets such as The Daily Mail (London)
column2: The Daily Beast
column3: and EuroNews ""are all wrong
column4: tweeted O'Leary. On Wednesday morning ""It took me about 10 mins to check with the reporter who wrote the original Dutch story.""

column1: Infuriatingly
column2: it's too late: this misinformation has already spread all over the world from Australia to the United States to India. Her name
column3: #noapothoven is even trending in Italy. pic.twitter.com/CN22J7xdkK — Naomi O'Leary (@NaomiOhReally) June 5

column1: The Dutch reporter
column2: Paul Bolwerk of De Gelderlander
column3: wrote in a lengthy 2018 profile of Pothoven that she had previously requested legal euthanasia without her parents' knowledge but was turned down. Many on social media have been shaming the parents for allegedly ""allowing"" her to go through state-sanctioned assisted suicide; they did no such thing.

column1: Hurling insults at Pothoven's poor parents is only one strain of the strange moral panic and tribal vitriol that this story quickly spawned.
Conservative writer David Marcus suggested the story was emblematic of the divide between newly popular Catholic theocrats and more traditional conservatives like David French
column2: positing both that the very pro-life French and others like him would roll over for pro-teen euthanasia policies in America and that this will likely be on the liberal agenda soon.

column1: Not only is that all bizarre and unlikely
column2: it bears no relation to what actually happened in this extremely sad story that everyone wants to paint their culture war all over.

column1: As Bolwerk's original story noted
column2: and O'Leary summarized: ""The family had tried many kinds of psychiatric treatment and Noa Pothoven was repeatedly hospitalised; she made a series of attempts to kill herself in recent months. In desperation the family sought electro shocktherapy
column3: which was refused due to her young age.""

column1: Pothoven—who had been sexually assaulted as an 11- and 14-year-old and wrote a book about her struggles afterward—was set up with in-home care but
column2: at the beginning of this month
column3: began to refuse all food and fluids. After watching her struggle and trying so many different options for years (""we have tried everything
column5: her parents made what was surely a heart-wrenching decision not to keep her alive through force-feeding.

column1: Decisions like these have long been controversial
column2: and surely many will still disagree with (but can hopefully find compassion for) her parents and doctors in this situation. But as O'Leary pointed out
column3: ""a decision to move to palliative care and not to force feed at the request of the patient is not euthanasia. Dutch media did not report Noa Pothoven's death as a case of euthanasia. This idea only appeared in English language pickups of Dutch reporting.""

column1: Ultimately
column2: we have an anorexic and depressed survivor of sexual assault
column3: near legal adulthood
column4: who chose to stop struggling and her parents who
column6: chose to accept that. Whatever you think of that
column7: please stop politicizing this private tragedy.

column1: Over one million New Jersey Gun owners defy Governor Murphy's gun magazine ban & turn in demands of what some estimate is easily more than ten million now illegal standard capacity gun mags.
New Jersey –-(Ammoland.com)- New Jersey's standard capacity magazine ban is now in effect making New Jersey's one million gun owners criminals in the eyes of the state. But in an act of mass definace
column2: New Jersey residents refuse to comply.

column1: Any magazine holding more than ten rounds is now illegal in the Garden State. The standard magazine for an AR-15 holds 30 rounds. Glock 19s
column2: which is the most popular pistol in the United States
column3: holds 15 rounds. Anyone who is possession of larger magazine is committing a fourth-degree felony.

column1: Anyone caught with one of the now banned magazines in their possession faces up to 18 months in prison and up to $10
column2: 000 in fines or both for each magazine found.

column1: The bill was signed into law last June by Gov. Phil Murphy (D). Residents had until December 11th
column3: to turn over magazines to police or sell or store them out of state.

column1: Pro-gun groups sued New Jersey to try to prevent the law from going into effect. Their attempt on blocking the law failed in a federal appeals court. The three-judge panel ruled that a law limiting the number of rounds a magazine holds did not violate the US Constitution and did not put an undue burden on New Jersey gun owners.
“New Jersey’s law reasonably fits the State’s interest in public safety and does not unconstitutionally burden the Second Amendment’s right to self-defense in the home
column2: ” the court wrote in their decision. “The law also does not violate the Fifth Amendment’s Takings Clause because it does not require gun owners to surrender their magazines but instead allows them to retain modified magazines or register firearms that have magazines that cannot be modified.” AG Gurbir Grewal applauded the ruling on Twitter stating: “This just in: for months
column3: individuals have been challenging NJ’s limits on large capacity magazines—a sensible law to address mass shootings. Today
column4: the court of appeals upheld the law. Big win for public safety and law enforcement safety!”

column1: Residents of New Jersey on various message boards have called the magazine ban unenforceable. Some were going as far as laughing at Gov. Murphy and his attempt at regulating magazine size.

New Jersey is not saying how they plan to enforce the ban on standard capacity magazines. Gov. Murphy's office referred AmmoLand to the New Jersey Attorney General's office. The AG's office refused to comment.
Sharon Lauchaire
column2: Director of Communications for the Office the Attorney General told AmmoLand: “We do not discuss law enforcement strategies.”

column1: AmmoLand's sources within the New Jersey State Police that spoke on a condition of anonymity stated that they had not received any guidance on how to enforce the ban from the AG’s office. They said that there is currently no plan to investigate gun owners suspected of having the now banned magazines.
According to the source
column2: the plan that has been discussed among officers is only to file charges against people who are guilty of other crimes. This plan might change once superiors give guidance on how to enforce the ban.

column1: AmmoLand reached out to several local police departments in New Jersey to see how they plan on enforcing the ban and what the turn in numbers have been? Much like the New Jersey State Police
column2: none of these departments have a concrete plan on how to proactively enforce the ban and none had a single report of magazines turned over.

column1: From all Reports
column2: NO Mags Turned In
column3: Governor Murphy & His Law are Joke

column1: AmmoLand also asked the Governor's office what Gov. Murphy thinks of users on the internet saying that the ban is unenforceable and laughing at the Governor's attempt at regulating magazine sizes.
Gov. Murphy and his office refused to comment on these gun owner's opinions.
AmmoLand also asked Gov. Murphy's office about the number of magazines turned in by New Jersey residents. Once again AmmoLand was referred to the New Jersey Attorney General's office.
In this case
column2: Lauchaire would not offer a comment and referred AmmoLand to the New Jersey State Police. Lauchaire stated she was aware of AmmoLand's previous inquire to the State Police on the number of magazines turned in meaning that State Police contacted the AG’s office about our request for information.

column1: The New Jersey State Police have not officially responded to our request on the number of magazines that were turned over by citizens.
Two sources from within the State Police
column2: who spoke to AmmoLand on condition of anonymity
column3: told AmmoLand News that they both do not know of any magazines turned over to their agency and doubted that any were turned in. They also stated that the State Police also engaged the AG's office for guidance on how to respond to inquiries such as ours. They were unaware if the Attorney General has returned to their request for guidance.

column1: All the local police departments that AmmoLand contacted stated that they have not had any magazines turned into them.

AmmoLand has filed a Freedom of Information Act request with The New Jersey State Police to get an official count of the number of magazines turned in by New Jersey citizens. We will update the story if our FOIA request is fulfilled.

column8: 'https://theconversation.com/record-high-to-record-low-what-on-earth-is-happening-to-antarcticas-sea-ice-66114']	https://theconversation.com/record-high-to-record-low-what-on-earth-is-happening-to-antarcticas-sea-ice-66114	https://theconversation.com/	"2016 continues to be a momentous year for Australia’s climate
column9: on track to be the new hottest year on record.

column1: To our south
column2: Antarctica has also just broken a new climate record
column3: with record low winter sea ice. After a peak of 18.5 million square kilometres in late August
column4: sea ice began retreating about a month ahead of schedule and has been setting daily low records through most of September.

column1: It may not seem unusual in a warming world to hear that Antarctica’s sea ice – the ice that forms each winter as the surface layer of the ocean freezes – is reducing. But this year’s record low comes hot on the heels of record high sea ice just two years ago. Overall
column2: Antarctica’s sea ice has been growing
column3: not shrinking.

column1: So how should we interpret this apparent backflip? In our paper published today in Nature Climate Change we review the latest science on Antarctica’s climate
column2: and why it seems so confusing.

column1: NASA
column2: Author provided

column1: Antarctic surprises
First up
column2: Antarctic climate records are seriously short.

column1: The International Geophysical Year in 1957/58 marked the start of many sustained scientific efforts in Antarctica
column2: including regular weather readings at research bases. These bases are mostly found on the more accessible parts of Antarctica’s coast
column3: and so the network – while incredibly valuable – leaves vast areas of the continent and surrounding oceans without any data.

column1: In the end
column2: it took the arrival of satellite monitoring in the 1979 to deliver surface climate information covering all of Antarctica and the Southern Ocean. What scientists have observed since has been surprising.

column1: Overall
column2: Antarctica’s sea ice zone has expanded. This is most notable in the Ross Sea
column3: and has brought increasing challenges for ship-based access to Antarctica’s coastal research stations. Even with the record low in Antarctic sea ice this year
column4: the overall trend since 1979 is still towards sea ice expansion.

column1: The surface ocean around Antarctica has also mostly been cooling. This cooling masks a much more ominous change deeper down in the ocean
column2: particularly near the West Antarctic Ice Sheet and the Totten glacier in East Antarctica. In these regions
column3: worrying rates of subsurface ocean warming have been detected up against the base of ice sheets. There are real fears that subsurface melting could destabilise ice sheets
column4: accelerating future global sea level rise.

column1: In the atmosphere we see that some parts of the Antarctic Peninsula and West Antarctica are experiencing rapid warming
column2: despite average Antarctic temperatures not changing that much yet.

column1: In a rapidly warming world these Antarctic climate trends are – at face value – counterintuitive. They also go against many of our climate model simulations
column2: which
column3: for example
column4: predict that Antarctica’s sea ice should be in decline.

column1: Jan Lieser
column2: Author provided

column1: Winds of change
The problem we face in Antarctica is that the climate varies hugely from year to year
column2: as typified by the enormous swing in Antarctica sea ice over the past two years.

column1: This means 37 years of Antarctic surface measurements are simply not enough to detect the signal of human-caused climate change. Climate models tell us we may need to monitor Antarctica closely until 2100 before we can confidently identify the expected long-term decline of Antarctica’s sea ice.
In short
column2: Antarctica’s climate remains a puzzle
column3: and we are currently trying to see the picture with most of the pieces still missing.

column1: But one piece of the puzzle is clear. Across all lines of evidence a picture of dramatically changing Southern Ocean westerly winds has emerged. Rising greenhouse gases and ozone depletion are forcing the westerlies closer to Antarctica
column2: and robbing southern parts of Australia of vital winter rain.

column1: The changing westerlies may also help explain the seemingly unusual changes happening elsewhere in Antarctica.
The expansion of sea ice
column2: particularly in the Ross Sea
column3: may be due to the strengthened westerlies pushing colder Antarctic surface water northwards. And stronger westerlies may isolate Antarctica from the warmer subtropics
column4: inhibiting continent-scale warming. These plausible explanations remain difficult to prove with the records currently available to scientists.

column1: Australia’s unique climate position
The combination of Antarctica’s dynamic climate system
column2: its short observational records
column3: and its potential to cause costly heatwaves
column4: drought and sea-level rise in Australia
column5: mean that we can’t afford to stifle fundamental research in our own backyard.

column1: Our efforts to better understand
column2: measure and predict Antarctic climate were threatened this year by funding cuts to Australia’s iconic climate research facilities at the CSIRO. CSIRO has provided the backbone of Australia’s Southern Ocean measurements. As our new paper shows
column3: the job is far from done.

column1: A recent move to close Macquarie Island research station to year-round personnel would also have seriously impacted the continuity of weather observations in a region where our records are still far too short. Thankfully
column2: this decision has since been reversed.

column1: But it isn’t all bad news. In 2016
column2: the federal government announced new long-term funding in Antarctic logistics
column3: arresting the persistent decline in funding of Antarctic and Southern Ocean research.

column1: The nearly A$2 billion in new investment includes a new Australian icebreaking ship to replace the ageing Aurora Australis. This will bring a greater capacity for Southern Ocean research and the capability to push further into Antarctica’s sea ice zone.

Whatever the long-term trends in sea ice hold it is certain that the large year-to-year swings of Antarctica’s climate will continue to make this a challenging but critical environment for research."	Record high to record low: what on earth is happening to Antarctica’s sea ice?	2016-09-28 20:12:29+00:00	['Matthew England'
column2: 'Nerilie Abram'
column3: 'Tessa Vance']	['record'
column18: Antarctica has also just broken a new climate record
column19: with record low winter sea ice.

column1: But this year’s record low comes hot on the heels of record high sea ice just two years ago.
Overall
column2: Antarctica’s sea ice has been growing
column3: not shrinking.

column1: Even with the record low in Antarctic sea ice this year
column2: the overall trend since 1979 is still towards sea ice expansion.

column1: This will bring a greater capacity for Southern Ocean research and the capability to push further into Antarctica’s sea ice zone."

column2: 'http://web.archive.org/web/20030417021101/http://www.8march2003.com/thepublicitycampaign.html']	http://web.archive.org/web/20021119130350/http://www.8march2003.com/Originalpage.htm	http://web.archive.org/	"

column1: GLOBAL
PUBLIC ANNOUNCEMENT
www.8march2003.com
On this date an astounding discovery will be revealed to the world
O n March 8th 2003 something extraordinary will be posted on this site
S omething that could have Global implications
S omething that will make you want to rethink your future ...
My story:

Due to reasons you will come to understand as you read on I cannot reveal my identity at this time. Some months ago while trekking through a mountain range on an amateur photo shoot during my holidays
column2: my attention was taken by a glint of light from under a shrub. I discovered it was the suns reflection off a piece of broken glass.

column1: PHOTO
glass lens
By the curved polished surface on one side I thought it might have been from some type of magnifying lens. I rummaged around under the shrub wondering if someone had dropped their binoculars
column2: but instead
column3: to my surprise I found a badly damaged camera lens. I looked at the piece of glass in my hand. It was a fragment from the shattered lens. Beyond the shrub was a stony terrain that lead to the rock face of a sheer cliff towering high above the area. I spotted some other parts of the lens scattered between the rocks. Then I found the main body of the camera. It was an Olympus OM40 SLR
column4: which was in production during the early eighties. The entire camera was smashed and covered in a silvery soot-like powder
column5: as if it had been thrown onto a fire. Yet
column7: there was some oxidization on parts of the exposed metal casing. It had obviously been there for quite some time.

column1: PHOTO
scorched camera PHOTO
Back of camera
My first thought was that someone must have dropped the camera from the top of the cliff causing it to shatter on the rocks below
column2: and that there must have been a raging fire through the valley at some stage. Taking a closer look at my surroundings there were no signs of recent fires. Had someone tried to destroy the camera by burning it? When I sniffed the soot it had a pungent explosives-like smell to it. I turned it over and wiped the film cartridge display window. The hair on the back of my neck stood on end. There was still film in the camera.

column1: It was late evening by the time I arrived home some days later. I'd been having mysterious dreams about the camera every night since I found it. Overwhelmed with curiosity and excited anticipation
column2: I immediately took the camera to my darkroom. I had to pry the back open with a screwdriver as the plastic section of the outer casing had melted then solidified over the cover. Most of the film was badly damaged
column3: parts of it having disintegrated due to extreme heat. I developed the strips of film that were salvageable. Nearly all of the negatives were color distorted. The images on the film sent chills down my spine. When I finally developed the photos and blew them up
column4: I couldn't believe what I was seeing. It made me wonder what the hell was about to happen on the planet!

damaged negatives"	OriginalPage		[]	['negatives'

column1: An Act concerning the disclosure of federal income tax returns by candidates for President and Vice-President of the United States and amending P.L.1944
Be It Enacted by the Senate and General Assembly of the State of New Jersey:
1. Section 1 of P.L.1944
column2: c.16 (C.19:14-8.1) is amended to read as follows:

column1: 1. a. When Presidential Electors are to be elected
column2: their names shall not be printed upon the ballot
column3: either paper or voting machine
column5: the names of the candidates of their respective parties or political bodies for President and Vice-President of the United States shall be printed together in pairs under the title ""Presidential Electors for."" All ballots marked for the candidates for President and Vice-President of a party or political body
column6: shall be counted as votes for each candidate for Presidential Elector of such party or political body.

column1: b. (1) The names of candidates for President or Vice-President of the United States shall not be printed upon the ballot unless
column2: not later than 50 days before the general election
column3: each candidate files with the Division of Elections in the Department of State a copy of the candidate’s federal income tax returns
column4: as that term is defined in section 6103(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code (26 U.S.C. s.6103)
column5: for at least the five most recent taxable years for which the candidate has filed such a return with the Internal Revenue Service.

column1: (2) Each candidate for President or Vice-President of the United States shall provide written consent to the division
column2: in such form as the division shall prescribe
column3: for the public disclosure of the income tax returns. The division shall post income tax returns filed with the division pursuant to this subsection on the Internet website of the division no later than seven days after the candidate has filed the income tax returns with the division.

column1: (3) Prior to making public any income tax return filed pursuant to this subsection
column2: the division
column3: in consultation with the Attorney General
column4: shall redact any information that the division deems necessary.

column1: 2. R.S.19:36-1 is amended to read as follows:
19:36-1. a. The electors of president and vice president shall convene at the State House at Trenton
column2: or in another State building within the State House Complex at Trenton
column3: or the War Memorial at Trenton
column4: on the day appointed by congress for that purpose
column5: at the hour of three o'clock in the afternoon of that day
column6: and constitute an electoral college. In any year in which
column8: the ""Agreement Among the States to Elect the President by National Popular Vote"" is in effect in states cumulatively possessing a majority of the electoral votes
column9: and the State of New Jersey remains a member of that agreement
column10: the electors for president and vice president shall be those electors certified as the elector slate in accordance with section 1 of P.L.2007

column1: b. An elector shall not vote for a candidate for President or Vice-President of the United States
column2: unless the candidate had filed
column3: or caused to be filed
column4: the candidate’s federal income tax returns in accordance with the provisions of subsection b. of section 1 of P.L.1944

column1: 3. This act shall take effect immediately.
STATEMENT

This bill requires candidates for President and Vice-President of the United States to submit their federal income tax returns to the Division of Elections in the Department of State for at least the five most recent taxable years for which the candidate has filed such a return with the Internal Revenue Service. Under the bill
column2: each candidate would also submit written consent to the division for the public disclosure of the income tax returns. The bill requires a candidate for President or Vice-President of the United States to file the income tax returns and written consent for disclosure with the division no later than 50 days before the general election. The division would then post the income tax returns on its Internet website no later than seven days after the candidate has filed the income tax returns with the division. The bill requires the division
column3: in consultation with the Attorney General
column4: to redact any information contained in the income tax returns that the division deems necessary before the division posts the income tax returns on its website. Additionally
column5: the bill provides that an elector cannot vote for a candidate for President or Vice-President unless the candidate submits federal income tax returns to the division in accordance with the provisions of the bill."	S119		[]	['president'

column1: At 8:00 am on March 12
column2: the Los Angeles Fire Department responded to “a medical request” at the Los Angeles home of Anderson. She had apparently collapsed in a bathroom. Firefighters attended to Anderson on the scene before transporting her to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center
column3: where she was admitted with complications attributed to Hepatitis C. According to Chief Coroner Jonathan Lucas M.D.
column4: during the course of her treatment Anderson developed pneumonia and died at 10:04 this morning after going into cardiac arrest.

column1: Anderson
column2: a Canadian American actress and model
column3: is best known for her roles on the television series Home Improvement
column4: Baywatch and V.I.P. after rising to fame as Playmate of the Month for Playboy magazine in February 1990.

column1: Anderson appeared as the cover girl on Playboy magazine’s October 1989 issue. She moved to Los Angeles to further pursue a modeling career. Playboy subsequently chose her as Playmate of the Month in their February 1990 issue
column2: in which she appeared in the centerfold photo. Anderson has since appeared in Playboy several times in the 1990s and the 2000s.

column1: Anderson’s Playboy career spans 22 years
column2: and she has appeared on more Playboy covers than any other model.

column1: After Anderson moved to Los Angeles
column2: she won a minor role as Lisa
column3: the original “Tool Time girl”
column4: on the ABC comedy series Home Improvement. She left the show after two seasons and won the role of C. J. Parker on Baywatch
column5: whom she played for five seasons between 1992 and 1997 making her one of the longest-serving cast members. This has been one of her best-known roles to date and has gained her a lot of popularity from international viewers. She reprised her role in a reunion movie
column7: and also to star in commercials for DirecTV in 2007."	Pamela Anderson: Famous Playboy Model and Baywatch Star Dies Aged 50	2018-03-15 00:00:00	[]	['model'

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/the-love-machine/	vending machines in japan offer for sale panties purportedly worn by schoolgirls.	true.	['Kinky']		David Mikkelson	['http://web.archive.org/web/20040226204619/http://www.smn.co.jp/e/key/burusera.html']	http://web.archive.org/web/20040226204619/http://www.smn.co.jp/e/key/burusera.html	http://web.archive.org/	"Teenage Sex and Buru-sera Shops
Yoshiro Mizuguchi
column2: Editor in Chief of Monthly Women's Magazine ""Fujin Koron""

column1: There is a certain sort of used clothing shop that has been booming in recent years.
The shop is one room in an apartment. There are two display cases
column2: one on each side of the room
column3: facing each other. There are mountains of underwear in every color. You begin to notice the 'abnormality' of the place. This is not a department where beautiful lingerie is sold. These items are all stained and soiled. In other words
column4: they are used. Uniforms from famous middle and high school girls' schools are also on display. They are also dingy. This is place that sells items that should have been thrown away or sent to the cleaners.

column1: Shorts (bloomers) which are used in physical education classes (known as Buruma in Japan)
column2: school uniforms
column3: and sailor or middy clothes (known as sera) are in these stores. As a result these stores have come to be known as buru-sera shops.

column1: The sellers are just common middle school and high school girls. They stop by on their way home
column2: looking for a little pocket money. Some take out sundry items from their bags
column3: while others take off their underwear on the spot. The clerks then check the amount of soiling and price them accordingly. Among other considerations are smell
column4: and these items are ranked such as 'three day items
column6: ' etc... An appropriate amount of residue of menstrual blood or excrement brings particularly high prices.

column1: In the case of underwear 2000 yen ($20) is the general price. If there is a photo of the girl attached the price can more than double. The 'sailor' clothes are more expensive if they are from a school that is well known or from an 'uptown' girls school. There are some maniacs who will pay any price for a uniform from the Princess' home school.
The girls who come to sell are happy go lucky. ""We just want money. This is an easy way to get it and it's better than working part time.""
There is a never ending flow of white collar workers in their twenties and thirties and college students coming in to buy these unusual items.
The girls who come in to sell are not from poor families; on the contrary
column2: they are from established households. It must be said that the monetary values of these ""neo-yamatonadeshiko"" (daughters of Japan) are severely warped. They have never had to endure anything and the carefree atmosphere has removed the boundaries of common sense. ""Get money. Have fun. What's wrong with that?"" is how it goes. This is the kind of value that is common to present day Japan.

column1: The girls sell their bodies to get brand name items and have fun. ""Matter"" has overtaken ""Soul."" To state it plainly
column2: this is bartering between bodies (matter) and brand name items (matter). There are such markets all over the place. They can sell their bodies as well as their underwear.

column1: It goes without saying that the parents and adults who cannot say
column2: ""Cut out this foolishness!"" are equally guilty. No one wants to think that selling underwear leads directly to prostitution. But the middle school girls in prostitution say
column3: ""I'm not doing anything wrong. I'm keeping it a secret from my parents

column1: According to analysis by psychiatrists
column2: the men who steal or buy or wear women's underwear view the underwear as a substitute for female genitals. This points to a lack of erotic communication between the sexes. There is also a great problem in the sudden increase in adults who buy this underwear and the sexual services of young girls.

column1: Sexual perversion is related to the form of society. What must be pointed out is that there is something fundamentally wrong with this nation when 'buru-sera' shops flourish and 'neo-yamatondeshiko' are allowed to sell themselves without comment from their parents or older. It is a bartering session
column2: one without a soul.

column3: 'Wild Inaccuracies']	1996/02/27	David Mikkelson	['http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=wildlifenews.view_article&articles_id=56']	http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=wildlifenews.view_article&articles_id=56	http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/	"Alaska Fish & Wildlife News

column1: September 2003
Lemming Suicide Myth
Disney Film Faked Bogus Behavior
By Riley Woodford
Lemmings do not commit mass suicide. It's a myth
column2: but it's remarkable how many people believe it. Ask a few.

column1: It's a complete urban legend
column2: said state wildlife biologist Thomas McDonough. ""I think it blew out of proportion based on a Disney documentary in the '50s
column3: and that brought it to the mainstream.""

column1: Lemmings are a kind of short tailed vole
column2: a mouse-like rodent that favors tundra and open grasslands. Three kinds are found in Alaska
column3: including the collared lemming
column4: the only rodent that turns white in winter.

column1: In 1958 Walt Disney produced ""White Wilderness
column2: part of the studio's ""True Life Adventure"" series. ""White Wilderness"" featured a segment on lemmings
column3: detailing their strange compulsion to commit mass suicide.

column1: According to a 1983 investigation by Canadian Broadcasting Corporation producer Brian Vallee
column2: the lemming scenes were faked. The lemmings supposedly committing mass suicide by leaping into the ocean were actually thrown off a cliff by the Disney filmmakers. The epic ""lemming migration"" was staged using careful editing
column3: tight camera angles and a few dozen lemmings running on snow covered lazy-Susan style turntable.

column1: White Wilderness"" was filmed in Alberta
column2: Canada
column3: a landlocked province
column4: and not on location in lemmings' natural habitat. There are about 20 lemming species found in the circumpolar north - but evidently not in that area of Alberta. So the Disney people bought lemmings from Inuit children a couple provinces away in Manitoba and staged the whole sequence.

column1: In the lemming segment
column2: the little rodents assemble for a mass migration
column3: scamper across the tundra and ford a tiny stream as narrator Winston Hibbler explains that
column4: ""A kind of compulsion seizes each tiny rodent and
column5: carried along by an unreasoning hysteria
column6: each falls into step for a march that will take them to a strange destiny.""

column1: That destiny is to jump into the ocean. As they approach the ""sea
column2: (actually a river -more tight cropping) Hibbler continues
column3: ""They've become victims of an obsession -- a one-track thought: Move on! Move on!""

column1: The ""pack of lemmings"" reaches the final precipice. ""This is the last chance to turn back
column2: Hibbler states. ""Yet over they go
column3: casting themselves out bodily into space.""

column1: Life-loving lemming: lemmings do not commit mass suicide
column2: although in lean times they may become cannibalistic. These mouse-like rodents are found in Alaska and in northern countries around the world
column3: mostly favoring tundra and open grassland.

column1: Lemmings are seen flying into the water. The final shot shows the sea awash with dying lemmings.
Certainly
column2: some scenes in nature documentaries are staged. In Sir David Attenborough's recent documentary
column3: ""The Life of Birds
column4: the close-up footage of a flying duck
column5: filmed razor-sharp from the bird's wingtip
column6: was shot from a car using a mallard drake trained to fly alongside the car. But faking an entirely mythical event is something else.

column1: Disney had to have gotten that idea from somewhere
column2: said Thomas McDonough
column3: the state wildlife biologist. Disney likely confused dispersal with migration
column5: and embellished a kernel of truth.

column1: Lemming populations fluctuate enormously based on predators
column2: food
column3: climate and other factors. Under ideal conditions
column4: in a single year a population of voles can increase by a factor of ten. When they've exhausted the local food supply

column1: Lemmings can swim and will cross bodies of water in their quest for greener pastures. Sometimes they drown. Dispersal and accidental death is a far cry from the instinctive
column2: deliberate mass suicide depicted in ""White Wilderness
column3: but Hibbler explains that life is tough in the lemmings' ""weird world of frozen chaos."" The voice-over implies that lemmings take the plunge every seven to ten years to alleviate overpopulation.

column1: What people see is essentially mass dispersal
column2: said zoologist Gordon Jarrell
column3: an expert in small mammals with the University of Alaska Fairbanks. ""Sometimes it's pretty directional. The classic example is in the Scandinavian mountains
column4: where (lemmings) have been dramatically observed. They will come to a body of water and be temporarily stopped
column5: and eventually they'll build up along the shore so dense and they will swim across. If they get wet to the skin

column1: There's no question that at times they will build up to huge numbers
column2: Jarrell added. ""One description from Barrow does talk about them drowning and piling up on the shore.""

column1: Jarrell said when people learn that he works with lemmings
column2: the mass suicide issue often comes up.

column1: It's a frequent question
column2: he said ""'Do they really kill themselves?' No. The answer is unequivocal
column3: no they don't.""

column1: Receive a monthly notice about new issues and articles."	Lemming Suicide Myth
