column1: That's why candy maker Mars pledged $1 billion last September toward sustainability efforts aimed at saving chocolate

column3: with the corporation recruiting University of California researchers to develop a sturdier cacoa plant that won't wilt in drier climates.

column1: It all could come down to CRISPR
column2: a tool developed by UC Berkeley geneticist Jennifer Doudna that lets scientists tinker with DNA strands to potentially alter anything from produce to people. Already
column3: genome researcher Myeong-Je Cho is growing cacao seedlings at the university that may let cacao farms stay put even as environmental shifts occur

column1: The latest school shooting to horrify the United States has ignited the gun control debate once again
column2: and Nikolas Cruz’ social media posts are likely to add fuel to that discussion because they are filled with weaponry. column1: Update via AP: Federal authorities announced on Tuesday they have ended their investigation of the fatal police shooting of John Crawford III in a Walmart store
column2: concluding there wasn’t enough evidence to charge the white officer who killed him.​

column1: Original reporting
column2: Sept. 5
column3: 2014: The phone call plays back in John Crawford Jr.'s head ""every day

column1: The mother of his son's young children – boys
column2: five months and nearly 2 – was screaming.

column1: Crawford Jr. was in Fairfield on business that Tuesday and had stopped by to see if his son
column2: John Crawford III

column1: Mr. John. Mr. John. They shot him. They shot him
column2: Crawford recalls the cries from LeeCee Johnson.

column1: She put her cell phone on speaker.
You could hear in the background he was gasping
column2: John Crawford Jr. told The Enquirer in a phone interview this week from his home in Jackson
column3: Tenn. ""I'm virtually listening to my kid taking his last breath.""

column1: Crawford Jr. painted the dramatic scene Thursday as he talked to The Enquirer about his son's life and what he wants from the investigation into his son's fatal shooting by police at a Walmart in the Dayton suburb of Beavercreek on Aug. 5.
The shooting has drawn national attention in the wake of the death of 18-year-old Michael Brown
column2: who was gunned down by a Ferguson
column3: Mo.
column4: police officer and a series of shootings of black males by police elsewhere. The Crawford investigation has even become an issue in the November election as Ohio Attorney General's Mike DeWine's contender David Pepper has suggested DeWine's involvement in the Crawford investigation is unethical.

column1: The shooting came seven days after Crawford Jr. had celebrated his son's 22nd birthday together with a few rounds of pool at Memories Sports Bar in Fairfield
column2: where Crawford III had resided for three or four years following graduation from Greensburg Christian Academy in Indiana.

column1: Crawford III had lived in Cincinnati pretty much all of his life
column2: attending at least 11 private
column3: public or charter schools since entering the first grade in 1998
column4: Cincinnati Public School records show. Crawford Jr.
column5: who had never married his son's mother
column7: said he visited their only son nearly every weekend.

column1: On that day at Memories
column2: Crawford III
column3: frustrated by not being able to find a job
column4: had confided to his father that he wanted to start college. Crawford III
column5: who had played football in high school
column6: had shopped around for a football scholarship after high school
column7: his father said. When that didn't happen
column8: sons John IV and Jayden came along and plans for college were put on hold.

column1: 'He was figuring out his next step'
Crawford Jr. described his son as a typical 22-year-old who was laid back and very family oriented. He had once considered going into the military
column2: following in the footsteps of a grandfather who served in the Army.

column1: Hamilton County court records show that Crawford III had some minor scrapes with the law – two payout tickets for marijuana possession and a disorderly conduct charge.
He was charged with serious felonies in 2013 for allegedly carrying a concealed weapon and for aggravated robbery involving an incident at Clovernook Country Club. However
column2: a Hamilton County grand jury declined to indict Crawford III. His father said Crawford III was wrongly accused and was charged because he was in a car with his cousin
column3: but had no involvement in what happened.

column1: He was just figuring it out. He was figuring out his next step. I remember when I was 22
column2: said Crawford Jr.
column3: a college graduate who worked in the court system in Tennessee for two decades. ""Unfortunately
column4: all of that was cut down on the night of Aug. 5

column1: That's when authorities have said that Crawford III was walking around the Walmart store with a MK-177 BB/Pellet Rifle. He was pronounced dead at Miami Valley Hospital around 9:25 p.m. shortly after police officers opened fire at the store.

Crawford Jr. said his son was at the store with a female friend to pick up picnic items on the way to a cookout in Dayton. Crawford III walked around the store and away from the female friend after receiving a call from Johnson. She could not be reached for comment.
Crawford Jr. has disputed that his son was waving the air rifle around and had refused to comply with police commands to drop it. Police responded when customers called 911
column2: believing the gun was real. Police have said they repeatedly told Crawford III to put the gun down.

column1: What does security footage show?
Crawford Jr. said security footage of the shooting and the time leading up to it – which he and family lawyer
column2: Michael Wright
column3: have viewed – shows that his son was standing in an aisle of the pet department holding the air rifle with his left hand with the barrel pointing to the floor. Crawford III was talking on his cell phone to Johnson with his back to the officers when he was shot

column1: The footage we saw
column2: he didn't know the officers were in the store. There was no reaction (from him) at all by the time the trigger was pulled
column3: Crawford Jr. said.

column1: We were waiting to see him menacing
column2: waving this thing in a threatening position with women or children. None of that happened from the footage we saw. He wasn't doing anything. He was just standing there. The final analysis is that my son was murdered.""

column1: All this nonsense of (them saying) 'Put the weapon down' two or three times. There was no reaction from him. There couldn't have been a cadence given.""
Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine has refused to release the surveillance video to the public while the Ohio Bureau of Criminal Investigation (BCI)
column2: a branch of DeWine's office
column3: investigates the shooting to determine if Beavercreek Officers Sean Williams or Sgt. David Darkow broke the law.

column1: Wright said the coroner has told him that Crawford III was shot twice. The final autopsy report has not been completed. Crawford Jr. said the family has not been told which of the two officers shot his son. Williams remains off duty
column2: while Darkow has returned to work.

column1: The Greene County prosecutor has asked for a special prosecutor to avoid any appearance of a possible conflict of interest because DeWine – whose office would typically prosecute the case – used to be Green County prosecutor and his daughter now is an assistant prosecutor there.

Assistant Hamilton County Prosecutor Mark Piepmeier is now leading the prosecution team as special prosecutor. Wright has asked the U.S. Attorney's Office to take over the investigation and look into potential civil rights violation. He wants DeWine off the case altogether
column2: saying DeWine is too close to people at the center of the investigation. It's a demand DeWine has refused.

column1: DeWine's spokesman Dan Tierney said there's no conflict because DeWine is not directly involved in the investigation.
Beavercreek police officials asked for BCI to investigate the shooting because it was a conflict for them to fairly investigate their own officers
column2: Tierney said. Greene County Prosecutor Stephen Haller sought a special prosecutor from the attorney general's office
column3: but DeWine suggested Piepmeier because of his experience in prosecuting use of force cases.

column1: Taking the investigation away from BCI and handing it over to another agency would cause a delay because the new agency would have to start from scratch
column2: Tierney said.

column1: Our goal is to do a very thorough investigation but to make sure it is concluded in a compressed length of time to allow closure to the family
column2: he said.

column1: Crawford Jr. thinks that race played a factor in the shooting.
I think there would have been more tolerance. We are not inside the cop's head. But I would be not honest with you if I didn't (say) there was a little bit of racial undertone in this whole situation
column2: Crawford Jr. said.

column1: That's why Wright and the family are trying to get the U.S. Department of Justice involved in the investigation.
We do believe there was a violation of his civil rights and that does have to do with race
column2: Wright said."	John Crawford III was 'figuring out his next step'	2014-09-05 00:00:00	['Sheila Mclaughlin']	['crawford'
