https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/dennis-the-menace/	the portrayal of a black character in a dennis the menace cartoon prompted outbursts of violence and apologies from newspapers that published it.	true	['Important If True']		David Mikkelson	['http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Interviews/Schulz/interview_charles_schulz.htm']	http://www.michaelbarrier.com/Interviews/Schulz/interview_charles_schulz.htm	http://www.michaelbarrier.com/	"INTERVIEWS
Charles M. Schulz
An Interview by Michael Barrier
[Click here to listen to a roughly one-minute/1
column2: 000 KB audio excerpt from the Schulz interview (MP3 player required); be prepared for rough sound quality.]

column1: [My apologies to Jim Sasseville
column2: who ghosted the ""Peanuts"" comic books for Schulz
column3: for misspelling his name in the interview as originally posted. I spelled Sasseville's name phonetically
column6: and I somehow failed to correct that misspelling when I was editing and posting the interview. A full account of Sasseville's work with Schulz
column8: was published in The Comics Buyer's Guide No. 1473

column1: In the late eighties and early nineties
column2: I wrote features called ""Lessons of Leadership"" and ""Making It"" for Nation's Business
column3: the magazine where I was a senior editor. The ""LOLs"" were about the heads of relatively large companies
column4: the Making Its about the heads of relatively small ones. It was an enjoyable assignment
column6: one that involved lots of travel
column7: some of it to places I actually wanted to go (Los Angeles
column9: where I combined my work assignments with research for Hollywood Cartoons: American Animation in Its Golden Age). In choosing subjects for the features
column10: I slipped in animation- and comics-related people as often as possible. Bill Melendez
column15: who was then still in charge of his Portland
column17: Claymation studio. I also wrote a Making It on Denis Kitchen
column19: and an LOL on Chet Krause
column20: the publisher of Comics Buyer's Guide and other collector publications.

column1: The subject of my only other comics-related LOL was Charles M. Schulz
column2: whose ""Peanuts"" was by the late eighties generating licensing revenues
column3: especially overseas
column4: that made Schulz unquestionably a big businessmanalthough
column5: as he made clear to me
column6: ""businessman"" was not a title he would willingly accept. When I called his offices in Santa Rosa
column9: I was startled to be put through immediately to Schulz himself. Although Schulz worked in the same small building as Ron Nelson and Evelyn Ellison
column10: who oversaw the licensing of his characters
column11: the usual phalanx of assistants and PR people was missing. When my wife and I arrived for the interview
column14: it took place in the room where Schulz drew his comic strip
column15: with him seated at the drawing board. In the interview
column16: although Schulz professed no interest in business as such
column17: he showed the same concern for the integrity of his ""product"" that any good businessman might show.

column1: Schulz differed markedly in one respect from many of the people I interviewed
column2: though. The typical entrepreneur is absorbed in his work almost to the point of self-parody. As I sometimes said in those days
column3: I could have walked into most of my interviews wearing a grass skirt with a ring in my nose
column4: and the person I was interviewing would have grabbed my arm and said
column5: ""Let me tell you about my business."" Schulz
column7: actually seemed interested in what Phyllis and I did and thought (there's some evidence of that in the excerpts that follow
column8: and much more on the tape itself). I can't recall encountering a similar awareness of other people in anyone else I interviewed for an LOL
column10: who like Schulz is a celebrity who is and is not a business person. As genuinely nice as Schulz was
column12: he was also a very proud and competitive man
column13: and that comes through clearly in the interview.

column1: Schulz expressed skepticism about whether United Feature Syndicate would be able to successfully recycle old ""Peanuts"" strips after he retired. The last new ""Peanuts"" appeared early in 2000the last Sunday page appeared the day after Schulz's death on February 12 of that yearbut UFS is still distributing ""Classic Peanuts.""
The Schulz LOLbased not just on my interview with Schulz
column2: but also on interviews with his associates Nelson and Ellison and Robert Roy Metz
column3: head of United Media and its UFS subsidiaryturned out very well
column7: it was mangled at the last minute in the editorial process. Scheduled to fill three pages
column8: ""Working for 'Peanuts'"" was cut clumsily to make room for a half-page ad. I seem to have lost my copy of the article as I wrote it
column9: but the first pagewhich was not damaged significantly in the editingis on display in Snoopy's Gallery in Santa Rosa
column10: a block away from the new Charles M. Schulz Museum and Research Center that I write about in the Essays section of the site. For reasons best consigned to history
column11: Nation's Business in those days sent the subjects of its LOLs the first page of each article as a metal plaque
column12: and it is that plaque that is on display.

column1: Excerpts from my interview with Schulz follow. For many more Schulz interviews
column2: see Charles M. Schulz: Conversations (University Press of Mississippi)
column3: a collection edited by M. Thomas Inge.

column1: BARRIER: My focus here is not on dollar figures
column2: but on the way you have blended business and the creative side of your work. You've been able to balance the two over a long period of time
column3: in a way that a lot of people in the comics haven't been able to do. The more typical thing seems to be like Jim Davis and ""Garfield
column4: where you have essentially a corporate operation and a corporate comic strip.

column1: SCHULZ: How'd you find that out?
BARRIER: There was a TV special; I didn't see it
column2: but I understand they were quite explicit about the way the work is delegated. And
column3: of course
column4: you've had examples like Al Capp in the past. There were long stretches where Al Capp didn't do anything on the comic strip

column1: SCHULZ: I never knew how Al worked; I never got to know him that well. He kept it pretty quiet.
BARRIER: People like Frank Frazetta
column2: I know
column3: drew the strip for a long time ...

column1: SCHULZ: Probably drew all the girls.
BARRIER: I'm sure that's why he was hired. But from what I've heard about your work
column2: you've always done everything on your strip. That must make you an exception
column3: certainly among successful cartoonists.

column1: SCHULZ: I suppose 1 or 2 percent. I just spent the last few hours with Pat Brady
column2: who does ""Rose Is a Rose
column3: and he does everything himself. I don't know the working habits of hardly any of the others; I know Lynn Johnston
column4: who does all of her own thing. She's a wonderful lady
column5: lives up in Canada; we talk to each other on the phone quite often. I don't know about Cathy Guisewite. I'm sure [Garry] Trudeau doesn't draw his strip.

column1: [The conversation turned to Bill Watterson
column2: whose comic strip ""Calvin and Hobbes"" was very popular at the time
column3: and Schulz mentioned an Editor & Publisher item about Watterson's stipulation
column4: for his appearance at a ""Pogo"" celebration in Ohio
column5: that he would not be photographed or interviewed.]

column1: BARRIER: That's kind of sad.
SCHULZ: Well
column2: you know
column3: you have an obligation
column4: because this is not a pure art form. You have an obligation not only to the syndicate with which you work
column5: but you have a strong obligation
column7: to the poor salesman out there who's marketing your work
column8: going from newspaper to newspaper and setting up appointments with the hard-hearted editors and trying to sell your work. You have an obligation to a lot of people. If you're Picasso
column10: that's all right. But we're not Picasso or Andrew Wyeth.

column1: [To Phyllis Barrier] Do you read the comics
column2: too? There aren't very many worth reading.

column1: BARRIER: One focus of this article
column2: obviously
column3: is going to be the licensing operation
column4: because that's the real business side of your work. You were born in 1922

column1: SCHULZ: November 26.
BARRIER: So you would have been growing up in the early thirties
column2: when the first wave of Disney licensed merchandise was coming through
column3: and some other comic-strip licensing. You've mentioned in other interviews how much you were influenced by other comic strips
column4: like ""Krazy Kat"" and ""Wash Tubbs""; but were you attracted by the licensed merchandise that was available then?

column1: SCHULZ: I don't think we even paid any attention to it. I don't recall any licensing
column2: except Mickey Mouse watches
column3: which I never got. But I also recall that we always wanted some Buck Rogers things. Some of the other kids in the neighborhood and I loved Buck Rogers
column4: and we always wanted a rocket pistol. I don't recall if they ever put out official rocket pistols or not. Beyond that
column5: my only acquaintance with licensing would have been in comic magazines and Big Little Books. I used to buy every comic magazine that came out and every Big Little Book that came out
column6: until finally they both became so popular and I was just overwhelmed and I couldn't keep up with them all. That was all
column8: just before the war. Then I was trying to think of how to get started
column9: and I used to draw comic strips
column10: and couldn't really establish myself in any particular direction
column11: so I started drawing gag cartoons. I read all the magazines that published gag cartoons
column12: and I used to buy all the gag-cartoon books that were reprintsthe New Yorker and Saturday Evening Post reprint books
column13: and things like that. Books by George Price and all of those. I was concentrating on gag cartoons in those days. Then
column15: the war wiped me out for three years.

column1: When I came back
column2: that's when I got my job with Art Instruction. So I don't recall that much about licensing. I never even thought about it
column3: and I certainly never thought about it when I began the strip. That was the farthest thing from my mind. I think the first thing that I was interested in was to get a reprint book
column6: Walt Kelly came out with Pogo
column7: and I remember it had a writeup in Time magazine; I think it was just a dollar reprint in a small format. He had 80 papers
column9: and I thought that was astounding
column10: because at the time I only had 40 and didn't think I'd ever get more than 40. Then one day I got a letter from the editor at Rinehart
column11: and he had seen Schroeder play one of his first pieces
column14: because he'd never seen anybody use real music in a comic strip before. He began to read the strip
column15: and I suppose he was influenced by the Pogo book
column17: so he came out with our first dollar book. That was the first real licensed product. We had a regular series of them after that.

column1: So
column2: I never even thought about licensing; all I thought about was just trying to draw the strip as well as I could
column3: each day. I realized this is a business
column4: and I knew it was possible to make a lot of money at it
column5: but I just wanted to draw something that was really good and was different. We never sought out any of the licensing
column6: for years; everything that we ever did was the thought of someone else who came to us. Hungerford Plastics came to us with the idea to do that first set of dolls; I think there were six of them. Then he retired
column7: and I don't know what happened to Hungerford Plastics; they just disappeared. Each person that came to us had a particular idea. Connie Boucher got the idea to do the datebooks
column8: and that exploded; her company got bigger and bigger. Lee Mendelson was doing a series on Bay area personalities; he had done Willie Mays. He called me to see if I'd be interested
column11: I thought it was wonderful. So he did a documentary
column12: which never got on the air
column13: but it opened up the chance to do A Charlie Brown Christmas.

column1: Everything like that has always been somebody coming to me. Robert Short came to us with The Gospel According to Peanuts
column2: Clark Gesner came to us with the idea for the play
column3: the musical
column6: the Ford Motor Company came to us with the big project to do those ads. We got criticized quite a bit for that
column7: which is something that always puzzled me
column8: why they thought that that should have been the wrong thing to do. We've received a little bit of criticism for doing the insurance ads. A lot of people apparently don't believe in insurance and hate insurance companies. Maybe they're justified; I hated them a couple of years ago when they were destroying skating rinks

column1: BARRIER: Oh
column2: the liability insurance problem.

column1: SCHULZ: Yeah. I suppose licensing now has become enormous; I don't think United Features even had a licensing department when I was drawing the first 20 years. They had a business manager
column2: but that was it. I don't think he ever really went out and sought licensing; everything came to us. Now
column3: this doesn't mean that he took everything
column4: but the one thing that was different about mineand I'm not sure
column6: but none that I know ofI think I was the first cartoonist who insisted that he see everything that was done. I tried to watch over all the products and make sure that what we did was right. I tried to make all the drawings that would appear
column7: even though my contract didn't necessarily allow for that supervision. I've heard some cartoonists complain because their syndicate doesn't let them get involved. Well
column8: I think they should just demand that they [be allowed to] get involved. Fortunately
column9: I had good people to work with
column11: and they always let me see what they were discussing with other people
column12: and I had a chance to meet with all the different licensees. They never did anything behind my back. At least
column13: the first group of people. Later on
column15: another group of people came in
column16: and they began to do some things behind my back
column17: and that caused us a lot of trouble. Since then
column18: within the past seven or eight years
column19: I have a new contract. Again I'm dealing with reasonable people
column20: and I now have the legal right to have complete control over everything's that done.

column1: BARRIER: I was going to ask you about that
column2: because I knew that traditionally when a cartoonist signed up with a syndicate
column3: the syndicate owned the strip
column4: and I guess in the fifties
column6: they could have fired you and hired somebody else to draw ""Peanuts.""

column1: SCHULZ: They would have had to show
column2: however
column3: that I was not keeping up the quality. They would have had to show some justification for doing it
column4: but I think legally they could have done that. But not any more.

column1: BARRIER: Now around 1970 was when you had this fellow Warren Lockhart [working for Schulz as a business representative]; what has happened to him?
SCHULZ: I don't know. He got involved with a film projecthe was one of the producers
column2: and it won an Academy Award
column3: and he used that as a jumping-off point
column4: to go off on his own. I haven't seen Warren for a couple of years.

column1: BARRIER: How long was he with you?
SCHULZ: Boythe time goes by. He and Ron Nelson both had worked for Ice Follies
column2: and Ron was just telling me yesterday that he now has been with me for 18 years. I suppose Warren was with me maybe 10 years. I can't remember.

column1: BARRIER: According to a 1971 Newsweek article
column2: the Creative Development Corporation
column3: as I guess it was called originally [later Creative Associates]
column5: so that would have been 18 years ago. At that point
column7: how had things developed so that you werewell
column8: let me put it this way. I read a story from 1965
column9: and at that point you said that when people were calling you about licensing agreements
column10: you would refer them automatically to United Features. You had nobody working with you
column12: who could help you screen such licensing requests or handle them otherwise. You would refer them to UFS
column13: which would decide if it wanted to do them or not
column14: and then the licensees would get back to you as to exactly how the product would be handled. How had things developed by 1970 so that you felt the need to set up some other mechanism?

column1: SCHULZ: It all started with the ice arena. The small arena across town had been forced to close because of structural difficulties
column2: and my first wife
column3: Joyce
column4: came home one day and said
column7: ""That's terrible."" We had just started to skate there with our kids
column8: and I wished there were something we could do about it
column9: because we liked the two men who were running it
column11: ""I was hoping you'd say that."" She already had in her mind
column13: just in driving across the town
column14: and two years later she had built what has been regarded as the world's most beautiful ice arena. She tried running it herself for a while
column15: and then one dayI don't know how it happenedI think a couple of men came in and conned her into helping her promote the arena with shows. They got the Ice Follies to come in
column16: and the Ice Follies had Warren Lockhart and Ron Nelson running that division. It was a smaller version of the larger Ice Follies show. Warren had always liked Snoopy
column17: and said that if we had the Ice Follies here
column18: we should also sell Snoopy to the Ice Follies. He arranged that
column19: and so Joyce hired them both to help her run the arena; they were not hired to work for me.

column1: She kept saying
column2: ""These are bright young fellows. They can probably help you in your business
column3: too."" I used to think in the back of my mind
column7: somebody to help me run my business. As it turned out
column8: Ron really was an enormous help. He sort of took over all the financial affairs
column9: not only of the arena but our own financial affairs
column10: and then eventually did come in to work in here
column11: and we formed Creative Associates. I still don't know exactly why we did that; you'd have to ask Ron. I just don't pay any attention. He hands me pieces of paper
column13: and that's it. Then we built this studio
column14: and they've been working with me ever since. Ron now has become a real expert on all the ramifications of licensing and promotion. I trust him implicitly; he handles all of my business affairs. I rarely question him. He doesn't question my drawings
column15: and I don't question the business part of it. And that's really how it happened. I didn't hire them at all to help me run the business; I was perfectly satisfied with the way things were going.

column1: BARRIER: You were not swamped with too many distractions?
SCHULZ: No
column2: I'm never swamped by that kind of distraction. The only kind of distractions that bother me are the continual requests for special drawings for my grandfather who's retiring
column3: or the priest in our church who is retiring and who uses your cartoon
column5: or so-and-so is sick in hospital
column6: and auctionswe get auction requests every day. Some are fine
column7: and some are not; if they write ""Dear Celebrity
column9: we throw it away. I cannot understand anybody wanting a favor from somebody and not only not evenmost of the time not spelling your name right
column10: but not even using your name at all. But we try to do the best we can with all of these things. Those are the things that bother me the most.

column1: BARRIER: I can't imagine that would be that much of a drain on your time. Are there so many that you have a blanket policy of saying no to every one of them?
SCHULZ: No; it's not the time
column2: it's the anxiety and the guilt feelings that they give to you. Time is no problem with me. I actually don't even work very long hours. I start here at 9
column3: and usually I go home at 4 o'clock. That's not bad. Five days a week; I don't work at night
column4: or on the weekends. So it's not a matter of time
column5: it's just a matter of the energy
column7: plus the fact that it's not a job which depends strictly on the amount of hours you put in. It depends on what you can think of. The never-ending burden of having to do something day after day after day
column8: and it never lets up. Plus there are the television shows and the other little side items that have to be thought of
column9: and the requests for special drawings for program covers and different things like that. I was very flattered to be asked
column11: to do a cover for the AT&T golf tournament; it used to be the Crosby. I've been drawing golf cartoons for the Crosby tournament now for about 32 years. I enjoy that
column13: it's just another group of things that you have to think of. Always having to think of something funny. And the television shows: That's a monstrous medium
column14: to try to write those stories. Right now we're in the midst of doing a special film on cancer for people who are relating to children who might have cancer. It's a difficult thing to write. So something's always in the back of my mind; I wake up at 3 o'clock in the morning
column15: and I roll over in bed
column17: what am I gonna do in the third scene in the cancer film? Maybe I can think of something before I go back to sleep. Then I wake up in the morning
column18: and I haven't thought of anything. But that's the way it goes all the time.

column1: But I purposely don't get involved in the business affairs. I never see any of the business people who come here to see Ron on things like investments or things that he might be buying. I never see those people; I don't even know who they are. Somebody asked me today
column2: ""Who are these people that go into your studio that carry briefcases?"" and I say
column3: ""I don't know."" If they're carrying a briefcase
column4: that means they're trying to sell us something. And I would say that I attend maybe three quarters of the meetings with licensees. Sometimes I simply don't go in and get involved; I let the other people here do that. If I know it's something very important
column6: then I might do it. But again
column7: I stay mainly in my own room here and draw the comics.

column1: BARRIER: How much of the artwork for the licensed products do you do yourself?
SCHULZ: I don't but rarely make new drawings any more. We issued orders
column2: a long time ago
column3: that they use only pickup art from the strip. And then another man who does some special designing for us
column5: came up with the idea of creating a large booklet which has glossy reprints of all of the characters in a variety of poses
column6: and the licensees are supposed to pick whatever drawings from that
column7: and be inspired in some cases by those poses. In rare instances where it's something that I feel is very importantif it's a cover of a certain box or a book or something like that
column8: and they want a drawing which would be unique
column9: then I might make a special drawing
column10: but I rarely do that any more.

column1: BARRIER: Years agothis would be back in the early sixties
column2: maybefor Hallmark
column3: for example
column4: they had other people actually drawing the characters

column1: SCHULZ: No
column2: never. Hallmark has never had anybody draw [the characters].

column1: BARRIER: I worked with a fellow whose wife had worked for Hallmark in Kansas City
column2: and she was speaking of having done art for ""Peanuts"" cards; this would have been in 1965
column3: or something like that. I was startled
column4: because it had never occurred to me that you had not done all the artwork.

column1: SCHULZ: In fact
column2: I did the first drawings myself. A man named Arnold Shapiro was the one who came up with the idea and finally sold Hallmark on doing it. I drew all the first cards. Some of them were foldout cards that had as many as four to six drawings. I was also doing all of the Ford ads at that time. Some of them would have as many as six drawings; it would be a whole newspaper ad. I was working with the J. Walter Thompson people
column3: creating all of the ads. And I did the [drawings] for the billboards
column4: and helped them do the television commercials. And I was doing the special drawings for Connie Boucher's Happiness Is a Warm Puppy books; we did six of those. I illustrated two books for Art Linkletter
column5: on Kids Say the Darnedest Things. I did a couple of books on letters to President Johnson
column7: and I was also doing teen-age cartoons for a church publication. Finally
column10: this is too much."" I just couldn't stand it all. Now
column11: if anybody said they did some drawings for Hallmark
column12: what they did was to draw in some backgrounds and create the cards. I've always admired the way Hallmark created the cards
column13: but no one ever drew the characters themselves. Since then
column15: there have been a few poses that might require an extra arm of Snoopy holding something or doing something
column17: they rarely make any special drawings themselves
column18: but they do make some wonderfully decorative backgrounds and things of that kind.

column1: BARRIER: There was a series of comic books back in the late fifties; you couldn't have drawn all that.
SCHULZ: No. I had a very close friend named Jim Sasseville
column2: who now lives down in the San Jose area some place
column3: and he always wanted to draw comic strips and everything
column4: and when United Features came up with the idea of having a few comic pages in the Nancy books and all of that
column7: but I have this friend who can really draw."" Jim did those for quite a while
column8: and moved out here to California with his wife. Later on
column9: he quit and went on to something else
column10: and I had another man work with me for a while. It was just a good way to have somebody around who could help in the studio
column11: to do all the little things like answer the letters. In those days
column12: I had no secretary. This fellow who took Jim's place was named Tony; since then he has died
column13: but he used to answer the fan mail for me
column14: and do all the little extra thingsrun to the post officeand he drew all of the comic magazines. All of the money we got from the comic magazines went to pay Tony's salary
column15: so that worked out fine. He liked doing it. But then
column17: they didn't want us any more
column18: so we just stopped doing it.

column1: BARRIER: In other words
column2: the time pressures you've felt have never been from having to spend too much of your time being a businessman or a celebrity
column3: but just from having to draw too many things.

column1: SCHULZ: It probably wasn't so much a matter of choice as it was just plain ignorance or lack of ability. I don't know anything about business
column2: I really don't; it doesn't interest me. If I were to have to sell a product
column3: I wouldn't even know how much to charge for it. I don't know anything about it
column4: and I refuse to get involved in something I don't know anything about. That was the syndicate's job; I would draw the comic strip and they would market it
column5: they'd make the decisions. I always liked the people at United Features
column6: the business manager and the president. The president was named Larry Rutman
column7: [and] he treated me not unlike a father. We always got along well; we only had a couple of arguments in all those years. And now
column9: they're a good group of people. I trust their judgment
column12: probably puts a lot of pressure on them now
column14: I think. Ron has learned probably more about the business than they have.

column1: BARRIER: But you said that at one point
column2: I guess after Rutman had retired
column3: that there was a period there when you were not happy with United Features.

column1: SCHULZ: Oh
column2: terribly unhappy.

column1: BARRIER: When would this have been?
SCHULZ: I don't know; I can't remember dates.
BARRIER: Would this have been around the time that Ron
SCHULZ: Ron was working for me at the time.
BARRIER: Oh
column2: it was in the seventies.

column1: SCHULZ: Yeah. I think these new people mistrusted Warren
column2: and maybe with justification; I have no idea. But there was really some mistrust there. I remember once they signed a contract with Random House for me to do eight books
column3: and I said
column4: ""Where in the world did that come from? I can't write eight books. Who said I was going to write eight books?"" And they said
column6: that's what the contract says."" I said
column7: ""I can't write eight books."" They said
column11: we won't do it."" But why in the world some man would sign a contract for me to write eight books is beyond me. And then I remember they were selling Charlie Brown razor blades over in Germany. Whose idea was that? Charlie Brown shouldn't be selling razor blades. These were the things that were beginning to annoy me. I can't even remember the others.

column1: I also
column2: for a long period of time
column3: even back in Larry Rutman's day
column4: I remember talking with him down in his home in Monterey once
column7: I think I have done more for you than any cartoonist you've ever had. I think I deserve something extra."" ""What do you mean?"" ""I don't even know
column8: but I think I deserve a little something extra. How about a guaranteed income of a certain amount for the rest of my life?"" ""Oh
column10: we can't do that. But you get more than the others."" ""No
column13: that's what everybody else gets. If I get more
column14: it's because I work harder."" He couldn't understand that; and the next man didn't even come close to being able to understand that. I kept saying
column15: ""I want something more. I don't know what it is
column16: but I want something more."" They just couldn't understand it. It was interesting that when the third president came in
column18: he understood it within five minutes. All I wanted was to control my property. I wasn't out to destroy it. I think the other people were afraid that I was going to run away with it
column19: that if I got control of it I would go off and do all sorts of wild things. Well
column20: it was just the opposite: I was afraid that was what they were going to do. And so I now have a contract which means that I can do anything that I want
column21: as long as it does not destroy the property
column22: which I'd been insane to do
column23: anyway. I never asked for more money.

column1: BARRIER: The 50 percent split is still
SCHULZ: I'll bet anything that I could have threatened them and said
column2: ""From now on I want 70."" But why? That wasn't the object. The strip brings in plenty of money. That's not the object of the whole thing. There's plenty of money to go around for everybody. I just want to make sure that this product is not killed off and we can do everything properly. This doesn't mean I've always made the right decisions
column3: but I bet I've made more right decisions than they have.

column1: BARRIER: Have there been occasions when United Features has sent back a strip
column2: or said
column3: ""We're really worried about this one?""

column1: SCHULZ: Yeah. There were only two occasions. One was a long time ago; Linus's blanket suddenly took on a life [of its own] and began to attack Lucy. Larry Rutman called; this scared him to death. He thought for sure that it would frighten children
column2: that the blanket doing this would frighten the child reader. Which was ridiculous
column3: when you think of the things that they see in other places. I remember I finished up the little series and let it go at that. Later on
column4: when Franklin was introduced into the strip
column5: the little black kidI could have put him in long before that
column7: I didn't. I didn't want to intrude upon the work of others
column8: so I held off on that. But I finally put Franklin in
column9: and there was one strip where Charlie Brown and Franklin had been playing on the beach
column12: it's been nice being with you
column13: come on over to my house some time."" Again
column14: they didn't like that. Another editor protested once when Franklin was sitting in the same row of school desks with Peppermint Patty
column16: ""We have enough trouble here in the South without you showing the kids together in school."" But I never paid any attention to those things
column17: and I remember telling Larry at the time about Franklinhe wanted me to change it
column18: and we talked about it for a long while on the phone
column19: and I finally sighed and said
column22: let's put it this way: Either you print it just the way I draw it or I quit. How's that?"" So that's the way that ended. But I've never done much with Franklin
column23: because I don't do race things. I'm not an expert on race
column24: I don't know what it's like to grow up as a little black boy
column25: and I don't think you should draw things unless you really understand them
column26: unless you're just out to stir things up or to try to teach people different things. I'm not in this business to instruct; I'm just in it to be funny. Now and then I may instruct a few things
column27: but I'm not out to grind a lot of axes. Let somebody else do it who's an expert on that

column1: BARRIER: I've read a number of interviews where you say in effect that social issues are not what

SCHULZ: What are called ""social issues"" in some of these strips I think are so obvious and so obnoxious thatI think the social issues that I deal with are much more long-lasting and more important than losing the White House. Those are easy targets
column2: no matter which party is in the stew. People say
column3: ""Don't you ever deal in social issues?"" ""Well
column4: don't you read the strip?"" If you read the strip every day
column5: you'll see that I deal with more social issues in one month than some of these deal [with] in a whole year. But you have to be a little more sensitive to it.

column1: BARRIER: Watterson
column2: when he was still doing interviews
column3: had what I thought was a very interesting comment about you
column4: and I wanted to get your response to this. He said
column5: ""I have a tremendous amount of respect for 'Peanuts.' Every now and then I hear that 'Peanuts' isn't as funny as it was or it's gotten old or something like that. I think that what's really happened is that Schulz's 'Peanuts' changed the entire face of comic strips and everybody had now caught up to him. I don't think he's five years ahead of everybody else like he used to be
column6: so that's taken some of the edge off it. I think it's still a wonderful strip in terms of solid construction
column8: the fantasy element... Things that we now take for granted-reading the thoughts of an animal
column9: for examplethere's not a cartoonist who's done anything since 1960 that doesn't owe Schulz a tremendous debt."" I read another quotation from an interview with you
column10: in which you described yourself as a very competitive person
column11: and I wondered now that you've done the strip for almost 40 years
column12: and there are cartoonists who are obviously tremendously in your debt
column14: do you feel a certain satisfaction at seeing that kind of thing
column15: or do you feel a certain edginess
column16: like ""I want to get out there and knock these kids out of the park""?

column1: SCHULZ: Well
column2: in the first place
column3: I'm always stunned to discover that I am now one of the old-timers. Somebody said
column5: that makes you kind of the dean of the comic-strip artists."" I still think of myself as being one of the young ones. Garry Trudeau stopped by here over 10 years ago
column6: and he was doing an article for a magazine on the bright young cartoonists of the day
column7: and I noticed that I was not in there; and then all of a sudden it occurred to me
column8: I'm not one of the bright young cartoonists. It's flattering to think that these men were influenced by me
column10: I think that's fine. It's a little bit sad when I see some of the others that are imitating
column11: or at least think they're imitating
column14: philosophical remarks in the last panel which are neither sly nor philosophical
column15: but are just plain dumb. They don't have the touch to know how to do that. And I think if you don't have the touch
column16: you shouldn't do it. I see this so often.

column1: I'm very proud of what I think is the most difficult thing to do in a comic strip
column2: and that is to come up with the very broad theme on which the strip can be built. That I have created what has become part of the language
column3: the term ""security blanket
column7: he's a real Charlie Brown."" I was stunned last night-it's about 10:30 at night
column9: and I'm reading the biography of Shirley Jackson
column13: she is talking about one of Shirley Jackson's friends
column14: and she brings up Charlie Brown kicking the football. And I said to Jean
column15: ""Look at this. This is astounding."" Here she's writing a serious biography
column16: and yet she uses Charlie Brown to point up a certain point in this book. That makes me feel wonderful. Every now and then I'll be reading a detective novel or something like that
column17: and Snoopy will be mentioned. John MacDonald used to mention Snoopy in his detective novels
column18: the Travis McGee ones. But some of these other imitators
column19: who try to do this little philosophical thing ... It's kind of sad; they should just try to be themselves and not try to imitate others. Of course
column21: I could see in college papers and in submissions that young people would send to me hoping to get criticism
column22: they were all imitating ""Doonesbury."" That's crazy
column24: and you should just draw yourself.

column1: BARRIER: You said something else
column2: in another interview
column3: about ""Peanuts"" that took me aback a little bit. You talked about the strip having ""a bitter feeling"" to it
column4: and said it ""dealt in defeat."" I was thinking about that in connection with all the licensing of children's products in particular. There are certain ironies and paradoxes connected with ""Peanuts""; it's never been a children's strip
column5: and yet Snoopy has become a sort of icon
column7: divorced in a way from the strip itself.

column1: SCHULZ: Oddly enough
column2: I have fought against children's products all these years
column3: because I do not consider it a children's strip. I have always said
column4: ""If you have to do something for children
column6: but let's not forget that our main reading audience is out there among the college kids
column7: and in the fathers and mothers and grandmothers. Let's not forget all of those products; I just don't want a bunch of children's things out there. But they keep coming out anyway. I have not been able to close the floodgates. The children's products just keep coming. And I guess it's all right; it doesn't hurt anything. But that always has been a personal problem with me.

column1: BARRIER: Still
column2: I would think there would be a certain satisfaction in seeing a child carrying a Snoopy doll
column3: for example. It's kind of like seeing your audience ...

column1: SCHULZ: Oh
column2: yeah. If you go to a skating competition
column3: invariably there will be two or three girls involved in the skating who are carrying their little plush Snoopy around with them. I think one of the most satisfying things is to pull up at a school stop sign early in the morning and see some school kids crossing in front of you
column4: and one of them is carrying a Snoopy lunch box. There's something about that that's very satisfying. I mean
column5: they have to carry something and they might as well carry mine.

column1: BARRIER: What do you think people get out of having a product with a picture of Snoopy on it? What do you think makes them buy that sort of thing?
SCHULZ: I was driving along one day
column2: and came to a stop sign
column3: and there was a truck in front of me
column4: and glued to the window of that truck was a little cartoon character of Yosemite Sam. Now
column5: I defy you to tell me what Yosemite Sam has done. He's been in some animated cartoons
column7: but you can't tell me anything that he ever did
column9: or that he ever said. And yet
column10: this just showed to me that people like cartoon characters. They like to be able to try to draw them themselves
column11: and they like all sorts of cartoon characters. I think this was the foundation of cartoon licensing; people just like cartoons
column13: and they'll put anything on their refrigerator or on their car
column15: anything that they happen to like. If you can come up with a cartoon character that is even more appealing than the others
column17: and I think that's where it all starts.

column1: Now
column2: there are some people who are against licensing
column3: and in a way
column4: I suppose it should be flattering. They have become fond of your work
column5: and they clutch it to themselves very selfishly. They want it to be theirs. They have discovered this new comic strip and they want to talk about it with their friends
column6: and all of a sudden it becomes popular. It's like hearing a new singer for the first time
column7: and you think she's just wonderful
column8: and before you know it she's got four or five hit records and everybody in the country is talking about her. You've lost her-she's not yours any more. You've lost your discovery
column9: and I suppose this is one of the things that people don't like. But we live in a culture where this is almost taken for granted. Everybody is involved in licensing. If Bill Cosby can sell chocolate pudding and all of the other things that he sells
column10: and Willie Mays can sell things with his picture
column15: I'm too good for this sort of thing""? Because it's not all mine anyway. As I said back at the beginning
column16: this is not a pure art form by any means
column19: ""How can a commercial product be accused of turning commercial?"" It doesn't make sense. As I've also said
column20: I've been very careful about all the things that we've done. Perhaps we've made some mistakes
column21: but I don't think we've ever turned out anything that was offensive
column22: and I know I've never drawn anything that was offensive. Our television cartoons are as inoffensive as we can make them
column23: without being sugary sweet and dumb. All I can say is that I've just done the best that I can

column1: BARRIER: Have there been products that people on your staff have wanted to license and you have said
column2: ""No
column3: this makes me uncomfortable
column4: I don't want to do it.""

column1: SCHULZ: We talk about that every now and then
column2: and I just can't remember which ones.

column1: BARRIER: I've heard about some vacuum-cleaner company that wanted to use Pigpen as a mascot.
SCHULZ: I don't know why we turned that down. Maybe it just didn't interest me. Offhand
column2: I just can't think of anything.

column1: BARRIER: It sounds as if you and your people here are pretty much in sync ...
SCHULZ: Oh
column2: yeah. Evelyn [Ellison]
column3: who handles the first look at the products that come in
column4: always brings all the Hallmark cards in to me. They're doing a new line now
column6: and I bet I turned down half of those
column7: because I'm very sensitive to what we call ""spiritual humor
column8: or something like that. I don't like phrases like ""the man upstairs
column9: and things like that. I despise that kind of humor. So I turned down at least six of those cards. I also turn down anything where you're using a phrase that has become quite popular but created by somebody else. I want all of the phrases that are used to be mine
column10: and not something that was created by some comedian.

column1: BARRIER: You're not going to have Lucy saying
column2: ""Make my day.""

column1: SCHULZ: No
column2: I don't think so. That would be a perfect example.

column1: BARRIER: On the TV shows
column2: I gather from what Bill [Melendez] told me that you've always kept very tight control over the scripting.

column1: SCHULZ: Yes
column2: I wish that I could live right in Hollywood and work in Bill's studio and not have to do all these other things
column3: but be right there when all these shows are done
column4: and be there every daywork with the animators
column6: and have absolute tight control over them. But I can't. I believe the strip is still the most important thing
column7: so a lot of the things get away from me. He has a good group of animators
column8: and I like them all; we get along well
column9: but I still watch over things so that they don't do animators' tricks. My characters do not run into trees or go speeding off in different directions. It's a different type of animation. Our shows are very difficult to do
column10: and I don't think Bill is given the credit most of the time for overcoming all of the difficulties
column11: because these little characters act almost real
column12: in the things that they do; they don't do many cartoon things

column1: BARRIER: Something I've always wonderedand this is more a matter of satisfying personal curiosity than for the articleis why
column2: in the cartoons
column3: you never hear Snoopy's thoughts as you do in the strip
column4: or as you did on the stage

column1: SCHULZ: That was a decision that was made years ago when we were doing the first animation
column2: which was for the Ford commercials. J. Walter Thompson was the advertising company
column3: and they had several people come out
column4: and we discussed all of these things
column5: and we actually made some tests of some Hollywood actors imitating what they thought Snoopy's thoughts might sound like
column7: but I just vetoed the whole thing. I said
column8: ""We can get around it. We will lose something there
column9: but we will gain something else in animation."" Which is the difference between the two mediums. As long as you know which medium you're working in
column10: you're all right. You'll gain something in animation
column11: and you'll gain something in strip; they're two different mediums. I'm glad that we stuck to that.

column1: BARRIER: There have been fewer new ""Peanuts"" specials in the last few years
column2: and Bill said that you were the reason
column3: essentially
column4: you were the bottleneck. One thing I wanted to get clear
column5: you actually initiate the scripts yourself

column1: SCHULZ: Oh
column2: that's an enormous problem. I like to initiate the scripts myself. I think that our best shows have been ones that have been created spontaneously by a certain thought which has come to me. Being forced to do a show because our producer
column3: Lee Mendelson
column4: has committed himself to the networks for a show
column5: I have not always turned out our best work. We have done a show for virtually every holiday that is
column6: and I think in some cases they have not been as good as they should have been
column7: simply because we were forced to grind out a show on a subject which I was not ready to write about. Our best shows are shows which have come about because I just happened to make a trip to France and visit Omaha Beach and be inspired to do ""What Have We Learned
column8: Charlie Brown?"" or read an article in Sports Illustrated once about sled dogs
column10: ""Snoopy would make a terrible sled dog; he has to run on his two hind feet and he's too civilized."" That's always been one of the favorite shows of Bill and myself. And
column12: my acquaintance with ice skating prompted the Peppermint Patty ice-skating show
column13: which we have been complimented on so often
column14: because of the authenticity of the skating in it. We had real skaters perform for Peppermint Patty
column15: and the animators followed their actions
column16: so that when Peppermint Patty skated a third-test figure
column17: it was absolutely authentic. This is the way shows should be done; shows should not be ordered by somebody else from the outside
column18: and then ground out that way. That's the worst way of all to do them.

column1: BARRIER: I did want to ask you about the arenadid I read that you had sold it?
SCHULZ: No. Nobody else could own it. Because it loses so much money.
BARRIER: It's more of a hobby than a real business.
SCHULZ: It's more of an obligation.
BARRIER: In what sense?
SCHULZ: Well
column2: I don't want to let down all the people that love skating. Last week we finished our fourteenth Senior Hockey Tournament; we had 600 men 40 and over
column3: on up into their seventies
column4: come to play hockey. They look forward to this all year long. We gave them a barbecue one night
column6: 500 steaks. We gave them all nice jackets and shirts
column7: and all sorts of things. I just don't want to let them down

column1: BARRIER: Why does it lose money?
SCHULZ: Because we run such a quality operation. We employ about 50 or 60 people over there. I don't think an arena could make money
column2: anyway
column3: even if we set it down to a bare operation. It's so expensive just to keep the ice going; that's quite a buildup.

column1: BARRIER: That's on Steele Lane
column2: is that right?

column1: SCHULZ: You can't miss it; it's across the street. The big Swiss-style building. And then right across from it is our Snoopy Gallery
column2: which we built because we didn't have room for the all the things that we sell and the skating equipment and all the Snoopy things. And then I had accumulated so many other gadgets and trophies and plaques and things that the whole upstairs is Snoopy's Gallery
column3: which you'll enjoy visiting.

column1: BARRIER: There was a lot of publicity
column2: when you first moved to Santa Rosa
column3: about the arena being a tourist attraction
column4: and this place being a tourist attraction
column5: and tourists were knocking on the door. Does that still happen?

column1: SCHULZ: Well
column2: it does if I go over there. It's almost impossible for me to go over there without somebody coming up for an autograph
column3: or 15 Japanese students lining up
column4: all giggling and wanting drawings. Drives me crazy. But we don't allow visitors here any more
column5: unless they accidentally knock on the door and walk in. I just can't take it. The payoff
column7: was when a busload of Japanese tourists pulled up one day. Without even asking us
column8: the driver was going to make this a curiosity stop. They all came roaring in
column9: with all the little cameras. They wouldn't do that to a doctor or an attorney
column10: but I'm supposed to go out there and pose for their pictures. Again
column11: it just lays another guilt problem on me
column12: because I'm thoroughly grateful for all the nice things that have happened to me
column13: but I also am being driven by all of the obligations
column14: too. I just can't do all these things. And I hate autographing. I just despise autographing. I get so annoyed. Every time you pick up the paper
column15: it shows some athlete signing something; it's always a picture of so-and-so autographing something. What's so great about autographing? I declined yesterday at the county fair. We had some visitors from England
column16: and Jeannie and I walked in the gate and walked down in the midway and were looking around
column17: and some couple stopped me and said
column19: ""Yeah."" ""Can we have your autograph?"" I said
column20: ""No. Can't I just be left alone to enjoy the fair?""

column1: BARRIER: You moved to California inwas it '58 or '59?
SCHULZ: '58. Jill was just a baby.
BARRIER: And you lived in Sebastopol at first
column2: and then moved here.

column1: SCHULZ: Yeah. And all the kids grew up and moved out into the country
column2: for a while
column3: and then Joyce and I separated. She lives in Hawaii
column4: and I now live here right on the edge of town.

column1: BARRIER: A former bishop's residence?
SCHULZ: We sold that. That was owned by the local bishop; beautiful place.
BARRIER: How did you settle on Santa Rosa as a place to live?
SCHULZ: Jeannie lived in Santa Rosa. Her kids were still teenagers
column2: and were still going to school
column3: so we just bought a house in Santa Rosa.

column1: BARRIER: One more thing on the TV shows. Bill did the first ""Garfield"" special
column2: and he said you had told him that was a conflict of interest and he should not be doing ""Garfield"" as well as ""Peanuts.""

column1: SCHULZ: Not true. The president of United Features came to me one day and he said
column2: ""I've got something very sensitive to ask you
column3: and I'll understand whatever your response is. We have a chance now to sell a 'Garfield' show
column4: and we think Bill is the best person to do it. Would you mind if we asked Bill to do it?"" I said
column7: because I know Bill always needs work to keep his animators going
column8: and if Bill wants to do it
column9: that's all right with me. I don't want to stand in the way of Jim Davis
column10: if he has a chance to do a television show
column11: as long as it doesn't interfere with Bill's doing 'Peanuts' things. If Bill suddenly decides he'd rather do 'Garfield' and forget me
column12: then I would object."" I think Bill did the first one
column13: then one of his animators broke away and took over doing the ""Garfield"" shows
column14: so Bill didn't do any more after that.

column1: Lee Mendelson's wife and another man
column2: Ed Bogas
column3: started to write the music for both shows
column4: and one year ""Garfield"" and one of our shows were both competing for an Emmy
column5: and they had written the music for the ""Garfield
column6: and they won the Emmy. I said
column7: ""Now we're getting to a conflict. Now we're competing. Before
column9: but I just don't think that you people can write music for both shows. Make up your mindeither you write for me or you write for 'Garfield
column10: ' because you can't do it for both."" It hasn't come out yet
column13: there was a ""Garfield"" showI think he went to Hawaii
column14: or something like thatand a Snoopy show. They ran the ""Garfield"" at 8 and they ran ours at 8:30. I thought the ""Garfield"" show was so terrible that I said
column15: ""I don't want any more being paired with 'Garfield. '"" Maybe we lose viewers
column17: I don't know8:30 is supposed to be a better time slot. But I said
column18: ""That show was so badnever again. Don't put me with 'Garfield. '"" That's the only conflict that has ever arisen. I like Jim Davis; I don't know him real well
column19: but I think he's a nice fellow. But there comes a time when you do compete.

column1: BARRIER: One thing I wanted to confirmI saw a cryptic reference to a story that there was a real Snoopy
column2: you had a dog named Snoopy at some point
column3: and you traded him for a truckload of gravel.

column1: SCHULZ: Well
column2: yeah
column3: but that had nothing to do with it. The real Snoopy was based upon the dog I had whose name was Spike
column4: who wasn't a beagle. Later on
column7: and Craig wanted a dog. Craig was a year younger than Monte. So we went out to a puppy farm one Sunday morning and we got Craig a little beagle. I said to Craig
column8: ""What are you going to name him?"" ""I'm going to name him Spike."" Then Monte suddenly decided he wanted a dog
column11: and Monte named his beagle Snoopy. They came back
column12: and within the next few days they began to scrap. As the days went on
column13: the fights got more ferocious. So we thought
column14: this can't carry on. A guy came by one day who was delivering shale to some driveway they were putting in
column15: and he saw the dog. He said
column17: I'd sure like to have that dog."" So we traded Snoopy for a load of shale. And he loved that dog; every time we'd see him he'd say
column19: that Snoopy is a real dog
column20: he and I really get along."" So it was a good sale. But Spike outlived Snoopy

column1: BARRIER: Something else I wanted to check with you
column2: because it's such a wonderful story. I have an old press release here that United Features put out in 1959
column3: about how you sold your first strips to them. It's the kind of anecdote that would be wonderful to use in the story
column4: if it's true. Since it's a press release from the syndicate
column7: the odds are maybe 50-50 it's true. [Reading from the press release] ""'My wife and I kept our fingers crossed
column10: 'and when the syndicate wrote that they would be interested in seeing my funny youngsters developed in comic-strip form
column12: I really got excited. I had already developed some definite little characters that I thought would make a good daily strip
column13: so I drew them up and left for New York.' It was a nasty
column14: rainy morning when he arrived in New York
column15: and to keep his drawings dry he tucked them under his coat and hurried to the syndicate office without pausing for breakfast. He was so early that none of the staff had arrived for the day
column16: so he left the drawings with the receptionist and went out to eat. While he was gone
column18: and the receptionist gave them the samples. They looked them over
column19: and by the time Schulz returned they had decided that his inimitable little charactersgood o1' Charlie Brown
column23: Schroeder and the otherswould indeed make a good comic strip. And thus was 'Peanuts' born.""

column1: SCHULZ: [laughing] Not true at all. Basically
column2: 80 percent of it is true. In the first place
column3: I wasn't married.

column1: BARRIER: I thought you got married in '49.
SCHULZ: Well
column2: that's a lie
column3: too [Schulz and Joyce Halverson married on April 18
column5: but we won't go into that. That's not important. It was drizzling that morning
column6: and I got to the syndicateI had sent them these wonderful panels; it was the best thing I had ever done. I took all of the best ""Li'l Folks"" ideas I had done for the Pioneer-Press and I put the title up here like this
column8: I've got to do something that's a little bit different
column9: I've got to give them an angle
column10: and my drawing style is so simple
column11: I know what I'll do: I'll draw two cartoons
column12: I'll draw one here and I'll letter in the gag line
column13: and I'll draw another one down here and letter in the gag line
column14: and this will be sold just as a panel
column15: the same size as ""Dennis the Menace"" and any others. It was really neat; I was very proud of that. I knew that this was going to come close
column18: and never heard a word. In the meantime
column19: I was working for Art Instruction
column21: and I waited for a month
column23: which was typical of United Features. Since then
column25: ""Couldn't you at least send people a postcard saying
column27: we'll be looking at them'?"" They never learned. Anyway
column28: I wrote them a letter and I said
column30: I think perhaps they were lost in the mail
column31: could you tell me if you received them because I'd like to put a tracer on them."" I got a letter from Jim Freeman; it said
column33: and we kind of like them. Would you care to come to New York?"" Etcetera. So that was great. I took the train to New York.

column1: In the meantime
column2: I had been doing some other strips which were three panels. They were very brief incidents. Up until then
column3: people drawing kid cartoons had used the old well-what-are-we-going-to-do-today sort of theme. Mine was very brief incidents; nobody had ever done things like this before. This is something that people forget about
column5: if they talk about imitating me
column6: or something. Nobody had ever done this type of humor before. There was a lot of gag-cartoon humor which was highly original
column8: but nobody had done anything like this in a strip
column9: and I had about six of them that I had been working on
column12: if I'm going to New York I should show them some of the other things that I've been doing
column13: just to show them how versatile I am. I had these in an envelope
column14: and it was drizzling that morning
column15: and I got to the office about 8 o'clock
column17: and there was nobody there except the girl at the switchboard. She said
column20: ""I'll go out and eat breakfast. It's raining out; can I just leave this package here?"" I didn't say what was in it
column21: or for them to open it
column22: or anything. I went out and had breakfast
column23: and when I came back the sales manager was there
column27: and we kind of think we'd rather have a strip if you think you could draw a strip."" I said
column29: I'd rather draw a strip."" They said
column30: ""Could you create some definite characters?"" See
column31: in there it says they were fascinatedthere was no Charlie Brown or anybody. They said

column1: That's when I went back to Minneapolis and asked my friend Charlie Brown if I could use his name
column2: and he said
column3: ""What does he look like?"" He looked at it and he said
column6: I was hoping I'd look more like Steve Canyon."" And I drew the little puppy
column7: Snoopy; originally he was to be called Sniffy
column8: but I was walking uptown one day and I saw a comic magazine about a little dog named Sniffy
column11: they broke my name. On my way back to my job
column12: I remembered that my mother had said
column14: you should name him Snoopy."" I thought
column16: why didn't I think of that before? I named him Snoopy
column17: and I had the little boy named Shermy
column18: named after a friend of mine
column20: who was named after a cousin of mine. Those were the first four characters. That was it; that's how it started.

column1: BARRIER: I've read that you are talking now about retiring.
SCHULZ: I don't know how I can. All of my friends are retiringeither retiring or dying. It's become a problem for me. I don't know what to do.
BARRIER: I've heard that you're concerned aboutand I noticed when you were drawing just now
SCHULZ: Oh
column2: my hand shakes. It's been shaking for years.

column1: BARRIER: You can see a little of that
column2: comparing the strip now with years ago
column3: you can see a little more wavering ...

column1: SCHULZ: It's just annoying
column2: that's all it is. It slows me down
column3: and I have to letter very carefully. I'm learning to live with it. After my heart surgery
column5: and then I had knee surgery last September. I remember one day I came back
column6: and I was so weak from the knee surgery I finally had to quit; I just couldn't hold that pen still. It's annoying
column7: but I can live with that. I just don't know is it worth it. Am I supposed to sit here the rest of my life drawing these things while all my friends are retiring and everybody's doing different things?

column1: BARRIER: I was looking back at some of the older interviews with you
column2: and you sounded like you never wanted to quit ...

column1: SCHULZ: I know
column2: well...

column1: BARRIER: ... And then some of the interviews I read recently
column2: it's like all of a sudden you're saying to yourself

column1: SCHULZ: I'm getting old. I'll be 66 years old; I can't believe it. Oh
column2: it's not that I want to [retire]
column3: I just wish there were some way of getting rid of all the other things and just drawing the comic strip. But I don't see how it could be done.

column1: BARRIER: It sounds like your people here
column2: though
column3: can do a pretty good job of ...

column1: SCHULZ: Well
column2: yeah
column3: but you take a look at those storyboards that they try to do down there in Hollywood without me. I always tease Bill and Lee
column4: and I look at the storyboards
column6: ""This is what it's going to look like after I'm dead
column7: isn't it?"" That's what's going to happen. It won't be the same

column1: BARRIER: I've heard that United Features will recycle the strip rather than having anybody
SCHULZ: I don't see how they can. They say they will. If I die tonight
column2: that's the end of the strip
column3: as far as my drawing it
column4: and I know the first thing they'll do is try to reprint things. But I seriously doubt that works. I know that's the first thing they'll try. But who knowsthat's all speculation.

column1: BARRIER: I can't imagine anybody continuing your strip. The factory-produced strips""Garfield
column2: yeswill continue
column3: but yours

column1: SCHULZ: And why? If Andrew Wyeth dies tonight
column2: are they going to bring somebody else in? Everything has to end sooner or later.

column1: BARRIER: How far ahead are you now? What kind of lead time do you have?
SCHULZ: I'm drawing the Sunday page
column2: I think
column3: for the second week of October
column4: the daily strip-the next batch of strips would be the last week in September.

column1: BARRIER: So you're not as far ahead as you used to be.
SCHULZ: No
column2: I lost a lot after my knee surgery
column3: and different things like that. I just haven't been able to recover; there are so many things that get in the way.

column1: BARRIER: When did you have heart surgery?
SCHULZ: Seven years ago. There was my best lead. I had three months' lead
column2: because I didn't know what was going to happen; and I only used a month of it. I wracked up my knee playing hockey. That was worse than the heart surgery; that just took all the life out of me. I haven't been able to come back. And then there are so many things that interfere.

column1: BARRIER: Like interviews.
SCHULZ: Interviews; today. See
column2: now this afternoon is gone. Wednesday
column3: Bill Melendez is coming up to talk about the cancer movie
column4: and he'll be here from 11 o'clock on. Friday I have to play in a charity golf tournament which I just can't avoid. August 15
column6: the girl who's doing my biography is coming
column7: and she'll be here all week long.

column1: BARRIER: Oh
column2: somebody is doing

column1: SCHULZ: It's kind of a biography; more of an interpretation rather than a literal biography [Good Grief: The Story of Charles M. Schulz by Rheta Grimsley Johnson
column2: was published in 1989]. It's that way all the time.

column1: BARRIER: But you do interviews like this one out of a sense of obligation
column2: I gather
column3: to the people who are

column1: SCHULZ: Well
column2: I suppose this one I would do out of obligation to the licensees
column3: I think
column4: although I learned my lesson on that one with Advertising Age. Did you ever see that one? Ironically
column5: it was written by a guy named [Bob]Garfield. The fellow calls up
column6: and he does a column for Advertising Age; his name is Bill Garfield or something
column7: I don't know. There was an article about him in Editor & Publisher last week. I thought
column11: that's good for the licensing. He came up
column12: we had a nice talk for about a half an hour or so. Pretty soon he says
column13: ""I guess it's about time that I should tell you something. I don't read your strip any more. I don't think it's as good as it used to be."" ""Well
column16: but if that's what you believe
column17: that's all right."" We talked a little bit more about that
column18: and I defended my position. So he left
column19: and as he went out the door
column23: because I've enjoyed talking with you and you seem to be a nice person."" Then he writes the whole column about the strip not being as good as it used to be. I don't see any object in that
column24: unless it's to prove how wonderfully perceptive he is.

column1: No
column2: I enjoy interviews
column3: and I like taking the telephone interviews; it's a good way to relax from the drawing.

column1: BARRIER: I must admit I was surprised when I called here
column2: and you were on the phone. I thought
column3: gee whiz

column1: SCHULZ: I don't understand people that don't want to do that
column2: because I think it's kind of fun. I enjoy talking to high school students
column3: and college students; I want to do little things like that. I don't like the ones in grade-school classes where they broadcast your voice in the classroom and they have the kids ask the questions
column4: because the questions are so obvious: Where did you get the idea for Snoopy? But I still do them. I also don't like all the commitments ahead of time; like my summer now has been committed. Here it is August 1
column5: and my summer is virtually gone. I've gotten to do almost nothing that I wanted to do
column6: because I'm committed to so many different things.

column1: BARRIER: One last question about the TV shows
column2: about the Saturday morning show. Bill said this was again a case where
column3: I gather
column4: it did not continue because there was a lack of scripts.

column1: SCHULZ: Yeah; they just couldn't do them. I don't know many Bill sold originallyor Lee
column2: Lee was the producer. Did he ever say how many? Was it l8?

column1: BARRIER: I think it was 15.
SCHULZ: Which we just couldn'tBill couldn't do that many. And I couldn't write a whole bunch of original stories
column2: so we went back and got the stories out of the various strips. Then he just couldn't keep up the schedule
column3: so he trimmed it back
column5: and then finally just gave up. There was too much. He just couldn't do them all. It had nothing to do with me.

column1: PHYLLIS BARRIER: I have a question: What type of music do you listen to?
SCHULZ: None.
PHYLLIS BARRIER: I thought maybe you were a music listener while you were drawing.
SCHULZ: I used to be
column2: years ago
column3: when I had my studio up in Sebastopol
column4: in the woods. I just had the one secretary; she stayed at one end of the studio
column5: and I was down at the other. We had the radio on to a kind of a quiet-music station all day long
column6: but I don't do that any more. After my divorce
column7: and the sadness of being separated from the kids temporarily and all of thatalthough they eventually all came back. But I used to get so depressed listening to songs and music that I stopped. Now it's just too much of an interruption. Most of my time is just sitting here trying to think of something. Then the phone rings
column8: and the stereo's on too loud. I never listen to it.

column1: A 17-year-old boy was struck and killed by a passing semitrailer on southbound Interstate 71 in Union Township Sunday morning.

column3: of Kings Mills

https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/exceptional-proof/	the exception proves the rule means counterexamples verify the adages claim.	true (but not for the reason you think)	['Not What You Think']		David Mikkelson	['http://www.worldwidewords.org/qa/qa-exc1.htm']	http://www.worldwidewords.org/qa/qa-exc1.htm	http://www.worldwidewords.org/	"Jump to content
Q From Dave Dewhurst
column2: British Columbia: How did the phrase
column3: the exception that proves the rule come about? Would an exception to some pattern or consistency not prove the need for a rule

column1: A You’re right to query the expression. It has caused as much confusion as any other in the language and is often argued about. The misunderstanding has been amplified by well-meaning but incorrect attempts going back a century to explain it.

These days it is often used sweepingly to justify an inconsistency. Those who use it seem to be saying that the existence of a case that doesn’t follow a rule proves the rule applies in all other cases and so is generally correct
column2: notwithstanding the exception. This is nonsense
column3: because the logical implication of finding that something doesn’t follow a rule is that there must be something wrong with the rule. As the old maxim has it
column4: you need find only one white crow to disprove the rule that all crows are black.

column1: It has often been suggested in reference works that prove here is really being used in the sense of “test” (as it does in terms like “proving ground” or “the proof of the pudding is in the eating”
column2: or in the printer’s proof
column3: which is a test page run off to see that all is correct with the typesetting). It is said that the real idea behind the saying is that the presence of what looks like an exception tests whether a rule is really valid or not. If you can’t reconcile the supposed exception with the rule
column4: there must indeed be something wrong with the rule. The expression is indeed used in this sense
column5: but that’s not where it comes from or what it strictly means.

column1: The problem with that attempted explanation is that those putting it forward have picked on the wrong word to challenge. It’s not a false sense of proof that causes the problem
column2: but exception. We think of it as meaning some case that doesn’t follow the rule
column3: but the original sense was of someone or something that is granted permission not to follow a rule that otherwise applies. The true origin of the phrase lies in a medieval Latin legal principle: exceptio probat regulam in casibus non exceptis
column4: which may be translated as “the exception confirms the rule in the cases not excepted”.

column1: Let us say that you drive down a street somewhere and find a notice which says “Parking prohibited on Sundays”. You may reasonably infer from this that parking is allowed on the other six days of the week. A sign on a museum door which says “Entry free today” leads to the implication that entry is not free on other days (unless it’s a marketing ploy like the never-ending sales that some stores have
column2: but let’s not get sidetracked). H W Fowler gave an example from his wartime experience: “Special leave is given for men to be out of barracks tonight until 11pm”
column3: which implies a rule that in other cases men must be in barracks before that time. So
column5: the principle is arguing that the existence of an allowed exception to a rule reaffirms the existence of the rule.

column1: Despite the number of reference books which carefully explain the origin and true meaning of the expression
column2: it is unlikely that it will ever be restored to strict correctness. The usual rule in lexicography is that sayings progress towards corruption and decay
column3: never the reverse. Unless this one proves to be an exception ..."	World Wide Words: Exception that proves the rule		[]	['expression'
column16: British Columbia: How did the phrase
column17: the exception that proves the rule come about?

column1: Would an exception to some pattern or consistency not prove the need for a rule
column2: not the existence of one?

column1: Those who use it seem to be saying that the existence of a case that doesn’t follow a rule proves the rule applies in all other cases and so is generally correct
column2: notwithstanding the exception.

column1: If you can’t reconcile the supposed exception with the rule
column2: there must indeed be something wrong with the rule.

column1: So
column2: in its strict sense
column3: the principle is arguing that the existence of an allowed exception to a rule reaffirms the existence of the rule."
