Season IV Field Work Narrative and Daily Events Log
Thursday July 7.

JVT arrives Rapa Nui via Tahiti. JVT met with Cristián Arévalo P. and Rosa Paoa Ika to deal with logistical plans for serving the crew a customary daily breakfast (coffee and bread) and also hot lunch (supper) at the end of each day. JVT and CAP met with students and others who wish to work on the field crew. JVT met with Sonia Haoa of the Consejo de Monumentos Nacional and Lili González.
Friday July 8
JVT and CAP met with Ninoska Cuadros Huke
column2: director of the Rapa Nui unit of CONAF. JVT and CAP audit profile drawings for RR-001-157.

column1: Saturday July 9
JVT met in the morning with Chris Stevenson. Rafael Paoa Rapu
column2: who is working on the XRF sourcing of the basalt tools removed from our excavations
column3: will be at Chris’s lab in the U.S. for one week in January. He has an opportunity
column5: to visit the EISP office and UCLA as a follow-up experience. Obsidian samples from the lowest
column6: previously unexcavated levels of our RR-001-157 excavations
column8: will be carried by Rafael to Chris’s lab for the benefit of his learning process and for potentially useful analysis. We have retrieved 509 tools (toki) during our Rano Raraku excavations to Season III
column9: and Rafael has collected the XRF data on 179 of them. This large sample forms the nucleus of his lithics studies.

column1: Site Visit

Niko Fredes Hey joins us and we pick up some of our field equipment at the Mana Gallery and purchase poles to take to Rano Raraku to erect a tent as insurance against rain. CAP and NiKo erect the tent while JVT documents the current status of the site.
Site Monitoring

CAP’s observations made and actions taken during weekly monitoring of the site between field seasons have been very useful. Guava is persistent and tiny plants that had sprung up in various areas have been removed throughout the time since Season III. The profiles are fully documented in our audited stratigraphic drawings
column2: and after our final photo record is made we intend to close the excavation of RR-001-157 during this season. We plan for Monday’s first field day and schedule tasks
column3: including the backfill of RR-001-157.

column1: Site Condition: RR-001-157
Squares 16
column4: and 19 were among the first excavated and are in good condition
column5: but fragile. Some toki and flakes once present in the NE sidewall and shown in the profile drawings have weathered slightly out of the sidewall and we removed them and will add them to the object collection after they are properly registered. They will be stored with the toki in Square 30. A toki in the corner of Square 12 was photographed in more detail and will be removed while backfilling.

column1: The current depth of Square 19 is 65 cm measured from the surface (originally
column2: according to our notes
column3: at 80 cm measured from the line). The first set of photos shows Square 16 at 60 cm deep. Square 8 is eroded from its original 50 cm width to about 45 cm. Square 12 is eroded from 50 cm to 47 cm width. This is negligible.

column1: Photos were taken to document the colors of the back of RR-001-157 to compare them with those taken in February. There is essentially no change
column2: except that the top of the head to the bottom of the ears seems to be darker since the application of the water repellent. The lichens on the back of the head are dying and some have changed color from white to gray and black. The next level of color is gray to the shoulders
column3: then tan to the mid-point of the arm. The tan portion is quite dry.

column1: Control statue RR-001-158 was photographed (Figure 3 above) and the damage inflicted on its face by vandals in April
column2: 2010 is nearly invisible now. The fence is intact and monitoring equipment is in place. Final overviews of the site were taken once the tent was erected. Excavation tools and the portable table we use as an office are stored on site.

column1: Sunday July 10
JVT works on the collections in the EISP Field Office (Mana Gallery) for most of the day. All of the collections made during the previous excavations for Seasons I
column2: II
column3: and III had already been washed
column4: bagged and logged. A print-out of that log was included in the Season III report. Our next task is to generate museum accession numbers in the catalog and then to physically assign them to each bag. All collected materials are stored in their original bags and the bags are in individual
column5: labeled plastic bins annotated by season. A major task for October-November field season is that each bag
column6: once the museum number has been attached
column7: will have to be photographed with its contents prior to moving it into museum storage. We are training two Rapa Nui field assistants this process
column8: and their experience on the actual excavations will facilitate this lab work.

column1: Monday July 11
RR-001-157 Square 5 30-220 (stopped at 175 cm)
RR-001-156 Squares 10 and 13 Shovel Scrape
Bags Collected: 6

We (7 members of crew) arrived at Rano Raraku. Vai photographed the overall condition of the excavation site as well as the various squares and their sidewalls and the papa or bedrock in the west wall of the excavation
column2: along with various petroglyph details. Nico began clearing RR-001-157 Squares 4 and 5. JVT with Tari clears Squares 10 and 13 extensions under the papa. Vai photographed details of the papa west wall. Our goal today is to excavate RR-001-157 Square 4 now at 30 cm deep on the south and 1 m deep on the north and to begin Square 5.

column1: Tuesday July 12
Bags Collected: 20

A large number of tourists in big groups are in the interior today. It is very time consuming as they have a lot of questions for us. CAP and Nico begin digging Squares 12 and 13. During the afternoon JVT photographs previously mapped paenga (RR-001-179)
column2: taheta (RR-001-178) and umu pae (RR-001-177) features in the middle of the interior slope in order to amplify EISPMap Sheet 5 and Map Sheet 6 (Van Tilburg and Arévalo Pakarati 2009).

column1: Wednesday July 13
RR-001-156 Square 10 150-220 cm (half)
Bags Collected: 28
JVT begins excavating Square 10
column2: 150-220 cm (see July 20 notes). Shovel scrape of the square revealed a few bone fragments (animal) and numerous pebbles. One large rock was removed from the NW corner of Square 10. It measures 25 x 30 x 30 and is of very porous light gray basalt and
column3: with the others
column4: is stored on site. We note that the wall of Square 13 extension is holding nicely after a recent light rain. Vai repeats many artifact photos of the previous day due to a camera focus problem now resolved. In Square 4 we find a large piece of metal fused with coral in proximity to the statue.

column1: Notes on stratigraphy: NE wall to 220 cm
organic black to dark brown surface layer with vegetation extends as a lens about 30 cm deep into the next layer;
yellow-brown soil with lapilli;
lapilli layer is shot through with a thin inserted layer of brown-gray soil. Large pieces of basalt are present and there are vertical cracks throughout;
thin layer of gray
column2: lumpy soil;

column1: wide uneven layer of brown-gray soil has organic yellow-green material including pebbles; large piece of broken basalt and cultural material throughout;
layer of pebbles and organic material
ozidized metal associated with the Williamson
column2: Balfour Company at about the 170 cm level (see earlier notes)

column1: our historic level book shows the 1914 level very clearly and from it we have calculated the rate of deposition.
the 470 m deposit around RR-001-157 indicates the placement of the statue in an upright position at least 500 years ago.
Condition Notes: Dorsal View RR-001-157

The top of the head is ash gray and relatively smooth in appearance. White lichens on the upper half of the back of the head are spotted with gray-black pin pricks and appear to be dead or dying. There is a meandering patch of yellow-brown and thin
column2: hair line cracks overall on the surface of both statues. The back of the head has an overall honey brown color and the surface is very even in texture. The raised spine is very apparent. The lower portion of the right ear has an overall gray and smooth surface but
column3: just above it
column4: there is a patch of brown and gray that seems to be an extension of the stratigraphy of the back of the head. The petroglyphs on the right side are visible. In general
column5: the right side is more pulverized on the surface than is the left. The surface is dry thanks to the water repellant.

column1: The shoulders are smooth with diagonal bands running right to left on the smoothed surface. The petroglyphs on the upper back are cut into this layer. There is a nearly rounded patch on the right back at the shoulder that is deep and reveals a thick conglomerate surface into which petroglyphs there are cut. The cupules on the left shoulder are in the lower eroded stone layer. Sheer plates and cracks both horizontal and vertical are present
column2: and the petroglyphs are clearly etched into the previously eroded surface. The two vertical patches made on the loose slabs of tuff at the back of the head contrast in color with the current surface but will weather. Interestingly
column3: not a single visitor has asked about them.

column1: The EISP image database contains full documentation of the back of the statue and its condition to certain excavated levels. Images are on file from the Mana Expedition to Easter Island
column2: 1914-1915; the Carnegie Expedition 1916; private collectors
column3: 1914; the Norwegian Archaeological Expedition

column1: Condition Notes: RR-001-156 Ventral View

Some traces of original surface are still visible in the right eye socket and under the left brow. The top of the head is a very consistent ash gray in color and the same color is present on the left side of the brow. The brow itself has alternate lines of deep lapilli and smooth conglomerate. Diagonal and nearly horizontal lines of erosion cross the damaged face
column2: which is dark gray to black. White spots of lichens on the left ear and the side of the face are present
column3: along with a few spots on the bridge of the nose. The previously buried surface of the statue is an overall honey-brown color. Pieces of exposed basalt spot the lip. By far the best preserved surface is on the right side of the face below the ear. The surface there is plane and the Makemake petroglyph on it is very visible. The surface of the ear lobe just above is pulverized with visible conglomerate. The EISP image database contains documentation of the ventral side of the statue in the form of photographs or drawings made in 1914-1915

column1: Thursday July 14 RR-001-156 Square 9 220-320 cm
Bags Collected: 19
We begin excavation (CAP with Nico) in Square 9. Small fragments of toki are relatively common
column2: but intact or interesting specimens are rare. It may be that most of the toki from both statues were simply returned by Routledge to RR-001-157
column3: whether or not they were originally removed from there. Unidentified fish bones are collected and the apparent remains of an umu are visible as a lens of black and gray in the soil. CAP clears the soil from near the right arm of the statue in Square 9. The stone is very yellow in color.

column1: Friday July 15
RR-001-156 Square 8 220-320 cm (not completed)
Bags Collected: 13
Rain and drizzling all day makes it possible to view the highly successful results of the water repellant applied to the statues in May. The statues’ stone surfaces are soaked repeatedly
column2: the beads of water simply cascade off and
column3: if there is any sun at all
column4: the entire exposed surface is dry within 10 minutes.

column1: In Square 8 we exposed a deeply etched horizontal line drawn across the back of the statue precisely at the level of the top of the square. A single
column2: large piece of carbon was collected at 54 cm deep near the back of the statue on the NW corner of Square 9 and just below the horizontal line. The soil is dark brown and heavy
column3: and is water soaked with fine small pebbles throughout. A mass of animal bone (sheep?) is encountered. In Square 12 we uncover a thin but relatively even and consistent line of pebbles at the bottom of this level. When the soil was at this level (before 1914) there was an umu made (probably by men who worked for the Company).

column1: Saturday July 16
Rain all day. Field work canceled. JVT meets with C. Stevenson
column2: T. Ladefogel and their students to give an informal overview of the excavation prior to their site visit planned for July 19. CAP continues audit of profiles for RR-001-157.

column1: Sunday July 17
JVT and CAP finalize profile drawings for RR-001-157. An interesting series of events is encoded in the stratigraphy and the various intrusions of excavations
column2: especially by the Mana Expedition
column3: are evident in the profiles.

column1: Monday July 18
RR-001-156 Square 7 Shovel Scrape (I bag surface)
RR-001-156 Square 10 Shovel Scrape (1 bag surface)
RR-001-156 Square 8 Completed
Bags Collected: 6
Nico begins Square 9
column2: which is wet but not flooded. JVT cleans the side of the papa on the west wall. The day is sunny and windy. Some more animal bone (sheep) is recovered in Square 8. Small stone rubble is found at 320 cm
column3: including toki fragments and a quantity of black
column4: decomposed basalt. A lens of this material is visible in the photograph of the square at 320 cm. Some small
column5: thin roots of guava are attached to the sidewall but not to the statue back.

column1: At about 4:00 PM today
column2: which is very windy
column3: a fire was accidentally started by someone employed to cut the grass and shrubbery. Flames
column5: were sometimes over 4 m high and the smoke was very thick. Some of our crew went to help fight the fire
column6: but it was obviously too dangerous. At the request of CONAF P. Hito
column7: who arrived right away to try and control the fire
column8: CAP drove to Hanga Roa to inform CONAF.

column1: Tuesday July 19
Bags Collected: 16
JVT and CAP review RR-001-155
column2: the remnants of a hare paenga. This feature
column3: and another on the other end of the quarry (RR-001-212) were used as our GPS control points (Van Tilburg and Arévalo Pakarati 2009). Three of the stones (paenga) in RR-001-155 were visible during our mapping project
column4: and one of them was used (Stone 3) the exact location of the point (Figures 17
column5: 18). Three more stones are visible and we clear further vegetation and overburden to expose roughly half of the foundation.

column1: Notes on RR-001-155 (hare paenga and survey control point)
The hare paenga is placed perpendicular to the slope and as exposed is 370 cm long
column2: 156 cm wide at mid-point and 117 wide at the narrowest point (measured at Stone 4). It consists of 17 stones with an entrance and a portion of the poro paved terrace (taupea). Other stones from this structure are down slope. The stones are numbered from southwest to northeast and were documented consecutively.

column1: Stone 1 Gray brown smooth basalt; total length 102 cm; width at widest point 16.5 cm; exposed 5 cm above ground; six holes on upper surface varying from 4 to 10 cm in diameter and from 2.5 to 7 cm deep.
Stone 2 Gray
column2: porous basalt; total length 86 cm; width at widest point 15 cm; exposed above ground 5.5 cm; 3 holes varying from 4.5 to 5 cm in diameter and all about 4 cm deep.

column1: Stone 3 Smooth
column2: light gray and blue-gray basalt; 125 cm long; 19.5 cm wide at the top and 27 cm wide at the bottom including the beveled edge; 14 cm exposed above ground. There are two very small and shallow cupules on one end
column3: one of which is broken; three cupules on the top range from 5 to 7.5 cm in diameter and from 2 to 6 cm deep. This stone is the EISP survey control point.

column1: Stone 4 Gray-white crystalline basalt; the stone is in two pieces (A and B). Both of these stones are included in the EISP survey control point photographs. Stone A is 52 cm long and beveled. It is very well-made of a pock-marked
column2: gray basalt. The top of it is 12 cm at the widest part and the base is 20 cm wide. Two shallow holes are 3.5 and 2 cm deep
column3: respectively. Stone B is also beveled and of the same basalt type. It has one hole on the bottom that is 3.5 cm deep and two deep holes on the top (7 and 7.5 cm deep
column4: respectively). The stone is 54.5 cm long and 39 cm wide.

column1: Stone 5 is broken and 45 cm long. It is 11 cm wide and has two small and shallow holes.
Stone 6 is badly burned and discolored gray-black o top and reddish brown on the the sides. It is 68 cm long
column2: 10 cm wide and 19 cm above the current ground level. There are 2 holes on top
column3: one of which is 7 cm deep and the other 4 cm deep.

column1: Stone 7 is 34 cm long and 16 cm above the current ground level. There are three holes
column2: and the middle one is connected through another cupule on the site to another next to it. There appears to be a wear mark from the insertion of rope on the SE edge of one hole.

column1: Stone 8 This stone may be part of Stone 7. I tis 37.2 cm long and 10 cm wide with two shallow holes
Stone 9 This stone may be part of Stone 10. It is very squared off
column2: rectangular in shape and has two large holes. Total length is 40 cm long and 18 cm wide. It is only 7 cm above the current ground level.

column1: Stone 10 is 30 cm long and has one broken edge and two holes. It may be part of Stone 9.
Stone 11 is an incomplete fragment that may be part of Stone 10. It is 17 cm long and 6.5 cm wide with three holes
column2: one on each end is broken.

column1: Stone 12 is 43.5 cm long and 16 cm wide. It has no holes and is located in front of the entrance to the structure.
Stone 13 is 30 cm long and 19 cm wide
column2: with only 1 hole.

column1: Stone 14 is 46 cm long
column2: 14 cm wide
column3: and has 3 holes

column1: Stone 15 is 37.5 cm long and has 3 holes of different sizes and depths.
Stone 16 is 26 cm long and 14 cm wide with one shallow hole
Stone 17 is 21 cm long and 16 cm wide (exposed) with one hole.
The hare paenga foundation was excavated to 60 cm deep at the top of the slope and was exposed at ground level at the bottom of the slope.

The doorway is formed of 3 paenga and is 99 cm long from the curb and 48 cm wide. The exposed length of the structure is 7.80 m with a conjectured length of at least 10 m. It is 171 cm wide at the mid-point (exclusive of the entrance).
A curved endstone was brought from down slope and inserted back in the foundation at what we believe to be the approximately correct original location. The curbstone is 64 cm long
column2: 29 cm wide and 12 cm height. It is formed of porous basalt similar to others in the foundation and has 1 broken post hole.

column1: The significance of this structure is its relationship to RR-001-003.
Wednesday July 20
Bags Collected: 6

CAP continues to clear the hare paenga. A photographic record is made to amplify the map and object record. Note: On the bags collected from Square 5 (July 11) the level was noted as 2m but digging stopped at 175 cm. Square 5 is brought down to the level of Square 4 to clean the dirt from the surface of RR-001-157. A large
column2: apparently unworked basalt stone is present in the sidewall but not removed. We retrieve lithics as usual and scattered animal bone. We begin the second half of Square 10 (divided longitudinally on July 13) at 150-220 cm.

column1: Thursday July 21
Bags Collected: 15
Notes on Backfill RR-001-157:

Ata will help Pato as he begins backfill of RR-001-157. Their first task is to clean and remove the vegetation (primarily roots) from the backfill pile and to remove the small stones so that all of the latter can all be deposited in the same layer at the same time. A portion of the east side of the enclosure fence is removed to accommodate the backfill process. The plan is to move the clean dirt from the pile by wheel barrow
column2: deposit it in Square 19
column3: and then to shovel it into the hole bit by bit. While time consuming
column4: this will certainly protect the statue. This work begins at 12:20. The dirt is completely clean of refuse and stones. After several meters are deposited Pato compacts the soil.

column1: Simultaneously
column2: Tari and Nico continue the excavation of Square 4 at 220-320 cm. Martine
column3: Margarita
column4: and Melisanda with JVT are screening. The rain yesterday evening left everything damp or wet and we go extremely slowly so as not to overlook anything. The floor of Square 4 is smoothed to make it even with Square 12 at 320 cm. CAP and JVT discuss the curve of the statue’s back and consider constructing a frame that will allow us to measure it more closely.

column1: In Square 4 at 300 cm we encountered an extremely large concentration of heavily weathered basalt (decomoposed) and large pieces of carbon near the SW corner of the square. The NE corner of Square 14 is eroded and uneven. A lens of charcoal is also present there. We create a step in which the ladder can be placed and then divide Square 6 in half with the top step being at 220 cm and the second at 270 cm down to Square 9 at 320 cm. CAP begins Square 7 at 220-270 cm at 3:45. Carbon and some animal bone is retrieved.
Friday July 22
RR-001-156 Square 10 150-220 (completed)
Bags Collected: 9

Rain off and on throughout the night has further compacted the backfill. Some rain appeared again at about 10:30 AM. The excavation is wet but not even close to being flooded. We begin in Square 7 at 220 cm exactly. In Square 4 at 220-320 we find a very unusual portion of what appears to be the jaw of either a lamprey or blow fish. Pato and Ata continue the backfill. We level Square 7 for photos. We bring buckets of water from the lake and wash everything in the field before collecting. One of the CONAF rangers volunteers to screen
column2: which is very helpful on a day like this. Finally finish Square 10 (begun July 13) at 220 cm by removing 30 cm of soil to the west near the papa to even everything out and make the sidewall of 7 and 10 meet properly. Finished Square 7 at 220-320 cm and continued backfill.

column1: Saturday July 23
Bags Collected: 16

Square 13 is measured at only 93 cm because one sidewall is slightly bowed. The 1 m measurement is accurate at the top of the square but slightly tilted inward. This is not a function of erosion or error
column2: but during the original excavation Dario and we thought that the wall would be the tallest in the excavation and would need to be somewhat stronger or more stable. The area in question is thus 150 cm long across Squares 10 and 13 at the top. The extension under the papa was amplified on the drawing and new measurements were taken. Bone (animal) was found immediately we began Square 13. Our goal in Square 13 is to even the line that defines the edge of it with Square 10 before going under the papa via the mapped extension. Digging of the next level of Square 10 220-320 begins.

column1: Simultaneously
column2: backfill continues on RR-001-157 to the level of the “M” design on the statue’s back. Larger rocks
column3: including cores and some with worked surfaces
column4: which were earlier removed from the excavation and stored on site are now placed on the back dirt in the manner of a level pavement. Some small flakes and chips are included in this level.

column1: JVT checks and records notes on the level of damage to the various statues that resulted by the accidental fire of a few days ago. It seems that about 10 statues
column2: exclusive of worked features such as shaped blocks
column3: quarry details
column4: and papa may have suffered flame or smoke damage.

column1: Informal Notes on Damage Due to Fire (July 18

column2: the EISP mapping project was carried out after a major accidental grass fire. All of the vegetation and every single statue
column3: quarry and feature we mapped was included in the burned area. The ash under foot was several centimeters thick. This fire was confined to a more limited area.

column1: During the recent (2011) fires we note that the entire stone alignment (RR-001-197) was burned
column2: as were the following: taheta 195; statue torso 198; moai 202 and all those above and to the east of this statue. Everything on EISP Map Sheets 9 to 13 and in EISP Quarry Sections 15 to 19 was in the fire zone.

column1: Monday July 25
Bags Collected: 9
Observations on RR-001-156
column2: Dorsal View

column1: From below the deeply etched horizontal line (220cm) a single strip of what appears to be moisture registers as a dark
column2: wide line running from the right arm of the statues in an arc across the back and through the two circles to meet with a nearly square patch that is similarly dark. That patch extends from the spine to the arm and downward to the soil level. The lower portions of the circle and the arched lines on which they sit are now visible at 320 cm.

column1: Coral is recovered in some quantity close to the moai in Square 9 at 340 cm. A large quantity of large pieces of carbon with mixed coral fragments
column2: bone
column3: obsidian flakes
column5: as are two molars (human?). Fowl and fish bone collected as well. Photos are taken at this point to document the accomplishment of our excavation of RR-001-157 and a bottle with the names of everyone on the crew (all four seasons) is buried in the soil at the middle of the circle.

column1: Tuesday July 26
Heavy rain makes field work impossible today. JVT working on field notes; CAP on the second profile for RR-001-157.
Wednesday July 27
RR-001-155 : Surface to 60 cm (hare paenga)
Bags Collected: 2
We complete work on the hare paenga (see above). We surface clear most of the squares
column2: which are still wet but undamaged and begin excavation of the extensions under the papa of Squares 10 and 13. Some bone (presumed to be human) is removed and stored in a separate box with a form given to us by the local museum. Once cataloged
column3: the materials will be stored in the local museum with others previously retrieved (see November field report). Bone is all removed by JVT and CAP by hand. The rest were retrieved by Vai and Melisanda using tweezers at the field office at the back of the quarry. Privacy is ensured by blocking tourist access to that entire area.

column1: In Square 10 at 166 cm we find metal. On another note
column2: Margarita tells us today that last night an “old woman” cousin of Alberto Hotus told her that the name of the hare paenga we excavated (see above) is Hare Kai nga Poki.

column1: Thursday July 28
Square 4 sidewall
Squares 7 and 9 surface 220 cm
Square 10 extension 120 cm
Square 13 extension 120 cm
Bags Collected: 14
Because portions of the excavation were wet due to rain we concentrated on the extensions of the squares under the papa
column2: as they were nearly completely dry. All of the bones in these areas
column3: some of which are human and most of which are sheep
column4: were removed by CAP by hand.

column1: Friday July 29
Square 4 extension 220 cm
Squares 7 and 10 extensions 220 cm
Bags Collected: 13

Shovel scrape surface of Square 10. CAP works on Square 10 extension under the papa while Ata continues the backfill of RR-001-157. We begin to remove a portion of Square 7 under the papa. Some red pigment is noted throughout the square and at 200 cm exactly Cristián found a large
column2: egg-shaped quantity of pure red and still very bright pigment concentrate (kie’a).

column1: Saturday July 30
Square 13 extension 175 cm
Bags Collected: 4

We begin removing Square 13 extension at 125 cm measured from the turf on the south wall and 120 cm from the papa on the same wall. The backfill of RR-001-157 is complete to just below the line of discoloration previously recorded by Routledge (1919)
column2: the Carnegie Expedition (1916) and later by the Norwegian Archaeological Expedition (1955-56). All surface erosion and other anomalies observed by the conservation process are contained above this line. Note the drying out of the left side of the back of the statue after exposure is proceeding nicely.

column1: August 1
Square 13 extension to 220 cm
Bags collected: 6
Carbon is collected from three discrete lens in Square 13 extensions: one on the surface of the square at 220 cm; a second one on the same level but removed from the first
column2: and a third at 194 cm in the sidewall of the same square.

column1: August 2
JVT
column2: Vai and Margarita meet with Francisco Torrres H.
column3: Director of Museo Antropolólgico P. Sebastián Englert (the local museum) to deposit the kie’a found (see above) and to discuss the curation of this fragile material. Later JVT
column5: and Vai meet again with the director to finalize a system to expedite the cataloging of the collection of RR-001-157. We will insert a museum catalog number into our existing computerized catalog of bags collected and then also write the same number on the individual bag. The time consuming aspect of the process is then to photograph each bag and its contents and add that to the linked photo record. We have
column7: entered a preliminary count of 479 bags collected. A detailed listing of those objects by material is given in the Season III report and will be provided as an addendum to this report as well. The final days on the island are devoted to completing field records
column8: closing the site and storing collections.

column1: 2:53 P.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you everybody. It’s a great place; I’ve been here before. We love this location. We love this base and
column2: most particularly
column3: the people that are working so hard here and so effectively.

column1: So I want to start by saying
column2: “At ease.” Just relax. Do you have seats? You can sit down. Come on. Sit. If you want to stand
column3: you can. We’ll just get one big standing ovation
column4: right? (Laughter.) Sit down. Thank you. That’s pretty good. Everybody has got a seat. Thank you very much.

column1: I want to thank our wonderful Vice President
column2: Mike Pence
column3: and say a special hello to the incredible patriots of Fort Drum and the 10th Mountain Division. Special people. Thank you. (Applause.)

column1: A few moments ago
column2: I witnessed your extraordinary capabilities firsthand during an artillery raid demonstration. So I’d like to begin by applauding the 10th Mountain Division Combat Aviation Brigade
column3: along with the 3rd Battalion
column4: 6th Field Artillery. (Applause.) I hate to say this
column5: but nobody stands a chance against you folks. Nobody stands a chance. (Applause.)

column1: I’m here today to sign our new defense bill into law and to pay tribute to the greatest soldiers in the history of the world: the United States Army. Thank you. Thank you. (Applause.)
The National Defense Authorization Act is the most significant investment in our military and our warfighters in modern history
column2: and I am very proud to be a big
column3: big part of it. It was not very hard. You know
column4: I went to Congress; I said
column5: “Let’s do it. We got to do it. We’re going to strengthen our military like never
column6: ever before.” And that’s what we did. I want to say
column8: there is no better place than right here at Fort Drum to celebrate its passage. No better place.

column1: After years of devastating cuts
column2: we’re now rebuilding our military like we never have before
column3: ever. Because we know that to survive and having that survival of our freedom
column4: it depends upon the might of our military. And no enemy on Earth can match the strength
column6: and skill of the American Army and the American Armed Forces. Nobody is even close. They never will be.

column1: We’re grateful to be joined today by many of our nation’s top military leaders. I’d like to recognize Deputy Secretary of Defense Shanahan
column2: who’s with us. Please
column3: Mr. Secretary. (Applause.) People I’ve heard about all my life — a very prestigious title; I always loved the ring: The Joint Chiefs of Staff. Right? That’s got a good ring. Anybody in the audience going to be a member of that someday? I think so. Raise your hand. If you think you’re going to make it
column4: raise your hand. Go ahead. Oh
column5: come on. That’s all? Only a few? I don’t know. (Applause.)

column1: I want to thank General Dunford
column2: General Milley
column3: General Neller
column7: and Vice Admiral Ray. Thank you all for your leadership. You’re magnificent. We appreciate it very much. Thank you. (Applause.) Thank you.

column1: A very special thank you to the commanding general of the 10th Mountain Division
column2: Major General Walt Piatt. What a special man. Walt
column3: I want to thank you. Where is Walt? Where is Walt? Walt
column4: thank you very much. (Applause.) Thank you. Thank you. Walt is back on American soil after a deployment in Iraq. And I just want to welcome you home. You have tremendous respect. They have great
column5: great admiration and respect for you

column1: I also just had the chance to meet Division Command Sergeant Major Jason Roark
column2: along with 10th Mountain Division Soldier of the Year
column3: Michael Lima. Where’s Michael? Where is Michael? Soldier of the Year. (Applause.) Michael. Pretty good. And that’s Soldier of the Year

column1: SERGEANT LIMA: Eighteen thousand
THE PRESIDENT: How many?
SERGEANT LIMA: Eighteen thousand
THE PRESIDENT: That’s a lot of soldiers. Eighteen thousand? Do you want to work for me? (Laughter.) Thank you
column2: Michael. Great job.

column1: We would not be here for today’s signing ceremony without the dedicated efforts of the members of Congress who worked so hard to pass the National Defense Authorization Act. I’d like to recognize Congresswoman Elise Stefanik
column2: whose district proudly includes Fort Drum. And I have to tell you about Elise. She called me so many times. I said
column3: I don’t want to take her call. She wanted me to be here. I said
column4: I won’t be able to; we’ll have to change a lot of scheduling. But that didn’t suit her. She didn’t stop. And here I am. (Applause.) Here I am.

column1: Elise
column2: come here. Come here
column3: Elise.

column1: REPRESENTATIVE STEFANIK: Thank you
column2: Mr. President. It is truly an honor to welcome you to Fort Drum
column3: home of the historic 10th Mountain Division
column4: the most deployed unit in the U.S. Army since 9/11. Thank you for being here to sign the historic National Defense Authorization Act
column5: which includes the largest pay increase
column7: and investing in our military readiness. Climb to glory

column1: THE PRESIDENT: She’s an incredible representative.
I also want to thank Representatives Don Bacon
column2: Dan Donovan
column3: and Joe Wilson
column4: who are with us today also. Thank you. Where are you? Stand up
column6: Dan. Stand up. (Applause.) Thank you. Thank you

column1: There’s another member of Congress here today who is not only an Air Force veteran
column2: but the first woman ever to fly a fighter jet in combat in U.S. history. And I’ve gotten to know her very well
column3: and she is terrific. Congresswoman Martha McSally. Congresswoman. (Applause.) Thank you
column4: Martha. Thank you for being here. Thank you very much.

column1: Thank you all for fighting for our military and for fighting for our vets. Nobody has made more progress on anything than what we’ve done with our vets. We have Choice approved. You know that. We have so many other things approved for our vets
column2: and it’s really moving along well.

column1: I think
column2: maybe
column3: almost as important as Choice is Accountability. Now
column4: when we find somebody not treating our vets probably
column6: right? “You’re out. Get out. You’re fired. Get out.” (Laughter.) They couldn’t do that. They couldn’t do that. Now they can do it. (Applause.) Now they have to treat our vets properly. Our vets are our great people

column1: So you have Choice and you have Accountability
column2: and nobody thought that would ever get approved. They’ve been trying for many
column3: many decades.

column1: Finally
column2: I want to thank a very special group of patriots at Fort Drum: all of the amazing spouses and family members whose love and support make your service possible. Whether you like it or not
column3: they make it possible. Please. Thank you. Thank you very much. (Applause.) They know. They know. Right? Look at them. He’s smiling. They know.

column1: Last year
column2: we secured a historic $700 billion to rebuild our military. And now
column3: the National Defense Authorization Act paves the way for another 1
column4: 700 — listen to this now. So we’ve been trying to get money. They never gave us money for the military for years and years. And it was depleted. We got $700 billion. And next year
column6: we have $716 billion to give you the finest planes
column9: and missiles anywhere on Earth. Nobody makes them like we do.

column1: And very
column2: very far distant
column3: in this case — jobs are very important in all cases — but in this case
column4: military might is more important than even jobs. But all of this equipment is made right here in the USA
column5: and it’s the best equipment on Earth. Nobody makes it like we do. So you have $700 billion and now $716 billion. So congratulations. (Applause.)

column1: America is a peaceful nation. But if conflict is forced upon us
column2: we will fight and we will win. Right
column3: General? Right? Right? Better believe it
column4: generals. (Applause.) They’re the guys. We’re powered by the unstoppable force of the United States Army. Very special.

column1: With this new authorization
column2: we will increase the size and strength of our military by adding thousands of new recruits to active duty
column3: reserve
column6: 000 new active-duty soldiers. And we will replace aging tanks
column7: aging planes and ships with the most advanced and lethal technology ever developed. And hopefully we’ll be so strong we’ll never have to use it. But if we ever did

column1: It all includes 135 brand-new
column2: beautiful M1 Abrams tanks
column3: 60 Bradley Fighting Vehicles
column5: 000 Joint Light Tactical Vehicles for the Army Armored Brigade Combat Team. New Black Hawk and Apache helicopters — finest in the world — for the Army National Guard. Seventy-seven F-35 Joint Strike Fighters. You know
column6: that’s stealth. I talked to a couple of pilots — great pilots — I said
column8: “They’re hard to beat because you can’t see them.” It’s always hard to beat the enemy when you can’t see it. The greatest in the world.

column1: Full funding for the B-21 Raider bomber program. Thirteen new Battle Force ships and support ships
column2: including a fourth Ford-class aircraft carrier and three additional Littoral Combat Ships.

column1: Funding to modernize our nuclear arsenal is so important. We’re doing a major upgrade of our missile defense. We’re spending a tremendous amount of money on our nuclear arsenal. Nobody will have close. We will hopefully never
column2: ever have to use it. But nobody will be close.

column1: More than $11 billion for the military construction
column2: including family housing. And we are proudly giving our troops the biggest pay increase in a decade. And I know you don’t want it because you’re very patriotic. You’ll say
column3: just save the money. We’re going to pay down debt. Does anybody not want it? Please raise your hand. What’s going on here? (Laughter.) Are these real patriots? I don’t know
column4: General. I don’t know. It’s the biggest increase in a decade.

column1: A strong military also requires a strong economy
column2: and our economy is setting records like never before. We have the great economy we’ve ever had. I think that’s going to help us a lot in a lot of ways. It also helps us a lot in funding and doing all of the things we’re doing for our great military.

column1: We’ve created almost 4 million new jobs since the election. A number that the media in the back would never have said would be possible if during the campaign. (Applause.) I’m so proud of myself; I didn’t call them the “fake-news media.” I didn’t call them. (Applause.) I said to myself
column2: I will not today
column3: in front of our great armed forces
column4: call them fake news. (Laughter.) We know the real truth
column5: but we won’t say it today. (Laughter.) But they wouldn’t have believed it possible — 4 million new jobs. Nobody would have thought that possible on the campaign trail.

column1: If when we were campaigning
column2: Mike
column3: if I would have said that — if I would have said
column5: ” people would have laughed us off the stage. Well

column1: Something I’m very proud of: the African American
column2: Hispanic — Hispanic American
column3: and Asian — Asian American — the unemployment rates for all three have reached the lowest levels in the history of our country. Unemployment for African Americans
column6: the lowest level in the history of our country. (Applause.)

column1: Women’s unemployment is not — I’m sorry — doing quite as well. It’s only the lowest level in 65 years. (Laughter.) So we’re not doing as well. (Applause.) But we’ll do better. I think within about three weeks
column2: when the new numbers come out
column3: you’ll probably be lowest in history also.

column1: Very importantly
column2: the veterans’ unemployment rate recently reached its lowest level in nearly 20 years. It’s a big one. (Applause.)

column1: And we are creating manufacturing jobs again. Remember during the campaign
column2: they said
column3: “Oh
column4: you can’t create manufacturing jobs.” I said
column5: “Really? We’re not going to make things anymore? Is that what it’s come to? We’re going to have other country make things? They’re going to make things and we’re going to buy them? And they’re going to have the jobs and we’re not?” Doesn’t work that way. We’re doing manufacturing jobs at the fastest pace in many

column1: No longer are we apologizing for America. Instead
column2: we are now standing up for America. It’s called “America First
column3: ” if that’s okay with you. (Applause.) We’re standing up for our military
column4: and we’re standing up for our great American flag. We’re standing for our flag. (Applause.)

column1: The armed forces have endured continuous combat for the past 17 years. Yet
column2: since the 1990s
column3: the number of soldiers on active duty was cut by more than one-third. Our bases and vital equipment were allowed to fall into a state of disrepair. And I saw some of them. Total disrepair. But those days are over. Every day the Army is fighting for us
column4: and now we are fighting for you — 100 hundred percent. (Applause.)

column1: No one better understands how stretched our military has become than the soldiers of the 10th Mountain Division. Is that right
column2: General?

column1: You were the first conventional combat force to deploy after 9/11. Since then
column2: no division in the Army has been deployed more times to Iraq and Afghanistan than you. You’ve sent over 9
column3: 000 courageous soldiers to 26 different countries all around the world in the past year alone.

column1: The 2nd Brigade Combat Team just returned from a rotation at the Joint Readiness Training Center
column2: and later this year they will once again bravely answer our nation’s call and deploy to Afghanistan. Through it all
column3: you’ve proven to the world
column6: that Fort Drum soldiers aren’t just tough; you’re “mountain tough.” That’s what you are — you’re mountain tough. (Applause.)

column1: I said to you
column2: General
column3: “What’s the difference?” He said
column6: there’s a difference.” So I said

column3: Brayden — good location

column1: Last October
column2: his team came under heavy fire while cleaning and clearing — clearing out Taliban strongholds in various locations in Afghanistan. An Afghan soldier fighting alongside U.S. troops was badly wounded when an explosive detonated nearby. Specialist Cook braved the hail of bullets and mortar rounds all over — they said it was all over; it was heavy fire — saving the life of that wounded soldier and earning a Bronze Star for Valor for his courageous action.

column1: Brayden
column2: I want to thank you. A brave young man. Thank you. Please

column1: We’re also inspired by the devotion to duty shown by the family members who serve their nation here at home.

Ashley Shepard is one of those family members. She has been married to Sergeant First Class Ian Shepard for more than 14 years. Ashley supports military families in every way you can imagine. She has served as a Family Readiness Group leader
column2: co-leader
column3: treasurer
column4: and assistant treasurer for three companies. She works hard. She raises money for scholarships
column5: organizes charity events for Gold Star families
column7: I want to thank you. Ashley? Where is Ashley? I had a feeling that was you
column9: Ashley. (Applause.) Thank your husband too. Thank you.

column1: America is eternally grateful for every soldier
column2: service member
column3: and family member here at Fort Drum. And we are forever in the debt of every American who has ever served our nation in uniform — from the snows of Valley Forge to the jungles of Vietnam and the mountains of Afghanistan. It’s just incredible what you do.

column1: A few days ago
column2: Vice President Pence flew to Hawaii to greet the remains of some of our nation’s greatest heroes: our fallen warriors who gave their lives many years ago in Korea. Now these American heroes are finally starting to come home. They will be laid to rest on American soil. We believe in no American left behind. (Applause.)

column1: And we believe our warfighters deserve the tools
column2: the equipment
column3: and resources they have earned with their blood

column1: In a few moments
column2: in honor of that sacred obligation
column3: I will put my signature on the National Defense Authorization Act. This authorization will give America’s warfighters the firepower they need to win any conflict quickly and decisively.

column1: Thanks to the leadership of Representative Stefanik
column2: we’re also making an unprecedented commitment to developing our artificial-intelligence capabilities.

column1: In order to maintain America’s military supremacy
column2: we must always be on the cutting edge. That is why we are also proudly re-asserting America’s legacy of leadership in space. Our foreign competitors and adversaries have already begun weaponizing space
column3: developing new technologies to disrupt vital communications
column6: you look at what they’re doing. They’ve given me rundowns. I’ve seen things that you don’t even want to see
column7: what they’re doing and how advanced they are. We’ll be catching them very shortly. They want to jam transmissions
column9: and so many other things. We will be so far ahead of them in a very short period of time your head will spin.

column1: China even launched a new military division to oversee its warfighting programs in space. Just like the air
column2: the land
column3: the sea
column4: space has become a warfighting domain. It is not enough to merely have an American presence in space. We must have American dominance in space.

column1: So that is why
column2: just a few days ago
column3: the Vice President outlined my administration’s plan to create a sixth branch of the United States military
column4: called the United States Space Force. (Applause.) Got to get it

column1: We will ensure that the next great chapter in history is written by the heroes of the United States military. America will always rise to every challenge and overcome every danger
column2: because we are backed by the strength and power of the American soldier.

column1: Speaking to his troops
column2: General George Patton — a great one — once said: “We have the finest…equipment [and] the best spirit
column3: and the best men in the world.” Now
column5: he would be saying “the best men and women” in the world. Things do change. But that was quite a statement many years ago.

column1: Continuing his remarks
column2: Patton then declared: “I don’t want to get any messages saying
column3: ‘I am holding my position.’ We are not holding a [God]damned thing…We are advancing constantly.” That was Patton.

column1: Nearly 75 years later
column2: Patton’s words still ring true. America has the best equipment anywhere in the world. We have the best spirit
column3: the best soldiers ever to set foot on any battlefield
column5: at any time. We are the most powerful. We are the best funded. We are the biggest. We are the strongest. We are the smartest.

column1: And we are still not holding a damned thing
column2: because America is on the move once again
column3: and we are not backing down. Our country is respected again. I don’t know if you see it
column4: but America is respected again. There’s a big difference
column5: and a big difference in the air. You take a look around; there’s a big

column1: We are advancing forward with our confidence renewed
column2: our might restored
column3: and the unwavering conviction that our destiny is our victory. America’s future is safe
column6: because each of you is Mountain tough
column9: and always will be climbing to glory. You will be climbing to glory.

column1: Thank you again for the incredible men and women of Fort Drum. Special
column2: special
column3: great people. God bless our troops. And God bless the United States of America.

column1: I’d now like to invite a few of our fantastic soldiers from the 10th Mountain Division 2nd Brigade Combat Team to join me onstage to sign the National Defense Authorization Act. It’s been an honor to be with you today. Thank you all very much. Thank you. (Applause.)
(The Act is signed.)
END

column7: 2017 called ""Art and China after 1989."" If the Guggenheim's plans stay as they are
column8: the exhibit will feature several distinct instances of unmistakable cruelty against animals in the name of art.

column1: In one example
column2: artists Peng Yu and Sun Yuan tether four pairs of American pit bulls to eight wooden treadmills for a live exhibit. The dogs are faced off against one another
column3: running ""at"" each other but prevented from touching one another
column4: which is a stressful and frustrating experience for animals trained to fight. The dogs get wearier and wearier
column5: their muscles more and more prominent
column6: and their mouths increasingly salivate. At this live 2003 ""performance"" in China
column8: complete with close-up shots of the dogs' frantic
column9: foaming faces. This 7-minute video will be on display at the Guggenheim exhibit (information from NY Times article ""Where the Wild Things Are: China’s Art Dreamers at the Guggenheim"").

column1: In another example
column2: artist Xu Bing stamped meaningless characters all over the bodies of two pigs
column3: a boar and a sow
column6: in a museum exhibit in Beijing in 1994. The Guggenheim will feature the video of that ""performance"" as well.

column1: Finally
column2: this exhibit will feature live animals (reptiles
column3: amphibians
column4: insects) that are trapped in a glass enclosure for attendee viewing. According to the NY Times article
column5: ""During the three-month exhibition some creatures will be devoured; others may die of fatigue. The big ones will survive. From time to time
column6: a New York City pet shop will replenish the menagerie with new bugs.""

column1: The video you are about to watch below is quite disturbing. For the last eight years Costco has claimed that their egg supply came from hens who were cage free. The picture used on their cartons depict chickens roaming free in a beautiful field of grass. An undercover investigation by the Humane Society of the United States
column2: sadly uncovered quite a different reality.

column1: If you are a Costco shopper
column2: the shocking information reported in this footage
column3: is critical for you to be aware of. It reveals that the egg suppliers for Costco keep their chickens in the very worst conditions imaginable.

column1: These poor birds are packed so tightly in wire bottom cages
column2: that they are unable to reach the food and water they need to survive
column3: and can’t even spread their wings. Many die as a result of these inhumane conditions
column4: and their corpses are left their for days
column5: while live chickens lay their eggs on top of them.

column1: Such inhumane conditions of keeping hens in cages is not only gravely sad for these poor animals
column2: but according to The Center for Food Safety
column3: doing so increases the risk of Salmonella. The cruel and unhealthy conditions for the chickens in the following footage
column4: is not only harmful for the animals
column5: but puts the consumer at great risk for Salmonella poisoning.

column1: The video is hard to watch
column2: but making consumers aware of what Costco is selling
column3: is essential in forcing them to make a change in the brand of eggs they are selling and misrepresenting.

column2: in fact

column4: she says. People who come in contact with the colonies will get at least a few itchy
column5: probably painful pustules. But how your skin reacts can differ from swelling to life-threatening allergic reactions. “Once they hit you
column6: you're a solid surface so they're gonna crawl on you
column7: ” Keck says. “When the first one stings
column8: they emit a pheromone that causes a chain reaction that tells everybody else to sting
column9: so you're going to experience quite a few stings.” The best thing to do is to rub them off as quickly as possible. “They'll kind of roll up when you brush against them
column10: and so that's an easy way to try and get them to detach from you

column1: Those looking to go on the offensive may want to spray the ants with dish soap to break down their waxy rafts
column2: according to Wired. Of course
column3: that means getting close to the adrift colony
column5: a professor of integrated biology at the University of Texas at Austin
column6: strongly advises against. “You protect yourself by avoiding them
column8: ” he says. ""They don't come to attack you. They're just passively floating along. It's a matter of being just intelligent and evasive.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in Cuero
column3: the river has brought my aunt all of the fire ants. Yes
column4: those are all (of the) fire ants. pic.twitter.com/dEibWYxAdl — Bill O'Zimmermann (@The_Reliant) August 29

column1: But if you find yourself unable to escape their path
column2: Keck suggests creating waves to wash them away from you. “They are pretty well globbed up
column3: and so if you're quick enough
column4: you can kind of move them a few inches away from you so you can avoid them
column5: ” Keck says. At the very least
column6: their distinctive rust coloring makes them easy to spot for what they are and not a piece of debris.

column1: Keck says there’s no danger of them spreading beyond states they already inhabit. That might not be comforting for those in Texas and Louisiana
column2: but at least the fire ants are not building wriggling Eiffel towers. Yet."	Here's how to deal with those clumps of floating fire ants in Houston	2017-08-29 00:00:00	['Megan Farokhmanesh'

column1: “They've been known well before this hurricane to float on top of water like that.”Pro tip: Don't touch the floating fire ant colonies.

column2: or they float to a spot where they hit dry land

column8: prince regent of Bavaria. Trump had been ordered to leave Bavaria for failing to complete mandatory military service and to register his initial emigration to the United States twenty years earlier. Prince Luitpold rejected Trump’s request for repatriation; the family later settled in New York. Translated from the German by Austen Hinkley.

column1: Most Serene
column2: Most Powerful Prince Regent! Most Gracious Regent and Lord!

column1: I was born in Kallstadt on March 14
column2: 1869. My parents were honest
column3: plain
column4: pious vineyard workers. They strictly held me to everything good — to diligence and piety
column5: to regular attendance in school and church
column6: to absolute obedience toward the high authority.

column1: After my confirmation
column3: I apprenticed to become a barber. I emigrated in 1885
column4: in my sixteenth year. In America I carried on my business with diligence
column6: and prudence. God’s blessing was with me
column7: and I became rich. I obtained American citizenship in 1892. In 1902 I met my current wife. Sadly
column8: she could not tolerate the climate in New York
column9: and I went with my dear family back to Kallstadt.

column1: The town was glad to have received a capable and productive citizen. My old mother was happy to see her son
column2: her dear daughter-in-law
column3: and her granddaughter around her; she knows now that I will take care of her in her old age.

column1: But we were confronted all at once
column2: as if by a lightning strike from fair skies
column3: with the news that the High Royal State Ministry had decided that we must leave our residence in the Kingdom of Bavaria. We were paralyzed with fright; our happy family life was tarnished. My wife has been overcome by anxiety
column4: and my lovely child has become sick.

column1: Why should we be deported? This is very
column2: very hard for a family. What will our fellow citizens think if honest subjects are faced with such a decree — not to mention the great material losses it would incur. I would like to become a Bavarian citizen again.

column1: In this urgent situation I have no other recourse than to turn to our adored
column2: noble
column3: wise
column5: our exalted ruler His Royal Highness
column7: who has already dried so many tears
column8: who has ruled so beneficially and justly and wisely and softly and is warmly and deeply loved
column9: with the most humble request that the highest of all will himself in mercy deign to allow the applicant to stay in the most gracious Kingdom of Bavaria.

column1: Your most humble and obedient
Friedrich Trump"	The Emigrants

column1: A: You will probably do all right with Allstate

column11: at this point I retract my intention to cancel my business with State Farm. Unless Atkinson steps forward to release more details about his situation
column12: I cannot conclude that State Farm is against gun owners per se; perhaps the only thing he needed to do was find another State Farm agent.""

column1: A: I don't know what more ""specifics"" anyone needs that haven't been discussed. But

He advised that there is NO way SF would cover a shooting range on my property. He told me and Renee that he would look into what options I might have. He never called me back. Subsequent calls to SF headquarters' Mr. Ted Loy confirmed that SF would not cover shooting ranges on policy holder property. He did say that it was handled on a case by case basis. Renee Wilder went on to say that SF precludes hunting on a policy holder's land
column3: as well

column9: on a SF policy holder's property. PERIOD. So let's cut to the chase. Anyone got a tape measure? Bring it and yourself to Chapin for a guided tour of my place. I DID NOT get that review from anyone at SF or any such offer to the effect. -Gary

column1: Q: State Farm canceled our insurance in Pennsylvania because of guns. We had their insurance on our home and our in home business. We had a federal firearms license and the agent who issued the business liability policy in 1983 knew that. No problem. In 1995
column2: due to a regulation in the Brady Bill that you have a letter from your local zoning board to renew your ffl
column3: the borough tried to take that ffl away from us (partly because we were within 1000 feet of an elementary school).

column1: Well
column2: we won the court case. Cost us $25
column3: 000 in legal fees and we lost at least that in lost business. The ATF was nicer to us than anyone else
column4: believe it or not... And once we won the case
column5: State Farm canceled our insurance. We appealed it to the PA State Insurance commission
column6: who sided with State Farm saying due to all the publicity
column7: we were a ""risk"".... State Farm also has stopped insuring gun dealers and home businesses because of ""risk"". Somehow
column8: I thought ""risk"" was why we were buying insurance!! Without ""risk""

I'm not disbelieving you! I want something in writing also as my carrier is SF also and has been for 40 years. However I'm ready to drop the $%&#@ and find another carrier. It makes no particular difference to me whether State Farm's WRITTEN policy is pro- or con- towards our sports and the Second Amendment. That is their business decision to make. I have EVERY confidence that the shooting / hunting / gun owner populace will then choose the companies that best suit their needs based on fully informed decisions. We will simply let our free enterprise system sort this matter out in the market place.""

column1: That's all I need unless someone else has something I'm missing. It might take them a day to put this entire matter to rest.
But

column3: from my son

column1: Tom learned to shoot on our range when he was five
column2: along with other ""braves"" in his Indian Guide tribe. Tom and his 9-year old brother
column3: Yates

column6: tonight. Tom also is wrestling with how to address one of his fifth grade classmates next week. Seems that boy's dad killed himself and estranged wife in a murder / suicide last weekend.

column1: From my phone conversations
column2: Tom is also puzzled about what State Farm has done. Last night
column3: he asked me why they don't like our ""rifle range?"" I said State Farm thinks it's dangerous. A puzzled look.

column1: Tom asked
column2: ""Dad
column3: are we were going to loose the rifle range?"" I said
column5: is it important to you that we keep the rifle range?"" ""Yes
column9: then don't worry. We won't loose the rifle range.""

column1: So there it is
column2: gentlemen. That's what we're working for. Thanks for your support. -Best Regards

column1: Now let's post some remarks GrassRoots has received and our responses Note color changes for change in person speaking:
From a State Farm Agent:
Just so all State Farm Agents don't get painted with the same brush
column2: you need to know that I
column3: for one
column4: have a SC Concealed Weapons Permit
column11: the title of your article is misleading
column12: as are the conclusions you draw
column13: and you need to clear the air.

column1: Gun ownership and discharging fire arms in a populated area are two quite different issues. There is an ordinance on the Richland County books which requires that any shooting be at least 100 yards from the closest residence. Is that the case in this situation?
More to the point
column2: your article and it's title seem to suggest that gun ownership is an issue with State Farm. I have been with State Farm for 33 years and NEVER has gun ownership been a factor in determining if an individual qualifies for State Farm Insurance. Whether or not you own firearms simply has nothing to do with being insured by State Farm. In fact
column3: State Farm has a variety of low-cost options whereby a gun owner can adequately insure his guns--hardly something an anti-gun insurance company would do.

column1: Grassroots has already done much good
column2: and can do much more
column3: but frothing at the mouth and making unfounded statements that are inflammatory at best
column4: and outright lies at worst simply do not help our cause. Are there issues involved in this case? You bet. But gun ownership is not one of them!

column1: Again
column2: the title of your article is flat out untrue
column3: and the conclusions it tries draw are misleading and a manipulation of the facts. At a minimum
column4: you need to print my response and then you need to get the facts by getting up with someone in State Farm Management to find out what really happened in this case. I suspect you will find that reality is more than the fiction that you just printed.

column1: Incidentally
column2: if Grassroots is going to be as dishonest and misleading in our pro-gun efforts as are our anti-gun fanatics
column3: then I will need to look for another organization.

column1: GrassRoots Response:
I'll pass this on to leadership. Perhaps the title should read: State Farm Dumps Gun Owner in South Carolina for Shooting on Rural Property
As for ordinances. Gary checked. He was in compliance will all ordinances. His activity was completely legal and allowable on his property.

The article was not intended to harm State Farm agents at all. We understand that agents are not the issue here. This is apparently a State Farm policy. Can you provide us with more info from State Farm regarding the issue of shooting on property on which they carry the coverage?

Gary has said nothing but good things about his agent. He is not upset with her. He is upset with State Farm Policy and wants everyone to be aware of this policy. His primary interest is preventing this type of exclusion from becoming the ""standard"" for insurance companies.
Again
column2: the point of this article is not to malign State Farm Agents.

column1: I am willing to take a suggestion from you for the appropriate title of the piece. Thanks
State Farm:
Without being too repetitive
column2: I want to point again that this issue is not about gun ownership and I think your article should have so stated. Our membership--many of who are insured with State Farm
column3: some of whom may by my clients--should not be confused by thinking that their insurance company has taken sides on the gun ownership/control issue. That simply is not the case.

column1: GrassRoots:
I can attempt to make changes to the article to reflect that we are not upset or attacking agents nor are we referring to anything other than the activity of shooting on one's property.
Your logic is what we repeatedly hear from Merchants that post against Concealed Carry. They say they are not anti-gun
column2: frequently say they own guns
column3: hunt
column5: and may have a CWP. However they post against CWP because the law allows them that privilege. Basically our position is to acknowledge that they are right on all points - however our membership wants to know about businesses that take their position.

column1: State Farm:
Without speaking for State Farm
column2: but only as an insurance agent
column3: I can understand what has happened in this situation. If I were your insurance agent and came to your house and saw a broken front step
column4: I would ask that you repair it. There is certainly nothing illegal with your having a broken step. It is your right as a homeowner to either repair that step or not. No one
column5: not the local or even the federal government is going to make you repair it. BUT
column8: will ultimately cancel your insurance if you don't fix it. Why? Simply speaking
column9: you have a substantially increased risk of loss over folks with homes just like yours where the steps are in good repair.

column1: GrassRoots:

I agree with all you say. I am sure every insured has an inherent degree of risk even with steps in good repair. State Farm has decided it doesn't want to insure a property where a personal range is located
column2: shooting takes place
column3: or hunting. Okay
column4: fine. Maybe a great idea from a risk standpoint. Shouldn't our membership know that? Shouldn't they be given this information and the option to take their coverage to an insurance company that IS willing to insure the activity they enjoy on their property. I am not angry with State Farm - it just seems they don't want to insure properties that involve shooting activities. This definitely IS relevant and something members of an organization such as ours would want to know about.

column1: State Farm:
Does having an unlicensed shooting range on a piece of property in a highly populated area increase the risk of loss? Yep
column2: absolutely. Is it legal? Just like the step
column3: it is (if it's over 300 feet from the nearest residence it is in Richland County. And
column5: good journalism would dictate that YOU measure the distance before writing the article).Will any insurance company cancel your insurance for any substantial increase in potential liability loss? Yep
column7: it is in your best interest
column8: as it is in mine as a homeowner to support this stance since our rates depend upon losses which are paid.

Then we could revise and say State Farm doesn't want to insure policyholders what meet such-and_such criteria. column1: State Farm:
If I were a betting man

column1: GrassRoots:

Reread the article. Gary has gladly given out the name of the company that holds his insurance. He has advised me that this was his first question to alternate companies after State Farm gave him 7 days to find alternative coverage. Also

column4: 000 through NRA referred insurance company. Yes

column1: State Farm:
Here's the major point. If a stray shot hits and injures someone else on their own property

column4: and whether or not he had the ""right"" has absolutely nothing to do with it.

column1: GrassRoots:

You are correct. No argument here. Don't you think GrassRoots members that have State Farm should know that State Farm would rather not be their carrier if they are shooting on their property? Doesn't State Farm want these types of risky folks off their policyholder list?
State Farm:
So
column2: if you were the insurance company and you know all of this
column3: would you continue to accept the exposure?

column1: GrassRoots:

If I was the insurance company I would insure anyone and everyone based on financial actuarial risks. If there is increased risk then your premium increases such that it matches the risk involved. Isn't this what insurance companies do?
State Farm:
Like I said in the beginning
column2: it has nothing to do with gun ownership. And it really doesn't have anything to do with whether or not shooting a gun on your own property is legal or not.

column1: GrassRoots:
It has a lot to do with gun ownership if you want to exercise shooting your gun on your property. If you just like to look at them and clean them on your property you'd be correct.

Finally

column3: will not allow homeowners to own trampolines
column4: refuse to let you keep junked cars on your property
column5: require that you remove discarded refrigerators
column6: and regularly inspect homes to be sure that--horror of horrors--your home is maintained and kept in good order--none of which is required by law
column7: or written into your policy. You can also keep a bad dog--its perfectly legal--but just as soon as your insurance company--any company--finds out
column8: they will cancel your policy. I'm glad that they do
column10: but you just have never thought about it
column11: because if the companies were not about reducing their exposure
column12: which means that they often must ""infringe on your rights as a homeowner
column13: all of our rates would substantially higher than they are now. Any insurance company is required to do all it can to limit exposure. The states require it

column1: GrassRoots:
Yes
column2: you are correct. I don't argue this point. State Farm has decided it doesn't want to cover certain activity it considers risky. Okay. Both our membership as well as State Farm should be happy we are getting the word out.

If you would like to talk more about this

State Farm:

A good title for your article might be: State Farm Continues Try to Keep Homeowner Rates Affordable and Cancels Gunowner Who Has Unlicensed Shooting Range. That's a lot more truthful than first title.
GrassRoots:

How about ""State Farm Cancels Gunowner Who Has Shooting Range."" Gary was not given the option of paying more so keeping rates affordable doesn't apply - he would have paid more - money wasn't an issue here. As for ""Unlicensed"" there is no such thing as a ""Licensed Range"" so how can there be an ""Unlicensed Range?"" State Farm:
State Farm Cancels Homeowner Who Has Gun Range"" is a truthful title.

Gary has stated that this is NOT open to the public and is not a commercial range. If he is violation of the law he show be arrested and charged accordingly. Since he has not I would not put the cart before the horse and find him guilty beforehand.
State Farm:
Hey
column2: I'm trying to help our organization here. The shooting range is no different from the trampoline and we are going to look pretty silly when you do find out that all insurance companies manage risks and a gun range

column1: Lately our society has been changing quite a bit; rather notably as a culture intolerant of guns. column1: State Farm's Response to an inquiry from South Carolina Policyholder...
Dear Carol:

It is State Farm's policy not to discuss individual policyholder situations unless they have given us permission in writing to do so. State Farm Insurance has no political stance on the gun issue. We do not take issue with a person's right to own guns. We do offer insurance on guns.

State Farm is in the business of selling insurance to protect people against the risks of everyday life. We are the nation's leading homeowners insurer because we strive to provide the best mix of coverage
column2: service and price. In order to provide a competitive product
column3: we have to carefully consider all risks we are undertaking when we choose to provide coverage. We recognize there are some cases that provide exposures that fall outside of typical homeownership. Liability for these cases cannot affordably be included in the cost of homeowners insurance.

column1: Thank you for your inquiry.
Sincerely
Jairon L. Wills
State Farm Corporate Customer Service Supervisor

column2: January 30
column3: 2019 – It’s Bell Let’s Talk Day 2019 and you’re invited to talk

column1: “Bell Let’s Talk Day has quickly grown into the biggest conversation about mental health anywhere and we hope you’ll join in to let those who struggle know they’ve got your support. By raising our voices today

column1: The Bell Let’s Talk Day videos

column2: text and other interactions of support today

column1: Join the conversation to drive Bell donations

It’s easy to be part of the Bell Let’s Talk Day conversation all day long and across multiple communications platforms. Bell donates 5 cents to Canadian mental health programs for each of these interactions
column2: at no extra cost to participants beyond what they would normally pay their service provider for online or phone access:

column1: Talk: Every mobile call and every long distance call made by Bell wireless and phone customers
Text: Every text message sent by Bell wireless customers
Twitter: Every tweet and retweet using #BellLetsTalk
column2: featuring the special Bell Let’s Talk emoji and Bell Let’s Talk Day video view at Twitter.com/Bell_LetsTalk

column1: Twitter: Every tweet and retweet using #BellLetsTalk

column1: Instagram: Every Bell Let’s Talk Day video view at Instagram.com/Bell_LetsTalk
Snapchat: Every use of the Bell Let’s Talk filter and Bell Let’s Talk Day video view

column3: Jessica Holmes and Dr. Joti Samra.

column1: Bruno Guévremont at CFB Halifax

Royal Canadian Navy veteran Bruno takes part in the first Bell Let’s Talk Day flag raising ceremony at CFB Halifax at 8 am AT before speaking with healthcare professionals at the IWK Health Centre at 9 am AT. He then joins the annual Canadian Armed Forces panel discussion on mental health at 2 pm AT with DND Co-Champion for Mental Health Jerry Ryan
column2: Commodore Chris Sutherland
column3: Lieutenant-Colonel David Coker
column6: and psychologist Chimène Jewer. The event will be moderated by CTV’s Paul Hollingsworth with Base Operations Officer Lieutenant-Commander Sylvie Robinson
column7: and will live-stream on Facebook. Bruno will also speak with visitors at the Discovery Centre at 6 pm AT.

Jonathan and Richard will take part in a Bell Let’s Talk flag raising event at 2nd Canadian Division Support Group at 8:30 am ET.

Andrew Jensen in Winnipeg

Andrew will participate in the True North Youth Summit at Bell MTS Place at 11 am CT. Andrew will also present a 2018 Bell Let’s Talk Community Fund cheque to the Mood Disorders Association of Manitoba at the Spin Away Stigma event at 1:30 pm CT.
Chris Johnson in Edmonton

Chris will participate as a panelist at CMHA Edmonton’s annual Distress Line Breakfast at 7 am MT. Chris will also speak at a fundraiser for the Edmonton Mental Health Awareness Committee at Block 1912 Café at 6 pm MT.

column1: The 5 simple ways to help end the stigma around mental illness
Together
column2: we can all help end the stigma around mental illness with the 5 simple ways developed by Dr. Heather Stuart
column3: the Bell Mental Health and Anti-Stigma Research Chair at Queen’s University:

column1: Language matters – pay attention to the words you use about mental illness
Educate yourself – learn
column2: know and talk more
column3: understand the signs

column1: Be kind – small acts of kindness speak a lot
Listen and ask – sometimes it’s best to just listen
Talk about it – start a dialogue
column2: break the silence

column2: please visit Bell.ca/LetsTalk.

column1: Courtesy of The New York Post Recovery crews combing through debris from the north tower at Ground Zero found a firetruck yesterday - buried some 40 below street level. ""I just think it's ironic that it's appearing now [six months after Sept. 11]

column6: was one of five men killed from Engine Co. 55 in Little Italy. She said members of her husband's company had been out to Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island to look for the company's missing truck - little suspecting it was still buried deep within the wreckage at Ground Zero. The members of Engine 55 parked the truck next to the north tower before rushing in to help rescue the people inside - and when the building collapsed it apparently sucked the empty truck down with it. ""They were one of the first two companies there. That's probably why [the truck was buried so deep]
