Songs of Freedom/Tears of Remembrance The following is an excerpt from a five-part journal detailing one man's crusade to bring healing to a New York firehouse after Sept. 11
column25: heal himself. Barrington stockbroker Joe Cantafio is on a year-long concert tour to raise money for the widows and bereaved families of Engine Company 55
column26: who lost five men at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. In July 2002
column27: Cantafio went to New York City to spend a week with Engine 55 and raise money with several club appearances. Daily Herald staff writer Jim Fuller and photographer Mark Welsh went along. They stayed in the firehouse in Little Italy
column28: sleeping and eating alongside the men of Engine 55. Fuller kept a journal of that extraordinary week. In part one
column30: meet the firefighters and see ground zero for the first time. At night
column31: it's show time. Joe plays his first show at an Irish tavern called ""Molly Wee
column32: where many of the Chicago rescue crews would go for a break after digging. It's not a neighborhood bar. Salt and pepper shakers sit on the tables and the waiters wear shirts and ties. Waiting inside is a face from Engine 55's past. Steve Buscemi was with Engine 55 before Hollywood came calling. His face is recognizable to millions
column33: but tonight he's just a firefighter again. At one point he blends in so well that a woman asks him to watch the men's room door for her while she goes in to use the facilities instead of the crowded ladies room. He's not dressed for the red carpet tonight with black pants and a short-sleeve
column36: class has no position. Some Budweiser reps show up in their suits and ties
column37: but they mix right in with the jean shorts and sandals and start buying beer for everyone. Buscemi put on his gear and dug at ground zero with the rest of them. Tonight
column38: he sings almost every song from ""We Won't Get Fooled Again"" to ""Born to Run."" There are smiles again. As they sing

column2: 'https://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/oakland/2018/11/27/oakland-university-hockey-pucks/2129677002/']	https://www.freep.com/story/news/local/michigan/oakland/2018/11/27/oakland-university-hockey-pucks/2129677002/	https://www.freep.com/	"Oakland University using hockey pucks to protect against active shooters

column1: To prepare for an active shooter
column2: faculty and students at Oakland University are arming themselves — with hockey pucks.

column1: The idea of using the quirky self-defense tool grew out of a training session Police Chief Mark Gordon led in March for faculty members on what they should do if a gunman enters their classroom.
A participant asked what people could bring to campus to be better prepared in case they need to fight back. The university has a no-weapons policy.
Gordon's advice? Be ready to throw something — anything — that could distract a shooter
column2: even a hockey puck
column3: as a last resort if fleeing or hiding aren't an option.

column1: It was just kind of a spur-of-the-moment idea that seemed to have some merit to it and it kind of caught on
column2: Gordon said.

column1: Following up on the suggestion
column2: Tom Discenna
column3: a professor of communication and president of the faculty union
column4: spearheaded an effort by the union to purchase 2
column6: 94-cent hockey pucks — 800 for union members and another 1
column7: 700 for students. Distribution of the pucks on campus began earlier this month.

column1: It’s just the idea of having something
column2: a reminder that you’re not powerless and you’re not helpless in the classroom
column3: Discenna said.

column1: The little black discs have a dual purpose: They are also part of a campaign to raise funds to install interior locks on classroom doors. Some doors are only lockable from the hallway.
The pucks are imprinted with a number that people can enter on the university's website to donate money toward the new locks.
We know locking the classroom
column2: in and of itself
column3: is a big deterrent"" to a shooter being able to enter the room

column1: The American Association of University Professors union has donated $5
column2: 000 toward new inside locks for the 37 classrooms in South Foundation Hall. The student government
column3: Oakland University Student Congress
column4: has made a donation in the same amount for new locks in an as-yet-to-be-determined building.

column1: The student congress also recently ordered 1
column2: 000 hockey pucks that it intends to distribute to students.

column1: Gordon said the 2007 shootings at Virginia Tech inspired Oakland University's efforts to help students
column2: faculty and staff prepare for a possible active shooter and how to defend themselves. At Virginia Tech
column3: a 23-year-old student went on a shooting spree that left 32 people dead before he killed himself.

column1: Gordon said his experience as a youth hockey coach — he once got hit in the head with a puck — gave him the idea that pucks could be a possible self-defense tool.
He said there are no studies or research on using pucks in active shooter situations. They are simply part of a defense posture
column2: he said
column3: such as throwing a stapler
column5: ""or anything that has weight"" and could hurt and distract a shooter so he or she could be disarmed.

column1: “Anything that you can throw that’s heavy and will cause damage
column2: cause injury is the bottom line of what you’re trying to do
column3: he said. ""(A hockey puck) was just a thing that was suggested that could possibly work
column4: especially when you have 20 or 30 people in a classroom and they all throw hockey pucks at the same time
column5: it would be quite the distraction.""

column1: Gordon stressed that the university's active shooter training sessions
column2: which are held several times a year
column3: focus on fleeing first and then
column5: hiding. Fighting back by throwing a hockey puck or through other means should be ""an absolute last strategy.""

column1: Student body vice-president Brittany Kleinschmidt
column2: a junior
column3: said the pucks are raising awareness about the need for the new door locks and generating a lot of buzz on campus.

column1: It gets people talking
column2: she said.

column2: 'http://archive.is/psBXr']	https://www.lifesitenews.com/news/a-mass-sterilization-exercise-kenyan-doctors-find-anti-fertility-agent-in-u	https://www.lifesitenews.com/	"UPDATE (Nov. 12): Kenya's government has launched an investigation into the Catholic Church's allegations. See follow up article here.

column1: Kenya’s Catholic bishops are charging two United Nations organizations with sterilizing millions of girls and women under cover of an anti-tetanus inoculation program sponsored by the Kenyan government.
According to a statement released Tuesday by the Kenya Catholic Doctors Association
column2: the organization has found an antigen that causes miscarriages in a vaccine being administered to 2.3 million girls and women by the World Health Organization and UNICEF. Priests throughout Kenya reportedly are advising their congregations to refuse the vaccine.

column1: “We sent six samples from around Kenya to laboratories in South Africa. They tested positive for the HCG antigen
column2: ” Dr. Muhame Ngare of the Mercy Medical Centre in Nairobi told LifeSiteNews. “They were all laced with HCG.”

column1: Dr. Ngare
column2: spokesman for the Kenya Catholic Doctors Association
column3: stated in a bulletin released November 4
column4: “This proved right our worst fears; that this WHO campaign is not about eradicating neonatal tetanus but a well-coordinated forceful population control mass sterilization exercise using a proven fertility regulating vaccine. This evidence was presented to the Ministry of Health before the third round of immunization but was ignored.”

column1: But the government says the vaccine is safe. Health Minister James Macharia even told the BBC
column2: “I would recommend my own daughter and wife to take it because I entirely 100% agree with it and have confidence it has no adverse health effects.”

column1: And Dr. Collins Tabu
column2: head of the Health Ministry’s immunization branch
column3: told the Kenyan Nation
column4: that “there is no other additive in the vaccine other than the tetanus antigen.”

column1: Tabu said the same vaccine has been used for 30 years in Kenya. Moreover
column2: “there are women who were vaccinated in October 2013 and March this year who are expectant. Therefore we deny that the vaccines are laced with contraceptives.”

column1: Newspaper stories also report women getting pregnant after being vaccinated.
Responds Dr. Ngare: “Either we are lying or the government is lying. But ask yourself
column2: ‘What reason do the Catholic doctors have for lying?’” Dr. Ngare added: “The Catholic Church has been here in Kenya providing health care and vaccinating for 100 years for longer than Kenya has existed as a country.”

column1: Dr. Ngare told LifeSiteNews that several things alerted doctors in the Church’s far-flung medical system of 54 hospitals
column2: 83 health centres
column3: and 17 medical and nursing schools to the possibility the anti-tetanus campaign was secretly an anti-fertility campaign.

column1: Why
column2: they ask does it involve an unprecedented five shots (or “jabs” as they are known
column3: in Kenya) over more than two years and why is it applied only to women of child-bearing years
column4: and why is it not being conducted without the usual fanfare of government publicity?

column1: “Usually we give a series three shots over two to three years
column2: we give it anyone who comes into the clinic with an open wound
column3: men
column4: women or children.” said Dr. Ngare. “If this is intended to inoculate children in the womb
column5: why give it to girls starting at 15 years? You cannot get married till you are 18.” The usual way to vaccinate children is to wait till they are six weeks old.”

column1: But it is the five-vaccination regime that is most alarming. “The only time tetanus vaccine has been given in five doses is when it is used as a carrier in fertility regulating vaccines laced with the pregnancy hormone
column2: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (HCG) developed by WHO in 1992.”

column1: It is HCG that has been found in all six samples sent to the University of Nairobi medical laboratory and another in South Africa. The bishops and doctors warn that injecting women with HCG
column2: which mimics a natural hormone produced by pregnant women
column3: causes them to develop antibodies against it. When they do get pregnant
column4: and produce their own version of HCG
column5: it triggers the production of antibodies that cause a miscarriage.

column1: “We knew that the last time this vaccination with five injections has been used was in Mexico in 1993 and Nicaragua and the Philippines in 1994
column2: ” said Dr. Ngare. “It didn’t cause miscarriages till three years later
column3: ” which is why
column5: the counterclaims that women who got the vaccination recently and then got pregnant are meaningless.

column1: Ngare said WHO tried to bring the same anti-fertility program into Kenya in the 1990s. “We alerted the government and it stopped the vaccination. But this time they haven’t done so.”
Ngare also contrasted the secrecy of this campaign with the usual fanfare accompanying national vaccination efforts. “They usually bring all the stakeholders together three months before the campaign
column2: like they did with polio a little while ago. And they use staff in all the centres to give out the vaccine.” But with this anti-tetanus campaign
column3: “only a few operatives from the government are allowed to give it out. They come with a police escort. They take it away with them when they are finished. Why not leave it with the local medical staff to administer?”

column1: Brian Clowes of Human Life International in Virginia told LifeSite News that WHO was not involved in the Nicaragua
column2: Mexican and Philippines campaigns. “They try to maintain a spotless record. They let organizations like United Nations Population Fund and USAID do the dirty work.”

column1: In the previous cases
column2: said Clowes
column3: the vaccinators insisted their product was pure until it was shown not to be. Then they claimed the positive tests for HCG were isolated
column4: accidental contaminations in the manufacturing process.

column1: LifeSiteNews has obtained a UN report on an August 1992 meeting at its world headquarters in Geneva of 10 scientists from “Australia
column2: Europe
column3: India and the U.S.A” and 10 “women’s health advocates” from around the world
column4: to discuss the use of “fertility regulating vaccines.” It describes the “anti-Human Chorionic Gonadotropin vaccine” as the most advanced.

column1: One million Kenyan women and girls have been vaccinated so far with another 1.3 million to go. The vaccination is targeting women
column2: according to the government
column3: in order to inoculate their children in the womb against tetanus as well. The government says 550 children die of tetanus yearly.

column1: In covering the contest of words the pro-government Nation found plenty of women who had been vaccinated and were now pregnant
column2: even one who was the wife of a former Catholic priest who left the Church to marry. The paper ignored Kenya’s reliance on the Catholic medical system
column3: while setting the bishops’ stand in a questionable historical context of irrational responses “largely based on religious beliefs
column4: ” the more recent murder of vaccination teams in Nigeria
column5: and even of CIA conspiracy theories.

column1: Why would the UN want to suppress the population in developing countries? “Racism
column2: ” is Brian Clowes’ first explanation. “Also
column3: the developed countries want to get hold of their natural resources. And lately
column4: there is the whole bogus global warming thing.”

column1: Dr. Ngare said it was the Catholic Church’s hope that the government could have resolved the matter quietly by testing the vaccine. “But the government has chosen to be combative
column2: ” forcing Kenya’s bishops and Catholic doctors to go public.

column1: WHO’s Kenyan office and several WHO media contacts in Washington
column2: D.C. failed to respond to LifeSiteNews enquiries over a 24-hour period."	‘A mass sterilization exercise’: Kenyan doctors find anti-fertility agent in UN tetanus vaccine		['Steve Weatherbe']	['health'

column1: (NaturalNews) Ten brands of baby wipes produced by the Pennsylvania-based Nutek Disposables
column2: Inc.
column3: were recalled on January 25
column5: following complaints of foul odor and discoloration.

column1: Upon further testing
column2: the baby wipe and adult washcloth manufacturer discovered that some of their products contained Burkholderia cepacia
column3: a species of antibiotic-resistant bacteria frequently found in soil and water
column4: according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

column1: Known for its vinegar-like odor
column2: B. cepacia has emerged as a human respiratory pathogen in people with weakened immune systems or chronic lung disease
column3: especially cystic fibrosis patients.

column1: Pulmonary infections involving these bacteria are capable of causing accelerated decline in lung functions and can induce “cepacia syndrome
column2: ” a progressive form of pneumonia that can be fatal and untreatable
column3: according to MicrobeWiki.

column1: Resistant bacteria found in baby wipes prompts mass recall
“After receiving a small number of complaints of odor and discoloration
column2: Nutek conducted microbial testing that showed the presence of a bacteria
column3: called Burkholderia cepacia (B. cepacia)
column5: ” according to the company’s press release.

column1: “Soon after
column2: on January 3
column3: 2017 the company initiated a voluntary withdrawal of lots that had tested positive for the bacteria
column4: as well as other baby wipes in the surrounding time frame. After some additional lots were tested
column6: Nutek believed it was a prudent decision to withdraw all its baby wipe products.”

column1: The following brands are included in the nationwide recall:
Cuties
Diapers.com
Femtex
Fred’s
Kidgets
Member’s Mark
Simply Right
Sunny Smiles
Tender Touch
Well Beginnings
The baby wipe brands are sold at a variety of retailers including Walgreen’s
column2: Family Dollar
column3: Sam’s Club and internet retailer Diapers.com. Reports confirm that some of the packages distributed prior to January 21
column6: prompting the company to halt shipping of all baby wipes produced at the facility.

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
Before October 3
column2: Nutek Disposables says they only received one report of irritation; however
column3: many more complaints emerged following the recall announcement.

column1: Consumers reported side effects including rash
column2: irritation
column3: infections
column5: gastrointestinal issues and respiratory issues; however
column6: these reports “have not been confirmed to be related to the use of these products

column1: The U.S Food and Drug Administration (FDA) says the company is still unable to determine the cause of the problem but is continuing to investigate
column2: and the administration will work closely with Nutek to communicate the issue with affected retailers and distributors.

column1: “Nutek takes the safety of consumers and the quality of its products very seriously and is taking all appropriate steps to address the issue and ensure this does not happen again
column2: ” according to the FDA.gov.

column1: “Consumers who have purchased this product can return it to the place of purchase for a full refund
column2: ” or contact the company with questions at 1-855-646-4351 Monday through Friday 10 AM – 4 PM EST.

column1: Mouthwash and contaminated medical equipment tied to previous B. cepacia infections
This isn’t the first time a personal care product has been contaminated with B. cepacia. In 2005
column2: the CDC learned that several states had clusters of pneumonia and other infections caused by the bacteria
column3: which ended up being connected to contaminated mouthwash.

column1: Over-the-counter nasal spray was linked to B. cepacia infections in 2004
column2: while that same year medical equipment and solutions used for intensive care unit patients were associated with the gram-negative bacteria.

column1: The antibiotic-resistant bacteria can be transferred by direct contact with contaminated surfaces
column2: exposure to B. cepacia in the environment and through person-to-person contact
column3: according to the CDC.

column1: Good hand hygiene and infection-control practices are recommended for successfully preventing infection from this bacterium.
Sources:

column1: Twitter
column2: a social media site that verifies Nazis
column3: is legally required to hide Nazi content and symbols in Germany and France. You can take advantage of this without moving to Germany.

column1: Advertisement
Twitter user Christa Peterson discovered that you can just tell Twitter you’re in Germany
column2: and it will try to hide Nazi accounts and tweets:

column1: Advertisement
Twitter lists these instructions on a support page
column2: but it doesn’t mention that you can hide Nazis this way. (A separate page explains content withholding.) Here’s how to do it:

column1: 1. From the Twitter homepage
column2: click your avatar on the top right.

column1: 2. From the drop-down menu
column2: select “Settings and privacy.”

column1: 3. In the third section
column2: “Content
column3: ” change your country to Germany.

column1: Advertisement
Now any new page will load with Germany’s content filters in place.
Of course
column2: because Twitter is awful
column3: it only hides some of the Nazis
column4: but it’s better than nothing. Here’s a comparison of the top profile results for “National Socialism” before and after I changed my settings:

column1: Barack Obama: Still not a Nazi.
Advertisement
If you try to view a flagged account
column2: you get this:

column1: Advertisement
The filter also applies to specific flagged tweets. Here’s conservative Christian author and convicted felon Dinesh D’Souza lying about the Holocaust
column2: before and after:

column1: Advertisement
Your trending topics and language preference stay the same. So does the location displayed on your profile page. We’ve noticed one bonus: The Moments tab disappears.
As user CanolaYogurt points out
column2: Twitter saves the setting in your browser
column3: not your account. So you can log into other accounts and you’ll still get German filtering. But you’ll need to re-apply the setting in every different browser or computer you use.

column1: 12. AFTERMATH
As the Allies swept through Europe to victory over the Nazi regime in early 1945
column2: hundreds of thousands of concentration camp prisoners were liberated. The Allied Military Government of Germany repealed countless laws and decrees. Left unchanged
column3: however
column4: was the 1935 Nazi revision of Paragraph 175. Under the Allied occupation
column5: some homosexuals were forced to serve out their terms of imprisonment regardless of time served in the concentration camps. The Nazi version of Paragraph 175 remained on the books of the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany) until the law was revised in 1969 to decriminalize homosexual relations between men over the age of 21.

column1: The continued legal and social prohibitions against homosexuality in Germany hindered acknowledgement that homosexuals were victims of Nazi persecution. In June 1956
column2: West Germany's Federal Reparation Law for Victims of National Socialism declared that internment in a concentration camp for homosexuality did not qualify an individual to receive compensation. Homosexuals murdered by the Nazis received their first public commemoration in a May 8
column4: speech by West German President Richard von Weizsäckerthe fortieth anniversary of the war's end. Four years after reunification in 1990
column6: the German parliament completed legislation to pardon all homosexuals convicted under Paragraph 175 during the Nazi era.

column1: Since 1984
column2: memorials to homosexual victims of the Nazi regime have appeared in various cities and memorial sites at former concentration camps
column3: including: ""Homomonument
column13: 1994; and on the bank of the Rhine River at the WallrafRichartsMuseum

column4: 'https://www.insidescience.org/news/my-1975-cooling-world-story-doesnt-make-todays-climate-scientists-wrong']	https://www.insidescience.org/news/my-1975-cooling-world-story-doesnt-make-todays-climate-scientists-wrong	https://www.insidescience.org/	"My 1975 'Cooling World' Story Doesn't Make Today's Climate Scientists Wrong

column1: It's time for deniers of human-caused global warming to stop using an old magazine story against climate scientists.
Peter Gwynne
column2: Contributor

column1: Inside Science Minds presents an ongoing series of guest columnists and personal perspectives presented by scientists
column2: engineers
column3: mathematicians
column4: and others in the science community showcasing some of the most interesting ideas in science today. The opinions contained in this piece are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Inside Science nor the American Institute of Physics and its Member Societies.

column1: (Inside Science) -- ""The central fact is that
column2: after three quarters of a century of extraordinarily mild conditions
column3: the Earth seems to be cooling down. Meteorologists disagree about the cause and extent of the cooling trend
column4: as well as over its specific impact on local weather conditions. But they are almost unanimous in the view that the trend will reduce agricultural productivity for the rest of the century."" – Newsweek: April 28

column1: That's an excerpt from a story I wrote about climate science that appeared almost 40 years ago. Titled ""The Cooling World
column2: it was remarkably popular; in fact it might be the only decades-old magazine story about science ever carried onto the set of a late-night TV talk show. Now
column3: as the author of that story
column5: let me say this: while the hypotheses described in that original story seemed right at the time
column6: climate scientists now know that they were seriously incomplete. Our climate is warming -- not cooling

column1: Nevertheless
column2: certain websites and individuals that dispute
column3: disparage and deny the science that shows that humans are causing the Earth to warm continue to quote my article. Their message: how can we believe climatologists who tell us that the Earth's atmosphere is warming when their colleagues asserted that it's actually cooling?

column1: Well
column2: yes
column3: we should trust them
column4: despite the views of detractors such as comedian Dennis Miller
column5: who brought my story to The Tonight Show in 2006. Several atmospheric scientists did indeed believe in global cooling
column6: as I reported in the April 28
column7: 1975 issue of Newsweek. But that was then.

column1: [Photo removed May 2
In the 39 years since
column2: biotechnology has flowered from a promising academic topic to a major global industry
column3: the first test-tube baby has been born and become a mother herself
column4: cosmologists have learned that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate rather than slowing down
column5: and particle physicists have detected the Higgs boson
column6: an entity once regarded as only a theoretical concept. Seven presidents have served most of 11 terms. And Newsweek has become a shadow of its former self.

column1: And on the climate front? The vast majority of climatologists now assure us that Earth's atmosphere is not cooling. Rather it's warming up. And the main responsibility for the phenomenon lies with human activity.
There's no serious dispute any more about whether the globe is warming
column2: whether humans are responsible
column3: and whether we will see large and dangerous changes in the future – in the words of the National Academy of Sciences – which we didn't know in the 1970s
column5: a climatologist at Pennsylvania State University in University Park. He added that nearly every U.S. scientific society has assessed the evidence and come to the same conclusion.

column1: The recent National Climate Assessment takes an equally emphatic view.
What is new over the last decade is that we know with increasing certainty that climate change is happening now
column2: it states. ""While scientists continue to refine projections of the future
column3: observations unequivocally show that climate is changing and that the warming of the past 50 years is primarily due to human-induced emissions of heat-trapping gases.""

column1: I'm sure it's clear by now that I accept the views of the National Academy
column2: National Climate Assessment
column3: Mann
column4: and the huge majority of his fellow climatologists. Nevertheless
column5: websites devoted to denying the existence of human-caused climate change – or at least promoting the idea that nothing should be done about it – continue to use my article to validate their thinking. In fact the article has reportedly become the most-cited article in Newsweek's history.

column1: Those that reject climate science ignore the fact that
column2: like other fields
column3: climatology has evolved since 1975. The certainty that our atmosphere is indeed warming stems from a series of rigorous observations and theoretical concepts that fit into computer models and an overall framework outlining the nature of Earth's climate.

column1: These capabilities were primitive or non-existent in 1975. In fact my report reflected a real strand of climatological thinking back then. I was far from the only science writer to cover the possibility of global cooling. Time
column2: Science News
column3: and the New York Times
column6: because some climate scientists had genuine reasons to believe that the global climate might be cooling and had published scholarly papers on the matter.

column1: Speaking personally
column2: though
column3: I accept that I didn't tell the full story back then. Indeed
column4: the issue raises questions about the relationship between science writers and scientists as well as the attitudes toward science of individuals with political agendas.

column1: Three independent strands of science at the time got conflated in the articles: analyses of direct temperature data that showed a decline in temperatures particularly over the Northern Hemisphere since the 1940s; a very high level of pollution by sulfate aerosols that cooled the planet; and evidence that the timing of ice ages was caused by wobbles in Earth's orbit
column2: explained Gavin Schmidt
column3: deputy chief of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies
column6: ""some parts of the article are OK even today.""

column1: At the same time
column2: however
column3: evidence had emerged of increases in the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide
column4: a gas known to warm the atmosphere.

column1: The science was sort of speculative [in 1975]
column2: Mann recalled. ""A National Academy of Sciences report concluded there wasn't enough information at that particular time because we had two competing forces – aerosols and greenhouse gases. It wasn't entirely clear which would win out.""

column1: Ironically
column2: efforts to clean up the atmosphere made it possible to resolve the scientific mystery and convince climatologists that human activity is warming the planet. Policy actions such as the Clean Air Act of 1970 in the United States and similar initiatives in other countries aimed to reduce the amount of sulfate aerosols in the atmosphere. Since those compounds primarily reflect heat
column3: their reduction effectively gave carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases more control over the Earth's temperature.

column1: NASA scientist James Hansen was the first to sound the alarm. In 1988
column2: he pointed out that a sort of Faustian bargain had cleaned up the atmosphere but at the cost of worsening the greenhouse problem.

column1: (Click image to enlarge)
Hansen and other climatologists began to develop models of the climate which showed the influence of human activity
column2: via the burning of fossil fuels
column3: on global temperatures.

column1: Observations and analyses since then have confirmed and strengthened the models and the broad understanding of climate change
column2: along with the portion that's due to human activity. Richard Somerville
column3: a climate scientist at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography and the University of California
column5: summarized the findings in an email. ""There are many lines of observational evidence that the world is warming
column6: including globally rising air and ocean temperatures
column10: and mass loss on the ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica
column12: an entire new body of climate science called 'detection and attribution' convincingly shows that the observed climate changes have distinctive space-time patterns that are consistent with causes due to human activities."" The counterattack had started by the beginning of the 1990s. The purported evidence against global warming included the news articles on cooling by myself and others.

column1: Some commentators
column2: such as Dixy Lee Ray
column3: former chair of the Atomic Energy Commission
column4: asserted that the articles represented climate scares that inevitably turned out to be untrue – as would the idea of global warming

column1: Others took a less subtle route. The articles proved
column2: they argued
column3: that the atmosphere was cooling and that there was no reason to change that conclusion. In that view

column1: However
column2: both types of warming deniers
column3: along with policymakers who have consistently opposed any regulation designed to reduce acid rain
column4: the destruction of the ozone layer
column6: have consistently used the articles – particularly mine – as ammunition.

column1: But that's just one line of attack. Mann suffered another starting in 1998
column2: after he published an article in the journal Nature; that included a ""hockey stick"" model that demonstrated a dramatic increase in the rate of recent global warming.

column1: I was at the receiving end of the attacks from many of the same individuals
column2: think tanks
column3: and organizations implicated in past attacks on other climate scientists
column5: he wrote in an email. ""The attacks on climate science and on me specifically have escalated for a simple reason: As the scientific evidence becomes clearer and the threat becomes clearer
column6: it takes yet more disinformation and propaganda to obscure the truth. Hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent by fossil fuel interests seeking to muddy the waters. That has
column8: provided cover for politicians doing their bidding in opposing any attempts to regulate carbon emissions.""

column1: Opponents of Mann and his fellow climatologists also seek to highlight areas of disagreements among climatologists. Certainly those disagreements exist. But they don't affect the reality that human activity is the primary trigger of warming in recent decades.
Icemelt.jpg Muir Glacier
column2: Alaska. Left: August 13
column3: 1941. Right: August 31
column4: 2004. 1941 photo taken by Ulysses William O. Field; 2004 photo taken by Bruce F. Molnia. Courtesy of the Glacier Photograph Collection
column5: National Snow and Ice Data Center/World Data Center for Glaciology.

column1: Take
column2: for example
column3: research on the relationship between climate change and extreme weather.

column1: It is a very nuanced subject
column2: and a legitimate controversy
column3: Mann said in an interview. ""There really are different schools of thought
column4: each of which are credible and making arguments in good faith. Jennifer Francis at Rutgers argues that there is a connection with loss of sea ice
column5: and others are skeptical."" Schmidt agrees.

column1: It is a genuine debate
column2: he said. ""Scientists don't just sit around congratulating ourselves on what we've done. We look for things at the cutting edge between known and unknown. It's a complex terrain and that's what makes it interesting.""

column1: Certainly
column2: the disputes have become more nuanced. But their existence provides opponents of scientific findings that they find unpopular with opportunities to muddle the facts.

column1: The American political system has always had a rather odd connection to the role of expertise
column2: Schmidt added. ""There's a clear strand in American discourse that is anti-intellectual and anti-expertise.""

column1: While the affair reveals much about the relationship between politics and science
column2: it also casts a shadow on science writing.

column1: There's too much handwaving in science journalism
column2: Schmidt noted. ""Scientists don't spend a lot of time when talking to journalists about what their research doesn't mean. One of the fault lines between science and journalism is how you pull together the bigger picture. So a reticence on the part of scientists to fill in the big picture
column3: and over-enthusiasm on the part of journalists to say what does it all mean
column4: means that the journalists don't get it quite right.""

column1: Here I must admit mea culpa. In retrospect
column2: I was over-enthusiastic in parts of my Newsweek article. Thus
column3: I suggested a connection between the purported global cooling and increases in tornado activity that was unjustified by climate science. I also predicted a forthcoming impact of global cooling on the world's food production that had scant research to back it.

column1: The messages for science writers are to ask questions beyond the obvious and to seek out what the science doesn't imply as well as what it does. If I had applied those lessons back in 1975
column2: I might not now be in the embarrassing position of being a cat's paw for denial of climate change.

column1: Over my career I've covered subjects as diverse as cell biology
column2: the world of physics a century after Einstein's birth
column3: space commerce
column4: and World Cup soccer. I've won prizes for my writing
column5: including a lifetime award from the American Chemical Society. But I fear that my obituary will be dominated by that single article in Newsweek."	My 1975 'Cooling World' Story Doesn't Make Today's Climate Scientists Wrong	2014-05-21 11:35:08-04:00	['Peter Gwynne']	['cooling'

column1: Yes You Can!
In the spring of 1977
column2: Rick Hoyt told his father
column3: Dick Hoyt
column4: that he wanted to participate in a 5-mile benefit run for a lacrosse player who had been paralyzed in an accident. Far from being a long-distance runner
column5: Dick agreed to push Rick in his wheelchair and they finished all 5 miles

​Four Multi-sport Legends Inducted into USA Triathlon Hall of Fame
TEMPE
column2: Ariz. — USA Triathlon and the multi-sport community celebrated the achievements of four triathlon legends Friday night
column3: as Cherie Gruenfeld
column4: Richard Eugene “Dick” Hoyt and Richard Eugene “Rick” Hoyt
column6: and Mike Plant (posthumous) were inducted into the USA Triathlon Hall of Fame. The gala and ceremony
column8: were held in Tempe in conjunction with the inaugural Endurance Exchange conference hosted by USA Triathlon and Triathlon Business International this week.

column1: USA Triathlon Hall of Fame member and longtime Boston Marathon race director Dave McGillvray introduced the Hoyts
column2: telling the story of how he met the famous push-assist team at the Boston Marathon — the iconic race the duo would go on to run 37 times.

column1: “I looked upon them with bewilderment. What is this? Someone is actually pushing another person in a wheelchair? I’d never seen that before. I waited for them at the finish line as I just had to find out who they were and what this was all about. That began a 40-year relationship and friendship between us
column2: ” McGillivray said. “I asked Dick if he wanted to do my Bay State Triathlon. He said
column3: ‘Not without Rick.’ I thought
column4: ‘how is he going to do this?’ As we all know
column5: the rest is history. They did it and never looked back.”

column1: “Team Hoyt” became the first duo ever to complete the IRONMAN World Championship in Kailua-Kona
column2: Hawaii
column4: and repeated the feat in 1999. Over three decades
column5: they have paved the way for the countless push-assist teams around the world who participate in endurance sports today.

column5: who spoke on behalf of himself and his son

column1: Weekly Would News knew that these allegations could only be just the tip of the iceberg so we sent our crack team of reporters to the streets to find out what else could be behind these allegations.

It did not take long for our team to discover that the meat that Taco Bell uses for its beef based products is imported from China. This set off a myriad of bells and whistles on our end so we asked our Japanese WWN affiliates to check out the Kuang Ren factory in the Zhejiang province where the beef is packaged. Within hours our Japanese colleagues were back in touch with a shocking discovery
column2: the so called beef is actually cat and dog meat.

column1: Upon the discovery of the news
column2: we immediately did the right thing and informed the FDA. The FDA has since mandated that all Taco Bells must be closed forever. So go get as many doggy burritos and kitty fajitas as you can before they are gone for good."	TACO BELL MEAT	2011-01-26 10:12:38+00:00	['Pierce Blodyn']	['beef'

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/hindu-goddess-kali-empire-state-building/	an image of the hindu goddess kali was projected onto the empire state building.	true	['empire state building'

column10: Ma Kali took New York on Saturday

column1: Just as this Venus Retrograde began to take us all deeper into the darkness of the underworld
column2: the Divine Feminine Maha Shakti
column3: goddess of spiritual death
column5: rode the zeitgeist straight onto the face of the Empire State Building and into the heart of collective consciousness.

column1: This Kali apparition over Manhattan may be our last warning. Fierce protectress of truth
column2: she tells it like it is
column3: she beckons us to dive into the dark
column4: to face the stark reality of the global ecological crisis upon us
column5: and to let heartbreak be the ground from which we awaken and serve.

column1: Perhaps it is even too late now
column2: perhaps only calamity can make us silence the ego and hear the cries of the World Soul
column3: perhaps destruction must be our baptism into change
column4: but this is the time and we are the ones summoned to be the shamans of the Shift.

column1: Never underestimate the power of holy darkness to reveal the Soul of all matters. The dark is where illusions are shattered
column2: where false certainties are broken; the dark is where the mind is cut off so that only the heart can see… It is time to let holy darkness be our medicine. The world as we know it must change or perish.

column1: In an unprecedented and awe-inspiring public display of art by filmmaker Louie Psihoyos and his team
column2: Projecting Change
column3: projected onto the NYC skyline by Obscura Digital
column4: was meant to spark awareness of massive wildlife extinction
column5: and be a chilling call to conservation turning the Empire State Building
column6: New York’s brightest and most recognizable symbol and capitalism’s earliest totem
column8: as well as its most epic tombstone and oracle of the Dark Feminine.

column1: From the colossal projection of Cecil the Lion
column2: whose recent tragic death provoked a mass outpouring of love and outrage
column3: to the images of hundreds of nameless endangered animals
column7: creeping and crawling and running for their lives across the Empire State Building

column1: “If you are not heartbroken
column2: you are not paying attention!” this project seems to scream from its illustrious rooftop. For as the parade of near-extinct animals appear on the screen
column3: it is impossible not to face the crushing realization that it is not a question of if hundreds of species will continue to go extinct
column4: but when… Our shiny unsustainable systems based on glamour and greed have taken us to a world on the edge of collapse — only holy darkness can save us now.

column1: And it was Kali
column2: the dark mother
column3: the destroyer of illusions and the personification of time
column6: that stole the show in New York

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/incredibles-2-epilepsy-warning/	"the animated film ""incredibles 2"" contains scenes that prompted an epilepsy warning at movie theaters."	true	['epilepsy'
column2: 'health warnings'
column3: 'incredibles 2'
column7: my family and I saw Disney/Pixar’s Incredibles 2
column8: a movie we had all been looking forward to seeing for months. We were excited to see the characters again and wondered how the sequel would compare to the original film
column9: which was shown shortly before in a double feature. After last night
column10: I can say that the movie is unlike anything I have ever seen before
column11: in that the villain’s weapon of choice can hurt not only characters on-screen
column12: but can also hurt the people in the audience as well. The weapon? Continuous sequences of rapidly flashing/strobing lights.

column1: Scene description (NO SPOILERS)
There are at least five scenes throughout the movie
column2: all of which feature the villain
column3: that use bright white flashing/strobe lights for more than fifteen seconds
column4: with at least one scene going over 90 seconds in continuous strobing lights. These lights stay at their rapidly flashing speed in the entirety of these scenes
column5: which are scattered throughout the movie. My brother estimated the light flashes being as fast as 3 flashes per second.

column1: Why is this an issue?
Many different populations can be sensitive to flashing and strobing lights
column2: not just people with photosensitive epilepsy. Here is a small sampling of conditions that can be affected:

column1: Migraines
Vision impairment
Seizure conditions
Vertigo (specifically flicker vertigo)
Autism
ADHD
PTSD
Even people who do not have these conditions or have a history of them can still have an adverse reaction to strobe lights. This risk is increased for children and young adults.
Signs of adverse strobe reactions
Some common signs of adverse strobe reactions include:
Seizure
Blank staring
Fumbling
Chewing
Wandering
Shaking
Garbled speech
Muscle twitching
Loss of consciousness
Migraine
Large amount of pain centralized in head
Light sensitivity
Temporary visual auras (blindness
column2: double vision
column3: floaters)

column1: Nausea/vomiting
This post is not a replacement for medical advice. If you begin experiencing any of these symptoms please seek appropriate medical attention.
How descriptive audio helped
Since I am visually impaired
column2: I use descriptive audio devices provided by my theater to get descriptions of visual information on screen. One of the hidden benefits is that I had a warning about scenes involving strobe lights ahead of time
column3: so I could close my eyes and avoid them. While the descriptive audio did not warn me about all of the flashing lights used in the film
column4: I know that had I not had descriptive audio
column5: I would have had to leave the movie early.

column1: Related links
Isn’t there a flashing light warning in place?
As of publishing time
column2: there is no warning in place about the intense flashing/strobing light effects in Incredibles 2. There are warnings attached to many other media types when strobe and flashing lights are present for long periods of time
column3: such as video games
column6: and even certain theme park attractions
column7: but there are typically no formal or informal warnings in place for movies
column8: and none for Incredibles 2. In addition
column9: I do not know of any apps that provide information about flashing lights in movies.

column1: What can be done about this?
I am not asking for Disney and/or Pixar to remove the movie from theaters
column2: nor am I asking them to change the movie to get rid of the strobing lights (though they certainly can if they want to!). I would like for these companies as well as movie theaters to issue a warning to guests purchasing tickets that this movie has a significant amount of strobing lights that can cause adverse health effects
column3: especially in young children. Families have the right to be able to make informed decisions about movies and to determine if this is safe for their children to watch.

column1: Update June 19
After this post went viral
column2: Disney/Pixar sent a notice to theaters asking them to put up a sign warning guests about the flashing light scenes! Thank you Disney for listening to the needs of your customers!

column1: Should I see Incredibles 2?
This post is not a call to boycott Incredibles 2
column2: or any other Disney/Pixar movies. Despite the large amount of strobe lights
column3: my family and I really enjoyed watching Incredibles 2. We thought that the script was brilliant
column4: with the movie being very well done. If it wasn’t for the large amount of strobes
column5: we would give it a 10/10. However
column6: due to the amount of flashing/strobe lights
column7: I recommend carefully considering whether to watch this movie or not
column8: especially if you have young children.

column7: and my immediate thought was how disasterously unsafe this movie is for my photosensitive epilepic friends. @markingatlightspeed I’m tagging you with this specifically because I feel that this would be extremely dangerous for you to watch.

column1: There are multiple scenes in this movie with full-screen
column2: black-and-white flashing strobe effects. They all happen without warning
column3: and last anywhere between a few seconds to more than two minutes. In a darkened movie theater
column4: this means the likelihood of a seizure could be VERY HIGH if you are sensitive to these effects.

column1: If you have photosensitive epilepsy or another disorder that is triggered by strobe lights
column2: I would highly recommend you DO NOT SEE THE INCREDIBLES 2 IN THEATERS. Wait until the movie’s released on digital/Bluray
column3: and you can watch it in a fully-lit room
column4: with someone with you who will be able to help if the strobe effects do trigger a seizure.

column1: Please stay safe.
UPDATE: After talking to some people who have loved ones with severe epilepsy
column2: I would sadly have to recommend that you DO NOT SEE THIS MOVIE - PERIOD - IF YOU HAVE SEVERE SEIZURES WHEN EXPOSED TO STROBE EFFECTS. DO NOT PUT YOUR HEALTH AT RISK FOR A MOVIE. NO KIND OF MEDIA IS WORTH GAMBLING WITH YOUR LIFE.

column1: The scenes in which the flashing happens are MAJOR plot points and CANNOT be skipped. The one workaround I can suggest would be to find a version of the movie (when it’s released) with Audio Descriptions for the visually impaired. Watch it on your PC - turn the monitor OFF
column2: but keep the audio going.

column1: If you have been disappointed by the creative decisions made by Disney-Pixar
column2: please sign the petition created by @moviehealthcommunity for Disney to include a seizure warning for moviegoers and people who buy/rent the movie. It is unlikely they would edit these things out of the movie entirely - but there are nearly 20
column3: 000 notes on this post
column5: 000 people asked them to consider people with epilepsy
column6: it could mean they consider these things more carefully in the future.

column1: Over the past several months

column4: civil court cases and criminal records of members of the United States Congress. We have talked with former associates and business partners who have been left out in the cold by people they thought were friends.

column1: What emerges from this examination is a disturbing portrait of a group of elected officials who routinely avoid payment of debts
column2: write bad checks
column3: abuse their spouses
column4: assault people and openly violate the law.

column3: have driven creditors into bankruptcy because of unpaid debts left over from aborted Presidential campaigns. Even millionaire Senator Ted Kennedy has left a trail of unpaid debts from past campaigns.

column3: fraud and other charges. Our research found 117 members of the House and Senate who have run at least two businesses each that went bankrupt

column1: In that brave new world which science is preparing for the housewife of the future
column2: the young mother has apparently been forgotten. Almost nothing has been done to ease her lot by simplifying and improving the care of babies.

column1: When we decided to have another child
column2: my wife and I felt that it was time to apply a little labor-saving invention and design to the problems of the nursery. We began by going over the disheartening schedule of the young mother
column3: step by step. We asked only one question: Is this practice important for the physical and psychological health of the baby? When it was not
column4: we marked it for elimination. Then the “gadgeteering” began.

column1: The result was an inexpensive apparatus in which our baby daughter has now been living for eleven months. Her remarkable good health and happiness and my wife’s welcome leisure have exceeded our most optimistic predictions
column2: and we are convinced that a new deal for both mother and baby is at hand.

column2: nightdress
column3: sheet
column4: and blankets. This is never completely successful. The baby is likely to be found steaming in its own fluids or lying cold and uncovered. Schemes to prevent uncovering may be dangerous
column5: and in fact they have sometimes even proved fatal. Clothing and bedding also interfere with normal exercise and growth and keep the baby from taking comfortable postures or changing posture during sleep. They also encourage rashes and sores. Nothing can be said for the system on the score of convenience
column6: because frequent changes and launderings are necessary.

column1: Why not
column2: we thought
column3: dispense with clothing altogether-except for the diaper
column4: which serves another purpose-and warm the space in which the baby lives? This should be a simple technical problem in the modern home. Our solution is a closed compartment about as spacious as a standard crib (Figure 1). The walls are well insulated
column6: which can be raised like a window
column7: is a large pane of safety glass. The heating is electrical
column8: and special precautions have been taken to insure accurate control.

column1: After a little experimentation we found that our baby
column2: when first home from the hospital
column3: was completely comfortable and relaxed without benefit of clothing at about 86 ° F. As she grew older
column4: it was possible to lower the temperature by easy stages. Now
column7: with a relative humidity of 50 per cent.

column1: Raising or lowering the temperature by more than a degree or two produces a surprising change in the baby’s condition and behavior. This response is so sensitive that we wonder how a comfortable temperature is ever reached with clothing and blankets.
The discovery
column2: which pleased us most
column3: was that crying and fussing could always be stopped by slightly lowering the temperature. During the first three months
column5: the baby would also cry when wet or hungry
column6: but in that case she would stop when changed or fed. During the past six months she has not cried at all except for a moment or tow when injured or sharply distressed-for example
column7: when inoculated. The “lung exercise” which so often is appealed to reassure the mother of a baby who cries a good deal takes the much pleasanter form of shouts and gurgles.

column1: How much of this sustained cheerfulness is due to the temperature is hard to say
column2: because the baby enjoys many other kinds of comfort. She sleeps in curious postures
column3: not half of which would be possible under securely fastened blankets.

column1: When awake
column2: she exercises almost constantly and often with surprising violence. Her leg
column3: stomach
column4: and back muscles are especially active and have become strong and hard. It is necessary to watch this performance for only a few minutes to realize how severely restrained the average baby is
column5: and how much energy must be diverted into the only remaining channel crying.

column1: A wider range and variety of behavior are also encouraged by the freedom from clothing. For example
column2: our baby acquitted an amusing
column3: almost apelike skill in the use of her feet. We have devised a number of toys
column4: which are occasionally suspended from the ceiling of the compartment. She often plays with these with her feet alone and with her hands and feet in close cooperation.

column1: One toy is a ring suspended from a modified music box. A note can be played by pulling the ring downward
column2: and a series of rapid jerks will produce Three Blind Mice. At seven months our baby would grasp the ring in her toes
column3: stretch out her leg and play the tune with a rhythmic movement of her foot.

column1: We are not especially interested in developing skills of this sort
column2: but they are valuable for the baby because they arouse and hold her interest. Many babies seem to cry from sheer boredom-their behavior is restrained and they have nothing else to do. In our compartment
column3: the waking hours are invariably active and happy ones.

column1: Freedom from clothes and bedding is especially important for the older baby who plays and falls asleep off and on during the day. Unless the mother is constantly on the alert
column2: it is hard to cover the baby promptly when it falls asleep and to remove and arrange sheets and blankets as soon as it is ready to play. All this is now unnecessary.

column1: Remember that these advantages for the baby do not mean additional labor or attention on the part of the mother. On the contrary
column2: there is an almost unbelievable saving in time and effort. For one thing
column3: there is no bed to be made or changed. The “mattress” is a tightly stretched canvas
column4: which is kept dry by warm air. A single bottom sheet operates like a roller towel.1 It is stored on a spool outside the compartment at one end and passes into a wire hamper at the other. It is ten yards long and lasts a week. A clean section can be locked into place in a few seconds. The time which is usually spent in changing clothes is also saved. This is especially important in the early months. When we take the baby up for feeding or play
column5: she is wrapped in a small blanket or a simple nightdress. Occasionally she is dressed up “for fun” or for her play period. But that is all. The wrapping blanket
column7: and the usual diapers are the only laundry actually required.

column1: Time and labor are also saved because the air which passes through the compartment is thoroughly filtered. The baby’s eyes
column2: ears
column3: and nostrils remain fresh and clean. A weekly bath is enough
column4: provided the face and diaper region are frequently washed. These little attentions are easy because the compartment is at waist level.

column1: 1The canvas and “endless” sheet arrangement was soon replaced with a single layer of woven plastic
column2: which would be cleaned and instantly wiped dry.

column1: It takes about one and one-half hours each day to feed
column2: change
column3: and otherwise care for the baby. This includes everything except washing diapers and preparing formula. We are not interested in reducing the time any further. As a baby grows older
column4: it needs a certain amount of social stimulation. And after all
column5: when unnecessary chores have been eliminated
column6: taking care of a baby is fun.

column1: An unforeseen dividend has been the contribution to the baby’s good health. Our pediatrician readily approved the plan before the baby was born
column2: and he has followed the results enthusiastically from month to month. Here are some points on the health score: When the baby was only ten days old
column3: we could place her in the preferred face-down position without danger of smothering
column4: and she has slept that way ever since
column5: with the usual advantages. She has always enjoyed deep and extended sleep
column6: and her feeding and eliminative habits have been extraordinarily regular. She has never had a stomach upset
column7: and she has never missed a daily bowel movement.

column1: The compartment is relatively free of spray and air-borne infection
column2: as well as dust and allergic substances. Although there have been colds in the family
column3: it has been easy to avoid contagion
column4: and the baby has completely escaped. The neighborhood children troop in to see her
column5: but they see her through glass and keep their school-age diseases to themselves. She has never had a diaper rash.

column1: We have also enjoyed the advantages of a fixed daily routine. Child specialists are still not agreed as to whether the mother should watch the baby or the clock
column2: but no one denies that a strict schedule saves time
column3: for the mother can plan her day in advance and find time for relaxation or freedom for other activities. The trouble is that a routine acceptable to the baby often conflicts with the schedule of the household. Our compartment helps out here in two ways. Even in crowded living quarters it can be kept free of unwanted lights and sounds. The insulated walls muffle all ordinary noises
column4: and a curtain can be drawn down over the window. The result is that
column5: in the space taken by a standard crib
column6: the baby has in effect a separate room. We are never concerned lest the doorbell
column9: or children at play wake the baby
column10: and we can therefore let her set up any routine she likes.

column1: But a more interesting possibility is that her routine may be changed to suit our convenience. A good example of this occurred when we dropped her schedule from four to three meals per day. The baby began to wake up in the morning about an hour before we wanted to feed her. This annoying habit
column2: once established
column3: may persist for months. However
column4: by slightly raising the temperature during the night we were able to postpone her demand for breakfast. The explanation is simple. The evening meal is used by the baby mainly to keep herself warm during the night. How long it lasts will depend in part upon how fast heat is absorbed by the surrounding air.

column1: One advantage not to be overlooked is that the soundproofing also protects the family from the baby! Our intentions in this direction were misunderstood by some of our friends. We were never put to the test
column2: because there was no crying to contend with
column3: but it was never our policy to use the compartment in order to let the baby “cry it out.”

column1: Every effort should be made to discover just why a baby cries. But if the condition cannot be remedied
column2: there is no reason why the family
column3: and perhaps the neighborhood as well
column6: might persuade many a landlord to drop a “no babies” rule
column7: since other tenants can be completely protected.)

column1: Before the baby was born
column2: when we were still building the apparatus
column3: some of the friends and acquaintances who had heard about what we proposed to do were rather shocked. Mechanical dish-washers
column6: and other laborsaving devices were all very fine
column7: but a mechanical baby tender - that was carrying science too far! However
column9: which were raised against the plan
column10: have faded way in the bright light of our results. A very brief acquaintance with the scheme in operation is enough to resolve all doubts. Some of the toughest skeptics have become our most enthusiastic supporters.

column1: One of the commonest objections was that we were gong to raise a ""softie” who would be unprepared for the real world. But instead of becoming hypersensitive
column2: our baby has acquired a surprisingly serene tolerance for annoyances. She is not bothered by the clothes she wears at playtime
column3: she is not frightened by loud or sudden noises
column4: she is not frustrated by toys out of reach
column5: and she takes a lot of pummeling from her older sister like a good sport. It is possible that she will have to learn to sleep in a noisy room
column6: but adjustments of that sort are always necessary. A tolerance for any annoyance can be built up by administering it in controlled dosages
column7: rather than in the usual accidental way. Certainly there is no reason to annoy the child throughout the whole of its infancy
column8: merely to prepare it for later childhood.

column1: It is not
column2: of course
column3: the favorable conditions to which people object
column4: but the fact that in our compartment they are “artificial.” All of them occur naturally in one favorable environment or another
column5: where the same objection should apply but is never raised. It is quite in the spirit of the “world of the future” to make favorable conditions available everywhere through simple mechanical means.

column1: A few critics have objected that they would not like to live in such a compartment themselves-they feel that it would stifle them or give them claustrophobia. The baby obviously does not share in this opinion. The compartment is well ventilated and much more spacious than a Pullman berth
column2: considering the size of the occupant. The baby cannot get out
column3: of course
column4: but that is true of a crib as well. There is less actual restraint in the compartment because the baby is freer to move about. The plain fact is that she is perfectly happy. She has never tried to get out nor resisted being put back in
column5: and that seems to be the final test.

column1: Another early objection was that the baby would be socially starved and robbed of the affection and mother love
column2: which she needs. This has simply not been true. The compartment does not ostracize the baby. The large window is no more of a social barrier than the bars of a crib. The baby follows what is going on in the room
column3: smiles at passers-by
column5: and obviously delights in company. And she is handled
column7: and played with whenever she is changed or fed
column8: and each afternoon during a play period
column9: which is becoming longer as she grows older.

column1: The fact is that a baby will probably get more love and affection when it is easily cared for
column2: because the mother is likely to feel overworked and resentful of the demands made upon her. She will express her love in a practical way and give the baby genuinely affectionate care.

column1: It is common practice to advise the troubled mother to be patient and tender and to enjoy her baby. And
column2: of course
column3: that is what any baby needs. But is is the exceptional mother who can fill this prescription upon demand
column4: especially if there are other children in the family and she has no help. We need to go one step further and teat the mother with affection also. Simplified childcare will give mother love a chance.

column1: A similar complaint was that such an apparatus would encourage neglect. But easier care is sure to be better care. The mother will resist the temptation to put the baby back into a damp bed if she can conjure up a dry one in five seconds. She may very well spend less time with her baby
column2: but babies do not suffer from being left alone but only from the discomforts
column3: which arise from being
column4: left alone in the ordinary crib.

column1: How long do we intend to keep the baby in the compartment? The baby will answer that in time
column2: but almost certainly until she is two years old
column3: or perhaps three. After the first year of course
column4: she will spend a fair part of each day in a playpen or out of doors. The compartment takes the place of a crib and will get about the same use. Eventually it will serve as sleeping quarters only.

column8: known as the “Right to Try Act
column9: ” will prohibit the FDA from banning natural cures
column10: and allow patients to try medications that have not been approved by the FDA
column11: but are currently under clinical trial.

column1: Right to Try was passed unanimously by the Senate last summer and by the House of Representatives on Tuesday in a vote of 250 to 169
column2: after Trump personally lobbied for its passage. While the bill’s provisions are targeted at a wide range of medications
column3: they also apply to medical marijuana thanks to a clinical trial being conducted by the Multidisciplinary Association of Psychedelic Sciences (MAPS).

column1: Big legislation will be signed by me shortly. After many years
column2: RIGHT TO TRY and big changes to DODD FRANK. — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) May 23

column1: Herb reports : The MAPS trial
column2: currently in the second phase of the FDA approval process
column3: is testing the effectiveness of smoked cannabis in veterans with PTSD and meets all of the criteria set out by the Right to Try.

column1: The majority of states already have their own form of Right to Try legislation
column2: with one notable exception being New York. In Utah
column3: a recently passed law specifically addresses the right of terminally ill patients to try cannabis. However
column5: even if a terminally ill patient has the “Right to Try” cannabis on the state level
column6: they’re still in violation of federal law.

column1: The Right to Try bill
column2: recently passed by Congress
column3: would change that. In addition to cannabis
column4: MDMA and psilocybin could also potentially be used by ‘eligible patients’ since FDA trials of both substances meet the requirements set out in the federal bill.

column1: What’s not clear is what illnesses qualify as life-threatening. Post-traumatic stress disorder
column2: for example
column3: could be argued to be life-threatening given the high rates of suicide among those who are diagnosed
column4: but it’s up for debate. It’s likely that those details will be hammered out on a state by state basis in jurisdictions that have already passed their own version of Right to Try. The full title of the bill suggests as much stating

column1: However
column2: in states that lack their own local provisions
column3: the new bill appears to leave plenty of room for interpretation and a potential conflict with local drug laws.

column1: Under the broad wording of the federal bill
column2: no specific illnesses are mentioned. Instead
column3: an ‘eligible patient’ is defined as
column4: “Diseases or conditions where the likelihood of death is high unless the course of the disease is interrupted; and Diseases or conditions with potentially fatal outcomes
column5: where the endpoint of clinical trial analysis is survival.”

column1: Patients must also have exhausted all existing treatment options and must be unable to participate in the ongoing trials investigating the drug they want access to. Additionally
column2: they must provide written consent from a qualified physician who does not stand to gain from the trial.

column1: The bill passed on Tuesday after receiving some opposition from Democrats on Capitol Hill who believe that the law will undermine the FDA’s processes.
It’s likely that President Trump will sign the bill in the coming days since he has personally lobbied Congress for its passage. In January
column2: Trump even mentioned the bill in his State of the Union Address saying
column3: “People who are terminally ill should not have to go from country to country to seek a cure. I want to give them a chance right here at home. It is time for the Congress to give these wonderful
column4: incredible Americans the right to try.”

column1: Early Wednesday morning
column2: Trump reiterated his support for the bill tweeting his intention to sign it into law.

column1: A mother-of-three has spoken of her terror after she almost lost her legs to a deadly infection which she caught from shaving her bikini line.
Dana Sedgewick
column3: from Sheffield
column4: trimmed her pubic area with a brand new razor but ended up cutting a spot on her groin.

column1: Her body almost immediately went into shock
column2: causing a red rash on her legs before they turned black from necrotising fasciitis - a flesh-eating infection.

column1: Rushed to intensive care
column2: doctors operated to remove as much of the rotting skin as they could - but she developed sepsis during the procedure.

column1: She was placed in a coma as her family were told she had just a 30 per cent chance of survival as her kidneys failed and her heart stopped four times.
Having managed to survive the horrific ordeal
column2: she underwent 21 operations to repair the damage to her skin - but doctors warned she would never walk again.

column1: But with the support of her husband
column2: Mathew
column4: she has now recovered and can walk using crutches and is back at home with her children - Megan

column1: Dana Sedgewick
column3: trimmed her pubic area with a brand new razor
column4: but ended up in a coma after she developed the flesh-eating infection
column6: using a crutch to walk - despite being told she may never be able to use her legs again)

column1: Mrs Sedgewick said: 'Like a lot of women
column2: I tried to keep a tidy bikini line. So I had a quick trim with a new razor.

column1: 'But over the weekend
column2: I felt unwell and noticed a little pimple on my groin which kept bleeding. I didn't think anything of it as I often got a rash from shaving.

column1: 'Little did I know that this tiny pimple would almost cost me my life.'
Mrs Sedgewick's ordeal began in May 2012. Two days after she'd shaved
column2: she began experiencing dizziness and nausea.

column1: She visited her GP
column2: who took swabs of the area and prescribed her antibiotics to combat a suspected infection.

column1: Later that day
column2: her eldest daughter Megan discovered her lying in bed
column3: with her legs covered in a bloody red rash.

column1: Her body almost immediately went into shock
column2: causing a red rash on her legs before they turned black from the rotting flesh (pictured in September 2012 after a couple of skin graft procedures to repair some of the damage on her legs)

column1: Afterwards
column2: her GP called to say that the swabs had revealed it was serious and that she needed to go in for another examination.

column1: But when her husband dropped her off at the surgery
column2: she collapsed.

column1: “ Like a lot of women
column2: I tried to keep a tidy bikini line. So I had a quick trim with a new razor ” Dana Sedgewick

column1: An ambulance was called and she was rushed to the trauma unit at the Northern General Hospital in Sheffield
column2: where doctors diagnosed her with necrotising fasciitis.

column1: The condition causes bacteria to release toxins that attack the surrounding soft tissue
column2: and can be caused by a minor cut or scratch.

column1: Mrs Sedgewick said: 'By the time I got to the hospital
column2: my legs were covered in black
column3: rotting flesh. It was touch-and-go as to whether I'd make it.'

column1: Over the next ten hours
column2: surgeons battled to save her legs. Cutting through seven inches of infected skin
column3: they removed the diseased flesh and reapplied skin from her back.

column1: Rushed to intensive care

column1: Having managed to come round from the horrific ordeal

column1: Doctors told Mrs Sedgewick that she had been very lucky to survive her terrifying ordeal with necrotising fasciitis (pictured in hospital in June 2012)
During surgery
column2: she developed sepsis and was given a slim chance of survival after going into septic shock.

column1: The ‘silent killer’ strikes when an infection such as blood poisoning sparks a violent immune response in which the body attacks its own organs.

column1: WHAT IS NECROTISING FASCIITIS? Necrotising fasciitis is most commonly caused by an infection with group A Streptococcus. Those infections normally last just a few days - they are mild and typically clear themselves up. But in some unusual cases it can develop into necrotising fasciitis. They infect flat layers of a membrane known as the fascia
column2: which are connective bands of tissue that surround muscles
column3: nerves
column5: and blood vessels. The infection also damages the tissues next to the fascia. Sometimes toxins made by these bacteria destroy the tissue they infect
column6: causing it to die. When this happens
column7: the infection is very serious and can result in loss of limbs or death. .
