column18: and not long after hearing of their Brothers death
column19: took up Arms to revenge themselves of the Enemy
column21: and certain party of Horse (which proved very offensive to the Indians) made such havoc and slaughter among them
column22: that the half of this Kingdom was laid waste and depopulated.

column1: Xaraqua is the Fourth Kingdom
column2: and as it were the Centre and Middle of the whole Island
column3: and is not to be equalled for fluency of Speech and politeness of Idiom or Dialect by any Inhabitants of the other Kingdoms
column4: and in Policy and Morality transcends them all. Herein the Lords and Peers abounded
column5: and the very Populace excelled in in stature and habit of Body: Their King was Behechio by name and who had a Sister called Anacaona
column6: and both the Brother as well as Sister had loaded the Spaniards with Benefits and singular acts of Civility
column7: and by delivering them from the evident and apparent danger of Death
column8: did signal services to the Castilian Kings. Behechio dying the supreme power of the Kingdom fell to Anacaona: But it hapned one day
column9: that the Governour of an Island
column11: and 30 Foot (now the Cavalry was sufficiently able to unpeople not only the Isle
column12: but also the whole Continent) he summoned about 300 Dynasta's
column13: or Noblemen to appear before him
column14: and commanded the most powerful of them
column15: being first crouded into a Thatcht Barn or Hovel
column16: to be exposed to the fury of the merciless Fire
column17: and the rest to be pierced with Lances
column18: and run through with the point of the Sword
column19: by a multitude of Men: And Anacaona her self who (as we said before
column21: to her greater honor was hanged on a Gibbet. And if it fell out that any person instigated by Compassion or Covetousness
column22: did entertain any Indian Boys and mount them on Horses
column24: another was appointed to follow them
column25: who ran them through the back or in the hinder parts
column26: and if they chanced to escape Death
column28: they immediately cut off his Legs; and when any of those Indians
column30: betook themselves to an Isle eight miles distant
column32: they were then committed to servitude during Life.

column1: The Fifth Kingdom was Hiquey
column2: over whom Queen Hiquanama
column3: a superannuated Princess
column5: did preside and Govern. The number of those I saw here burnt
column9: the poor Remnants of such matchless Villanies
column11: is infinite. But because so much might be said concerning the Assassinations and Depopulating of these people
column12: as cannot without great difficulty be published in Writing (nor do I conceive that one fragile part of 1000 that is here contained can be fully displayed) I will only add one remark more of the prementioned Wars
column13: in lieu of a Corollary or Conclusion
column15: that notwithstanding all the above-named Injustice
column16: profligate Enormities and other Crimes which I omit
column17: (tho sufficiently known to me) the Indians did not
column18: nor was it in their power to give any greater occasion for the Commission of them
column19: than Pious Religioso's Living in a well regulated Monastic Life did afford for any Sacrilegeous Villains to deprive them of their Goods and Life at the same time
column20: or why they who by flight avoided death should be detain'd in perpetual
column21: not to be ransom'd Captivity and Slavery. I adde farther
column23: and am satisfied by certain undeniable conjectures
column24: that at the very juncture of time
column25: when all these outrages were commited in this Isle
column26: the Indians were not so much guilty of one single mortal sin of Commission against the Spaniards
column27: that might deserve from any Man revenge or require satisfaction. And as for those sins
column28: the punishment whereof God hath reserved to himself
column29: as the immoderate desire of Revenge
column30: Hatred
column31: Envy or inward rancor of Spirit
column32: to which they might be transported against such Capital Enemies as the Spaniards were
column33: I judge that very few of them can justly be accused of them; for their impetuosity and vigor I speak experimentally
column34: was inferior to that of Children of ten or twelve years of age: and this I can assure you
column35: that the Indians had ever a just cause of raising War against the Spaniards
column36: and the Spaniards on the contrary never raised a just was against them
column37: but what was more injurious and groundless then any undertaken by the worst of Tyrants. All which I affirm of all their other Transactions and passages in America.

column1: The Warlike Engagements being over
column2: and the Inhabitants all swept away
column3: they divided among themselves the Young Men
column5: and Children reserved promiscuously for that purpose
column8: to this Man one hundred were disposed
column10: and the more one was in favor with the domineering Tyrant (which they styled Governor) the more he became Master of
column13: that he should see them instructed in the Catholick Religion
column14: when as they themselves to whom they were committed to be taught
column15: and the care of their Souls instructed them were
column19: infected and stained with all sorts of Vices. And this was the great care they had of them
column20: they sent the Males to the Mines to dig and bring away the Gold
column21: which is an intollerable labor; but the Women they made use of to Manure and Till the ground
column22: which is a toil most irksome even to Men of the strongest and most robust constitutions
column23: allowing them no other food but Herbage
column24: and such kind of unsubstantial nutriment
column25: so that the Nursing Womens Milk was exsiccated and so dryed up
column26: that the young Infants lately brought forth
column28: and females being separated from and debarred cohabitation with Men
column29: there was no Prolification or raising up issue among them. The Men died in Mines
column30: hunger starved and oppressed with labor
column31: and the Women perished in the Fields
column32: harrassed and broken with the like Evils and Calamities: Thus an infinite number of Inhabitants that formerly peopled this Island were exterminated and dwindled away to nothing by such Consumptions. They were compelled to carry burthens of eighty or one hundred pound weight
column33: and that an hundred or two hundred miles compleat: and the Spaniards were born by them on the Shoulders in a pensil Vehicle or Carriage
column34: or kind of Beds made of Net-work by the Indians; for in Truth they made use of them as Beasts to carry the burthens and cumbersom baggage of their journeys
column36: that the Shoulders and Backs of the Indians were deeply marked with their scourges and stripes
column37: just as they used to serve a tired Jade
column38: accustomed to burthens. And as to those slashes with whips
column42: with a Thousand of such kind of Torments they suffered during the fatigue of their laborious journeys it would require a long tract of time
column43: and many Reams of Paper to describe them
column44: and when all were done would only create Horror and Consternation in the Reader.

column1: But here is is observable
column2: that the desolation of these Isles and Provinces took beginning since the decease of the most Serene Queen Isabella
column3: about the year 1504
column4: for before that time very few of the Provinces situated in that Island were oppressed or spoiled with unjust Wars
column5: or violated with general devastation as after they were
column6: and most if not all these things were concealed and masked from the Queens knowledge (whom I hope God hath crowned with Eternal Glory) for she was transported with fervent and wonderful zeal
column8: almost Divine desires for the Salvation and preservation of these people
column9: which things so exemplary as these we having seen with our eyes

column1: Take this also for a general Rule
column2: that the Spaniards upon what American Coasts soever they arrived
column3: exercised the same Cruelties
column5: Tyrannies and detestable Oppressions on the most innocent Indian Nation
column6: and diverting themselves with delights in new sorts of Torment
column7: did in time improve in Barbarism and Cruelty; wherewith the Omnipotent being incensed suffered them to fail by a more desperate and dangerous lapse into a reprobate state.

column1: Of the Isles of St. John and Jamaica.
In the Year 1509
column2: the Spaniards sailed to the Islands of St. John and Jamaica (resembling Gardensa and Bee-hives) with the same purpose and design they proposed to themselves in the Isle of Hispaniola
column3: perpetrating innumerable Robberies and Villanies as before; whereunto they added unheard of Cruelties by Murdering
column6: and Exposing Men to be torn to pieces by Dogs; and Finally by afflicting and harassing them with un-exampled Oppressions and torments in the Mines
column7: they spoiled and unpeopled this Contrey of these Innocents. These two Isles containing six hundred thousand at least
column8: though at this day there are scarce two hundred men to be found in either of them
column9: the remainder perishing without the knowledge of Christian Faith or Sacrament.

column1: _Of the Isle of _Cuba.
In the Year of our Lord 1511. They passed over to Cuba
column2: which contains as much ground in length as there is distance between Valledolid and Rome
column3: well furnished with large and stately Provinces and very populous
column4: against whom they proceeded with no more humanity and Clemency
column5: or indeed to speak truth with greater Savageness and Brutality. Several memorable Transactions worthy observation
column6: passed in this Island. A certain Cacic a potent Peer
column8: who not long before fled Hispaniola to Cuba for Refuge from Death
column9: or Captivity during Life; and understanding by certain Indians that the Spaniards intended to steer their course thither
column10: made this Oration to all his People Assembled together.

column1: You are not ignorant that there is a rumor spread abroad among us of the Spaniards Arrival
column2: and are sensible by woeful experience how such and such (naming them) and Hayti (so they term Hispaniola in their own language) with their Inhabitants have been treated by them
column3: that they design to visit us with equal intentions of committing such acts as they have hitherto been guilty of. But do you not know the cause and reason of their coming? We are altogether ignorant of it
column5: but sufficiently satisfied that they are cruelly and wickedly inclined: Then thus
column7: they adore a certain Covetous Deity
column8: whose cravings are not to be satisfied by a few moderate offerings
column9: but they may answer his Adoration and Worship
column10: demand many unreasonable things of us
column11: and use their utmost endeavors to subjugate and afterwards murder us. Then taking up a Cask or Cabinet near at hand
column13: he proceeded in this manner: This is the Spaniards God
column14: and in honour of him if you think well of it
column15: let us celebrate our Arcytos (which are certain kinds of Dances and caprings used among them); and by this means his Deity being appeas'd
column16: he will impose his Commands on the Spaniards that they shall not for the future molest us; who all unanimously with one consent in a loud tone made this reply. Well said
column18: and thus they continued skipping and dancing before this Cabinet
column20: till they were quite tired and grown weary: Then the Noble Hathney re-assuming his discourse
column23: till ye be ravished from us
column27: that we cast it into the River
column28: which advice was approved of by all without opposition
column29: and the Cabinet thrown in to the next River.

column1: When the Spaniards first touched this Island
column2: this Cacic
column3: who was thoroughly acquainted with them
column4: did avoid and shun them as much as in him lay
column5: and defended himself by force of Arms
column7: but at length being taken he was burnt alive
column8: for flying from so unjust and cruel a Nation
column9: and endeavuoring to secure his Life against them
column10: who only thirsted after the blood of himself and his own People. Now being bound to the post
column11: in order of his Execution a certain Holy Monk of the Franciscan Order
column12: discours'd with him concerning God and the Articles of our Faith
column13: which he never heard of before
column14: and which might be satisfactory and advantagious to him
column15: considering the small time allow'd him by the Executioner
column16: promising him Eternal Glory and Repose
column18: or other wise Everlasting Torments. After that Hathney had been silently pensive sometime
column19: he askt the Monk whether the Spaniards also were admitted into Heaven
column20: and he answering that the Gates of Heaven were open to all that were Good and Godly
column21: the Cacic replied without further consideration
column22: that he would rather go to Hell then Heaven
column23: for fear he should cohabit in the same Mansion with so Sanguinary and Bloody a Nation. And thus God and the Holy Catholick Faith are Praised and Reverenced by the Practices of the Spaniards in America.

column1: Once it so hapned
column2: that the Citizens of a Famous City
column3: distant Ten Miles from the place where we then resided
column4: came to meet us with a splendid Retinue
column5: to render their Visit more Honourable
column8: with as great a quantity of Fish as they could possibly procure
column9: and distributing them among us; but behold on a sudden
column10: some wicked Devil possessing the minds of the Spaniards
column13: and without the least Pretence or Occasion offered
column14: they cut off in cold Blood above Three Thousand Men
column16: such Inhumanities and Barbarisms were committed in my sight

column1: Some time after I dispatch Messengers to all the Rulers of the Province of Havana
column2: that they would by no means be terrified
column3: or seek their refuge by absence and flight
column5: and that I would engage (for they understood my Authority) that they should not receive the least of Injuries; for the whole Country was extremely afflicted at the Evils and Mischiefs already perpetrated
column6: and this I did with the advice of their Captain. As soon as we approached the Province
column7: Two and Twenty of their Noblemen came forth to meet us
column8: whom the Captain contrary to his Faith given
column9: would have expos'd to the Flames
column10: alledging that it was expedient they should be put to Death
column13: capacitated to use any Stratagem against us
column14: but with great difficulty and much adoe
column15: I snatcht them out of the fire.

column1: These Islanders of Cuba
column2: being reduc'd to the same Vasselage and Misery as the Inhabitants of Hispaniola
column3: seeing themselves perish and dy without any redress
column4: fled to the Mountains for shelter
column6: put a period to their days with a Halter
column8: together with his Wife and Children
column10: put an end to those Calamities.

column1: By the ferocity of one Spanish Tyrant (whom I knew) above Two Hundred Indians hang'd themselves of their own accord; and a multitude of People perished by this kind of Death.
A certain Person here in the same Isle constituted to exercise a kind of Royal Power
column2: hapned to have Three Hundred Indians fall to his share
column3: of which in Three Months
column5: One Hundred and Sixty were destroy'd
column6: insomuch that in a short space there remained but a tenth part alive
column8: but when the number was doubled
column9: they all perisht at the same rate
column10: and all that were bestow'd upon him lost their lives
column11: till at length he paid his last Debt to Nature and the Devil.

column1: In Three or Four Months time I being there present
column2: Six Thousand

column1: Children and upward were murder'd
column2: because they had lost their Parents

column1: who labour'd in the Mines; nay I was a Witness of many other stupendous
Villanies.
But afterward they consulted how to persecute those that lay hid in the Mountains
column2: who were miserably massacred
column3: and consequently this Isle made desolate
column4: which I saw not long after
column5: and certainly it is a dreadful and depolorable sight to behold it thus unpeopled and laid waste

column1: Of the CONTINENT.
In the Year 1514
column2: a certain unhappy Governour Landed on the firm Land or Continent
column3: a most bloody Tyrant
column4: destitute of all Mercy and Prudence
column6: with a Resolution to people these parts with Spaniards; and although some Tyrants had touched here before him
column7: and Cruelty hurried them into the other World by several wayes of Slaughter
column8: yet they came no farther than to the Sea Coast
column9: where they comitted podigious Thefts and Robberies
column10: but this Person exceeded all that ever dwelt in other Islands
column11: though execrable and profligate Villains: for he did not only ravage and depopulate the Sea-Coast
column12: but buried the largest Regions and most ample Kingdoms in their own Ruins
column13: sending Thousdands to Hell by his Butcheries. He made Incursions for many Miles continuance
column15: in those Countries that are included in the Territories of Darien and the Provinces of Nicaraqua
column16: where are near Five Hundred Miles of the most Fertil Land in the World
column17: and the most opulent for Gold of all the Regions hitherto discover'd. And although Spain has bin sufficiently furnished with the purest Gold
column18: yet it was dig'd out of the Bowels and Mines of the said Countries by the Indians
column19: where (as we have said) they perished.

column1: This Ruler
column2: with his Complices found out new inventions to rack
column3: torment
column4: force and extort Gold from the Indians. One of his Captains in a certain Excursion undertaken by the Command of his Governeur to make Depraedations
column5: destroy'd Forty Thousand Persons and better exposing them to the edge of the Sword
column7: Dogs and variety of Torments; of all which a Religious Man of the Order of St. Francis
column9: who was then present was an Eye-Witness.

column1: Great and Injurious was the blindness of those praesided over the Indians; as to the Conversion and Salvation of this People: for they denyed in Effect what they in their flourishing Discourse pretended to
column2: and declar'd with their Tongue what they contradicted in their Heart; for it came to this pass
column3: that the Indians should be commanded on the penalty of a bloody War
column7: and submit to the Obedience of the Spanish King; as if the Son of God
column8: who suffered Death for the Redemption of all Mankind
column11: Go and teach all Nations that Infidels
column12: living peaceably and quietly in their Hereditary Native Country
column13: should be impos'd upon pain of Confiscation of all their Chattels
column19: without any precedent instruction to Confess and Acknowledge the true God
column20: and subject themselves to a King
column22: or heard mention'd before; and whose Messengers behav'd themselves toward them with such Inhumanity and Cruelty as they had done hitherto. Which is certainly a most foppish and absurd way of Proceeding
column25: nay Hell itself. Now suppose this Notorious and Profligate Governour had bin impower'd to see the Execution of these Edicts perform'd
column26: for of themselves they were repugnant both to Law and Equity; yet he commanded (or they who were to see the Execution thereof
column27: did it of their own Heads without Authority) that when they phansied or proposed to themselves any place
column28: that was well stor'd with Gold
column29: to rob and feloniously steal it away from the Indians living in their Cities and Houses
column30: without the least suspicion of any ill Act. These wicked Spaniards
column31: like Theives came to any place by stealth
column32: half a Mile off of any City
column34: and there in the Night published and proclaim'd the Edict among themselves after this manner:

column1: You Cacics and Indians of this Continent
column2: the Inhabitants of such a Place
column3: which they named; We declare or be it known to you all
column4: that there is but one God
column7: who is Lord of these Countries; appear forth without delay
column8: and take the oath of Allegiance to the Spanish King

column1: So about the Fourth Watch of the Night
column2: or Three in the Morning these poor Innocents overwhelm'd with heavy Sleep
column3: ran violently on that place they named
column9: Women and Children; kill'd whom they pleas'd upon the Spot; but those they preserv'd as Captives
column10: were compell'd throughTorments to confess where they had hid the Gold
column11: when they found little or none at their Houses; but they who liv'd being first stigmatized
column12: were made Slaves; yet after the Fire was extinguisht
column13: they came hastily in quest of the Gold. Thus did this Wicked Man
column14: devoted to all the Infernal Furies
column15: behave himself with the Assistance of Profligate Christians
column16: whom he had lifted in his Service from the 14th to the 21. or 22. Year
column17: together with his Domestick Servants and Followers
column18: from whom he received as many Portions
column19: besides what he had from his Slaves in Gold
column22: as the Chief Governor would have taken
column23: and all that were constituted to execute any kind of Kingly Office followed in the same Footsteps; every one sending as many of his Servants as he could spare
column24: to share in the spoil. Nay he that came hither as Biship first of all did the same also
column25: And at the vory time (as I conjecture) the Spaniards did depraedate or rob this Kingdom of above Ten Hundred Thousand Crowns of Gold: Yet all these their Thefts and Felonies
column26: we scarce find upon Record that Three Hundred Thousand Castilian Crowns ever came into the Spanish King's Coffers; yet there were above Eight Hundred Thousand Men slain: The other Tyrants who governed this Kingdom afterward to the Three and Thirtieth year
column27: depriv'd all of them of Life that remain'd among the Inhabitants.

column1: Among all those flagitious Acts committed by this Governour while he rul'd this Kindom
column2: or by his Consent and Permission this must by no means be omitted: A certain Casic
column3: bestowing on him a Gift
column5: or (which is more probably) induced thereunto by Fear
column6: about the weight of Nine Thousand Crowns
column7: but the Spaniards not satisfied with so fast a Sum of Money
column9: fix him to a Pole; extended his Feet
column10: which being mov'd near the Fire
column11: they demanded a larger Sum; the Casic overcome with Torments
column13: procur'd Three Thousand more to be brought and presented to them: But the Spaniards
column14: adding new Torments to new Rage and Fury
column15: when they found he would confer no more upon them
column16: which was because he could not
column17: or otherwize because he would not
column18: they expos'd him for so long to that Torture
column19: till by degrees of heat the Marrow gusht out of the Soles of his Feet
column20: and so he dyed; Thus they often murder'd the Lords and Nobles which such Torments to Extort the Gold from them.

column1: One time it hapned that a Century or Party of One Hundred Spaniards making Excursions
column2: came to a Mountain
column3: where many People shunning so horrid and pernicious an Enemy conceal'd themselves
column5: putting all to the Sword they could meet with
column6: and then secur'd Seventy or Eighty Married Women as well as Virgins Captives; but a great Number of Indians with a fervent desire of recovering their Wives and Daughters appear'd in Arms against the Spaniards
column7: and when they drew near the Enemy
column8: they unwilling to lose the Prey
column9: run the Wives and Maidens through with their Swords. The Indians through Grief and Trouble
column11: brake out into these Exclamations. O perverse Generation of Men! O Cruel Spaniards! What do you Murder las Iras? (In their Language they call Women by the Name of las Iras as if they had said: To slay Women is an Act of bloody minded Men
column12: worse than Brutes and Wild Beasts.

column1: There was the House of a Puissant Potentate scituated about Ten or Fifteen Miles from Panama
column2: whose name was Paris
column3: very Rich in Gold; and the Spaniards gave him a visit
column4: who were entertained with Fraternal Kindness
column7: presented the Captain with a Gift of Fifteen Thousand Crowns; who was of opinion
column8: as well as the rest of the Spaniards
column9: that he who bestow'd such a quantity of Money gratis
column10: was the Master of vast Treasure; whereupon they counterfeit a pretended Departure
column11: but returning about the Fourth Night-Watch
column12: and entring the City privily upon a surprize
column13: which they thought was sufficiently secur'd
column14: consecrated it with many Citizens to the Flames
column15: and robb'd them of Fifty or Sixty Thousand Crowns. The Dynast or Prince escaped with his Life
column16: and gathering together as great a Number of Men as he could possibly at that instant of time
column17: and Three or Four Days being elapsed
column19: who had depriv'd him also by Violence and Rapine of a Hundred and Thirty or Forty Thousand Crowns
column21: recover'd all his Gold with the destruction of Fifty Spaniards
column22: but the remainder of them having receiv'd many Wounds in that Rencounter betook them to their Heels and sav'd themselves by flight: but in few days after the Spaniards return
column23: and fall upon the said Casic well-arm'd and overthrow him and all his Forces
column24: and they who out-liv'd the Combat
column26: were expos'd to the usual and frequently mention'd Bondage.

column1: Of the Province of NICARAQUA.
The said Tyrant An. Dom. 1522. proceeded farther very unfortunately to the Subjugation of Conquest of this Province. In truth no Person can satisfactorily or sufficiently express the Fertility
column2: Temperateness of the Climate
column3: or the Multitude of the Inhabitants of Nicaraqua
column4: which was almost infinite and admirable; for this Region contain'd some Cities that were Four Miles long; and the abundance of Fruits of the Earth (which was the cause of such a Concourse of People) was highly commendable. The People of this place
column5: because the Country was Level and Plain
column8: that they could not leave it without great grief
column10: they were therefore tormented with the greater Vexations and Persecutions
column11: and forced to bear the Spanish Tyranny and Servitude
column12: which as much Patience as they were Masters of: Add farther that they were peaceable and meek spirited. This Tyrant with these Complices of his Cruelty did afflict this Nation (whose advice he made use of in destroying the other Kingdoms) with such and so many great Dammages
column19: could not express them all fully. He sent into the Province (which is larger than the County of Ruscinia) Fifty Horse-Men
column20: who put all the People to the Edge of the Sword
column21: sparing neither Age nor Sex upon the most trivial and inconsiderable occasion: As for Example
column22: if they did not come to them with all possible speed
column23: when called; and bring the imposed burthen of Mahid (which signifies Corn in their Dialect) or if they did not bring the Number of Indians required to his own
column24: and the Service or rather Servitude of his Associates. And the Country being all Campaign or Level
column25: no Person was able to withstand the Hellish Fury of their Horses.

column1: He commanded the Spaniards to make Excursions
column2: that is
column3: to rob other Provinces
column4: permitting and granting these Theiving Rogues leave to take away by force as many of these peacable People as they could
column5: who being iron'd (that they might not sink under the Burthen of Sixty or Eighty Pound weight) it frequently hapned
column8: and so they dyed by the way; but if any of them chanced to faint
column10: or through great Hunger and Thirst should be siezed with a Distemper; or too much Debility and Weakness
column11: that they might not spend time in taking off their Fetters
column13: so the Head fell one way
column14: and the Body another: The Indians when they spied the Spaniards making preparations for such Journeys
column18: just upon their setting out with Sighs and Tears
column19: burst out into these or the like Expressions.

column1: Those were Journeys
column2: which we travelled frequently in the service of

column1: Christians
column2: and in some tract of time we return'd to our Habitations

column1: Wives and Children: But now there being no hope of a return
column2: we are for

column1: ever depriv'd of their Sight and Conversation.
It hapned also
column2: that the same President would dissipate or disperse the Indians de novo at his own pleasure
column3: to the end (as it was reported) he might violently force the Indians away from such as did infest or molest him; and dispose of them to others; upon which it fell out
column4: that for the space of a Year complete
column5: there was no sowing or planting: And when they wanted Bread
column6: the Spaniards did by force plunder the Indians of the whole stock of Corn that they had laid up for the support of their Families
column7: and by these indirect Courses above Thirty Thousand perished with Hunger. Nay it fortun'd at one time
column8: that a Woman opprest with insufferable Hunger
column9: depriv'd her own Son of his Life to preserve her own.

column1: In this Province also they brought many to an untimely End
column2: loading their Shoulders with heavy planks and pieces of Timer
column3: which they were compell'd to carry to a Haven Forty Miles distant
column4: in order to their building of Ships; sending them likewise unto the Mountains to find out Hony and Wax
column5: where they were devour'd by Tygers; nay they loaded Women impregnated with Carriage and Burthens fit for beasts.

column1: But no greater pest was there that could unpeople this Province
column2: than the License granted the Spaniards by this Governour
column3: to demand Captives from the Casics and Potentates of this Region; for at the Expiration of Four or Five Months
column4: or as often as they obtain'd leave of the Governour to demand them
column5: they deliver'd them up Fifty Servants
column6: and the Spaniards terrified them with Menaces
column7: that if they did not obey them in answering their unreasonable Demands
column9: or baited to Death by Dogs. Now the Indians are but slenderly stor'd with Servants; for it is much if a Casic hath Three or Four in his Retinue
column10: therefore they have recourse to the Subjects; and when they had
column13: they required earnestly and instantly one Son of the Parent
column15: and Two of him that had but Three
column16: and for the Lord of the place satisfied the desires of the Tyrant
column17: not without the Effusion of Tears and Groans of the People
column18: who (as it seems) were very careful of their Children. And this being frequently repeated in the space between the Year 1523
column20: the Kingdom lost all their Inhabitants
column21: for in Six or Seven Years time there were constantly Five or Six Ships made ready to be fraighted with Indians that were sold in the Regions of Panama and Perusium
column22: where they all dyed; for it is by dayly Experience prov'd and known
column23: that the Indians when Transported out of their Native Country into any other
column24: soon dye; because they are shortned in their allowance of Food
column25: and the Task impos'd on them no ways dimished
column26: they being only bought for Labour. And by this means
column27: there have been taken out of this Province Five Hundred Thousand Inhabitants and upward
column30: and in the Wars made on them
column31: and the horrid Bondage they were reduc'd unto Fifty or Sixty Thousand more have perished
column32: and to this day very many still are destroy'd. Now all these Slaughters have been committed within the space of Fourteen years inclusively
column33: possibly in this Province of Nicaraqua there remains Four or Five Thousand Men who are put to Death by ordinary and personal Opressions
column34: whereas (according to what is said already) it did exceed other Countries of the World in multitude of People.

column1: Of new SPAIN.
New Spain was discovered Anno Dom. 1517. and in the detection there was no first or second Attempt
column2: but all were exposed to slaughter. The year ensuing those Spaniards (who style themselves Christians) came thither to rob
column3: kill and slay
column4: though they pretend they undertook this Voyage to people the Countrey. From this year to the present
column6: Violence and Tyranny of the Spaniards came to the highest degree of extremety: for they had shook hands with and bid adieu to all fear of God and the King
column7: unmindful of themselves in this sad and deplorable condition
column14: &c. which they perpetrated in so many and such ample Kingdoms
column16: and strike the minds of Men with so great horror
column17: that all we have related before are inconsiderable comparatively to those which have been acted from the year 1518 to 1542
column18: and to this very month of September that we now live to see the most heavy
column19: grievous and detestable things are committed
column20: that the Rule we laid down before as a Maxim might be induputably verified
column22: that from the beginning they ran headlong from bad to worse
column23: and were overcome in their Diabolical acts and wickedness only by themselves.

column1: Thus from the first entrance of the Spaniards into New Spain
column2: which hapned on the 18th day of April in the said month of the year 1518
column4: the space of ten whole years
column5: there was no end or period put to the Destruction and Slaughters committed by the merciless hands of the Sanguinary and Blood-thirsty Spaniard in the Continent
column6: or space of 450 Miles round about Mexico
column7: and the adjacent or neighboring parts
column8: which might contain four or five spatious Kingdoms
column9: that neither for magnitude or fertility would give Spain her self the pre-eminance. This intire Region was more populous then Toledo
column13: and Faventia; and there is not at this day in all of them so many people
column14: nor when they flourisht in their greatest height and splendor was there such a number
column17: four hundred and eighty Miles. Within these twelve years the Spaniards have destroyed in the Said Countinent
column23: and Children above Four Millions of people in these their Acquests or Conquests (for under that word they mask their Cruel Actions) or rather those of the Turk himself
column25: tending to the ruin of the Catholick Cause
column26: together with their Invasions and Unjust Wars
column27: contrarty to and condemned by Divine as well as Human Laws; nor are they reckoned in this number who perished by their more then Egyptian Bondage and usual Oppressions.

column1: There is no Tongue
column2: Art
column3: or Human knowledge can recite the horrid Impieties
column4: which these Capital Enemies to Government and all Mankind have been guilty of at several times and in several Nations; nor can the circumstantial Aggravations of some of their wicked Acts be unfolded or display'd by any manner of Industry
column6: but yet I will say somewhat of every individual particular thing
column8: that I conceive I am not able to comprehend one of a Thousand.

column1: Of New Spain in Particular.
Among other Slaughters this also they perpetrated in the most spacious City of Cholula
column2: which consisted of Thirty Thousand Families; all the Chief Rulers of that Region and Neighboring places
column3: but first the Priests with their High Priest going to meet the Spaniards in Pomp and State
column4: and to the end they might give them a more reverential and honourable reception appointed them to be in the middle of the Solemnity
column5: that so being entertained in the Appartments of the most powerful and principal Noblemen
column6: they might be lodged in the City. The Spaniards presently consult about their slaughter or castigation (as they term it) that they might fill every corner of this Region by their Cruelties and wicked Deeds with terror and consternation; for in all the Countries that they came they took this course
column7: that immediately at their first arrival they committed some notorious butcheries
column8: which made those Innocent Sheep tremble for fear. To this purpose therefore they sent to the Governours and Nobles of the Cities
column9: and all Places subject unto them
column11: that they should appear before them
column12: and no soner did they attend in expectation of some Capitulation or discourse with the Spanish Commander
column13: but they were presently seized upon and detained prisoners before any one could advertise or give them notice of their Captivity. They demanded of them six thousand Indians to drudge for them in the carriage of their bag and baggage; and as soon as they came the Spaniards clapt them into the Yards belonging to their Houses and there inclosed them all. It was a thing worthy of pity and compassion to behold this wretches people in what a condition they were when they prepared themselves to receive the burthens laid on them by the Spaniards. They came to them naked
column15: their Shoulders loaden with food; only covered with a Net
column16: they laid themselves quietly on the ground
column17: and shrinking in their Bodies like poor Wretches
column18: exposed themselves to their Swords: Thus being all gathered together in ther Yards
column19: some of the Spaniards Armed held the doors to drive them away if attempting to approach
column20: and others with Lances and Swords Butcher these Innocents so that not one of them escaped
column21: but two or three days after some of them
column22: who hid themselves among the dead bodies
column23: being all over besprinkled with blood and gore
column25: imporing their mercy and the prolongation of their Lives with tears in their Eyes and all imaginable submission
column27: not in the least moved with pity or compassion
column28: tore them in pieces: but all the Chief Governours who were above one hundred in number
column30: whom the Captain commanded to be affixed to posts and burnt; yet the King of the whole Countrey escaped
column31: and betook himself with a Train of thirty or forty Gentlemen
column32: to a Temple (called in their Tongue Quu) which he made use of as a Castle or Place of Defence
column33: and there defended himself a great part of the day
column34: but the Spaniards who suffer none to escape out of their clutches
column37: burnt all those that were there inclosed
column38: who brake out into these dying words and exclamations. O profligate Men
column39: what injury have we done you to occasion our death! Go
column41: where our supream Lord Montencuma will revenge our cause upon your persons. And 'tis reported
column42: while the Spaniards were engated in this Tragedy destroying six or seven thousand Men
column43: that their Commander with great rejoycing sang this following Ayre;

column1: Mira Nero de Tarpeia
column2: Roma como se ardia
column3: Gritos de Ninos y Vieyot

column1: From the Tarpeian still Nero espies
Rome all in Flames with unrelenting Eyes
And hears of young and old the dreadful Cries.
They also committed a very great Butchery in the City Tepeara
column2: which was larger and better stored with Houses than the former; and here they Massacred an incredible number with the point of the Sword.

column1: Setting sail from Cholula
column2: they steer'd their course to Mexico
column3: whose King sent his Nobles and Peers with abundance of Presents to meet them by the way
column4: testifying by divers sorts of Recreations how grateful their arrival was and acceptable to him: but when they came to a steep Hill
column5: his brother went forward to meet them accompanied with many Noblemen who brought them many gifts in Gold
column7: and Robes Emboidered with Gold and at their entrance into the City
column8: the King himself carried in a golden Litter
column9: together (with the whole Court) attended them to the Palace prepared for their reception; and that very day as I was informed by some persons then and there present by a grand piece of Treachery
column10: they took the very great King Montencuma
column11: never so much as dreaming of any such surprize
column12: and put him into the custody of eighty Soldiers
column13: and afterward loaded this Legs with irons; but all these things being passed over with a light pencil of which much might be said
column14: one thing I will discover acted by them
column15: that may merit your obervation. When the Captain arrived at the Haven
column16: to fight with a Spanish Officer
column18: and left another with an hundred Soldiers
column19: more or less as a Guard to King Montencuma
column21: that to act somewhat worth remembrance
column22: that the dread of their Cruelty might be more and more apprehended

column1: In the interim all the Nobility and Commonality of the City thought of nothing else
column2: but how to exhilarate the Spirit of their Captive King
column3: and solace him during his Confinement with varity of diversions and Recreations; and among the rest this was one
column5: Revellings and Dances which they celebrated in all Streets and Highways
column6: by night and they in their Idiom term Mirotes
column7: as the Islanders do Arcytos; to these Masques and nocturnal Jigs they usually go with all their Riches
column9: together with any thing that is pretious and glorious
column10: being wholly addicted to this humor
column11: nor is there any greater token among them then this of their extraordinary exultation and rejoycing. The Nobles in like manner
column12: and Princes of the Blood Royal every one according to his degree exercise these Masques and Dances
column13: in some place adjoyning to the House where their King and Lord is detained Prisoner. Now there were not far from the Palace about 2000 Young Noblemen who were the issue of the greatest Potentates of the Kingom
column14: and indeed the flower of the whole Nobility of King Motencuma
column15: and a Spanish Captain went to visit them with some Soldiers
column16: and sent others to the rest of the places in the City where these Revellings were kept
column17: under pretence only of being spectators of the solemnity. Now the Captain had commanded
column19: at a certain hour appointed they should fall upon these Revellers
column20: and he himself approaching the Indians very busie at their Dancing
column22: San Jago (that is St. James it seems that was the Word) Let us rush in upon them
column24: but they all began with their naked Swords in hand to pierce their tender and naked Bodies
column25: and spill their generous and Noble blood
column26: till not one of them was left alive on the place
column27: and the rest following his example in other parts
column28: (to their inexpressible stupefaction and grief) seized on all these Provinces. Nor will the Inhabitants till the General conflagration ever discontinue the Celebration of these Festivals
column29: and the Lamentation and Singing with certain kind of Rhythmes in their Arcytos
column30: the doleful ditty of the Calamity and Ruin of this Seminary of the antient Nobility of the whole Kingdom
column31: which was their frequent Pride and Glory.

column1: The Indians seeing this not to be exampled cruelty and iniquity executed against such a number of guiltless persons
column2: and also bearing with incredible patience the unjust Imprisonment of their King
column3: from whom they had an absolute Command not to take up Arms against the Spaniard
column4: the whole City was suddenly up in Arms fell on the Spaniards and wounded many of them
column5: the rest hardly escaping; but they presenting the point of a Sword to the Kings Breast
column6: threatned him with death unless he out of the Window commanded them to desist; but the Indians for the present disobeying the Kings Mandate
column7: proceeded to the Election of a Generalissimo
column8: or Commander in Chief over all their Forces; and because that the Captain
column9: who went to the Port returned Victor
column10: and brought away a far greater number of Spaniards then he took along with him
column11: there was a Cessation of Arms for three or four days
column13: and then the Indians having gatherered together and made up a great Army
column14: fought so long and so strenuously
column15: that the Spaniards despairing of their safety
column16: called a Council of War and therein resolv'd to retreat in the dead time of night and so draw off their Forces from the City: which coming to the knowledge of the Indians they destroyed a great number Retreating on the Bridges made over their Lakes in this just and Holy War
column18: deserving the approbation of every upright Judge. But afterward the Spaniards having recruited and got together in a Body
column19: they resolved to take the City and carried it at last
column20: wherein most detestable Butcheries were acted
column21: a vast number of the people slain
column22: and their Rulers perished in the Flames.

column1: All these horrid Muders being commited in Mexico and other Cities ten
column2: fifteen and twenty miles distant. This same Tyranny and Plague in the abstract proceeded to infest and lay desolate Panuco; a Region abounding with Inhabitants even to admiration
column3: nor were the slaughters therein perpetrated less stupendous and wonderful. In the same manner they utterly laid wasate the Provinces of Futepeca
column5: every one of them being as large as the Kingdoms of Leon
column6: and Castile. It would be very difficult or rather impossible to relate the Cruelties and Destruction there made and committed
column7: and prove very nauseous and offensive to the Reader.

column1: 'Tis observable
column2: that they entred upon these Dominions and laid waste the Indian Territories
column3: so populous
column4: that it would have rejoyced the hearts of all true Christians to see their number upon no other title or pretense
column5: but only to enslave them; for at their first arrival they compel'd them to swear the Oath of Obedience and Fealty to the King of Spain
column6: and if they did not condescend to it
column7: they menace them with death and Vassalage
column8: and they who did not forthwith appear to satisfie the unequitable Mandates
column9: and submit to the will and pleasure of such unjust and Cruel Men were declared Rebels
column10: and accu's of that Crime before our Lord the King; and blindess or ignorance of those who were set over the Indians as Rulers did so darken their understanding that they did not apprehend that known and incontrovertible Maxim in Law
column11: That no Man can be called a Rebel
column12: who is not first proved to be a subject. I omit the injuries and prejudice they do to the King himself
column13: when they spoil and ravage his Kingdoms
column14: and as much as in them lies
column15: diminish and impair all his Right and Title to the Indians
column16: nay in plain English invalidate and make it null and void. And these are the worthy Services which the Spaniards do for our Kings in those Countries
column17: by the injust and colourable pretences aforesaid.

column1: This Tyrant upon the same pretext sent two other Captains
column2: who exceeded him in impiety and cruelty
column3: if possible to the most flourishing and Feril (in Fruits and Men) Kingdoms of Guatemala
column5: who had also received Orders to go to the Kingdoms of Naco
column9: and are Borderers on Mexico three hundred miles together. The one was sent by Land and the other by Sea
column10: and both well furnished with Horse and Foot.

column1: This I declare for a Truth
column2: that the outrages committed by these two
column3: particularly by him that went to Guatimala (for the other not long after his departure died a violent Death) would afford matter sufficient for an entire Volume
column4: and when completed he so crouded with slaughters
column7: so horrid and detestable as would Ague-shake the present as well as future ages with terror.

column1: He that put out to Sea vexed all the Maritime Coasts with his cruel Incursions; now some inhabitants of the Kingdom of Jucatan which is seated in the way to the Kingdoms of Naco and Naymura
column2: to which places he steered his course
column3: came to meet him with burthens of Presents and Gifts: and as soon as he approacht them
column4: sent his Captains with a party of Soldiers to depopulate their Land
column5: who committed great spoils and made cruel slaughters among them; and in particular a Seditious and Rebellious Officer who with three hundres Soldiers entred a Neighboring Country to Guatimala
column6: and there firing the Cities and Murdering all the Inhabitants
column7: violently deprived them of all their goods
column9: for the space of an hundred and twenty miles; to the end that if his Companions should follow them
column10: they might find the Country laid wast
column11: and so be destroyed by the Indians in revenge for the dammage they had received by him and his Forces which hapned accordingly: for the Chief Commander whose order the abovesaid Captain had disobey'd and so became a Rebel to him
column12: was there slain. But many other bloody Tyrants succeeded him
column13: who from the year 1524 to 1535. did unpeople and make a Desert of the Provinces of Naco and Hondura (as well as other places) which were lookt upon as the Paradise of delights
column14: and better peopled then other Regions; insomuch that within the Term of these eleven years there fell in those Countries above two Millions of Men
column15: and now there are hardly remaining Two Thousand
column16: who dayly dye by the severity of their Slavery.

column1: But to return to that great Tyrant
column2: who outdid the former in cruelty (as hinted above) and is equal to those that Tyrannize there at present
column3: who travelled to Guatimala; he from the Provinces adjoyning to Mexico
column4: which according to his prosecuted journey (as he himself Writes and testifies with his own hand in Letters to the Prince of Tyrants) are distant from Guatimala four hundred miles
column5: did make it to his urgent and dayly business to procure Ruin and Destruction by slaughter
column7: compelling all to submit to the Spanish King
column8: whom they lookt upon to be more unjust and cruel then his inhumane and bloodthirsty Ministers.

column1: Of the Kingdom and Province of GUATIMALA.
This Tyrant at his first entrance here acted and commanded prodigious Slaughters to be perpetrated: Notwithstanding which
column2: the Chief Lord in his Chair or Sedan attended by many Nobles of the City of Ultlatana
column3: the Emporium of the whole Kingdom
column7: and brought with them all sorts of Food in great abundance
column8: with such things as he stood in most need of. That Night the Spaniards spent without the City
column9: for they did not judge themselves secure in such a well-fortified place. The next day he commanded the said Lord with many of his Peers to come before him
column10: from whom they imperiously challenged a certain quantity of Gold; to whom the Indians return'd this modest Answer
column11: that they could not satisfie his Demands
column12: and indeed this Region yeilded no Golden Mines; but they all
column14: without any other Crime laid to their Charge
column15: or any Legal Form of Proceeding were burnt alive. The rest of the Nobles belonging to other Provinces
column16: when they found their Chief Lords
column17: who had the Supreme Power were expos'd to the Merciless Element of Fire kindled by a more merciless Enemy; for this Reason only
column18: becauase they bestow'd not what they could not upon them
column22: commanding their Subjects to obey the Spaniards
column24: but withal strictly and expressly prohibiting and forbidding them
column25: to inform the Spaniards of their Flight
column26: or the Places of their Concealment. And behold a great many of the Indians addrest themselves to them
column28: they would admit them as Subjects
column29: being very willing and ready to serve them: The Captain replyed that he would not entertain them in such a Capacity
column30: but instead of so doing would put every individual Person to Death
column31: if they would not discover the Receptacles of the Fugitive Governours. The Indians made answer that they were wholly ignorant of the matter
column33: their Wives and Children should serve them; that they were at home
column34: they might come to them and put them to Death
column35: or deal with them as they pleas'd. But the Spaniards
column36: O wonderful! went to the Towns and Villages
column37: and destroy'd with their Lances these poor Men
column41: secure and free from danger. Another large Village they made desolate in the space of two hours

column1: The Indians perceiving that this Barbarous and Hard-hearted People would not be pacified with Humility
column2: large Gifts
column3: or unexampled Patience
column4: but that they were butcher'd without any Cause
column5: upon serious Consultation took up a Resolution of getting together in a Body
column6: and fighting for their Lives and Liberty; for they conceiv'd it was far better
column7: (since Death to them was a necessary Evil) with Sword in Hand to be kill'd by taking Revenge of the Enemy
column8: then be destroy'd by them without satisfaction. But when they grew sensible of their wants of Arms
column10: and that they were altogether incapable of the management of Horses
column11: so as to prevail against such a furious Adversary
column14: to dig Ditches and Holes in the High-way into which the Horses might fall in their passage
column15: and fixing therein purposely sharp and burnt Posts
column16: and covering them with loose Earth
column17: so that they could not be discern'd by their Riders
column18: they might be transfixed or gored by them. The Horses fell twice or thrice into those holes
column19: but afterward the Spaniards took this Course to prevent them for the future; and made this a Law
column20: that as many of the Indians of what Age or Sex soever as were taken
column21: should be cast into these Ditches that they had made. Nay they threw into them Women with Child
column22: and as many Aged Men as they laid hold of
column23: till they were all fill'd up with Carkasses. It was a sight deserving Commiseration
column24: to behold Women and Children gauncht or run through with these Posts
column25: some were taken off by Spears and Swords
column26: and the remainder expos'd to hungry Dogs
column27: kept short of food for that purpose
column28: to be devour'd by them and torn in pieces. They burnt a Potent Nobleman in a very great Fire
column30: That he was the more Honour'd by this kind of Death. All which Butcheries continued Seven Years
column32: to 1531. I leave the Reader to judge how many might be Massacred during that time.

column1: Among the Innumerable Flagitious Acts done by this Tyrant and his Co-partners (for they were as Barbarous as their Principal) in this Kingdom
column2: this also occurs worthy of an Afterism in the Margin. In the Province of Cuztatan in which S. Saviour's City is seated
column3: which Country with the Neighbouing Sea-Coasts extends in Length Forty or Fifty Miles
column4: as also in the very City of Cuzcatan
column5: the Metropolis of the whole Province
column6: he was entertain'd with great Applause: For about Twenty or Thirty Thousand Indians brought with them Hens and other necessary Provisions
column9: commended every single Spaniard to make choice of as many of these People
column10: as he had a mind to
column12: they might use them as Servants
column13: and forced to undergo the most servile Offices they should impose on them. Every one cull'd out a Hundred
column15: according as he thought convenient for his peculiar service
column16: and these wretched Indians did serve the Spaniards with their utmost strength and endeavour; so that there could be nothing wanting in them but Adoration. In the mean time this Captain requir'd a great Sum of Gold from their Lords (for that was the Load-stone attracted them thither) who answered
column17: they were content to deliver him up all the Gold they had in possession; and in order thereunto
column18: the Indians gathered together a great Number of Spears gilded with Orichalcum
column20: and in truth some Gold in them intermixt) and they were presented to him. The Captain ordered them to be toucht
column21: and when he found them to be Orichalcum or mixt Metal
column22: he spake to the Spaniards as followeth. Let that Nation that is without Gold be accursed to the Pit of Hell. Let every Man detain those Servants he Elected
column23: let them be clapt in Irons
column24: and stigmatiz'd with the Brand of Slavery
column27: who did no excape with the King's Mark. I my self saw the Impression made on the Son of the Chiefest Person in the City. Those that escap'd
column29: engaged the Spaniards by Force of Arms
column30: but with such ill success
column31: that abundance of them lost their Lives in the Attempt. After this they return'd to Gautimala
column33: which God in his Judgement with Three Deluges
column37: as big as half a score Oxen
column38: all concurring at one and the same time
column39: laid Level with its own Ashes. Now all being slain who were capable of bearing Arms against them
column41: paying so much per Head for Men and Women as a Ransom; for they use no other servitude here
column42: and then they were sent into Pecusium to be sold
column43: by which means together with their slaughters committed upon the Inhabitants
column44: they destroy'd and made a Desert of this Kingdom
column45: which in Breadth as well as Length contains One Hundred Miles; and with his Associates and Brethren in Iniquity
column46: Four Millions at least in Fifteen or Sixteen Years
column47: that is
column50: and dayly continues destroying the small residue of that People with his Cruelties and Brutishness.

column1: It was the usual Custom of this Tyrant
column2: when he made War with any City or Province
column3: to take along with himas many of those Indians he had subjugated as he could
column4: that they might fight with their Country-men; and when he had in his Army Twenty
column5: or sometimes Thirty Thousand of them
column6: and could not afford them sustenance
column7: he permitted them to feed on the Flesh of other Indians taken Prisoners in War; and so kept a Shambles of Man's Flesh in his Army
column8: suffered Children to be kill'd and roasted before his Face. They butcher'd the Men for their Feet and Hands only; for these Members were accounted by them Dainties

column1: He as the Death of many by the intolerable Labour of Carrying Ships by Land
column2: causing them to Transport those Vessels with Anchors of a vast weight from the Septentrional to the Mediterranean Sea
column3: which are One Hundred and Thirty Miles distant; as also abundance of great Guns of the largest fort
column4: which they carried on their bare
column6: so that opprest with many great and ponderous Burthens
column7: (I say no more than what I saw) they dyed by the way: He separated and divided Families
column8: forcing Married Men from their Wives
column10: which he bestow'd upon his Marriners and Soldiers
column11: to gratifie their burning Lust. All his Ships he freighted with Indians
column12: where Hunger and Thirst discharg'd them of their Servitude and his Cruelty by a welcome Death. He had two Companies of Soldiers who hackt and tore them in pieces
column13: like Thunder from Heaven speedily. O how many Parents has he robb'd of their Children
column14: how many Wives of their Husbands
column15: and Children of their Parents? How many Adulteries
column17: and what Libidinous Acts hath he been guilty of? How many hath he enslav'd and opprest with insufferable Anguish and unspeakable Calamities? How many Tears
column18: Sighs and Groans hath he occasion'd? To how many has he bin the Author of Desolation
column20: and of Damnation in the World to come
column24: by whose help and assistance he committed such detestable Butcheries and flagitious Crimes? I supplicate Almighty God
column25: that he would please to have Mercy on his Soul
column26: and require no other satisfaction than the violent Death
column27: which turn'd him out of this World.

column1: A farther Discourse of New Spain: And some Account of Panuco and Xalisco.
After the perpetration of all the Cruelties rehearsed in New Spain and other places
column2: there came another Rabid and Cruel Tyrant to Panuco
column3: who acted the part of a bloody Tragedian as well as the rest
column4: and sent away many Ships loaden with these Barbarians to be sold for Slaves
column5: made this Province almost a Wilderness
column8: that had Rational Souls were given in Exchange for a Burthen-bearing-Beast
column11: He was made Governour of the City of Mexico
column13: and with him many other Tyrants had the Office of Auditors confer'd upon them: Now they had already made such a progress toward the Desolation of this Region
column14: that if the Franciscans had not vigorously opposed them
column16: the best and greatest Encourager of Vertue) it had not speedily bin prevented
column17: that which hapned to Hispaniola in Two Years
column18: had bin the Fate of Hispania nova
column21: and intomb'd in its own Rules. A Companion of this Governour employed Eight Thousand Indians in Erecting a wall to inclose his Garden
column26: at whose Death he was not in the least concern'd.

column1: After the first Captain before spoken of had absolutely profliaged and ruin'd the Panuconians
column2: Fifteen Thousand whereof perished by carrying their Bag and Baggage: At length he arriv'd at the Province of Machuacan
column3: which is Forty Miles Journey from Mexico
column4: and as Fertile and Populous: The King to honour him in the Rencounter
column7: from whom he had received One Thousand Services and Civilities very considerable
column8: who gratefully requited him with Captivity
column9: because Fame had nois'd it abroad
column10: that he was a most Opulent Prince in Gold and Silver; and to the end he might export from
column11: and purge him of his Gold
column12: he was cruciated with Torments after this manner; his Body was extended
column14: and his Feet put into a pair of Stocks
column15: they all the while applying burning Coals to his Feet at a tormenting distance
column17: who by little and little sprinkled them with Oyl
column18: that his Flesh might roast the better: Before him there stood a Wicked Fellow
column19: presenting a Bow to his Breast charged with a Mortal Arrow
column21: another with Dogs held in with Chains
column22: which he threatned to let loose at him
column24: he had bin torn to pieces in a moment; and with these kind of Torments they racked him to extort a Confession
column25: where his Treasures lay; till a Franciscan Monk came and deliver'd him from his Torments

The landmark symbolizes a stack of records topped by a stylus and is representative of Programmatic architecture on an epic scale. This Hollywood historic icon is 150 feet high with a 90 foot spire and a beacon constantly blinking out HOLLYWOOD in Morse Code. The round shape is repeated in curved
column9: and cylindrical light fixtures; glass walls
column11: and stainless steel elevators are typical of the period. Below ground are echo chambers and recording studios
column12: the first ever built for high fidelity recordings. Though the exterior is virtually unaltered
column13: the interior offices and studios have undergone numerous remodellings. Inside the lobby is an astounding array of gold records
column14: spanning the entire history of rock and roll. In December
column15: the tower is lit to create Hollywood's tallest Christmas tree. Occasionally
column16: the tower is decorated with various promotional ornaments. Past ""dress ups"" have included various flags on the rooftop
column17: covering the circular Capitol Records sign with images of the Beatles
column18: and recently a Beatles Yellow Submarine giant postage stamp was stuck to the side of the building. Since the tower is clearly visible from most of Hollywood and the busy 101 Freeway
column19: the tower acts as the company's most recognizable billboard. At the base of the building's southern face (overlooking a parking lot) is a wall mural by artist Richard Wyatt
column20: titled ""Hollywood Jazz"". The mural features large portraits of Capitol Recording jazz legends Nat King Cole
column24: and Miles Davis. The Beatles and many others recorded in the studios in this building. Live concerts have also been performed in the parking lot over the years

column11: more: Is this election a moment for the transgender community?

column1: Tuesday night
column2: voters elected at least five transgender candidates to government offices around the nation. It's not a large number
column3: but it's a meaningful one.

column1: Last night was a victory for so many remarkable LGBTQ candidates
column2: but it was also a victory for inclusion and acceptance
column3: said Sarah Kate Ellis
column5: on Wednesday. “This is a clear repudiation of President Trump’s hate-fueled politics of bullying and browbeating. Yesterday
column6: Americans took to the polls and chose optimism
column8: and new leadership – and this is only the beginning of our resistance.”

column1: The Gay & Lesbian Victory Fund
column2: a national organization dedicated to electing openly LGBTQ people said in a statement that ""2017 will be remembered as the year of the trans candidate.”

column1: Here's a look at those elected:
Danica Roem
column2: Virginia's House of Delegates

column1: Democrat Danica Roem
column2: a former journalist
column3: defeated incumbent Republican candidate Del. Bob Marshall Tuesday to become the first openly transgender elected official in Virginia. Roem
column5: is now also set to make history as the first openly transgender person to be elected and seated in a state legislature. She led by about 9%. Roem's campaign focused on jobs
column6: schools and traffic problems rather than gender identity. She argued that Marshall had spent too much of his energy in office tackling social issues like the bathroom bill.

column1: Danica is not the first transgender person elected to state office
column2: but she is the first openly transgender person
column3: GLAAD noted in an email to USA TODAY. Althea Garrison was elected in Massachusetts in 1992
column4: but did not disclose that she was transgender —she was outed as being transgender after she won her race and then did not win re-election.

column1: More: Virginia elects its first openly transgender delegate to state House
Andrea Jenkins
column2: Minneapolis City Council

column1: Andrea Jenkins
column2: along with Cunningham
column3: has made history as the first out transgender black person elected to public office of a major U.S. city. She ran against three other candidates and won more than 70% of the votes in her ward. She only needed to break 50% to win.

column1: “My election is what resistance looks like
column2: Jenkins said in a statement Tuesday night. ""It’s also about hope. As a City Council Member
column3: I will be committed to advocating for equity for the most marginalized in our community.”

column1: Jenkins has 12 years of experience as a campaign aide to other city council members. She said she wants to make Minneapolis a better place for African Americans to live in
column2: create more affordable housing
column3: police accountability and economic development.

column1: More: Trump distances himself from Ed Gillespie after Virginia election loss
Phillipe Cunningham
column2: Minneapolis City Council

column1: Phillipe Cunningham joined Jenkins as the only out trans black people to be elected to the city council of a major U.S. city after the transgender man's victory over the city’s longtime council president was announced Wednesday afternoon. The result had been delayed due to Minneapolis’ instant-runoff voting system.
With Cunningham and Jenkins' wins
column2: the Minneapolis City Council is now ""15% qualified Black queer transgender leaders
column3: Cunningham said in a statement.

column1: There will never be another generation born in this country where Black flamboyant boys
column2: butch girls (with whom I will always share a kinship)
column3: and transmasculine boys won’t have an example that even the honor being elected as representatives of our communities is possible for them

column1: Cunningham's campaign focused on ways his ward can build community wealth through small businesses
column2: homeownership
column3: environmental justice
column4: safer neighborhoods and empowering a community voice.

column1: Lisa Middleton
column2: Palm Springs
column3: Calif.

column1: Lisa Middleton became the first transgender person elected to a non-judicial office in California. She secured a spot on the Palm Springs City Council with nearly 31% of the votes. As a member of the Palm Spring Planning Commission
column2: she focused on revitalizing downtown Palm Springs and promoted use of solar and renewable power.

column1: It's all because of all of you that we are here tonight
column2: celebrating a victory
column3: a historic victory for our city and for our state

column1: More: Transgender candidate wins
column2: makes history in California

column3: suicide

column1: Thank you to my volunteers

column3: and every voter
column4: Titus said on Twitter. ""We made history tonight.""

column1: An ominous edict issued from the Office of the President of Russia today to all Ministries of the Russian Government ordering that all “past
column2: present and future” information relating to Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster now be rated at the highest classification level “Of Special Importance” states that this condition is “immediately and urgently needed” due to a series of underground nuclear explosions occurring at this crippled atomic plant on 31 December as confirmed by the Ministry of Defense (MoD).

column1: “Of Special Importance” is Russia ’s highest classification level and refers to information which
column2: if released
column3: would cause damage to the entire Russian Federation .

column1: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster was a catastrophic failure at the Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant on 11 March 2011. The failure occurred when the plant was hit by a tsunami triggered by the 9.0 magnitude Tōhoku earthquake.

The plant began releasing substantial amounts of radioactive materials beginning on 12 March 2011 becoming the largest nuclear incident since the 1986 Chernobyl disaster and the second (with Chernobyl ) to measure at the highest Level 7 on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES).
According to this report
column2: MoD “assests” associated with the Red Banner Pacific Fleet detected two “low-level” underground atomic explosions occurring in the Fukushima disaster zone on 31 December
column3: the first measuring 5.1 magnitude in intensity
column4: followed by a smaller 3.6 magnitude explosion moments later.

column1: The MoD further reports that the 5.1 magnitude event corresponds to the energy equivalent in megatons of TNT of 0.0005
column2: while the 3.6 magnitude event equals 0.0000005.

column1: As a comparison
column2: the MoD states that the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945 by the United States released the equivalent of 16 Kilotons = 0.016 megatons of TNT
column3: about the energy equivalent of a magnitude 6 earthquake
column4: and the largest hydrogen bomb ever detonated was the Tsar bomb
column5: a device exploded by the Soviet Union on 30 October 1961
column6: with an energy equivalent of about 50 megatons of TNT.

column3: was that the architect of Fukushima Daiichi Reactor 3
column5: warned on 17 November 2011 warned that a “China Syndrome” (aka: Hydrovolcanic Explosion) was “inevitable” due to the melted atomic fuel that had escaped the container vessel and was now burning through the earth.

Ted Cruz recently issued a summons to potential supporters.

column1: It’s not really a summons. It’s a fundraising letter — as in
column2: Cruz is summoning support. But the problem is the Cruz campaign has made the envelope look much like a legal summons
column3: which can be pretty serious. A summons occurs when a person is sued or ordered to appear in court. Most people are probably not thrilled about getting such a summons.

column1: A reader brought this mailer to our attention because she viewed it as misleading and intimidating. We reached out to the Cruz campaign and explained the concern. The Cruz campaign later provided the following statement:
“Out of more than 50
column2: 000 mailers to the San Antonio area targeting likely supporters there was one complaint that came not to us but to the local media. Our mail efforts have been both effective and critical to identifying and engaging our supporters
column3: and getting them involved in our campaign efforts to keep Texas strong.”

column1: No doubt
column2: the fundraising letter
column3: itself
column4: is effective. But we think the Cruz campaign could do without the legal summons language on the envelope. It’s just too official looking. The envelope has two clear windows. Above those windows it says
column5: “Summons Enclosed — Open Immediately” in bold letters.
