column1: Coordinates:
2000 case of missing girl in North Carolina
Asha Jaquilla Degree (born August 5
column2: 1990; first name pronounced AY-shuh[1]) went missing at the age of nine from Shelby
column3: North Carolina
column4: United States. In the early morning hours of February 14
column8: left her family home north of the city and began walking along nearby North Carolina Highway 18 despite heavy rain and wind. Several passing motorists saw her; when one turned around at a point 1.3 miles (2.1 km) from her home and began to approach her
column9: she left the roadside and ran into a wooded area. In the morning
column10: her parents discovered her absence. No one has seen her since.[2]

column1: An intensive search that began that day led to the location of some of her personal effects near where she was last seen. A year and a half later
column2: her bookbag
column3: still packed
column4: was unearthed from a construction site along Highway 18 north of Shelby in Morganton. At the point where she ran into the woods
column5: a billboard now stands appealing for help finding her. Her family hosts an annual walk from their home to the billboard to draw attention to the case.

column1: While the circumstances of Degree's disappearance at first seemed to suggest she was running away from home
column2: investigators could not find a clear reason she might have done so
column3: and she was younger than most children who do so. They have speculated that she might have been abducted instead. The case has drawn national media attention. In 2015
column4: the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) joined state and county authorities in a reopened investigation
column5: offering a reward for information that could help solve the case.

column1: Background [ edit ]
Harold and Iquilla Degree married on Valentine's Day in 1988. Their son
column2: O'Bryant
column3: was born a year later
column4: and their daughter Asha was born in 1990.[3] The Degrees raised both children in their house on Oakcrest Drive in a residential subdivision amidst a generally rural area north of Shelby
column6: on the western edge of the Charlotte metropolitan area.[4] Both worked regular jobs nearby. The children let themselves in after school
column7: [5] where their parents expected that they would either be doing their homework or finished with it by the time they returned.[6]

column1: They made sure their children were insulated from outside influences and had a life centered around their extended family
column2: church
column3: and school. The Degrees did not have a computer in the house. ""[E]very time you turned on the TV there was some pedophile who had lured somebody's child away
column5: Iquilla recalled in a 2013 Jet interview.[7] Iquilla said Asha handled this well; she was cautious
column6: shy and content mostly to stay within the limits her parents set. ""She was scared to death of dogs
column7: she recalled years later. ""I never thought she would go out of the house.""[8]

column1: Asha was in fourth grade at nearby Fallston Elementary School going into a three-day weekend on the second week of February 2000. The Cleveland County Schools were closed on Friday
column2: February 11
column3: while the Degrees still had to work; the children spent the day at their aunt's house in the same neighborhood
column4: from which they went to their youth basketball practices at their school. The following day
column6: on which she was a star point guard
column7: lost its first game of the season. Asha had fouled out. Her parents recalled that she was somewhat upset about this
column8: crying along with her teammates afterwards
column9: but seemed to have gotten over it and watched her brother's game afterwards.[6]

column1: Disappearance [ edit ]
On February 13
column2: a Sunday
column3: the children went to church from a relative's house and then returned home. Around 8 p.m. that night
column4: both children went to bed in the room they shared. Almost an hour later
column5: the power went out in the neighborhood after a nearby car accident. The power came back on at 12:30 a.m.
column6: at which time Harold checked on his children and saw both Asha and O'Bryant asleep in their beds.[9] He checked again shortly before he went to bed at 2:30 a.m. on February 14

column1: Shortly afterwards
column2: O'Bryant
column3: then age 10
column4: recalls hearing Asha's bed squeak. He did not further rouse himself as he assumed she was merely changing positions in her sleep. Apparently around this time
column6: taking a bookbag she had previously packed with several sets of clothes and personal items
column7: and left the house. Between 3:45 and 4:15 a.m.
column8: a truck driver and a motorist saw her walking south along Highway 18
column9: wearing a long-sleeved white T-shirt and white pants
column10: just north of its junction with Highway 180.[10] They reported this to police after seeing a TV report about her disappearance.[6] The motorist said that he turned his car around because he thought it was ""strange such a small child would be out by herself at that hour"". He circled three times and saw Degree run into the woods by the roadside and disappear. It was a rainy night
column11: and the witness said there was a ""storm raging"" when he saw her.[8][11] County sheriff Dan Crawford said
column12: ""We're pretty sure it was her because the descriptions they gave are consistent with what we know she was wearing."" He added that they also saw her at the same place

column1: Iquilla awoke at 5:45 a.m. to get the children ready for school. On the morning of February 14
column2: an important day since it was not only Valentine's Day but the Degrees' wedding anniversary
column3: [13] this involved drawing a bath for them as they had not been able to take one the night before due to the power outage. When she opened the children's room to wake them up before their 6:30 alarm and call them to the bath
column4: O'Bryant was in his bed but Asha was not
column5: and Iquilla was unable to find her in the house
column6: nor in the family cars.[7] She told Harold she could not find their daughter. He suggested Asha might have gone over to his mother's house across the street
column7: but when Iquilla called there her sister-in-law said Asha was not there. ""That's when I went into panic mode. I heard a car next door ... I put shoes on and ran outside."" Iquilla called her mother
column8: who told her to call the police.[7]

column1: Search [ edit ]
By 6:40 a.m.
column2: the first police officers had arrived on the scene. Police dogs called to the scene could not pick up Asha's scent. Iquilla went through the neighborhood calling Asha's name
column3: which she said had awakened everyone by 7 a.m.[7] Friends
column4: family and neighbors canceled their plans for the day to assist police in searching the vicinity while the pastor of their church
column6: came to the Degrees' home to support them. By day's end all that had been found was a mitten
column7: which Iquilla Degree said did not belong to her daughter as she had found that no winter clothing had been taken from the house.[14] Local news coverage resulted in the two drivers who had seen Asha walking along the road early that morning
column8: including the one whose attempt to approach her apparently prompted Asha to flee into the woods

column1: On February 15
column2: candy wrappers were found in a shed at a nearby business along the highway
column3: near where Asha had been seen running into the woods.[15] Along with them were a pencil
column4: marker and Mickey Mouse-shaped hair bow that were identified as belonging to her.[8][16] It was the only trace of her found during the initial search. On February 16
column5: Iquilla realized that Asha's bedroom was missing her favorite clothing
column6: including a pair of blue jeans with a red stripe.[17][6][10] A week later
column8: 000 man hours had been invested in a search of the 2–3-mile-radius (3.2–4.8 km) of where she had last been seen
column9: flyers posted all over the area and 300 leads ranging from possible sightings to tips about abandoned houses and wells where Asha might have ended up
column10: the search was called off. ""We have never really had that first good
column12: said county sheriff Dan Crawford at a news conference. He urged the media to keep the story alive.[18]

column1: Later developments [ edit ]
At the news conference on February 22
column2: Crawford said he was going ""long-range"" with the search for Asha. Both the FBI and North Carolina's State Bureau of Investigation (SBI) got involved and put her on their respective databases of missing children. While the agencies were done searching in the area of her home and route
column3: ""we're following everything

column1: From Iquilla's account of what Asha had taken with her
column2: investigators believed she had planned and prepared for this departure over the several days preceding her disappearance. ""She's not your typical runaway
column3: observed SBI agent Bart Burpeau. Another expert
column4: Ben Ermini of the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
column5: noted that most children who run away are at least 12.[11] An FBI agent also pointed to the lack of an issue she might have been running away from
column6: such as a dysfunctional family or poor academic performance. Still
column7: investigators believed that was the most likely explanation for her departure
column8: but that for some reason she either got off track or was abducted.[18]

column1: The media attention went national. A month after Asha's disappearance
column2: the Degree family appeared on The Montel Williams Show to call attention to the case. America's Most Wanted and The Oprah Winfrey Show also devoted segments to it.[7]

column1: On August 3
column3: Asha's bookbag and other items were discovered during a construction project off Highway 18 in Burke County
column5: about 26 miles (42 km) north of Shelby. It was wrapped in a plastic bag.[2][19][20][21] The worker who found it said the bookbag contained Asha's name and phone number.[16] The FBI took it to their headquarters for further forensic analysis; results from that testing have not been shared publicly.[22] To date it is the last evidence found in the case.[23] On the 20th anniversary of Asha's disappearance
column6: the FBI confirmed that the bookbag contained a copy of Dr. Seuss's McElligot's Pool and a T-shirt depicting the band New Kids on the Block. Neither appeared to have been her property before they were found in her bag; the book was from the library at her elementary school.[1]

column1: Later leads have turned out to be dead ends. In 2004
column2: acting on a tip reportedly received from an inmate at the county jail
column3: the sheriff's office began digging at an intersection in Lawndale. The bones that were found turned out to be from an animal.[20]

column1: External image Age progression of Degree to age 29
The Degrees took steps to keep Asha's memory
column2: and the case
column3: alive in the public's mind. In 2008
column4: they established a scholarship in her name for a deserving local student.[24] They host an annual walk to raise awareness and money to fund their search.[25] The walk starts at their home and ends at a missing person's billboard for Asha along Highway 18
column5: near where she was last seen.[2] It was originally held on February 14
column6: but it was changed to February 7 in 2015 and February 6 in 2016
column7: as Harold and Iquilla felt it was not fair to participants to make Valentine's Day a somber occasion.[5][4] Pictures of Asha
column8: both real and those showing her as she might appear in later years created by investigators to help the search
column9: still decorate the Degree house. ""I fully expect her to walk through the door

column1: Iquilla Degree lamented in a 2013 interview with Jet that her daughter's disappearance had not gotten as much media attention over the years as some subsequent cases of missing children. She believed it was because Asha was black. ""Missing white children get more attention. I don't understand why
column2: she said. ""I know if you ask them they will say it's not racial. Oh
column3: really? I'm not going to argue because I have common sense.""[7]

column1: In February 2015
column2: the FBI announced that FBI agents
column3: Cleveland County Sheriff's Office investigators
column4: and State Bureau of Investigation agents were re-examining the case and re-interviewing witnesses. They also announced a reward of up to $25
column5: 000 for ""information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons responsible for her disappearance.""[26] A community group is offering an additional $20

column1: The FBI announced 15 months later
column2: in May 2016
column3: that their reinvestigation of the case had turned up a possible new lead. They disclosed that Asha may have been seen getting into a dark green early 1970s Lincoln Continental Mark IV
column4: or possibly a Ford Thunderbird from the same era along Route 18 near where she was last seen later that night. It was described as having rust around its wheel wells.[28]

column1: In September 2017
column2: the FBI announced that its Child Abduction Rapid Deployment (CARD) team was in Cleveland County to assist in the investigation and ""provide on-the-ground investigative
column3: technical
column5: and analytical support to find out more about what happened to Asha"". The team worked alongside FBI Charlotte employees
column7: and North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation agents for ten days.[29] The agencies also meet ""several times a month to go over the latest on the investigation."" Since September 2017
column8: local agents and investigators have conducted approximately 300 interviews.[30]

column1: In October 2018
column2: the Cleveland County Sheriff's Office detectives appealed for information from the public about two items of interest that were found in Degree's bookbag: McElligot's Pool
column3: a children's book by Dr. Seuss
column4: which was borrowed from the Fallston Middle School library in early 2000
column5: and a New Kids on the Block concert T-shirt.[1] An investigator said the items are ""critical to solving [the case]"".[31][32]

column1: Officials from the U.S. Attorney’s Office of the District of Delaware
column2: the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division and the FBI met today with representatives of the McDole family to inform them of this determination. The department makes this decision based on the determination that the evidence does not indicate that the corporals willfully used excessive force in shooting McDole.

column1: Federal authorities devoted significant time and resources to reviewing the events surrounding McDole’s death. This involved reviewing detailed and lengthy analysis of voluminous materials
column2: including police reports
column3: law enforcement accounts
column7: the autopsy report and an enhanced cell phone video of the incident.

column1: The team of experienced federal prosecutors from the Civil Rights Division Criminal Section and the U.S. Attorney’s Office reviewed thousands of pages of documents and other evidence to determine whether the subject corporals violated federal law. Under the applicable federal criminal civil rights statute
column2: prosecutors must establish
column3: beyond a reasonable doubt
column4: that a law enforcement officer willfully deprived an individual of a Constitutional right. To establish willfulness
column5: federal authorities must show that the officer acted with the deliberate and specific intent to do something the law forbids. This is the highest standard of intent imposed by law. Mistake
column7: negligence or poor judgment are not sufficient to establish a federal criminal civil rights violation.

column1: The evidence developed during the investigation revealed that corporals Thomas Silva
column2: James MacColl
column3: Thomas Lynch and Joseph Dellose were dispatched pursuant to a 911 call reporting that a male suspect in a wheelchair
column5: was armed with a handgun and may have sustained self-inflicted gunshot wounds. Silva arrived first at the scene
column6: and the 911-caller pointed out McDole and said McDole was still in possession of a gun. Silva commanded McDole to show his hands and drop the gun
column7: but McDole instead rolled his wheelchair into the street and reached into his waistband. MacColl arrived next and saw that McDole was not responding to Silva’s commands. Dellose arrived and immediately approached McDole from the opposite direction of Silva and MacColl. Dellose also ordered McDole to show his hands; however
column8: McDole continued to reach into his waistband. Dellose stated that he observed the handle of a gun
column9: so he fired a round at McDole from his shotgun. Lynch arrived immediately after Dellose fired.

column1: After the shotgun blast
column2: McDole continued moving his hands around his lap and waistband. McDole then reached into the right side of his waistband as if to grab something and began withdrawing his right hand
column3: in which he held what the corporals believed to be a handgun. Silva
column4: MacColl and Lynch each fired four shots at McDole from their service pistols. McDole fell to the ground and a responding officer approached him and removed from his waistband a handgun.

column1: The incident was recorded in a cell phone video
column2: which was enhanced at the FBI Laboratory. The video shows McDole continuously moving his hands around his waistband as WPD officers yell for him to show his hands and drop the gun. The camera pans away from McDole the instant before the shotgun blast. Toward the end of the video
column3: McDole reaches into his waistband with his right hand
column4: then begins pulling his right hand upward. A volley of shots is heard
column5: but the camera pans away from McDole for a moment while the shots are being fired. Several law enforcement officers and civilians witnessed the shooting and the events leading up to it. These witnesses corroborated the claim of the corporals who fired at McDole that McDole failed to respond to law enforcement commands and continued moving his hands around his waistband when the shots were fired. The investigation also revealed that McDole’s DNA was located on the grip of the handgun recovered from his waistband and that there was gunshot residue was on McDole’s right palm and shirt sleeve.

column1: There is insufficient evidence to disprove the corporals’ claims that they shot McDole in self-defense and in defense of nearby civilians and fellow officers. Other witnesses also corroborate Dellose’s claim that McDole was reaching into his side immediately before Dellose fired his shotgun
column2: even though the video does not capture that precise moment. Accordingly
column3: the government cannot disprove that Dellose saw a handgun or believed he saw a handgun. When Silva
column4: MacColl and Lynch fired their weapons a few moments later
column5: they had reason to believe that McDole had a gun that he had recently fired. They also knew that McDole had not responded to repeated commands to show his hands and drop the gun
column6: was reaching into his waistband and was at that moment pulling his hand upward. The testimonial
column7: video and physical evidence corroborates the corporals’ version of the events.

column1: Accordingly
column2: after extensive investigation into this incident
column3: the federal review of this incident has been closed without prosecution. This decision is limited strictly to an application of the high legal standard required to prosecute the case under the federal civil rights statute; it does not reflect an assessment of any other aspect of the incident that led to McDole’s death.

column1: The U.S. Attorney’s Office of the District of Delaware and the Civil Rights Division are committed to investigating allegations of civil rights violations by law enforcement officers and will continue to devote the resources required to ensure that all allegations of serious civil rights violations are fully and completely investigated. The department will aggressively prosecute criminal civil rights violations whenever there is sufficient evidence to do so." column1: The Stamford Advocate reports:
A homeless woman from Bridgeport who enrolled her 6-year-old son at a Norwalk elementary school has become the first in the city to be charged with stealing more than $15
column2: 000 for the cost of her child's education.

column1: Tanya McDowell
column3: whose last known address was 66 Priscilla St.
column5: was charged Thursday with first-degree larceny and conspiracy to commit first-degree larceny for allegedly stealing $15
column6: 686 from Norwalk schools. She was released after posting a $25

column1: McDowell's babysitter
column2: Ana Rebecca Marques
column3: was also evicted from her Roodner Court public housing apartment for providing documents to enroll the child at Brookside Elementary School.

column1: According to the story
column2: McDowell was primarily sleeping at a home in a different city
column3: although she could not be there during the days
column4: and also spent time at a local shelter. The boy went to the sitter's house daily after school.

column1: An argument could be made that as they had no permanent home
column2: there is no reason why the babysitter's house isn't a place of residence
column3: as it was a place he went to daily and had more permanence than their other living situations appeared to. However
column4: the school disagreed and decided after an investigation to press charges against the mother

column1: The Chair of the board of education admits the move is unusual -- normally a child found attending school out of district is just sent away. Others are speculating why this case became the case that the district appears to be interested in using to ""set an example"" in order to discourage other parents from attempting to send their children to school with false addresses
column2: especially since the mother obviously has no ability to pay for the ""theft."" A lawyer involved in a similar case wonders why they wouldn't choose to go after someone where they may have a chance to get reimbursement back for the educational costs while making their point.

column1: Could it be that the district is less concerned about sending a general example and more concerned about sending one geared to a specific audience? Like
column2: for example
column3: the low-income and homeless in the area?

column6: DC – In a continued effort to help struggling families stay safe and healthy through initiatives that assist with energy costs
column7: U.S. Senators Jack Reed (D-RI) and Susan Collins (R-ME)
column8: who helm the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Transportation
column11: are leading a bipartisan coalition of senators urging President Trump to include robust funding in his Fiscal Year (FY) 2018 budget request for the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) and the Weatherization Assistance Program (WAP).

column1: In a letter to President Trump and Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Acting Director Mark Sandy
column2: Senators Reed
column3: Collins and 43 of their colleagues noted the bipartisan support behind both LIHEAP and WAP and described the critical role both programs play in providing vulnerable populations and low-income households with affordable home energy.

column1: “LIHEAP helps low-income households
column2: veterans
column3: and seniors with their energy bills
column4: providing an indispensable lifeline during both the cold winters and hot summer months
column5: ” the Senators wrote. “More than 90 percent of LIHEAP recipients have at least one household member who is a child
column8: and the percentage of households with at least one veteran has grown to 20 percent. The program helps to ensure that eligible recipients do not have to choose between paying their energy bills and affording other necessities like food and medicine.”

column1: Preserving LIHEAP funding is a perennial bipartisan priority for Reed and Collins
column2: who in recent years have worked together to prevent any funding cuts to the program. The current funding level for LIHEAP is able to serve less than 20 percent of the eligible population and that those who receive LIHEAP assistance have seen their average grant significantly reduced.

column1: In FY 2016
column2: Rhode Island households received over $26 million in LIHEAP funding
column3: as part of $3.01 billion in total LIHEAP funds provided to states. Last October
column4: Reed helped secure funding under the FY 2017 Continuing Resolution (CR)
column5: totaling over $3 billion nationally for LIHEAP and $22.49 million for Rhode Island.

column1: The letter also emphasizes the importance of the Weatherization Assistance Program
column2: which has helped reduce the burden of high energy prices for more than forty years by helping low-income families
column3: seniors
column4: and individuals with disabilities make necessary energy efficient improvements to their homes. Rhode Island households received nearly $1.1 million in WAP funds for FY 2016 as part of over $213 million allocated to states. Since 1990
column5: Rhode Island has used WAP funds to successfully weatherize more than 13
column7: according to the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE). The DOE also notes that WAP helps eligible Rhode Island families reduce annual energy bills by an average of $264.

column1: “By supporting lasting and cost-effective home energy efficiency improvements for low-income families
column2: seniors
column3: and individuals with disabilities
column4: WAP is increasing the energy efficiency of dwellings
column6: improving the health and safety of our most vulnerable citizens
column7: and helping to lower the need for short-term assistance

column1: “LIHEAP and WAP are vital programs that help thousands of Rhode Islanders stay safe and help improve the energy efficiency of their homes through the coldest winters and the hottest summers
column2: ” said Senator Reed
column3: the Ranking Member of the Transportation
column4: Housing and Urban Development (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittee. “We need robust funding for both programs to ensure vulnerable populations don’t have to choose between paying high energy bills and paying for food

column1: Other Senators who signed the letter include Tammy Baldwin (D-WI)
column2: Michael Bennet (D-CO)
column3: Richard Blumenthal (D-CT)
column30: Bill Nelson (D-FL)

column1: The full text of the letter is below:
The President
The White House
1600 Pennsylvania Avenue
column2: N.W.

column1: Washington
Dear Mr. President:
We write in support of two successful federal programs
column2: the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) and the Weatherization Assistance Program (WAP)
column3: that are currently helping to meet the energy needs of eligible low-income households across the country. Access to affordable home energy is a matter of health and safety for many low-income households
column6: and seniors. LIHEAP and WAP have enjoyed bipartisan support
column7: and we hope that you will prioritize funding for both programs in your fiscal year 2018 budget proposal.

column1: LIHEAP helps low-income households
column2: veterans
column3: and seniors with their energy bills
column4: providing an indispensable lifeline during both the cold winters and hot summer months. More than 90 percent of LIHEAP recipients have at least one household member who is a child
column7: and the percentage of households with at least one veteran has grown to 20 percent. The program helps to ensure that eligible recipients do not have to choose between paying their energy bills and affording other necessities like food and medicine. This is especially important during the peak winter heating and summer cooling seasons
column8: when energy bills can comprise roughly 30 percent of a low-income household’s monthly income. Sadly
column10: the number of households eligible for LIHEAP assistance continues to exceed the program’s capacity.

column1: The Weatherization Assistance Program is another key initiative
column2: which for 40 years has helped to reduce more permanently the burden of high home energy prices for over 7.4 million low-income households. By supporting lasting and cost-effective home energy efficiency improvements for low-income families
column3: seniors
column5: WAP is increasing the energy efficiency of dwellings
column7: improving the health and safety of our most vulnerable citizens
column8: and helping to lower the need for short-term assistance. WAP has been repeatedly demonstrated as cost-effective and has supported thousands of high quality
column9: skilled jobs. A study by Oak Ridge National Laboratory found that weatherization saves eligible single-family homes on average $283 in annual energy cost savings
column10: which benefits not only the household but the local economy.

column1: Thank you for your attention to and consideration of this important request. We recognize the ongoing challenges facing the discretionary budget and look forward to working with you to support these vital programs and ensure access to affordable home energy for the most vulnerable households in every state.

column1: President Donald Trump loves putting his name on everything from ties to steaks to water — and
column2: of course
column3: his buildings. But now the Trump Organization appears to be borrowing a brand even more powerful than the gilded Trump moniker: the presidential seal.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: the Trump Organization has ordered the manufacture of new tee markers for golf courses that are emblazoned with the seal of the president of the United States. Under federal law
column3: the seal’s use is permitted only for official government business. Misuse can be a crime.

column1: Past administrations have policed usage vigilantly. In 2005 the Bush administration ordered the satirical news website The Onion to remove a replica of the seal. Grant M. Dixton
column2: associate White House counsel
column3: wrote in a letter to The Onion that the seal “is not to be used in connection with commercial ventures or products in any way that suggests presidential support or endorsement.”

column1: Listen to the Podcast
After listening to the new ProPublica/WNYC podcast “Trump
column2: Inc.
column3: ” a listener brought the signs to our attention.

column1: Eagle Sign and Design
column2: a metalworking and sign company with offices in New Albany
column3: Indiana
column6: said it had received an order to manufacture dozens of round
column7: 12-inch replicas of the presidential seal to be placed next to the tee boxes at Trump golf course holes. Two tee markers are placed on the ground at the start of a hole on golf courses to indicate where golfers should stand to take their first swing.

column1: “We made the design
column2: and the client confirmed the design
column3: ” said Joseph E. Bates
column5: declining to say who the client was.

column1: A table of presidential seal tee markers at Eagle Sign. This photo was provided to ProPublica by a source.

An order form for the tee markers reviewed by ProPublica and WNYC says the customer was “Trump International.” The Facebook page for Eagle Sign and Design shows a photo of the markers in an album with the caption “Trump International Golf Course.”
It is unclear how many Trump International golf courses will feature the markers. The Trump Organization owns four courses with the “International” name in the U.S. and abroad
column2: with a fifth course in Bali
column3: Indonesia

column1: Eagle Sign makes a wide array of tee markers out of bronze and aluminum
column2: and has made other signs for Trump’s courses
column3: according to its website. At some of Trump’s golf courses
column4: tee markers have sported the Trump family crest
column5: which he took from the family that originally owned Mar-a-Lago without permission and then altered by adding his own name.

column1: Ethics experts have long been on the lookout for signs that the Trump Organization would exploit the office of the presidency for commercial gain. Several said that using the presidential seal on the company’s golf courses would fall into this category.
A law governs the manufacture or use of the seal
column2: its likeness
column3: “or any facsimile thereof” for anything other than official U.S. government business. It can be a criminal offense punishable by up to six months in prison.

column1: Get More Trump
column2: Inc. Stay up to date with email updates from WNYC and ProPublica about their ongoing investigations.

column1: The “law is an expression of the idea that the government and government authority should not be used for private purpose
column2: ” said Kathleen Clark
column3: a law professor at Washington University specializing in government and legal ethics said. “It would be a misuse of government authority.”

column1: The Department of Justice declined to comment on whether it was aware the seal had been used by entities outside the government. The White House and the Trump Organization did not respond to request for comment.
The presidential seal was first sketched out by President Millard Fillmore in 1850 and the current design — which shows a bald eagle with an olive branch in its right talon
column2: a bundle of 13 arrows in the left
column3: and a scroll bearing the words “E pluribus unum” in its beak — was chosen by President Truman and made official in a 1945 executive order.

column1: The seal that adorns the president’s speaking lecterns is handmade by the Institute of Heraldry
column2: a department of the Army located at Fort Belvoir in Virginia that designs and provides guidance related to military and governmental symbols.

column1: Versions of the seal have occasionally been put to personal use by past presidents. George W. Bush and Barack Obama had custom sets of golf balls made with the seal. Ronald and Nancy Reagan had a set of presidential china bearing the seal
column2: and there have even been M&M’s and jelly beans that featured the seal.

column1: In this case
column2: the difference is that a private company is using the seal
column3: said Richard Painter
column4: vice chairman of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington
column5: a government accountability group. Painter also served as an associate White House counsel during the George W. Bush administration.

column1: “If we had heard of a private company using it for commercial purposes
column2: we would have sent them a nasty letter
column3: ” he said.

column10: 'https://archive.li/aFx9V']	https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/news-analysis/ivanka-trump-clothing-relabeled-adrienne-vittadini	https://www.businessoffashion.com/	"An Ivanka Trump blouse (left) and a blouse relabeled as Adrienne Vittadini Studio (right).

column1: NEW YORK
column2: United States — At American discount retailer Stein Mart
column3: Ivanka Trump apparel is being sold under the guise of a different label. BoF has learned that the Jacksonville
column4: Florida-based chain — which has 290 stores in 31 states
column7: Wisconsin — is selling Ivanka Trump garments relabeled as Adrienne Vittadini Studio.

column1: G-III
column2: the company that owns the right to manufacture and distribute Ivanka Trump apparel through a license agreement — and also owns brands including DKNY outright — acknowledges that it sold the relabelled merchandise to Stein Mart without the knowledge of the Ivanka Trump brand. It is not known whether this inventory was also sold to other retailers.

column1: “G-III accepts responsibility for resolving this issue
column2: which occurred without the knowledge or consent of the Ivanka Trump organisation
column3: ” a representative for G-III said in a statement to BoF. “G-III has already begun to take corrective actions
column4: including facilitating the immediate removal of any mistakenly labelled merchandise from its customer. The Ivanka Trump brand continues to grow and remains very strong.”

column1: BoF has obtained photos of identical garments being sold at Stein Mart
column2: with the only difference being the name on the label. Some say “Ivanka Trump” while others say “Adrienne Vittadini.”

column1: Why did this happen?
Since the election of her father Donald J. Trump to the office of US president
column2: Ivanka Trump-branded merchandise has been dropped from several prominent American retailers
column3: most notably Nordstrom — which cited weak sales — as well as Neiman Marcus and Shoebuy.com. According to a source within Stein Mart
column4: the retailer has received negative feedback from customers regarding Ivanka Trump product
column5: with one customer spitting on a blouse in front of a cashier before storming out of a store.

column1: But the motivating factors may not be that simple. Swiping labels — or simply ripping the label out completely — before a garment is sold to a discount retailer has long been commonplace. One reason is brand protection: if a brand is hot
column2: it’s not desirable to be associated with a discounter. However
column3: this practice occurs less often now that many major full-price retailers — such as Nordstrom
column4: Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue — operate their own off-price outlets
column5: marketing the same brands they sell at full-line stores.

column1: “US textile product labelling laws allow substitution of labels
column2: so long as the entity making the substitution is identified on the new label and keeps records for three years
column3: ” explained Susan Scafidi
column4: professor of fashion law at Fordham Law School and founder of the Fashion Law Institute. “This is mostly for supply chain tracking reasons. All of the other required information on the label — fibre content

column1: It could be argued that G-III was simply looking to protect the Ivanka Trump brand from being associated with a discount retailer. In its 2016 fiscal year — which ended at the end of January 2017 — G-III reported that net sales of Ivanka Trump merchandise increased by $17.9 million from 2015
column2: although the company does not break out exactly how much revenue the merchandise generated altogether.

column1: Sales performance of G-III's Ivanka Trump merchandise for the first quarter of 2017 — and since President Trump’s inauguration — has yet to be reported
column2: although much of the success of the brand is thought to be due to sales in China
column3: where she is often referred to as a “goddess” on social media. G-III does not break out Ivanka Trump sales by region.

column1: In a call on Friday with BoF
column2: Stein Mart chief executive D. Hunt Hawkins said that
column3: despite certain customer complaints regarding the Ivanka Trump label being sold in stores
column4: the retailer’s decision to carry the relabelled product was not motivated by politics. “We’ve had both labels for a while. We may see more Adrienne Vittadini in the short term
column5: ” he said. “I’ve had an equal number of [customers] say that they don’t want and do want [the Ivanka Trump merchandise] in the store. If we get it

column1: The retailer doesn’t have the luxury of being choosy. Unlike many of its off-price competitors — which have benefited from the rise of discount culture
column2: expanding at a rapid rate — Stein Mart
column3: which generated $1.4 billion in its 2016 fiscal year
column4: has struggled. While year-over-year net sales were about flat in 2016
column5: sales at stores open at least one year were down almost 4 percent.

column1: While G-III and Stein Mart have both acknowledged their participation in the swap
column2: it is unclear what role Adrienne Vittadini has played. Authentic Brands Group licenses Adrienne Vittadini
column3: not G-III. However
column4: G-III declined to explain how the Adrienne Vittadini labels ended up on the Ivanka Trump garments. A representative from Authentic Brands Group declined to comment for this story.

column1: It certainly matters if Adrienne Vittadini did not know about the swap. “If the original label [is replaced] with that of a third party unaware of the substitution
column2: the [responsible party] would be liable to the third party
column3: ” Scafidi says. “All of this derives historically from the law of fraud.”

column1: And even if label swapping is technically legal
column2: questions remain on whether or not the practice is ethical or in line with customer expectation. “Of course
column3: the fact that a clothing retailer can legally relabel with certain restrictions doesn't mean that it should
column4: especially if label-conscious consumers are likely to be outraged by the switch
column5: ” Scafidi says. “Fashion may be trending toward modesty
column6: but when it comes to labels
column7: customers are demanding more transparency than ever.”

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/fukushima-officials-never-eat-pacific-fish-again/	fukushima scientists have warned that fish in the pacific ocean will never again be safe for human consumption due to radioactive contamination	false	['fish'
column2: 'fukushima'
column3: 'newspunch.com'
column14: has been detected at an extremely low level in a Canadian salmon by the InFORM project. The single sockeye salmon that tested positive was sampled from Osoyoos Lake in the summer of 2015
column15: according to scientists from the Radiation Protection Bureau at Health Canada
column16: in cooperation with Fisheries and Oceans Canada and local First Nations. The sample was one of a few (8 out of 156 total) individual fish that had trace levels of the longer lived cesium-137 (137Cs) (30 yr half-life) that we reported on last winter. To determine if this trace 137Cs was from Fukushima or remnant from atmospheric weapons testing
column17: InFORM reexamined these individual fish samples to see if extremely low levels of 134Cs may be present. The results of this extended analysis show that trace (0.07 Bq kg-1) levels of 134Cs were detected in one sample from Okanagan/Columbia River population. No 134Cs was detectable in the other samples. The observed levels remain well below the action level (1000 Bq kg-1) set by Health Canada guidelines.

column1: As we reported in the winter 2016 update
column2: 8 individual fish (out of the 156 measured) from 2015 tested positive for low levels (<1 Bq kg-1) of cesium-137 (137Cs). With its ~30 year half-life
column3: 137Cs is still present in the environment from 20th century atmospheric weapons testing and Chernobyl in addition to the Fukushima accident. In contrast
column4: no individual fish from the 2014 monitoring effort were found to contain detectable levels of 137Cs. This difference led the team at the Radiation Protection Bureau to conduct a more detailed investigation of some of those few positive samples to determine if 134Cs
column6: was present. Results from 5 of those 8 are now available and discussed below. The remaining three samples have now been processed
column7: and no elevated levels of 137Cs or 134Cs.

column1: A more detailed investigation requires that the minimum detectable concentration (MDC) be lowered. When studying ionizing radiation
column2: the MDC is a threshold that refers to the statistics of detecting individual nuclear disintegrations after a sample has been on a detector for a period of time. With each additional disintegration detected
column3: the signal becomes more distinct from the noise. When detecting trace concentrations of isotopes
column4: disintegrations are infrequent and thus more time on the gamma spectrometer detector is necessary to lower the MDC and determine with confidence (signal clearly
column6: above the noise) that an isotope is present. Lowering the MDC is analogous to increasing the exposure time for a camera to capture a good night scene as shown below.

column1: For these salmon samples
column2: each was freeze dried
column3: to prevent the meat from going rancid
column4: then placed on the detector for a full two weeks (336 hours). For comparison
column5: InFORM salmon samples are normally counted for 6 hours. Similar to the photos above
column7: you can just make out the scene of a campfire on the beach
column8: but it is difficult. In the case of those 8 samples
column9: it was even possible to see that something was present
column10: as with the logs on the shoreline in the photo (red square)
column11: but there is not enough signal to clearly resolve what that item might be. When placed on the detector for 2 weeks the decay signal is improved and the MDC threshold is lowered
column12: similar to increasing the length of the camera’s shutter speed to capture more light.

column1: With the lower MDC
column2: the results are more statistically robust. In the graph above we see the 2 week results (darker teal and brown vertical bars) are now above the associated MDCs (horizontal lines) so we have greater confidence in the signal. In four of the five samples reporting
column3: those early indications of of 137Cs in the sample turned out to be cases that weren’t statistically significant and the longer analysis revealed that levels of 137Cs decreased and the new results were in agreement with the average value for all the 2015 samples. This result is not totally surprising and is a good example of statistical regression to the mean.

column1: However
column2: one of the samples from Osoyoos Lake confirmed the level of 137Cs (0.53 Bq kg-1) and showed a very low (0.07 Bq kg-1)
column3: signal for 134Cs

column1: We can validate that the observed signal comes from Fukushima by comparing the observed levels of 134Cs and 137Cs. The salmon sample was collected in 2015
column2: almost exactly 2 half-lives of 134Cs (t 1/2 = 2.06 years)
column3: or 4 years
column4: after the majority of this radioisotope was released into the environment. If we decay correct the 134Cs in the sample to the time of the Fukushima disaster in 2011
column5: we get 0.35 Bq kg-1. We know from previous work by other scientists that 134Cs and 137Cs were released from the Fukushima accident in equal amounts. This should mean that the level of 137Cs in the sockeye sample is approximately equal
column6: so what is the source of the additional 0.2 Bq kg-1? Examining the results of the 155 other salmon collected in 2015 we see from the sum of their spectra that the average concentration of 137Cs in all of these fish was ~0.2 Bq kg-1. Since no Fukushima radiation was detected in any of those samples we deduce that this is the level of contamination attributable to historic atmospheric weapons testing. Therefore
column7: we conclude that just over half of the observed levels of radiocesium in this sample are from Fukushima contamination with the rest being from historical sources of human contamination in the 20th century.

column1: The InFORM team stresses that even though the results presented confirm Fukushima radiation in this Pacific salmon
column2: the levels of contamination do not approach levels that represent a significant health threat to the fish or to a human consumer. Based on this measurement
column3: the total cesium (137Cs + 134Cs) radioactivity in this sample is 0.60 Bq kg-1
column4: which is over 1000x lower than the level of concern according to Health Canada. For perspective
column5: you would need to consume 1000-1500 kg of salmon with this level of contamination in a short period of time to increase your radiation dose by the same amount as a single 5 hour cross-country flight.

column1: To view the full results from all 156 salmon from 2015 that were analyzed as part of our Fukushima biotic monitoring effort see our earlier summary or Open Data Canada. Initial results from the 2016 biotic monitoring program will be available shortly.

Updated 1 Mar 2017: Correction was made to the source location of the salmon that tested positive. The fish was caught in Osoyoos Lake and is known to spawn in the Okanagan River. The fish was not from Okanagan Lake

column1: The new analysis ranked 48 continental states and the District of Columbia by measuring the psychopathic personality of their residents.

column2: Ryan Murphy
column3: told Newsweek:

column1: “These results are the first estimates we have

column3: on the degree of psychopathy found in each state.""

column1: Murphy claimed that each state’s ranking was computed on a previous study that ranked each state on the “Big Five” personality traits:
Agreeableness
Extraversion
Openness
Conscientiousness
neuroticism
© press

According to Miamiherald.com: This was done by analyzing the results of personality surveys given to thousands of residents in each state. People tended to have different levels of each of the “Big 5” traits depending on where they lived.
That previous study
column2: which was published in 2013
column3: aimed at separating the United States into broad regions of personality.

column1: The states in the mid-Atlantic and northeast were classified as “temperamental and uninhibited.”
Those in middle America were “friendly and conventional

column2: empathy

column1: They do things purely for their own interests

column1: Murphy used the data on personality from the previous study and used it to calculate a new score based on personality traits that indicated psychopathy

column1: “The top five observations in psychopathy are the District of Columbia
column2: Connecticut
column3: California
column5: and a tie of New York and Wyoming for fifth. The states that are least psychopathic are West Virginia

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/is-there-a-warrant-for-cia-nominee-gina-haspels-arrest/	cia deputy director gina haspel has a warrant for her arrest in germany.	false	['bush administration'
column2: 'CIA'
column3: 'enhanced interrogation techniques'
column11: 'https://www.mccain.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=F5AE735B-2F08-4CBA-B954-F04BA0006626']	https://www.thedailybeast.com/could-cia-nominee-gina-haspel-be-prosecuted-for-war-crimes	https://www.thedailybeast.com/	"The nomination of Gina Haspel to be the next director of the CIA faces trouble amid accusations that she personally supervised the torture of suspected terrorists and destroyed the evidence of the interrogations.

column1: Haspel supervised a U.S. “black site” in Thailand in 2002 where Abu Zubeidah and Abdul Rahim Nashiri were tortured by CIA personnel. In 2005
column2: she helped destroy 92 videotapes showing their torture. She faced no consequences for those actions
column3: and
column4: assuming senators ask about them at her upcoming confirmation hearing
column5: it’s likely that her answers will be given in a closed

column1: But Haspel’s actions may well have violated international law
column2: specifically the U.N. Convention Against Torture. Could she face prosecution?

column1: Legally speaking
column2: yes. But politically
column3: almost certainly not.

column1: There are two legal avenues for a case against Haspel. The first is the International Criminal Court (ICC)
column2: and the second is a domestic court of a European nation.

column1: The ICC is a better fit conceptually. Its entire purpose is to prosecute people for “genocide
column2: war crimes
column3: crimes against humanity
column4: and aggression.” And despite legal counsel provided to the Bush administration at the time
column5: the kinds of torture which Haspel supervised when she oversaw a CIA “black site” in Thailand are almost certainly violations of the U.N. Convention Against Torture.

column1: Mary Ellen O’Connell
column2: professor of international law at Notre Dame Law School
column3: told The Daily Beast that Haspel “clearly broke the law… Every member of the CIA is aware that the U.S. is a party to the Convention Against Torture. Even members of the military would have had the duty to disobey a manifestly unlawful order from superiors to use torture.”

column1: Not only did Haspel not disobey orders
column2: some experts believe that she gave them herself
column3: while supervising the interrogation of Zubaydah and Nashiri
column4: and subsequently destroyed the tapes. The answers may be in the 6
column5: 000-page Senate intelligence committee report on torture during the Bush administration that remains classified (only the 524-page executive summary is authorized for release).

column1: “ Every member of the CIA is aware that the U.S. is a party to the Convention against Torture. Even members of the military would have had the duty to disobey a manifestly unlawful order from superiors to use torture. ” — Mary Ellen O’Connell
column2: professor of International Law at Notre Dame

column1: Moreover
column2: O’Connell noted
column3: the ICC itself is “under pressure
column5: for the court to look even-handed.” Nearly all ICC prosecutions have thus far been of Africans; a high-profile investigation of a sitting CIA director would help dispel concerns that the ICC is biased in favor of “first world” defendants.

column1: The problem with the ICC is jurisdiction. Under the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court
column2: which established the body in 1998
column3: the court can only hear of abuses that were either committed by an ICC member nation or took place within an ICC member nation. The United States is not a member: It signed the Rome Statute
column4: but the Senate didn’t ratify it.

column1: Thailand
column2: where Haspel’s black site was located—at the international airport outside Bangkok—is in the same situation. It’s a signatory
column3: but not a member.

column1: The only way that Haspel could be prosecuted at the ICC
column2: then
column3: is if she had responsibility for war crimes that took place in another country that

column1: The most likely candidate is Poland
column2: where the CIA operated another black site
column3: but it is not known whether Haspel had responsibility for that site
column4: or exactly what took place there.

column1: In other words
column2: the ICC may not have jurisdiction at all
column3: and absent additional leaks
column4: it’s hard to see them gaining any information about what did or didn’t happen in Poland.

column1: Even Haspel’s testimony to the Senate may be of little use. It is common practice for intelligence officers to request a closed hearing for matters related to national security
column2: and until the Russia Investigation
column3: it was unheard of for members of Congress to divulge the records of such hearings.

column1: At Haspel’s public hearing
column2: you can expect her to refuse to answer any question that has to do with torture
column3: black sites
column5: on the grounds it could compromise national security—to say nothing of her own prosecution.

column1: So much
column2: then
column3: for the ICC. What about the second option: domestic courts in other countries?

column1: Andrew Novak
column2: professor of international law at George Mason University
column3: told The Daily Beast that “many countries have universal jurisdiction laws when the law of nations has been violated
column6: or genocide. They would have jurisdiction if someone’s not being prosecuted elsewhere.”

column1: Moreover
column2: “after Rwanda and Yugoslavia
column3: there are very broad laws to prosecute war crimes

column1: This has happened before. According to O’Connell
column2: cases against Americans implicated in torture have proceeded in Spain
column3: Italy
column6: “Italy issued arrest warrants for CIA agents involved in the kidnapping and rendition of a Muslim cleric. One of the agents… was arrested on the warrant and held for a time in Panama. Another woman was arrested in Portugal a few months ago.”

column1: A similar process is already underway in Haspel’s case. In Germany
column2: the European Center for Constitutional and Human Rights (ECCHR)
column3: has filed a series of complaints with the country’s federal prosecutor

column1: Andreas Schüller
column2: director of ECCHR’s International Crimes and Accountability Program
column3: told The Daily Beast that this campaign has been going on for years. “In 2014
column4: when the Senate report on the CIA came out
column5: we filed a brief criminal complaint… They opened a preliminary examination—not yet an investigation
column6: but a file that establishes the initial suspicion to open a case.”

column2: ECCHR filed two more extended complaints
column3: one regarding the Army’s alleged torture of inmates at Guantanamo Bay and Abu Ghraib
column4: and a second on the CIA’s alleged torture at black sites.

column2: Gina Haspel’s name was not known
column3: ” Schüller said
column4: “but when she was nominated as vice-director of the CIA last year
column5: we had a name to connect to other facts we had presented already.”

column1: Now
column2: the ECCHR says
column3: “Gina Haspel must face arrest on traveling to Europe.”

column1: But would the German federal prosecutor really go after the the CIA director
column2: when such a move would gravely damage U.S.-German relations?

column1: Schüller agreed it was unlikely.
“We don’t expect to see that move
column2: ” he said. “What we want to achieve is to say: look
column3: there was torture
column4: there is the UN Convention Against Torture
column5: and you [the government] know who this person is. If you allow her to come here
column6: you are making a clear political decision that you prioritize that over your obligations under the Convention Against Torture… They can’t say they didn’t know who was coming here.”

column1: Moreover
column2: Schüller added
column3: “the legal accountability debate continues and makes life at least a little bit harder for the people making those decisions [to conduct torture]. It’s something they have to take into account.”

column1: In sum
column2: while the actions documented in the Senate’s report would be strong grounds for a war crimes prosecution of Gina Haspel
column3: it’s very unlikely that anyone will make use of them. International law often takes a back seat to international relations
column4: and realpolitik often dictates results. Even when the law
column6: are clear."	Could CIA Nominee Gina Haspel Be Prosecuted for War Crimes?	2018-03-19 09:04:24+00:00	['Jay Michaelson']	['nominee'

column1: NEW YORK (AP) — Replicas of the official presidential seal displayed at one of Donald Trump’s golf courses were given to the club by members and have since been removed
column2: the Trump Organization said Tuesday.

column1: The statement to The Associated Press came a day after a report from two news organizations that said order forms for dozens of presidential seals listed “Trump International Golf Course” as the customer. Under federal law
column2: the seal bearing the American eagle can only be used for official government business
column3: with violations punishable by up to two years in jail.

column1: ADVERTISEMENT
“The plaques were presented to the club by a small group of members
column2: who are incredible fans of the president
column3: in honor of Presidents’ Day weekend
column4: ” said Trump Organization spokeswoman Amanda Miller. “They were temporary and have since been removed.”

column1: The Trump Organization did not respond to a request for clarification on who ordered the plaques
column2: the names of the members who “presented” them
column3: how they were displayed and at what club.

column1: ProPublica and WNYC reported Monday that the president’s company ordered the seal plaques to be used to mark where golfers should stand while teeing off on Trump courses. A photo accompanying the story
column2: which was attributed to an unnamed source at the plaque manufacturing company
column3: showed a table with at least 32 of the replica seals on it.

column1: The president is mostly exempt from conflict-of-interest laws that prevent officials of the executive branch from profiting off their government positions. And lobbyists
column2: special interest groups and diplomats have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars already at Trump properties.

column1: But federal law regarding the presidential seal is another matter. It specifically bans the use of the seal for private purposes in a way that gives a “false impression of sponsorship or approval by the Government of the United States.”
Manufacturers are also prohibited from “knowingly” making the seal for anything other than “official use” by the U.S. government
column2: punishable by fines and jail.

column1: The company behind the presidential seals
column2: Eagle Sign & Design in New Albany
column3: Indiana
column4: did not reply to phone calls and emails.

column1: A Facebook page by the Eagle Sign & Design had a link to photos of its products that displays a blank page with the words “Presidential Seal” and “Trump International Golf Course
column2: ” but no photo. ProPublica/WNYC reported that there was a photo of the plaques there before it published its story."	Trump Org: Presidential seals at golf club came from members	2018-03-06 20:48:53+00:00	['Bernard Condon']	['club'

column1: By Amanda Froelich
People who refuse chemotherapy treatment live on average 12 and a half years longer than people who undergo chemotherapy
column2: says Dr. Jones.

column1: chemotherapy doesn’t work 97% of the time. According to recent statistics
column2: approximately 1 in 2 men and 1 in 3 women will develop cancer in their lifetimes. This saddening reality is made worse when it is acknowledged that modern methods of ‘treating’ the disease are often ineffective and only make the symptoms of the disease worse. In fact
column3: according to one Berkeley doctor

column1: In the eye-opening video above
column2: Dr. Hardin B. Jones
column3: a former professor of medical physics and physiology at the University of California
column5: discusses how ‘leading edge’ cancer treatment is a sham.

column1: He has personally studied the life expectancy of patients for more than 25 years and has come to the conclusion that chemotherapy does more harm than good. The bone-chilling realization prompted Dr. Jones to speak out against the billion-dollar cancer industry.
“People who refused chemotherapy treatment live on average 12 and a half years longer than people who are undergoing chemotherapy
column2: ” said Dr. Jones of his study
column3: which was published in the New York Academy of Science.

column1: “People who accepted chemotherapy die within three years of diagnosis
column2: a large number dies immediately after a few weeks.”

column1: According to the physician
column2: the only reason doctors prescribe chemotherapy is because they make money from it. Such an accusation doesn’t seem unreasonable
column3: as cancer treatment runs

column1: “Patients with breast cancer who reject conventional therapy live four times longer than those who follow the system. So this is something that you will not hear in the mass media
column2: which will continue the myth…”

column1: Despite the fact that the United States spends more on healthcare than any other high-income nation in the world
column2: diseases of affluence continue to increase in prevalence
column3: resulting in a shorter life expectancy.

column1: Perhaps this is because mainstream media and the allopathic healthcare system don’t teach about the importance of preventative medicine . Eating a healthy diet
column2: engaging in exercise
column3: thinking positive thoughts
column5: and enjoying the company of others – or habits that bring joy – are all proven to improve longevity and happiness.

column1: As it is
column2: there is no money in a healthy population
column3: which is why fast food joints and pharmaceutical industries thrive in America. Hopefully
column4: Dr. Jones’ efforts will inspire people to seek out alternative options if they or someone they know develops the debilitating disease.
