column1: 1:25 P.M. EDT
SANDERS: Good afternoon. As you all know
column2: President Trump is deeply committed to our veterans. These brave men and women have given so much to our country and deserve our absolute best
column3: which is why this President is fighting for reform and accountability at the VA.

column1: In keeping with his campaign pledge
column2: the President donates his salary on a quarterly basis to further important projects. Today
column3: the President is proud to donate his 2018 first-quarter salary to the Department of Veterans Affairs to support their caregiver programs.

column1: Acting Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert Wilkie is here to accept the check. I’d like to bring him up to say a few words about how these funds will be used.
And make sure that I give you —
ACTING SECRETARY WILKIE: Thank you very much
column2: Sarah.

column1: SANDERS: — the all-important actual check.
ACTING SECRETARY WILKIE: Thank you very much
column2: Sarah. And good afternoon.

column1: Before I address the President’s generosity
column2: I want to say a couple of things about what happened in the House yesterday. I want to send my thanks and the thanks of Veterans Affairs to the Chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee
column3: Dr. Roe
column4: and thank him for the bipartisan coalition that he forged together. The vote yesterday was overwhelming

column1: And this is long-awaited legislation that our veterans have been waiting in anticipation of. This takes seven community care programs that we have been using for the last 15 to 20 years and condenses them into one. It also makes it much easier for our veterans to obtain care that they need at the moment that they need it
column2: in homes and in facilities closest to where they live.

column1: This also opens up the Caregiver Program to long-waiting communities within our veterans’ world — those veterans from World War II
column2: Korea
column3: Vietnam
column4: and the Gulf War who have not had access to a community caregiver program that was opened up for those who have served in the military since 9/11.

column1: So with this strong bipartisan support
column2: we urge the Senate to take up the House bill and give it to President Trump
column3: hopefully before Memorial Day.

column1: But I also want to single out the major veteran service organizations. Thirty-eight of them signed a letter in support of this legislation to the House and Senate leadership. Their people have been walking the halls of the Congress for the last week. They will be in the Senate next week
column2: and we can’t thank them enough for their support for our nation’s 20 million veterans.

column1: And Sarah
column2: I want to thank you for the announcement. I want to thank you for President Trump’s generosity. The President’s gift underscores his promise to do all that he can for veterans
column3: which includes supporting those who care for our veterans — not just those of us at VA
column7: and the community caregivers who are out there day in and day out making life easier for those who have borne the battle.

column1: President Trump understands the critical role of caregivers in meeting the essential needs of America’s veterans.
So we have already earmarked this gift for caregiver support in the form of mental health and peer support programs
column2: financial aid
column3: education training

column1: I am deeply grateful to President Trump for providing me the opportunity to serve America’s veterans and for his generosity in supporting them.
So thank you
column2: Sarah
column3: and thank you to President Trump. I know how much this means to American’s veterans. Thank you.

column1: SANDERS: Thank you so much. Thank you. Thank you very much.
Lastly
column2: this week is set aside each year to honor those across our country who wear the badge. In the spirit of Police Week
column3: I want to read a quick letter from Samuel of San Antonio
column4: Texas that he sent the President:

column1: “Dear Mr. President Donald J. Trump
Last year
column2: I raised about $375 for our police. I went down to McDonald’s and bought 75 $5 gift cards so the police officers could get coffee or lunch. It would be really cool to meet you. I wish I could vote for you
column3: but I’m only 11. But my mom voted for you. I’m starting a fundraiser called
column4: “A Break for the Blue.” I listen to your talks
column5: and I went to the inauguration and saw you. You’re awesome.

column1: Sincerely
column2: Samuel”

column1: Thankfully
column2: I had the honor of meeting Samuel earlier today. He was adopted by his family in Guatemala. He is incredibly grateful to be an American
column3: and he’s very grateful to all of the law enforcement officers around the country.

column1: The President is very proud of Samuel and believes our country needs more young people like him who give back to their communities. And he’s a really
column2: really great kid and it was great to meet him.

column1: And with that
column2: I will take your questions. John.

column1: Q Sarah
column2: we haven’t had a chance to hear of any kind of an in-depth analysis here. Where are we with the summit with Kim Jong-un? And the statements that we’ve heard over the last few days out of North Korea
column3: do you think that these throw in jeopardy the idea of a summit? Or is this just North Korea doing what it does in trying to get the best deal possible?

column1: SANDERS: Look
column2: the President is prepared and will be ready to meet
column3: and we’re continuing to move forward with the preparations at this point. And if the North Koreans want to meet
column4: we’ll be there. And at this point
column5: there is not a lot of change beyond that
column6: and certainly not in our process.

column1: Q So what North Korea is saying now about the joint military exercises after Moon Jae-in said Kim knows that these take place and he understands that they have to take place. I mean
column2: what game is North Korea playing?

column1: SANDERS: You’d have to ask North Korea what game they’re playing. I can tell you what we’re doing
column2: and we’re continuing to move forward in preparations. And the President
column3: as we’ve said all along
column4: will be prepared and ready to meet. And there’s really not a lot to add beyond that point.

column1: Jon.
Q Thanks a lot
column2: Sarah. What leverage does the U.S. have as it relates to having this meeting take place on June the 12th? And to that meeting actually taking place
column3: when it takes place — if it takes place — what leverage does the U.S. have over accomplishing the American goal of denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula?

column1: SANDERS: We’re continuing in the maximum pressure campaign. But again
column2: nothing has changed on our end. This was an invitation that North Korea offered and that we’ve accepted
column3: and we’re continuing to move forward in those preparations.

column1: Q But on another issue on —
SANDERS: Sorry
column2: I’m going to keep going because we’re really tight on time today.

column1: Steve
column2: go ahead.

column1: Q If I could just follow up on that. What the North Koreans also announced was they were stopping the dialogue with South Korea. So is it possible that there could be a meeting between the United States and North Korea if that whole dialogue between the North and South is on ice?
SANDERS: The meeting that would take place on June 12th is between the United States and North Korea
column2: should it take place. We’re going to meet with President Moon next week. And beyond that
column3: again
column4: there are no changes at this point to our schedule or anything else.

column1: Blake.
Q Sarah
column2: does President Trump believe that the FBI had a spy at one point inside his campaign?

column1: SANDERS: I haven’t spoken with him directly about that
column2: but certainly seen the reports. And if there is any truth to that
column3: it should certainly be looked into.

column1: Q And what is —
SANDERS: Sorry
column2: I’m going to keep going just because we’re tight.

column1: Emerald
column2: go ahead.

column1: Q Thank you. Following up on Blake’s question — if it is proven without a shadow of a doubt that there was a spy planted in the Trump campaign
column2: does that change the President’s position on firing Robert Mueller?

column1: SANDERS: I’m not going to speak about hypotheticals or get into what could happen if. We’ll move forward in the process and make a determination at that point.
John.
Q Thank you
column2: Sarah. The Iraqi elections are over and it’s very clear that the two big winners — the two top vote-getters — were the party that was linked to Muqtada al-Sadr
column3: a sworn enemy of the United States and someone aligned with the Iraqi Communist Party. And the second-place finisher was the party aligned with Mr. al-Amiri
column4: a warlord who was once backed by Iran. What’s the U.S.’s attitude on a government in Baghdad having either of those individuals as the key player?

column1: SANDERS: I’ll start with the fact I’m glad you said the names and not me — (laughter) — because I probably wouldn’t have gotten them right. But in terms of our policy
column2: we don’t have any new policy announcements with a potential change there.

column1: Q So you don’t care if either of them is —
SANDERS: Certainly we care
column2: but I don’t have any specific changes in U.S. policy while that’s happened.

column1: Jeff.
Q Sarah
column2: what does the United States expect out of negotiations today with China on trade? And what are the President’s intentions on helping or changing the policy towards Chinese company ZTE?

column1: SANDERS: In terms of the meeting
column2: I’ll start there. Those conversations are ongoing. When we have something from that
column3: I’ll be happy to share it with you. But right now
column4: those are just discussions and there’s nothing to add to that at this point
column5: since they’re just now taking place.

column1: I can say that we expect that the President will meet with the head of the Chinese delegation later this afternoon.
Q And ZTE?
SANDERS: On ZTE — look
column2: the United States and China relationship has a lot of issues that we have regular
column3: ongoing conversations about: national security
column5: and ZTE is one of them. As we’ve said before
column6: and as the President has stated
column7: he’s asked Secretary Ross to look into the issue and do whatever is consistent with the law and regulations. But right now it’s just something that he’s asked them to look into.

column1: Julie.
Q Thanks
column2: Sarah. Also on trade
column3: the President said yesterday that Mexico does nothing for us
column4: especially for the border. We know there are talks today on NAFTA — today and tomorrow. And I wonder if the administration is going to condition any NAFTA deal on a safe third-country agreement with Mexico
column5: or Mexico stepping up to do more to absorb asylum-seekers and other migrants who are seeking entry to the U.S.

column1: SANDERS: I’m not going to get into the trade conversations at this point because they are ongoing and those are negotiations that we’re in the middle of. But I can tell you that the President does want to see Mexico step up and do more. There’s a lot that comes through their country
column2: and he wants them to be tougher and more aggressive on that front.

column1: Jeff.
Q Thank you
column2: Sarah. This morning
column3: the President marked the one-year anniversary of the Mueller investigation
column7: and a witch hunt. But his own FBI director yesterday said it’s not a witch hunt. Does the President — why does the White House still believe it’s a witch hunt? And why did he cancel his news conference this afternoon
column8: which was originally set for three o’clock with the NATO Secretary?

column1: SANDERS: Different topics. But the President knows that there was no collusion in the campaign and he has been quite clear about this. It’s gone on for over a year. They found no evidence of collusion and still strongly believe that it’s a witch hunt. I’m not sure how we could be any more clear and certainly not sure how the President could be any more clear about his beliefs in his opinion.
In terms of a press engagement
column2: the President will have press at his event here shortly
column3: which is why we’re going to have to keep it quick and short today and likely take a few questions at that event.

column1: Jordan.
Q Thanks
column2: Sarah. On immigration
column3: there seems to be — we’re moving closer to action in the House of Representatives and I’m wondering what bill the President would accept anything short of the four pillars that he laid out earlier this month. Something like border security and DACA
column4: it seems to be a proposal that is gaining steam. Is that something that the President could support?

column1: SANDERS: The President definitely supports border security
column2: as he’s laid out multiple times and again talked about some yesterday. He would like to see the border security
column3: he would like to see the loopholes closed. Our priorities have not changed in the immigration conversation at all.

column1: Ayesha.
Q Thank you. Just going back to North Korea
column2: you have said that the President would be willing to meet with North Korea if North Korea is. So does that put North Korea in the driver’s seat here? Is it North Korea that’s going to decide whether a meeting takes place? And also
column3: the President said yesterday that the White House hadn’t heard anything from North Korea. Has that changed? Have you heard anything since these talks were called off with South Korea?

column1: SANDERS: They’re certainly not in the driver’s seat. Nothing could be further from the truth. But they’re the ones that extended the invitation; we’ve accepted it. If they want to meet
column2: we’re happy to do that. If they don’t
column3: as the President has said
column4: we’ll see what happens. But we’re going to continue the maximum pressure campaign in the meantime.

column1: I don’t know how they would be in the driver’s seat in any capacity
column2: form
column3: or fashion.

column1: Q Well
column2: is the White House setting a standard for “We won’t meet with you unless you do X
column3: Y

column1: SANDERS: Look
column2: the North Koreans have already made concessions. They’ve already — three Americans are home now that weren’t. The President has had some success in this process
column3: and certainly we’ve given up nothing. And we are going to continue moving forward
column4: and we’re moving into this with our eyes wide open. We’re not naïve in this process
column5: but the President is fully prepared to have the meeting. But if not
column6: that’s okay too. And we’ll see what happens beyond that.

column1: Shannon.
Q I know we’ve asked this a few times
column2: but —

column1: SANDERS: That’s okay. That’s kind of what we do here
column2: ask the same question over and over and over again.

column1: Q Can you say yet when Michael Cohen stopped being the President’s personal lawyer?
SANDERS: I’m not going to get into anything on that matter. You’d have to reach out to the President’s outside counsel.
Q Yeah
column2: but you still haven’t been able to answer that.

column1: SANDERS: Jill
column2: go ahead.

column1: Q Thank you
column2: Sarah. Why didn’t the President disclose the reimbursement to Michael Cohen in last year’s financial disclosure report? And just to follow up on other peoples’ questions on North Korea
column3: has any consideration been given at this point to potentially canceling those joint military exercises with South Korea?

column1: SANDERS: On the first question
column2: that was addressed in the financial disclosure and that’s something that would be determined by White House Counsel — how things would be categorized in the filings.

column1: And on the second part
column2: those are ongoing exercises that are routine and they’re aware of
column3: they’re annual. And at this point
column4: we have no intention of changing it.

column1: Steven.
Q I just want to ask you
column2: because so many people around the country have been talking about it in the last 24 hours
column3: what did the President mean when he said some immigrants are not people

column1: SANDERS: The President was very clearly referring to MS-13 gang members who enter the country illegally and whose deportations are hamstrung by our laws. This is one of the most vicious and deadly gangs that operates by the motto of rape
column2: control
column3: and kill. If the media and liberals want to defend MS-13

column1: Frankly
column2: I don’t think the term that the President used was strong enough. MS-13 has done heinous acts. It took an animal to stab a man a hundred times and decapitate him and rip his heart out. It took an animal to beat a woman — they were sex trafficking — with a bat 28 times
column3: indenting part of her body. And it took an animal to kidnap
column5: and rape a 14-year-old Houston girl. Frankly
column6: I think that the term “animal” doesn’t go far enough. And I think that the President should continue to use his platform and everything he can do under the law to stop these types of horrible

column1: I’m going to take one more question. Peter.
Q Thank you
column2: Sarah. Are the chances of a summit now less likely than they were a week ago before these statements came out from Kim Jong-un?

column1: SANDERS: I’m not going to get into a percentage game. I can tell you that we’re ready and prepared. And if they happen
column2: they happen; and if they don’t
column3: we’ll see what happens.

column1: Thanks so much
column2: guys. We’ll see you here in a few minutes with the President.

column1: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/lindsey-graham-nominate-trump/	"senator lindsey graham once said that republicans would ""get destroyed"" if they nominated donald trump as their presidential candidate."	true	['donald trump'
column2: 'lindsey graham']	2018/10/09	Dan Evon	['https://www.weeklystandard.com/john-mccormack/the-neo-trumper'
column3: 'https://mashable.com/article/lindsey-graham-tweets/'
column6: 'https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2018/09/27/watch-lindsey-graham-angry-defense-brett-kavanaugh/lWntvrd4xP02cXr5R7w25L/story.html']	https://www.weeklystandard.com/john-mccormack/the-neo-trumper	https://www.weeklystandard.com/	"Lindsey Graham is running a half-hour late when he arrives back at his Senate office at 6:00 p.m. for an interview
column7: but that’s understandable. There was rush-hour traffic on Constitution Avenue
column8: and he’s had more important places to be. Graham has just finished a meeting at the White House with a group of 15 Republican senators and President Donald Trump. They’d been discussing tariffs in the wake of Trump’s increasingly bellicose trade moves and Tennessee Republican senator Bob Corker’s announcement the day before
column10: that he’d introduce a bill to take back some of the authority Congress had given the executive branch to raise tariffs.

column1: “He asked me to call the meeting
column2: ” Graham says of Trump. “We talked yesterday and I said
column3: ‘Well
column4: let me get a group together
column5: and we’ll see what happens.’ ” Within days
column6: it’s clear that the meeting has been a success for Trump. Bob Corker is on the Senate floor berating his fellow Republicans for blocking a vote on his amendment despite the fact
column8: that “95 percent of the people on this [Republican] side of the aisle support intellectually this amendment” but are afraid “we might poke the bear”—i.e.

column1: “There’s a lot of concern that this tariff thing is going to get out of hand
column2: ” Graham tells me in his office on June 6. “We have to realize this is one of the centerpieces of the campaign; it’s not traditional Republican policy
column3: but we need to respect the fact that he won. . . . Maybe we need to change [Section] 232 [tariffs] one day
column4: but now is not the time to do that
column5: because it will undercut his negotiating position.”

column1: Graham’s role in protecting Trump’s protectionist policies isn’t entirely out of character. The senator from South Carolina
column2: a textile-manufacturing state
column3: has a mixed record on free trade: He voted against the Central American Free Trade Agreement in 2005
column5: but backed the Trans-Pacific Partnership in recent years.

column1: What is surprising is the very existence of Graham’s close relationship with Donald Trump.
Trump is “the world’s biggest jackass
column2: ” Graham said a month after Trump launched his presidential campaign
column3: in response to Trump’s trashing his friend John McCain and other American prisoners of war (“I like people who weren’t captured”). Trump responded by calling Graham an “idiot” who is “probably . . . not as bright
column5: as Rick Perry” and by reading off Graham’s cell phone number at one of his televised rallies. Graham had to get a new number.

column1: While most Republicans fell in line before the 2016 election
column2: Lindsey Graham—along with fellow senators Mike Lee
column3: Ben Sasse
column5: and Rob Portman—was a high-profile NeverTrumper on Election Day. “My party has gone batshit crazy
column6: ” Graham said in a February 2016 speech about Trump. Graham told Fox News that Trump is “a kook. I think he’s crazy. I think he’s unfit to be president.”

column1: But sometime after the election
column2: Graham became a neo-Trumper. “You know what concerns me about the American press is this endless
column3: endless attempt to label the president some kind of kook
column4: ” Graham said in November 2017. “I intend to support him in 2020 without equivocation

column1: What changed since 2016? A neoconservative
column2: in Irving Kristol’s famous formulation
column3: was a liberal who’d been mugged by reality. Neo-Trumpers like Graham
column5: are NeverTrumpers who were mugged by—what

column1: To hear Graham tell it
column2: policy is what changed his mind. “He’s on track to do big things
column3: ” Graham says of the president. “He built up the military. I campaigned on it. He got out of the Iran deal. I campaigned on it. He’s destroying ISIL. I campaigned on it. He’s restructuring the tax code and the way we do business. I campaigned on it. He’s doing much of what I campaigned on
column4: and I’m pleased.” Graham now speaks regularly with Trump and has become a close ally on matters ranging from North Korea to health care.

column1: What about the issues of temperament that in 2016 made Trump
column2: in Graham’s view
column3: unfit to be president? Is there anything specific
column5: that has convinced the senator that Trump isn’t the “kook” Graham called him back then? “One
column7: ” Graham says. “I’ve played golf with him. You know
column8: play golf with somebody for three or four hours
column9: you get to know them better. He’s funny as hell. He’s got a great sense of humor. There’s a method to the madness.”

column1: “He’s nobody’s fool
column2: ” Graham adds. “Very smart. And he asks a lot of good questions.”
Graham also suggested Trump’s character made him unfit. “Name one sports team
column3: university
column5: etc. that would accept a person like this as their standard bearer?” Graham tweeted in October 2016 after the release of the Access Hollywood video
column6: in which Trump bragged about groping women by the genitals. If that behavior disqualified Trump in 2016
column7: why doesn’t it disqualify him in 2020? “The American people listened to all that
column8: and they said: ‘I want him to be president.’ Okay. I believe the elections have consequences
column9: ” Graham says. “I’ve always been of an opinion when the election’s over
column10: you try to help the guy that won.”

column1: In his efforts to help Trump
column2: Graham hasn’t just been running interference on trade policy. He took the lead on a last-ditch attempt to partially repeal and replace Obama-care by block-granting money to the states
column3: a bill that conservative health-care expert Yuval Levin called the “most coherent” plan considered by Republicans. Graham says Trump “loves the idea
column4: ” and it’s “almost a certainty” it would pass in the (unlikely) event Republicans pick up a seat or two in the Senate and hold the House.

column1: Graham has also been the most enthusiastic congressional supporter of Trump’s North Korea diplomacy. Graham says that Trump’s credible threat of military force has brought North Korea to the negotiating table
column2: and he believes Trump agrees with him that a war with North Korea is better than letting North Korea develop an arsenal of nuclear-tipped missiles that could strike the United States. The prospect of war with a regime that already has nuclear weapons might seem crazy to many
column3: but Graham at least doesn’t downplay how apocalyptic a war would be. “If [President Trump] has to pick between millions of people dying in America and millions of people dying over there
column4: he’s going to pick millions of people dying over there if he has to
column5: ” Graham says. There’s no hint in his rhetoric that military action against North Korea would stop at giving them a “bloody nose.”

column1: Graham says that he still calls it like he sees it
column2: supporting the president when he’s right and opposing him when he’s wrong. “I’m really worried about what he’s talking about in Syria. We pull out of Syria
column3: ISIS will come back
column4: and the Kurds will get eaten alive by Turkey
column5: ” Graham says. “That’d be the biggest mistake he could make. It will undo all of his achievements when it comes to ISIS. It’d be an Obama-on-steroids decision. I told him that.”

column1: Graham has also warned Trump against firing special counsel Robert Mueller and refuses to call the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election a “witch hunt.” But he thinks it’s unlikely Mueller will uncover evidence Trump has committed any impeachable offenses: “You could fire [former FBI director James] Comey for any reason except a corrupt reason.” The May 2017 memo by deputy attorney general Rod Rosenstein
column2: critical of Comey’s handling of the investigation of Hillary Clinton’s emails
column3: “suggests there were valid reasons. Democrats wanted Comey fired. I think it’s going to be tough to prove that the president committed obstruction of justice in firing a guy that most people wanted to fire.”

column1: Back in August 2017
column2: after a neo-Nazi killed counter-protester Heather Heyer in a vehicular terrorist attack at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville
column3: Trump blamed “many sides” for the violence
column4: failing to forcefully single out the side that committed murder
column5: the side that claimed to have Trump’s support. The president made matters worse by saying some “very fine people” had participated in a torchlit white nationalist march where protesters chanted: “Jews will not replace us!” Graham issued a scathing statement:

column1: Through his statements yesterday
column2: President Trump took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency between the white supremacist neo-Nazis and KKK members who attended the Charlottesville rally and people like Ms. Heyer. I
column3: along with many others
column4: do not endorse this moral equivalency.

column1: Many Republicans do not agree with and will fight back against the idea that the Party of Lincoln has a welcome mat out for the David Dukes of the world.
Trump responded with a pair of tweets: “Publicity seeking Lindsey -Graham falsely stated that I said there is moral equivalency between the KKK
column2: neo-Nazis & white supremacists and people like Ms. Heyer. . . . Such a disgusting lie. He just can’t forget his election trouncing. The people of South Carolina will remember!”

column1: It was only a few months after Trump warned Graham “the people of South Carolina will remember!” that Graham publicly did a 180 on whether Trump is a “kook.” Graham’s criticism of the president has been more tempered since Trump’s threatening August 2017 tweets
column2: but he hasn’t gone completely in the tank for Trump.

column1: In January 2018
column2: Graham was at the Oval Office meeting where Trump said he opposed letting in more immigrants from certain “shithole” or “shithouse” countries. Georgia GOP senator David Perdue
column3: who was also in the room
column4: called the reported quotation a “total misrepresentation.” But Graham couldn’t bring himself to lie for Trump. “My memory hasn’t evolved
column5: ” Graham told reporters. “I know what was said
column6: and I know what I said.”

column1: “Following comments by the president
column2: I said my piece directly to him yesterday
column3: ” Graham said. “The president and all those attending the meeting know what I said and how I feel. I’ve always believed that America is an idea
column4: not defined by its people but by its ideals.”

column1: But there has been perhaps no greater rhetorical desecration of American ideals by President Trump than his recent gratuitous praise that Kim Jong-un
column2: the tyrant of the North Korean gulag state
column3: “loves his people” and that the North Korean people love him with “great fervor.” In Graham’s media tour following the Trump-Kim summit
column4: he left no illusions about the brutality of Kim
column5: but he didn’t call on Trump to stop sanitizing the Stalinist dictator. Trump demands an unusual level of loyalty from his supporters
column6: and there is some price to be paid for being his ally.

column1: While President Trump was initially arguing last week that he was forced to impose a policy of separating children from parents who had illegally crossed the border because a law passed by Democrats tied his hands
column2: Graham said on CNN that it simply wasn’t true: “President Trump could stop this policy with a phone call.” But Graham didn’t call on Trump to actually make that call. When Graham was asked on CNN on June 15 whether his newfound support for Trump was “two-faced
column3: ” he had a simple answer: “If you don’t like me working with President Trump to make the world a better place

column1: While Graham argues he’s been motivated by policy and principle
column2: it would be naïve not to consider the possibility that political necessity played some role in his evolving view of Trump. Texas senator Ted Cruz
column3: for example
column4: withheld his support from Trump through the Republican convention
column5: relenting coincidentally at a time when the presidential polls tightened and he faced mounting pressure from his donors to back Trump. Cruz was thus able to avoid a serious primary challenge in 2018.

column1: Graham was always certain to face a primary challenger in 2020
column2: and the fact that he hasn’t previously been defeated is somewhat surprising. Frequently derided on talk radio for his stance on immigration as Lindsey “Grahamnesty
column3: ” he won a seven-way 2014 primary in conservative South Carolina with 56 percent of the vote (his closest challenger lost by 41 points)
column4: just a year after participating as an author of the “Gang of 8” comprehensive immigration reform bill.

column1: But while voters were willing to tolerate Graham’s heresy on immigration
column2: there’s reason to think they wouldn’t be as ready to tolerate opposition to the incumbent president in 2020. On June 12
column3: South Carolina Republican congressman and staunch Trump critic Mark Sanford was defeated in a primary. In the 2013 House primary
column4: voters were willing to overlook Sanford’s extramarital affair. But harsh criticism of Trump was apparently a bridge too far. On June 5
column6: who had said she couldn’t vote for Trump after the Access Hollywood tape came out
column7: came in first in her primary (39 percent to 28 percent) but
column8: having failed to win a majority
column9: was forced to a July runoff. Even in suburban Northern Virginia
column11: a Republican who didn’t vote for Trump
column12: lost 39 percent of the vote to a primary challenger.

column1: It’s no coincidence that two of Trump’s most outspoken Republican critics in the Senate
column2: Jeff Flake of Arizona and Bob Corker of Tennessee
column3: are not seeking reelection in 2018. Mitt Romney will very likely win the Utah Senate nomination this month without having committed to backing Trump in 2020
column4: but Utah Republicans were a national outlier in their opposition to Trump. Among the dozens of current and former prominent Republican officials who didn’t vote for Trump in 2016
column5: Lindsey Graham may be the first neo-Trumper. But he likely won’t be the last.

column1: Correction: This article originally stated that Mark Sanford resigned as governor of South Carolina. Sanford finished his term as governor but did resign as chairman of the Republican Governors Association."	How Lindsey Graham Became a Neo-Trumper	2018-06-22 04:06:46.782000	['Art Credit'

column1: Why we need an LGBTQIA-inclusive safer sex guide Update: We have updated this section to clarify how we use terms referring to genitalia. You can read more about these changes here. Traditional safe sex guides are often structured in a way that presumes everyone’s gender (male/female/nonbinary/trans) is the same as the sex they were assigned at birth (male/female/intersex or differences in sexual development). Sex education resources often use videos
column2: pictures
column3: and diagrams as a way to convey important information
column4: though these images and videos have historically failed to reflect or provide information about same-sex and queer relationships. In fact
column5: the GLSEN 2015 National School Climate Survey shows that only about 5 percent of LGBTQ students saw LGBTQ representation in health class. These guides also often unnecessarily gender body parts as being “male parts” and “female parts” and refer to “sex with women” or “sex with men
column6: ” excluding those who identify as nonbinary. Many individuals don’t see body parts as having a gender — people have a gender. And as a result
column7: the notion that a penis is exclusively a male body part and a vulva is exclusively a female body part is inaccurate. By using the word “parts” to talk about genitals and using medical terms for anatomy without attaching a gender to it
column8: we become much more able to effectively discuss safe sex in a way that’s clear and inclusive. For the purposes of this guide
column9: we’ve chosen to include alternative words for readers to use for their genitals. For example
column10: some trans men choose to use the words “front hole” or “internal genital” instead of “vagina.” Alternatively
column11: some trans women may say “strapless” or “girl dick” for penis. This usage is meant for one-on-one communication with trusted persons
column12: such as your doctor or partner
column13: not for broad discussion. In this guide
column14: whenever we use the medical term “vagina
column15: ” we’ll also include “front hole” as clinically recommended by researchers in the BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth journal. The lack of representation and anti-LGBTQIA bias that LGBTQIA and nonbinary people often see in safe sex guides stigmatizes certain sexual behaviors and identities. It’s also directly related to the health disparities and higher rates of HIV and STIs reported within these communities. Discrimination in the sex ed world along with lack of access to healthcare tailored for LGBTQIA people and their needs plays a role in health disparities observed in LBGTQIA communities. For these reasons
column16: it’s imperative for safe sex guides to become more inclusive of LGBTQIA and nonbinary people and their experiences. This will help address barriers to accessing care and effective educational tools
column17: while simultaneously normalizing and acknowledging the true diversity that exists with regard to gender and sexuality.

column1: Consent Sexual consent is the act of agreeing to participate in any kind of touching or sexual activity. Sexual consent should take place in every sexual encounter and with all types of sexual activity and touching. Yes

column3: consent involves a lot more than just a simple yes or no. It’s important to remember that the absence of a no doesn’t mean yes. There are often multiple behaviors to a sexual interaction
column4: and consenting to one stage doesn’t necessarily mean someone is consenting to everything. column1: STIs An STI is an infection that’s passed from one person to another through sexual contact and activity. Although there’s often a lot of negative stigma — and sometimes shame — around contracting STIs
column2: it’s actually quite common. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column3: there are approximately 20 million new STIs contracted every year in the United States
column4: and 50 percent of these cases occur among people aged 15 to 24. Talking about STIs can be scary
column5: but it’s super important to get tested regularly and talk with your healthcare provider about STIs if you’re sexually active. Ways STIs can be transmitted Skin-to-skin contact

Medications are used to help decrease the chances of transmission and protect against the serious health issues that could surface if the STI is untreated. But the virus remains inside the body. column1: Use a new barrier or condom with each new sexual partner and sexual activity.

Be sure to put the condom on correctly. Pinching the reservoir tip of a condom before rolling it over the penis will leave space to collect semen and reduce the chances the condom will break when the semen is released. The condom should be rolled down to the base of the penis so the barrier is covering the entire body part.

Secure the base ring of the condom when removing the condom-covered penis from the other person’s body. This helps prevent bodily fluids from sliding out of the condom and having contact with your partner.
Never put more than one condom on a penis at one time. Using two condoms on the same penis at this same time increases friction and the likelihood that one or both condoms will break.
Apply lube. Lube cuts down on the amount of friction on a condom

Here’s a step-by-step guide for using some of the most common barriers: Outside condoms (commonly referred to as ‘male condoms’) An outside condom is a sexual protection barrier that can be used for penetrative and oral sex involving a penis. Outside condoms are designed to contain the bodily fluids (such as semen or ejaculate) that are released during sex. This prevents sexual partner(s) from being exposed to anyone’s fluids but their own. Outside condoms can be purchased at convenience stores

Inside condoms are designed to line the wall of the front hole/vagina or anus in order to prevent bodily fluids from coming into contact with the toy or body part penetrating it. Or both. I wish that the media and the Red Cross and all the rest of the people who are so worried about these criminals would realize that this is not a troop of errant Boy Scouts. These are killers of the worst kind. They donít need protection from us
column11: we need protection from them. If you donít get anything else out of this soapbox

column14: the war against terror and the one against the loudmouthed lawyers and left wing media who would sap the strength from the American public by making us believe that weíre losing the war or doing something wrong in fighting it. column8: 'https://www.si.com/vault/1992/03/23/126195/scholar-lawyer-catcher-spy-moe-berg-baseballs-renaissance-man-of-the-20s-and-30s-was-a-us-atomic-spy-in-world-war-ii#']	https://www.cia.gov/news-information/featured-story-archive/2007-featured-story-archive/moe-berg.html	https://www.cia.gov/	"It’s baseball season. Fans are filling stadiums from coast to coast to watch America’s pastime. They hope to see their favorite player in action
column10: and – perhaps – catch a fly ball.

column1: For well over a century
column2: summer in America has been synonymous with baseball. The greats – Babe Ruth
column3: Jackie Robinson
column5: and Joe DiMaggio (to name just a few) – have earned a place in history for their skill and for their dedication to the sport. But there is one – Morris “Moe” Berg – whose spot in American history comes not from baseball
column6: but from espionage. He was a catcher who put his multitude of talents to work for his country as an intelligence officer.

column1: The Brainiest Man in Baseball
Moe was born in New York City on March 2
column2: 1902. He began playing baseball as a child
column3: and while majoring in modern languages at Princeton University
column4: he played shortstop on the school team. After graduating from college in 1923
column5: Moe was signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers. He started his career as a first baseman and shortstop. But
column6: Moe was a man of many skills (he spoke 12 languages)
column7: and baseball was by no means his only passion.

column1: Off the field
column2: Moe studied French at the Sorbonne in Paris and then decided to attend Columbia University Law School. In 1926
column3: Moe joined the Chicago White Sox
column4: and changed positions from shortstop to catcher. When asked how he did it
column5: Moe replied that “they didn’t call me the brainiest man in baseball for nothing.”

column1: He received his law degree and was admitted to the New York State bar in 1928. He joined the law firm of Satterlee and Canfield and kept playing ball for the White Sox. Moe injured his right knee in 1930
column2: which eventually limited his playing time. In 1931
column3: Moe was traded to the Cleveland Indians
column4: and then to the Washington Senators. The move to Washington would change his life.

column1: Joining a Different Kind of Team
Being a baseball player with vast intellectual gifts
column2: Moe was frequently invited to embassy dinners and parties. He impressed many with his exceptional language ability and quick wit. He soon became very well known around town and caught the attention of the Roosevelt administration.

column1: Moe played with the Senators until 1934; that year
column2: he toured Japan with the American All-Star baseball team. While in Japan
column3: the Japanese-speaking ball player filmed Tokyo Harbor
column5: and other facilities for the US government.

column1: Moe Berg
When he returned from Tokyo
column2: Moe began playing with the Boston Red Sox. While with Boston
column3: Moe played in the inaugural Baseball Hall of Fame game in 1939. He played and coached for the Boston Red Sox until his retirement in 1942.

column1: Shortly afterward
column2: Moe toured Latin America with the Office of Inter-American Affairs
column3: an agency set up to counter Axis propaganda in Latin America. During this trip
column4: Moe used his linguistic talents to meet government officials

column2: the Office of Strategic Services (OSS) – the forerunner of the CIA – recruited Moe into its ranks. Although he got off to a rocky start in the OSS
column3: he was sent to Switzerland to collect intelligence on Germany’s efforts to build an atomic bomb. He met German physicist Werner Heisenberg
column4: who – during a lecture – let slip his belief that Germany would lose the war and that the Nazis were not close to developing the bomb.

column1: Moe provided the United States with incredibly helpful intelligence during World War II.
Life After World War II
Moe stayed with the OSS until it was dissolved in 1945. Afterward
column2: he served on the staff of NATO’s Advisory Group for Aeronautical Research and Development.

column1: Known as a man of mystery
column2: Moe planned to write a book detailing his career as an intelligence officer. He never wrote the book
column3: and many of his secrets will never be known.

column1: Before his death in 1972
column2: he said
column3: “Maybe I’m not in the Cooperstown Baseball Hall of Fame like so many of my baseball buddies
column4: but I’m happy I had the chance to play pro ball and am especially proud of my contributions to my country. Perhaps I couldn’t hit like Babe Ruth
column5: but I spoke more languages than he did.”"	A Look Back … Moe Berg: Baseball Player

column6: 'https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4155027/']	https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2018/09/trump-administration-review-human-fetal-tissue-research	https://www.sciencemag.org/	"Trump administration to review human fetal tissue research

column1: The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) in Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: which funds much of the nation’s biomedical research
column4: has launched a “comprehensive review” of human fetal tissue research
column5: to ensure that it’s complying with laws and regulations. The move comes on the heels of letters to the chiefs of HHS and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in Silver Spring
column7: from antiabortion groups and lawmakers decrying a recent FDA contract with a firm that supplies fetal tissue. Fetal tissue research is legal under a 1993 law.

column1: “HHS has initiated a comprehensive review of all research involving fetal tissue to ensure consistency with statutes and regulations governing such research
column2: ” and to ensure adequate oversight “in light of the serious regulatory
column3: moral
column5: ” the department said in a statement issued yesterday.

column1: The action was accompanied by the abrupt cancellation of a contract under which a company
column2: Advanced Bioscience Resources (ABR) of Alameda
column3: California
column4: was supplying fetal tissue to FDA to create so-called humanized mice for drug testing. HHS also said it would now audit all similar government contracts for tissue procurement.

column1: HHS spokespeople declined to elaborate on the scope of the new research review
column2: but it appears likely to encompass both projects within HHS agencies and work by outside researchers who are funded by HHS grants. The lion’s share of such research is funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH)
column3: which is part of HHS.

column2: NIH spent $103 million of its $37 billion budget on projects that used human fetal tissue; it expects to spend $95 million in 2019. In 2017
column3: the most recent year for which a breakout is available
column4: NIH funded 197 projects involving the tissue
column5: at a cost of $98 million. However
column6: NIH does not currently contract with suppliers like ABR to acquire fetal tissue for intramural research
column7: the agency said in a statement today. Human fetal tissue is used most often to study infectious diseases
column11: as Nature reported in this feature.

column1: Such research has long been controversial. In 2016
column2: Republican members of the House of Representatives
column3: led by Representative Marsha Blackburn (TN)
column4: produced a report that urged the federal government to transition to obtaining fetal tissue from miscarriages and stillbirths. But opponents of fetal tissue research have failed repeatedly to pass legislation that would end funding for research using tissue from electively aborted fetuses—most recently earlier this month
column5: when language prohibiting such funding was stripped from a 2019 HHS spending bill.

column1: The battle now appears to be shifting to the executive branch. Yesterday
column2: HHS said it was canceling a $15
column3: 900 contract to ABR to supply tissue to FDA because “it was not sufficiently assured” that the tissue will be obtained in a way that comports with the law that governs fetal tissue research. That 1993 law specifies that firms may not profit from transferring fetal tissue
column4: but can collect “reasonable payments” such as for processing
column6: and transportation. FDA was implanting the tissue into mice to create humanized mice that have immune systems that behave like a human’s
column7: and can be used to test drugs for safety and effectiveness.

column1: FDA also wrote to the company that it’s not convinced that the contract
column2: which was awarded this past July
column3: should have been finalized without a competition. A few months ago
column4: FDA had determined that ABR was the only firm in the country that could provide the tissue.

column1: As recently as this past August
column2: FDA had defended the ABR contract and its use of human fetal tissue
column3: writing to a reporter with CNSnews.com that the agency “has in place systems to ensure” that any research by the agency
column6: complies with federal and state laws and regulations. FDA
column8: “is committed to ensuring that its [fetal tissue] research … meets the highest ethical standards.”

column1: On 11 September
column2: 45 antiabortion groups wrote to HHS Secretary Alex Azar that they were “shocked and dismayed” by the FDA contract. On 17 September
column3: 85 members of Congress wrote a similar letter to FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb asking him to cancel the contract.

column1: Reacting to HHS’s actions yesterday
column2: Alta Charo
column3: a professor of law and bioethics at the University of Wisconsin in Madison
column4: said: “My instinct is that this is driven by politics
column5: and is part of the overall effort to stigmatize and eventually criminalize abortion
column6: as well as part of a larger campaign to roll back the clock on sexual and reproductive rights.”

column1: Lawrence Goldstein
column2: a neuroscientist at the University of California
column3: San Diego
column4: worried about the effect of HHS’s action on firms like ABR. “It could have a chilling effect on valuable research because companies who provide tissue may be scared out of use and provision

column1: Ross McKinney
column2: chief scientific officer at the Association of American Medical Colleges in Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: called fetal tissue “an important resource for biomedical research.” He added: “Fetal tissue research is already subject to a robust ethical and legal framework and research that continues to meet those standards should be continued.”

column1: Abortion opponents
column2: on the other hand
column3: argued that HHS has not gone far enough. Marjorie Dannenfelser
column4: president of the Susan B. Anthony List in Washington
column6: which spearheaded the letter to Azar
column7: called his action “completely inadequate. … Secretary Azar must put an immediate moratorium on funding for research using aborted baby organs and tissue purchased from the abortion industry
column8: ” she said in this statement."	Trump administration to review human fetal tissue research	2018-09-25 17:50:00-04:00	['Meredith Wadman']	['hhs'

column7: 'http://archive.fo/hRFdC']	https://www.apnews.com/68d4e49316e143788f190ee21720997e	https://www.apnews.com/	"U.S. Rep. John Joyce said that his trip to the U.S.-Mexico border in Arizona was a fact-finding mission that turned into an eye-opening experience.

column1: Joyce

column1: “My takeaway is after having seen firsthand what is going on
column2: after sitting down and talking to border agents
column3: the message is we need to build the wall
column4: ” he said on a conference call with reporters Thursday morning. “The wall frees up our agents to do their job.”

column1: Joyce said the trip allowed him to see firsthand the crisis at the border and what is needed from Congress to allow border patrol agents to do their job better. He said he also wanted to see the damage Democrats have caused by claiming for months that there is no crisis at the border.

“Speaker (Nancy) Pelosi said it was manufactured and I had to laugh

column1: During his trip he visited an Arizona-based company that could build a mile of wall a day to secure the border. He also visited an area where it is believed people enter the country illegally through shallow portions of the Colorado River.
He also had dinner with border patrol agents. He said they related that they are often stretched thin.
He also did a ride-along.
He said the agents often work double shifts
column2: occasionally using outdated technology.

column1: He said he witnessed a group of 32 adults illegally crossing the border
column2: each of them with a child. The Drug Enforcement Administration also confiscated a large amount of heroin and fentanyl that was being brought into the country.

column1: “They made an interesting point that they have seen more of the manufactured drugs

column3: ” he said.

column1: He said that smugglers will sometimes use the distraction caused by a large group of migrants with children to cross the border into the United States.
“I was surprised (by) the number of undocumented aliens who sit down and give themselves up. They wanted to be brought into the system (and) then it became clear to me why
column2: ” he said. “The case was they were housed

column1: When he returns to Washington

He said that often people use children to cross the border.
